headline: Robert Rheault, Green Beret Ensnared in Vietnam Murder Case, Dies at 87
text: When the Army charged the Green Beret commander, Col. Robert Rheault, and six of his officers with murder and conspiracy on July 21, 1969, in the secret execution of a Vietnamese spy suspect, it caused consternation on both sides of the growing American divide over the war in Vietnam.

headline: Red Bulls’ Cahill a Soccer Globetrotter
text: If things go according to plan, the peripatetic Tim Cahill will have only a few more soccer sojourns on his itinerary this year.

headline: How Trains Saved the Union
text: On Sept. 20, 1863, Union Gen. William S. Rosecrans was defeated at the crucial battle of Chickamauga that left 16,000 men killed, wounded and captured, after which he retreated into Chattanooga, situated on the south bank of the Tennessee River. Confederate Gen. Braxton Bragg pursued him, taking possession of the heights of Missionary Ridge and Lookout Mountain, east and south of town. Rosecrans was trapped – the only main road out of town, along the river toward a railhead that linked Chattanooga with Nashville, was in range of Confederate artillery in the mountains. Rosecrans’s only good supply route was lost.

headline: After Long Careers, Hill and Kidd Are on Different Paths This Season
text: Grant Hill celebrated his 41st birthday last month, and on that day he was on the Duke campus, appearing at an event to mark the 50th anniversary of black students attending the university.

headline: Nets Prevail, Showing Heat That Rivalry Has Two Sides
text: It is too early, perhaps, to assess how the Nets will fare against the Miami Heat as this N.B.A. season progresses. But within a so-called rivalry that has been so one-sided, so punishing, in recent years, it is probably never too early to start the emotional buildup.

headline: One-Month Checkup
text: Success signing up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act has been elusive for some and a dream come true for others. It often depends on geography.

headline: Health Exchange: A One-Month Checkup
text: The Affordable Care Act’s goal of providing health insurance for all Americans grew more complicated when governors of more than 30 statesopted not to create their own health care exchanges. That left the federal government responsible for enrolling a much larger portion of the population than it had expected, which is at least part of the reason for the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov.

headline: Revisiting Case Amid Doubts on Evidence
text: After 18 years in prison, Sundhe Moses was paroled. His case is part of a broad investigation into Louis Scarcella, a retired detective suspected of using questionable tactics and evidence.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) PROMISED LAND (2012) Matt Damon, above, plays a corporate predator and staunch defender of his company’s cause — fracking, the contentious drilling technique for natural gas — who arrives in a small farming town with the belief that he is offering local landowners a lifeline. Some, hearing the amounts being offered for drilling rights, are eager to sign up. But troubles arise when an old-timer (Hal Holbrook) starts asking questions about what fracking will do to the water supply, the livestock and the land itself. Then an environmental activist (John Krasinski) appears on the scene. The movie “has a point to make, and it does so in a way that is both honorable and disappointing,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, directed by Gus Van Sant and written by Mr. Damon and Mr. Krasinski. “It admirably tries to represent both sides of the fracking debate, even though its allegiance is clearly to the antifracking position. There is nothing wrong with such advocacy, except that in this case it means that the movie veers away from its strengths, ending in a welter of convenient (and dubious) plot twists and puffed-up speeches.”

headline: How the Pakistani Taliban Became a Deadly Force
text: Q. Who are the Pakistani Taliban?

headline: Education Life: The Disrupters
text: When President Obama visited campuses recently to push to make college more affordable, he called on educators to think creatively. And he gave a shout-out to new competency-based programs at public universities, private institutions and profit-making colleges alike. The programs dispense with the credit hour and classrooom time with a professor in favor of self-paced online learning and assessments that measure what people can actually do.

headline: Defending Germany
text: OK, I’ve just written a couple of posts talking about the harm German policy is doing. But this is dumb and destructive:

headline: A Closer Look at Climate Panel’s Findings on Global Warming Impacts
text: Updated, 1:02 p.m. | Justin Gillis has provided a look at the forthcoming report on climate change impacts, vulnerability and adaptation options from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, based on a leaked final draft (dated Oct. 28) that was posted on the blog of Donna Laframboise, a longtime critic of the panel. (You can also download it here.)

headline: 344,000 Minivans Recalled by Honda for Brake Problem
text: Honda is recalling 344,000 of its 2007-8 Odyssey minivans because a malfunctioning computer could cause “heavy and unexpected braking without the driver pressing on the brake pedal and without illumination of the brake lamps,” the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: In Baseball’s Time Machine, 21st Century Belongs to the Red Sox
text: If it were not bad enough that the Yankees missed the playoffs for only the second time since 1993, and if there were not enough agony with all the injuries and the losses and the Alex Rodriguez story leaving a sour taste for everyone, surely the final indignity came the night before Halloween when their archrivals became champions — again.

headline: The N.S.A.’s Evolution
text: The National Security Agency was founded in 1952, and its surveillance capabilities were limited by legislation in 1978. But with the attacks of September 2001 came a new sense of urgency.

headline: Documents Show N.S.A. Efforts to Spy on Both Enemies and Allies
text: Classified documents showing how the N.S.A. routinely spies on friends as well as foes.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic to Set Your Clock By
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — A very timely puzzle this is, because we get to set our clocks back this Sunday and enjoy either an extra hour’s sleep or additional mayhem, depending on your lifestyle.

headline: Pace’s Influence Grows as His Playing Time on Jets’ Defense Declines
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The wall outside the Jets’ locker room at their headquarters here is lined with the team’s historical numerical roster, and that was where Calvin Pace was pointing, discussing his football mortality, on a recent afternoon.

headline: No Morsel Too Minuscule for All-Consuming N.S.A.
text: When Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, sat down with President Obama at the White House in April to discuss Syrian chemical weapons, Israeli-Palestinian peace talks and climate change, it was a cordial, routine exchange.

headline: With Saints, Affable Ryan Is Locked in a Big Easy Bear Hug
text: NEW ORLEANS — On a recent night at Ms. Mae’s, a smoky, always-open bar in the Uptown section here at the corner of Magazine and Napoleon Streets, a woman with rollers in her hair feverishly danced alone to Robin Thicke’s “Blurred Lines” under a flag that read, “You’re in Saints country.” In the back of the bar, the air hockey, Foosball and pool tables went unattended, and the video poker machines, sandwiched by an ATM on one side and a Ms. Pac-Man game on the other, managed to lure only one patron.

headline: How Anna Chakvetadze, Rising Star at 20, Became a Retiree at 26
text: As Russia faces Italy in the Fed Cup final without its top 11 players, Anna Chakvetadze will be watching and reminiscing. She represented her country eight times at the Fed Cup and helped Russia defeat Italy in the final six years ago.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Gather to Select Successor to Leader Killed in U.S. Drone Strike
text: LONDON — Pakistani Taliban commanders met Saturday to choose a successor to Hakimullah Mehsud, their leader who was killed Friday in an American drone strike, as mainstream political leaders stepped up their criticism of the United States and vowed to press ahead with peace talks.

headline: At Los Angeles International Airport, Two Lives Collide in a Fatal Instant
text: LOS ANGELES — One was a troubled 23-year-old, with an assault rifle and an apparent grudge against the government, who witnesses said seemed to be hunting for airport security officials. The other was a 39-year-old father of two who for three years had been a screener of the torrent of passengers who move through the security lines at Los Angeles International Airport.

headline: Women’s Flexibility Is a Liability (in Yoga)
text: FROM my own practice and research, I know that yoga is generally a good thing. The bending, stretching and deep breathing can renew, calm, heal, strengthen, lift moods, lower the risk of heart disease, increase flexibility and balance, counter aging and improve sex. In short, the benefits are many and commonplace while the serious dangers tend to be few and comparatively rare.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 3
text: “I’m not going anywhere. There’s plenty of work left to do.”

headline: Robots or Aliens as Parents? Colleges Gauge Applicants’ Creativity
text: As legions of high school seniors polish their college applications, plowing through predictable essay topics about their lives and goals, they might also run across something like this: “Tell us your favorite joke and try to explain the joke without ruining it.”

headline: Seeking Laughs in a New Place
text: The journalist Sami Shah satirized Pakistani politics. Then, facing security threats, he and his family moved to Australia, where he now uses stand-up comedy to help adapt to his new life.

headline: Honeywell’s David Cote, on Decisiveness as a 2-Edged Sword
text: This interview with  David Cote, chairman and chief executive of Honeywell, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Hopefuls in New York and New Jersey Pack Their Final Weekend
text: On a bright autumn day, the candidates for governor of New Jersey and mayor of New York City embraced the final days of their campaigns with rallies, bus tours and visits to diners, butcher shops — and the site of a planned garbage transfer station.

headline: Business Best Sellers
text: 1. Lean In by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell (Knopf). The chief operating officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.

headline: When Backstage Was No Big Deal
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE Lou I knew liked speed and cheap Scotch. Had short hair and wore weird shoes. Just as he could write something as harrowing as “Rock Minuet” or as tender as “Perfect Day,” he could also be frightening, the surliest of misanthropes, or the most gentle person imaginable.

headline: At Sears, Those Big Losses Get in the Way
text: “I’d like to go faster. I’d like to go bigger. We’re just not making money, which makes it much, much harder to fund the transformation.”

headline: Red Bulls Prepare for a Seasoned Rival
text: HANOVER, N.J. — On their last trip to Texas, only two weeks ago, the Red Bulls’ game against the Houston Dynamo was over moments after it started.

headline: In New York Casino Vote, a Dance With Temptation
text: In the 48 states that permit at least some form of commercial gambling, lively debate continues over the industry’s relentless efforts to expand. On Tuesday, New Yorkers will vote on a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit up to seven new full-scale gambling casinos in the state. (The state’s five existing casinos are confined to Indian reservations.)

headline: Oden Has a Fragile Body but a Strengthened Spirit
text: MIAMI — Never a man of many words, Greg Oden still has a few quick moves. On the eve of another season he was not physically ready for, he posted up his slender 7-foot frame for an interview in a corner of the Heat’s practice gym, took a few questions and spun his way through the door leading into the locker room.

headline: Keep the Gates of Paradise Open
text: I RECENTLY made what can best be described as a personal pilgrimage to Florence, Italy, where I wanted to gaze once again on Lorenzo Ghiberti’s recently restored golden Baptistery doors, known as the Gates of Paradise, and remember how they changed my life.

headline: Japanese Civil Servant Runs Marathon for Fun, Not Profit
text: Over the years, Japan has produced some of the world’s best marathon runners, yet few of them have made their mark in New York, largely because many of them run for corporate teams that have restrictive schedules.

headline: Virginia Governor’s Race
text: I.O.U.’s Give the Democrat a Significant Edge

headline: The Dangers of a Stock Market Melt-Up
text: Investors aren’t worrying much about the stock market, and that worries Edward Yardeni.

headline: Earning Less, but at Home
A Goalkeeper’s Revenge: Stoke City’s Begovic Scores Goal
text: It is one thing to score a goal only 14 seconds into a game. But it is quite another when that goal scorer turns out to be a goalkeeper.

headline: I Want to Be Friends With Republicans
text: The trouble started the night Jeff, one of the guys I drink and talk about God with, announced that he’d been summoned to court for the Zimmerman trial jury pool. We’d kept politics out of our Wednesday night meetings, which are held on my back porch, the six of us seated at an old dining room table propped next to my broken hot tub (Florida short-sale homes come standard with broken hot tubs). Instead of Bible Study, we call it our Tavern Ministry, and while we were often drunk halfway through, a churchlike decorum had always held sway. Once the case came up, though, decorum collapsed.

headline: In Praise of Art Forgeries
text: IN Queens, a guy working in his garage churned out “Pollocks” and “Rothkos” that fooled the experts, sold for millions of dollars and helped destroy the Knoedler & Company gallery, as we learned in recent months. In China, thousands of artisans have forged the country’s artistic treasures, both ancient and modern, according to a report in The New York Times.

headline: Calling America: Hello? Hello? Hello? Hello?
text: SINGAPORE — HAVING lived and worked abroad for many years, I’m sensitive to the changing ways that foreigners look at America. Over the years, I’ve seen an America that was respected, hated, feared and loved. But traveling around China and Singapore last week, I was confronted repeatedly with an attitude toward America that I’ve never heard before: “What’s up with you guys?”

headline: A Bad Day to Die
text: You probably know the scene in Stanley Kubrick’s “Dr. Strangelove”: Slim Pickens, playing the pilot of the B-52 that has been ordered to attack Russia by his bonkers commander, General Ripper, is reviewing the contents of the crew’s survival kit. It contains among other essential items $100 in gold, nylon stockings and “one issue of prophylactics.” At the end of the list he remarks, “Shoot, a fella could have a pretty good weekend in Vegas with all that stuff.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Obama’s Use of His Power
text: Readers discuss the president’s style and accomplishments.

headline: Pot and Jackpots
text: BASED on what stirs passions and wins headlines, it would be easy to imagine that the only cultural debates that matter in America are the ones that have to do with sex.

headline: The Tumbling Boundaries of Gay Rights
text: ELLIOTT MANAGEMENT’S lofty offices in Midtown Manhattan look north, south, east and west across the borough’s thicket of skyscrapers. But the most intriguing view I got during a visit there last week was of something else: the changed gay-rights landscape and its implications for the Republican Party.

headline: This Is Why We Need Obamacare
text: THE biggest health care crisis in America right now is not the inexcusably messy rollout of Obamacare.

headline: Mark Rampolla
text: As a Peace Corps volunteer in Latin America, Mark Rampolla developed a taste for coconut water and turned it into a food trend by founding Zico, a leading brand of coconut water.

headline: From Love Nests to Desire Surveillance
text: I ASKED Mike Nichols, the director of Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal” on Broadway, why love triangles have such a mythic hold on the imagination.

headline: Poverty in America Is Mainstream
text: Few topics in American society have more myths and stereotypes surrounding them than poverty, misconceptions that distort both our politics and our domestic policy making.

headline: In the N.B.A., ZIP Code Matters
text: AS the N.B.A. season gets under way, there is no doubt that the league’s best player is 6-foot-8 LeBron James, of the Miami Heat. Mr. James was born poor to a 16-year-old single mother in Akron, Ohio. The conventional wisdom is that his background is typical for an N.B.A. player. A majority of Americans, Google consumer survey data show, think that the N.B.A. is composed mostly of men like Mr. James. But it isn’t.

headline: ‘The Frackers’ and the Birth of an Energy Boom
text: One could argue that, except for the Internet, the most important technological advance of the last two decades has been hydraulic fracturing, widely known as fracking. Practically overnight, it seems, this drilling technique has produced so much oil and gas beneath American soil that we are at the brink of something once thought unattainable: true energy independence. And its repercussions, for geopolitics, the environment and other areas, are only now being grasped.

headline: That Dreadful Day in December
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — “Every day in this first year is a very difficult journey,” said Mark Barden, whose 7-year-old son Daniel was one of the 20 schoolchildren slain last December here in the Sandy Hook shooting massacre. “And with the anniversary of the tragedy coming up, it seems to be getting more difficult.”

headline: Insurance Policies Not Worth Keeping
text: Congressional Republicans have stoked consumer fears and confusion with charges that the health care reform law is causing insurers to cancel existing policies and will force many people to pay substantially higher premiums next year for coverage they don’t want. That, they say, violates President Obama’s pledge that if you like the insurance you have, you can keep it.

headline: The Aloha Spirit, for Everyone
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — Hawaii is on the brink of becoming the 15th state to allow same-sex couples to marry. The victory, once it comes, will have a special resonance. This is the state whose Supreme Court in 1993 first opened the door to marriage equality by declaring marriage a basic civil right, setting off a reactionary scramble that led to the federal Defense of Marriage Act, a legal bulwark against gay couples that the United States Supreme Court has partly demolished.

headline: A Victory Against Dark Money
text: A group of wealthy donors wanted to give millions to two right-wing California political campaigns last year, but didn’t want anyone to know their identities. They came up with a scheme that any money-launderer would be proud of, funneling the cash through a convoluted series of independent spending groups that were allowed to collect unlimited dollars. By the time the donations had been used to buy advertising, the original money trail had been erased.

headline: States Take on Privacy
text: Tired of waiting for Congress to pass comprehensive privacy legislation, state lawmakers are taking matters into their own hands, and not a moment too soon. Legislatures across the country have enacted laws to regulate the kinds of information that companies and law enforcement agencies can collect about individuals and how it can be done.

headline: A Teenager’s Course, Altered by Motherhood
text: In the third trimester of her pregnancy, Daniel Harris, then 16, struggled to comfortably sleep through the night. So she was awake just after 4 a.m., when the sound of screaming became audible. She thought a next-door neighbor was responsible for the commotion, until her frightened younger sister went to her bedroom and a sick realization hit.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: So You Want to Play Pro Basketball
text: A look at the traits of basketball players.

headline: Week 9: Saints (6-1) at Jets (4-4)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Eloquent Empty Spaces
text: A photographer captures glimpses of cityscapes in their rare moments of emptiness.

headline: Eloquent Empty Spaces
text: WHEN I began photographing cities at twilight, I was attracted to outlying regions, places that seemed unloved and overlooked. More recently, I have been lured back to the central areas of cities, where economic turmoil has produced its own gaps in the urban facade.

headline: The Human Face of Our Health Care Mess
text: Republicans have been focusing on the messiness of the Obamacare rollout, and that’s perfectly legitimate. It has been very messy. Some liberals think they shouldn’t acknowledge the problems, because that just gives the critics more talking points. I disagree: The rollout has been a disaster, and President Obama was misleading when he said everyone could keep their existing insurance. Let’s not disguise the truth.

headline: In Touch With Nature, and With Rock ’n’ Roll
text: WOODEN WONDERS My business partner, Joel Babbit, picked out the furniture, including the desk in my office. I was really pleased with his choice. Wood gives us so much, including beautiful furniture. And let’s not forget that wood is a renewable resource. The instrument that has given me so much joy and a great career, the piano, is also made of wood, as are so many other musical instruments.

headline: Boy, 9, Is Killed by S.U.V. in Brooklyn
text: A 9-year-old boy was killed and three other people were hurt when a sport utility vehicle jumped the curb at an intersection in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Filly Sustains Fatal Injury at Breeders’ Cup
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — The second day of the Breeders’ Cup off to a tragic start when Secret Compass fell during the Juvenile Fillies race, dismounting her rider, John Velazquez. The filly sustained a lateral condylar fracture with dislocation and was euthanized.

headline: Sin and Unsinn
text: Continuing on my German theme: Matt O’Brien catches something that I’d missed — and it’s really, really bad. I’ve mentioned before that the European Commission’s estimates of the structural rate of unemployment in troubled economies are disastrously misleading. Its model (pdf) just isn’t designed to cope with sustained slumps that put some countries into near- or actual deflation, where the downward stickiness of nominal wages becomes a crucial issue. What the model does in such cases is interpret the failure of these countries to experience accelerating deflation as a rise in the structural rate of unemployment.

headline: If a Young Child Wanders, Technology Can Follow
text: Most parents have experienced that feeling of fear when a young child wanders off at the playground or disappears during a trip to the supermarket. New technology, in the form of voice watches and miniature sensing devices, is aimed at thwarting such distress by keeping track of children who are too young to carry a smartphone.

headline: Fantasy Football: 2013 Matchup Analysis, Wide Receiver
text: This chart looks ahead to the rest of the season and indicates what kind of fantasy matchup a player will have.

headline: Riding the Hashtag in Social Media Marketing
text: About once a week, Gary Vaynerchuk posts a Twitter message that reads, “Is there anything I can do for you?” He means it literally. He is inviting his roughly one million followers to send requests for any kind of help or favor. And if you respond, he will try to punch you in the face.

headline: Social Media Animal for Hire
text: A day in the life of Gary Vaynerchuk, an entrepreneur whose energy seems endless.

headline: Oarfish Offer Chance to Study an Elusive Animal Long Thought a Monster
text: It was a big day for marine biologists: On Oct. 13, the body of an 18-foot oarfish was dragged from the water onto Santa Catalina Island off the California coast, presenting a rare opportunity for local scientists to study one of the world’s most elusive and awe-inspiring big fish.

headline: Two French Journalists Are Kidnapped and Killed by Gunmen in Mali
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Two French journalists were kidnapped and killed in northern Mali on Saturday, the French Foreign Ministry said, underscoring the continuing instability of a region retaken from fighters linked to Al Qaeda only eight months ago.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 3
text: Technical problems that continue to complicate President Obama’s signature health care law and reports of high-level espionage on both enemies and allies have made for a tumultuous week in the White House. Also, some Republicans are threatening to block the administration’s nominees for federal posts until the survivors of the 2012 attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, appear before Congress. Supporters on both sides of each issue will hash it out on the Sunday news shows.

headline: France 1930, Germany 2013
text: Did France cause the Great Depression? It sounds a bit like a joke (Billy Crystal in Moscow, 1989: “I was raised thinking you were the enemy; you were raised thinking I was the enemy. We were both wrong: it’s the French”) But it’s the actual title of a very good paper by Doug Irwin, who points out that France, with its undervalued currency, soaked up a huge proportion of the world’s gold reserves in 1930-31, and suggests that France was responsible for about half the global deflation that took place over that period.

headline: Stolen Produce
text: Greetings all! I’m filling in for Deb for the day, which is just long enough to rave about this Sunday puzzle from Andy Kravis and Victor Barocas. Fair warning first: there are spoilers below.

headline: Little-Noticed Czech Team Snares a European Title
text: A Czech team with few top-ranked players on its roster was the surprise winner of the European Club Cup open division title last week in Rhodes, Greece.

headline: In Detroit, Mayor’s Race Is One Piece of a Puzzle
text: DETROIT — If people along the streets of this city seem less than consumed by the prospect of choosing a new mayor on Tuesday, perhaps it is the barrage of distractions: the governor who has been testifying in a courthouse here about Detroit’s descent into bankruptcy; the appointed emergency manager who has brought in his own team to run City Hall; the long list of questions about the fate of this city’s artwork, its streetlights, its tens of thousands of empty buildings.

headline: I.O.U.’s Give the Democrat an Edge in Virginia
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Their cheeks brushed as they whispered into each other’s ears, Bill Clinton and Terry McAuliffe, together again.

headline: As Bush Settles Into Dallas, Golf Tees and Family Time Now Trump Politics
text: DALLAS — When the executive director of former President George W. Bush’s public policy institute decided to move on recently, he stopped by for an exit interview. Mr. Bush asked if he had anything in particular he wanted to talk about.

headline: Japanese Pitcher’s Winning Streak Ends at 30
text: Masahiro Tanaka finally lost. In what may have been his last start in Japan, the ace of the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles, who had not lost in more than a calendar year, dropped a game with his team on the verge of a championship.

headline: G.O.P. Pursues Hispanic Votes With Abortion Stance
text: Following this summer’s divisive abortion debate in the State Legislature, Texas Republicans see an opening for the 2014 election as they work to reach out to Hispanic voters who could be spurred to the polls by the party’s anti-abortion stance.

headline: Twerking? Oh, Please. That Was Back in ’10.
text: Three years ago, on a small side stage of Austin’s Fun Fun Fun Fest, the rapper Big Freedia introduced Austin to New Orleans “bounce music,” the hip-hop subgenre that prominently features what — thanks to Miley Cyrus’s performance at this year’s Video Music Awards ceremony — has since become known far and wide as twerking.

headline: Names Invoked on the Stump May Shift Votes
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: With or Without $2 Billion, Water Woes Unlikely to Go Away
text: Ahead of Tuesday’s election, hundreds of thousands of Texans have already cast ballots on Proposition 6, which would amend the State Constitution so that $2 billion could be taken from the state’s savings account to help finance water infrastructure projects.

headline: Allan Block, Whose Sandal Shop Was Folk Music Hub, Dies at 90
text: Allan Block, a leather craftsman and fiddler who made sandals and music in his Greenwich Village shop — which became a bubbling hub of folk music during the 1950s and ’60s; a showcase for talented pickers and singers like Ramblin’ Jack Elliott, Doc Watson and Maria Muldaur; and a destination for aspiring musicians like John Sebastian and Bob Dylan — died on Oct. 23 at his home in Francestown, N.H. He was 90.

headline: College Football Around the Country
text: ANTHONY LACOSTE The Air Force back, right, ran for 263 yards, the second most in program history, and scored three touchdowns for the host Falcons, who ended a seven-game skid with a 42-28 win over Army, which had three scores from Angel Santiago.

headline: Bernard Goetz, Man in ’84 Subway Shooting, Faces Marijuana Charges
text: Nearly three decades after becoming notorious as the subway rider who shot four teenagers on a Manhattan train, Bernard H. Goetz found himself back in the news on Saturday, after being charged with trying to sell marijuana to an undercover police officer.

headline: Brothers Share Stage, but Rangers’ Stepan Steals It
text: Neither Jordan nor Eric Staal could recall a time when they and their brother Marc played an organized game together.

headline: A Mansion Without an Occupant
text: After 12 years as a backdrop for V.I.P. receptions and high-powered meetings, Gracie Mansion, home of New York’s mayors, is expecting a full-time resident.

headline: New York Mayor’s Mansion Seeks a Missing Item (the Mayor)
text: John Quincy Adams slept there before he was president, and Louis-Philippe of France slept there before he was king — as did, at one time or another, Charlie Chaplin and Menachem Begin; also, Fiorello H. La Guardia and eight other mayors.

headline: Filly’s Death Overshadows a Triumph at the Breeders’ Cup
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — A span of less than three hours at the Breeders’ Cup World Championships at Santa Anita Park on Saturday starkly illustrated the excruciating swings of emotion intrinsic to thoroughbred racing.

headline: Srdja Popovic, 76, Serbian Champion of Rights, Dies
text: Srdja Popovic, a Serbian lawyer and celebrated human rights advocate who pressed for reform and free speech for five decades, first under Communist rule in the former Yugoslavia and later under the strongman Slobodan Milosevic and his successors, died on Tuesday in Belgrade. He was 76.

headline: Gérard de Villiers, 83, French Spy Writer, Dies
text: Gérard de Villiers, a French popular novelist whose raffish, long-running spy-thriller series, S.A.S., sold more than 100 million copies and became a kind of drop box for real-world secrets from intelligence agencies around the world, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 83.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 2, 2013
Schumer Endorses Clinton for President in Iowa Speech
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, used a speech to Iowa Democrats on Saturday night to endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton for president, another indication of how quickly the party is coalescing behind the former secretary of state.

headline: Corrections: November 3, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Mutai and Jeptoo Storm to Victories in New York Marathon
text: It was a day for the Kenyans at the New York City Marathon on Sunday: Geoffrey Mutai and Priscah Jeptoo won the men’s and women’s races. This is their country’s third sweep of the individual titles in this race.

headline: Stick Figures and Stunted Growth as Warring Syria Goes Hungry
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rana Obaid began her life less than two years ago in a comfortable house draped with roses, the daughter of a grocer locally famous for his rich homemade yogurt. But war and siege brought hunger so quickly to their town near Damascus that when she died in September, at 19 months, her arms and legs were as thin as broomsticks.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 1, 2013
text: When Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius apologized about the rollout of the Obamacare website this week, she joined a growing number of leaders in business and government who have decided that saying sorry was the smart choice in the face of some crisis or gaffe.

headline: Hard-Luck Horse Wins Breeders’ Cup Classic by a Nostril
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — This is how championship races should be run — with fury and beauty and with the horses carrying not only jockeys on their backs, but hopes and dreams and stories. As Mucho Macho Man, Declaration of War and Will Take Charge pounded down the stretch of North America’s richest race, the people who had taken them here gritted teeth, pounded their programs and willed their horses to the finish line.

headline: Reeling From War, Afghan Society Ill-Equipped to Face Addiction
text: Afghanistan’s western border towns with Iran have become veritable zombie villages in recent years — encampments where entire families are shambling addicts.

headline: That Other Big Afghan Crisis, the Growing Army of Addicts
text: ISLAM QALA, Afghanistan — The addicts stalk the streets of this border post like hollowed-out skeletons, hair matted by filth and eyes glassy. The villages that hug the roads are veritable zombie towns, where families of men, women and children hide their addiction within barren mud compounds.

headline: Marina Gruber, Clayton Nall
text: Marina Cristine Gruber and Clayton Matthew Nall were married Saturday in Stanford, Calif. Joyce Allegro, a retired judge of the Santa Clara County Superior Court, officiated at the Faculty Club of Stanford University.

headline: Denise Signorelli and Colin Benn
text: Denise Maria Signorelli and Colin Michael Benn were married Saturday in Naples, Fla. The Rev. Angelia Winn of the nondenominational Springs of Bonita Church in Florida officiated in Eighth Avenue South Park.

headline: J. D. McClatchy and Chip Kidd
text: Joseph Donald McClatchy (left) and Charles Iacone Kidd were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, a staff member of the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Johanna Sourbeer, James Lasser
text: Johanna Nicole Sourbeer and James Lawrence Lasser are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Kaaterskill farm in Catskill, N.Y. Rabbi Harold Kudan is to officiate.

headline: Megan Piper, Joseph Incantalupo
text: Megan Katherine Piper and Joseph Charles Incantalupo were married Friday at St. Mary’s Roman Catholic Church in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Ralph Barile, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennifer Posner, Mark Cognetti
text: Jennifer Elizabeth Posner, a daughter of Holly Jane Posner and Dr. Martin Allan Posner of Larchmont, N.Y., was married Saturday to Mark Anthony Cognetti, a son of Susan Cognetti and Sal Cognetti Jr. of Clarks Green, Pa. The Rev. Leo J. O’Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest and former president of Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Church in New York.

headline: Paul Hertz, James Rauchman
text: Paul Eric Hertz and James Howard Rauchman were married Saturday in the James Room at Barnard College in New York. Dana Patton, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Rebecca Chesler and Michael Baum
text: Rebecca Faye Chesler, the daughter of Barbara G. Chesler and Evan R. Chesler of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Michael Peter Baum, the son of Barbara Baum and Steven P. Baum of White Plains. Judge Loretta A. Preska of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

headline: Kimberly Eisler, Gareth Glaser Jr.
text: Kimberly Fanya Eisler and Gareth Evan Glaser Jr. were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Janet Roberts in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Alexandra Chopivsky and Martín Corredera Silván
text: Alexandra Natalya Chopivsky and Martín Corredera Silván were married Friday in the Bishop’s Garden of the Washington National Cathedral. The Rev. Daniel P. Kane, a priest with the Catholic Dioceses of One Spirit, led a nondenominational ceremony. On Aug. 31, Archbishop Zoria Yevstratiy led a religious ceremony at St. Volodymyr’s Ukrainian Orthodox Cathedral, Kiev Patriarchate in Kiev, Ukraine.

headline: Katherine Ludlow, Ricardo Palmerola
text: Dr. Katherine Dodge Ludlow was married Saturday in Philadelphia to Dr. Ricardo Ismael Palmerola. The Rev. James F. McAndrews, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph’s Church.

headline: An Age Difference Proves Beneficial
text: Minsuh Son and Joshua Ari Savitch were married Friday by Robert P. Duckworth, the clerk of the Anne Arundel County Circuit Court, who officiated at the courthouse in Annapolis, Md.,

headline: Bevin Hill, Daniel Gilmour
text: Bevin Grace Hill and Daniel Peterson Gilmour were married Saturday in Cleveland, Ga. The Rev. Ophelia G. Laughlin, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Neverland Farms, a wedding venue.

headline: Christopher Kelly, Neritan Xhaferi
text: Christopher Michael Kelly and Neritan Xhaferi were married Saturday by Mary C. Pugh, a Connecticut justice of the peace, at St. Clements Castle and Marina in Portland, Conn.

headline: Timothy Bralczyk, Martin Torre
text: Timothy Stephen Bralczyk and Martin Borromeo Torre were married Saturday at the Alger House, an event space in New York. Leslie C. Petrick, Mr. Bralczyk’s sister, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: William Reynolds, Daryl Muller
text: William Joseph Reynolds and Daryl Andrew Muller were married Friday in Washington. Barbara Barton Greenberg, an aunt of Mr. Muller who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the District of Columbia War Memorial.

headline: Sara Tedeschi, James Psota
text: Dr. Sara Katharine Tedeschi and James Ryan Psota are to be married Sunday at Castle Hill on the Crane Estate in Ipswich, Mass. Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, a friend of the couple, has received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

headline: Dinah Denmark, Alice Greene
text: Dinah Marie Denmark and Alice Greene were married Friday in New York. Eileen Koretz, who retired as the supervising judge of New York County Criminal Court, officiated at Judge Koretz’s apartment.

headline: Caitlin McNamara, Christopher Chalke
text: Caitlin Daly McNamara and Christopher Thomas Chalke were married Saturday evening at St. Aloysius Gonzaga Church in Washington. Bishop Kevin J. Farrell, of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Dallas, performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John J. Enzler.

headline: Did He Make the Doritos? Who Cares
text: Rebecca Sagner Buurma, a daughter of Deborah Sagner of New York and Matthew W. Buurma of Summit, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Lawrence Howard Rappoport, the son of Bernice Rappoport and Kenneth Rappoport of Egg Harbor Township, N.J. Rabbi Julie Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: Jessica Sibelman, Erez Davy
text: Jessica Lynn Sibelman and Erez Joseph Davy are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Richard S. Fagan at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

headline: Joy Freeman and Drew Freilich
text: Joy Esther Freeman and Dr. Drew Alexander Freilich were married Saturday evening in Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Dan Levin officiated at the Polo Club.

headline: Jeffrey Trammell, Stuart Serkin
text: Jeffrey Bevis Trammell and Stuart David Serkin were married Tuesday in Washington. Sandra Day O’Connor, the retired associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, officiated at the court.

headline: Lucille Sawyer and Jonathan Keller
text: Lucille Kille Sawyer and Jonathan McNeil Keller were married Friday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in Manhattan. Matt Green, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Bitten by the Same Bug
text: Chloe-Valentine Roeder and Adam Carter Roberts were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Sarasota, Fla., where Rachel Roberts, a sister of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Gillian Brody, Noah Zachary
text: Gillian Sloane Brody and Noah Joshua Zachary were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, an event space in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Tracy Duñgo, John Porges Jr.
text: Tracy Palac Duñgo and John Randolph Porges Jr. were married Saturday at Belle Mer, a wedding reception hall in Newport, R.I. Carlo D. Guzman, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Alyse Shorland, Kyle Bruno
text: Alyse Renee Shorland and Kyle Christopher Bruno were married Saturday at the Trump Winery in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Truman Bishop Smith, a Baptist minister and a great-uncle of the bride, officiated.

headline: Kyong Pak, Andrew Spraggs
text: Kyong Joo Pak and Andrew Laurence Spraggs were married Saturday at Elysian, an event space in Los Angeles. Claire Doyle, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

headline: With Rivalry Rejuvenated, Florida State Routs Miami
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The Florida State crowd, a Doak Campbell Stadium record of 84,409, decided it was going to be impatient, brush off the final month of the season, ignore unbeatens Oregon and Ohio State, and just declare what was on its mind.

headline: From Samurai and Cherry Tree
text: The small town of Kakunodate is the only place in the world where cherry bark ware, or kabazaiku, is still made.

headline: Samsung Ready to Slowly Lift Veil to Investors
text: TOKYO — Secrecy has served Samsung Electronics well. Keeping its rivals guessing has helped Samsung, the South Korean technology giant, build a formidable lead in the smartphone industry, where it now sells more than one in three handsets worldwide.

headline: London’s National Theater Celebrates 50 Years on Stage
text: LONDON — London’s National Theater threw itself a 50th birthday party on Saturday, paying tribute to the storied past of what is arguably the most important address in the English-speaking stage.

headline: Egyptians Following Right Path, Kerry Says
text: CAIRO — In the highest-level American visit here since the Egyptian military removed the country’s first democratically elected president from power, Secretary of State John Kerry pressed Egyptian leaders on Sunday to stick to their “road map” for restoring democracy.

headline: Bangladesh Sentences 2 Expatriates to Death for War Crimes
text: NEW DELHI — A war crimes tribunal in Bangladesh on Sunday sentenced two expatriates — one now living in the United States and the other in Britain — to death by hanging for the murder of 18 people described as prominent intellectuals, during the country’s 1971 war of independence from Pakistan.

headline: German Surpluses: This Time Is Different
text: There’s a tendency, in discussing Germany’s position in world trade, to assume that massive surpluses have always been the German norm — that the country’s high-quality products have always fueled an export engine that inevitably sold much more abroad than Germans bought. But it’s not true. Here’s Germany’s current account balance as a percentage of GDP since 1980:

headline: Behind Autism and a Tantrum, a Break in a Child’s Routine
text: The game plan was simple. My mother Brenda and I were on a shopping trip to buy clothes for Michael, my 4-year-old autistic son, and his 5-year-old sister, B.J., at the PX in West Point, N.Y. I figured 15 minutes, tops, from front door to checkout. Anything longer was courting trouble. I never took both children out unless I had a one-to-one adult-to-child ratio. Yet my mother had limited mobility. She had recently moved in with us after a serious illness. Two months later, my son was given his diagnosis, and since then I had felt torn between taking care of the children and giving my mother the time she needed.

headline: In Our Pages: November 4
text: 1913 German Scientist Lauds America’s Aigrette LawBERLIN — ‘‘In prohibiting the importation and wearing of the plumage of live birds, the American Government has enacted an epoch-making legislative measure!’’

headline: ‘To Those Influencing Environmental Policy But Opposed to Nuclear Power’
text: Four climate scientists, three of whom have published in peer-reviewed literature on energy issues (a sampler from Wigley, Hansen and Caldeira), are pressing the case for environmental groups to embrace the need for a new generation of nuclear power plants in a letter they distributed overnight to a variety of organizations and journalists.

headline: Disruptions: Under a New Chief, Yahoo Still Seeks Its Voice
text: In Google’s early days, when employees were preparing to release a new project, they had to make a pilgrimage to see Marissa Mayer, employee No. 20, and the head of design and user interface. This was not fun.

headline: Bringing Golf to East Harlem’s Girls
text: It was on the first tee at the Mosholu Golf Course in the Bronx that Teddy Griffith introduced a group of teenage girls to golf.

headline: Driver Charged With Negligent Homicide in Death of Boy, 9
text: The red Ford Expedition mounted the sidewalk along DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Saturday afternoon not once, but twice.

headline: First Winner Named in Madonna’s ‘Art for Freedom’ Project
text: Madonna announced on Sunday the first winner in the Art for Freedom online competition that she and Vice, the multimedia company, have established to encourage visual and video artists, photographers and poets to create works that focus on social justice. Madonna has also expanded her partnerships in the project to include the social website Tumblr.

headline: Jeptoo Wins in a Sprint From Behind
text: Priscah Jeptoo of Kenya sprinted on the last leg to win the New York City Marathon women’s race on Sunday and take the World Marathon Majors series title.

headline: Mutai Bides His Time for a Repeat Victory
text: Before the New York City Marathon started Sunday, Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya was the man to watch. He set the course record of 2 hours 5 minutes 6 seconds in 2011 and owned the unofficial world record, set in Boston the same year.

headline: Clemency for Snowden? U.S. Officials Say No
text: If Edward J. Snowden believes he deserves clemency for his disclosures of classified government documents because they provoked an important public debate about the reach of American spying, he has failed to sway the White House and at least two key members of Congress.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 7 P.M. (BET) BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Black Girls Rock!, a nonprofit organization dedicated to the emotional development of young black women, joins forces with BET to pay tribute to role models in professional and public service. Tracee Ellis Ross and Regina King host this special, taped at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, honoring women in business, politics, entertainment, sports and community service, including Queen Latifah, Patti LaBelle, Venus Williams, Misty Copeland, Marian Wright Edelman and Ameena Matthews. Performers include Ledisi, foreground above, and Jennifer Hudson, Kelly Rowland, Janelle Monáe, Sevyn Streeter and Amber Riley.

headline: When the Sky Is No Limit
text: There was no way that Julie Taymor was ever going to dream a little “Dream.” The director who redefined spectacle on Broadway for better (“The Lion King”) and for worse (“Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”) has now given New York a “Midsummer Night’s Dream” that doesn’t so much reach for the heavens as roll around in them, with joyous but calculated abandon.

headline: ‘Ender’s Game’ Is No. 1, With a Caveat
text: Summit Entertainment marketed “Ender’s Game” as “the motion picture event of the year,” but moviegoers — fresh off “Gravity” and looking ahead to “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire” — apparently saw through that: “Ender’s Game” took in a so-so $28 million at North American theaters over the weekend, winning the box-office race but probably ending studio hopes of introducing a new film franchise. A Summit spokesman called the total “solid” and “in line with the studio’s preweekend expectations.”

headline: Are We Too Dependent on Apps?
text: How many times a day do you play a game on your phone, send messages through WhatsApp or Snapchat, post updates on Twitter and Facebook or upload a selfie to Instagram? A dozen? Two dozen?

headline: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’
text: Photos from Julie Taymor’s production for Theater for a New Audience.

headline: Djokovic Rallies Twice Against Ferrer to Win Paris Masters
text: PARIS — The resilient autumn of Novak Djokovic was showcased in microcosmic form Sunday as he twice rallied to defeat David Ferrer, 7-5, 7-5, in the final of the BNP Paribas Masters.

headline: 4 Wheelchair Titles in 4 Top Marathons
text: Nothing could stop Tatyana McFadden’s race toward a milestone — not the headwind, not the concern about another searing rib injury, not the threat of another crippling flat tire and certainly not the other female wheelchair competitors Sunday in the New York City Marathon. McFadden sped past them all.

headline: Rand Paul Muses About ‘Dueling’ With His Accusers
text: In the 1800s, so many Kentuckians were killing one another in duels that the Legislature saw fit to require that incoming state officeholders swear an oath that they had not fought in a duel, issued a challenge for a duel or assisted at a duel, “so help me God.”

headline: China Strips Army Official of Position After Attack
text: BEIJING — A senior military commander in China’s restive far west has been stripped of his position on a powerful Communist Party governing body after an attack in the nation’s capital last week that claimed five lives and deeply unnerved the Chinese leadership.

headline: The Changing Geography of Beggar-thy-Neighbor
text: Not about China anymore.

headline: Power Plants Try Burning Wood With Coal to Cut Carbon Emissions
text: WASHINGTON — Even as the Environmental Protection Agency considers requiring existing coal-fired power plants to cut their carbon dioxide output, some utilities have started to use a decidedly low-tech additive that accomplishes that goal: wood.

headline: Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Seem
text: Americans spend an estimated $5 billion a year on unproven herbal supplements that promise everything from fighting off colds to curbing hot flashes and boosting memory. But now there is a new reason for supplement buyers to beware: DNA tests show that many pills labeled as healing herbs are little more than powdered rice and weeds.

headline: When Socrates Met Phaedrus: Eros in Philosophy
text: Crazy Hot

headline: Senate Vote on Workplace Bias Against Gays Poses a Test for the G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — A major test of how carefully Republicans can navigate the intraparty politics of sexuality will come on Monday, when the Senate holds a crucial vote on a bill to outlaw workplace discrimination against gay men, lesbians and transgender people.

headline: The Difference Four Days Can Make
text: Television networks would prefer ratings that include those who view a recorded show up to seven days after it airs as opposed to the current standard of three days. On these shows, the extra days would result in a measure that boosted the audience by a million viewers, on average.

headline: Colorado Is Asking Taxpayers for $1 Billion to Help Schools
text: DENVER — In one poor school district in Colorado’s San Luis Valley, students take classes in a bus garage, using plastic sheeting to keep the diesel fumes at bay. In another, there is no more money to tutor young immigrants struggling to read. And just south of Denver, a district where one in four kindergartners is homeless has cut 10 staff positions and is bracing for another cull.

headline: Error-Free Jets Outrun Saints
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It has been like this for the Jets every week for the last two months, whether on the banks of the Ohio River or in a dome in Atlanta or in a Boston suburb, so on Sunday, it had to be that way again: They walked into a stadium and, for three hours, transformed it into one of the most interesting places in town.

headline: Sharing a Heritage, a Home and a Way With Words
text: The Celtic oral tradition merges with snapshots of old Manhattan — and old Dublin — in Eamon Morrissey’s engrossing one-man show “Maeve’s House,” at the Irish Arts Center. The woman of the title is Maeve Brennan, the Irish writer whose short stories and Talk of the Town items, often written under the nom de plume “the Long-Winded Lady,” filled pages at The New Yorker for about 30 years, beginning in 1949. Mr. Morrissey’s play recites passages from some of her work and recalls his family’s links with Brennan as well.

headline: Epic TV Series Aims to Celebrate China-Myanmar Ties
text: The first-ever television series jointly produced by China and Myanmar — a 40-episode epic depicting the adventures of a ninth-century Burmese prince who travels to the Tang dynasty imperial court with his famed dancing troupe — has wrapped up filming and is scheduled for broadcast next year.

headline: Elections Today
text: Tuesday is Election Day, and voters across the region will elect local and state officials and will decide the fate of proposed constitutional amendments.

headline: Short Peeks Backstage at New York City Ballet
text: What does it really take to be a dancer in New York City Ballet? In “city.ballet.,” a new web series to be released on Monday by AOL On Originals, key ingredients are strength, grit, talent and perseverance. Having a life outside ballet is not a bad idea. And when all else fails, reach for the wine. After a recent performance of “Swan Lake,” the principal dancer Teresa Reichlen confesses, she “kind of had two dinners, half a bottle of wine and” — she adds with a sheepish smile — “a margarita, and that’s it. That’s it!”

headline: Camp Classic
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — The Monday through Thursday puzzles this week appeared last Saturday at the Arlington Puzzle Festival in Arlington, Va. A report on the 2012 festival is posted here and the 2013 results should be posted soon.

headline: Recovery on the Roads
text: Since losing a leg while serving in Afghanistan, Alfredo De Los Santos has become a national champion in the handcycle marathon.

headline: A Night of Revivals With Fokine, Tharp and Morris
text: All three works shown on Friday by American Ballet Theater at the David H. Koch Theater were making welcome returns to the company’s repertory after too-long absences. All three were pure dance; they made marvelously diverse fare. The opener was Michel Fokine’s “Les Sylphides” (1909), which used to be a signature work for Ballet Theater through most of its first five decades; when Fokine staged it for this company in 1940, it was his final version of what was already a classic. This revival was followed on Friday by two ballets created for this troupe: Twyla Tharp’s “Bach Partita” (1983) and Mark Morris’s “Gong” (2001).

headline: A Veteran’s Path to Recovery by Marathon Racing
text: A light mist covered the hilly roads by Alfredo De Los Santos’s neighborhood in Hopewell Junction, N.Y., last week. The streets of his tidy development were quiet and deserted, except for Freddie, as he likes to be called, whizzing along the rain-slicked road, intensely pumping his handcycle.

headline: Solemn Panorama of Battle
text: Graphic novelists tend to be a little neurotic and obsessive, but in that fraternity, Joe Sacco has long been regarded as an exception. For one thing, Mr. Sacco, whose new book, “The Great War,” comes out on Monday, is completely well adjusted. “Of all of us, he’s far and away the most normal,” his colleague Art Spiegelman said recently. Mr. Sacco laughed when told of this and said, “I’m not sure that’s a good thing or not.”

headline: Voices Raised for Peace, With Noh and Manga
text: Looking for new frontiers in opera has become a full-time preoccupation for some observers, critics and fans alike. It’s disappointing, then, that “War Sum Up,” presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House as part of the Next Wave Festival on Friday night, had just two engagements. A stimulating multidisciplinary, pan-cultural creation mounted by the Danish arts laboratory Hotel Pro Forma, the show was just the kind of thing that could get adventuresome opera lovers thinking and talking.

headline: Tug of War Stretches Architect’s Legacy
text: When Luis Barragán, considered by many to be Mexico’s greatest architect, died in 1988, he left a scattering of gemlike private houses and public works around Mexico City and Guadalajara, his hometown. But an important part of his legacy — his professional archive and the copyright to designs and images of much of his work — ended up thousands of miles from his native land.

headline: Rebelling With Global Beats and WikiLeaks
text: Not every dance party starts — as did M.I.A.’s show on Friday night at Terminal 5 — with a live video transmission from Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, urging a sold-out crowd to fight the “military occupation of cyberspace.” Mr. Assange called M.I.A. “the most courageous woman working in Western music” and “prescient.” He cited lyrics from “The Message,” a song M.I.A. released in 2010 with the lines “iPhone connected to the Internet/Connected to the Google/Connected to the government,” and added, “It turns out she was right.”

headline: A Spider-Man Caper Full of Broadway Characters, All of Them Real
text: It’s unseemly to take pleasure in any creative failure. Artists strive and struggle all the time, and those who refuse to court the possibility of humiliation probably aren’t trying hard enough. If the sound of somebody’s well-intentioned work going splat makes you happy, perhaps you should seek worthier targets for your schadenfreude.

headline: Ex-Bassist for the Grateful Dead Strikes a Deal
text: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — Phil Lesh has logged countless miles on the road as the bassist of the Grateful Dead and, since the late 1990s, in various post-Dead ensembles. But at 73, he is looking for a change.

headline: New Details Emerge About Tainted Gallery
text: The art forger Ken Perenyi remembers Anthony Masaccio as a practiced partner in the sale of fake paintings, a man with movie-star looks and the nickname Tony Cha Cha who mingled with models and artists in the back room of Andy Warhol’s hangout Max’s Kansas City during the 1970s.

headline: Art Found in Germany Linked to Nazi Looting
text: Works by Matisse, Picasso and Chagall are said to be among a collection of 1,500 pieces of art found in Munich, according to BBC News and the German magazine Focus. The works were reportedly confiscated by the Nazis during the 1930s and ’40s and, if confirmed as genuine, would be among the largest recoveries of looted art with a possible value over $1.3 billion. The stockpile was discovered by chance in 2011, when tax investigators obtained a warrant to search the home of Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of the art dealer Hildebrand Gurlitt. There are international warrants out for at least 200 pieces in the collection, which is being stored in a secured warehouse in Munich. It is unclear why the discovery was not publicly reported until now. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum estimates that the Nazis seized about 16,000 works of art in all, according to BBC News.

headline: Distance Swimmer Has a Book Deal
text: Diana Nyad, the 64-year-old whose quest to swim from Cuba to Florida captivated the world, has struck a deal to write a memoir. Knopf, the publisher of Sheryl Sandberg, Alice Munro and Nathan Englander, acquired the memoir, calling it a book “about her life in and out of the water.” Jordan Pavlin, executive editor at Knopf, will edit the book.

headline: ABC Extends the Lives of Some New Sitcoms
text: ABC has announced the short-term fates of its remaining freshman comedies, with “The Goldbergs” and “Trophy Wife” both receiving full-season orders. “Super Fun Night,” which stars Rebel Wilson, received an additional order of only four episodes, setting the show up to be replaced at some point later in the season. Another new comedy, “Back in the Game” starring James Caan, did not receive an additional episode order, leaving its future in doubt after its initial 13-episode order is completed. The vote of confidence for “Trophy Wife” was something of a surprise, considering its ratings have been the lowest out of the four shows through the early part of the season. The other three have been on fairly equal ground in terms of viewership, but none could be qualified as hits. “The Goldbergs” has averaged 6.1 million total viewers; “Super Fun Night” 6.4 million; “Back in the Game” 6.7 million; “Trophy Wife” has averaged 4.7 million.

headline: The Tallest, Richest Additions to the Skyline
text: Three residential buildings under construction in Manhattan are so tall that they will be instant landmarks. And apartments inside are selling for record amounts.

headline: Amnesty Bill That Would Clear Ousted Premier Stirs Thai Anger
text: BANGKOK — The Thai government is facing growing anger among its own supporters as well as protests by an emboldened opposition over a far-reaching amnesty bill that could allow former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to return home by wiping clean corruption cases against him.

headline: Gift Books for Your Favorite Bridge Player
text: As we continue our look at bridge gift books published this year, we come to those for intermediate players looking to better their game.

headline: Seeking More Pay for Delayed Play
text: In 2007, faced with the growing popularity of digital video recorders, advertisers agreed to pay television networks for commercials viewed within three days of a show’s first broadcast.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Talk to Iran, It Works
text: There were high expectations after President Obama and Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, talked on the phone in late September. Those hoping for a diplomatic resolution to the nuclear standoff were excited that a breakthrough was imminent; meanwhile, some American allies, like Israel and Saudi Arabia, expressed deep skepticism over a potential American rapprochement with Iran.

headline: Start-Up to Offer Didion E-Books
text: The start-up Zola Books is trying to persuade book buyers to flock to its website, a hybrid that is designed to be a bookseller, curator and social-networking site all in one.

headline: New Leaders for Bucks County Playhouse
text: Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., has announced that Robyn Goodman will be the theater’s new executive producer and that Alexander Fraser will be the new producing director. They will assume their roles in January, after the departure of Jed Bernstein, who is set to become the next president of Lincoln Center. Ms. Goodman is the lead producer of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” on Broadway. She was also the producer of the Broadway runs of “Avenue Q” and “In the Heights.” Mr. Fraser’s recent credits include serving as an associate producer on the Chicago staging of “Kinky Boots” and the Broadway production of “The Normal Heart.”

headline: Doctor, First Tell Me What It Costs
text: DURHAM, N.C. — IF an antibiotic would cure your infection, your doctor would probably still warn you about the chance of sun sensitivity before prescribing the pill.

headline: Frank Wess, 91, Saxophonist and Flutist With the Basie Band, Dies
text: Frank Wess, who helped popularize the flute as a jazz instrument in the 1950s and ’60s with the Count Basie Orchestra, where he was also a standout saxophone soloist, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Mexico's Soda Pop Ploy
text: My first job out of college, in 1983, was working for Coca-Cola. The training, which lasted a month, was the same for everyone: all day in a truck, making deliveries, mostly to rural areas. We would leave before dawn and return as the sun was setting. We delivered soft drinks to churches and whorehouses. We went to places that didn’t appear on any map, where there were no roads beyond the tracks left by trucks like ours. We went where the government didn’t go, where there were no hospitals, no schools and sometimes even no running water.

headline: A New Publisher for Playbill
text: It seems as if Bruce Hallett will work only for magazines with instantly identifiable covers.

headline: Brands Align With the Mustachioed Month of Movember
text: IN November 2011, executives at Just for Men, the hair color brand, noticed an inexplicable surge in Canada for sales of its facial-hair line, Mustache & Beard. The brand had done no special advertising or promotion, and yet Canadian sales were up 30 percent over the month before, and up slightly in the United States as well.

headline: Sub-Elite Runners Chase Improvement
text: Greg Cass crossed the finish line in 2 hours 36 minutes 33 seconds, his lifetime earnings from distance running holding steady at $75.

headline: Reflecting on a Dream, and Preparing to Move On

headline: Ads Scant When Twitter Crosses Borders
text: BERLIN — From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter.

headline: Walt Bellamy, Hall of Famer Traded by the Knicks, Dies at 74
text: Walt Bellamy, the Hall of Fame center who was among the leading N.B.A. scorers and rebounders of his time but who was remembered as well for being traded away by the Knicks for Dave DeBusschere in a final step toward their first championship season, died on Saturday. He was 74.

headline: In Rodriguez Arbitration, Two Sides Play Hardball
text: A trainer for Alex Rodriguez was shopping in Times Square with his wife and three young children one recent Saturday when he was followed into Toys “R” Us. A man working on behalf of Major League Baseball approached and handed him some paperwork. It was a subpoena to testify against Mr. Rodriguez.

text: VOTING AGE CITIZENS 46,767

headline: An Event for the Elite and the Average Alike
text: Welcome back. The New York City Marathon had to be canceled in 2012 after the killer storm Sandy invaded the region, and Sunday’s marathon was shadowed by the memory of shrapnel murderously exploding across Boylston Street in Boston last April. But back they came, the elite whippets near the front, the more standard human body types massed in the back — two races in one.

headline: The Appearance of Impartiality
text: A New York judge is accused of improperly steering cases and commenting out of court. What restrictions should be placed on judges?

headline: Day After Throwing 160 Pitches, Tanaka Closes Japan Series Clincher
text: One day after he threw 160 pitches in a complete-game loss in Game 6 of the Japan Series on Saturday, Masahiro Tanaka went back to the mound and threw 15 more pitches to get the save in Game 7.

headline: Lonely Advocate for Restraint in Egypt Tiptoes Around Talk of Compromise
text: CAIRO — The news agency headline last week seemed harmless enough, perhaps even flattering. It paraphrased an Egyptian cabinet minister saying that his government and its opponent, the Muslim Brotherhood, should pursue “reconciliation.”

headline: Stratospheric Views, and Prices
text: Walking slowly to the windows facing the meadow of green that is Central Park, Gary Barnett slips into salesman mode as he spreads his arms wide, embracing the sweeping bird’s-eye view he has from the 87th floor of his shimmering skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Buildings for Billionaires
text: A new crop of ultra-luxurious New York high rises are vying to be the next hot “it” building and are attracting billionaires from nearby as well as abroad.

headline: Diverse Neighborhood Has Mixed Enthusiasm About New York City Mayor’s Race
text: The last presidential candidate Steve Waldman voted for was Hubert H. Humphrey. The last mayor he cast a ballot for was Edward I. Koch. And he’ll be darned if he is going to break his nonvoting streak by partaking in the mayoral election on Tuesday.

headline: Security Noticeable at First and Then a Blur
text: As the elite runners came down the final 150 yards of the New York City Marathon, and the finish line came into focus, the crowd on either side of them erupted in cheers, blowing horns, ringing bells and clapping inflatable sticks. They passed several police officers and four bomb-sniffing dogs sitting in the middle of the street and an officer wearing an N.Y.P.D. hat and wielding a video camera. Just beyond the finish line, to the side, were more officers and more dogs.

headline: Disney and Dish Wrangle Not Over Broadcast Fees, but the Future of TV
text: A sweeping distribution deal between television giants, the Walt Disney Company and Dish Network, expired more than a month ago, and there is still no new deal in sight.

headline: Obama Campaigns for Terry McAuliffe
text: Ahead of Tuesday's election, President Obama campaigned in Arlington alongside Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia.

headline: Breakneck Pace a Certainty in Duel Between Sixers and Warriors
text: Each week during the N.B.A. season, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue.

headline: In Pakistan, Drone Strike Turns a Villain Into a Victim
text: LONDON — In life, Hakimullah Mehsud, the leader of the Pakistani Taliban, was Public Enemy No. 1: a ruthless figure who devoted his career to bloodshed and mayhem, whom Pakistani pundits occasionally accused of being a pawn of Indian, or even American, intelligence.

headline: Moving Moments Send Shivers, Both Good and Bad
text: ARCADIA, Calif. — There were awe-inspiring moments aplenty, like Magician moving like a John Deere tractor as he mowed down rivals in the lane of the Breeders’ Cup Turf to give European horses their fifth victory of these world championships. Or Wise Dan, the reigning horse of the year, showing why he should retain that title with a last-to-first rush in the Turf Mile that was as breathtaking as it was powerful.

headline: Both Sides Invoke Obama in Climax of Virginia Governor’s Race
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — To motivate voters, Virginia’s bitter rivals for governor reached out to the same figure on the weekend before Election Day: President Obama.

headline: It’s the Golden Age of News
text: OVER the past 20 years, to loud laments from media veterans, American news organizations have retreated from the costly business of foreign coverage — closing bureaus, slashing space and airtime. Yet for the curious reader with a sense of direction, this is a time of unprecedented bounty.

headline: Romney Sees Christie as Potential G.O.P. Savior in ’16
text: Mitt Romney said on Sunday that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey could be the Republican nominee for president in 2016 and could “save our party,” comments that appeared to contradict reports that Mr. Romney’s presidential campaign had been concerned about Mr. Christie’s health.

headline: Those Depressing Germans
text: German officials are furious at America, and not just because of the business about Angela Merkel’s cellphone. What has them enraged now is one (long) paragraph in a U.S. Treasury report on foreign economic and currency policies. In that paragraph Treasury argues that Germany’s huge surplus on current account — a broad measure of the trade balance — is harmful, creating “a deflationary bias for the euro area, as well as for the world economy.”

headline: Under Health Care Act, Millions Eligible for Free Policies
text: Millions of people could qualify for federal subsidies that will pay the entire monthly cost of some health care plans being offered in the online marketplaces set up under President Obama’s health care law, a surprising figure that has not garnered much attention, in part because the zero-premium plans come with serious trade-offs.

headline: A Prayer in the Town Hall
text: The wall between church and state is one of the most powerful and enduring images in American law, but as a metaphor it fails to capture the complicated and porous relationship most Americans have to the expression of religion in public life.

headline: Arrest of the Avalanche’s Goalie Casts a Shadow on a Promising Season
text: DENVER — During their drive to Pepsi Center, there was much shimmering ground for two Colorado Avalanche fans to cover: the poise and production of the team’s 18-year-old rookie forward, Nathan MacKinnon; the inspired play of the defense; the mad genius of the first-year coach, Patrick Roy. And yet, as Keith Martin and his son-in-law drove to the Avalanche’s game here Saturday night against the Montreal Canadiens, they spoke mostly of the dark cloud shadowing the team’s resurgence.

headline: Congress Can Help on Iran
text: It is crucial that Congress work constructively with President Obama as he tries to lead the way in negotiating a nuclear agreement with Iran. But some lawmakers are so suspicious of Iran and so blindly committed to more sanctions that they could sabotage the best opportunity in years for a peaceful resolution of an issue that has long blocked any fundamental improvement in relations between the two countries while complicating the prospects for stability in the Middle East.

headline: Marijuana and Alcohol
text: Americans are growing more comfortable with marijuana, with 58 percent favoring legalization, according to the latest Gallup poll. At the same time, some researchers believe they have identified a side benefit to increasing availability of the drug: It could lead to decreased consumption of alcohol among young people.

headline: Add a Dollar an Hour in New Jersey
text: Ideally, Congress would raise the federal minimum wage above the paltry $7.25 an hour. But since there is little chance of that happening soon, it is up to the states to provide relief for low-wage workers. Nineteen states and the District of Columbia have so far increased the minimum wage above the federal level. Tuesday will be New Jersey’s chance to do the same.

headline: Outside Money at Issue in Boston Mayor’s Race as Labor Unions Weigh In
text: BOSTON — With Boston’s first competitive mayor’s race in three decades going down to the wire, John R. Connolly has seized on the issue of outside labor support for his opponent, Martin J. Walsh.

headline: To Shape Young Palestinians, Hamas Creates Its Own Textbooks
text: GAZA CITY — When a class of Palestinian ninth graders in Gaza recently discussed the deadly 1929 riots over access to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, it was guided by a new textbook, introduced this fall by the Islamist Hamas movement.

headline: SAC Nears an Insider Trading Guilty Plea, but Legal Cases Aren’t Shut
text: The criminal case against the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors has reached a conclusion, people briefed on the matter said, with the government expected to announce Monday that SAC will plead guilty to insider trading charges and pay a fine of roughly $1.2 billion.

headline: End of Casino Partnership Leaves Fate of East Boston Racetrack in Doubt
text: BOSTON — Suffolk Downs, a famed but fading thoroughbred racetrack in the neighborhood of East Boston, had dreams of a major revitalization, and when the state approved casinos in 2011, it partnered with the Caesars Entertainment Corporation to apply for the sole casino license that would be awarded in the greater Boston area.

headline: Iran’s Top Leader and U.S. Counter Criticism of Talks
text: TEHRAN — With talks over Iran’s nuclear program set to resume in Geneva this week, both sides engaged in a bit of public diplomacy Sunday: Iran’s supreme leader moved to quiet hard-liners in his country by expressing support for his negotiating team, while the chief American negotiator reiterated in an Israeli television interview that “no deal is better than a bad deal.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 3, 2013
At Marathon, Security Wins
text: When Krista Powell boarded a ferry at the southern tip of Manhattan early Sunday to head to the starting line of her first New York City Marathon, she expected to spend some quiet moments taking in the city’s skyline. Then she looked to her left.

headline: Time Travel and Time Steps: Tapping Into Harlem History
text: The band takes the last bow in “After Midnight,” the sparkling new jazz revue that opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Sunday night. This may be unusual for Broadway, where the players are normally in the pit — and the music often sounds as if it could have been piped in from Hong Kong — but it’s entirely as it should be.

headline: Koch Group Has Ambitions in Small Races
text: CORALVILLE, Iowa — Election seasons in this small eastern Iowa town are usually cordial affairs. But this year, a group backed by the billionaire Koch brothers has changed that.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 4
text: BLACKBERRY Shareholders of BlackBerry will learn on Monday if Fairfax Financial Holdings, which owns about 10 percent of the beleaguered smartphone maker, will transform a tentative offer for the company into a formal bid. Fairfax is conditionally offering $9 a share, valuing BlackBerry at about $4.7 billion, but it is unclear if it has raised enough money to make a firm offer. A group made up of BlackBerry’s co-founders, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, as well as Qualcomm, which makes the chips inside BlackBerry phones, and the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management may also make a bid as soon as Monday.

headline: A Few Paces From the Race, a Starting Line for Girls in Basketball
text: On marathon Sunday, crowds lining Lafayette Avenue in Brooklyn cheered enthusiastically as wave after wave of runners passed by.

headline: European Borders Tested as Money Is Moved to Shield Wealth
text: PARIS — There was nothing extraordinary about the casually dressed businessman waiting on a Paris train platform except, it turned out, for the envelopes he carried — stuffed with 350,000 euros in cash, and seized by French customs agents as he prepared to depart for Belgium.

headline: Saints’ High-Octane Offense Sputters
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Quarterback Drew Brees understands that the cadence of the New Orleans Saints’ offense is precious, not just for each individual play, but for the course of an entire game. When the offense is in rhythm, the team scores a plethora of points, and opponents are left helpless.

headline: Top 2 Candidates Vow to Make City Hall More Faith-Friendly
