headline: A B.C.S. Logjam, Possibly, to End Them All
text: For those who wish the college football playoff would start this year instead of next season, welcome to Week 11. This is when three games laden with Bowl Championship Series implications will help clear a logjam of undefeated teams atop the rankings or bolster the likelihood that at least three will finish the season without a loss.

headline: Referendum on Casinos Stirs Hopes in Tiny Town
text: NICHOLS, N.Y. — Sitting on a temperamental bend of the Susquehanna River, this upstate New York town is not exactly Las Vegas, with little to offer visitors other than some baseball diamonds, a couple of bars and a Main Street that dead-ends at an excavation company.

headline: Tapping Medical Marijuana’s Potential
text: Marijuana has been used medically, recreationally and spiritually for about 5,000 years. Known botanically as cannabis, it has been called a “crude drug”: marijuana contains more than 400 chemicals from 18 chemical families. More than 2,000 compounds are released when it is smoked, and as with tobacco, there are dangers in smoking it.

headline: Love’s Improbable Shot for Timberwolves Spoils Knicks Rally
text: The Knicks avoided Kevin Love last season. He missed the Minnesota Timberwolves’ first game against the Knicks because of an eye injury, and he missed the second after having surgery on his right hand. His team lost both contests without him.

headline: Red Bulls Blow Lead and Settle for Draw
text: After a workout on Friday at the team’s training complex, Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke, with a smile, sidestepped the inevitable question: Would a tie at Houston in the first-game of a home-and-home playoff series suffice?

headline: Jets Close-Up
text: KEY PLAY/PERFORMANCE Trailing by 26-17 midway through the fourth quarter, New Orleans went for it on a fourth-and-inches at the Jets’ 36. The Saints, with all their offensive talent, handed the ball off to tight end Josh Hill on a misdirection play. Jets linebacker Quinton Coples thundered in and stopped Hill for an 8-yard loss. Coples said that he had not seen the play on film but that “you can’t be surprised by anything.”

headline: A Student at N.Y.U. Is Rescued From a Shaft
text: A 19-year-old New York University student whose friends said he had been missing since early Saturday was rescued Sunday evening from a narrow shaft sandwiched between two buildings in TriBeCa.

headline: With ‘Alpha House,’ Amazon Makes Bid for Living Room Screens and Beyond
text: Not long ago, I was on the set of a show about politics, Washington and a senator gone rogue. The set had all the trappings of a big-time television production, but it will be delivered not by broadcast or cable, but over the Internet by a technology company that has not historically been in the business of original productions.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 9 P.M. (13) LOU REED: ROCK AND ROLL HEART (1998) The director Timothy Greenfield-Sanders tours Mr. Reed’s career, from his days with the Velvet Underground and denizen of Warhol’s Factory to his solo work and collaboration with Robert Wilson. The film also touches on dark side of Mr. Reed, above, but “is careful to note that he has gone past all that,” Caryn James wrote in The New York Times about this “American Masters” presentation. “And though the documentary takes too much at face value, Mr. Reed himself sounds more sophisticated about how public image and reality bleed together. ‘I’m not remotely really like the Lou Reed character that I managed to make on record, although after a while I thought he was so cool that I thought it might be fun to be him, so I did,’ he says. He later points out that in the ’80s he married and started going to A.A. Having cleaned up his act no doubt certifies him as PBS ready.” Mr. Reed died at 71 on Oct. 27.

headline: Giving Awards, Raggedly
text: If you believe in awards, you believe in importance, in hierarchies, in arcs of triumph that take you from the bottom to the top. An award says you matter. An awards show is not only a celebration of excellence, but also of people who believe in the system.

headline: Photo Replay: Oct. 28-Nov. 3
text: Eye-hand coordination is a critical element of sports. Then again, sometime the hands seem to act on their own.

headline: One Place Where the U.S. Can Rest Easy About China’s Influence?
text: The bond between China and Pakistan is often called as high as the highest peaks, as deep as the deepest ocean. When things are going well, the proximity phrase — “as close as lips and teeth” — is thrown in, with winces on both sides.

headline: Egypt’s Ex-President Is Defiant at Murder Trial
text: CAIRO — Held incommunicado for the four months since his overthrow as president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood walked into a makeshift courtroom on Monday for his new role as a defendant in a murder trial.

headline: Take Me to the River
text: In Erica McDonald’s imagination, normal folks doing their laundry become hardy trekkers hauling their cumbersome loads across a concrete plain looking for somewhere to clean their clothes. She sees them as victims of industrial prosperity, where a built-over landscape obliterates rivers and forces the sherpas on a search for man-made oases for washing. To carry out her vision, Ms. McDonald, a New York-based art and documentary photographer and founder of Develop Photo, an online photo educational resource, followed real-life strangers to and from the Laundromat — some quite a ways away.

headline: HSBC Profit Rises; Bank Is Cooperating With Foreign Exchange Inquiry
text: LONDON – HSBC, Britain’s biggest bank, said on Monday that third-quarter earnings rose 10 percent from the period a year earlier, helped by its cost-reduction program.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Not Monsters, But Really Big Fish, Found in California
text: In the article “Oarfish Offer Chance to Study an Elusive Animal Long Thought a Monster,” Douglas Quenqua reports on two big fish that washed up on California shores in recent weeks.

headline: Who’d Import Pigs to Israel? Ancient Europeans, Researchers Say
text: JERUSALEM — Israel may not be the most obvious place to study pigs, given that religious strictures in both Judaism and Islam forbid their consumption.

headline: What Personal Essay Topic Would You Assign to College Applicants?
text: Influential figures, obstacles overcome, dreams for the future–these are common topics for college application essays.

text: Patriots 55, Steelers 31

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Moss on Getting People to Eat Their Vegetables
text: Michael Moss, a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporter for The Times, wrote an article for this week’s health issue about creating an effective marketing campaign for broccoli. His last article for the magazine, about the processed-food industry, was adapted from his book, “Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us.”

headline: New York Today: A Losing Tradition
text: Updated 12:05 p.m. | Candidates trailing in the polls usually tell you not to trust the numbers.

headline: Changing Style in Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES — Sting had Hollywood’s finest up on their feet and dancing when he performed at the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles on Saturday. But there was no pushy paparazzi or frenetic public cheering and flourishing cellphone cameras, as music, film and art stars from Mary J. Blige, through Jane Fonda and Jake Gyllenhaal, to the art dealers Larry Gagosian and Dasha Zhukova gathered at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art for its third annual fund-raising gala.

headline: 当代爱情：71岁陷入爱河
text: 诺拉·约翰逊遇到乔治的时候，并没有在寻找爱情。她离婚多年，而他83岁、丧偶。一切就那么自然而然地发生了。

headline: Ryanair Cuts Its Annual Outlook for the Second Time in Two Months
text: PARIS — Ryanair, the European budget airline, slashed its annual profit forecast for the second time in two months on Monday, reflecting the intensifying scramble for passengers among airlines, particularly in Western Europe, at a time of high unemployment and stalled economic growth.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 4, 2013
text: Update: Nov. 5, 2013

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Looks to Increase Ad Revenue Beyond U.S.
text: From Manila to Madrid, international consumers now represent more than three-quarters of the 232 million people who regularly use Twitter. The problem is, Twitter is still figuring out how to make money from those users abroad. The company received 26 percent of its total revenue from markets outside the United States in the third quarter, compared with around 17 percent at the end of last year, according to regulatory filings, Mark Scott reports.

headline: The War on Cancer: From Nixon Until Now
text: When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act many expected quick results, comparing the effort to the one that put man on the moon. After 42 years, what progress have we made?

headline: Hopeful Glimmers in Long War on Cancer
text: This week’s Retro Report video examines the “war on cancer” — a federal research initiative authorized by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971. Many anticipated quick results, in part because of the public relations campaign, complete with ads suggesting we could cure cancer by the bicentennial, that successfully pushed Mr. Nixon into making the commitment.

headline: Hedge Funds Plan Proxy Battle for ValueVision Media
text: Two activist hedge funds, the Clinton Group and Cannell Capital, have joined forces to mount a proxy battle for control of the Internet and television shopping network ValueVision Media.

headline: New Options for Small Businesses Looking to Go Paperless
text: Academics predicted the rise of a paperless society decades ago. We’re not there yet, but at least on the small-business front, we’re getting closer. In fact, a host of new tools have arrived recently, including Shake, an app platform that allows users to create, sign and send legally binding agreements from their smartphones; Zipmark, a digital checkbook; and SimpleScan, a mobile scanner and document management system that integrates with cloud apps used by small businesses.

headline: Home Builders to Merge in $2.7 Billion Deal
text: Tri Pointe Homes, the West Coast builder controlled by Barry S. Sternlicht’s Starwood Capital, is merging with the home-building subsidiary of Weyerhaeuser, a large owner of timberlands, in a deal valued at $2.7 billion.

headline: What Will a New Army Chief Mean for Pakistan and the Neighborhood?
text: Since it was announced last month that Pakistan’s army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, would be retiring, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has kept the country dangling on his choice, creating a new parlor game for the chattering classes in the process. General Kayani has been characteristically mum, except for an unusual press release that said he was leaving the office on Nov. 29, without closing out other options, even as he accepted the concurrent role of chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

headline: In Providence, a Hipster Hotel in a Former Brothel
text: It was only a matter of time before Providence, R.I., long a petri dish for eggheads, design wunderkinds and culinary aspirants, would get its very own vintage-y, self-consciously cool hotel. The Dean, 52 rooms housed in a historic building from 1911 that was once a brothel, reflects the state’s bookish and somewhat gritty impulses toward homegrown authenticity. The lodging’s original mosaic tile flooring is intact, as is the old-timey brick facade, and rooms are furnished mostly with flea market finds. While the hotel’s name is an ode to the area’s academic community — it’s close to R.I.S.D. and Brown University — its arrival signals Providence’s continued cultural renaissance outside campus gates.

headline: In Poll, Many Chinese ‘Angry’ at Perceived U.S. Media Bias
text: Lawyers might call it a leading question, one that would possibly be ruled out of order in a court of law: “How do you feel about the American media repeatedly putting out malicious views of China?”

headline: Report of Nazi-Looted Trove Puts Art World in an Uproar
text: BERLIN — There was no hint that the older man who called a couple of years back about selling a picture could be sitting on an unimaginable trove of art confiscated or banned by the Nazis. When the proffered work, “Lion Tamer” by the German artist Max Beckmann, was collected, the seller seemed to be a proper gentleman in Munich dispensing with a lone, dusty art gem at the end of his life.

headline: Militant Attack Kills Seven in Assam
text: NEW DELHI — At least seven members of the Rabha tribe were gunned down during Diwali celebrations in the northeastern state of Assam, killed by militants from a rival tribe, the state police said Monday.

headline: In Our Pages: November 5

headline: A Takeover Bid for BlackBerry Collapses, and Its Chief Executive Vacates His Post
text: Updated, 9:06 p.m. | OTTAWA — A tentative takeover bid for BlackBerry from its largest shareholder collapsed on Monday, clouding the immediate future of the company.

headline: Pakistan Court Grants Bail to Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A court in Islamabad granted bail to the former military leader Pervez Musharraf, his lawyer said Monday, in a case related to his role in the 2007 siege of a mosque where the army fought militants holed up inside the compound.

headline: Epic Fail: The Business Edition
text: BlackBerry is just the latest example where a promising company falls in love with its own product while missing the signs that consumers are destined to move on.

headline: Twitter Raises Price Range for Its I.P.O.
text: Twitter is feeling more optimistic about investor appetite for its imminent initial public offering.

headline: Issue of Prayer Returns to the Court
text: WASHINGTON — Thirty years ago, a state senator and a Presbyterian minister faced off in the Supreme Court over whether the Nebraska Legislature could open its sessions with a prayer. The court said yes, siding with the minister, and for three decades that settled matters. Such prayers are commonplace.

headline: Violence Mars Election in Kosovo
text: PARIS — The future of a landmark power-sharing agreement between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in Kosovo was called into doubt on Monday after local elections in Kosovo over the weekend were blighted by violence and intimidation by people suspected of being Serbian hard-liners.

headline: A Tale of Two Fed Presidents
text: Props to Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Richmond Fed, for admitting that he has been wrong so far about inflation. Indeed he has: Lacker has been warning about inflationary dangers for more than five years. Still, given the behavior of so many interest rate and inflation hawks in this Lesser Depression — the norm seems to be never even acknowledging the wrong predictions, or trying to rewrite what they said in the past — Lacker’s frank confession of error is refreshing.

headline: Reaction on the Streets and Online as Morsi Appears in Court
text: Last Updated, 5:38 p.m. | As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Mayy el-Sheikh report, Egypt’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, appeared in court on Monday to face charges of inciting the murder of protesters, his first public appearance since his removal from office in July.

headline: In Part-Time Jobs, Women Outearn Men
text: The oft-lamented gender wage gap disappears and actually reverses when only part-time workers are considered, according to a new data release from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Rejects Jos. A. Bank Again
text: Men’s Wearhouse again rebuffed a $2.3 billion takeover bid by Jos. A. Bank on Monday, refusing to allow the rival retailer confidential access to its books. The move may be the last salvo in the battle to combine two of the country’s biggest retailers of men’s suits.

headline: Europe’s Inflation Problem
text: It’s too low.

headline: The Airbnb Economy in New York: Lucrative but Often Illegal
text: Tama Robertson is an artist who sells paintings and makes jewelry, but this being New York City, she also works in real estate. She has worked as an associate broker and invested in some properties of her own, but in recent years, she has supplemented her income with something a bit more contentious: She rents out a room in her own apartment to travelers she finds on the website Airbnb.

headline: Ghesquière Named Vuitton Women’s Design Director
text: Nicolas Ghesquière was appointed on Monday as the women’s design director for Louis Vuitton, taking over from Marc Jacobs, who left the fashion house last month.

headline: Ousted Egyptian President in Court
text: Egyptian state television showed video of Mohamed Morsi arriving for his trial on charges of inciting murder — the deposed president’s first public appearance since being removed from office July 3.

headline: Bill Advances to Outlaw Discrimination Against Gays
text: WASHINGTON — A measure that would outlaw workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity overcame a significant obstacle in the Senate on Monday as seven Republicans crossed party lines and voted to begin debate on the bill.

headline: Tiling Torment
text: Our puzzle this week was proposed by regular Numberplay contributor Joshua Zucker. The puzzle begins with a classic.

headline: Today in Small Business: Unwinding a Failed Start-Up
text: What is affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: What a Big Investment Says About BlackBerry’s Endgame
text: BlackBerry’s announcement that the company was ending its sale process and receiving a $1 billion investment is all about the company’s endgame.

headline: $1.2 Billion Fine for Hedge Fund SAC Capital in Insider Case
text: The hedge fund titan Steven A. Cohen sat at the center of his vast trading floor on Monday, buying and selling stocks. In a sign of his enduring influence on Wall Street, he did business with major banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Reports of a Positive Test in 2006 Call Rodriguez’s Words Into Question
text: Alex Rodriguez tested positive for a banned stimulant in 2006, the first year Major League Baseball tested for the substance, according to two people with knowledge of the drug testing results. The positive test raises questions about public statements Rodriguez has made in connection with the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: ScienceTake: The Contagious Yawn
text: People are not the only animals who yawn, or who catch yawns from each other; dogs and chimps even catch human yawns. It may have to do with empathy, which seems to have deep roots in evolution.

headline: Kerry Reassures Saudis U.S. Shares Their Goals
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — In his first meeting with Saudi Arabia’s ruling monarch since becoming secretary of state, John Kerry sought to reassure the king on Monday that the Obama administration and the Saudis shared common objectives on Syria, Iran and Egypt.

headline: Where Is Nadya of Pussy Riot?
text: MOSCOW — Soon after she arrived in a penal colony in Mordovia in late 2012, Nadezhda (Nadya) Tolokonnikova, the leader of the protest punk group Pussy Riot, asked for a copy of Anatoly Marchenko’s “My Testimony,” an exhaustive accounting of the life of Soviet political prisoners. Marchenko spent 15 of his 48 years in Soviet prisons, including a number in Mordovlag (an acronym for Mordovian camps), the part of the gulag where Tolokonnikova was serving her two-year sentence.

headline: Feeling For | Boys in the Hood
text: The season’s best men’s parkas are vibrant, sleek and meant to be worn on the slopes and off.

headline: Brazil Says It Spied on U.S. and Others Inside Its Borders
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s government acknowledged on Monday that its top intelligence agency had spied on diplomatic targets from countries including the United States, Iran and Russia, putting the Brazilian authorities in the uncomfortable position of defending their own surveillance practices after repeatedly criticizing American spying operations.

headline: The ‘New Vintage’ Life
text: A look inside three Brooklyn apartments decorated with the taxidermy, antique skeletons and other Victoriana that are making their way back into home decor.

headline: Rentals That Are Local, and Luxurious
text: HomeAway, the private home rental company, has started a new website aimed at its ritziest customers, who want not only accommodations owned by locals, but the very best of such.

headline: Justices Decline an Appeal on Abortion
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court decided on Monday not to hear an appeal from a decision striking down an Oklahoma abortion law after all, dismissing as “improvidently granted” a case it had agreed to consider in June.

headline: Sting and Paul Simon Will Tour Together
text: In the continuing sitcom that is popular music — and also in real life — Sting and Paul Simon once lived in the same building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, they recalled in a recent telephone conversation.

headline: Teenagers Postpone Learning to Drive, and That’s Not Good
text: More and more teenagers are putting the brakes on driving.

headline: Gluten-Free Chocolate Buckwheat Biscotti
text: These biscotti have a crumbly texture when they emerge from the first baking, so allow the logs to cool and cut them carefully, about 1/2 inch thick (if you cut them too thin they can fall apart). Buckwheat flour is a great backdrop for the chocolate; it doesn’t dominate but seems rather to show off the chocolate.

headline: Gluten-Free Raisin Pistachio Biscotti
text: I use a mix of almond flour and either millet flour or cornmeal for these. They are irresistible. If you soak the raisins in amaretto before you make the biscotti there will be a slightly bitter edge to the flavor. As in other whole grain biscotti I use some butter here, which makes for a more delicate cookie, requiring a slightly thicker slice than a wheat flour cookie.

headline: Hazelnut, Orange and Honey Biscotti
text: Orange, hazelnut and honey make a wonderful combination in this whole wheat biscotti. The hard cookies should be sliced thin, which will yield a lot of cookies! They are wonderful dipped in tea.

headline: Cornmeal Coconut Biscotti
text: When I use a grainy flour like cornmeal I always include some fat in the biscotti, and this time I went with coconut oil, which contributes great flavor and a sweet perfume. Use fine or medium-grind cornmeal and make sure to use fine coconut flakes. I used organic sugar (not brown) for these; the sugar is off-white rather than white, and coarser than regular granulated sugar.

headline: Image of the Day: November 4
text: Cricketer Sachin Tendulkar at the entrance of the Eden Gardens cricket ground in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: More Turmoil in Russian Ballet World
text: Nikolai Tsiskaridze, the flamboyant former Bolshoi Ballet star who hit the headlines when his disputes with company management were linked to the January acid attack on the company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, is once again in the spotlight.

headline: J.&J. to Pay $2.2 Billion in Risperdal Settlement
text: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay more than $2.2 billion in criminal and civil fines to settle accusations that it improperly promoted the antipsychotic drug Risperdal to older adults, children and people with developmental disabilities, the Justice Department said on Monday.

headline: High-Level Executive Switches to Carlyle From Warburg Pincus
text: The Carlyle Group has hired Kewsong Lee away from his post as managing director at Warburg Pincus, an unusually high-level transition within private equity’s executive ranks.

headline: Weigh In on Twitter’s I.P.O. Value
text: Twitter is increasing the price for its upcoming initial public offering by as much as a third. The social network is now looking to raise $23 to $25 a share, according to a filing on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Lithuanian Opera Rounds Out Prototype Festival Lineup
text: The “Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now” festival of avant-garde chamber opera and musical theater has added one stage production — the American premiere of “Have a Good Day!” by the Lithuanian composer Lina Lapelyte — as well as two concerts to the schedule it announced in July. It has also set the dates for the individual productions.

headline: Casinos, Pot and the Quest For Consistency
text: My Sunday column on “pot and jackpots” — that is, the march toward marijuana legalization and the spread of casino gambling — tried to widen the usual culture-war frame to encompass not just bedroom-and-altar hot buttons, but the way the broader logic of “consenting adults” is working itself out in other areas of American life. One point I didn’t get to, though, is the extent to which both of these issues, pot and gambling, illustrate what one might call the rationalizing impulse in modern American politics, which seeks perfect fairness and consistency at the expense of compromises rooted in the accidents of history, and which makes it hard for conservatives to defend older, inherently-arbitrary arrangements even when they make practical sense.

headline: Rosie Huntington-Whiteley’s Jet-Set Chic
text: The Girl: The actress was travel-ready in a star-print cardigan, oversize shades and fedora at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday.

headline: Appealing Observation Status to Medicare
text: A question for readers: Have you filed an appeal with Medicare after it would not cover nursing home care or prescription drugs following hospitalization — because you were on observation status? We’d like to know about it. Please leave a comment.

headline: Ask Well: CoQ10-Drug Interactions?
text: Question:

headline: Two-Faced Allies: Pakistan and the U.S.
text: Less than a week after Pakistan’s prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, returned home from a trip to Washington, an American drone killed Hakimullah Mehsud, a man who had terrorized all Pakistan as the leader of the country’s most dangerous militant group, the Pakistani Taliban.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: New Chief Curator for the Frick
text: The Frick Collection has appointed Xavier F. Salomon to be its chief curator, filling a spot left vacant by Colin B. Bailey who left in June to become director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: AARP promoted three members of the AARP Media Sales management team, based in New York, to new posts. Mark Bradbury, director of insights and integrated marketing, becomes senior director of insights and integrated marketing. Shelagh Daly Miller, vice president for advertising, becomes vice president and group publisher. And Peter Zeuschner, Northeast sales manager, was promoted to digital sales manager.

headline: Iranians Rally Against U.S., 34 Years After Embassy Takeover
text: TEHRAN — Thousands of Iranian demonstrators surrounded the former United States Embassy building in Tehran on Monday, in the largest anti-American rally in years, bolstering hard-liners who oppose attempts by the Iranian president, Hassan Rouhani, to establish relations with the Islamic republic’s archenemy.

headline: So, Travis Bickle Walked Into a Bar
text: Over the past decade or so, mixologists have seemed to resurrect almost every significant drinking era in American history. Pre-Prohibition cocktails have been meticulously recreated. The aesthetic of the Prohibition-era speakeasy has been thoroughly explored. And “Mad Men” has inspired bars to plumb the hard-drinking days that followed World War II.

headline: On Gay Rights, Congress Lags
text: Here’s a study in contrast:

headline: LACMA Red Carpet
text: Looks from the Art and Film Gala in Los Angeles red carpet, including Kate Hudson’s dress, with its barely-there breast pieces.

headline: Ads Celebrate Mozart in the City
text: Each year, November becomes Movember as men raise money to fight cancer by growing mustaches. This year, November is Movember for another reason, as a radio station and website known for classical music celebrate what they are declaring to be a “month of Mozart.”

headline: An Operatic Monster Mash
text: A mild-mannered bachelor tried to kiss a zombie on Saturday evening on the Lower East Side. He succumbed to her bite soon after. A group of medical students made earnest attempts to reanimate a corpse. Religious objects were desecrated. There was blood.

headline: Marathon Style
text: Runners in the New York City Marathon showed their style during the race.

headline: Excerpt: 'Domesticated'
text: Laurie Metcalf and Jeff Goldblum in a scene from Bruce Norris's new play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Johnson Overwhelms Texas Nascar Field
text: Jimmie Johnson proved to be unbeatable Sunday in the 500-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Texas Motor Speedway. In the process, he moved into the points lead in the chase for the season championship.

headline: A Memorial for Marcella Hazan
text: Marcella Hazan, the cooking teacher and author whose works redefined Italian food for a generation of American cooks, was remembered Sunday by her friends and colleagues at a memorial dinner in New York, where she lived and taught for four decades. Mrs. Hazan died at 89 in Florida on Sept. 29. Friends and colleagues said at the dinner, which was at SD26 in Chelsea, Mrs. Hazan was remembered as a rigorous teacher, a fond mother, a brilliant and straightforward cook and a curmudgeon on culinary matters.

headline: Dismiss Diversification at Your Own Risk
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His sketches are archived on Your Money.

headline: A Key to Quantum Computing, Close to Home
text: A blue dye found in many household items, including the British five-pound note, could fill an important need in the quest to develop a quantum computer, researchers say.

headline: No Heroism in Playing After a Head Injury
text: Manchester City once had a goalkeeper named Bert Trautmann. Trautmann, a German, spent his professional career in England and was known for his uncanny ability to save penalty kicks. His most famous moment, though, came when he helped City win the F.A. Cup at Wembley Stadium despite playing the final part of the game with a broken neck.

headline: Ali, Tyson and Captain Kirk: Coil Festival Announces Lineup
text: An imagined boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Mike Tyson and a video remix built of Capt. James T. Kirk’s observations from the original “Star Trek” television series are among the offerings in the 2014 edition of Performance Space 122’s ninth Coil Festival.

headline: Central Connecticut State University Ends Lockdown After Suspect’s Arrest
text: The report on Monday afternoon was alarming: A man in a ski mask carrying a gun and a samurai sword had been seen walking on campus at Central Connecticut State University. That 911 call led officials to declare a campus emergency, direct everyone on campus to stay indoors for several hours and cancel classes.

headline: The Impact of the Settlement on SAC Capital and Cohen
text: The plea agreement between the Justice Department and SAC Capital Advisors that calls for the firm to pay almost $1.2 billion to resolve insider trading charges is carefully drafted to permit the government to continue its pursuit of Steven A. Cohen, the hedge fund firm’s founder and owner. SAC has finally put the government’s criminal case behind it, but Mr. Cohen remains the focus of a continuing criminal investigation and an administrative complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Editorial Is Under Fire for Saying President ‘Clearly Misspoke’ on Health Care
text: A Times editorial on Sunday on the new health care law let President Obama off the hook with its too-soft choice of words, according to some readers who complained to me on Monday.

headline: Hepatitis C, a Silent Killer, Meets Its Match
text: Determined to get rid of the hepatitis C infection that was slowly destroying his liver, Arthur Rubens tried one experimental treatment after another. None worked, and most brought side effects, like fever, insomnia, depression, anemia and a rash that “felt like your skin was on fire.”

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert Finds Inspiration Behind the Garden Gate
text: LOS ANGELES — After the runaway success of “Eat, Pray, Love,” her 2006 memoir of divorce, spirituality and self-improvement, the writer Elizabeth Gilbert set off on an entirely different path. “The Signature of All Things,” her acclaimed new novel, is about — of all things — a fictional 19th-century botanist.

headline: New Hope on Hepatitis, Herbal Supplements Under Scrutiny, Eat, Pray, Botany
text: New drugs could change the way Hepatitis C is treated; think that’s St. John’s Wort you’re buying?; Elizabeth Gilbert talks about her new novel, “The Signature of All Things.”

headline: Extra Cash and New Chief Buy BlackBerry Just a Bit More Time
text: BlackBerry’s liquid infusion won’t douse its cash burn. The troubled company is selling $1 billion of convertible debt after attempts to find a buyer flopped. Even its big supporter, Fairfax Financial, has backed away from taking full control. The extra money and a new boss buy BlackBerry a bit more time. But its prospects are bleak.

headline: Far-Off Planets Like the Earth Dot the Galaxy
text: The known odds of something — or someone — living far, far away from Earth improved beyond astronomers’ boldest dreams on Monday.

headline: Pakistani Party Votes to Block NATO Supply Lines if Drones Persist
text: LONDON — The ruling party in a northwestern province of Pakistan voted Monday to block NATO supply lines by Nov. 20 unless the United States stops its drone strikes in the nearby tribal belt.

headline: Vaccine Approved for Brain Fever
text: The World Health Organization has approved a new vaccine for a strain of encephalitis that kills thousands of children and leaves many survivors with permanent brain damage.

headline: Poisonous to Pets
text: Q. I know chocolate is harmful to dogs. What else hurts pets but not people?

headline: Why a Pension Case Will Not Change Private Equity Tax Law
text: Steve Judge is president and chief executive of the Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

headline: Wall Street’s Marathoners Go the Extra Mile
text: Updated, 5:14 p.m. |

headline: S.E.C. Clarifies That Crowdfunding Portals Will Be Able to Take Commissions
text: Last week, in our post about the Securities and Exchange Commission’s proposed regulation for crowdfunding, we reported that the rules might make it harder for specialized crowdfunding portals to earn much of a living facilitating such deals.

headline: Medical Ethics Have Been Violated at Detention Sites, a New Report Says
text: A group of experts in medicine, law and ethics has issued a blistering report that accuses the United States government of directing doctors, nurses and psychologists, among others, to ignore their professional codes of ethics and participate in the abuse of detainees in Afghanistan, Iraq and Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Walkabout: A Flight Safety Video Set to Song; a Museum Dedicated to Show Biz
text: Jazz Hands Virgin America’s new foot-stomping, musical flight-safety video is attracting lots of attention on the Internet (our In Transit post is here), but some remain unconvinced that all of the pizzazz will actually get passengers’ attention. (The Economist)

headline: Concerns About Jerky Pet Treats
text: Seven years ago, Jordan Smith offered her two dogs a Christmas treat: pieces of chicken jerky. Within hours, Eugene, a 14-year-old wire-haired pointing griffon, and Choppy White, a poodle of uncertain age, had diarrhea and were vomiting. A week later, Choppy White died of liver failure.

headline: Humpback Dolphin Clan Branches Out
text: A group of humpback dolphins off the northern coast of Australia has been designated a separate species, previously unknown, following a genetic investigation by scientists with the Wildlife Conservation Society. Looking to prove that there were more than two species of humpback dolphin, researchers collected physical and genetic evidence from the animals around the world, eventually proving there were four distinct species. The Australian group has not yet been given a name.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 29 – Nov. 4, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Rethinking Medical Programs (2 Letters)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: How to Shorten Commutes (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Survival of the Extraordinary – A Fly With Tricky* Wings
text: [Update, Nov.8, 8:00 p.m. | The wings on this fly are tricky, indeed. Read this great post by Morgan D. Jackson, an entomology grad student and photographer, to get a very nuanced and appropriately skeptical examination of such wing patterns: “Ants, Spiders, or Wishful Thinking?“]

headline: Maine Governor Candidate Says He Is Gay
text: BOSTON — Michael H. Michaud, a Democrat who represents conservative, northern Maine in Congress and is a leading candidate for governor next year, announced in a newspaper column Monday that he is gay.

headline: Not-So-Herbal Supplements
text: A study using DNA testing offers perhaps the most credible evidence to date of adulteration, contamination and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.

headline: Bangladesh Takes Step to Increase Lowest Pay
text: Criticized over unsafe conditions and low pay in its garment industry, Bangladesh took a first step to raise wages on Monday with a special government-appointed board voting to nearly double the minimum wage. Factory owners complained that the increase was too high, labor leaders that it was too low.

headline: Science on His Own Terms
text: There is Big Science, defined as science that gets the big bucks. There is tried and true science, which, from an adventurous dissident’s point of view, is boldly going where others have gone before but extending the prevailing knowledge by a couple of decimal places (a safe approach for dissertation writers and grant seekers).

headline: More Like Her
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Netflix Acquires Streaming Rights to a Highly Praised Documentary
text: Netflix said on Monday that starting early next year it will be the exclusive streaming distributor for “The Square,” an Arabic documentary about the Egyptian protest centered in Tahrir Square, which is considered a leading contender for an Oscar nomination.

headline: The Read Around: Nicholas Sparks
text: Nicholas Sparks, author of “The Longest Ride,” says elements like betrayal, loss and honesty are all needed to make a novel work.

headline: Finding the Higgs Leads to More Puzzles
text: Near the end of “The Tempest,” in what has been taken as Shakespeare’s farewell speech, the sorcerer Prospero breaks his staff and declares, “Our revels now are ended.” And he goes on:

headline: When Fuzzy Slippers Aren’t Enough
text: I eat soup all year long. But when the wind blows cold enough for me to unearth my fuzzy slippers, that’s when I really crave a bowl of thick, puréed vegetable soup.

headline: Yankees Offer One-Year Deals to Three Players
text: The Yankees extended one-year qualifying contract offers of $14.1 million to Curtis Granderson, Robinson Cano and Hiroki Kuroda on Monday, setting the stage for intrigue in the days ahead.

headline: The Texas Abortion Emergency
text: Outside the chambers of federal appellate judges Priscilla Owen, Jennifer Elrod, and Catharina Haynes, virtually everyone understands that H.B. 2, the new Texas law that places various restrictions on a woman’s ability to obtain an abortion, is not about protecting women’s health — it’s about stopping abortion.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 1-3, 2013
text: On Friday morning, Paul Ciancia, 23, walked into Los Angeles International Airport with a legally purchased .223-caliber assault rifle and five 30-round magazines and opened fire on a T.S.A. security checkpoint, killing 39-year-old Gerardo Hernandez, a father of two who had screened passengers there for three years, and wounding four others—two additional T.S.A. agents and two passengers. The rampage was halted when he was shot in the mouth and the leg by authorities. The next day, federal prosecutors charged him with murder.

headline: A Talent Whose Light Was Bright but Brief
text: For some in the dismayingly large club of rock stars who died too young, it’s easy to imagine an alternate future in which fate or bad judgment does not intervene and they live to a ripe old age. John Lennon becomes a patron of the arts and fends off repeated requests that he run for office. Cass Elliot does a stint on “The View.”

headline: Testing Supplements
text: Genetic testing of 44 herbal supplements from a dozen companies found that only two companies used completely authentic ingredients.

headline: Raft of New Works Scheduled for Ecstatic Music Festival
text: The Ecstatic Music Festival, which has quickly become the alt-classical world’s main showcase, will offer 11 concerts during its fourth season, which opens Jan. 31 and runs through March 29. As in past years, the concerts, which are assembled by the composer Judd Greenstein, are double or triple bills in which ensembles (many led by composers) perform separate sets and also join forces, either on new collaborative works or improvisations.

headline: The Read Around: Nicholas Sparks
text: In “The Read Around,” a new weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Nicholas Sparks talks about his novel “The Longest Ride” and how he approaches building a story that will work for both page and screen.

headline: Being a Working Mother Means Always Having to Say You’re Sorry
text: Sorry!

headline: Editor Did Not Agree to Phone Hacking, Lawyer Says
text: LONDON — Andy Coulson, former editor of the tabloid The News of the World, now defunct, never agreed to any illegal phone hacking at the newspaper, his lawyer told the jury on Monday at the Old Bailey in the trial of Mr. Coulson; his former boss and onetime lover, Rebekah Brooks; and six others.

headline: Book About Amazon Is Reviewed on Amazon, by Founder’s Wife
text: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has yet to make a public peep about “The Everything Store,” a major biography of Mr. Bezos and his company that was published last month.

headline: Disabled Chinese Struggle for a Good Education, and Acceptance
text: Ni Zhen didn’t want to become a masseur, even though neighbors, educators and seemingly everyone else in his native Shandong Province urged him in that direction — because he is blind.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: With cuts to SNAP, 76 million meals will be off the table for the poorest families in New York City alone. Related: A sobering piece by Ian Frazier in the New Yorker about homelessness in New York, which is higher than it’s been in decades.

headline: Supreme Court Takes Up Steelworkers’ Bid for Time to Put on Work Gear
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which ordinarily confronts complicated questions, heard arguments on Monday about what might seem like a simple one: What does it mean to change clothes?

headline: Brahms to Ives to Knotty Swedish Consonants, a Mezzo Goes the Full Range
text: The superb mezzo-soprano Jamie Barton, quickly becoming known for the flood of sound she can unleash, began her recital on Sunday afternoon singing against type.

headline: A Science Project With Legs
text: The average teenage boy is likely to have an interest in chicken only when it hits his dinner plate.

headline: A Traitor to His Class? Such Good Fun
text: David Letterman is not only an author of “This Land Was Made for You and Me (but Mostly Me),” a new humor book he created with Bruce McCall. He is also a target of its pointed populist satire, and he knows it.

headline: Taking a Toll
text: The number of new infections and acute cases of hepatitis C has fallen sharply, but because many of those currently infected are baby boomers now middle-aged and older, long-term medical problems caused by the virus are expected to rise.

headline: Defectors Land on Their Feet
text: PHOENIX — Cuba takes special measures to hold on to one of its most precious cultural resources: ballet dancers. To discourage defections, authorities sometimes keep talented performers from touring or warn younger artists that finding a ballet job will be tough in an unappreciative capitalist world.

headline: Don’t Start Up Your Tablet on the Runway Just Yet
text: THE confusion light is on.

headline: Holidays Holding Hands
text: The expectations for our family’s holiday meals are usually as rigid as the compartments of a plastic prison plate. Any deviation, any scrambling of tradition (“Who put raisins in the cranberry sauce?” “You call this a latke? It looks more like matzo brei!”), is treated as heresy. The offending cook can expect hours of protest, and maybe a loss of skillet privileges.

headline: In Performance: Patrick Page
text: Patrick Page plays Rufus Buckley, the district attorney in the stage adaptation of John Grisham’s novel “A Time to Kill.” The show is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Fergus Henderson’s ‘The Complete Nose to Tail’ Cookbook
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: The Sounds of a Torn Region United in Many Languages
text: At the end of “The Cycles of Life: A Musical Exploration of the Balkans,” conceived and presented by the Catalan early-music explorer Jordi Savall at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, five soloists sang five different songs at once. In five different languages.

headline: Using a Familiar Device to Dance Out of the Past, Page by Page
text: The device of using old dance photographs as material for new choreography goes back decades. Nineteenth-century photographs of people in motion by Eadweard Muybridge — pointing the way to flip-book continuity — have inspired several choreographers. Images of Isadora Duncan and Vaslav Nijinsky have entered into many dances.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Russia and Indonesia.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Graywolf Press
text: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Jeffrey Shotts, Graywolf’s executive editor, with Fiona McCrae, the press’s director and publisher.

headline: CDs From Celine Dion and Midlake
text: CELINE DION

headline: A Roman Sculpture, a Study on Lying and a Disturbing F.D.A. Report
text: There are only about 4,000 black rhinoceroses left in the world — at least until next year, when a high bidder gets a chance to shoot one. This week brought news of a controversial auction, plus an account of what the Food and Drug Administration found in imported spices.

headline: Playing the Game Again, With an Insider’s Look at the Players
text: Barack Obama’s performance in Denver in Debate No. 1 against Mitt Romney was widely perceived as something between a flop and a disaster: even supporters complained that the president seemed listless, passive, peevish, disdainful and distracted. The president and his aides promised a comeback in Debate No. 2 — suddenly a must-win showdown, needed to stop the bleeding, reassure the base and stem a migration of independents to Mr. Romney.

headline: A Force for Face-to-Face Communication
text: Clifford I. Nass, a professor of communication at Stanford who died on Saturday, regaled me several times over the years about his method for torturing students in the undergraduate dorm hall where he was an adviser. He would make them communicate face to face.

headline: CNN Ratings Fall as Health Care Coverage Rises
text: CNN provided heavy coverage last week of the troubled introduction of the website tied to the Affordable Care Act. The result was the lowest weekly ratings for CNN in more than a year.

headline: Bartok’s Quartets Mixed With a Dose of Indie Rock
text: Bartok primarily wrote instrumental music, with a large catalog that features relatively few vocal selections. But his instrumental pieces owe a substantial debt to the voice, with inflections of his native Hungarian woven throughout works like his fourth string quartet.

headline: The Continued Taming of the N.F.L.
text: The N.F.L. has made several rule changes to try to limit injuries. William C. Rhoden wonders if the often violent onside kick could be the next play to be outlawed.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: The Continued Taming of the N.F.L.
text: The N.F.L. has made several rule changes to try to limit injuries. Could the often violent onside kick be the next play to be outlawed?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Unicorn Club, and Explaining N.S.A. Access to Tech Company Data
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: DNA Bar Coding
text: DNA Bar Coding  is a technique for quickly analyzing short sequences of genes to identify plant or animal species.

headline: Singleton to Retire as Chairman of MediaNews Group
text: William Dean Singleton, the co-founder and chairman of MediaNews Group, who over the years earned a reputation for extensive cost-cutting, will retire in December, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Role of Humanities, in School and Life
Getting International Aid Relief to War-Torn Syrians
A Surreal Spying Industry
Parking Rules
text: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

Immigration Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary in 2016? Not So Fast
text: Hillary Clinton of all people knows how political fortunes turn on a dime. But she must be puzzled nonetheless, and spooked, that over a six-month period when she made no big news whatsoever, her popularity took a double-digit tumble.

headline: Glamour Travel With Four Boys
text: MY father was a pilot, and when I was a child we never had family vacation road trips. We got to fly, and I thought that was so cool. My parents insisted that I had to wear a suit jacket. That rule stuck, and I still wear a jacket when I travel.

headline: The Animated Life of A. R. Wallace
text: This paper-puppet animation celebrates the life of Alfred Russel Wallace, who is co-credited with Charles Darwin for the theory of natural selection.

headline: Secrets of a Game Show Writer
text: The word “only,” an adverb that portends disappointment for the hopeful theatergoer (“standing room only”) and an adjective that mocks the sibling-deprived (“only child”), is a trivia writer’s best friend. Shortly before he died, Dr. Seuss confessed that “Green Eggs and Ham” was “the only book I ever wrote that still makes me laugh.” The actor Bruce Dern, after appearing alongside the Duke in the 1972 western “The Cowboys,” correctly boasted that he was “the only actor who ever killed John Wayne.”

headline: Crist, Former Florida Governor, Tosses Hat in Ring Again
text: ST. PETERSBURG — Hopscotching from one Democratic touchstone to the next — education, voting rights, the environment and bipartisanship — former Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida announced Monday that he would run for the job once again, this time as a Democrat.

headline: ‘The Animated Life of A.R. Wallace’
text: Although Alfred Russel Wallace made one of the most important scientific discoveries in history, he’s been all but forgotten. A contemporary of Charles Darwin, Wallace was the other guy to discover natural selection – the evolutionary process whereby better adapted organisms are more likely to survive and pass on their traits than less adapted ones. Although two people discovered this theory, evolution by natural selection is virtually synonymous with Darwin. This is partly due to the lasting fame of Darwin’s opus, “On the Origin of Species,” but some argue it is also due to Wallace’s extraordinary modesty – he lauded Darwin’s work and humbly downplayed his own contributions. In 1889 he even wrote a book in support of evolution titled “Darwinism.”

headline: No Riders Killed in First 5 Months of New York City Bike-Share Program
text: To many, the ingredients for New York City’s bike-share program suggested a sort of sadistic alchemy.

headline: With Cows in Mind, Swiss Farmers Wage Litter Battle
text: SOLOTHURN, Switzerland — Before he mows the hay he feeds his dairy cows, Hansueli Wyss performs a new ritual: He scours the fields of his 65-acre farm amid the rolling hills of this farming region, dotted with steep-roofed homes like his 150-year-old farmhouse, for junk — empty bottles and soda or beer cans, hamburger cartons, and much else.

headline: Turning On iTunes Menus
text: Turning On

headline: De Blasio Seeks Mandate as Lhota Hopes for Upset
text: Concerned that his overwhelming lead in the race to be New York mayor could depress voter turnout, Bill de Blasio on Monday warned supporters against complacency as he sought to win with a decisive mandate that could propel his liberal agenda.

headline: Ukraine: Workers Removing Parts of Chernobyl Plant
text: Workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine have begun dismantling a ventilation stack that has filtered radioactive gases from the reactor that was destroyed in an accident in 1986. The first section, weighing 33 tons, was lifted off the stack Thursday for storage in the plant’s turbine hall, according to a report on the plant’s website. The work is expected to take about five weeks. The distinctive red-and-white tower is being removed to allow a new arch-shaped enclosure to be placed over the concrete sarcophagus that was built after the disaster to entomb the wrecked reactor. The arch, scheduled to be completed in 2015, will allow workers to eventually dismantle the old sarcophagus and dispose of the radioactive fuel. As part of the preparation for the work, a new, smaller ventilation stack for removing radioactive aerosols that remain in Reactor 4 was built nearby.

headline: The Mets’ Delicate Dance With a Billionaire
text: When the Mets needed money after their owners were fleeced by Bernard L. Madoff, they turned to Steven A. Cohen, a hedge-fund billionaire. Their first request to him to invest came in 2010. A year later, Cohen emerged again as a possible financial lifeline before the Mets agreed to sell 33 percent of the team for $200 million to David Einhorn, another hedge-fund wizard. But that deal eventually collapsed.

headline: For Athletes, a Home for Away Games
text: When the Minnesota Vikings checked into the J. W. Marriott Chicago last season, the hotel’s staff scrambled to fix a mistake: They had stocked the wrong flavor of Pedialyte, a favorite rehydration drink for players.

headline: Election Day Choices
text: Here are our recommendations for some races and state constitutional amendments in New York and New Jersey. Poll hours are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. in New York and 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. in New Jersey.

headline: Arming the T.S.A. Is Not a Solution
text: Police are still piecing together the details of Friday’s fatal shooting at Los Angeles International Airport, but it appears as if the gunman, Paul Ciancia, targeted Transportation Security Administration agents. In response to the attack, the union representing T.S.A. screeners said the agency should arm certain employees and assign them to checkpoints. The administrator of the T.S.A., John Pistole, said he would discuss changes to security protocols with Congress.

headline: F.C.C.’s Chief Hires a Critic of the Agency
text: WASHINGTON — Tom Wheeler was sworn in on Monday as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission and promptly named to his senior staff Gigi B. Sohn, one of the agency’s most outspoken critics but a supporter of the new leader.

headline: Mr. Kerry Fumbles in Egypt
text: Secretary of State John Kerry’s trip to Egypt, included in his Middle East itinerary at the last minute, served only to add to the confusion over the Obama administration’s policy toward this critically important Arab nation. Mr. Kerry was the highest-ranking American official to visit Cairo since Mohamed Morsi, the country’s first democratically elected president, was deposed in July. Mr. Kerry seemed to go further than necessary or prudent to make common cause with the authoritarian generals who led the coup and are now running the country.

headline: The Fate of the Humanities
text: Can the study of the humanities thrive at a time of changing needs, or will they be too much of an academic luxury?

headline: Brooklyn Diocese Sues One of Its High Schools in Queens
text: For more than 30 years, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and the nonprofit group running Christ the King High School in Queens have acted as one, managing the twin hurdles of declining enrollments and shrinking revenues with a joint aim of fostering parochial education.

headline: Toward Ending Workplace Discrimination
text: An overdue measure to outlaw employment discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity cleared a procedural hurdle on Monday night in the Senate. The move is one step toward putting into federal law a basic principle most Americans support: Job applicants and employees should be judged on their professional credentials and the caliber of their work, and not be held back because of who they are.

headline: SAC: A Textbook Case of Corporate Prosecution
text: SAC Capital’s guilty plea to insider trading and $1.2 billion fine may represent a sweeping victory for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney, and his team of prosecutors, and vindication for their multiyear investigation of one of the country’s most successful hedge funds. But the decision to indict a company, and to spare, at least for now, its founder and billionaire manager, Steven A. Cohen, has already ignited criticism.

headline: ‘Buy One, Give One’ Spirit Imbues an Online Store
text: TOMS started in 2006 with what was then a novel idea: for every pair of shoes it sold, it would donate a pair to a child living in poverty. Along with donating more than 10 million pairs to date, the company spurred a trend of “buy one, give one” companies, with the eyeglass maker Warby Parker among the best known.

headline: Few Eager to Talk Peace in Syria, but a Mediator Won’t Stop
text: UNITED NATIONS — Lakhdar Brahimi says he prefers to navigate by sight. By this, he means that to find ways out of war, he looks for a course while talking. It distinguishes his mediating style, those who have worked with him say, and it has worked in his favor in the many conflicts he has mediated on behalf of the United Nations: holding elections in Haiti, forming a government in Iraq, ending a civil war in Lebanon.

headline: Hockey History, as Documented by Prime Minister
text: The historian Jacques Barzun once wrote, “Whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn baseball.” That notion probably goes double for Canada and hockey.

headline: Uighur Scholar in Ugly Confrontation With Security Agents
text: Ilham Tohti, a well-known scholar who is arguably China’s most vocal advocate for the rights of its Uighur minority, said he got into an ugly confrontation with security agents in Beijing on Saturday after the men rammed his car and threatened to kill his wife and children.

headline: After a Decade, SAC Capital Blinks
text: SAC Capital Advisors first sought to fend off a federal indictment. Then the hedge fund, run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, offered to pay about $700 million to settle. Finally, SAC suggested it plead guilty to only some of the criminal charges in the five-count indictment.

headline: After Los Angeles Airport Shooting, No Easy Answers on Security Strategies
text: WASHINGTON — When Stephen L. Holl, the chief of police at the Washington Metropolitan Airports Authority, gathered his staff for the regular morning meeting on Monday, he opened with a sobering assessment.

headline: Americans Jailed for Months in Qatar After Daughter’s Death
text: Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple with three adopted children from Africa, lived as a family in the affluent Persian Gulf kingdom of Qatar starting in July 2012. For most of the time since then, the parents have been imprisoned there, accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death with the intent of selling her organs.

headline: For 36 Hours, N.Y.U. Student Was Trapped Between 2 Buildings
text: In a crowded city, Asher Vongtau was completely alone, trapped in a space barely wider than a shoe box after plummeting perhaps 100 feet into the tiny crevice between two buildings in TriBeCa.

headline: A Finding of Guilty in the Killing of Sean Taylor
text: MIAMI — After an 11-day trial, a 23-year-old man charged in the killing of the Washington Redskins star Sean Taylor in 2007 was found guilty Monday of second-degree murder and armed burglary.

headline: U.S. in Talks to Settle Suit Over American-US Airways Merger
text: The Justice Department has started talks with American Airlines and US Airways, seeking concessions on airport takeoff and landing slots in exchange for dropping an antitrust lawsuit aimed at blocking their merger, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said on Monday

headline: Shooting Suspect’s Steps Are Traced in Search for Clues to L.A. Airport Attack
text: LOS ANGELES — The morning that a gunman opened fire at the Los Angeles International Airport, killing a security official and wounding two others, Paul Ciancia walked unannounced into a roommate’s room and asked for a ride the airport, according to a federal search warrant released by federal prosecutors Monday.

headline: Fixing the System
text: It’s Election Day. Virginians are electing a new governor, New Yorkers are choosing a new mayor, and all over the country, dozens of local races are being decided. Because this is an off-year election, in which there are no federal races, voter turnout is going to be abysmal. We all know that.

headline: Strategic Move Exempts Health Law From Broader U.S. Statute
text: WASHINGTON — The Affordable Care Act is the biggest new health care program in decades, but the Obama administration has ruled that neither the federal insurance exchange nor the federal subsidies paid to insurance companies on behalf of low-income people are “federal health care programs.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 5, 2013
text: “It seems that the universe produces plentiful real estate for life that somehow resembles life on Earth.”

headline: Big Money Flows in New Jersey Races to Thwart Christie Agenda
text: Democrats and unions, fearful that a landslide victory by Gov. Chris Christie will reshape New Jersey’s political landscape, have poured tens of millions of dollars into a record-breaking outside spending campaign that has transformed the state’s election season.

headline: In Bullying Case, Questions on N.F.L. Culture
text: Jonathan Martin and Richie Incognito spent most of the season side by side, a pair of 300-pound men made rich from football, crouched inches apart on the offensive line of the Miami Dolphins. When the defense took the field, they sat on the bench in order of their position — Martin, the left tackle, next to Incognito, the left guard. They were as connected as teammates could be — though they could hardly be more different.

headline: Christie Hopes to Show G.O.P. He Has Diverse Support
text: The question in the governor’s race in New Jersey on Tuesday is not who will win, but by how much, and where?

headline: A Plea for Catholic Schools to Ignore New Guidelines
text: A group of Roman Catholic scholars has called on Catholic schools to ignore the new educational standards known as the Common Core, a set of guidelines on what students should know and be able to do from kindergarten through 12th grade, opening a front with parallels to the fight over using the guidelines in public schools.
