text: FRONT PAGE

headline: After Extramarital Activities, Politician Looks for the Words
text: All he’s trying to do, says Bill, a proverbial man in a bar, struggling to find the words, is “to begin the conversation, the honest conversation.”

headline: The Revolution Is Not an Apple
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The southeast was the last sector to fall in for me today, which may just be the way Paula Gamache wanted it. Whether or not that is true, it worked out well because it saved the reveal for last and, indeed, cracked me up.

headline: As U.S. Weighs Spying Changes, Officials Say Data Sweeps Must Continue
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has told allies and lawmakers it is considering reining in a variety of National Security Agency practices overseas, including holding White House reviews of the world leaders the agency is monitoring, forging a new accord with Germany for a closer intelligence relationship and minimizing collection on some foreigners.

headline: In Housing Court, Different View of New York City’s Mayoral Race
text: A chill wind pinching his face, Compton Bremner takes his place among hundreds of men and women who clutch dispossess notices and rent receipts.

headline: Hearing Voices, and Listening to the Right One
text: Two distinct voices have fought for authority over RaeJanese Chambers since the onset of her schizophrenia at age 29. While both speak with equal clarity, Ms. Chambers, 41, ascribes only one of them to her illness.

headline: A Yiddishe Momme of Music, Chana Mlotek, Dies at 91
text: Chana Mlotek, an impassioned sleuth and archivist of Yiddish music whose song collections allowed thousands to imbibe the mirthful and mournful melodies of the shtetl, ghetto and Yiddish theater, died on Monday at her home in the Bronx. She was 91.

headline: Knicks Dissect Ugly First Quarter With the Hope to ‘Clean It Up’
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It was not enough for Raymond Felton to live through one of the franchise’s worst first quarters in recent memory.

headline: Nalini Ambady, Psychologist of Intuition, Is Dead at 54
text: Nalini Ambady, a social psychologist whose research on the surprising accuracy of first impressions was popularized by Malcolm Gladwell in “Blink,” his best-selling nonfiction book of 2005, died on Oct. 28 in Boston. She was 54.

headline: For Uninsured, Clearing a Way to Enrollment
text: LA GRANGE, Ky. — Kelli Cauley’s fingers raced over her keyboard as she asked the anxious woman at her side a series of questions. What was her income? How many people lived in her household? Did she smoke? (“That’s the only health question it asks,” Ms. Cauley said of the application they were completing.)

headline: North Korean Sailors Reported Killed in October Sinking; South Says There Was No Clash
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A North Korean naval vessel sank last month, killing an unspecified number of sailors, according to North and South Korean news media.

headline: Eligible to Enroll
text: David Elson is among thousands of Kentuckians who are considering their options for health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Nets Full of Stars and Questions About Roles
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The most parroted word lately among Nets players and coaches has been “process.” It is a euphemism, really, that connotes the distinct growing pains the team is going through at the moment, trying to array its vast talent into winning combinations.

headline: Kentucky Is Ahead in Health Insurance Enrollment
text: The work of enrollment “navigators” in states like Kentucky shows how the federal exchange could work once its many technical problems are solved.

headline: Suspect Is Dead in New Jersey Mall Shooting
text: A man wearing black and carrying a rifle opened fire at a large northern New Jersey mall on Monday night, prompting hundreds of customers to seek cover and an extensive search for the suspect, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Pesticides Linked to Endometriosis Risk
text: Why some women and not others get endometriosis — the growth of uterine tissue outside the uterus that can cause pain and infertility — is not known, but researchers have come up with one possible contributing factor: pesticide poisoning.

headline: Q. and A. With Ron Duguay
text: Ron Duguay was selected 13th in the 1977 N.H.L. amateur draft by the Rangers. He became a fan favorite, not just for his hockey skills but for his cascading brown hair, active night life and commercial appearances.

headline: Manning Set to Face Motivated Raiders
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning was on a plane home to New Jersey on Sunday evening when Philadelphia’s Nick Foles was heaving touchdown pass after touchdown pass against the Oakland Raiders.

headline: Seattle’s Mayor Faces Challenge, Despite Signs of Success
text: SEATTLE — Mayor Mike McGinn seems like the kind of candidate this city would love. A former Sierra Club chapter leader and an avid cyclist, he bikes to work from his home in north Seattle. He has focused his campaign for a second term on issues voters care about here: climate change, transportation and reducing police brutality. And the economy is doing pretty well, with construction cranes whirring on the horizon and job numbers growing.

headline: Idzik Pleased With Performance of Ryan and Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — John Idzik committed a bit of a Freudian slip Monday while mentioning how many challenges Geno Smith has confronted during the last nine months — er, nine games.

headline: Senator Rand Paul Faces New Charges of Plagiarism
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who in recent weeks has had to explain how Wikipedia entries came to be incorporated into his speeches with no attribution, faced charges of direct plagiarism on Monday night.

headline: Mets Games Move to WOR-AM
text: The Mets formally announced that their radio games are moving to WOR-AM (710) in a five-year deal with the news and talk station’s owner, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment. The announcement did not say if Howie Rose, who has called Mets games since 1996, and Josh Lewin, who joined the Mets’ broadcast team in 2012, will be moving to WOR from WFAN, AM and FM, which had carried the games since 1987. In a statement, the Mets said: "Now that our agreement is official, WOR is in discussions regarding announcers.”

headline: Obama to Campaign to Ensure Health Law’s Success
text: WASHINGTON — On the fifth anniversary of his election, President Obama told a rally of grass-roots supporters on Monday evening that “I’ve got one more campaign in me” — to make sure his signature health care law works.

headline: The Bidding Is Sluggish at a Special Estate Sale
text: The highly anticipated fall auction season got off to a surprisingly gloomy start on Monday night at Christie’s, which held a special sale of paintings, drawings and sculptures from the estate of Jan Krugier, the Geneva-based dealer who died in 2008.

headline: The Decline of the Tea Party
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Helpouts From Google Connects People With Experts Over Live Video
text: A new product from Google, Helpouts, connects people with experts over video chat to give free or paid advice for tasks as varied as how to apply lipstick, how to treat a burn or how to speak Mandarin.

headline: Word of the Day | congeal
text: congeal •\kən-ˈjel\• verb

headline: Ducks Defeat Rangers Behind a Rookie’s 32 Saves
text: The Anaheim Ducks were concluding an eight-game trip, but the Rangers were the more lethargic squad Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) IN THE SPOTLIGHT WITH ROBIN ROBERTS: COUNTDOWN TO THE CMA AWARDS Ms. Roberts visits some of country music’s biggest stars at home in this lead-in to the Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday. The lineup features Jason Aldean (above with Ms. Roberts), who discusses fame, fortune and the tabloid headlines that he says contributed to the end of his marriage; Luke Bryan, who talks about two family tragedies that nearly broke him; Shania Twain, who ponders her battle with stage fright; and Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers, who reminisce about their hit “Islands in the Stream.”

headline: I Want to Be a Millennial When I Retire
text: My son Max is a 25-year-old singer and songwriter who goes by the moniker Dolfish. When my friends ask how his career is going, I say, “There’s a girl in Indiana with Dolfish tattooed on her arm,” although that doesn’t exactly answer their question.

headline: China’s Dynasties, in Song
text: The order of China’s dynasties can be a complicated puzzle for students of Chinese history. The Harvard professors William Kirby and Peter Bol offer this trick: a song that names the major dynasties, the Republic of China and the People’s Republic of China (or as the lyrics have it, “Mao Zedong”) to the tune of “Frère Jacques.”

headline: News Quiz | November 5, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Tweets From Inside N.J. Mall During Gunfire
text: Updated 9:05 a.m.Hundreds of police officers descended on the sprawling Garden State Plaza Mall in Paramus, N.J., Monday night after multiple shoppers reported a gunman with a long rifle fired shots inside the mall around 9:15 p.m. No one was reported injured, officials said.

headline: Home Buyers Feel Let Down by India’s Top Builders
text: Nitin Grover, a 33-year-old lawyer, has been dreaming of moving from his rented home to an apartment of his own. In 2008, Mr. Grover and his wife, who were paying monthly rent of 30,000 rupees, or nearly $500 at the current exchange rate, surveyed the real estate landscape around New Delhi, India’s capital. They decided to buy a place in Gurgaon, on the outskirts of the city.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 5, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Claim to Be
text: In the article “Herbal Supplements Are Often Not What They Seem,” Fares Akram and Jodi Rudoren report on a recent study that found widespread adulteration and mislabeling in the herbal supplement industry.

headline: Renault and Nissan Seek a Tie-Up With Mitsubishi
text: PARIS — Renault, the French automaker, and its Japanese alliance partner Nissan Motor, are exploring a possible tie-up with Mitsubishi Motors in a deal to include cooperation on electric vehicles, the companies said Tuesday.

headline: South Korean Government Seeks  Ban on Small Leftist Party
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The government of President Park Geun-hye asked the Constitutional Court of South Korea Tuesday to disband a small leftist party accused of supporting North Korea at the cost of the South’s national security.

headline: Outsource Your Way to Success
text: Jon Steinsson and Emi Nakamura do not have enough time to do everything they need to do. They’re recently tenured, highly productive rising stars at Columbia University, as well as parents to an infant. But they have a secret weapon helping them prioritize: Econ 101.

headline: At West Point: Duty, Honor, Gay Marriage
text: Daniel Lennox and Larry Choate III were wandering the aisles of a Walmart in Fort Benning, an Army post near Columbus, Ga.

headline: Does TV Capture the Diversity of America Yet?
text: “Saturday Night Live” does not have a black woman as a cast member, a fact that has become a hotly discussed issue. The debate raises a larger issue that seems to come up again and again: Is television too white?

headline: E.U. Predicts Anemic Growth and High Unemployment in 2014
text: BRUSSELS — A fragile recovery across the European Union is not expected to bear fruit until next year. And unemployment is likely to remain high in countries like Greece and Spain, and even rise in France, the Union’s head of economic policy warned Tuesday.

headline: Diplomats Fail to Agree on Details for Syria Peace Talks
text: GENEVA — Senior diplomats from the United States, Russia and the United Nations failed on Tuesday to agree on a date for convening a long-awaited peace conference aimed at settling the Syria conflict, acknowledging it would not take place this month and possibly not this year.

headline: German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art
text: It is almost certainly the biggest trove of missing 20th-century European art discovered since the end of World War II, and the first glimpse of it on Tuesday brought astonishment but also anger and the early stirrings of what will likely be a prolonged battle over who owns the works.

headline: New York Today: To the Polls
text: Updated 12:10 p.m. | It’s finally here — Election Day.

headline: It’s Election Day
text: Today is Election Day across the nation, as voters in many states go to the polls to choose local and state officials.

headline: Broccoli Gone Wild
text: Two weeks ago, while researching Michael Moss’s cover story about broccoli’s image problem, I learned about the Kitchen Community, a Colorado-based nonprofit that has put up, in low-income neighborhoods, billboards with simple recipes to encourage people to cook. Cool idea, except that the broccoli recipe struck me as wrong: “Olive oil & salt, 350° oven, 1 hour.” Broccoli is a favorite in my house. During the week, I boil the florets in two inches of water, drain and add butter and salt. Sometimes, if I’ve had enough sleep, I go wild and sauté it after parboiling — this adds char and brings out sweetness. My husband can steam it with scientific precision. None of these methods take an hour; maybe 15 minutes.

headline: Daily Report: In New York, Airbnb Offers Extra Income but Questionable Legality
text: Airbnb is a service adored by some, despised by others, and most commonly known as a place to rent out your apartment while you are out of town for a few days, Elizabeth A. Harris reports. But doing so is often illegal in New York City, one reason the company has locked horns with the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: United Nations Group Warns on Emissions
text: PARIS — Major polluters must immediately begin to reduce greenhouse gas emissions if the rise in global temperatures is to be held in check, or else a higher price will have to be paid later, according to a report released Tuesday by the United Nations Environment Program.

headline: U.S.-Saudi Relations
text: A tense meeting between Secretary of State John Kerry and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia.

headline: After Outside Pressure, Rebels in Congo Lay Down Their Arms
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — Col. Mamadou Moustafa stood at the front lines of the battle for eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, surveying his soldiers fighting to dislodge rebels from the surrounding hills.

headline: New Warnings for Old Problems
text: The latest revisions to The Times’s stylebook gave us an opportunity to take aim at some perennial usage problems, nagging missteps that are staples of After Deadline. We’ve added a handful of new warnings in hopes of cutting down on these repeat offenses.

headline: Where to Vote in the New York Region
text: The polls are now open throughout the New York region.

headline: On the Chinese Internet, Big Interest in Smog’s Threat to Fertility
text: How do you get online readers to click on a story about a long, official report about climate change? One answer, grabbed by editors of Chinese news sites Tuesday, was to play up a single line about a link between air pollution and fertility rates.

headline: Intersection: Fall Style in Boston
text: In Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood, residents are inspired by the change of seasons, old relationships and the Beastie Boys.

headline: Chiara de Blasio Style
text: Looking at how the daughter of New York City’s Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio and others have made the floral headband a part of their fashion.

headline: Pink Floyd’s ‘Comfortably Numb’ and Other Takes
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: An 8-Year-Old Girl’s Lung Cancer Is Blamed on Air Pollution
text: An 8-year-old girl in Jiangsu Province is the youngest person in China to have received a diagnosis of lung cancer, which a doctor treating her has attributed to air pollution, according to an official news report.

headline: Endo Health to Buy Specialty Drug Maker for $1.6 Billion
text: Endo Health Solutions, a health care company known for its pain medication, has reached a deal to acquire a Canadian specialty drug company, Paladin Labs, for $1.6 billion in stock and cash.

headline: In Performance: Patrick Page of ‘A Time to Kill’
text: In the courtroom drama “A Time to Kill,” a stage adaptation of the John Grisham novel, Patrick Page plays a Mississippi district attorney, prosecuting the case against black man who kills his daughter’s two white attackers. In this scene, he addresses the jury. The show, adapted by Rupert Holmes and directed by Ethan McSweeny, is on Broadway at the Golden Theater.

headline: An Alternative to the Family Business: The Family Bank
text: Lately, I’ve noticed that children of business owners seem less interested than previous generations in joining a family business. Of course, just because they do not want to work in a business with their parents does not mean they are not interested in business at all. And that has led some families who have the means to try a concept known as the family bank.

headline: AOL Revenue Rises 6% as Profit Plunges
text: AOL, the giant online portal turned media company, on Tuesday reported third-quarter revenue of $561 million, up 6 percent from a year earlier.

headline: The Changing Rules of Outing
text: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: In Kentucky, a Glimpse of Health Insurance Help
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. – Jennifer Albrecht lost her job after being given a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis last year – a turn of events that her husband, Hugh, described as feeling like “a building fell on us.” She stretches out her medicine because she cannot afford the refills, suffering worse flare-ups as a result. But last month, after seeking the help of a “kynector” – one of Kentucky’s counselors certified to help people sign up for insurance under the federal health care law – Ms. Albrecht found she qualified for Medicaid. Her coverage will take effect at the beginning of 2014.

headline: Spies R Us
text: WASHINGTON — A solid majority of Americans say it is “unacceptable for the United States to monitor the phones of allied leaders,” according to a recent poll by the Pew Research Center. But Israelis aren’t so fussed.

headline: Suicide Ends Long Night of Chaos Inside New Jersey Mall
text: A young man. A powerful weapon. And a crowded public space.

headline: European Telecom Giants in More Deals
text: Consolidation continued on Tuesday in Europe’s telecommunications industry, as the big players dispose of assets to refocus their strategies.

headline: The Making Of | Waldorf Astoria’s Eccentric New Ad Campaign, Starring Olga Kurylenko
text: “Don’t laugh at her!” The French photographer Bruno Dayan was shushing two young crew members who were snickering while his subject, the actress Olga Kurylenko, flapped her arms in an effort to stay upright. It wasn’t her maroon stilettos that were giving her trouble, it was her pose. For the main image in a new campaign for Waldorf Astoria Hotels & Resorts, Dayan had positioned Kurylenko, a Ukrainian-born beauty, in midstride in the lobby of the luxury hotel chain’s Chicago location. A bellhop, who had been yanked into the shot by Dayan from the curb outside, stood 20 feet behind her holding a luggage cart. To Kurylenko’s left stood a male model in a velvet dinner jacket whom she was supposed to “notice” as she breezed by. Kurylenko took two deep breaths and made eye contact with the model as Dayan’s flash started again. “Beautiful,” he barked. “No, no, no, relax your mouth. Not too sultry.”

headline: A Child’s Take on the Mayoral Election
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Detroit: A Race Overshadowed by Bankruptcy
text: As a trial scrutinizing America’s largest municipal bankruptcy enters its seventh day here, the fight over Detroit’s top elected office will be decided Tuesday when voters select the next mayor of this battered city in desperate need of a comeback.

headline: My Suicide Attempt and My Struggles to Get Help
text: “To the woman I love with my whole heart and soul: You are finally free of the terror I have caused in your life,” I wrote. “I am sorry for everything I have done to you. I deserve every bit of sorrow I feel.”

headline: During I.V.F., Keeping a Marriage Strong
text: My friend Rachel is undergoing treatment at the same in vitro fertilization clinic, so I often check in with her: to commiserate, compare notes, even meet up – either at our clinic uptown or downtown at the acupuncturist, where we both got pricked a few times a week to “warm our wombs.” And yet for all our similarities in treatment, there’s one difference between us: she’s single.

headline: A Slum Spends Sleepless Nights in Fear of Eviction
text: NEW DELHI – On the morning of March 24, 2011, several hundred police officers, accompanied by giant bulldozers, surrounded the slum of Gayatri Colony in west Delhi as part of an eviction drive by the Delhi Development Authority, which claims ownership of the colony’s land.

headline: Militants Kill 5 Police Officers in India
text: NEW DELHI — Militants killed five Indian police officers in a shootout in the forest near India’s border with Bangladesh on Tuesday, marking the second deadly episode in a week linked to the same armed group, known as the Garo National Liberation Army.

headline: New York: The Other Races on Your Ballot
text: The race for mayor of New York City has dominated headlines for months, but dozens of other contests will also take place during the general election on Tuesday. Click here to learn more about statewide ballot proposals and candidates for other New York City races, including borough president, district attorney and your local City Council seat.

headline: Greece Resumes Talks With Lenders Over Budget Gap
text: ATHENS — Government officials resumed talks with representatives of Greece’s foreign creditors on Tuesday amid a dispute over the size of a budget gap for next year and whether more austerity measures would be needed to cover it.

headline: The Gun Report: November 5, 2013
text: Guns are now allowed in public libraries in Seattle, thanks to a state supreme court ruling holding that cities have no right to ban guns in public places such as parks and libraries. The board of the library system said it did not have a choice but to remove its longstanding ban on firearms.

headline: 1963: First Woman in Space
text: “Hello Hawk, hello Hawk, this is Seagull”

headline: National Races We’re Watching Today
text: In Virginia, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the Republican candidate, and Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, are running for governor of a state that had once been a Republican stronghold. Mr. McAuliffe, who has been slightly ahead in the polls, was joined by President Obama at a rally on Sunday. And Mr. Cuccinelli has been winding down his campaign with a whirlwind of events, campaigning alongside a roster of Republican governors and presidential hopefuls.

headline: Lady Gaga Said to Fire Her Manager
text: Lady Gaga has fired her manager, Troy Carter, just days before the release of her new album, according to three people with direct knowledge of the news who were not authorized to speak about it.

headline: New York: Lhota Has Little to Say as He Casts Ballot
text: If voting for himself for mayor felt climactic for Joseph J. Lhota, he did not revel in the moment on Tuesday morning.

headline: Acer’s Chief Resigns Amid Slump in PC Sales
text: SEOUL — Acer, the Taiwanese computer maker, said Tuesday that its chief executive, J.T. Wang, had resigned, citing an inability to come to grips with a downturn in the PC business.

headline: Ford Pays a High Price for Plant Closing in Belgium
text: GENK, Belgium — Rumors of job cuts at the big Ford plant in this scruffy former coal mining town had been circulating for months. But on a clear morning a year ago, almost nobody in Genk expected what came next.

headline: Nominees Named for Clive Barnes Awards
text: The nominees for the fourth annual Clive Barnes Awards for young actors and dancers were announced Tuesday by the Clive Barnes Foundation, which was established in 2009 to administer the prize.

headline: 152 Bangladeshi Border Guards Get Death Penalty Over Revolt
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — In an apparently unprecedented ruling, 152 former members of the Bangladesh Rifles, a paramilitary border security force, were sentenced to death on Tuesday in connection with a bloody 2009 mutiny in which several thousand troops took control of their headquarters, demanding better working conditions, and killed scores of people.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Making of a Food Truck King
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: New York: For Bloomberg, a Last Vote as Mr. Mayor
text: When a man named Bloomberg, dressed in a crimson tie and a crisp winter coat, showed up to vote on Tuesday at Public School 6 on the Upper East Side, Jeris Coles, the poll worker assisting him, had a question. What was the mayor’s first name, again?

headline: Belgian Town Braces for Ford Exit
text: After battling unions and politicians, Ford has reached a settlement allowing it to close its factory in Genk, Belgium. The move comes at a high price for the company, its workers and the community.

headline: Feeling For | Furry Accessories for Winter
text: Take the chill off by layering on sumptuously shaggy gear that will keep you warm without sacrificing even a bit of cool.

headline: Paintings Discovered in Germany
text: Hundreds of forgotten art works were found hidden in a Munich apartment.

headline: In the N.F.L., Even the Strong Have Weaknesses
text: Who could have predicted that winless Tampa Bay would nearly upset Seattle? After nine weeks in the N.F.L., 25 teams have lost at least three games. The other seven teams, including the Seahawks, have significant strengths, but also weaknesses that they hope to hide.

headline: Free-Floating Inflation Hysteria
text: Brad DeLong has some fun with Senator Pat Roberts, who has gone from praising Janet Yellen in August to denouncing her as a dangerous inflationist now. So the senator is willing to say whatever the Tea Party wants him to say; big surprise.

headline: What Would Aldous Huxley Make of the Way We Consume Media and Popular Culture?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Jennifer Szalai on the prescience — or lack thereof — of the “Brave New World” author, who died 50 years ago this month.

headline: Worst. Conspirators. Ever.
text: From the FT, about the Murdoch phone-tapping affair:

headline: Image of the Day: November 5
text: India launched its first mission to Mars on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Democracy Gone Awry
In JetBlue Loyalty Program, Families Can Share Points
text: JetBlue Airways recently announced the latest addition to its TrueBlue loyalty program – family pooling. Families can now elect to earn and share points as a group, free of charge.

headline: ‘Don’t Tell Coach': Playing Through Concussions
text: Nausea, sensitivity to bright lights, headache: Chris Coyne knew right away that the helmet-to-helmet hit during football practice had given him a concussion. His fifth, in fact.

headline: For a Rich Fish, Red Wine Flatters
text: If you are going to treat a rich fish like tuna as if it were a steak, complete with a red-wine sauce, you’ll want to drink red wine, too. But not a red that’s heavy, oaky or tannic. I would look for a wine that will flatter the peppery spicing. This immediately suggests a Loire Valley red made with cabernet franc, like a Chinon, Bourgueil or Saumur-Champigny, either on the lighter, fresher side or well aged. Burgundy would be delicious, especially a lighter wine like a Marsannay or Santenay, or maybe an older Volnay.

headline: Bill De Blasio Votes With His Family
text: After voting in Park Slope, Bill De Blasio shared a story about how his daughter made a surprise visit on Election Day.

headline: New York: An Election Day Surprise for de Blasio
text: Bill de Blasio arrived almost an hour behind schedule at his polling place at a library in Park Slope, Brooklyn. But Mr. de Blasio, who recently admitted that he was not a morning person, said that he had not overslept. Instead, his daughter, Chiara, who had told him that she couldn’t make it back from college in California for Election Day because of tests, had surprised him by showing up at their house this morning, causing the delay.

headline: A New Design for Wireless Sound
text: Pity the poor audio speaker. So boxy and square.

headline: The Gin Goes Back Into the Barrel
text: John Little, the founder and master distiller of Smooth Ambler, a West Virginia microdistillery, fell into the aged-gin business by accident. Early in 2012 he had just distilled a batch of his standard gin when he realized he was out of bottles to put it in.

headline: End of the Assembly Line
text: Automotive plants in Europe that closed or ceased production this year, or whose closure has been announced.

headline: Musical America Names Audra McDonald Musician of the Year
text: The soprano and actress Audra McDonald, though better known for her theater and jazz performances than for her classical work these days, has been named musician of the year by Musical America, a classical music journal that was founded as a weekly newspaper in 1898 and now publishes an online magazine and an annual directory (in print and online) that lists performers, ensembles, music schools and management companies.

headline: New Jersey: Hometown Voting
text: Gov. Chris Christie, left, cast his vote in his hometown of Mendham, N.J., on Tuesday morning. His Democratic opponent for governor, Barbara Buono, voted in Metuchen, N.J., where she currently lives.

headline: Though Defiant, Senator Accused of Plagiarism Admits Errors
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky acknowledged Tuesday that “mistakes” in his office had caused unattributed writing by others to appear in his own work and announced that he was instituting safeguards to prevent such breaches from happening again.

headline: Boston: A New Mayor for the First Time in 20 Years
text: Election Day in Boston began briskly as voters went to the polls under sunny blue skies to elect a new mayor for the first time in two decades.

headline: New York: Crossover Votes Unlikely This Year
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Michael R. Bloomberg both ran for mayor as Republicans (Mr. Bloomberg later became an independent) and were elected mayor in large part thanks to the support of Democratic voters. Scholars at the City University of New York’s Center for Urban Research have analyzed the crossover Democratic vote, and suggest that this year’s pattern is likely to be very different. Their analysis is available here.

headline: Brazil's North Zones
text: The Frugal Traveler heads to the north sides of São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, where urban explorers can find affordable adventures.

headline: In Rio and São Paulo, Go North
text: It is a startlingly pleasant anomaly in the normally intimidating 11-million-person megacity of São Paulo. On a quaint square across from a tiny 112-year-old church, a bar called Frangó (frangobar.com.br) offers worn wooden tables in cozy nooks, an astonishing 500-label beer list and a celebrated version of the popular Brazilian chicken croquettes called coxinhas.

headline: Virginia: A Street Fight for Turnout
text: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor, just shrugged when one commuter declined to shake his hand at a Metro station. “Can’t get ’em all,” he said, more amused than disappointed.

headline: Palestinian Inmate With Cancer Dies in Israeli Hospital
text: GAZA — A Palestinian prisoner with cancer died in an Israeli hospital on Tuesday, prompting accusations of medical malpractice by Palestinian leaders.

headline: Mighty, Muslim and Leaping Off the Page
text: With most superheroes, when you take away the colorful costume, mask and cape, what you find underneath is a white man. But not always. In February, as part of a continuing effort to diversify its offerings, Marvel Comics will begin a series whose lead character, Kamala Khan, is a teenage Muslim girl living in Jersey City.

headline: Should Our Daughters Come to Our (Gay) Wedding?
text: One morning when I was making breakfast before school, my second-grade daughter, fresh off her school’s diversity unit on homosexuality, decided it was time I had a lesson in gay rights. First, she said, you should never use the word “gay” in a negative way, as in “That’s so gay!” Very interesting, I said, plotting to push a little deeper into this intriguing topic. So what is “gay,” I asked? Gay is when two boys like each other, and lesbian is when two girls like each other, she explained. Did she know anyone who was gay or lesbian, I asked? “I’m pretty sure I’m a lesbian because all my friends are girls,” she declared. Did she know anyone else? “Well, Larry only plays with boys, so he must be gay.” Anyone else? Nope.

headline: In Our Pages: November 6
text: 1938 Plot to Kill King of Siam Found

headline: Diane Paulus’s Cirque du Soleil Show Headed to New York
text: Cirque du Soleil has discovered that one way to wow New Yorkers — that is, beyond the company’s usual blend of daring acrobatics and high-gloss artistry — is to come to town with productions staged by major directors. Last year, Cirque brought “Totem,” staged at Citi Field by Robert Lepage, the Canadian director whose production of Wagner’s “Ring” at the Metropolitan Opera has been the subject of debate among opera aficionados in recent years, and who also directed “Ka,” the Cirque spectacular in which an acrobat fell to her death in June.

headline: New Rule, and Vacancy, for a Wall St. Regulator
text: Updated, 8:10 p.m. | Bart Chilton, the outspoken regulator whose colorful commentary on financial risk taking positioned him as a fierce critic of the industry he helped oversee, announced on Tuesday that he was leaving his post at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The move is the latest sign that Wall Street’s scrappiest regulatory agency is poised for a makeover.

headline: It’s Election Day. Why Is No One Panicking?
text: Election Day! A day for fresh starts and new directions, though probably not in New Jersey, which looks set to re-elect its Republican governor, Chris Christie, by an overwhelming margin over the Democrat, Barbara Buono. Just how overwhelming is the big question, and the answer may well affect how much Mr. Christie will intrude into the lives of non-Jersey Americans in the next presidential race.

headline: New York: Stop-and-Frisk Crosses into the Ballot Box
text: Just after 7 a.m. on Tuesday, Darrian Smith, 48, a custodian at Public School 150 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, was sweeping the grounds outside the school, which also serves as a polling place.

headline: On the Verge | In Portland, a New Shopping Center That’s So Portland It Hurts
text: An unexpected location in Portland, Ore., has evolved into a gleaming retail destination.

headline: ‘Listen to the Mockingbird’
text: The tune, so recognizable, was composed by an African-American street musician named Richard Milburn in 1855, about whom too little is known. The words were written by “Alice Hawthorne,” the nom de plume of a lyricist whose real name was Septimus Winner. (Why would anyone refuse to use such a name?)

headline: New York: As Expected, Not Very Many Voters at the Polls
text: By early Tuesday afternoon, election officials and both mayoral campaigns said turnout at the city’s 1,200 polling places was low to moderate, at most.

headline: Allen Edmonds Changes Private Equity Hands
text: The private equity firm Brentwood Associates has won the bidding war for the Allen Edmonds Corporation, the high-end men’s shoemaker, ending a sale process that included suitors like Men’s Wearhouse.

headline: Notes Reveal Chaotic White House Talks on Health Care Site
text: WASHINGTON — More than 100 pages of “war room notes” released by congressional investigators on Tuesday offer a window into the chaos that overwhelmed the Obama administration as the federal health insurance marketplace started up last month and officials realized that its problems could not be fixed quickly.

headline: Chris Chase, Actress Who Turned to Writing, Dies
text: Chris Chase, an actress, journalist, memoirist and co-author of autobiographical books about Rosalind Russell, Josephine Baker and Betty Ford, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

headline: Behind Those Fast Growth Rates, Rising Inequality
text: DAKAR, Senegal — It was his first post-election news conference, at a luxurious villa high above the Congo River, and the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo was in a combative mood. How dare the reporters question his country’s progress, he argued: just look at our sizzling growth rate — double, even triple, the rates of those pitiful laggards in the West.

headline: DirecTV Reports Gain in U.S. Subscribers
text: DirecTV surprised Wall Street on Tuesday by reporting a gain of 139,000 television subscribers in the United States in the third quarter of the year, a sharply higher rise than analysts had expected.

headline: Proposed Rule Limits Size of Commodities Traders’ Positions
text: In 1979, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Hunt famously bought up as much silver as they could in the commodities market. By the time they were done, the brothers had acquired more than a third of the world’s supply of silver, sending the price of the precious metal soaring.

headline: Idaho Town Struggles After Pinning Hopes on a Failed Factory
text: POCATELLO, Idaho — With great fanfare, a Chinese polysilicon factory broke ground on 67 acres here in 2007. Then, as the rest of the nation tumbled into recession, the plant rose up in shimmering promise, leaving this tough-edged railroad town — blue collar and union in a sea of southeast Idaho potato farms — feeling pretty good about the future.

headline: Detroit: Challenges Loom for Next Mayor
text: A federal bankruptcy judge will have final say over this city’s financial overhaul. A state-appointed emergency manager has run this City Hall for months and may not leave anytime soon. The current mayor, Dave Bing, would not seek another term, criticizing a “supposed partnership” with state officials that has left him powerless and perturbed.

headline: Election Day in New York City
text: New Yorkers cast their vote for a new mayor.

headline: In Mideast, Kerry Tries to Nudge Peace Talks Along
text: JERUSALEM — With Middle East peace negotiations showing signs of lapsing into an all-too-familiar paralysis, Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here Tuesday night for a flurry of meetings aimed at jolting the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to reinvigorate the three-month-old round of talks.

headline: A Website Concludes Its Users Need More Hand-Holding
text: In my most recent post, we were challenged to simplify a fairly complex online value proposition. Bid4Spots allows advertising clients to “reverse bid” for radio airtime. When the site was introduced, the company believed that customers would fully commit to the auction online without human interaction. Over time, however, it realized that it was going to be necessary to have Bid4Spots representatives walk clients through the process.

headline: Buttercream Frosting
text: Melissa Clark gets help from her daughter Dahlia to make a delicious and fluffy cake topping.

headline: New Italian Sculptures Will Have a Park View
text: A pair of 13-foot-high statues — one in marble and the other in polished stainless steel — by the architect and designer Antonio Pio Saracino are coming to a public plaza in Manhattan.

headline: Boston: Deciding on a New Mayor and a Casino
text: At lunch time on Election Day, there were more volunteers than voters clustered at a high school in East Boston, where voters had gone to pick the city’s first new mayor in 20 years and to decide whether to approve a referendum that could reshape this faded neighborhood by allowing a new casino there.

headline: A Party Is Icing on the Cake
text: Here’s a peek behind the scenes: we shot this video on my actual birthday. And this is the cake I have been making over the last several years to celebrate. It’s a rich almond birthday cake frosted with buttercream.

headline: Wheelies: The Pickup Slowdown Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

headline: Even Elected Officials Have Trouble Voting in Texas
text: When Republican lawmakers began making it harder to vote by passing voter ID laws, their target was not white politicians.

headline: With TiVo, More Features for TV Lovers
text: TiVo knows what television lovers want.

headline: Lael Brainard to Step Down From Treasury Post
text: WASHINGTON — Lael Brainard, the country’s top financial diplomat, is leaving her post at the end of the week, a Treasury official said. Some have speculated that the White House might choose her for a position on the Federal Reserve’s board of governors.

headline: She Snoozes, but Wins
text: What’s the most memorable moment in “Sleeping Beauty”? When Princess Aurora encounters the fateful spindle, or when the prince awakens her with a kiss?

headline: ‘I Have Smoked Crack Cocaine,’ Toronto’s Mayor Admits on Camera
text: Last Updated, 5:34 p.m. | After dodging questions for months about video evidence said to show him using drugs, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto stunned constituents and his own staff on Tuesday by telling a scrum of reporters, “Yes, I have smoked crack cocaine.”

headline: A Congolese Rebellion Routed, a Photographer’s Work Continues
text: The column of soldiers marched uphill single file, slowly but deliberately making its way to the town of Bunagana, on the border between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda. Pete Muller trekked alongside them to photograph the moment when Congolese soldiers liberated the town from the control of the M23 rebel group, part of a rapid advance by government forces that pushed the group out of areas it held in its year-and-a-half long insurrection.

headline: Taking a Better Selfie With an Audiovox App
text: It appears that selfies — those self-portraits of you and your arm — are here to stay, even gaining mention in the Oxford Dictionaries.

headline: New York: In the Running
text: A major element of The Times’s reporting on the mayoral race was the long-form, biographical series called “In the Running,” which examined the lives and careers of the leading candidates, with detail and perspective. The series was intended to offer a picture of the candidates behind the scenes, how they thought and how they acted in high-pressure situations. Here is a catalog of these articles. Check them out — they offer a unique look back at the campaign and some insight into the next administration.

headline: New York: Sunshine at the Polls
text: Mary Hennessey, left, and Joan Forhane, both election employees, shield their faces from the sun while waiting for voters at Public School 234 in Queens on Tuesday.

headline: Road to Morocco Stops in Yonkers
text: YONKERS — It is sometimes said that if you go to the makeshift Jewish museum in the medina of Fez, Morocco, and quietly ask the custodian there if he has any mahia, you might get lucky. Then again, you could simply turn to a married couple in downtown Yonkers.

headline: On Staten Island, Wilderness With Creature Comforts
text: It’s not surprising that the 19th-century transcendentalists were attracted to Emerson Hill on Staten Island: The neighborhood still has a measure of the natural beauty of the wilderness that first attracted those poets and philosophers.

headline: Iranian Minister Says Nuclear Deal Is Possible This Week
text: PARIS — Two days before negotiations resume in Geneva between Iran and the United States and other Western powers aimed at ending a fight over the disputed Iranian nuclear program, the country’s foreign minister sounded an optimistic note on Tuesday, saying a deal was possible as soon as this week.

headline: Toronto Mayor Admits Crack Use, as Wild Ride in Office Continues
text: TORONTO — He has been thrown out of a Toronto Maple Leafs hockey game for being drunk and belligerent. He groped a female politician at a fund-raiser for a Jewish community group, and was asked to stop coaching a high school football team after having a violent confrontation with one of the players. He has admitted to drinking too much.

headline: New York Sees Light Turnout After Lopsided Mayoral Polls
text: New York City voters headed to the polls on Tuesday to decide whether they would put a Democrat back in control of the nation’s largest city for the first time in two decades.

headline: Mayor of Toronto Admits to Drug Use
text: Mayor Rob Ford said he smoked crack cocaine when he was in a "drunken stupor" last year.

headline: Going
text: By Sam Phillips

headline: Pretty Time Bomb
text: By Sam Phillips

headline: Tavis Smiley to Write Book on Martin Luther King Jr.’s Final Days
text: The television and radio host Tavis Smiley will write a book about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Smiley’s publisher said, exploring the attacks on Dr. King’s “character, ideology, and political tactics and how they shaped both the year leading up to his death in 1968 and his lasting legacy.”

headline: The Art of the Prosthesis
text: The people who ask Sophie de Oliveira Barata to make their prosthetic limbs — Nadav Kander photographed several of them for this past weekend’s health issue — want hands and legs that are not only functional but also personally expressive in some way. She produces her bespoke creations, like the snake-arm seen above, out of her London-based Alternative Limb Project. The pictures made us curious to know more about de Oliveira Barata’s enterprise, so she sent us some interesting facts about her work making prostheses:

headline: The Tax Motive in Endo Health’s Deal
text: Greed is seeping into the art of mergers and acquisitions. Endo Health Solutions is the latest buyer to receive a warm welcome for a sensible acquisition with notable savings. Its market value jumped almost as much as the $1.6 billion price of its purchase, Paladin Labs. But the deal also involves a huge tax dodge, and investors aren’t factoring in enough risk.

headline: Look-Alikes Top the B.C.S. Standings
text: Alabama and Florida State, which both remain undefeated and are Nos. 1 and 2 in this week’s Bowl Championship Series standings, are look-alikes, right down to the shades of red in their jerseys, one crimson, the other garnet.

headline: At the Polls
text: Voters cast their ballots in races across the country.

headline: Colorado: Drive-Through Voting in Denver
text: Madeline Doak, a volunteer student election judge, collects ballots at a drive-up ballot drop-off station in Denver. Colorado voters will decide whether to increase taxes to raise $1 billion in exchange for more school funding and an educator’s wish-list of measures.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 10: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
text: Socrates said: “The more you learn, the more you realize how little you know.” That saying held true this past week more so than usual, leading to another abnormal scoring leader list that included the likes of Nick Foles, Jerricho Cotchery, Jason Campbell and the previously thought to be missing Tom Brady.

headline: Chevron and Ukraine Set Shale Gas Deal
text: LONDON — Western oil companies trying to find shale gas in Europe are discovering that Ukraine, eager to reduce its dependence on Russian energy imports, is one of their most willing partners.

text: Headliner

headline: Rachel Roy’s Beauty Regimen for Two Coasts
text: Unlike many clothing designers, Rachel Roy, 39, lives in New York and Los Angeles, whose different climates pose skin-care challenges. But her beauty routine is fairly consistent. BEE SHAPIRO

headline: Rand Paul’s Plagiarism
text: The story so far, told (almost) entirely in other people’s words. Brackets indicate original thinking. Click the links for attribution.

headline: Tasting Tokyo With a Chef’s Notes
text: As much as David Kinch, the chef and owner of the restaurant Manresa in Los Gatos, Calif., uses local ingredients like abalone and nasturtium petals in his kitchen and features them in his new cookbook, “Manresa: An Edible Reflection,” it would be misleading to say the Bay Area is his only muse.

headline: Restaurant Report: Cúrate in Asheville, N.C.
text: On paper, the recipe for Cúrate, a traditional Spanish tapas restaurant that opened in 2011 in downtown Asheville, seems to lack some requisite ingredients. First, the chef and co-owner Katie Button isn’t Spanish. Then there’s the fact that just six years ago she was a budding scientist, not a restaurateur. Finally, real Spanish food is an anomaly in this part of the country, where farm-to-table Americana is firmly rooted.

headline: New York: Awaiting a Democrat’s Return
text: On the Upper East Side, some voters were jubilant at the prospect of sending a Democrat to City Hall after two decades — even if they had mixed feelings about the candidate.

headline: Prince Charles May Have Unfair Tax Edge, Report Says
text: LONDON — Royal households have historically been better at collecting tax than paying it. Prince Charles is about to find that out.

headline: Karley Sciortino: In Her Own Voice
text: AGE 28

headline: A Taste of the Wild
text: Stripping cooking to its raw elements in South Carolina: foraging, hunting, fishing and farming.

headline: Swamp to Table
text: HARDEEVILLE, S.C. — “I am sitting in the most amazing puddle of mire,” Matt Jennings, the chef at Farmstead in Providence, R.I., announced into the dark from his perch atop a 12-foot-high hunting blind.

headline: Federal Charges in Port Chester Police Dept. Feud
text: A caustic feud in Westchester County between a village’s longtime police chief on medical leave and the acting chief reached a climax recently with some physical and verbal threats and resulted in a federal witness-tampering complaint against the longtime chief that carries the possibility of a 20-year sentence.

headline: J Mays, Noted Ford Designer, to Retire
text: Ford Motor announced Tuesday that J Mays, who has directed the automaker’s designs for 16 years and is group vice president and chief creative officer, would retire in January. Succeeding Mr. Mays, 59, will be Moray Callum, 54, who has been responsible for the design of Ford’s cars in the Americas since 2006 and will assume the title of vice president of design.

headline: Virginia: Marking a Broken Voting Machine
text: A broken voting machine, left, was marked with tape at a polling station in Rosslyn, Va., on Tuesday.

headline: Syrian Children Draw What Used to be Home
text: After enduring two and a half years of the grueling brutality that defines Syria, the fall of Assad’s regime is no longer the most pressing concern of most Syrians. Rather, “When will we return home?” is the question that haunts the over seven million displaced Syrians. Of course, the fact that the first concern is the reason the second one exists adds to the country’s mass despair.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Brooks Brothers Cashmere Scarf
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Quality Italian
text: Inside the Midtown restaurant that seems to have figured out that some people would rather eat in a theater than a church.

headline: Domestic Dispute Leads to Test of Federal Power
text: WASHINGTON — A lurid domestic dispute provided the unlikely backdrop for a major test of federal power on Tuesday at the Supreme Court, one a government lawyer said could affect the eradication of chemical weapons in Syria.

headline: The Hardy Folks Who Found Gold in Shale
text: The history of oil and natural gas extraction has largely been the story of men with long straws, as Daniel Day-Lewis memorably demonstrated in “There Will Be Blood,” trying to drink one another’s milkshakes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, Yemen and the West Bank.

headline: New York: Hugs and Handshakes in Crown Heights
text: Outside a subway station in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, this afternoon, Bill de Blasio hugged and kissed women, shook men’s hands, and bent from his 6-foot-5-inch height to greet small children and ask their ages.

headline: Where the Trolleys Still Run in New York
text: The steak will be here in a minute. First, the show.

headline: The Pulitzer Prize Was Nice and All, but a Work Is Finally Fully Heard
text: You might assume that any music piece that wins the Pulitzer Prize would already have had its premiere. Not necessarily, as indicated by the inspiring story of Caroline Shaw’s “Partita for Eight Voices,” an exhilarating, sensual and playful work.

headline: Parts of a Pretzel Empire Are for Sale in Amish Country
text: GAP, Pa. — Since 1988, philanthropy and a highly successful brand of soft pretzel have combined to provide marriage counseling and other family services to this community in Lancaster County, some 55 miles west of Philadelphia.

headline: Swan Song Too Hawkish for Some
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Wind Rises” is the type of art film that typically speeds into the Oscar race. Critics at film festivals have swooned over its nuance. It delivers messages about turbulent modern times by examining traumatic events of the past. The film’s 72-year-old director and writer, Hayao Miyazaki, a cinematic giant, has said the ambitious animated picture will be his last, a final bow.

headline: Profits at 21st Century Fox Hampered by TV Investments
text: Investments in new cable channels were a drag on 21st Century Fox’s third-quarter profits, but total revenues still surpassed analysts’ expectations.

headline: Putting Up With Evil, Then Getting a Princely Hand
text: PHOENIX — Few careers in ballet have shown a more remarkable trajectory than that of Ib Andersen. I remember him in 1979 in Copenhagen as a young star of the Royal Danish Ballet (he had been the youngest principal in its history), shining in several of the mid-19th-century classics by the Danish master August Bournonville. A year later Mr. Andersen was a principal of New York City Ballet, where he created roles in new ballets by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins.

headline: Blooming, Languishing, Reviving
text: Most of the guys are in their 50s now, and 50 isn’t old for rock stars anymore. But most rock stars have not messed things up as thoroughly as the Stone Roses did roughly 20 years ago. One minute their debut album was being acclaimed as among the greatest ever; the next they were embroiled in a legal battle that delayed their follow-up album for five years. It flopped, and the group broke up.

headline: Philip Smith, Philharmonic’s Principal Trumpet, to Retire
text: Philip Smith, the New York Philharmonic’s principal trumpet, announced on Tuesday that he would retire from the orchestra at the end of the 2013-14 season. He will have been a member of the orchestra for 36 years: he joined as co-principal trumpet in 1978, when Zubin Mehta, then the orchestra’s music director, hired him away from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. He became the orchestra’s principal trumpet in 1988.

headline: The Making of an Immortal Movie
text: In 1967, George Romero, a Bronx-born 27-year-old transplanted to Pittsburgh, shot a cheap independent movie in rural Pennsylvania. The film, “Night of the Living Dead,” became a horror classic, spawning sequels and helping to inspire the vogue for zombies raging on television and in multiplexes. Rob Kuhns’s informative documentary “Birth of the Living Dead” recounts the risks, improvisation and innovation that went into the movie’s production.

headline: Alabama: Small Race Reflects G.O.P. Divide
text: The city of Atmore in southwestern Alabama typically takes a turn in the national spotlight when an inmate is executed at the state prison there.

headline: N.J. Exit Poll: Economy Weighs Heavily on Voters
text: According to early results from exit polls conducted by Edison Research, the issue that mattered most to voters in the New Jersey race for governor was the economy, with half of all voters selecting it as the key issue for them. The economy was followed by taxes, which was selected by one out of every four voters.

headline: Romantic Comedy: Imbibe in Moderation
text: In Kat Coiro’s new film, “A Case of You,” the mildly neurotic Sam (Justin Long) is a struggling writer in Brooklyn making a living from movie novelizations, but he has a Serious Book inside him. Shamed for his bachelor status by his happily married and pregnant former classmate (Sienna Miller), Sam woos the mildly daffy coffeehouse clerk Birdie (Evan Rachel Wood, in a departure from her darker portraits), who is also a caricature artist in Prospect Park. To impress her, he studies her Facebook page and awkwardly pretends to share her interests, including cooking, Joan Baez, the guitar, Carlos Castaneda and ballroom dancing.

headline: Va. Exit Poll: Mixed on Candidates, Sour on Economy
text: In the tight Virginia governor’s race, exit polls found voters giving the candidates equal marks on ethics.

headline: Meadham Kirchhoff’s Rule-Breaking Topshop Collection
text: Fresh off a triumphant ready-to-wear presentation this spring — a typically demented, dazzling mash-up of Charles Addams and Leigh Bowery — the London-based fashion label Meadham Kirchhoff has put together a witty new collection for Topshop, which includes everything from a pair of glittery ruby platforms with marshmallow heels to frilly baby-doll dresses and mohair jumpers. It’s another spirited line from a design team that is determined to break the rules. “The industry has become dictatorial,” Edward Meadham says. “All we ask is that we can show our clothes exactly how we want to, exactly how it comes out of us. What people make of it after that is up to them.” Available Nov. 21.

headline: Eminem Grows Older, but Not Up
text: We have watched Eminem age, all of us, difficult as it has been. We’ve seen him lash out at his mother, his then-wife, and his fans. We’ve seen him soften ever so slightly under the weight of fatherhood. We’ve seen him court protest, then express befuddlement over the hubbub. We’ve seen him retreat into drugs, and then climb out of the morass.

headline: A Fantastical Shootout, Moving Across Space and Time
text: With a story ripped not from the headlines but seemingly from a strategy guide for the Parker Brothers board game Risk — control of a unified South America is the best possible starting point for global military domination — Call of Duty: Ghosts is the silliest entry in an increasingly silly series, even as it remains quite possibly the most lucrative one in video games.

headline: N.Y. Exit Poll: Ready for Change
text: New York City residents went to the polls today with contrary views of the current administration. While they approve of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s performance, they are also looking for a change from his policies.

headline: Main Street Advocacy Advertisement
text: Main Street Advocacy, a moderate Republican group, is planning to defend candidates it views as more electable in Republican primaries against more conservative organizations.

headline: Illinois Sends Bill Allowing Gay Marriage to Governor
text: The Illinois House of Representatives voted Tuesday to allow same-sex couples to wed, ending months of delay over the issue in the Capitol and clearing the way for Illinois to become the 15th state, along with the District of Columbia, to permit gay couples to marry.

headline: LG Shows Off the Bend in Its Flex
text: SEOUL, South Korea — LG Electronics of South Korea took the wraps off its new curved smartphone, the G Flex, on Tuesday, showing off the device at a gathering of mostly Korean journalists at its headquarters here.

headline: N.J. Exit Poll: Problems for G.O.P., Support for Gay Marriage
text: Compared to the last time they voted for governor, New Jersey voters are less approving of Barack Obama’s performance as president, an exit poll conducted on Tuesday by Edison Research showed. In 2009, 57 percent approved of how Mr. Obama was handling his job; this year a bare majority approve.

text: Banksy! is still in police custody — that is, the balloons that spell the British street artist’s name, as well as an exclamation point, are. And they may never get out.

text: Because school districts are mostly funded locally, through property taxes, there are enormous disparities between states in the amount of resources available to public schools.

text: “There aren’t many things that are more important to that idea of economic mobility — the idea that you can make it if you try — than a good education,” President Obama told students at the State University of New York in Buffalo in August.

headline: Deceased Wife’s Foresight Helps Man Make Progress
text: The year: 1990. The place: Canóvanas, Puerto Rico. Anita Villalongo was a Puerto Rican, with dramatic cheekbones and skin the color of caramel. Eugenio German was a Dominican, the irises of his eyes chocolate brown rimmed by a deep ocean blue. Eugenio sold ice cream from a pushcart. Anita left her building each day to buy a cone.

headline: Live Nation Reports Lower Profits on Higher Revenue
text: Live Nation Entertainment, the concert industry giant that includes Ticketmaster, reported lower profits for its third quarter, but higher revenue as attendance to its concerts and festivals grew around the world.

headline: Charlie Trotter Dies at 54; Chef Made Chicago a Must

headline: Macy’s Splurges on a Makeover on 34th Street

headline: Oversight of Parade Faulted in Fatal Texas Train Collision

headline: New Student Loan Rules Add Protections for Borrowers
text: If you are a former student having trouble paying back college debt, you may be relieved to hear that the Education Department has created new rules that will bolster borrower protections for federal education loans.

headline: Chris Christie Coasts to 2nd Term as Governor of New Jersey
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey won re-election by a crushing margin on Tuesday, a victory that vaulted him to the front ranks of Republican presidential contenders and made him his party’s foremost proponent of pragmatism over ideology.

headline: Chris Christie Re-elected Governor of New Jersey
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey won re-election by a crushing margin on Tuesday, a victory that vaulted him to the front of the pack of Republican presidential contenders and made him his party’s foremost proponent of pragmatism over ideology.

headline: N.J. Exit Poll: Christie Gained Among Key Groups

headline: Nicholas S. G. Stern
text: Mr. Stern, 45, is the founder and principal of Stern Projects, a boutique construction management company focused largely on high-end residential projects in Manhattan. Before starting the company in 2010, he served as an executive vice president of Taconic Builders.

headline: Bloomberg, Champion of the Poor
text: DURING New York City’s mayoral race, criticism of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for neglecting the poor ignored his bold and unprecedented antipoverty measures. He may not have eliminated inequality or reversed the impact of the Great Recession — over the last two years, the poverty rate has crept up to 21.2 percent from 20.1 percent — but failure to acknowledge what he did in fact accomplish is not only unfair but also shortsighted. Usually depicted as a champion of the rich, Mr. Bloomberg mounted an antipoverty program at a moment when poverty as an issue was off the national radar and even politically toxic.

headline: Toronto’s Hot Mess
text: TORONTO — JUST the other day, a definitive Toronto image was making the rounds on Twitter. One of the turnstiles in the subway system had broken and no guards were around, so passengers had left their tickets and change in a small pile on the side. I live in an absurdly law-abiding, rule-following city. There’s one major exception: the mayor. He smokes crack. He said so on Tuesday. Twice.

headline: In a Message to Poachers, U.S. Will Destroy Its Ivory
text: WASHINGTON — The United States Fish and Wildlife Service will destroy six tons of illegal African elephant ivory next week that it has been stockpiling since the ’80s, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Va. Exit Poll: Many Find Republican ‘Too Conservative’
text: In the Virginia governor’s pitting Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, a Republican, against Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, voters on balance said that Mr. Cuccinelli’s positions on the issues were “too conservative,” while Mr. McAuliffe’s were “about right.”

headline: On Becoming China’s Farm Team
text: Look at the $4.7 billion purchase in September of the pork producer Smithfield Foods by Shuanghui International Holdings Ltd. -- the Chinese firm that counts Goldman Sachs among its backers -- from the standpoint of the Chinese. As this century’s economic titan, they had to “take a position” in United States pork. China’s population of nearly 1.4 billion is not only growing rapidly but growing wealthier rapidly, and flattering us by emulating our consumption patterns (for better or worse) while having trouble replicating some of our production systems.

headline: Too Big to Breathe?
text: SHANGHAI — I arrived here on Oct. 19th and was greeted with this news: A combination of cold weather, lack of wind, coal-powered heating and farmers burning off post-harvest debris had created a perfect storm of pollution in the northeastern industrial city of Harbin, home to 10 million people. It was so bad that bus drivers were getting lost because the smog-enveloped roads would only permit them to see a few yards ahead. Harbin’s official website reportedly warned that “cars with headlights turned on were moving no faster than pedestrians and honking frequently as drivers struggled to see traffic lights meters away.”

headline: Obama Presses Case for Immigration Changes
text: In a meeting at the White House, President Obama urged a group of business leaders to press the House of Representatives to pass broad immigration legislation. The leaders included Joe Echevarria, chief executive of Deloitte LLP; Marillyn A. Hewson, chief executive of Lockheed Martin; Stephen A. Schwarzman, chairman of Blackstone, and several others who had not previously played such prominent roles in supporting an immigration overhaul.

headline: A Vote Goes Against Outsize Executive Pay, but It’s Hardly a Blow
text: If you’re against high executive pay, don’t cheer because Oracle’s shareholders overwhelmingly rejected Lawrence J. Ellison’s $78.4 million pay package.

headline: CBS News Defends Its ‘60 Minutes’ Benghazi Report
text: CBS News, under fire from critics who dispute details in a “60 Minutes” report on the Benghazi attacks last year that was broadcast on Oct. 27, aggressively defended the report’s accuracy on Tuesday and the account of its main interview subject.

headline: Approving, and Suspending, a Dangerous Drug
text: The Food and Drug Administration made the appropriate call last week when it suspended sales of a promising leukemia drug for desperately ill patients that turned out to be unexpectedly dangerous. About 2,000 people have taken the drug to treat a relatively uncommon form of leukemia that kills about 600 Americans each year.

headline: New York Town Divided as Prayer Case Heads to Supreme Court
text: GREECE, N.Y. — The most recent meeting of the Town Board here had typical local fare: a new sidewalk proposal, permitting issues and a failed attempt to get a bid on some surplus soil.

headline: Remember the Second Responders
text: Nobody knows what kind of large-scale disaster will next hit the New York City region, but you can be sure that after the initial chaos will come the mess. And as Hurricane Sandy taught us, some of the hardest and most dangerous jobs fell not to first responders — cops, firefighters or utility crews — but to homeowners and small contractors left to improvise the cleanup and demolition and to the thousands of day laborers who joined them.

headline: China’s Leaders Confront Economic Fissures
text: WUHAN, China — The two-story employment complex here, like job centers across China, is crowded with educated young people who are trying to figure out their futures in a country where the job market still prizes assembly-line workers willing to labor monotonous hours on backless stools.

headline: A Pacific Trade Deal
text: Officials from the United States and 11 other countries bordering the Pacific are trying to complete a trade agreement by the end of the year that could help all of our economies and strengthen relations between the United States and several important Asian allies. But hard bargaining lies ahead.

headline: Tato Laviera, 63, Poet of Nuyorican School
text: Tato Laviera lost his sight, but not his vision. His acclaimed poems and plays captured the rhythms and language of Puerto Rico and the Lower East Side — his twin loves — with equal measures of protest, playfulness and hope.

headline: MF Global Customers Will Recover All They Lost
text: Two years after $1.6 billion vanished from their accounts, MF Global’s customers are now all but assured to collect every last penny.

But the allegations involving bullying on Philbin’s team raise many nuanced questions about how much control N.F.L. coaches have over their players and their behavior.

text: In striking its $1.2 billion settlement with SAC Capital Advisors, the government set a record for insider trading penalties. For the hedge fund industry, the hidden costs of the deal are even bigger.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 5, 2013

Republicans, locked into the iron suit of austerity, refuse to consider any spending that might stimulate economic growth.

headline: China: Envoy Sent to North Korea to Push for Talks

A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the envoy, Wu Dawei, arrived in Pyongyang on Monday amid signs that tensions on the peninsula had begun to ease. China was one of the backers of the so-called six-party talks that began in 2003 to work toward a solution of the nuclear issue. The talks broke down in 2008.

headline: Some Options for Granderson and the Yankees
text: If Curtis Granderson accepts the Yankees qualifying offer of $14.1 million the Yankees outfield for next season would be set, unless they turn around and trade him in the off-season. If Granderson turns down the offer, the Yankees get a draft pick and they can pursue a free agent outfielder like Shin-Soo Choo or Carlos Beltran to replace him.

headline: Editta Sherman Dies at 101

headline: Editta Sherman, Celebrity Portraitist and Doyenne of Carnegie Hall Studios, Dies at 101
text: Editta Sherman, a free-spirited photographer who made portraits of celebrities, raised four children and lived for 61 years in an artist’s paradise — a studio penthouse above Carnegie Hall — until forced out in 2010 in an epic landlord-tenant struggle, died on Friday at her Manhattan home on Central Park South, only blocks from the hall. She was 101.

Cuccinelli II, and confirming Virginia’s evolution as a state increasingly dominated politically by the Democratic-leaning Washington suburbs.

headline: Doug Ireland, an Acerbic Activist and Left-Wing Writer, Is Dead at 67
text: Doug Ireland, a fiercely articulate left-wing activist, journalist and blogger who managed the successful congressional campaigns of the liberal candidates Allard K. Lowenstein and Bella S. Abzug (as well as Ms. Abzug’s unsuccessful campaign for the Senate) and wrote with acerbic force about politics, the media and gay issues, died on Oct. 26 in his home on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: Ultramarathon Runner Embraces Physical and Mental Challenge

headline: Afghan Militant Group Faces Unusual Discontent
text: KHOST, Afghanistan — For more than a generation, the remote mountains of Khost and Paktia in eastern Afghanistan have been Haqqani country.

text: BOSTON — Martin J. Walsh, who grew up as the son of Irish immigrants in a triple-decker in Dorchester, will be the next mayor of Boston.

headline: Argentina Finds a Dictatorship’s Secret Records
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s government has found a trove of secret documents from the military dictatorship, which held power from 1976 to 1983. The discovery provides rare insight into the persecution of intellectual figures and efforts then to deal with inquiries into human rights abuses during the Dirty War, when as many as 30,000 people are thought to have been killed or disappeared.

headline: Colorado Rejects Move for Schools as Casino Fails in Massachusetts
text: DENVER — Colorado voters on Tuesday rejected one of the most sweeping school-financing measures in the nation this year, according to The Associated Press, deciding that the promise of smaller class sizes, full-day kindergarten and smarter education spending was not worth the price of a tax increase.

headline: Lhota Concedes Defeat
text: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor of New York City, offered congratulations and caution to Bill de Blasio.

headline: Canada: 3 Senators Suspended in Expenses Scandal
text: The Senate voted Tuesday to suspend without pay three senators at the center of an expenses scandal. The three, Mike Duffy, Pamela Wallin and Patrick Brazeau, were appointed by Prime Minister Stephen Harper. Mr. Harper’s chief of staff was found to have reimbursed Mr. Duffy for $90,000 in improper expenses.

headline: Nets’ Pride Restored as Consistency Is Rediscovered
text: The Nets last weekend had an emotional whiplash that stung their pride. They were puffing their chests late Friday night, celebrating a scintillating victory over the defending champion Miami Heat. Forty-eight hours later, they slunk onto their team plane after a blowout loss to the Orlando Magic, an untried team.

headline: Higher Wage Is Approved in New Jersey
text: Some employers in New Jersey, like Joseph Olivo, did not wait for the results of the vote on Tuesday to start preparing for the state’s minimum wage to rise by $1 an hour next year.

headline: Indian Craft Is Lofted Toward Mars, Trailed by Pride and Questions
text: NEW DELHI — India lofted a Mars-bound spacecraft into Earth’s orbit on Tuesday, a major step in its hopes to become the first country in Asia to reach Mars.

headline: New Jersey: Voters Pass a Higher Minimum Wage
text: Some employers in New Jersey, like Joseph Olivo, did not wait for the results of the vote on Tuesday to start preparing for the state’s minimum wage to rise by $1 an hour next year.

headline: Alabama: Byrne Wins G.O.P. Primary, The A.P. Projects
text: A Republican primary runoff in Alabama that became an example of the internal battle between the establishment and the populist wings of the party ended with a victory Tuesday night for Bradley Byrne. He defeated Dean Young, the Tea Party-backed candidate, according to The Associated Press.

headline: When Injury Takes Chandler Out, the Knicks Come Undone
text: Amid an uneven start to the season for the Knicks, Tyson Chandler had been a source of stability. As Coach Mike Woodson sought to unearth some semblance of consistency from the rest of his lineup, Chandler was as dependable as a roll of paper towels: no frills, but effective.

headline: New York: De Blasio’s Victory Speech
text: Here are excerpts from Bill de Blasio’s victory speech at the Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn.

headline: Keeping Black Voters in Their Place
text: The Republicans who now control the legislatures and governorships in the Deep South are using the landmark Voting Rights Act of 1965 to create a system of political apartheid.

headline: Byrne Wins Republican Runoff in Alabama House Race
text: MOBILE, Ala. — It took a flood of campaign donations from the business community and the backing of a large part of the Republican establishment, but Bradley Byrne, a lawyer and former state senator, successfully fought off a Tea Party-supported rival on Tuesday to become the Republican candidate for a House special election here in coastal Alabama.

headline: New York’s Next Mayor, an Audacious Liberal
text: The sidewalk outside the subway station in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was crowded on Tuesday morning. Bill de Blasio bent his 6-foot-5 frame again and again to shake hands.

headline: Virginia: The Governor’s Race, Minute by Minute
text: Terry McAuliffe, a former Democratic National Committee chairman, was elected governor of Virginia on Tuesday, narrowly defeating the state’s attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II. For much of the evening, Mr. McAuliffe trailed in the polls, as the first counties to report results were from more conservative areas of the state. But he pulled ahead shortly after 9:30 p.m. and was declared the winner just before 10 p.m. A look at the vote, minute by minute, over the course of the night.

headline: New York: Voters Approve Expanded Casino Gambling
text: New York voters on Tuesday approved a constitutional amendment to expand casino gambling, authorizing as many as seven full-scale casinos as part of a plan meant to bring jobs to economically distressed parts of Upstate New York.

headline: Expansion of Gambling in New York Is Approved
text: New York voters on Tuesday approved a constitutional amendment to expand casino gambling, authorizing as many as seven full-scale casinos as part of a plan meant to bring jobs to economically distressed upstate regions.

headline: Lackluster Bidding Dampens Second Night at Christie’s
text: A combination of high prices and middling quality made for a disappointing night on Tuesday at Christie’s, where paintings by Picasso, Modigliani and Léger failed to receive even one bid.

headline: Trying to Elevate the Sounds Competing With Subterranean Clatter
text: PARIS — On a rain-soaked afternoon in Paris’s edgy 11th Arrondissement, Antoine Naso squeezed down a winding staircase in his tiny office and walked toward a coterie of young men awaiting their chance to audition in an airless basement.

headline: New York: Thompson Claims Victory Over Hynes, Again, for Brooklyn District Attorney
text: As the bitterly fought race for Brooklyn district attorney drew to a close on Tuesday night, Kenneth P. Thompson, the Democratic nominee, claimed a landslide victory over the longtime incumbent, Charles J. Hynes.
