text: Instagram has created a new kind of voyeurism — in which you can look into the carefully curated windows of the rich, famous and stylish — and a new kind of lifestyle envy.

headline: J. Crew’s British Invasion, Designed by Confetti System
text: The Brooklyn design duo created to-scale installations of quintessentially British things for the windows of J. Crew’s new international flagship on Regent Street in London.

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Keep Telling Yourself, ‘This Workout Feels Good’
text: Tell yourself during exercise that you’re not as tired as you think you are and you could make that statement true, a new study shows, reminding us that the body intertwines with the mind in ways that we are only starting to understand.

headline: Plan to Raise Judges’ Retirement Age to 80 Is Rejected
text: An amendment to the New York State Constitution raising the mandatory retirement age to 80 for judges on the Supreme Court and on the Court of Appeals went down in defeat in a referendum on Tuesday, handing Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman a stinging rebuke.

headline: Votes on Fracking Limits Show Mixed Results
text: DENVER — The national debate over hydraulic fracturing and oil and gas drilling found its way to ballots on Tuesday in several communities in Ohio and Colorado, where voters considered proposals to ban or restrict fracking.

headline: Cuccinelli Concedes Defeat in Virginia
text: Republican candidate Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II lost the race for governor of Virginia, but said his strong showing is a sign of dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Two New York Counties Re-elect G.O.P. Executives
text: Two of the wealthiest counties in the nation, both with voters worried about property tax increases, decided in Tuesday’s elections to stick with Republican county executives who held the line on taxes, keeping Rob Astorino in Westchester and Edward P. Mangano in Nassau.

headline: New Chinese Drone Unveiled in Video
text: This week, the Internet lit up with an annotated video, above, of what appears to be China’s latest (or at least most recently unveiled) drone design.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 47TH ANNUAL CMA AWARDS Carrie Underwood and Brad Paisley (below) return as hosts of this ceremony, billed as “country music’s biggest night” and broadcast live from the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Kenny Rogers, a five-time Country Music Association Award winner and recent Country Music Hall of Fame inductee, will be honored with the Willie Nelson Lifetime Achievement Award and a tribute by Jennifer Nettles, Rascal Flatts and Darius Rucker. Taylor Swift will receive the Pinnacle Award, which recognizes an artist who has made a positive impact on the appreciation of country music. Ms. Swift will take the stage with Vince Gill and Alison Krauss, the Zac Brown Band will perform with Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, and Hunter Hayes will team up with Jason Mraz. And Jason Aldean, Luke Bryan, Blake Shelton, Ms. Swift and George Strait will compete for the evening’s top honor, entertainer of the year. “CMA Awards Red Carpet Live,” at 7 on Great American Country, features interviews with artists and nominees as they arrive.

headline: Decisions From Alabama to Boston, and Virginia to Detroit
text: Voters chose winners in races for mayor, governor and the Republican nomination for a vacant seat in Congress.

headline: Terry McAullife’s Victory Speech
text: Mr. McAullife, a former fundraiser for the Democratic Party, narrowly defeated his socially conservative, Republican opponent.

headline: News Quiz | November 6, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Milestones: Bill de Blasio
text: Bill de Blasio, who was elected to become the first Democratic mayor of New York City in 20 years, will have a far grander stage on which to test the liberal worldview that has been the hallmark of his career.

headline:
Profit Is Up 70% at Toyota,
Close to Its Old Milestone
text: TOKYO — In 2008, Toyota Motor was at giddy heights. Profit soared to a record high. The Japanese company knocked General Motors off its perch as the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Animal Protection Remains Elusive in China
text: Mr. Guo breeds pit bulls and other potential fighting dogs. He’s guarded about what he does. Pit bulls are illegal in much of Beijing, as are 40 other breeds deemed “vicious and large” by the police, including the Dalmatian, collie and Weimaraner, and some valued in other countries as guide dogs.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 6, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Israeli Court Clears Former Foreign Minister of Fraud Charges
text: JERUSALEM — Avigdor Lieberman, the former Israeli foreign minister who is among the nation’s most powerful and polarizing politicians, was acquitted Wednesday of corruption charges that have dogged him for more than a decade, a verdict with profound implications for Israel’s internal politics and its peace talks with the Palestinians.

headline: The Coach Who Exploded
text: Mike Rice is coaching again. Or rather, he’s running after-school clinics for third-to-sixth graders at a vast, four-court indoor basketball facility in Neptune, N.J., where he also works out local high-school players on Friday afternoons and coaches his son’s high-school team in a fall recreational league.

headline: King of the New York Streets
text: Neal Boenzi has an eye for quality, picking up deals on antique beer taps and neon signs at Southern California swap meets. His friends have no idea that the gravelly voiced East Coast retiree once used that eye to make some of the greatest New York City newspaper photographs for much of the latter half of the 20th century.

headline: Samsung’s Investment Plan Falls Short for Some
text: SEOUL — Samsung Electronics, the world’s biggest smartphone maker, summoned investors to a luxury hotel here Wednesday to tell them why they should buy its stock. Despite a promise of more cash and other goodies, some investors left grumbling that it was not enough.

headline: Is It an Unaffordable Luxury to Major in the Humanities in College?
text: What do you plan to study in college? Why? How much do you think your choice will be based on preparing yourself for the job market, and how much will be about following an intellectual passion? Why?

headline: Notes From Egypt’s Show Trial
text: CAIRO — DURING a court recess on Monday, I approached the floor-to-ceiling, webbed-metal cage confining Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president of Egypt, and seven other defendants.

text: Updated, 12:20 p.m. | The city woke today to a new mayor, Bill de Blasio, who won in a landslide.

headline: Slow Dancing With Part D
text: With the open enrollment period for switching Medicare Part D drug plans upon us, the Kaiser Family Foundation has released two reports that both question the design of the plans and the inattention of 23 million of us who have them.

headline: When ‘Do No Harm’ Hurts
text: LONDON — IT’S increasingly clear that humanitarian assistance to rebel-held areas of Syria is being impeded by a fear — shared by the United States, the European Commission and many nongovernmental organizations — that food, medicine and other supplies might fall into the hands of terrorists.

headline: China Bids for 2022 Winter Olympic Games
text: Beijing and Zhangjiakou, a city about 110 miles, or 180 kilometers, northwest of the Chinese capital, are bidding to jointly host the 2022 Winter Olympic Games, the Chinese Olympic Committee has announced.

headline: Investors Cool to 2 Chinese Bank Offerings
text: Two Chinese banks that sold nearly $2 billion worth of shares in Hong Kong stock market listings received lukewarm receptions on Wednesday from investors concerned about how China’s financial system would cope with a potential deluge of bad debt that could swamp the country’s economy.

headline: A Small Business Starts to Navigate the Affordable Care Act
text: Last week, I took a phone call from Maggie, my health insurance broker. “I’m calling my clients who are getting big increases this year,” she said. “I didn’t want to just send an email.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The New Mayor of New York City
text: In the article “Heading to City Hall, Bill de Blasio Is Used to Exceeding Expectations,” Javier C. Hernández writes about this man in the news.

headline: A Train Too Far
text: ISTANBUL — Last Tuesday the city celebrated the 90th anniversary of Turkey’s founding with unusual pomp. Senior politicians cut the ribbon on a spectacular new metro system that runs some 200 feet below the Sea of Marmara and can carry 1.5 million people every day between the European and Asian sides of the city.

headline: Cisco Counters Its Young Competitors in Data Networking
text: Cisco Systems has announced its big play for the future of data networking, a multibillion-dollar business that holds the Internet together. It’s comprehensive, probably compelling for people who already own lots of Cisco equipment (which is most large companies that operate networks), and for Cisco at least, expensive.

headline: Blurring Art, Artifice and Pop Culture
text: Lady Gaga the relentless is back in full force on “Artpop” (Streamline/Interscope), her third full-length studio album of new songs. It took hip surgery, for injuries that she had aggravated onstage, to knock her off her tour and sideline her from media exposure for a few months earlier this year. But in summer the next push began with a single, “Applause,” that simultaneously reaffirmed her need for the love of her audience and announced her new pivot to align herself with the (visual) art world, singing, “Pop culture was in art, now art’s in pop culture, in me.”

headline: Daily Report: Samsung Promises to Double Its Dividend
text: At a meeting with investors in Seoul on Wednesday, executives from Samsung Electronics laid out their vision for the company’s future, saying they would fine-tune a strategy that has helped the company become the world’s biggest smartphone maker, Eric Pfanner reports. Samsung’s one-third share of the global smartphone business is more than double the volume of its nearest competitor, Apple.

headline: The European Central Bank’s Inflation Conundrum
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank will meet on Thursday under renewed pressure to do more to stimulate the Continent’s sluggish economies, as evidence grows that the recovery is failing to pick up speed and that inflation has fallen so low as to become worrisome.

headline: Battle Over ValueVision Set to Heat Up
text: The move by the activist hedge fund Clinton Group to try to oust senior executives at the Internet and shopping network ValueVision Media is poised to become a bitter battle.

headline: New York: De Blasio to Meet With Bloomberg
text: Fresh off his overwhelming victory in Tuesday’s mayoral election, Bill de Blasio planned to meet on Wednesday morning with the man who has run the city for the last 12 years, Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Helen Caldicott, Chernobyl and the New York Academy of Sciences
text: Helen Caldicott, a physician who for decades has fought nuclear power, wrote a letter to The Times criticizing David Ropeik‘s recent Op-Ed article on outsize fears of radiation. Caldicott’s letter contained a mischaracterization of a much-criticized Russian study that attributed a million deaths to the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, calling it a “New York Academy of Sciences report.” I contacted academy staff to get the organization’s view. Here’s the result:

headline: Carlyle Reports Lower Earnings for Third Quarter
text: Updated, 11:02 a.m. | The private equity giant Carlyle Group reported lower third-quarter earnings on Wednesday, amid a slow period in selling its investments.

headline: On Beauty | Bare Is Beautiful
text: A face without makeup looks wholesome and shows confidence — but doesn’t come without effort.

headline: Shrinking Numbers and Growing Persecution Threaten Sikhs and Hindus in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — J.K. Sharma, a large Sikh man in a black turban, works out of a small room lined with jars and herbs in the ruined and dusty Shor Bazaar in Kabul. In a war-ravaged country where miracles are in short supply, Mr. Sharma makes a living as a magician, providing advice and talismans to Muslim Afghans for a fee.

headline: If Only… Grazed Grasslands Could Sop Up All Industrial CO2
text: There’s a very helpful post on the RealClimate blog critiquing the appealing, virally shared, and largely wishful climate change strategy that Allan Savory laid out in a popular TED talk not long ago. Savory — a biologist, farmer and environmentalist and more — claimed that certain approaches to managing grazed grasslands could more than absorb all of the carbon dioxide we’re adding to the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels.

headline: Despite Fumbles, Obama Defends Health Care Law
text: DALLAS — President Obama strongly defended his signature health care law on Wednesday in the largest state that has refused to participate, as rattled Senate Democrats called for changing or delaying key parts of the new health coverage.

headline: The Vespa 946: A Scooter for the Wealthy
text: Have you ever come across a $10,000 scooter? Well, meet the 946, Vespa’s newest and most expensive model. With swooping lines and a big red leather-textured seat, it neatly epitomizes the Italian brand’s gradual transformation from maker of inexpensive transportation for the masses to purveyor of two-wheeled fashion accessories.

headline: A Meaningful Minute
text: At 9:59 in the morning, in a seaside city somewhere, a little girl named Jodie is about to draw the final silver button on her picture of an elegantly dressed duck. She pauses for a minute to consider her work. That short span of time is all it takes for Jonathan, her baby brother, to take his first steps. And throughout the multiracial, multiethnic town, other important things happen in that same time frame. An ambulance speeds past, a soldier says goodbye to his mother, a grandfather plays a funny game of leaf houses with his granddaughter. A homeless woman pushes her belongings down the street in a grocery cart. A baby is born, and two friends, Belle and Vashti, pop seaweed on the beach.

headline: Lawyers Challenge Detention of Greenwald’s Partner in London
text: LONDON — In London’s High Court on Wednesday, lawyers challenged the legality of the temporary detention of David Michael Miranda, the partner of Glenn Greenwald, a journalist who has been writing about the secret documents taken by a former analyst for the National Security Agency, Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Sebelius Rejects Delays to Get Time to Repair Problems at Health Site
text: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Wednesday that the government needed to fix hundreds of problems with the website for the federal health insurance marketplace, but she categorically rejected bipartisan calls to delay parts of the new health care law.

headline: New York: Voter Turnout Appears to Be Record Low
text: Turnout in Tuesday’s election for New York City mayor appeared to have set a record low of 24 percent of registered voters.

headline: India Gives Foreign Banks New Door Into Local Market
text: MUMBAI — India’s central bank unveiled late Wednesday a far-reaching set of regulations to allow foreign banks into the country’s long-protected domestic market. But it demanded that they do so through subsidiaries incorporated in India and said that eligibility would be limited to banks from countries that reciprocate by letting in Indian banks.

headline: Neal Boenzi, Photographer
text: The art of the street photograph as told by Neal Boenzi, who has been recently celebrated as one of the most inventive masters of the form.

headline: Performing on the Paris Metro
text: Each year, thousands of musicians from around the world audition to earn a license to play on the Paris Metro.

headline: Pointless Political Punditry
text: I’ve never been a fan of the entrail reading that follows off-year elections, in which observers try to read great significance into details of the voting patterns. Partly that’s because nobody really knows how to do this; partly it’s because stuff happens, and the political environment a year or three years from now is going to be very different.

headline: In Our Pages: November 7
text: 1913 Olympia Auto Show

headline: North Atlantic Fiscal Policy
text: The economic crisis of 2008 was, as I like to say, a North Atlantic affair. There were monstrous housing bubbles in both America and Europe, rising household debt on both sides, and then more or less comparable busts in both places. Ours was more exotic, involving fancy instruments nobody understood, where theirs involved more plain-vanilla banking excess. But overall things weren’t that different.

headline: Reader Idea | Researching Political History to Understand How a Community Problem Was Solved
text: With New York City electing Bill de Blasio as its new mayor, we thought it was a fitting time to publish this Reader Idea, from the coordinator for educational programs at the LaGuardia and Wagner Archives, part of LaGuardia Community College in Queens.

headline: Released From Prison, and Starting a Company
text: Like most entrepreneurs, Frederick Hutson cannot resist trying to solve a thorny problem. His company, Pigeonly, based in Las Vegas, taps an underserved and “captive” market by offering prison inmates an easy and efficient way to receive photos from loved ones and to make phone calls to them inexpensively. “Isolation is the worst thing for an inmate,” Mr. Hutson said. “It makes it hard for him to rebuild his life when he gets out.”

headline: Remembering Editta Sherman, Duchess of Carnegie Hall
text: Someone had gotten a large black hat made of flowers and displayed it with a jaunty tilt – just the way Editta Sherman wore hers — next to the coffin, as if to set a “Let’s Party!” tone for the wake and funeral of Ms. Sherman, the 101-year-old portrait photographer who was known as the Duchess of Carnegie Hall.

headline: Backstage Nerves Through the Ages
text: The theater is like an old Jewish mother in a Woody Allen film: always melodramatically, nonsensically on the verge of death. The cause of the affliction, however, varies. Some say ticket prices. Others blame those miserable critics. Television and the Internet are occasionally villains in this drama. But for a historically minded set, a crucial data point in this tragedy is the decline of the repertory, a resident company of actors of the sort that, say, Shakespeare used at the Globe.

headline: Qatari Court Orders Temporary Release of American Couple
text: DOHA, Qatar — A court in the wealthy Persian Gulf emirate of Qatar on Wednesday ordered the temporary release of Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple accused of starving their 8-year-old daughter to death, a family member said after the hearing.

headline: SAC Capital Cuts a Deal
text: Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, was the target of a decade-long insider trading investigation. Six former SAC traders pleaded guilty and two others, who have denied the charges, have been indicted. Now the investigation has led to a deal that calls for SAC to plead guilty to criminal insider trading charges, and to pay a fine of $1.2 billion.

headline: Podesta Starting a Think Tank on Inequality
text: John Podesta, a longtime adviser to Bill and Hillary Clinton and President Obama, is starting a research center in Washington to investigate the causes and effects of growing economic inequality.

headline: Knicks Trying to Find Themselves, or Anybody at All, on Defense
text: Missed assignments, blown rotations, wild closeouts and a general lack of communication and purpose — the Knicks made just about every defensive error a team could make in their 102-97 loss Tuesday to the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: After de Blasio’s Big Victory, Even Bigger Challenges
text: He pledged to remake New York’s social fabric, stoked the hopes of discouraged liberals and vowed that a city defined by its luxuries would once again be a comfortable home for those with money struggles and the poor.

headline: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 1
text: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers’ questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members.

headline: Health Care Deal Is Latest to Seek Corporate Tax Shelter Abroad
text: Corporate inversions keep coming as American companies seek ways to avoid paying high taxes.

headline: The Revenge of Donorism
text: There were plenty of reasons for Ken Cuccinelli’s defeat last night in Virginia at the well-greased hands of Terry McAuliffe, but because the race turned out to be so surprisingly close we’re going to hear a lot about the money: McAuliffe (of course) had it, Cuccinelli did not, the national Republican Party did not exactly go all-in on his behalf, and so the campaign ended up being defined, and possibly won, by a Democratic advertising blitz that the G.O.P. barely countered.

headline: Today in Small Business: Working Weekends
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Nikki Finke Leaves Deadline Hollywood
text: After nearly a year of squabbling, the Hollywood blogger Nikki Finke has parted ways with Jay Penske, the media entrepreneur who in 2009 bought her high-octane industry website Deadline.com.

headline: Image of the Day: November 6
text: Prices of essential vegetables like onions have skyrocketed in recent months.

headline: Treating the Village to Cure the Disease
text: In communities across Africa, health workers are going house to house with medicine to combat lymphatic filariasis, or L.F., which is the world’s second-largest cause of chronic disability. They make sure the children are old enough, the women aren’t pregnant and no one is seriously ill. Then people take two pills while the health worker watches. She writes down their names in her ledger.

headline: It’s a ‘Captive’ Market. But Is It Big Enough?
text: Like most entrepreneurs, Frederick Hutson cannot resist trying to solve a thorny problem. As Donna Fenn explains in an article we have just published, his company, Pigeonly, which is based in Las Vegas, taps an under-served and “captive” market by offering prison inmates an easy way to receive photos from loved ones and to make phone calls to them inexpensively. “Isolation is the worst thing for an inmate,” Mr. Hutson said. “It makes it hard for him to rebuild his life when he gets out.”

headline: Classical Playlist: Jan Lisiecki, Mitsuko Uchida, Stile Antico and More

text: Obamacare’s early problems could recast the debate about a mortgage market overhaul.

headline: Marcella Cooks
text: Mark Bittman cooking with Marcella and Victor Hazan at their home in Florida.

headline: Remembering Marcella
text: Marcella Hazan, who died Sept. 29 at the age of 89, never intended to bring real Italian cooking to America. But no matter how accidental her impact, it can hardly be overstated. What Alice Waters did for restaurants, Hazan did for home cooks, demonstrating that the simple treatment of decent ingredients leads to wonderful dishes.

headline: Amid Capitol Turmoil, Postal Crisis Drags On
text: WASHINGTON — In early 2009, John E. Potter, then the postmaster general, delivered a dire warning to Congress: The United States Postal Service would run out of money unless lawmakers stepped in and passed legislation to help the agency stabilize its finances.

headline: Chandler’s Leg Fracture Leaves Knicks Thin in the Post
text: Even after 12 seasons in the N.B.A., Tyson Chandler wanted to improve his game over the summer. So he went to work on a short jump shot that he felt could stretch defenses and bolster the Knicks’ offense. The team considered it a bonus — a way for the 7-foot-1 Chandler to supplement his considerable responsibilities anchoring the post. But that was Chandler, searching for solutions where no problems existed.

headline: U.S. Investors Brush Aside Fears About Chinese Internet Companies
text: For American investors, love of technology has conquered a fear of China.

headline: A Better Night’s Sleep for a Slimmer Christie
text: SOUTH AMBOY, N.J. — While Gov. Chris Christie celebrated a big public victory in New Jersey on Tuesday, he has also been privately enjoying another success: better sleep, as a result of his weight loss.

headline: Homes for $750,000

headline: The Passion of Solomon Northup
text: Critics are already hailing the film adaption of Solomon Northup’s slave narrative, “12 Years a Slave,” as a shoo-in for the Academy Award nominations. But many viewers will likely wonder, given that this is a big-budget film with big-budget actors, how faithful it is to the book. The stakes may seem particularly high for a slave narrative, since many likely believe these books offer an unfiltered view of slavery.

headline: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Relive the ’70s
text: Those gloriously cheesy 1970s movies in which fistfuls of C-list celebrities face wholesale slaughter at the hands of unnatural acts of nature are lampooned in the new musical “Disaster!” at the St. Luke’s Theater.

headline: Time Warner’s Profit Rises, Lifted by TV
text: Time Warner reported mostly upbeat earnings on Wednesday, and television was the biggest reason.

headline: A Larger Place in Park Slope, This Time Ours
text: The small duplex on West 69th Street had been handed down to Andrea Wolinetz and Alexis Placzek by friends. During their three years there, the $2,050-a-month rent had risen to $2,300 — still a steal, but “not the same sort of steal,” Ms. Placzek said.

headline: Library Exhibition to Celebrate the Beatles’ Time in New York
text: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first visit to New York, and the “Ed Sullivan Show” appearances that lit the fuse on Beatlemania in America, the New York Public Library and the Grammy Museum are collaborating on a multimedia exhibition, “Ladies and Gentlemen … The Beatles!”

headline: Justices Weigh Constitutionality of New York Town’s Prayers
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which begins its sessions with an invocation to God, considered on Wednesday whether a town in upstate New York had crossed a constitutional line in opening its Town Board meetings with mostly Christian prayers. The justices seemed to find the issue unusually difficult, with several of them suggesting there was no satisfactory principled answer.

headline: Children Eat More After Sleeping Less
text: Children who do not sleep enough may be increasing their risk for obesity, according to a new study.

headline: Beneath Martinique’s Beauty, Guided by a Poet
text: As the stories poured out, eyes sparkled, smiles widened, hands danced. Everyone I met on Martinique harbored at least one intimate memory of Aimé Césaire — a quiet encounter or speech etched forever in their consciousness — but they all agreed: this poet, playwright and politician, who achieved an almost monumental status on the Caribbean island, was the most humble man they had ever known.

headline: Exploring Aimé Césaire’s Martinique
text: Scenes from the Caribbean island on the 100th anniversary of the poet and politician’s birth.

headline: Beyond Orlando’s Theme Parks, a Beer Culture Grows
text: Craft beer is usually not what comes to mind when thinking about Orlando. Walt Disney World, Universal Studios or another splashy theme park, yes, but not beer. Today, however, this landlocked central Florida city is getting a reputation for its growing craft beer scene. In the past few years, locals in the Orlando area have opened bars offering a wide selection of beers from small producers, and some are even opening spots that serve ales brewed in house.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Monaco in Philadelphia
text: Rates

headline: Nietzsche and Wagner’s Greatest Hits, and Naughty Bits
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — When Nietzsche and Wagner first met in 1868, the philosopher, more than 30 years Wagner’s junior, found a father figure. Wagner got an acolyte and mouthpiece.

headline: Russians Meet With an Uncle of Assad in an Effort to Jump-Start Peace Talks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As American diplomacy on the war in Syria flounders, unable to deliver the main exile opposition group to proposed peace talks, Russian officials on Wednesday stepped up their efforts to promote alternate opposition figures, meeting in Geneva with Rifaat al-Assad, an uncle of President Bashar al-Assad who was forced out of the country in 1984 after attempting to lead a coup.

headline: Why Twitter May Have to Pay Income Taxes One Day
text: Potential investors in Twitters’s planned initial public offering may be struggling to estimate how much the company will have to pay in taxes in the future. An article in Politico on Friday highlighted some of the techniques Twitter might use to legally avoid taxes.

headline: Baby’s Gaze May Signal Autism, a Study Finds
text: Updated, 1:11 a.m. | When and how long a baby looks at other people’s eyes offers the earliest behavioral sign to date of whether a child is likely to develop autism, scientists are reporting.

headline: Internet Kills the Video Store
text: Blockbuster, which had more than 9,000 retail stores across America just nine years ago, is closing the few hundred video-rental stores that it still has, the company’s owner, Dish Network, said on Wednesday in a bittersweet but long-expected announcement.

headline: House Hunting in Central Barcelona
text: Despite Spain’s punishing market, luxury properties like this one near Gaudí‘s Park Güell are showing some resilience.

headline: House Hunting in Barcelona, Spain
text: A 19TH-CENTURY VILLA IN CENTRAL BARCELONA

headline: Do Moderates Have the Guts to Take Back the G.O.P.?
text: Establishment Republicans feel pretty good about their wins yesterday in New Jersey and Alabama. (Many are also quietly saying “I told you so” about Ken Cuccinelli’s loss in the Virginia governor’s race.) For those in the traditional Chamber of Commerce wing of the party, the next year will be about regaining control from the Tea Partiers who have been driving the party’s policies since 2010.

headline: De Blasio, Preparing to Become Mayor, Signals Sea Change in New York
text: In his first morning as New York City’s mayor-elect, Bill de Blasio spent a cordial, if somewhat awkward hour with the man he will soon replace, Michael R. Bloomberg, making small talk about the intricacies of garbage pickup.

headline: Bill de Blasio’s Path to Mayoral Success
text: With his mantra "A Tale of Two Cities," Bill de Blasio captured voters' concerns about inequality in New York City. But he had to overcome far more famous rivals to get to City Hall.

headline: SAC’s $1.2 Billion Settlement Clears One Judicial Hurdle and Awaits Another
text: Federal prosecutors and SAC Capital Advisors cleared a legal hurdle on Wednesday after Judge Richard J. Sullivan said he would sign off on the civil portion of the hedge fund’s insider trading guilty plea and roughly $1.2 billion penalty.

headline: Fall Fashion That Is Anything but Stiff
text: You’ll always feel put together in a collared shirt, so why not wear one that brings a little pizazz to the party? The shirts here, with contrast collars, embellishments and playful tweaks, do for the classic what vodka does for tonic. Wear as you normally would, with tailored pants or jeans and a blazer; just have more fun.

headline: The Gun Report: November 6, 2013
text: Dick Metcalf, the technical editor of Guns & Ammo magazine, announced in his December editorial that he supports gun control regulations, a position that is earning him derision within the gun-rights crowd.

headline: Don’t Yell at Your Children. But If You Do, Don’t Yell at Yourself.
text: Personally, I wouldn’t yell at my children if they would just do what I’ve asked the first time, or maybe do the thing I’ve asked them to do 463 times in the past. Or if they didn’t chase one another through the kitchen at dinnertime, brandishing light sabers. Or if they got up when the alarm clock went off in the morning, or put their shoes on so we could leave the house, or moved that glass of milk, the one that’s right by your elbow and … too late.

headline: First Draft Pick Finally Gets First Basket
text: Anthony Bennett, the N.B.A.’s No. 1 draft pick this year, has already had many firsts in these early weeks of the season: his first home game with the Cleveland Cavaliers, his first blocked shot, his first victory.

headline: Who Beats Christie?
text: And now for the requisite “Chris Christie and 2016″ post, occasioned by all the other “Chris Christie and 2016″ posts that his landslide re-election have spawned. Mine is inspired by the skeptics — from the right, Henry Olsen; from the left, Jonathan Chait; from the media version of the center, Ron Fournier — who all offer reasons to doubt Christie’s presidential mojo, and spin out entirely plausible scenarios in which his liabilities cost him the G.O.P. nomination. Well, entirely plausible except for one thing, which I think Chait’s conclusion underplays:

headline: Mayor-Elect Bill de Blasio
text: When he began his mayoral campaign on a freezing cold January day outside his home in Brooklyn, Bill de Blasio was just one of several Democratic candidates all claiming to be the progressive voice of change for a post-Bloomberg New York. His Democratic and Republican opponents belittled his policy proposals, his record and his supposed lack of experience.

headline: De Blasio Enters to 'Royals'
text: Bill de Blasio entered his election night party to the song "Royals," by Lorde.

headline: Voters Reject* Labels for Genetically Engineered Food in Washington State
text: Washington State voters, with only four* mainly-urban counties around Seattle bucking the tide, appeared to reject* a ballot initiative that would have required labeling for foods with genetically modified ingredients (with a variety of exceptions), according to the state’s election Web site. The map above is from the state Office of the Secretary of State. There’s more from CNN and USA Today. Industry heavily outspent backers of the labeling initiative, but the measure was also opposed by many newspapers, including the Seattle Times and Olympian.

headline: 'Ain't No Mountain High Enough'
text: Bill de Blasio exited his victory night speech to "Ain't No Mountain High Enough."

headline: ‘Royals,’ a Dickensian Anthem, Becomes de Blasio’s Victory Song
text: Bill de Blasio strode onstage in Brooklyn on Tuesday night to give his victory speech as New York City’s mayor-elect to a song by a teenager from New Zealand, “Royals,” by Lorde. “Royals” is currently the No. 1 song in the United States on Billboard magazine’s Hot 100. It also gives catchy form to what had been a major theme of the de Blasio campaign: his “tale of two cities,” addressing the income inequality between the wealthy few and a struggling majority.

headline: Google Is Ordered to Block Images in Privacy Case
text: LONDON — A French court ruled Wednesday that Google must remove from its Internet search results all images of a former Formula One car racing chief at an orgy. The ruling in the privacy case could have ramifications for the tech giant’s operations across Europe.

headline: Kerry’s Path Steepens in Israeli-Palestinian Talks
text: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — Secretary of State John Kerry’s uphill path to a peace accord between Israel and the Palestinians seemed ever steeper on Wednesday, as the two sides clashed bitterly over Jewish settlements in the West Bank, while the exoneration of a right-wing Israeli politician threatened to inject a volatile element into the talks.

headline: Satellite Falls to Earth
text: A European satellite that mapped Earth’s gravitational field in exquisite detail will be pulled down by gravity to its fiery destruction sometime in the next few days.

headline: ‘Rocky’ on Broadway Finds Its Apollo Creed
text: The new Broadway musical “Rocky” has its Master of Disaster.

headline: Sel Rrose on the Lower East Side
text: A few months ago, in a gray, nondescript box on Delancey Street, a bar opened. No one was hired to hype it. It didn’t bait the blogs with a top-secret tequila cave or bacon-infused cocktails. And the stratagem worked, insofar as Sel Rrose, as the bar is called, has been ignored by the right people.

headline: Fantagraphics Seeks Support With a Kickstarter Campaign
text: Fantagraphics Books, the graphic novel imprint that, since the mid-1970s, has published a large and varied line, with new works and classic reprints, and has fought to establish comic books as a form of high art, has fallen on hard times since its co-founder, Kim Thompson, was diagnosed with lung cancer in February.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Sesame Letterpress Bespoke Stationery
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Travel Diary
text: Sam Buffa, the entrepreneur behind the Fellow Barber shops and several Brooklyn restaurants, heads to the Italian island to ride for Team USA in the International Six Days of Enduro.

headline: Call Collins? Knicks Have Little to Lose
text: One week into an already stressful season, the Knicks do not have a center, a defensive beacon in the N.B.A. storm. There is no short or complete answer to the loss of Tyson Chandler, who has a nondisplaced fracture of the right fibula. But there will be suggestions on how to cobble together a plan to survive for the next four to six weeks. And here is one:

headline: Gergiev Defends Himself Against Criticism Over Russia’s Anti-Gay Law
text: Valery Gergiev, the Russian conductor whose performances have drawn protests in New York and London this fall from gay-rights advocates opposing Russia’s new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality, issued a statement on his Facebook page Wednesday saying, “It is wrong to suggest that I have ever supported anti-gay legislation and in all my work I have upheld equal rights for all people.”

headline: Closing In: A Campaign’s Final Hours
text: Damon Winter went behind the scenes with Bill de Blasio in the days leading up to the mayoral election.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Book Thief’
text: Brian Percival, the director of “The Book Thief,” narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Vote of Confidence in Mexico’s Version of Amazon.com
text: The Mexican venture capital firm Latin Idea Ventures said this week that it had made its first investment in an e-commerce company, Linio, a Mexico City start-up that, like Amazon.com in the United States, sells a wide array of products.

headline: ‘A Time to Kill’ Sets Broadway Closing Date
text: John Grisham may lure readers to his novels in droves, but not to Broadway: The stage adaptation of his best-selling book “A Time To Kill” will close there on Nov. 17, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Killing of French Journalists Reverberates in France and Mali
text: PARIS — Diplomats, journalists and humanitarian workers gathered in Paris on Wednesday to mourn the brutal killing of two seasoned French journalists by insurgents in Mali, an episode that has raised questions about France’s plans to withdraw some of its troops from the country over the next two months.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Book Thief’
text: In this video, the director Brian Percival narrates a sequence from his film adaptation of the Markus Zusak novel featuring Sophie Nélisse as Liesel and Geoffrey Rush as her foster father Han. In this scene, Liesel has stolen a book from a Nazi book-burning rally. Mr. Percival discusses his ideas behind the scene and offers insight into how it was shot. The movie opens Nov. 8.

headline: Giving Old Loew’s Theater in Brooklyn a Second Chance
text: The Kings Theater is big. It’s the borough that got small.

headline: In ‘The Counselor,’ Fashions and Furnishings Play a Pivotal Role
text: CLOTHING, CARS, STRETCHES OF ASPHALT, a plush leather chair: no object is too insignificant to escape the director Ridley Scott, who injects such totems in his films with spirited lives of their own.

headline: Hey, Players, Make Yourselves at Home
text: You’d have to assume that the life of classical music’s star soloists and recitalists might be isolating and lonely, with long stretches of travel and short bursts of communal activity. But on Sunday, the violinist Hilary Hahn was at the center of a social whirl, which could be variously described as a marathon concert, a school day and a carnival.

headline: Nepal Tours Get Local
text: For those who want to meet local people as well as appreciate the grandeur of the landscape, the India-based tour operator Village Ways will introduce community-based trips to Nepal in 2014.

headline: Scene City: All Eyes on Tilda Swinton
text: Anna Wintour, David Bowie, Karl Lagerfeld and others at MoMA’s annual Film Benefit.

headline: Beethoven and One of France’s Musical Mystics Strive for Glimpses of the Divine
text: Since white light results not from an absence of color but from the presence of all colors, it is altogether appropriate that Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival should find a place for that supreme musical colorist Olivier Messiaen. And on Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the Cleveland Orchestra, led by its music director, Franz Welser-Möst, performed Messiaen’s “Trois Petites Liturgies de la Présence Divine” of 1944, a piece for a chorus of sopranos, piano and an orchestra fitted out with exotic instruments, alongside works by Beethoven.

headline: Dancing to Bach, With Head Wobbling and Chest Thumping
text: Along with new casts, the mixed bills by American Ballet Theater at the David H. Koch Theater on Saturday introduced the least distinguished offering of the company’s fall season. Made by Stanton Welch in 2001, it is a showpiece for seven men without shirts. The lead dancer slaps his chest, not like Tarzan but like a man applying a defibrillator to himself, an action that seems to call for a shouting of the work’s title: “Clear.”

headline: Enriching Your TV Picture, From the Couch
text: IF you are close to spending thousands of dollars on a TV because you want a better picture, you may want to save your money. You can almost certainly make your TV’s picture look better than it did when the set was brand-new, and doing so is relatively easy.

headline: A Wall Street Island for Lhota
text: Joseph J. Lhota will not be moving into Gracie Mansion. New Yorkers made sure of that in the mayoral election on Tuesday.

headline: Missing Nash but Not the Net, the Rangers Win Their 4th in 5 Games
text: Rick Nash followed through on a huge slap shot at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, but it was only in a photograph on the cover of the game program. The actual Nash was nowhere to be seen, still out with a concussion he sustained a month ago, leaving Rangers fans wondering when, if ever, he will be healthy enough to come back.

headline: Arcade Fire’s Album Is No. 1
text: Arcade Fire’s new album, “Reflektor” (Merge/Universal), debuted at No. 1 on this week’s Billboard album chart, with sales of 140,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The band’s previous album, “The Suburbs” (Merge/Universal), from 2010, also topped Billboard’s chart in its first week.

headline: Sympathy for the Devil Worshipers
text: It’s easy enough to be in favor of a “nonsectarian” prayer before a legislative session — some invocation of a higher power that theoretically doesn’t exclude anyone (besides atheists, that is) — but what exactly does such a prayer sound like?

headline: Twitter, a Risky Investment
text: Twitter will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. Here are three reasons the company may be a risky investment.

headline: BAE to Stop Building Ships at Historic British Site
text: LONDON — As an island nation that once built an empire by sea, Britain has a proud history and longstanding expertise in shipbuilding.

headline: Ombré: A Ubiquitous Word for That Faded Look
text: Some clients point to the photos they are clutching of Khloé Kardashian and Alexa Chung as they enter the hair salon. Others describe the desired effect: hair that transitions from dark roots to light ends. Then, there are those who are fluent in the language of trend. They ask for ombré.

headline: Google Gives a Hint About Its Mystery Barges
text: Google has finally commented on its mysterious barges floating near San Francisco and Portland, Me. But its comments do not shed much light on the mystery.

headline: The CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, a Support Network Comes of Age
text: After 9/11, a fashion competition was born, with the first award of $200,000 going to the Proenza Schouler designers in 2004. Here’s what some designers are doing now.

headline: Television Sales Look Grim Again This Year
text: The TV industry looks more bleak every year. After sales of television sets fell last year, they are poised to shrink once again this year.

headline: W.H.O., Fighting Polio in Syria, Says More Children Need Vaccinations
text: Escalating its emergency battle to stop the spread of a polio revival in Syria, the World Health Organization has doubled the number of children it says should be urgently vaccinated to more than 20 million throughout the Middle East, the organization’s top official in charge of eradicating the highly contagious and crippling disease said Wednesday.

headline: An African Past, Embodied and Onstage Today
text: A man in a shiny suit faces away from those who watch him. His fingers tickle the air, as if feeling for something. The signals he senses must be intensifying, since his weather-vane body starts shunting into angles, bouncing like a car with loose suspension. As a beat fades in, his shoulders and knees pick it up, until he is stepping high in a dance you might identify as African.

headline: More Asteroid Strikes Are Likely, Scientists Say
text: When an asteroid exploded over the Russian city of Chelyabinsk in February, shattering windows for miles and injuring well over 1,000 people, experts said it was a rare event — of a magnitude that might occur only once every 100 to 200 years, on average.

headline: Tilda Swinton Saluted by MoMA and a Starry Guest List
text: In her two-decade-plus film career, Tilda Swinton has been a muse to many fashion designers. No wonder a tribute to her on Tuesday night, at the Museum of Modern Art’s annual Film Benefit, had a starry guest list that rivaled the Met’s Costume Institute Gala.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
text: Photos from New York, England, Greece and Syria.

headline: Why I Lost It on Election Night
text: THE New York City mayoral election was hardly a nail-biter. But Bill de Blasio’s landslide win might have been nominally less historic had I not torn up my ballot and flung it at a bewildered election volunteer near my home on the Upper West Side.

headline: Thor’s Nemesis Makes Some Thunder
text: LONDON — In a scene close to the end of the 2011 superhero film “Thor,” the two central characters confront each other. They are brothers, although Loki, played by the British actor Tom Hiddleston, has just denied this. “Loki, this is madness,” says Thor (Chris Hemsworth). “Is it madness?” Mr. Hiddleston responds, his face quivering with intensity, his breath ragged, his eyes filming with tears. “Is it? Is it?”

headline: A Showman Whose Dazzle Hid Darkness
text: After Bob Fosse won an Oscar (for directing “Cabaret”), two Tonys (for choreographing and directing “Pippin”) and an Emmy (for directing “Liza With a Z”) in 1973, a rare triple coup, he reacted the way any world-class show business depressive would: He decided he had nowhere to go but down.

headline: U.S. Will Ease Sanctions if Iran Halts Nuclear Program, Official Says
text: GENEVA — On the eve of a new round of talks between world powers and Iran, a senior Obama administration official said Wednesday that the United States was prepared to offer Iran limited relief from economic sanctions if Tehran agreed to halt its nuclear program temporarily and reversed part of it.

headline: Roiling the Waters at River House
text: On a recent afternoon, the River Club was far from bustling. The main dining room was closed, so a handful of elderly couples headed to the pool area, where a bar menu was being served. A man using a walker spoke with his lunch companions of a recent trip to an antiques show. An Elsie de Wolfe aesthetic prevailed in several nearby sitting rooms, where the tufted red leather furniture was unoccupied.

headline: Cooking the Turkey Dinner, With a Little Help From My Phone
text: Thanksgiving is a time to spend wholesome moments with family and enjoy great food and drink.

headline: App Smart: Help With Thanksgiving
text: Android and iOS apps to help in the kitchen and keep the kids amused during the holiday, as reviewed by The Times’s Kit Eaton.

headline: Conquering Android’s World of Themes
text: A few weeks ago, I ditched my iPhone 4S for an HTC One, and now I think the difference between the world’s most popular smartphone operating systems — Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android — can be explained with a metaphor about home decorating.

headline: Hudson Valley Town Is a Playwright’s Home and Template
text: RHINEBECK, N.Y. — Whenever Richard Nelson hit a bump writing about the Apples, the fractious, fictitious family in his critically acclaimed cycle of four plays at the Public Theater this fall, inspiration lay just around the corner.

headline: Error Creates Deals Too Good to Be True on Walmart’s Site
text: First, there was Black Friday. Then came Cyber Monday.

headline: With the Raven, Henry Stimler Expands His Nightlife Presence
text: In his own words, Henry Stimler was “always a wandering spirit and dreamer.” He grew up the second child of five in an ultra-Orthodox home in the predominantly Jewish area of Golders Green, North London.

headline: A Band Likes to Morph and Blend as It Reaches
text: How far can R&B be pushed toward jazz? Hiatus Kaiyote, an Australian band that performed on Tuesday night at Le Poisson Rouge, seems determined to find out. It calls its music “future soul”; its album “Tawk Tomahawk” (Flying Buddha) was released in Australia last year and in the United States this year. On it, the band sails through one ambitious song after another.

headline: An Epic, Century-Old Motorcycle Race Comes to Sardinia
text: As the co-owner of the Brooklyn restaurants Vinegar Hill House and Hillside and the impresario behind the Fellow Barber mini-empire of elegant, old-timey men’s grooming salons, Sam Buffa is already the subject of major male lifestyle envy. The 35-year-old seems even more the embodiment of a certain type of guy’s fantasy life when you learn that he also races motorcycles, something he started doing with his dad as a kid growing up in Half Moon Bay, Calif.

headline: Vogue Fashion Fund: Where No Designer Is Left Behind
text: Whoever said, “If you want to try a risky career, open a restaurant,” surely never considered becoming a clothing designer.

headline: Sweating the Details Is Part of the Test for Designers
text: The challenge, as Steven Kolb, the chief executive of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, explained to the group in the backyard of Anna Wintour’s townhouse, was to create a ready-to-wear design incorporating elements from performance wear. In other words, something that could be worn “from the gym to the office,” he said.

headline: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 7
text: Openings

headline: Documents Reveal How Looted Nazi Art Was Restored to Dealer
text: Throughout the waning years of World War II, a band of Allied soldiers, art historians, curators and scholars labored to safeguard Europe’s cultural heritage and recover the millions of artworks and other treasures plundered by the Nazis and their collaborators. Nicknamed the Monuments Men, this group set up a string of temporary collection points for the valuables.

headline: ‘Blue,’ Through Lesbian Eyes
text: Of the many things to note about the seven-minute lesbian sex scene in “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” a French drama about a teenage girl who becomes passionately involved with a slightly older woman, is how very long it seems to go on.

headline: Despite Blackout, CBS Profit and Revenue Rise
text: Despite its protracted dispute over the summer with Time Warner Cable, CBS posted another solid earnings report on Wednesday with steady increases in revenue and profit for the third quarter.

headline: Cuts Have Hagel Weighing Realigned Military Budget
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has traditionally managed rivalries among services by giving each more or less equal shares of the base military budget.

headline: Late Night Ends Early for Some New York Clubbers
text: At Greenhouse, the smallish two-level dance club on Varick Street in Manhattan, Sunday nights are filled with a frisky mix of gay guys, club kids, homeys and an occasional tourist with a guidebook.

headline: Going Beyond the Baseboard
text: If you find yourself warming to a European-produced designer radiator, you’ll be happy to know that some models are distributed in the United States. Contact the company for the names of retailers. Or you can buy directly from overseas.

headline: Textiles with Roots in the Rain Forest
text: In 2010, Cristina Grajales Gallery in New York presented a solo exhibition of the work of Hechizoo, a textile studio founded in 2000 in Bogotá by Jorge Lizarazo, an architect-turned-weaver. Hechizoo combines native plant fibers like fique and cumare palm with nylon filament and metals to create iridescent carpets and screens.

headline: A Double Take Under Your Feet
text: The British artist Richard Woods creates stylized renderings of construction materials (such as brick and wood) and applies them to household décor. His colorful, comic book-like graphics have appeared on chairs, tables and wallpaper, as well as on the sides of buildings. The floor has certainly not escaped his attention. His latest project, a collection of 11 parquet- and floorboard-patterned wool rugs for Memphis-Milano, are produced in Nepal, where they are woven on traditional looms. “I like the idea of making a rug out of something that’s usually underneath the rug,” Mr. Woods said, adding that he isn’t conscious of any influence his surname may have had on his work. The rugs are produced in a signed limited edition of 36 and range in size from about 3 by 5 feet ($2,466) to about 8 by 11 feet ($14,466). Shown is RW Rug #5 ($6,692). Information: 011-39-02-655-4731 or store.memphis-milano.com.

headline: Dressing the Turkey? Dress the Menorah, Too.
text: When precocious children come up with ideas for salable inventions on long car rides, preoccupied parents typically just keep driving. But about 10 months ago, when Asher Weintraub, 9, suggested combining Thanksgiving table decorations and Hanukkah menorahs this year, since the holidays are making a rare simultaneous appearance, his parents, Anthony Weintraub and Caroline Baron, actually listened. The Manhattan family commissioned a prototype for Asher’s computer sketch of a menurkey, a menorah shaped like a turkey holding candles in its plumes. A Kickstarter campaign, also Asher’s idea, brought in $48,345 and Internet fame, and now plaster menurkeys are being sold for $50 at the Jewish Museum in New York. “When I saw it made,” Asher said, “it looked way better than I expected.” As for his next invention, he added, “Maybe an app.” Information: 212-423-3333 or shop.thejewishmuseum.org.

headline: Trust Me: You Should Be Impressed
text: A new superyacht by Zaha Hadid presents the billionaire playboy with a problem. There is undeniable prestige of trolling Mediterranean harbors in a yacht designed by a Pritzker-prize-winning architect. But the boat’s outer shell is made of an interwoven network of support bands, which gives it a futuristic webbed look and obscures the primary decks. Who on shore will see the bikinied frolicking?

headline: Turning Up the Heat
text: Europeans are endlessly inventive when it comes to radiator design. Why are Americans lagging behind?

headline: A Radiance All Their Own
text: Several winters ago, Guus van Leeuwen, who was then an industrial design student, was riding with his girlfriend in a horse-drawn sleigh in Sweden. Wrapped in reindeer pelts, the couple watched steam rise from the bodies of the sweating animals in front of them. That’s when “it all came together,” Mr. van Leeuwen said.

headline: A Fisherman in New York’s Sea of Faces
text: Here’s how Brandon Stanton spends several hours each day: He walks up to total strangers in New York City, requests permission to take their pictures and then asks questions so personal they might make Oprah Winfrey blush.

headline: 36 Hours in Aruba
text: Averaging 82 sunny degrees year round, fringed with blond beaches and lapped by turquoise shallows, Aruba lets the climate do the talking when it comes to appealing to tourists. Beach lovers flock here, happy to claim a chaise with a paperback in one hand and a cold Balashi beer in the other. But the Dutch island’s manageable 20-by-6-mile dimensions and its desert landscape — calm and sandy on one coast, rough and rocky on the other — make it an explorer’s island, too. Notably multicultural, with Dutch, the Creole-like Papiamento, Spanish and English commonly spoken, the island is also increasingly sophisticated, with an aloe-focused spa, a new avant-garde restaurant and a Ritz-Carlton resort, the island’s most luxurious property, set to open Nov. 22.

headline: From Architecture to Art in Aruba
text: Take a spin around this sunny island off the coast of South America.

headline: A Garden of Creature Comforts
text: Gardeners brought up on the mishaps of Peter Rabbit can now curl up with “Beatrix Potter’s Gardening Life: The Plants and Places That Inspired the Classic Children’s Tales,” by Marta McDowell, out this month from Timber Press ($24.95).

headline: Deals on Linens, Carpets and Chairs
text: During Mia & Finn’s basement sale, Friday and Saturday, bed and table linens are up to 70 percent off (an Izia quilt, usually $420, will be $135); 73 Saint James Place (Lafayette Avenue), Brooklyn, 646-943-0796.

headline: Should I Replace Worn Light Switches?
text: Q. My home has old, worn light switches and outlets. Should I replace them before I put it on the market?

headline: Case of Insect Interruptus Yields a Rare Fossil Find
text: About 165 million years ago, in what is now northeastern China, two insects were doing what comes naturally. Suddenly, in the middle of copulating, they were struck dead, felled by poisonous gas from a volcanic eruption.

headline: Judge Who Overturned Skakel Murder Conviction Declines Bail Request
text: ROCKVILLE, Conn. — Michael C. Skakel, a Kennedy relative who has been serving a 20-year-sentence for killing his Greenwich neighbor Martha Moxley when they were both 15, returned to prison on Wednesday after a hearing in which the judge who  set aside Mr. Skakel’s 2002 conviction declined to grant bail.

headline: Forgive Me, Virginia Woolf
text: When I was 5, my parents decided I was old enough to decorate my own bedroom.

headline: Bolshoi Director Testifies at Acid-Attack Trial
text: MOSCOW — It had all the intrigue and sensation of the Bolshoi Ballet’s most spectacular productions, but the drama that unfolded on Wednesday in the Meschchansky District Court here was one that storied dance company will forever dread.

headline: A Sprint or a Marathon? Bach and Beethoven Variations in a Single Evening
text: Andras Schiff’s latest traversal of Bach’s keyboard works, a two-year project, ended on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall with the “Goldberg” Variations.

headline: Teenager’s Lawyer Blames Pothole for Crash
text: There has been plenty of finger-pointing in the case of a teenage driver who struck a 4-year-old girl, killing her and injuring her grandmother in June while speeding away from the police on the Upper West Side. Now the boy’s lawyer is blaming a pothole for the accident.

headline: A Grand Slam From a Posthumous Victor Mollo Book
text: For the past few columns, we have been looking at noteworthy bridge books published this year that might make good gifts.

headline: The Making Of
text: The Brooklyn design duo created to-scale installations of quintessentially British things for the windows of J. Crew’s new international flagship on Regent Street in London.

headline: Saving Buffalo, Wreck by Wreck
text: In Upstate New York, buyers with activist inclinations are preserving a city, one foreclosed house at a time.

headline: Small-Scale Developers, Big Dreams
text: BUFFALO — It was the proverbial melting pot, festive, aromatic and polyphonic. There were young hipsters (identifiable by their wool caps and archaic facial hair) and local homesteaders, along with settlers from Myanmar, Bhutan, Pakistan and Africa, to name just a few of the cultures represented at this once-blighted city’s annual auction of foreclosed properties. Would-be homeowners and property moguls huddled over the listings for more than 4,300 parcels of vacant lots and houses, their hoped-for choices highlighted and starred.

headline: Tinkering With the Ghosts of Tailors
text: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns redo a Lower East Side loft, preserving the marks of former occupants (and their sewing machines).

headline: Staying in Character
text: The Canadian actors Paul Gross and Martha Burns had long fantasized about buying a place in New York, but it took an old clothing factory on Orchard Street to convince them.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Twitter Prices Its Initial Offering at $26 Per Share
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter, long protected in its Silicon Valley nest, is about to venture into the more unforgiving world of Wall Street.

headline: For Detroit’s New Mayor, Power, With Conditions
text: DETROIT — Congratulatory phone calls dominated Mike Duggan’s first 24 hours as the next mayor of this downtrodden city, but the coming days may be the most crucial to laying the groundwork for his administration, as conversations begin with state officials about his role at City Hall.

headline: Colombia and Rebels Reach Deal on Political Participation
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Negotiators for the Colombian government and the country’s largest guerrilla group announced Wednesday that they had agreed on a framework for the rebels to take part in the political process, a crucial step forward in peace talks aimed at ending nearly 50 years of fighting between the government and the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: ‘First Date’ Announces Last Performance
text: No need to pick out invitations or hire a caterer: the musical comedy “First Date” will finish its Broadway run on Jan. 5 after 34 previews and 174 regular performances, the producers announced late Wednesday.

text: To the Editor:
