headline: Iowa Town’s Vote Delivers Rebuke to Kochs’ Group
text: The mayoral and City Council candidates in an Iowa town who were most closely aligned with the message promoted by Americans for Prosperity, the deep-pocketed conservative political group, were roundly defeated on Tuesday in a sharp rebuke of outside influence in local politics.

headline: Peacekeepers in Congo to Focus on Another Rebel Group
text: UNITED NATIONS — Having helped rout one powerful rebel group in the eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo, United Nations peacekeepers are expected to turn their attention to subduing another, diplomats said Wednesday, as the Security Council prepared to draft a statement on the next steps in that vast, mineral-rich country.

headline: History Channel Is Eying Remake of ‘Roots’
text: The History Channel may remake “Roots,” the ABC mini-series that made history when it was broadcast in 1977. The cable channel confirmed that it had bought the rights to the mini-series (and the Alex Haley book that it was based upon) and had started developing an eight-hour version of it. The original “Roots,” about a multigenerational African-American family’s experiences from the time of slavery onward, was 12 hours and a national phenomenon, as evidenced by the fact that more than half of all American households tuned in for the finale. The development was first reported by Deadline.com on Tuesday, which quoted a senior vice president at the channel, Dirk Hoogstra, as saying “We would like to revive that cultural icon for a new audience.”

headline: Taking Aim at the Wrong Deficit
text: WASHINGTON — ASK most people in this city what the most important step is to increasing economic growth and job creation, and they’ll reply, “Reduce the budget deficit!”

headline: On Holding Hands and Fake Marriage: Stories of Being Gay in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Yegor grew up in a Siberian town called Lyubov, which means “love” in Russian, but he has never told his parents that when he falls in love, it is with other men.

headline: Thursday’s Games to Watch
text: 2 OREGON at 6 STANFORD

headline: Presidential! Season! Soonish!
text: Chris Christie! He won! Let’s talk about his presidential prospects incessantly for the rest of the month!

headline: Wall St. Bonuses Over All Are Predicted to Rise 5 to 10% (Bond Traders Excluded)
text: When it comes to compensation, it looks as if 2013 is going to be remembered as a pretty good year to have worked on Wall Street, unless you are a fixed-income trader.

headline: Obama Defends the Affordable Care Act
text: The president spoke in Dallas about the issues surrounding the health care legislation.

headline: New Bow for CARE Packages
text: THE CARE package, once a familiar symbol of providing relief overseas, is being taken down from the shelf, dusted off and reimagined for a new generation of potential donors.

headline: Slavery Isn’t a Thing of the Past
text: The movie “12 Years a Slave” is receiving rapturous reviews for depicting the antebellum South less as a gauzy land of elegant plantations than as the raw backdrop of monstrous brutality.

headline: N.F.L. Picks Lawyer to Lead Inquiry Into Dolphins
text: The N.F.L. has appointed Ted Wells, one of the country’s top defense lawyers, to investigate the allegations of workplace misconduct swirling around the Miami Dolphins, a sign the league wants to reassure the public that it is taking the matter seriously.

headline: Swiss Report Supports Theory Arafat Was Poisoned
text: JERUSALEM — Nine years of mystery and intrigue surrounding the death of Yasir Arafat, the symbol of the Palestinian national struggle, took a contentious turn on Wednesday with the publication of a forensics report by Swiss scientists that lends support to the theory that Mr. Arafat died of poisoning with radioactive polonium-210.

headline: Defeat of School Tax Stings Colorado Democrats
text: DENVER — They had $10 million in contributions, a barrage of advertising and support from the usually warring factions of the educational establishment. But Democratic leaders in this swing state were dealt a stinging defeat on Tuesday as voters resoundingly rejected an effort to raise taxes by $1 billion a year to pay for a sweeping school overhaul.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Redskins (3-5) at Vikings (1-7)
text: 8:30 p.m., NFL Network

headline: The Passion of Parenting
text: I’ve been a single dad for 13 years. As with most single parents — and indeed with most parents — it hasn’t always been easy.

headline: Measures to Legalize Marijuana Are Passed
text: DENVER — Marijuana proponents scored significant victories on Tuesday as voters around the country passed ballot measures decriminalizing marijuana possession and approved regulatory taxes on the drug.

headline: Ruble Hopes to Join Ranks of the $ and €
text: MOSCOW — The ruble, once the legal tender of the bread line and little else, is now almost a normal currency for international commerce, but it lacks a graphic symbol like the dollar sign. On Wednesday, in an effort the leadership hopes will further raise the currency’s profile and make it as acceptable as the dollar or the euro, the Central Bank posted five possible symbols for Russians to vote on. The winner will be announced on Dec. 5.

headline: In Slide of Swedish Tennis, There Is No End in Sight
text: STOCKHOLM — When the second-highest-ranked Swedish player took the court for his first match at the recent Stockholm Open, the fans who were scattered around the warm, wooden benches at the Kungliga Tennishallen stomped approval that echoed off the arched ceiling.

headline: Twitter’s Market Valuation Suggests Wall St. Sees Huge Growth Potential
text: Twitter is a young company generating large losses as it competes in a highly uncertain sector of the economy.

headline: Next Door to War, There’s Money to Be Made
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Wars, as businessmen have recognized for centuries, can be very profitable. Evidence of that is on display here, where a half-dozen military supply stores in the center of this town near the Syrian border are busy catering to a clientele flooding in from all over the Middle East.

headline: Details Emerge of Potential Google Monitor in Europe
text: Wanted: A Google watchdog in Europe.

headline: Pirate Nights
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Years ago, aboard my first ship as a young cadet, I noticed a man pacing along the bridge deck. I asked the third mate who he was.

headline: Texas’ Stringent Voter ID Law Makes a Dent at Polls
text: HOUSTON — First, Judge Sandra Watts was stopped while trying to vote because the name on her photo ID, the same one she had used for voter registration and identification for 52 years, did not exactly match her name on the official voter rolls.

headline: Nepal’s Tentative Democracy Prepares to Vote
text: After decades of political upheaval and paralysis, Nepal is scheduled to hold national elections on Nov. 19.

headline: Baylor’s Briles Is a Down-Home Innovator
text: STEPHENVILLE, Tex. — Jake and Dorothy’s Cafe opened in 1948, four decades before Art Briles came to town and helped change football with an offense that would, appropriately, spread from central Texas to the N.F.L.

headline: In Fractured Nepal, Plans for National Elections Provide a Series of Subplots
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Nepal’s former first lady insisted that she was not a crook.

headline: Mr. de Blasio’s Moment
text: Bill de Blasio won the New York mayor’s race on Tuesday night, and, on Wednesday, he started accepting job applications and citizens’ ideas for his administration at a website for the transition. It is a nice gesture, striking the notes of diversity and openness that he hit throughout the campaign.

headline: In New York City’s Sharp Left Turn, Questions of Just How Far
text: New York City voters stepped decisively to the political left on Tuesday, turning their collective back on two decades of Republican-backed mayoral rule.

headline: Chinese Leader’s Economic Plan Tests Goal to Fortify Party Power
text: HONG KONG — China’s president, Xi Jinping, is about to plunge the country and himself into a risky experiment: an attempt to carry out market-driven economic overhauls while reinforcing the Communist Party’s pillars of political and ideological control. This mixed agenda has magnified doubts about whether he can deliver on his promises of transformation.

headline: China Wants Its Movies to Be Big in the U.S., Too
text: LOS ANGELES — Investment capital? They’re loaded.

headline: Getting Government Technology Right
text: The problems with the federal health insurance website have highlighted the need for broad reform in how the government uses technology to deliver public services.

headline: Second Thoughts on Neighborhood Watches
text: Far too late to save the life of Trayvon Martin, the community of Sanford, Fla., where Mr. Martin was shot to death last year by a roaming neighborhood watch volunteer, is wisely changing course and banning civilians from packing firearms on future citizen patrols.

headline: Subject to Further Review
text: The National Football League once again finds itself searching beyond the X’s and O’s of the playing field to protect the game’s image as a rough-and-tumble entertainment rooted in innocent sport. The league has opened an investigation into accusations of locker room hazing on the Miami Dolphins that reportedly descended to racist and homophobic slurs and macho threats against a player and his mother.

headline: Lessons on Immigration in Two Governors’ Races
text: Republicans in Congress studying the results from the governors’ elections in New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday see two starkly different test cases for how the party should move on immigration.

headline: Protest Over Kelly Is Focus of Inquiry, Brown University Says
text: Brown University will investigate a protest last month that forced the cancellation of a speech by the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, and decide whether anyone should be disciplined, the university said on Wednesday.

headline: Mexico: Court Orders Full Sentence in Drug Agent’s Death, but Killer Is Free
text: The Mexico Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a lower court ruling that allowed a drug kingpin accused of murdering an American drug enforcement agent in the 1980s to walk free. The effect of the high court ruling is unclear; the drug lord, Rafael Caro Quintero, left prison Aug. 9 and may not be easy to find. The American government, which filed an extradition request for him after his release, this week offered a $5 million reward for information leading to his capture. According to the high court ruling, lower court judges made a mistake when they decided there had been a jurisdiction problem in trying Mr. Caro Quintero in federal court and ordered his release. The new ruling allows the Mexican authorities to order him back to prison to complete the remaining 12 years of his 40-year sentence for the killing of the agent, Enrique Camarena, although Mexico could choose to extradite Mr. Caro Quintero if he is found.

headline: The Netherlands Appeals Detentions of Greenpeace Activists in Russia
text: The Netherlands appealed to an international tribunal to order Russia to release a ship and 30 crew members of Greenpeace International who were detained in September while protesting offshore oil exploration in the Arctic. Russia, which has since charged the crew members with hooliganism, refused to recognize the court’s jurisdiction in what it considers an internal legal matter. The tribunal of the Law of the Sea Treaty, based in Hamburg, scheduled a ruling for Nov. 22, which could increase diplomatic pressure on Russia’s government to resolve the case.

headline: Who Should Get Financial Aid?
text: What factors should determine eligibility for financial aid from the government and from colleges? Should parents' income be considered?

headline: Virginia G.O.P. Assesses Loss to Rival It Saw as Weak
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Virginia awoke Wednesday with the knowledge that a bad streak had been extended: With the election of a Democratic governor, Terry McAuliffe, Republicans have lost seven of the past eight statewide, top-of-the-ballot races, including those for governor, senator and president — a run of misery dating to 2005.

headline: A College Degree Within Reach, Then Came the Medical Bills
text: The worst stomach ache of Manpriya Samra’s life sent her to Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn in March 2012, when doctors told her that her appendix was about to burst. An emergency surgery successfully removed the inflamed organ, but Ms. Samra soon learned that her ordeal was only just beginning.

headline: New Help for Poor Immigrants Who Are in Custody and Facing Deportation
text: At about 1:15 p.m. on Wednesday, Maximino Leyva Ortiz, wearing an orange jumpsuit, his wrists shackled, stood before a judge in an immigration courtroom in Lower Manhattan, a lawyer at his side. The federal government was seeking to deport him.

headline: An Offer From Amazon to Its Most Bitter Rivals
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon is going to the people who dislike and fear it the most — independent bookstore owners — and offering to work together to fulfill the needs and desires of their customers.

headline: Sharp Circle
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I know what you’re thinking. You’re probably thinking, “It’s a rebus. Let’s see how badly Deb messed up on this one.” And, if history is any way to predict these things, you’d be right. But not today.

headline: Playing With a Full Deck, and Your Head
text: As I write these words, I sit staring at a playing card. The five of hearts, actually. There’s nothing special about it: It’s from a classic pack, with the familiar oil-defying coating and the ornate design on the back featuring two odd winged creatures on what appear to be bicycles. (Never noticed that before.)

headline: A Cop Will Get a Killer to Sing (That’s Not a Spoiler)
text: “Murder for Two,” which opened at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in July, reopened Wednesday at the New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton; 212-239-6200, telecharge.com. Following are excerpts from the review that appeared in The New York Times on July 26; the full text is here.

headline: G.O.P. Weighs Limiting Clout of Right Wing
text: Leaders of the Republican establishment, alarmed by the emergence of far-right and often unpredictable Tea Party candidates, are pushing their party to rethink how it chooses nominees and advocating changes they say would result in the selection of less extreme contenders.

headline: An Exaggerated Vision of the Female Form in Venezuela
text: A national embrace of plastic surgery is reflected in increasing sales of mannequins with bulging bosoms and cantilevered buttocks, wasp waists and long legs.

headline: Growing Endowments Change Colleges’ Investment Strategy
text: In a year of strong gains, college endowments reversed a long-term trend toward alternative investments like private equity and venture capital funds, according to a study released Wednesday. Overall, endowments earned an 11.7 percent investment return in 2012-13, said the study, by the National Association of College and University Business Officers, and Commonfund. After years of increasing, alternative investments fell from 54 percent of assets to 47 percent. Endowment returns were sharply negative during the recession, then very strong for two years, and near zero in 2011-12.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 6, 2013
Venezuela’s Inflated Vision of Beauty
text: In Venezuela, women are confronted with a culture of increasingly enhanced physiques fueled by beauty pageants and plastic surgery.

headline: Mannequins Give Shape to a Venezuelan Fantasy
text: VALENCIA, Venezuela — Frustrated with the modest sales at his small mannequin factory, Eliezer Álvarez made a simple observation: Venezuelan women were increasingly using plastic surgery to transform their bodies, yet the mannequins in clothing stores did not reflect these new, often extreme proportions.

headline: Judge in Terrorism Case Orders Look at Secret Records
text: A judge presiding over the military commission’s prosecution of five people accused in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has ordered the government to show him confidential correspondence with the International Committee of the Red Cross about prison conditions at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a defense lawyer said Wednesday. The judge, Col. James Pohl, also issued an order taking control of the team that reviews correspondence between defense lawyers and the defendants, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. The order also relaxes some limits on what defense lawyers can discuss with their clients, said James G. Connell III, a defense lawyer for Ali Abd al Aziz Ali. The case has been bogged down in pretrial hearings, with no actual trial in sight. The judge decided that he would review the Red Cross records before deciding whether to allow the lawyers to see them.

headline: A Third Navy Official Is Arrested in Bribery Case
text: Federal prosecutors said Wednesday that a third Navy official had been arrested on charges of accepting prostitutes and luxury travel from an Asian ship-servicing company that overbilled the Navy by millions of dollars. Navy Cmdr. Jose Luis Sanchez, 41, was arrested in Tampa and was also charged with accepting $100,000 from Glenn Defense Marine Asia, whose chief executive, Leonard Glenn Francis, was arrested in September. Federal authorities in San Diego have also charged a Navy commander, Michael V.K. Misiewicz, 46, and John B. Beliveau II, a naval investigator, in the case.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,274 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: A Familiar Result in Seattle, as Voters Oust Mayor for the Third Time in 12 Years
text: SEATTLE — Seattle voters performed what has become a fall ritual: dumping the mayor.

headline: Legal Brief Filed in Support of Judge in Stop-and-Frisk Case
text: Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio has promised that on Day 1 of his administration, he would withdraw New York City’s appeal of sweeping reforms ordered by a federal judge in the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices.

headline: Arkansas: Man Charged in Power Grid Attacks
text: A 37-year-old man was indicted Wednesday in connection with a series of attacks on the power grid in Central Arkansas earlier this year. A federal grand jury charged Jason Woodring with eight counts, including a terrorist attack against a railroad carrier. Mr. Woodring was arrested last month after the authorities said he repeatedly sabotaged electrical equipment and caused at least $2.1 million in damage. In one instance, Mr. Woodring is alleged to have sought to use a moving train to down a support tower. No one was injured in the attacks, which began in August and led to brief power failures.

headline: Food Companies Claim Victory Against Labeling Initiative in Washington State
text: Some of the nation’s major food companies declared victory on Wednesday over an initiative in Washington State that would have required labeling of some foods that contain biotech ingredients, although supporters of labeling held out hope that hundreds of thousands of uncounted votes might yet turn the tide.

headline: Ace Parker, Pro Football Hall of Famer From Leather-Helmet Days, Dies at 101
text: Ace Parker, a star running back in the National Football League who could do just about everything on a football field in the days of leather helmets and 60-minute men, died on Wednesday in Portsmouth, Va. He was 101 and the oldest living member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

headline: Germany Considers Having Snowden Testify to Inquiry
text: BERLIN — The German government will examine how the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden could testify to a parliamentary inquiry into American intelligence activities in Germany, the interior minister said Wednesday, amid rising demands not only to thank Mr. Snowden for his disclosures but also to grant him full political asylum.

headline: Life on a Leaf
text: The title of a Finnish artist’s doctoral thesis is also the name of the home that it inspired.

headline: Corrections: November 7, 2013
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: N.F.L. Week 10 Game Probabilities: Balance of the Bengals
text: The A.F.C. North appears to have had a changing of the guard.

headline: Clifford Nass, Who Warned of a Data Deluge, Dies at 55
text: Clifford Nass, a Stanford professor whose pioneering research into how humans interact with technology found that the increasingly screen-saturated, multitasking modern world was not nurturing the ability to concentrate, analyze or feel empathy, died on Nov. 2 near Lake Tahoe. He was 55.

headline: Strong Mix of Art Propels a Fine Night at Sotheby’s
text: “So the market is alive, right?” asked the relieved auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, as a buoyant, two-hour sale of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby’s concluded on Wednesday night. After two dreary evening sales at Christie’s this week, fears that the art market was diving into the doldrums were dashed, at least for one night.

headline: Coalition Seeks Public’s Advice on New York City’s Goals
text: New York City’s mayoral transition will not be limited to the confines of City Hall.

headline: The Bankruptcy Exemption
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 7, 2013
text: “I say that inner beauty doesn’t exist. That’s something that unpretty women invented to justify themselves.”

headline: Red Bulls Extend Playoff Frustration
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Through 18 seasons in Major League Soccer, nothing has ever been easy for the Red Bulls. And so it was again Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena.

headline: Word of the Day | mollify
text: mollify •\ˈmä-lə-ˌfi\• verb

headline: Reports of Military Sexual Assault Rise Sharply
text: WASHINGTON — Reports of sexual assault in the military increased sharply during the last fiscal year, new Pentagon figures showed Wednesday, just weeks before a defense bill with provisions to tackle the problem is expected to reach the Senate floor.

headline: Billionaires Received U.S. Farm Subsidies, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government paid $11.3 million in taxpayer-funded farm subsidies from 1995 to 2012 to 50 billionaires or businesses in which they have some form of ownership, according to a report released Thursday by the Environmental Working Group, a Washington-based research organization.

headline: Cyprus in Plan to Develop a Natural Gas Industry
text: LONDON — Cyprus, seeking to rebuild its economy after the collapse of its banking industry, will announce on Thursday an agreement with Total, the French oil giant, to develop a plant to liquefy natural gas, the Cypriot energy minister said.

headline: Yankees Have Many Holes to Fill, and Many Phone Calls to Make
text: Facing an abundance of roster questions, the Yankees are willing to talk to virtually every free agent in the coming weeks, General Manager Brian Cashman said.

headline: Contractor Who Ran Special Education Pre-K Programs Is Charged With Fraud
text: A man who ran preschool programs for children in New York with developmental disabilities was arrested on Wednesday on charges that he diverted hundreds of thousands of dollars in government money meant to help the children to himself.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO James Lipton, who has a recurring guest role on Netflix’s “Arrested Development” as the prison warden Stefan Gentles, interviews his cast mates Will Arnett, Jason Bateman, Portia de Rossi, Alia Shawkat, Jeffrey Tambor and Jessica Walter (above with Mr. Lipton), as well as Mitchell Hurwitz, the show’s creator.

headline: Country Awards Hold Swift Close
text: How many Nashville stalwarts does it take to keep Taylor Swift in country music? That’s the question that was asked again and again at the 47th annual Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night.

headline: C.I.A. Is Said to Pay AT&T for Call Data
text: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. is paying AT&T more than $10 million a year to assist with overseas counterterrorism investigations by exploiting the company’s vast database of phone records, which includes Americans’ international calls, according to government officials.

headline: 2 French Banks Post Higher Profits and Plan Swap on Derivatives Venture
text: PARIS – Société Générale and Crédit Agricole, two of France’s biggest banks, said on Thursday that they were in talks about an asset swap that would give Société Générale full control of their Newedge Group derivatives venture.

headline: Signs of a Turnaround at Steel Giant ArcelorMittal
text: LONDON — ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, on Thursday reported a narrower loss than a year earlier, as an improving world economy helped offset persistent problems in Europe.

headline: News Quiz | Nov. 7, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 7, 2013
text: Use context clues and your knowledge of word roots to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

headline: Guangzhou Gives Hope to China’s Long-Suffering Soccer Fans
text: There have been numerous new dawns in Chinese soccer over the years, but this Saturday may witness the birth of a genuinely exciting period as Guangzhou Evergrande looks to become the first club from the world’s most populous country to become the champion of Asia since 1990.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Hundreds of Forgotten Art Works Found Hidden in Germany
text: The article “German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art” describes a recent discovery in Germany that astonished the art world.

headline: Indian Lawmaker Charged With Information Law Activist’s Murder
text: NEW DELHI — A member of the Indian parliament has been arrested on the charges of conspiring to kill a Right to Information activist in the western state of Gujarat. The arrest on Wednesday took place more than three years after the murder.

headline: Lee Harvey Oswald Was My Friend
text: It was 7 a.m. on Sunday when the single phone at the bottom of the stairs echoed through my parents’ red-brick house, right off Monticello Park in Fort Worth. “Mr. Gregory,” a woman said as my father picked up, “I need your help.” Who are you? he asked in his Texas-Russian accent, still half-asleep.

headline: Stars of the Silver Screen in Black Sweaters
text: In one of Victor Skrebneski’s earliest memories from the 1930s, he is 4 years old and sitting in the fifth row at Chicago’s Standard movie theater for a matinee double bill. His neck strains as he looks almost straight up at the towering image of Frankenstein.

headline: What Can Older People Learn From Your Generation?
text: In an article currently on the most emailed list, a baby boomer describes how his 25-year-old son does what he loves, even if it doesn’t earn him much money. His son’s life, he writes, is making him rethink how “success” might be measured.

headline: Greek Police Raid Occupied Broadcasting Building
text: ATHENS — Greek riot police officers raided the headquarters of the country’s former state broadcaster, ERT, on Thursday, forcibly removing dozens of staff members who had been occupying the building since June, when the authorities abruptly shut down the organization, citing wasteful spending.

headline: Earnings at Siemens Dip
text: FRANKFURT — The German engineering and electronics giant Siemens said on Thursday that its profit fell 10 percent in the quarter ended Sept. 30 as sales dipped and the company booked restructuring costs.

headline: Beijing Seeking a Break in the Impasse over North Korea
text: For a diplomat who reportedly does not like to fly — no-smoking cabins cut into his nicotine habit – Wu Dawei, China’s special representative for Korean Peninsula affairs, has been a busy man.

headline: Nestlé to Sell Its Jenny Craig Brand to Private Equity Firm
text: LONDON — Nestlé, the Swiss food giant, said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its Jenny Craig brand in North America and Australia, New Zealand and other parts of the Pacific region to North Castle Partners, a Connecticut private equity firm focused on health and wellness businesses.

headline: SEMA Show: A Candy Factory for the Auto Enthusiast
text: LAS VEGAS — The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show here can sound rather boring when just the facts are recited: about 2,500 vendors showing some 2,000 new products in one million square feet of exhibit space.

headline: New York Today: Stealth Drought
text: Updated 11:53 a.m. | There’s news in the weather forecast today: It may rain a tenth of an inch or so.

headline: Why Zimbabwe Sanctions Boomerang
text: Few Robert Mugabe speeches over the past 10 years have failed to include some blazing rhetorical flourish against the West. “Shame, shame, shame to the United States of America. Shame, shame, shame to Britain and its allies,” he declared at the United Nations General Assembly in September. “Zimbabwe is for Zimbabweans, so are its resources. Please remove your illegal and filthy sanctions from my peaceful country.”

headline: U.S. Signals Flexibility as Iran Nuclear Talks Resume
text: GENEVA — Negotiators from Iran and six world powers convened in Geneva on Thursday as American officials signaled that the United States was prepared to offer Iran limited relief from economic sanctions if it agreed to halt its nuclear development program and reverse part of it.

headline: Inspectors in Syria Have Only One Site Left to Check
text: LONDON — International chemical weapons inspectors reported further progress on Thursday in eliminating Syria’s stockpile, saying they had verified the destruction of 22 of the 23 sites that the Syrian government declared had been used for the production and mixing of the banned munitions.

headline: The Kombi Madeleine
text: SÃO BERNARDO DO CAMPO, Brazil — Over more than a half-century of production here, the Volkswagen Kombi, or minivan, has been many things to Brazil: ambulance, fire truck, hearse, food vendor, impromptu furniture store, school bus and sugar-cane juice dispenser — to name just a few. For most people in this nation of immigrants it is a Brazilian car with distant German roots.

headline: Bank of England Holds Rate Steady
text: LONDON — Britain’s central bank on Thursday decided to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low amid signs that the country’s economic recovery was gaining speed and consumer confidence improved.

headline: Ex-Leader Of Pakistan Is Released On Bail
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s former military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, was freed on bail Thursday after six months under house arrest.

headline: Tiananmen Attack Linked to Police Raid on a Mosque in Xinjiang
text: Could the attackers responsible for a deadly assault on the heart of the Chinese capital on Oct. 28 have been motivated by revenge? That is the theory offered up by a former local official from the hometown of Usmen Hasan, the man identified by the Chinese police as the driver of a car that struck and killed two tourists before going up in flames at Tiananmen Square.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter’s I.P.O. Takes Flight, Despite Slowing Growth
text: With 70 million shares sold in its initial public offering, Twitter has raised $1.8 billion. But as Twitter it makes the transition to a publicly traded company, attracting and retaining users has become one of its biggest challenges, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: European Central Bank Makes a Surprise Rate Cut
text: FRANKFURT — In an unexpectedly swift reaction to economic warning signals, the European Central Bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low on Thursday, moving to head off what some economists fear could be a long period of stagnation like the one that has afflicted Japan.

headline: Opening With a Pop, Key Moments From Twitter’s First Day of Trading
text: Updated, 4:22 p.m. | Twitter began life as a public company on Thursday, and DealBook followed the first day of trading as it happened.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Gut Feeling
text: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a previously healthy 47-year-old woman who for the past two years has had episodes of abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting so severe she has needed to be hospitalized?

headline: Warburg Pincus Names General Counsel
text: The private equity firm Warburg Pincus has appointed Robert B. Knauss, a corporate partner at the law firm Munger, Tolles & Olson in Los Angeles, as general counsel and managing director.

headline: Twitter’s Big Day
text: Twitter is ready for its Wall Street debut. The social media company set the price of its initial public offering at $26 a share on Wednesday evening, raising $1.8 billion and achieving a valuation of $18.1 billion, Vindu Goel reports in The New York Times. Its stock is set to begin trading on Thursday under the ticker symbol TWTR on the New York Stock Exchange. The I.P.O. price, a subject of debate between the board and its underwriters until late on Wednesday afternoon, came in above an already heightened price range, reflecting strong demand for the stock, Mr. Goel reports.

headline: Struggling to Manage a Multigenerational Staff
text: At the last She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about some of their most pressing concerns, including hiring high-level employees and managing a multigenerational staff.

headline: Growth Gain Blurs Signs of Weakness in Economy
text: Five years after the global economy was falling at its fastest rate, Western economies are still failing to gain much-needed momentum, despite the efforts of central bankers on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Social Security’s Job
text: Does Social Security need to be fixed?

headline: Nest’s Tony Fadell on Smart Objects, and the Singularity of Innovation
text: Tony Fadell is the founder and chief executive of Nest, a company that is trying to bring a high-end technology experience to some of the most prosaic areas of the home. Nest’s first product was a thermostat, which it followed with a smoke alarm.

headline: A Day That Will Live In IMFamy Forever
text: Or, actually, maybe not, since as far as I know it’s only being live-streamed. But anyway, I’m at the Jacques Polak research conference at the IMF, and the livestream is here. My own talk is at 4.

headline: Manmohan Singh’s Sri Lanka Dilemma
text: On Nov. 15, the presidents and the prime ministers of an array of countries once ruled by the British Empire will assemble in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, for the annual meeting of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

headline: F.D.A. Ruling Would All but Eliminate Trans Fats
text: The Food and Drug Administration proposed measures on Thursday that would all but eliminate artery-clogging, artificial trans fats from the food supply, the culmination of three decades of effort by public health advocates to get the government to take action against them.

headline: Identifying With the Bulldogs
text: The bulldog is no longer just the sports mascot at Fresno State. It has been appropriated by a violent street gang called the Bulldogs, vexing university officials.

headline: Fresno State Loves Its Bulldogs, but So Does a Gang
text: FRESNO, Calif. — Bulldogs can be seen snarling from flagpoles, from baseball caps, from T-shirts and from tattoos — one man has the dog’s face inked across his torso, its behind across his back. Young men on street corners bark at passing patrol officers. They call their children “little dogs” or “bull puppies.” Police raids find their targets asleep beneath red blankets emblazoned with the dog.

headline: In Oslo, an Art Rock Hotel
text: Guests staying in a newly renovated suite at The Thief, a boutique hotel in Oslo, Norway, are being offered the latest in luxury amenities: the chance to share a room with some rock stars.

headline: Sherman Alexie: By the Book
text: The author of “The Lone Ranger and Tonto Fistfight in Heaven” and “The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian” would love to go on a date with Dorothy Parker and “get verbally eviscerated.”

headline: The Opening Bell for Twitter
text: The actor Patrick Stewart and Vivienne Harr, a 9-year-old who has been protesting slavery, rang the opening bell before Twitter began trading shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Pick Hard-Liner as Leader, Imperiling Proposed Peace Talks
text: LONDON — In a surprise choice that bodes poorly for proposed peace talks, the Pakistani Taliban on Thursday appointed as their new leader the hard-line commander responsible for last year’s attack on Malala Yousafzai, the teenage Pakistani education activist.

headline: In Our Pages: November 8
text: 1938 Reich Embassy Secretary Shot

headline: Theme Parks and Movies Propel Profit at Disney
text: LOS ANGELES — Disney ended its fiscal year in blockbuster style on Thursday, reporting solid growth in fourth-quarter profit, unveiling a substantial Netflix deal and savoring a stock price that has climbed 35 percent over the last 12 months.

headline: Fast-Paced Evolution in the Andes
text: In 1799 the great naturalist Alexander von Humboldt and his companions set out from Caracas, Venezuela, to climb the Andes. They struggled up a mountainside enveloped in mist so thick they had to clamber over rocks by hand. When the fog cleared, von Humboldt was left astonished by the view. Vast grasslands stretched all around him, home to an astonishing number of different trees, shrubs and flowers.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: The Mets and Cano
text: The Mets are in desperate need of a left-handed power hitter who can bat cleanup in their lineup behind David Wright and give the batting order an identity.

headline: U.S. Reading and Math Scores Show Slight Gains
text: American fourth and eighth graders showed incremental gains in reading and math this year, but achievement gaps between whites and blacks, whites and Hispanics, and low-income and more affluent students stubbornly persist, data released by the Education Department on Thursday showed.

headline: When Advanced Math Placement Is a Struggle
text: This week’s question is an amalgam of two questions, but because I have received quite a few inquiries about ability grouping, I thought I’d do a mash-up in order to cover all the issues surrounding the challenge of academic placement.

headline: Feeling For | Bespoke Stationery From Cartier
text: Marco Zanini, the newly appointed creative director for the house of Schiaparelli, pens a love note to Cartier’s custom stationery.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Gone, Gone Again’
text: This Poetry Pairing commemorates Veterans Day, which will be celebrated in the United States on Monday. It pairs the poem “Gone, Gone Again” by Edward Thomas, which was published in 1917, with the ArtsBeat blog post “Kerry James Evans: From Combat Engineer to Poet” by Dana Jennings.

headline: Unequal Progress on Standardized Tests
text: Average scores on the National Assessment of Educational Progress have been rising but large disparities among races and economic classes remain.

headline: A Mysterious Realm of Exquisite Objects
text: Here’s a good question for “Jeopardy!”: One of the world’s longest-running dynasties, it emerged around 57 B.C. and grew to dominate the Korean Peninsula in the seventh and eighth centuries before meeting its demise in A.D. 935.

headline: If Congress Were Swayed by Facts…
text: If Congress were swayed by facts and evidence, lawmakers would not be considering cuts to food stamps and unemployment benefits. And the White House would rethink the cuts to Social Security that it included in its most recent budget.

headline: Counting the Costs of the Civil War
text: While the desire to document military exploits and wars is as old as writing itself, the recording of military medical data is a relatively modern phenomenon. Although some initial attempts to chronicle the health of troops occurred in the first half of the 19th century, the first large-scale, wartime medical and behavioral health surveillance effort was conducted during the American Civil War.

headline: Possible Meteor Over California Has Social Media Abuzz
text: A fireball lit up the sky over Southern California around 8 p.m. Wednesday, and scientists are saying that it may have been part of a South Taurid meteor shower.

headline: Image of the Day: November 7
text: The International Krishi Mela, or farmers’ festival commenced in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Thursday.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Matchup Breakdown
text: After the Indianapolis Colts’ Reggie Wayne was lost for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament, it was assumed that the team’s talented second-year wide receiver, T. Y. Hilton, would become the top receiving option for Andrew Luck. It took Hilton a couple of quarters to warm up Sunday night against the Houston Texans before racking up 114 yards and 3 touchdowns in the second half.

headline: Wheelies: The Hydrogen Toyota Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
text: Tropical looks used to be best left at the beach, but this season printed bags, chunky sandals and Hawaiian shirts hit the street in a sophisticated mash-up.

headline: After the Curtain
text: What happens to the characters in Mozart’s popular “Così Fan Tutte” when the curtain goes down? The love stories in the opera end so inconclusively that questions remain even for the cast.

headline: Liberating the Librettos
text: Most opera fans are intensely involved with the characters of great operas. We are protective of them, even the evil ones.

headline: Lee Harvey Oswald’s Wedding Ring, His Widow and an Anonymous Bidder
text: In this weekend’s magazine, Paul Gregory reflects on his friendship with Lee Harvey Oswald in the early 1960s. Here, Deirdre Bair writes about Oswald’s widow, Marina, and her remembrance of her late husband’s wedding ring.

headline: End of an Era: Yesterday’s Joy Became Today’s Inconvenience
text: It should be hard to say goodbye to a car that you’ve owned for almost 40 years, but that was not the case with my classic. My recently departed car was a 1974 Jensen-Healey. I’m sure you understand.

headline: V.A. Is Faulted Over Landmarks’ Condition
text: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of landmark buildings where wounded soldiers have received treatment, some dating back to the Civil War, are at risk of being abandoned or demolished because of poor management by officials at the Department of Veterans Affairs, preservationists said in a report released on Thursday.

headline: Wendy Davis, Texas Legislator, to Write Memoir
text: Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator whose 11-hour legislative filibuster of an abortion bill gave her instant fame in the Democratic Party, is about to take the next logical step in her political ascent: writing a memoir.

headline: Today in Small Business: Amazon’s Trojan Rabbit
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Carnegie Hall Benefit to Turn Nathan Lane Into Nathan Detroit Once Again
text: For one night Nathan Lane will again roll the dice as the gambler Nathan Detroit in Carnegie Hall’s concert staging of “Guys and Dolls,” the music hall announced on Thursday.

headline: Colon Cancer Screening Lags
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all adults aged 50 to 75 be screened for colorectal cancer, but the agency announced this week that one third of them — 23 million people — have never been properly tested.

headline: The Long-Term Cost of Feckless Policy
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

text: Tropical looks used to be best left at the beach, but this season printed bags, chunky sandals and Hawaiian shirts hit the street in a sophisticated mash-up.

headline: White House Tours Resume
text: The White House has resumed public tours of the executive residence and East Wing this week, after severe cuts to the government’s budget in March, known as sequestration, ended the visits, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Senate Approves Ban on Antigay Bias in Workplace
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved a ban on discrimination in the workplace based on sexual orientation and gender identity, voting 64 to 32 in a bipartisan show of support that is rare for any social issue. It was the first time in the institution’s history that it had voted to include gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people in the country’s nondiscrimination law.

headline: Ruling From the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
text: Jesse M. Furman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, found that the city, through “benign neglect,” was in violation of the of the Americans of Disabilities Act.

headline: What Our Patients Can Teach Us
text: When the man who was about to become my patient couldn’t tolerate the fatigue any longer, he asked his son, one of 10 children, to take him in their buggy from his woodworking shop to the local doctor who tended to this Amish community, located 90 miles south of Cleveland. Labs showed a white blood cell count that was 12 times normal and profound anemia, and he was driven by ambulance to our hospital.

headline: Kerry Takes Personal Approach to Mideast Peace
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Traveling around the Middle East with Secretary of State John Kerry, particularly for a reporter whose last State Department tour was with Hillary Rodham Clinton, is a seat-of-the-pants experience. Itineraries are notional. Improvisation is the rule.

headline: Goldman Discloses Foreign Exchange Inquiry
text: LONDON—Goldman Sachs on Thursday became the latest big bank to acknowledge that it was the subject of a series of wide-ranging investigations into the potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland to Pay $153.7 Million to Settle Mortgage Case
text: Updated, 8:14 p.m. |

headline: Michael Palmer, Doctor Who Became Top Author, Dies at 71
text: Dr. Michael Palmer, a physician who began writing tightly plotted thrillers at his kitchen table in 1978 to escape the inner chaos of alcohol and drug addiction, in the process finding a worldwide audience (and sobriety) as the author of top sellers like “Extreme Measures” and “Natural Causes,” died on Oct. 30 in Queens. He was 71.

headline: The Gun Report: November 7, 2013
text: The father of Jose Reyes, the 12-year-old boy who killed a math teacher and wounded two classmates before committing suicide at a Sparks, Nev., middle school on Oct. 21, said the handgun his son used was procured from their home and wasn’t locked up. Jose Reyes and his wife, Liliana, said they never told him where the 9mm semi-automatic pistol was stored, but he somehow managed to find it.

headline: Katia Beauchamp of Birchbox, on the Strength of Optimism
text: This interview with Katia Beauchamp, co-founder and co-chief executive of Birchbox, a beauty products website, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Court Says New York Neglected Disabled in Emergencies
text: New York City has violated the rights of about 900,000 of its residents with disabilities by failing to accommodate for their needs during emergencies, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: Scene City: At AREA Nightclubbing as an Art Form
text: AREA, the legendary nightclub from 30 years ago, reopens for one night only.

headline: The CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund: Where No Designer Is Left Behind
text: Many have landed high-profile positions or new backers. But has it all been a bed of roses?

headline: Card Act Cleared Up Credit Cards’ Hidden Costs
text: Four years ago, Congress decided to force down the hidden fees that credit card companies collect from their customers. It passed a law called the 2009 Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act — a name chosen so the law would be known as the Card Act.

headline: Imported From Turkey, a Taste of Home
text: For proof of how far hard work and a good attitude can take you in life, one could do worse than drop in at Lisa’s Mediterranean Cuisine in downtown Ridgewood.

headline: Reaction Is Cautiously Positive to India’s Bank Rules
text: MUMBAI — New regulations issued by India’s central bank would make it easier and more attractive for global banks to enter the Indian market, a senior banker and several analysts said on Thursday, though they cautioned that restrictions in the rules might slow the pace of expansion.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Player Tiers
text: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: My Caribbean: 5 Vignettes
text: How do you define the Caribbean? Writers intimately acquainted with the islands answer with postcards from their ancestral homes.

headline: Festivals Where the Beat Makes You Move
text: Am I the only one who returns from the Caribbean acutely in need of rest? Blame the music. The region is drenched in genres I crave — reggae, calypso, zouk, and the list goes on — which means that night after night has me feeling like Odysseus battling the Sirens: cursed be that delicious din at the dancehall or the rum shop, destined to foil my fantasy of an early night’s sleep.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Looking to Norwegian, 22, to Revive Image of Chess
text: On Saturday, Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, and Viswanathan Anand, a 43-year-old Indian, will stride to the center of a stage in a hotel in Chennai, India, shake hands and sit down at a chess board to begin a match for the world championship title.

headline: Rev. Eugene Callender, Who Saw Potential of School Dropouts, Dies at 87
text: The Rev. Dr. Eugene S. Callender, a civil rights advocate best known for starting an innovative series of “street academies” for disadvantaged New York City youths that became a model for nontraditional educational programs nationwide, died on Nov. 2 in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: British Intelligence Chiefs Say Leaks by Snowden Hurt Security
text: LONDON — Britain’s intelligence chiefs, in unprecedented public testimony before Parliament, said on Thursday that the published leaks of secret documents stolen by Edward J. Snowden, the former American intelligence analyst, had damaged their ability to keep Britain safe.

headline: Congo Rebels, After Giving Up Struggle, Are Disarmed
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Ugandan military has begun the process of disarming large numbers of rebels from the neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo, a military spokesman said Thursday.

headline: Living With Cancer: Tumbling Blocks
text: On a night several months ago, the digital clock blinked 11:53. My husband was asleep so I crept down the hall, only turning on a light when I got into my study. On a sheet on the floor were fabrics laid out for a new quilt in the tumbling block pattern. Pictures of my friends kept me company, but there was no photo of the woman over whom I was grieving.

headline: Hedge Fund Is Said to Push for Men’s Wearhouse Merger
text: Over the last two months, Men’s Wearhouse has steadfastly rebuffed a $2.3 billion takeover bid by a smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank.

headline: The Intrepid’s Re-enlisted Artifacts
text: Veterans of World War II and Vietnam War service on the Intrepid aircraft carrier, despite miserable living conditions aboard, developed sentimental attachments to souvenirs. Hundreds of artifacts have been donated in the last few months to the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in New York, in honor of the carrier’s 70th anniversary.

headline: So Far, So Good for Twitter
text: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange called out orders for shares of Twitter for the first time Thursday morning as one of Wall Street’s traditional rituals thrust the young company into the public markets.
