text: LONDON — The shop window has a flock of baby chicks apparently skittering by bold handbags. Inside, there are purses shaped like crumpled potato chip bags and beach totes with smiley suns and the words “Have a Nice Day.”

headline: On Field and on Sideline, Changes Bring Same Result for Texans
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The understudy Wade Phillips played an N.F.L. head coach on Sunday, and in some respects, it was as if nothing had changed since the last time he inhabited the role. Phillips, relieved of his lead position with a one-win Dallas Cowboys team three Novembers ago, was again at the helm of an underachieving Texas team, a Super Bowl contender gone bad.

headline: Textbooks Reassess Kennedy, Putting Camelot Under Siege

headline: In Detroit, Protests of Shooting of Woman Who Sought Help
text: Civil rights groups protested in Detroit this weekend after a young black woman was shot on the porch of a suburban home earlier this month, as she apparently sought help after she had car trouble.

headline: Behind E-Commerce Spree, a Day for ‘Bare Branches’
text: China’s burgeoning, one-day e-commerce festival goes by several names — Bare Branch Day, Singles Day (in English), the Double Eleventh. Observed every year on Nov. 11, it’s roughly the equivalent of Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined, with a “Not Valentine’s Day” thrown in for good measure. A festival aimed at the unmarried, this year it’s expected to clock up sales — on mostly discounted online goods — of about 30 billion renminbi, or $5 billion, the state media estimated.

headline: Encouraging Paid Employment
text: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Rethinking ‘Term Pregnancy’
text: Anyone who has roasted a turkey knows that if you take it from the oven too soon, it will not have cooked through, and if you leave it in too long, it will be dry and tough.

headline: Warnings on Children’s Drugs Found to Help Curb Misuse
text: In 2007, amid mounting concern that infant cough and cold medicines were unsafe and misused, manufacturers voluntarily withdrew products intended for children younger than 2. The makers revised the labels on the rest of the medicines, which now warn parents that they should not be given to children younger than 4.

headline: Evolving Portraits of J.F.K.
text: While textbook writers have been consistent in describing President John F. Kennedy’s charisma and ability to inspire the country, they have become more critical of his handling of issues from civil rights to the Cuban missile crisis and the Vietnam War.

headline: Postal Service to Make Sunday Deliveries for Amazon
text: WASHINGTON — The cash-short United States Postal Service, which has failed to win congressional approval to stop delivering mail on Saturdays to save money, has struck a deal with the online retailer Amazon.com to deliver the company’s packages on Sundays — a first for both, with obvious advantages for each.

headline: Gun Violence in American Movies Is Rising, Study Finds
text: LOS ANGELES — A study set for publication in the December issue of Pediatrics confirms what some of Hollywood’s sharpest critics have suspected: The level of gun violence in the top-selling PG-13 movies has been rising, and it now exceeds that in the most popular R-rated films.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 3-9

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) CRISIS HOTLINE: VETERANS PRESS 1 (2013) Since 2001, more veterans have committed suicide than have died in combat in Iraq and Afghanistan, according to the United States Department of Veterans Affairs. The Veterans Crisis Line in Canandaigua, N.Y., receives more than 22,000 calls each month from former soldiers who are contemplating ending their lives because of the psychological wounds of war and the challenges of returning to civilian life. In this documentary in honor of Veterans Day, Ellen Goosenberg Kent examines the traumas endured by veterans, and the hotline’s trained responders, above, who provide support in the hope of saving lives.

headline: China’s One-Day Shopping Spree Sets Record in Online Sales
text: HANGZHOU, China — Unmarried men across China used to spend Nov. 11 lamenting their single status with a drink. Now that unofficial holiday has become the world’s largest online shopping event.

headline: Delhi Battles Dengue Fever
text: NEW DELHI — Shakuntala, a 35-year-old domestic worker who uses only one name, watched, puzzled, as a city official poured water from a can placed outside her house into an empty paint bucket. Located in one of the many unauthorized slums of the capital, the house stands on the edge of a pond of muddy brown water. A herd of pigs frolicked about in the garbage that was collecting on the periphery of the water.

headline: Greek Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
text: ATHENS — The Greek government survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament early on Monday after its main political rival, the leftist Syriza, failed to gain adequate support for its censure motion. The coalition, however, saw its slim majority reduced further after one of its legislators broke ranks.

headline: What Are the Best Ways to Learn About History?
text: There are many ways to learn about history, including visiting historical sites, memorials and museums. People can also learn about the past from those who lived it, such as those who serve or are serving in the military and whom we formally honor on Veterans Day.

headline: Protests Escalate in Bangkok, Rattling Government and Raising Fears of Clashes
text: BANGKOK — With thousands of antigovernment protesters in the streets of Bangkok on Monday, Thailand’s opposition announced a campaign of civil disobedience, including a three-day general strike later this week and a call for businesses to delay paying their taxes.

headline: Kerry Tries to Reassure Mideast Allies on Iran
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Secretary of State John Kerry sought to reassure this Persian Gulf ally on Monday that negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program would not put its security at risk, and he pleaded with critics of a deal, notably Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, not to try to scuttle an accord before the details were hammered out.

text: Updated 12:05 p.m. | New York City’s Veterans Day parade, which steps off this morning, has marched a long way.

headline: The Day the Lights Went Out
text: In 2003, a blackout crippled areas of the U.S. and Canada, leaving some 50 million people in the dark. Ten years later, we are still grappling with concerns over the vulnerability of the power grid.

headline: China Offers Relatively Modest Aid for Typhoon Victims
text: As international aid pours into the Philippines for victims of Typhoon Haiyan, China has offered $100,000 in cash, a figure that seems modest compared with its other recent contributions for humanitarian relief abroad.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jonathan Mahler on Mike Rice, Rehabilitation and Aggression in College Sports
text: Jonathan Mahler, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about Mike Rice, the Rutgers basketball coach who was fired for mistreating his players. Mahler last wrote for the magazine about Oakland’s Occupy movement.

headline: The Blackout That Exposed the Flaws in the Grid
text: On a late Thursday afternoon in the summer of 2003, everything turned off. As this week’s Retro Report video illustrates, in the span of a few minutes, the biggest power outage in United States history brought swaths of the Northeast, the Midwest and Canada to a standstill. Around 50 million people were left without power. In the days and weeks that followed, reporters and investigators raced to pinpoint the source of the outage, while larger questions swirled about the stability of the power grid in the 21st century. Here, a Times reporter who covers energy technology reflects on that day and the changes that resulted.

headline: Daily Report: Hoping to See Big Pictures in a Blizzard of Tiny Data Points
text: David Soloff is recruiting an army of “hyperdata” collectors, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: A Business Owner’s First Brush With HealthCare.gov
text: A couple of years ago I wrote the following: “I would like to be able to go to my insurer’s Web site, and go to a page that generates an instant rate adjustment based on a brief description of a possible new hire. Let’s say I get to enter the age and sex (and maybe whether they smoke) of the prospective employee and any others in their family. Then I get a number right then and there that tells me what this will do to my insurance rates.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 11, 2013

headline: Markets Evolve, as Does Financial Fraud
text: It is usually the case that there are not new frauds, just new avenues for deception. As the financial world has evolved into a high-speed race to trade assets while investment strategies are kept secret, both regulators and investors face the challenge of finding the fine line between permissible trading and manipulation aimed at generating unfair profits.

headline: Struggle for Survival in Philippine City Shattered by Typhoon
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Decomposing bodies still lie along the roads, like a corpse in a pink, short-sleeve shirt and blue shorts facedown in a black, muddy puddle 100 yards from the airport. Just down the road is a church that was supposed to be an evacuation center but is littered with the bodies of those who drowned inside.

headline: Snapshots From the Fall Art Season in London
text: LONDON — The tiny figures are painted in brushstrokes thinner than a hair — a bride dressed in festive red, merchants with their wares, would-be bureaucrats studying for a state exam in a state pavilion — set against a bay, a stand of trees. They are part of “Prosperous Suzhou,” a vast panorama of urban life painted in 1759 by Xu Yang, one of the many works on view in “Masterpieces of Chinese Painting 700-1900” at the Victoria & Albert Museum here through Jan. 19.

headline: Separating the Market-Moving Tweets From the Chaff
text: Carl C. Icahn wields it as a megaphone. Traders and analysts use it to chat publicly about stocks. Eyewitnesses employ it to post messages about news events before they make headlines.

headline: India’s Politicians Ignore Women Voters in Election Campaigns

headline: Protests Over Delay of Election in Maldives
text: NEW DELHI — Political turmoil deepened in the Maldives on Monday as the police clashed with protesters after a third attempt to hold a presidential election was thrown off course by a court order.

text: PARIS — The International Atomic Energy Agency said on Monday that Iran had agreed to resolve all outstanding issues with the agency and would allow international inspectors “managed access” to two important nuclear facilities that have not been regularly viewed.

headline: Fresh Ideas on Wall Street
text: New rules and new technology are changing the way Wall Street does business. That has led to innovation, but it has also meant that old tricks appear in new guises, as DealBook shows in its fall special section on ideas and innovation.

headline: Amy Robach of ABC Says On-Air Mammogram Found Breast Cancer
text: Amy Robach, an anchor on ABC’s “Good Morning America,” had avoided her doctor’s recommendation for a mammogram screening for a year, when a producer for the show called at the end of September and asked her to consider undergoing a televised mammogram.

headline: On Losing a Veteran Son to a Broken System
text: As a parent, you spend your entire life trying to protect your children. You provide them with the very best you can; you hope they learn from your mistakes. It’s so easy when they are young and a simple “because I said so” is reason enough.

headline: Bloody End for Iranian Rockers Seeking Musical Freedom in U.S.
text: For their music they had risked the wrath of Iran’s government, practicing American-style rock in makeshift soundproof studios and performing it in underground clubs and parking lots, despite the threat of fines, detention or arrest. Growing up together in Tehran, they had found a sound: part punk, part garage rock, part their own invention.

headline: Leading Syrian Opposition Group, Yielding to Pressure, Votes to Join Peace Talks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — During the fractious weekend debates that ended with the main Syrian exile opposition coalition yielding to international pressure by dropping its refusal to hold peace talks with President Bashar al-Assad’s government, tensions ran so high that one prominent coalition member slapped another in the face, participants in the gathering said.

headline: Honesty That Benefits All
text: It seems that headlines too often highlight the bad deeds of players in financial markets. There are insider trading scandals. Traders collude on interest rate manipulation. Executives backdate options. We often hear the excuse, “Everyone else was doing it, so I didn’t think it was wrong.”

headline: The Francis Era: Synthesis or Civil War?
text: My colleague Laurie Goodstein had a good piece yesterday about conservative Catholics who feel unsettled by Pope Francis’s approach to the papal office, which seems like a good hook for returning, a month later, to my own take on the Francis experiment. In that piece, I talked a bit about the idea of a “religious center” — meaning a way of being religious that’s simultaneously modern and devout, engaged with contemporary realities but still rooted in a recognizably Biblical worldview – and argued that since the 1960s it’s become harder for believers of any traditional faith to claim that kind of ground. The tendency, instead, has been toward either toward a kind of separatism and retrenchment on the one hand, or accommodation and then often dissolution on the other – and this has been true for Jews and Protestants as it has been for Catholics.

headline: Pumpkin Pie
text: One of my all-time favorite pies, this one is sweet with spices but not very sugary. Because of the small amount of molasses, this is darker than classic pumpkin pie. Make it with fresh roasted pumpkin, or use canned pumpkin. I am finding small “pie pumpkins” in supermarkets, and they’re perfect for the job.

headline: Apple Tart With Almond Topping in a Gluten-Free Shell
text: This tart is inspired by a recipe by Jacquy Pfeiffer, from his upcoming cookbook “The Art of French Pastry.” The apples are caramelized first with sugar and spices, then spread in the pastry, topped with an almond, egg white and sugar topping, and baked.

text: I like this as much without a crust as with one. It’s not a flan in the traditional sense, with a caramel component. It’s an irresistibly creamy one. If you use 2 eggs instead of 3 (see variation) the texture will be smoother but it won’t slice as neatly.

text: From around the Internet, disheartening news about the difficulties confronting veterans.

headline: Janneke Straub Named Executive Director of Ojai Music Festival
text: The Ojai Music Festival, a classical music festival long known for its championship of adventurous contemporary works, announced on Sunday that it has appointed Janneke Straub as its executive director, starting in January. Ms. Straub comes to the festival from the American Youth Symphony, where she has been executive director since 2008. Before that, she spent 13 years at the Los Angeles Philharmonic, where she raised money for projects that included several new-music commissioning programs.

headline: Why I Let My Son (Finally) Join the Boy Scouts
text: My son started asking back in first grade: “Mom, can I join Boy Scouts?”

headline: Saying a Chapter of War Is Ending, Obama Vows Aid for Veterans
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama pledged Monday that Americans “will never forget” the sacrifices made by the country’s military veterans, and promised that his administration would continue pushing for money to support the men and women home from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Scene City | Starlets and Artists Toast Guggenheim
text: Dior drew a fashionable crowd at the Guggenheim International Gala.

headline: Stepping Up With a Plan to Save American Cities
text: FOR decades, cities and states that needed more cash for their workers’ pensions have turned to local taxpayers, the municipal bond market or even the workers themselves. Now those options appear to be drying up.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 5-11, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: For $99, Eliminating the Mystery of Pandora’s Genetic Box
text: IF DNA is destiny, then Anne Wojcicki is in the right business.

headline: On the Ground in Tacloban
text: The Times’s Keith Bradsher reported on the devastation in Tacloban, the Philippines, days after Typhoon Haiyan ripped through the city.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: American Advertising Federation, Washington, renamed its annual Addy Awards competition as the American Advertising Awards. James Edmund Datri, president and chief executive of the organization, said he hoped that local chapters would still call the awards that are presented to winners Addy awards.

headline: Fans and Friends React to the Shooting Deaths of Iranian Band Members
text: Early Monday, a rock musician in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, killed three other musicians before taking his own life, the police and neighbors said. Two of the victims were members of a rock band of Iranian expatriates called the Yellow Dogs. The gunman was another Iranian-American musician, the police said.

headline: Slowing the Revolving Door Between Public and Private Jobs
text: It has been called “corrupt,” “corrosive” and “hazardous to our health.” Yet, Washington’s revolving door spins on.

headline: Chanel, Self-Appointed Guardian of Paris’s Artisan Workshops
text: When fashion’s Old World specialty ateliers were on the verge of extinction, Chanel came to the rescue. Now it’s ushering them into the future.

headline: A Jolt to Complacency on Food Supply
text: For a look at what climate change could do to the world’s food supply, consider what the weather did to the American Corn Belt last year.

headline: For Better Performance, Hedge Funds Seek the Inner Trader
text: In the hedge fund industry, as in sports, performance is everything.

headline: Giving People a Glimpse of What Their Pets See
text: FORGET about a bird’s-eye view. A leader in pet foods is introducing a digital campaign for a principal brand that promises to provide views from the dog’s- and cat’s-eye perspective.

headline: Braves Plan to Leave Turner Field for Suburbs
text: The Atlanta Braves said Monday that they will leave Turner Field in four years for a ballpark they plan to build in the wealthy northern suburbs where most of their fans live. The move follows one already planned by the N.F.L.’s Atlanta Falcons, who have said that they will stay downtown but will trade their current home in the Georgia Dome for a retractable-roof stadium to be built nearby at a cost of $1.2 billion.

headline: Aaron Glick Awarded T Fellowship for Theater Producers
text: Aaron Glick, a theater producer whose productions have included the PigPen Theater Company’s Off Broadway staging of “The Old Man and the Old Moon,” has been awarded a T Fellowship, a one-year program meant to support the development of emerging producers.

headline: Cruise Lines Are Ready for Some Football
text: Over the last few years, it seems as if major cruise lines have been harnessing the star power of every kind of celebrity to sell more voyages. Some feature food from Top Chefs, entertainment from American Idols or even a chance to sail the Caribbean with the members of the band Kiss.

headline: 20 Million in Mideast to Get Polio Vaccine
text: Health officials will try to get polio vaccines to more than 20 million children across the Middle East to contain a major outbreak there, the World Health Organization and Unicef announced last week.

headline: Fighting Across the Rappahannock
text: Charlie Clark basked in the warmth of a budding romance on a cold autumn day in 1863. His friend and fellow lieutenant in the Union Army, Solomon Russell, had fallen for a Southern belle in war-torn Virginia. On the morning of Nov. 7, 1863, the officers left their camp in Warrenton to call upon her. They made their way to the home of the widow Rosina Dixon and found the focus of Russell’s desire: the 15-year-old Anna. Whatever words passed between the Yankee officer and rebel maiden went unrecorded, though Clark referenced the encounter years later in his reminiscences, noting that Russell “was deeply in love” with Anna.

headline: Injuries to Players Raise Questions on Athlete I.P.O. Plan
text: Sunday was a bad day for Fantex, the fledgling company promoting initial public offerings of National Football League stars.

headline: Determining the Victims of Insider Trading
text: The guilty plea hearing last week in the Justice Department’s prosecution of SAC Capital Advisors raised an interesting question about the law of insider trading: Just who are the victims of a violation? A provision of the federal securities laws gives those who traded at the same time as the insider a right to sue for a violation, but the Justice Department said they are not victims of the crime.

headline: Giving Foreign Clients a Piece of New York’s Luxury Real Estate
text: It takes a certain kind of person to regard luxury real estate in New York as cheap, maybe even embarrassingly cheap when compared with other global capitals. If such people hail from the former Soviet Union, and want to add a Manhattan address to a portfolio that might already include homes in London or Dubai or St. Tropez, they might seek out a real estate agent who appreciates their unusual perspective. They might seek out Gennady Perepada.

headline: Notes From a Storm-Wrecked Land
text: QUEZON CITY, Philippines — ON Wednesday, two days before Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, I assigned the short story “Fredo Avila,” by Gina Apostol, to my introduction to literature class at Ateneo de Manila University. It’s set in the writer’s hometown, Barugo, in the eastern province of Leyte.

headline: Adding Pounds, Then New Knees
text: In his mid-forties, Charles Carroll, a letter carrier in Shrewsbury, Mass., started taking anti-inflammatory medicine for his achy knees. Despite his young age, osteoarthritis had begun to settle in.

headline: Obama Speaks on Veterans Day
text: The president delivers remarks at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.

headline: Choosing to Chew Gum
text: Q. Is chewing gum bad for you?

headline: Gliders in the Ocean Deep, Autism in an Infant’s Gaze, Martin Cruz Smith’s Life With Parkinson’s
text: Autonomous robots take to the seas to investigate currents, fish and climate change; a new study uses eye-tracking techniques on infants to look for early signs of autism; the author of “Gorky Park” talks about living with a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease for the last 18 years.

headline: Getting Less Touchy on Windows 8, and Adjusting the iOS Mail App
text: Less Touchy

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Gay Talese and Juliette Lewis
text: The legendary journalist and the Oscar-nominated actress take on Saint Laurent roller skates, Sylvester Stallone as an artist and more.

headline: Martin Cruz Smith Reveals a Twist in His Tale
text: It is probably no accident that the pivotal object in Martin Cruz Smith’s newest detective thriller, “Tatiana,” is a notebook nobody can read.

headline: How to Help Philippines Typhoon Victims
text: Updated, Tuesday, 5:44 p.m. | As the full scale of the devastation wrought across the islands of the Philippines over the weekend by Typhoon Haiyan came into fuller view on Monday, governments around the world have pledged aid to the victims. The Pentagon has dispatched an advance team of 90 marines and sailors, and U.S.A.I.D. has pledged emergency shelter and hygiene materials and 55 tons of food. The American Embassy in Manila has donated $100,000 for water and sanitation assistance.

headline: BlackBerry’s Turnaround Starts All Thumbs
text: BlackBerry’s turnaround is starting out all thumbs. The $85 million worth of stock handed to the company’s new boss, John Chen, over five years at least provides the right incentives. But the struggling Canadian company surely needs more attention than one man doing both top jobs, especially if he’s commuting from California.

headline: Single Tooth Tells of Long-Extinct Platypus
text: Based on the discovery of a single tooth, researchers say they have identified an ancient species of giant platypus. The finding provides new clues about the lineage of the modern platypus. “The fossil record is very, very patchy for the platypus, and these are a unique group of mammals,” said the lead researcher, Rebecca Pian, a vertebrate paleontologist at Columbia University and the American Museum of Natural History. Unlike most mammals, they lay eggs instead of giving birth to live offspring; their snouts are covered with electroreceptors that can detect underwater prey; and the male has a venomous spur on its hind feet.

headline: When One Kitchen Isn’t Enough
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When Tony Maws designed the open kitchen at Craigie on Main, the celebrated restaurant he opened here five years ago, he positioned his workstation to serve as a kind of welcome mat.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Gay Talese and Juliette Lewis
text: The legendary journalist, known for his expertise in crafting the celebrity profile, and the Oscar-nominated actress, who will star alongside Meryl Streep and Julia Roberts in the forthcoming film adaptation of Tracy Letts’s Pulitzer-winning play, “August: Osage County,” take on Iggy Azalea, a feather-tipped ballpoint pen, high-top roller skates and more.

headline: A Winter Innovation: The Airport Coat Check
text: IT’S getting cold in the Northern Hemisphere, and that means we are about to enter the Winter Campaign in the overhead bin wars.

headline: In Hookups, Inequality Still Reigns
text: Natasha Gadinsky, 23, says she doesn’t have any regrets from her years in college. But the time she hooked up with a guy at Brown University does come close.

headline: Tracking the World’s Biggest E-Commerce Event
text: Chinese consumers were expected to spend more than $5 billion Monday for Singles’ Day, which is considered the world’s biggest e-commerce event.

headline: The Old-Fashioned, in Song and Dance
text: Updated, 12:15 p.m. | My Drink column this month was partially inspired by the song “I’m Old Fashioned,” by Jerome Kern and Johnny Mercer. It debuted in the 1942 romantic comedy “You Were Never Lovelier,” in a total charmer of a song-and-dance routine.

headline: After Near Miss on Iran, Kerry Says Diplomacy Is Still the Right Path
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Secretary of State John Kerry came up a few disputed words short of closing a landmark nuclear deal with Iran on Sunday in Geneva. Now he is defending the diplomacy that led to that near miss against a rising chorus of critics at home and abroad.

headline: Tidying Up Your Financial Life
text: From buying a home to paying for college, our financial decisions seem more complex, and it often seems as if things are far beyond our control. It leads to a feeling of anxiety. Plus, we’re so busy making money, trying to make ends meet, that it seems all but impossible to manage it in any meaningful way. Who has the time to track a monthly budget?

headline: A ‘Bully’ Defying the Bullies of His Era
text: The interplay between personality and politics, temperament and leadership is one of the key themes animating Doris Kearns Goodwin’s telling books about Abraham Lincoln (“Team of Rivals”), Franklin D. Roosevelt (“No Ordinary Time”) and Lyndon B. Johnson (“Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream”). The same is true of her sprawling new book, “The Bully Pulpit,” which gives us revealing portraits of Theodore Roosevelt and his close friend, handpicked successor and eventual bitter rival, William Howard Taft.

headline: The Read Around: Jesmyn Ward
text: In “The Read Around,” a new weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Jesmyn Ward talks about her memoir, “Men We Reaped,” and the challenge of writing about people she has known and loved.

headline: No Need to Fumble for Reading Glasses
text: Snakes can optimize their vision by controlling the blood flow in their eyes when they perceive threats, a new study from the University of Waterloo shows. Kevin van Doorn and Jacob Sivak of the university’s science faculty discovered that the visual blood flow patterns of the coachwhip snake changed depending on its surroundings. And instead of eyelids, snakes have clear scales called spectacles, which work like windows, covering and protecting their eyes. The findings were published in the latest issue of The Journal of Experimental Biology.

headline: Acquitted Israeli Politician Returns to Job as Foreign Minister
text: JERUSALEM — Avigdor Lieberman, the powerful Israeli nationalist politician whose blunt talk has often stirred outrage at home and abroad, was reinstated on Monday as the country’s foreign minister. Mr. Lieberman, who was acquitted last week of corruption charges that had dogged him for more than a decade, was back at the diplomatic helm on Monday night after a stormy debate in Parliament and a vote confirming his reappointment.

headline: Exploring the Ocean
text: Underwater drones are changing the way scientists study the sea.

headline: Ocean Drones Plumb New Depths
text: ATLANTIC CITY — Five miles offshore from the Golden Nugget casino, Michael F. Crowley, a marine scientist at Rutgers University, heaves three lifeboat-yellow drones off the back of his research vessel.

headline: The Rush to Coin Virtual Money With Real Value
text: Updated, 5:46 p.m. | If cash is king, virtual cash may be the crown prince in waiting.

headline: Long-Term Benefits of Music Lessons
text: Childhood music lessons can sometimes leave painful memories, but they seem to carry benefits into adulthood. A new study reports that older adults who took lessons at a young age can process the sounds of speech faster than those who did not.

headline: Science Bookshelf
text: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.”

headline: Not Quite Laverne and Shirley
text: Celeste Delacroix Griffin is having a lousy day. True, she’s been sprung from the slammer just in time for Christmas Eve, after that little shoplifting incident. But it’s been a quick roll downhill from there for this seedy vagabond from “The Mutilated,” a rarely seen Tennessee Williams comedy being boisterously revived at the New Ohio Theater in a production starring the quirky team of Penny Arcade and Mink Stole.

headline: Fifth Avenue, 11:38 A.M.
text: Veterans lined Fifth Avenue for the Veteran’s Day parade.

headline: In College Admissions, Social Media Can Be a Double-Edged Sword
text: When I wrote my Technophoria column this weekend about how some college admissions officers have occasionally identified social media posts that negatively affected applicants’ chances of acceptance, I assumed the phenomenon would not come as news to the parents of high school students.

headline: No Health Insurance? Just Drink.
text: This is the strangest P.R. campaign yet against the Affordable Care Act. Generation Opportunity, the Koch-funded group behind the Creepy Uncle Sam ads, is throwing tailgate parties to “educate” young people about the exchanges. Read: To convince young people to forgo health insurance.

headline: Walkabout: Garbage Piling Up in Madrid; Easing Travel for Passengers with Disabilities
text: A Mess in Madrid Travelers to Madrid may want to pack a pair of thigh-high boots: a strike by city sanitation workers has entered its seventh day, leading to some nasty trash pileups. (Bloomberg)

headline: When Healers Get Too Friendly
text: It takes only a moment to step over the line, especially when no one knows exactly where the line is. In my case, it started with a visit from my old friend the activist.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Philippines, Virginia, France and Serbia.

headline: A Marathoner’s Many Hurdles
text: Idrissa Kargbo, a coffee deliverer from Sierra Leone, dreams of becoming one of the best runners in the world. It is an audacious goal.

headline: An Accidental Cattle Ranch Points the Way in Sustainable Farming
text: PESCADERO, Calif. — When Tom Steyer first learned that his wife, Kat Taylor, wanted to sell beef from the cattle herd on their ranch here, he rolled his eyes.

headline: Quinoa Hush Puppies: A Healthful Twist on a Southern Staple
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: A New Political Party Aims to Save Socialism, and the Constitution, in China
text: “A lot of people have been applying to join. I can’t keep up with the applications,” said Wang Zheng, a scholar who on Nov. 6 did something unusual. She announced the establishment of a new political party in China, where the Communist Party holds all power and tolerates no opposition outside of it.

headline: East and West, Mingling in One Man’s Body
text: As a child in London, enthralled by Michael Jackson, Akram Khan wasn’t as interested in his Bangladeshi heritage as his parents might have liked. But he was serious about one thing: dance. After mastering the classical Indian form Kathak, he went to college and mastered Western contemporary forms. Inside his body, the collision of these ways of moving made him move in a way that was thrilling to behold. It was also a timely metaphor for second-generation immigrant identity and multiculturalism. Mr. Khan danced with astonishing speed, and his fame and the scale of his productions grew apace.

headline: Boardrooms Rethink Tactics to Defang Activist Investors
text: Executives and board members used to fear hostile bids above all else. In response, they devised defense mechanisms like poison pills and staggered boards to thwart attacks.

headline: Early Beatles on the BBC, Bantering and Bluesy
text: In the summer of 1971, one of the first Beatles bootlegs turned up, packaged in a white sleeve with “The Beatles — Yellow Matter Custard — Previously Unreleased Studio Material” rubber-stamped across it. It offered an odd lineup of tracks (performances of Ray Charles’s “I Got a Woman”; Buddy Holly’s “Crying, Waiting, Hoping”; Carl Perkins’s “Sure to Fall (in Love With You)”; Arthur Alexander’s “Shot of Rhythm and Blues”), 14 in all, in decent, if slightly tinny, quality.

text: What if?

text: LUSCIOUS JACKSON

headline: Honoring Female Pioneers in Science
text: Florence Nightingale, a statistician? Marie Curie, driving to the front during World War I to X-ray wounded soldiers?

headline: Colbert Recites the Gettysburg Address
text: Stephen Colbert is among the celebrities who are encouraging Americans to memorize Lincoln's famous speech.

headline: Three Days of Dancing, Starring D.J.s
text: Dance music has its hegemonies, its mainstream history, but in the last few years especially, mutation has complicated and diversified that narrative. Now in its sixth year, the Brooklyn Electronic Music Festival has been an incubator for these styles, often capturing rising D.J.s and producers before they make wide impact.

headline: Surveillance Leaves Writers Wary
text: A survey by the writers’ organization PEN American Center has found that a large majority of its members are deeply concerned about recent revelations regarding the extent of government surveillance of email and phone records, with more than a quarter saying that they have avoided, or are seriously considering avoiding, controversial topics in their work.

headline: The Quiet Before the Shots
text: Next to birthdays of prominent public figures, nothing engenders mass reflection and artistic endeavor as readily as big, round anniversaries of historical milestones. We’re just 10 days away from one such date: Nov. 22, the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy’s assassination in Dallas, which after half a century continues to take a dramatic toll on the collective American psyche.

headline: The Gettysburg Address, as Recited by Colbert and You
text: The filmmaker Ken Burns has found one way to bring together Republicans and Democrats in this politically divided time: Ask them to recite the Gettysburg Address, which Abraham Lincoln delivered on Nov. 19, 1863, at the dedication of the cemetery at the Civil War battlefield. The website Learn the Address features videos of notable names reciting the speech, including all the living American presidents and dozens of celebrities like Taylor Swift, Usher, Steven Spielberg, Uma Thurman, Shane Victorino and Bill O’Reilly. Other well-known reciters include Stephen Colbert and Gabrielle Giffords.

headline: Estonian Master, Through Lens of Compatriots
text: If any artist is emblematic of the spirit manifest in Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival, it might be Arvo Pärt. An Estonian composer based in Berlin for much of his career, Mr. Pärt achieved wide renown in the mid-1980s through a series of recordings on the German label ECM. His rise to prominence was also abetted by the conductor Neeme Järvi, a countryman whose continued advocacy was evident in a festival concert by the Estonian National Symphony Orchestra and the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening.

headline: Watch Out for Falling Space Junk and Asteroids
text: Fiery chunks of a European satellite fell from the sky, the latest in a parade of what scientists worryingly call “uncontrolled entries.” And new research showed that asteroids like the one that exploded over Russia in February will probably hit Earth more often than previously expected. All in all, not a bad week to begin a long journey to Mars.

headline: The Universe’s End
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 8-10, 2013
text: A Texas company has made the world’s first metal gun using a 3D printer. The fully functioning, semi-automatic .45-caliber pistol made by Austin-based Solid Concepts is modeled on on the Browning 1911 firearm. It’s been safely fired 50 times, and as for accuracy, the gun was able to strike a target bull’s-eye at more than 30 yards.

headline: Two Weeks That Kindle Hope
text: No ballet ensemble has a soul more divided than that of American Ballet Theater. Some people think it’s one of the world’s greatest companies; others think it’s not really a company at all. Both arguments make sense, and they largely correspond to which side of Lincoln Center Plaza the troupe is playing.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Jimmie Johnson Eyes Sixth Title
text: Kevin Harvick won the battle, but Jimmie Johnson may have won the war on Sunday in Nascar’s Sprint Cup Series race at Phoenix International Raceway. On the white flag lap, Harvick passed the leader, Carl Edwards, who was running out of fuel, and then held on for the final lap to take the checkered flag. Kasey Kahne came in second. Johnson was third, earning a decisive number of points in the quest for his sixth Sprint Cup season title.

headline: From the Philippines to Haiti, Disaster Recovery is a Way of Life
text: For many millions of people living in the planet’s poorest, most populous places, a state of recovery from what used to be called “natural” disasters has become the norm, not some exceptional circumstance. The central Philippines, now reeling from the impact of Typhoon Haiyan, a super storm if ever there was one, are just the latest place in which huge human losses follow a disaster that, in a rich country, would almost assuredly mainly exact a financial toll. See Keith Bradsher’s wrenching reports here and here for details on the damage. And the immediate search and rescue efforts are just a warmup for years of relocation, recovery and rebuilding.

headline: Supper Club to Reopen With ‘Carnal’ Take on ‘Magic Flute’
text: A famed theater-district supper club will reopen on New Year’s Eve with a high-tech “carnal” reimagining of “The Magic Flute” that aims to blur the lines between the audience and the performers. “Queen of the Night” is created by Randy Weiner, a founder of The Box burlesque space on the Lower East Side and a producer of the smash success “Sleep No More” downtown. Like “The Donkey Show,” the disco adaptation of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” that Mr. Weiner created with his wife, Diane Paulus, in 1999, “Queen of the Night” puts the audience into the middle of a reconfigured classic theater piece – in this case Mozart’s opera.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
text: The Renaissance wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosities — a personal collection of fabulous, rare, sometimes grotesque relics — inspires tableaus of the season’s most opulent baubles and fanciful curios.

headline: Germany to Form Task Force on Looted Art
text: After an avalanche of criticism at home and abroad, the German government announced late Monday it will establish a task force to investigate, “as quickly and as transparently as possible,” the provenance of a cache of more than 1,400 artworks that are suspected of being traded or looted during the Nazis’ reign and that are now in the hands of authorities in Bavaria.

headline: The Only Certainty Is That He Won’t Show Up
text: Maybe Godot never appears because everyone is mispronouncing his name.

headline: Welcome, in Mandarin
text: Mandarin television channels. Congee rice porridges. Smoking rooms.

headline: He Struts, but His Comb Is Trembling
text: “Year of the Rooster” at the Ensemble Studio Theater isn’t merely entertaining. It’s astonishingly entertaining, partly because the playwright, Eric Dufault, is only in his mid-20s and partly because who would have thought that a barnyard bird could make such an intriguing stage character?

headline: Art Matters | Bruce Weber on the Intimacy of Portraiture
text: As Bruce Weber releases a new installment of his ‘All-American’ photo anthology and a box set of his films, he reflects on the intimacy of taking pictures.

headline: In Music Piracy Battles, Lyrics Demand Respect Too
text: When the forces of the music industry go after websites for using copyrighted content without permission, that content tends to come in the form of MP3 files or YouTube videos.

headline: Lennon’s School Detention Sheets Head to Auction
text: John Lennon always described himself as a cut-up during his school years, an authority-baiting revolutionary in the making. But even keeping in mind the wisecracking assertiveness he cultivated during the Beatles years, and beyond, you always suspected that he was exaggerating.

headline: Crystal Bridges Museum Conducts Ambitious Survey of Contemporary American Art
text: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the institution founded in Bentonville, Ark., by Alice L. Walton, the Walmart heiress, is only two years old. But it has embarked on a mission that even more established museums might fear to take on: a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art, formed by visits to hundreds of artists’ studios, large and small, successful and almost unheard-of, across the country.

headline: For an Upgrade, Skip the Vegetarian Meal
text: I’M an entrepreneur in the promotional clothing and products business. That entrepreneurial spirit is in my blood.

headline: Art Survey Planned
text: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the institution founded in Bentonville, Ark., by Alice L. Walton, the Wal-Mart heiress, is only two years old. But it has decided to set out on a mission even more established museums might fear: a comprehensive survey of contemporary American art, formed by visits to hundreds of artists’ studios across the country. The resulting show, “State of the Art,” will bring together the work of 100 artists for a show that will open on  Sept. 13 and continue through  Jan. 5, 2015. For the last several months, the museum’s president, Don Bacigalupi, and an assistant curator for special projects, Chad Alligood, have been traveling by plane and car to almost every part of the country, relying on an initial list of 10,000 artists, to find works they will include in the show. They have visited more than 400 studios and artists so far, in dozens of cities, but also in rural places so small that the roads to them have not shown up on the curators’ GPS devices. “We’ve come to recognize that many extraordinary artists may be known in their own locales, but have yet to emerge on the national stage,” Mr. Alligood said. “Their work, however, deserves consideration from a national audience.” “State of the Art” could be seen as a traditionalist alternative to a show like the Whitney Biennial, but there are currently no plans to make it a recurring event.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Messaging Apps Threaten Facebook, and $4 Toast
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: ‘Godot’ Variations
text: A look at different interpretations of Samuel Beckett’s play.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Subtweets Kerry
text: As my colleague Mark Landler reports, Secretary of State John Kerry insisted on Monday that it was unfair to blame last-minute objections from his French counterpart, Laurent Fabius, for scuttling a potential deal with Iran over its nuclear energy program last weekend in Geneva. “The French signed off on it, we signed off on it,” Mr. Kerry said of the final proposal presented to Iran’s negotiating team. “There was unity, but Iran couldn’t take it.”

headline: Sounds That Fly on Digital Wings
text: Spatial music has been around for over 400 years, with composers from Gabrieli to Stockhausen exploiting the acoustic effect that results from separating performers in space. Technological advances of recent decades have made it possible to move sound about a room — and even enhance, distort or multiply it as it travels about — while keeping the musician rooted in place.

text: Brian Cross in a scene from Sharr White’s new play “The Snow Geese,” now on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

text: The Renaissance wunderkammer, or cabinet of curiosities — a personal collection of fabulous, rare, sometimes grotesque relics — inspires tableaus of the season’s most opulent baubles and fanciful curios.

headline: Maneuvering Begins as Three Yankees Rebuff Offers
text: In an off-season filled with uncertainty, the Yankees passed the first phase with no surprises as three players turned down qualifying offers from the team. The Yankees had made the offers — set by Major League Baseball at $14.1 million — to Robinson Cano, Curtis Granderson and Hiroki Kuroda.

headline: Silent Sentinels at Center of Lithuanian Debate on Bygone Era
text: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Watching over one of this city’s busiest thoroughfares are the sentinels of a loathed regime.

headline: For de Blasio, Contract Talks Offer Problem
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has promised all sorts of assistance to ease Bill de Blasio’s transition, but the mayor has nonetheless bequeathed one particularly thorny, potentially explosive issue to his successor: New York City’s 300,000 municipal workers are angry that their contracts expired years ago, and they are demanding more than $7 billion in retroactive pay to make up for their years without a regular raise.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Montréal, Quebec; Pennsylvania; Madrid
text: Salon des Métiers d’Art de Montréal, Quebec More than 400 regional artisans will gather at Place Bonaventure in Montreal from Dec. 6 to 22 to display their latest creations. Established in 1955, the event is described by its organizers as “the most important annual professional crafts exhibition in Canada.” Jewelry, musical instruments, games, toys, kitchen utensils, office accessories and other utilitarian and decorative objects (above) are among the original crafts for sale.

headline: Etsy’s Industrial Revolution
text: PASADENA, Calif. — HAND-KNIT sweaters? Hand-thrown pots? How about quilts stitched on a sewing machine? In an age when artisanal items can be sold at a premium, what products should qualify as “handmade”?

headline: Ex-Mob Boss Gotti Stabbed on Long Island
text: John A. Gotti, the former boss of the Gambino crime family, was stabbed in the stomach over the weekend in Syosset, N.Y., the authorities said on Monday.

headline: The Extra Legroom Society
text: For our time off together around Christmas, my siblings, their children and I recently began plotting an excursion to the Six Flags amusement park in the Los Angeles area. The discussion turned quickly from roller coasters to perks. To status. To just how high we’re prepared to fly in this service-obsessed, luxury-laden, class-fractured era of ours.

headline: Saudi Arabia: MERS Virus Found in Patient’s Pet Camel
text: The virus that causes Middle East Respiratory Syndrome — an often-lethal lung disease related to SARS — has been found in a pet camel belonging to a recent human victim, Saudi Arabia’s Health Ministry announced Monday. The discovery adds credence to the prevailing theory that the virus originates in bats but usually reaches humans through camels. In three earlier clusters of MERS cases, the first patient to fall ill in each was reported to have had contact with a sick camel. Although antibodies to the disease had been found in camels before, the virus itself had not. Genetic tests will be done, the ministry said, to see if the camel’s strain is identical to that found in the patient, a 43-year-old man in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, who is still hospitalized. MERS has killed 64 people since it was first isolated a year ago, 53 of them in Saudi Arabia. It can also spread from human to human, but seems to do so less readily than SARS — severe acute respiratory syndrome — did.

headline: Skeptics See Euro Eroding European Unity
text: LONDON — Europe’s slow emergence from its second recession in the last five years is raising new questions about whether the euro currency is doing more harm than good.

headline: City’s Plan to Relocate 2 Agencies Stirs Anger
text: The city official attempted a half smile as the baby was held before him, her tiny feet dangling in little pink striped socks. But her mother was in no mood for niceties.

headline: Russia: Four Are Sentenced for Airport Attack
text: The Moscow Regional Court sentenced three men on Monday to life in prison for their role in the 2011 suicide bombing at the Domodedovo airport in Moscow that killed 37 people and wounded 172, the court said. The men, Bashir Khamkhoyev and the brothers Islam and Ilez Yandiyev, were convicted of providing explosive materials to the bomber, Magomed Yevloyev, 20, and for organizing his stay in Moscow before the January attack. A fourth man, Akhmed Yevloyev, the bomber’s brother, was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Doku Umarov, the leader of an Islamist terrorist group carrying out an insurgency in the country’s North Caucasus region, later claimed responsibility for the bombing. Mr. Umarov, who remains a fugitive, has since called on his followers to disrupt the 2014 Winter Olympics, which Russia will host in Sochi, a resort city on the edge of the turbulent region.

headline: Problems With Federal Health Portal Also Stymie Medicaid Enrollment
text: WASHINGTON — Problems with the federal health insurance website have prevented tens of thousands of low-income people from signing up for Medicaid even though they are eligible, federal and state officials say, undermining one of the chief goals of the 2010 health care law.

headline: Boycotting Israeli Universities, Part Two
text: The responses to my column on the call by some academics to boycott Israeli universities in the name of academic freedom were impassioned and polarized. I was pleased to find more readers than usual on my side, but one argument favored by those who agreed with my negative view of the boycott is, I think, beside the point. That is the argument that the boycott is wrong because it is selective, because it singles out Israel when there are so many other countries in the world whose policies and actions are just as bad or worse. Actually, this is not an argument; it is a debating point (as some who offer it know): it is a form of reductio ad absurdum, the rhetorical trick of extending an opponent’s claim until it yields an absurd result, in this case the absurd result that follows if we are required to break off relations with universities housed in nations whose human rights record we find questionable: on this reasoning, we would have to break off relationships with everyone and there would be no academic exchange at all.

headline: An Author Reveals a Twist in His Tale
text: Martin Cruz Smith, author of thrillers like “Gorky Park,” recently revealed his diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease, which he hid for years.

headline: Russia: Greenpeace Detainees Are Transferred
text: Russia’s prison authorities began transferring 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship from Murmansk to St. Petersburg on Monday, nearly two months after they were arrested following a protest at an offshore oil rig in the Arctic. The move came a day after Foreign Minister Frans Timmermans of the Netherlands, where the ship is registered, expressed hope for a diplomatic resolution to the case but indicated that it could still be weeks away. Russia’s investigative committee explained the transfers by saying that the courts in Murmansk did not have jurisdiction over the hooliganism charges the 30 face and that the investigating body in charge of the case was in St. Petersburg. The Netherlands has appealed to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea for the release of the crew and the ship. The court’s decision is scheduled for Nov. 22, but Russia has said it would not accept its jurisdiction in this case.

headline: New York Looks to Cut Emissions by Private Trash Haulers
text: As aging garbage trucks rumble down the streets of New York, their fumes draw protests from residents and environmental advocates and raise concerns about asthma and other health effects.

headline: Why Do Female Chefs Get Overlooked?
text: Why do female chefs rarely win the adulation and recognition of male chefs?

headline: Michelle Obama Edges Into a Policy Role on Higher Education
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama, after nearly five years of evangelizing exercise and good eating habits, will begin a new initiative on Tuesday that seeks to increase the number of low-income students who pursue a college degree. The goals of the program reflect the first lady’s own life and will immerse her more directly in her husband’s policies.

headline: In Challenge, Former Rebels in Libya Form Own Oil Company
text: Former rebels who fought the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and are now challenging Libya’s shaky central government have announced the creation of their own oil company to sell crude from oil fields and port terminals they currently occupy.

headline: List of 25 Artworks Seized in Germany Released
text: The German authorities early Tuesday released a list of 25 of the 1,400 or so works of art the authorities confiscated from a Munich apartment said to be that of the son of a dealer who had been hired to acquire artworks for the Nazis during World War II.

headline: Lawyer for Ukraine Opposition Leader Is Questioned
text: Prosecutors in Ukraine on Monday questioned the chief defense lawyer of the main political opposition figure, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, on suspicion that he beat his former wife, a development that a spokeswoman for Ms. Tymoshenko called “absurd” and just another example of the government abusing its prosecutorial powers.

headline: Where Credit Is Due
text: Starting from a simple loan, credit markets have featured many innovations as well as costly crises.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Gets Early Start on Pushing for a 2016 Clinton Campaign
text: In the 2008 presidential primary campaign, Mitch Stewart devoted himself to defeating Hillary Rodham Clinton, overcoming the advantages of a well-funded Democratic front-runner through grass-roots organizing, and propelling Barack Obama to victory.

headline: Emotions High at  a Celebratory Lunch for the Met’s  James Levine
text: James Levine was wrapping up his remarks at the Metropolitan Opera Guild’s “Welcome Home, Jimmy!” lunch on Monday, which celebrated his return to the Met after an injury sidelined him for two years, when, with a flourish, he ripped his prepared text in two.

headline: De Blasio Honors Soldiers and Notes His Family’s Military Service
text: Switching gears from the political to the ceremonial, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio saluted America’s soldiers on Monday, while enthusiastically marching in his first official parade since his landslide victory last week.

headline: The Next Step in Stop-and-Frisk
text: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit created a public-policy crisis earlier this month when it stayed the remedies ordered by Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court to correct civil rights violations associated with the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policy. And by wrongly removing Judge Scheindlin from the case, the panel sent a chilling message to district court judges who challenge the practices of the police and other government entities. Instead of letting this matter linger, the full court should agree to review the panel’s ruling.

headline: An Overdue Ban on Trans Fats
text: The Food and Drug Administration is moving to ban virtually all artificial trans fats from the American food supply. This long-awaited move should save thousands of lives and potentially billions of dollars in medical and economic costs a year.

headline: A Media Services Agency Rides the Health and Wellness Wave
text: THE largest independent media services agency in advertising is expanding its purview again, this time into the booming field of health and wellness marketing.

headline: Running in the Dazzle of Neon
text: As fall marathon season unfolds, tens of thousands of runners thud along trails across the country.

headline: Redefining the Minimum Wage
text: Business has been brisk at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, with a record number of passengers spending record amounts of money eating and shopping. But for an estimated 6,500 workers at the airport and its nearby hotels, car rental agencies and parking lots, the activity has not translated into economic security, let alone prosperity. Wages for airport-related jobs average an estimated $11 an hour, ranging from less than $10 an hour for airline contractors, like baggage handlers and cabin cleaners, to about $13 an hour for car-rental employees.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks: Unfinished, but Alive
text: The inconclusive negotiations over the weekend on Iran’s nuclear program were disappointing, but two critical points have mostly been ignored. First, diplomacy takes work, and agreements rarely flow seamlessly from beginning to end. Second, if all those inveighing against any deal — namely members of Congress, Israel and Saudi Arabia — see the weekend results as a new opportunity to sabotage it, what is the alternative?

headline: New Consoles on the Way, but Gaming Isn’t the Same
text: The new video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft about to hit store shelves are almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year. The uncertainty for the games business is: What happens after Santa leaves?

headline: Jury to Decide How Much More Samsung Must Pay Apple in Patent Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Samsung Electronics lost an important patent battle with Apple last year. A new trial expected to start this week will determine how much Samsung has to pay for that loss.

headline: After Ugly Campaign, Finding Little Grace in Brooklyn District Attorney’s Exit
text: Sam Kellner, a voluble whistle-blower against child sexual abuse in Brooklyn’s Hasidic community, received a much-dreamed-of phone call last week.

headline: U.N. Relief Official to Help Coordinate Aid Efforts
text: The top United Nations relief official flew to the Philippines on Monday to help lead the global response to the powerful typhoon that killed thousands and upended the lives of nearly 10 million people in the country’s midsection. International aid groups mobilized to rush food, water and sanitation supplies to the victims, a struggle in the face of impassable roads, obliterated seaports and severely damaged airstrips.

headline: Unlearning Gun Violence
text: In 1995, an epidemiologist named Gary Slutkin returned to the United States from Africa where he had spent the previous decade helping Africans stem the spread of diseases like tuberculosis, AIDS and cholera. “I was exhausted,” he said in a TED Talk earlier this year. “I wanted to come home and take a break.”

headline: Djokovic Wins Final, but It’s Not Last Word
text: LONDON — After a year-end tennis championship that was played amid debate over playing surfaces, host cities and the length of a drug suspension, perhaps a new debate will emerge over who should end the season as No. 1.

headline: Typhoon in Philippines Casts Long Shadow Over U.N. Talks on Climate Treaty
text: The typhoon that struck the Philippines produced an outpouring of emotion on Monday at United Nations talks on a global climate treaty in Warsaw, where delegates were quick to suggest that a warming planet had turned the storm into a lethal monster.

headline: Oklahoma: Senator’s Son Dies in Crash Near Tulsa
text: Dr. Perry Inhofe, the son of Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma and ranking member of the Armed Services Committee, was killed in a plane crash on Sunday, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed Monday. Aaron Sauer, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board, said at a briefing on Monday that only one person was on board the twin-engine plane when it crashed in Owasso,. The plane had taken off from Salina, Kan., and was approaching the Tulsa airport for landing at the time, he said.

headline: Yellow Dogs, Iranian Band, Earned Fans Through Intensity and Promise
text: For most aspiring young rock stars, the night two years ago when a music critic walked into a music club in Brooklyn and laid eyes and ears on the intense, dark-haired foursome on the stage might have been their first significant break.

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks reconvened Monday morning at their practice facility, and none of their planned activities turned out to be much fun.

text: The day after Typhoon Haiyan swept through the Philippines, the bodies began to be recovered, and the displaced survivors tried to figure out what to do next.

text: Aid crews struggled to get to survivors three days after a storm that was feared to have left tens of thousands of people dead.

headline: Filipinos in U.S. Feel Helpless as They Try to Contact Kin
text: LOS ANGELES — When the typhoon hit the Philippine city of Ormoc on Friday, Joy Malinao scrambled to get in touch with her brother, who still lives there. But communications in the area were dead.

text: A judge had just struck down New York’s limits on large sugary drinks last March when a fairly obscure city councilman, James F. Gennaro, cornered Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his health commissioner near the refrigerator at Lucky’s Cafe on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: ‘Great Expectations for Female Lawyers’
text: On the bright summer morning of Sept. 9, 2001, I picked up the newspaper from my Brooklyn doorstep, just as I did every Sunday. I was 29, newly wed and relocated from Paris.

headline: Misery Did Not Work, but Vanity Saved Him
text: As a child, John Cox, 44, did not like getting dirty; he did not like to roughhouse; he did not like a lot of the activities that other boys seemed to love.

headline: Kermit Moore, Cellist, Conductor and Composer, Is Dead at 84
text: Kermit Moore, a cellist, conductor and composer who in all three capacities was concerned with music rooted in the black experience, died on Nov. 2 in Manhattan. He was 84.
