headline: Domo Arigato
text: Today’s constructor, Mike Doran, created an alliterative theme with one sucker punch of an ending. I was able to waltz through most of the theme answers except for the last one, and I think you’ll see what I mean after you solve it.

headline: Alderson Delivers More Laughs, but Few Definitive Answers
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Sandy Alderson stood there grinning, surrounded by a group of reporters in a hotel lobby Monday night, at the start of the annual general managers’ meetings. The off-season the Mets had pointed toward, the one their fans had been waiting for, was getting going. Alderson was asked what he had done thus far.

headline: Insurers Press for Way Around Healthcare.gov
text: Some major health insurers are so worried about the Obama administration’s ability to fix its troubled health care website that they are pushing the government to create a shortcut that would allow them to enroll people entitled to subsidies directly rather than through the federal system.

headline: One Step Forward, One Step Back
text: The double doors part to reveal five dancers, looking right at you, drenched in bright white light. From left to right, they are Robert Steijn, Biba Bell, Hristoula Harakas, Andros Zins-Browne and the choreographer, Maria Hassabi.

headline: Spying Scandal Alters U.S. Ties With Allies and Raises Talk of Policy Shift
text: BERLIN — Just as European and American negotiators resumed work on a groundbreaking trade accord meant to tie their two continents closer together, René Obermann, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, the German telecommunications giant, told a cybersecurity conference in Germany on Monday that his company was working to keep electronic message traffic from “unnecessarily” crossing the Atlantic, where it could fall into the hands of the National Security Agency.

headline: New York City Putting Bus Routes Out for Bid
text: The Bloomberg administration said on Monday that the city would save $400 million over several years by awarding new contracts for thousands of school bus routes, the focus of a bruising fight with the drivers’ union and a monthlong strike this year.

headline: Mauritania Confronts Long Legacy of Slavery
text: BOUTILIMIT, Mauritania — The protesters gathered in front of the low-slung police station, yelling “No to Slavery” and “Freedom.” They had come from across the country to demand the arrest of a family accused of holding a slave since childhood, but they elicited little more than dispassionate stares from the police officers sitting silently before them. The subprefect of the district went to take a nap in the afternoon heat.

headline: Bishops Are Urged to Expand Priorities
text: BALTIMORE — Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, in his final address as president of the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops, called on them Monday to take up the cause of Christians in places like Iraq, Syria, Nigeria and India who are persecuted and killed for their faith.

headline: Messages to and From Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan
text: Updated 7:35 a.m., Nov. 12 The messages to loved ones from survivors of Typhoon Haiyan were scrawled on paper plates and scraps of paper. Jiggy Manicad collected them as he reported on the devastation from Tacloban for a Philippines television station and took them back to Manila on Sunday. When GMA News broadcast and posted them online, he delivered what some families, unable to reach friends and relatives since Friday, were desperate to hear.

headline: 3 People Are Killed in Car Crashes
text: Three people were killed on Monday in car crashes in Queens and East Harlem, the police said.

headline: Wisconsin Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Collective Bargaining Law
text: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments on the constitutionality of a 2011 law that all but eliminated collective bargaining for most public employees.

headline: Nets Polish Up Their Brooklyn
text: The Nets are beginning their second year as Brooklyn tenants, and their effort to blend in took them to a far corner of the borough Monday.

headline: Back and Forth in Undecided Virginia Attorney General Race
text: In the week since Election Day, the lead in Virginia’s razor-thin, still undecided attorney general’s race has seesawed. First the Democrat, Mark R. Herring, was up by 32. Then the Republican, Mark D. Obenshain, went ahead by 55 as of Saturday night. He was ahead by 17 Sunday night.

headline: After Watching Rivals, Jets Turn Focus to the Bills
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets’ bye week over, Willie Colon returned to the team’s practice facility Monday feeling revitalized, a little Bahamian sand in his dreadlocks, and thinking about advice he considers relevant at this point in the season. Colon spent seven years in Pittsburgh, where his coach, Mike Tomlin, would tell the Steelers, “There’s no reason to look into your neighbor’s house.”

headline: Pictures of Typhoon Haiyan’s Wrath
text: Typhoon Haiyan, which cut a destructive path across the Philippines, is believed by some climatologists to be the strongest storm to ever make landfall.

headline: Official at Health Site Says He Didn’t Know of Potential Risk
text: WASHINGTON — The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace has told congressional investigators that he was not aware of tests that indicated potential security flaws in the system, which opened to the public on Oct. 1.

headline: Early Phillips Auction Draws Solid Sales for Contemporary Pieces
text: This week’s high-stakes contemporary art auctions got off to a solid, though unexciting, start at Phillips on Monday night. Although there were some disappointments, there were also some record prices for artists, including the Japanese avant-garde painter Kazuo Shiraga; the American installation artist, performance artist and sculptor David Hammons; as well as some of today’s trendier names, like Jacob Kassay, Nate Lowman and Lucien Smith.

headline: A Face-Off Outside Dallas in the Escalating Battle Over Texas’ Gun Culture
text: HOUSTON — A small meeting of a group seeking tougher gun laws was interrupted Saturday at a suburban Dallas restaurant when the woman who helped organize it saw something outside that startled her: at least two dozen men and women in the parking lot with shotguns, hunting rifles, AR-15s and AK-47s.

headline: Poverty, Government and Social Class
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | vigor
text: vigor •\ˈvi-gər\• noun

headline: Destroying in Order to Build
text: As the populations of many former industrial cities dwindle, buildings are being razed rather than raised to better position the cities for growth.

headline: Blighted Cities Prefer Razing to Rebuilding
text: BALTIMORE — Shivihah Smith’s East Baltimore neighborhood, where he lives with his mother and grandmother, is disappearing. The block one over is gone. A dozen rowhouses on an adjacent block were removed one afternoon last year. And on the corner a few weeks ago, a pair of houses that were damaged by fire collapsed. The city bulldozed those and two others, leaving scavengers to pick through the debris for bits of metal and copper wire.

headline: Intersection: New York City Union Square
text: Cara Araneta, 32, said the style of Union Square is a “mix of uptown and downtown.” Her personal wardrobe is influenced by men’s wear and Wong Kar-wai films.

headline: Iranian Musicians Shot Dead in Brooklyn
text: The Iranian indie band the Yellow Dogs fled Tehran so that they could live and play their music free of fear and repression. But in New York, two of the band's members met sudden, violent deaths.

headline: With Hard Sell, Big-Ticket Art Comes to Auction
text: The pressure to sell was so great that Christie’s used the word “masterpiece” three times in the first three paragraphs of its catalog essay promoting a Francis Bacon triptych that it hopes to auction on Tuesday for at least $85 million.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 1:30 A.M. (Sundance) SWIMMING POOL (2003) An icy English mystery writer (Charlotte Rampling, above) in a midcareer rut is plunged into hot water under the Mediterranean sun when her editor’s wanton teenage daughter (Ludivine Sagnier) and then a dead body show up at a vacation home in France in this thriller directed by François Ozon. “ ‘Swimming Pool,’ Mr. Ozon’s first English-language film (with a bit of French thrown in for local color), is simultaneously a thoroughly mannered, mischievously artificial confection and an acute piece of psychological realism,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Whose psychology, and which reality, remain ambiguous even after the tart, delicious final twist.” The movie, he added, “is alluringly insubstantial, like the light and air of the Luberon. You can’t hold onto it, but it lingers in your senses and plays tricks with your memory.”

headline: Michigan: Autopsy Shows Fatal Wound to the Face
text: Renisha McBride, a 19-year-old black woman whose death in a Detroit suburb has sparked protests from civil rights groups, was killed by a shotgun wound to the face, but not at close range, according to an autopsy report released Monday that ruled it a homicide. Ms. McBride was killed Nov. 2 on the porch of a home in Dearborn Heights. Her family believes she was seeking help after an accident. Demonstrators have called for the arrest of the homeowner, who is white, but no charges have been brought. The Wayne County prosecutor is expected to review evidence this week.

headline: Google Glass Will Expand Its Features Into Music
text: To sell Glass, its augmented-reality form of eyewear, Google has already tried to make it a fashion accessory and a must-have video device for any parent or sky diver. Now it is also presenting this $1,500 piece of wearable technology as a way to interact with music.

headline: Germany’s Lack of Reciprocity
text: Huge tensions over the ECB rate cut, with a split on the board and many German economists protesting. As usual, a lot of it is about the perception that those lazy southern Europeans are getting a free ride:

headline: News Quiz | November 12, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Israel Increasingly Courting China as an Ally
text: As an Israeli diplomat, Dore Gold has sat down with his country’s prime ministers, United States presidents and Palestinian negotiators, all in search of that elusive solution to the Middle East conflict.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 12, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Seeking Mao’s Matrimonial Blessing
text: Shaoshan, the birthplace of Mao Zedong, is no stranger to visitors: Last year, 8.5 million tourists journeyed to this small, county-level city in the mountains of Hunan Province. But on the morning of Nov. 10, with just over a month until the highly anticipated 120th anniversary of the chairman’s birth, Shaoshan hosted a new kind of pilgrim: 50 couples from across China who came to the city to participate in a “Collective Red Wedding.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy
text: In “Obama’s Portable Zone of Secrecy (Some Assembly Required),” Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt write about security precautions that the president and other senior officials must take when traveling abroad.

headline: Iranian Official Faults Kerry and France for Breakdown in Talks
text: LONDON — The Iranian foreign minister turned to a Twitter account late Monday to challenge Secretary of State John Kerry over the failure of weekend talks in Geneva to produce agreement on Tehran’s nuclear program.

headline: Rising Despair as Officials Struggle to Get Aid to  Typhoon Victims
text: CEBU, the Philippines — An American aircraft carrier headed to the Philippines on Tuesday on an emergency mission to help victims of Typhoon Haiyan as the situation on the islands became increasingly desperate, with food and water supplies running low and bodies lying uncollected in the streets of at least one devastated city.

headline: Mayor Ed Lee: ‘Tech Workers Are Not Robots’
text: One of your first encounters with San Francisco city government was when you fought against the demolition of an S.R.O. hotel.  Four chains of people wrapped their arms around the block to prevent its destruction. Horses came in, nightsticks, everything. We never allowed the development to happen, by the way.

headline: Shale’s Effect on Oil Supply Is Forecast to Be Brief
text: WASHINGTON — The boom in oil from shale formations in recent years has generated a lot of discussion that the United States could eventually return to energy self-sufficiency, but according to a report released Tuesday by the International Energy Agency, production of such oil in the United States and worldwide will provide only a temporary respite from reliance on the Middle East.

headline: Switzerland’s Proposal to Pay People for Being Alive
text: This fall, a truck dumped eight million coins outside the Parliament building in Bern, one for every Swiss citizen. It was a publicity stunt for advocates of an audacious social policy that just might become reality in the tiny, rich country. Along with the coins, activists delivered 125,000 signatures — enough to trigger a Swiss public referendum, this time on providing a monthly income to every citizen, no strings attached. Every month, every Swiss person would receive a check from the government, no matter how rich or poor, how hardworking or lazy, how old or young. Poverty would disappear. Economists, needless to say, are sharply divided on what would reappear in its place — and whether such a basic-income scheme might have some appeal for other, less socialist countries too.

headline: Do You Worry Colleges or Employers Might Read Your Social Media Posts Someday?
text: Facebook, Twitter and other social media sites have become an integral part of teenage culture. Yet the snarky comment or inappropriate picture we share with our friends just might not project the image we want the rest of the world to see, especially as we get older. How careful are you online?

headline: Checking In to a New Life in America
text: “The rooms and the corridors are all the same,” said the photographer Gabriele Stabile, “but the stories that inhabit these rooms are all different.”

headline: Indonesia Central Bank Increases Rate, Again
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s central bank made a surprise move on Tuesday to contain the country’s current-account deficit by raising its benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percentage point, to 7.5 percent.

headline: China’s Leaders Urge More Market Control of Economy
text: Chinese Communist Party leaders emerged from a four-day conference on Tuesday with vows to push through changes that will give market competition a “decisive role” in the economy and a plan to establish a new committee to oversee national security.

headline: New York Today: A Hispanic Police Commissioner?
text: Updated 12:34 p.m. | Heard of Rafael Piñeiro?

headline: Quebec's Tea Party Moment
text: MONTREAL — In Quebec, Canada’s second most populous province, the governing Parti Québécois plans to prohibit government employees from wearing “overt and conspicuous” religious symbols while on the job. Everyone from judges to teachers would have to doff their hijabs, kippas, niqabs, turbans and outsize crucifixes. Day care centers would be forbidden to serve kosher or halal foods. Government workers would be allowed to cover their faces only for weather-related — not religious — reasons.

headline: Rineke Dijkstra’s Moments of Photographic Transformation
text: For last weekend’s article about the impact earlier puberty is having on the Leipzig boys choir, we asked the Dutch photographer Rineke Dijkstra to take pictures of the singers. She has a longstanding interest in what she calls “moments of transformation” in people. Her past projects have included, for example, a series of portraits of Almerisa, a Bosnian girl she has photographed every couple of years since meeting her at a refugee center in the Netherlands nearly 20 years ago, as well as Olivier, whose training as a French Foreign Legion officer she documented over several years. This time, in addition to taking pictures of members of the boys choir, Dijkstra also made a short film of some of them rehearsing Mendelssohn’s  “Jauchzet dem Herrn, alle Welt.”

headline: Another Blow for Dolphins’ Already Shaky Line
text: Off the field, the Richie Incognito-Jonathan Martin dispute has dominated the headlines in Miami. On the field, the absence of the two players allowed the Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ defensive line to dominate the Dolphins’ offense on Monday night.

headline: Daily Report: New Consoles Enter a Changed Gaming Market
text: Consoles have been the thumping heart of the video game industry for decades. But the new PlayStation 4 from Sony and the Xbox One from Microsoft, both almost certain to be hot holiday gifts this year, will enter a landscape reshaped by tablets, smartphones and Facebook, all of which provide games at a lower price and in greater abundance, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims Who Can’t Get Aid, or Get Out
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Increasingly desperate survivors of Typhoon Haiyan mobbed the shattered airport here on Tuesday, begging for food, water or a flight to escape the chaotic aftermath of the storm, which flattened this city of 220,000 last week and ravaged vast swaths of the country’s midsection.

headline: Murder in Goa Shakes Tourist Paradise
text: “Oh, you have moved to Goa! You must be having so much fun.” This is the first reaction from most of my friends, who instantly picture me sitting on a beach and sipping beer in my home state.

headline: Business for Sale: Would You Pay $170,000 for This Restaurant?
text: In my posts, I occasionally take a look at businesses for sale, which can offer interesting lessons for both buyers and sellers. For this post we’ll look at a restaurant that’s on the market in Florida’s Tampa Bay area. As with my earlier posts on businesses for sale, I have no stake in the sale of the business. Nor do I certify that any of the information provided by the broker, Paul Gorny, is accurate.

headline: Cornelius Gurlitt Seen Headed to Munich Airport
text: MUNICH – Cornelius Gurlitt, the 80-year-old recluse who kept roughly 1,400 artworks hidden in his Munich home, left his apartment building Tuesday and took a taxi to the airport, witnesses said. It was not clear where he was heading. A woman who escorted Mr Gurlitt to the taxi and then drove off with him appeared to be Ozlem Gezer, an investigative journalist for Der Spiegel, Germany’s leading news magazine. The magazine declined to comment.

headline: Obama Nominates Treasury Official as Top Derivatives Regulator
text: Timothy G. Massad swept up the mess of the last financial crisis.

headline: South Africans Didn't Die for This
text: Cape Town — There’s a reason photographers like to take pictures of Cape Town, South Africa’s second largest city, from out over the Atlantic Ocean. From this vantage point, cerulean waters give way to a long line of luxurious sea-facing apartments that hug the Atlantic seaboard. Others nestle on the cliffs of Bantry Bay and overlook the sandy beaches of Clifton. To the left, the harbor, city center and manicured parks nestle at the foot of city’s most famous peak, Table Mountain.

headline: The Poverty and Population Factors Behind Vast Typhoon Losses
text: I encourage you to read every word in Seth Borenstein’s excellent Associated Press overview of the factors behind the vast toll in the central Philippines from Typhoon Hainan — most of which are related to population density and poverty in a disaster hot spot. Here’s an excerpt and link:

headline: More Style Choices
text: In our recent stylebook revisions, we have accepted as standard a few forms that until now were still treated as colloquial or informal. In some cases, these changes just formalize what we had already been doing in practice.

headline: In Performance: Brian Cross of ‘The Snow Geese’
text: Sharr White’s new play “The Snow Geese” stars Mary-Louise Parker as a World War I-era widow dealing with her fractious family after the death of her husband. In this scene her 18-year-old son, Arnold, played by Brian Cross, chastises his mother for the family’s questionable financial decisions. The show, directed by Daniel Sullivan, continues through Dec. 15 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Obama’s Pick to Lead Trading Commission
text: President Obama will nominate Timothy G. Massad as the new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Tuesday, choosing a senior Treasury Department official to run an agency that polices some of Wall Street’s riskiest activity, Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Protess report in DealBook. Mr. Massad, if confirmed by the Senate, would succeed Gary Gensler, who is credited with turning one of Wall Street’s laxest regulators into one of its most aggressive.

headline: The Gun Report: November 12, 2013
text: On Saturday, four members of the Texas chapter of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America held a lunch meeting in Arlington, and nearly 40 armed members of Open Carry Texas, a gun rights advocacy group, waited outside. Police monitored the incident at the Blue Mesa Grill, but took no action because state law allows people to openly carry guns.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Shinola Macbook Sleeve
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Nomura to Add More Bankers to Its Americas Arm
text: With more Manhattan office space at its disposal, Nomura of Japan seems intent to keep trying to fill it.

headline: Robin Hood in Varanasi
text: On an August afternoon I arrived in Varanasi for the shooting of a film. I was returning to the fabled city after eight years.

headline: Rescuing a Towed Car
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Diller on Banks, Snowden and His Broadcasting Start-Up
text: Barry Diller is not known to be particularly shy about speaking his mind. And as the leadoff speaker on Tuesday at DealBook’s Opportunities for Tomorrow Conference, he held true to form.

headline: Trouble for the Contraception Mandate
text: With a ruling on Friday by the Seventh Circuit, a total of five federal circuit courts have weighed in on religious challenges to the health care law’s contraception mandate.

headline: U.N. Appeals for $301 Million Toward Typhoon Relief
text: GENEVA — The United Nations appealed Tuesday for $301 million in emergency assistance to help millions of people in the Philippines affected by the typhoon that struck on Friday.

headline: Lawsuit Over Sale of Dia Artwork Is Withdrawn
text: Two founders of the Dia Art Foundation who have been vehemently opposed to the organization’s decision to raise money by selling several notable pieces from its collection have decided to withdraw a lawsuit filed last week to block the sale. The founders, Heiner Friedrich and Fariha de Menil Friedrich, said in a statement through their lawyers Tuesday morning that while they consider the sale “utterly wrong” and “against Dia’s mission,” the foundation is “our precious child, and we do not wish to continue to oppose it through legal action.”

headline: The Wild Feathers Pay Tribute to Tom Petty’s ‘Listen to Her Heart’
text: al Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Michigan Senator Critical of ‘Continuing Litany of Deception’ on Wall Street
text: Senator Carl Levin has some choice words for Wall Street.

headline: To Honor an Artist in Miami Beach, Sandals and a T-Shirt
text: Tracey Emin, one of Britain’s most prominent contemporary artists, will have her first United States museum exhibition beginning on Dec. 4 – the day before the start of Art Basel Miami Beach — at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami.

headline: The Inequality of Climate Change
text: Typhoon Haiyan has left an estimated 10,000 dead and hundreds of thousands homeless in the Philippines. And it has once again underscored for many development experts a cruel truth about climate change: It will hit the world’s poorest the hardest.

headline: Fighting to Stop an Entitlement Before It Takes Hold, and Expands
text: WASHINGTON — Underlying fierce Republican efforts to stop President Obama’s health care law and the White House drive to save it is a simple historical reality: Once major entitlement programs get underway, they quickly become embedded in American life. And then they grow.

headline: Justices Weigh Role Drug Played in a Fatal Cocktail
text: WASHINGTON — Joshua Banka’s prodigious appetite for drugs killed him. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court considered whether to hold a drug dealer who had sold heroin to Mr. Banka responsible for his death.

headline: A Fine or Do Time?
text: JERUSALEM — The Knesset is nearing a moment of truth: It has to vote by the end of the month whether to finally draft ultra-Orthodox men into the Israeli army. A proposed law that would lift a long-standing exception allowing Haredi men to avoid military service while they studied the Torah seemed all but ready to pass. Until a last-minute dispute over what to do with anyone who tries to dodge their duty.

headline: Scion of Art Family, in Court, Admits Role With a Gambling Ring
text: Hillel Nahmad, the jet-setting scion of a family whose gallery is a pivotal force in the art market, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a single federal gambling charge, part of a sweeping racketeering indictment handed up in the spring that also charged several reputed Russian mob figures.

headline: After Hours | At Performa, Ryan McNamara’s Pop-Rock Haunted House
text: The artist Ryan McNamara has become known in recent years for twisting uber-familiar pop references into his party-ready performance pieces. At Robert Wilson’s annual Watermill Benefit in 2011, he and a partner sang “Islands in the Stream,” the Dolly Parton-Kenny Rogers duet, while buried up to their necks in the ground. At the 2010 Whitney Biennial he transformed a corner of the museum into a karaoke jam called the Whitney Houston Biennial. McNamara billed “MEƎM: A Story Ballet About the Internet, the elaborate, multidancer piece he created for this year’s Performa festival as “a choreographic exploration of the online world as a space of engagement.”

headline: Justice Dept. Clears Merger of 2 Airlines
text: After months of setbacks and delays, the merger of American Airlines and US Airways to create the world’s largest airline became all but certain on Tuesday after the airlines reached a settlement with the Justice Department just two weeks before a scheduled trial.

headline: Image of the Day: November 12
text: A drill performed by Indian Air Force Personnel in Goalpara, Assam.

headline: Bishops Select Two Leaders Who Reflect New Tone Set by Pope
text: BALTIMORE — The nation’s Roman Catholic bishops on Tuesday chose as leaders of the bishop’s conference two prelates whose pastoral approach evokes the new tone for the church set by Pope Francis.

headline: A Husband’s Fertility Journey
text: After asking about how I’m doing with I.V.F., my friends and family always want to know, how is Solomon handling this? Although my husband considers himself a private person, he agreed to answer some questions.

headline: Today in Small Business: Tracking Online Ads
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Make It Whiskey in a Barrel, Neat
text: The old-fashioned served at Middle Branch, a stylish two-tier cocktail bar in Midtown Manhattan, is unlike any other old-fashioned in the world. It’s not the recipe that makes it special, or the house-made cherry or the custom ice, or the way the bartender prepares the drink. It’s the whiskey: Elijah Craig bourbon.

headline: Loeb Discusses His Strategy, Discloses Stake in FedEx
text: Updated, 3:22 p.m. | Despite a public scolding from George Clooney, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb does not have too many regrets about his activist investment strategy.

headline: Can’t Go Without: Garrett Oliver
text: The brewmaster of Brooklyn Brewery shares his packing list for a visit to Stockholm.

headline: Drinking Beer in Sweden
text: In the mid-1980s, before microbrew was even a term, let alone a trend, in the United States, Garrett Oliver, a brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, began creating beer in his home in New York City just so he could drink something other than the “thin, fizzy yellow liquid” that bars served at the time.

headline: Settlement in Airlines’ Merger Lawsuit
text: A merger of the American Airlines and US Airways, announced earlier this year, would create a new behemoth and would help lift American’s parent company out of a two-year-old bankruptcy case.

headline: Sequoia Capital Invests in Berlin Start-Up
text: LONDON – For many European start-ups, connections to Silicon Valley are still viewed as a sign of success.

headline: A Vacant Icon
text: The last full-time employee in the tallest building in Rhode Island has grown accustomed to the 26 stories of emptiness.

headline: Pivotal Steps Up to the Cloud
text: Pivotal, the company that EMC formed to build applications in the cloud computing era, is starting to deliver the goods. Now we’ll see if there’s a market for what it wants to sell.

headline: Storied Providence Skyscraper, Now Empty, Seeks a Future
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The last full-time employee in the tallest building in Rhode Island has grown accustomed to the 26 stories of emptiness. He doesn’t even hear the absence anymore — that silent roar of business not transacted.

headline: How Do We Judge Books Written Under Pseudonyms?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Daniel Mendelsohn on what readers’ and critics’ reactions say about pseudonymous works.

headline: First Snow, 8:30 A.M.
text: New York saw its first snow of the season on Tuesday morning, as small flakes fluttered from the sky during the morning commute. There was no accumulation, and temperate sidewalks and above-freezing air temperatures quickly turned the flakes into a mere memory. Fortunately, our photographers were quick on the draw.

headline: By a Spire, Manhattan Regains a Title From Chicago
text: For four decades, Chicagoans have been able to one-up New Yorkers on at least one measure: The City of the Big Shoulders had the tallest building in the United States.

headline: Rubenstein Not Planning a Retirement Party Just Yet
text: David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder and co-chief executive of one of the world’s largest private equity firms, the Carlyle Group, may be 64 years old, but he says he doesn’t plan to retire soon.

headline: YouTube Cleaning Up Its Comments
text: It’s sometimes a little frightening to read the comments on a YouTube video.  Let’s say you’ve just watched a cat video and want to find out how others responded to that moment when one kitten massaged another. You scroll down and find … a large helping of inanity as well as racism, sexism, anti-Semitism, homophobia and pure nonsense. It’s well known that the YouTube comments section is a virtual septic tank. In the immortal words of BuzzFeed: “YouTube IS the room with the million monkeys and the million typewriters.”

headline: Obama in Bind Trying to Keep Health Law Vow
text: WASHINGTON — Under intense bipartisan pressure to answer mounting consumer complaints about the botched health care rollout, White House officials are struggling to make good on President Obama’s promise that Americans can keep their insurance coverage without undermining the new health law or adding unaffordable costs.

headline: Bharara on His Wealth, Prosecutions and ‘Pulp Fiction’
text: Updated, 1:56 p.m. | Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, has no plans to retire in the near future.

headline: Despite Bumps, Tire Deal Still Makes Sense
text: The buyout of Cooper Tire and Rubber hasn’t gone flat yet.

headline: Not Giving In to Age or Rangers, Brodeur Tops Lundqvist
text: The old guy still has it. Martin Brodeur was superb in goal Tuesday night in a long line of duels with Henrik Lundqvist. He robbed Ryan Callahan and Derek Stepan alone in front, headed away a batted shot from Chris Kreider, got into a brief slap fight with Mats Zuccarello and all night long looked like a goalie far younger than his 41 years.

headline: ‘Steel Hammer’ and ‘The Christians’ Planned for Humana Festival
text: “Steel Hammer,” a new play built around the composer Julia Wolfe’s kaleidoscopic set of variations on the folk song “John Henry,” is among the works to be performed at the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky., next year.

headline: What’s In It | Pumpkin Flavor
text: Pumpkin-flavored products are on pace to have their best sales year yet. But the industry’s biggest secret about these products is that there is often little or no pumpkin in them.

headline: That Pinch of Pumpkin
text: THE FLAVOR CALLED PUMPKIN is surging toward a record season in processed foods, with Mars introducing Pumpkin M&Ms, Planters dusting “pumpkin spice” on its almonds and Starbucks bringing back its annual Pumpkin Latte. Sales of last year’s pumpkin offerings climbed nearly 20 percent to more than $290 million, Nielsen reports, and people in the flavor business say the trend has a powerful demographic wind at its back: strong popularity among millennials.

headline: Fairy Tale Opera Leads to Fairy Tale Career Break
text: The machine is coming back to the Metropolitan Opera, which plans to mount a revival of Robert Lepage’s high-tech, polarizing and glitch-prone “Ring” cycle in the 2018-19 season to showcase its next Brünnhilde: the soprano Christine Goerke. She was offered the role after her breakout success last week in Strauss’s fairy tale opera “Die Frau Ohne Schatten.”

headline: Excerpt: 'Patron Saint of Sea Monsters'

headline: Finally, a Place to Buy a Condo and a Basquiat

headline: ‘Silent Night,’ Pulitzer Winner, to Air on PBS
text: “Silent Night,” the opera by Kevin Puts that won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 2012, will have its television premiere on Dec. 13, when PBS broadcasts a performance by the Minnesota Opera, recorded during the work’s world-premiere run in 2011.

headline: A Quiet Release for the iPad Mini
text: The release of Apple’s new iPad Mini on Tuesday lacked the finesse of a typical Apple product release. It also lacked a lot of the pomp.

headline: Twitter Introduces Tool to Make Collecting and Sharing Tweets Easier
text: Twitter introduced a tool Tuesday, called custom timelines, that allows its users to drag and drop tweets to form custom lists of Twitter messages on whatever topic interests them.

headline: To Top JPMorgan Deal Maker, Mergers Still Look Strong
text: Many in the deal sector have been pessimistic about a recovery in the business of mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Program Seeks to Nurture ‘Data Science Culture’ at Universities
text: The modern flood of data comes in a many forms — sensor data, genomic data, web click streams and credit card transactions, to name a few. The disparate data sources are often called “silos,” suggesting the challenge of mingling different data sets to generate insights.

headline: Rich Risotto, Full-Bodied Wine
text: A dish this rich requires a similarly broad, full-bodied wine, like a sumptuous chardonnay, something from the Côte de Beaune, Pouilly-Fuissé, California or Oregon, even Australia, rather than a whipsaw Chablis or other lean example. Within that group, the best choices would be textured and mineral rather than overtly oaky or flamboyantly fruity.

headline: Michelle Obama Talks Education
text: The first lady, Michelle Obama, spoke to students at Bell Multicultural High School in Washington about the importance of education.

headline: Fink Worries About Implications of Health Care Law
text: Many Americans are worried about how their health care will change under the Affordable Care Act. Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, one of the largest money management firms, is worried about those worries.

headline: Poets Remember Seamus Heaney
text: When Seamus Heaney died in August, at 74, he was hailed as a poet of unusual grace and humility, an ambassador for poetry whose reach stretched far beyond the rural Ireland of his most famous verse. And since then, the tributes have kept coming, most recently on Monday night at Cooper Union’s Great Hall, where some 20 poets and friends gathered to read favorite Heaney poems to a packed house.

headline: When Facing Activist Investors, Fight Has Gone 24/7
text: When Carl C. Icahn sought to oppose a buyout of Dell this year, he turned to his classic playbook, issuing impassioned proclamations to shareholders.

headline: What Should Hillary Fear?
text: Noam Scheiber’s big New Republic essay on the idea of an Elizabeth Warren challenge to Hillary Clinton in 2016 is an illuminating window into the liberal mind circa 2013 and a fascinating political portrait-cum-psychobiography of Warren herself. What it is not, however, is a convincing argument that the presumptive Democratic nominee has anything significant to fear from a Warren candidacy right now, let alone that the Massachusetts Senator is anything like a “nightmare” for Team Clinton. Dave Weigel does a good job highlighting one of the key factors that Scheiber’s analysis (rather oddly) leaves out: The demographics of the Democratic primary electorate, which made the Obama insurgency different from pretty much every liberal primary insurgency before it:

headline: Rising Despair as Officials Struggle to Get Aid to Victims
text: The people of Tacloban, the hardest hit city, have been struggling largely on their own as they wait for relief operations to reach them.

headline: Israeli Move Over Housing Poses a Threat to Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — The troubled Middle East peace talks that started this summer threatened to collapse on Tuesday over what the Israeli government described as a routine bureaucratic move by its housing ministry to start long-term planning for 20,000 new apartments in West Bank settlements.

headline: An iPhone Case Hemingway Would Love
text: I’ve been a fan of Moleskine notebooks for years because of their rugged appearance and warm textures, which invite me to jot my thoughts down. But with the advent of smartphones, carrying the notebooks around seemed redundant because I could make notes digitally. So I ditched the notebooks for a smooth, cold iPhone.

headline: Investor Says Men’s Wearhouse Will Review Merger With Jos. A. Bank
text: Men’s Wearhouse and its investment bankers plan to review a number of strategic options, including an unsolicited $2.3 billion takeover bid by rival Jos. A. Bank, a big investor in the retailer said on Tuesday.

headline: Headphones Turn Up the Bass, Their Way
text: Headphone manufacturers may finally realize that imitating the thumping bass sound of Beats headphones does not automatically lead to Beats-size success.

headline: Fall Fashion for the iPhone

headline: The View From Saturn
text: On July 19, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft looked back from the shadow of Saturn to take a picture of the ringed planet in all its glory and indeed the entire inner solar system. Knowing that the Earth would also be in the field of view — the third time that our planet has sat for its portrait from the outer solar system, Cassini’s managers asked everyone to smile. Apparently, many of us did, although you might not be able to pick yourself out of the cosmic crowd in this image released by NASA and the Cassini team on Tuesday.

headline: Sushi Dojo and Kurumazushi
text: Inside two sushi restaurants: a new place leaning toward poppy neo-disco in the East Village, and an older, more sedate establishment in Midtown.

headline: Living Along Central Park North
text: The area’s population, historically dominated by blacks, has diversified at an even faster clip than Central Harlem as a whole.

headline: How the Word ‘North’ Affects Prices
text: The moment Gary Davis popped his head out of the subway station on Central Park North and Lenox Avenue in 2004, he understood he was looking at an extraordinary spot. An architect and real estate developer, he had been invited to the block by a lawyer for the owner of a two-story corner building there, and though Mr. Davis recalls not being “very excited about Harlem,” he was quick to see the site’s potential. He then sent a photographer 120 feet above the street in a bucket attached to a crane arm; the resulting pictures showed breathtaking panoramic views of Central Park and miles beyond.

headline: Philadelphia Schools See Cash in Old Classrooms
text: PHILADELPHIA — The financially troubled school district here is seeking buyers for more than two dozen school buildings that it shuttered last summer in one of the country’s biggest school closing programs.

headline: Dance Moves From the Deep Sea
text: Disco music with raw fish in the East Village may not strike you as a winning formula unless you remember when Avenue A had what was probably the only sushi bar in the city with a mirror ball and a D.J. booth. Everybody called it Disco Sushi, and I loved it for reasons that had nothing to do with the food. I had eaten enough good sushi to know I couldn’t afford it. But cold rice, fake wasabi and sinewy fish mattered much less when vinyl records and the mirror ball were spinning, the tables were filling up with musicians waiting for a 1 a.m. gig at Brownies, and we were all on our third round of sake bombs.

headline: Murder in the Midwest
text: The shooting occurred about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Aug. 4, 1863, “halfway between sundown and dark,” as one witness described it. The day had been a typically hot one in Indianapolis, but a rain shower in the early evening cooled the air and knocked down the dust. Residents came out of their houses and shops onto the streets. Others ate their suppers or relaxed on their porches after a long day of work.

headline: Scene City: Fashion Industry Crowns Young Designers
text: Public School takes top prize at the 10th annual CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner.

headline: Experts Reshape Treatment Guide for Cholesterol
text: The nation’s leading heart organizations released new guidelines on Tuesday that will fundamentally reshape the use of cholesterol-lowering statin medicines, which are now prescribed for a quarter of Americans over 40. Patients on statins will no longer need to lower their cholesterol levels to specific numerical targets monitored by regular blood tests, as has been recommended for decades. Simply taking the right dose of a statin will be sufficient, the guidelines say.

headline: When Doctors Share With Their Patients
text: At our very first visit, I was overwhelmed by all of the issues my new patient faced. She was nearly 300 pounds and her diabetes was raging out of control. She had asthma, but smoked to ease her anxiety. Her obesity severely limited her mobility, but the constant stress in her life led her to overeat.

headline: S.E.C. Tries New Tack in Hedge Fund Fraud Case
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has for the first time employed a new tool to encourage individuals involved in fraud investigations to cooperate by deferring their prosecution.

headline: In Sweden, the Fika Experience
text: Coffee is a way of life in Sweden. It is not simply a beverage you grab to go, or something used for a jolt in the morning. Coffee is an experience.

After the Typhoon, the Heartbreak

headline: Auction Highlights From Christie’s

headline: Finding Fault Everywhere He Looked
text: The radical Irish-American journalist Alexander Cockburn — he called himself Marxish, not Marxist — liked to bomb around America’s blue highways in large, decrepit cars, preferably convertibles, faxing in and later emailing his rowdy political columns (for The Nation, The Village Voice and elsewhere) from the road.

headline: 3 Things to Know About the New Cholesterol Guidelines
text: The American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association just released new cholesterol guidelines to reduce atherosclerotic cardiovascular risk –- and the change from the previous version, last updated in 2004, is profound. Here are three things you need to know about these new guidelines.

headline: Penn Kimball, Journalist Who Sued U.S., Dies at 98
text: Penn Kimball, a journalist and teacher who successfully sued the federal government in a 10-year quest to clear his name after he discovered that secret government files had identified him as a national security risk, died on Friday at a nursing home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 98.

headline: First Lady’s New Initiative: College, ‘Whatever It Takes’
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama urged high school students on Tuesday to increase the opportunities available to them by pursuing higher education as she kicked off an initiative that seeks to increase the number of low-income students graduating from college and signaled her plans to focus more on administration policy during the president’s second term.

headline: Using Food to Make an Off-Campus Area More Inviting
text: Redevelopment along the streets south of Columbia University has long been difficult. Urban renewal schemes, police sweeps and wars on rats have all been deployed since the 1950s with little success.

headline: Kennedy Is Sworn In as Japan Envoy, a Post Long Held by Political Notables
text: WASHINGTON — Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of John F. Kennedy and one of President Obama’s most prominent supporters, was sworn in Tuesday as the United States ambassador to Japan.

headline: What a ‘Paychecks for Pulses’ Plan Could, and Couldn’t, Do for Families
text: In Switzerland, activists have delivered enough signatures to the government to trigger a public referendum on an audacious proposal: the government would provide a monthly income to every citizen, no strings attached. As Annie Lowrey writes in “Switzerland’s Proposal to Pay People for Being Alive” for The New York Times Magazine:

headline: Emotional Speech by Philippine Delegate
text: Excerpts from a statement about Typhoon Haiyan by Naderev Saño, the chief representative of the Philippines at the Warsaw Climate Change Conference.
