headline: The Gun Report: November 13, 2013
text: The victims of gun violence we write about in this space are strangers. We feel for their plight and empathize with their loved ones, but we do not know them. That changed for me on Monday, when I pulled up the Times homepage and read about the death of someone I knew.

headline: A Moment of Love, Before a Goodbye
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Petrobras of Brazil Sells Peruvian Unit to Chinese Company
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – Brazil’s state-controlled oil company Petrobras announced on Wednesday that it was selling all of its Peruvian subsidiary, Petrobras Energia Peru, to the China National Petroleum Company for $2.6 billion.

headline: Hector Sants Resigns From Barclays
text: Updated, 10:38 a.m. |

headline: ‘Fifty Shades’ Film Release Is Pushed to 2015
text: LOS ANGELES — The movie masses will have to wait a little longer for “Fifty Shades of Grey.”

headline: Motorola to Offer Moto G Smartphone Aimed at Emerging Markets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, is still trying to find its niche in the smartphone market.

headline: The Fallen Hero of Serbian Tennis
text: The first time Serbia was in a Davis Cup final, Viktor Troicki won the decisive match in Belgrade and experienced what he still calls “the biggest moment” of his life.

headline: Bank of England Hints at Rate Increase, Citing Recovery
text: LONDON — The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it might consider raising interest rates earlier than previously expected because Britain’s economic recovery was gaining speed.

headline: Germany’s Neighbors Admonish It Over Surplus
text: FRANKFURT — Germany, which has often scolded other countries for accumulating too much debt and not being competitive enough in the global economy, now finds its own economic policy under heavy attack.

headline: Daily Report: Motorola’s Low-End Smartphone Faces Challenges
text: Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, is still trying to find its niche in the smartphone market, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: An Entrepreneur Who Manufactures Entrepreneurs
text: Conventional wisdom holds that some 90 percent of start-ups fail. After years of observation, Adeo Ressi — a serial entrepreneur who founded TheFunded.com, an online community where entrepreneurs rate investors; Methodfive, a website developer; and Total New York, which became AOL Digital Cities — concluded that the high failure rate was the result of the wrong people starting businesses and not getting the right training.

headline: How I Made My Biggest Mistake in China (So Far)
text: Every book on doing business in China touts the importance of building personal connections and “guanxi.”

headline: Ukraine Delays Bill to Free Ex-Leader
text: MOSCOW — In a move that could derail plans for Ukraine to sign political and free trade agreements with the European Union this month, the country’s Parliament on Wednesday postponed consideration of a bill that would free the jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, and allow her to seek medical treatment in Germany.

headline: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 2
text: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers’ questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members. Part 1 of her answers is here. [Update: Part 3 is here. Part 4 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

headline: Is This the Way to Teach Entrepreneurship?
text: The Times has just published a conversation with Adeo Ressi, who created the Founder Institute. In the conversation, Mr. Ressi reports that more than 1,000 aspiring entrepreneurs have graduated from his start-up incubator, each with a new company idea. Of those companies, about 10 percent have failed and 15 percent have gone dormant, Mr. Ressi said, while the rest are moving forward.

headline: In Experienced Hands
text: Compared with parents, who are sometimes stressed, distracted and short of sleep, grandparents are, at least by reputation, a relaxed and indulgent set; tolerant of youthful enthusiasm and well rested at last after their own adventures in child rearing.

headline: Attacks Across Iraq Kill Dozens
text: BAGHDAD — A series of bomb blasts and gunfire attacks swept Iraq on Wednesday, mostly targeting Shiites who were marking one of their holiest religious events.

headline: Image of the Day: November 13
text: Widows in Bhubaneshwar, Odisha, observing the Hindu festival of Kartik Poornima.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Dior Scorpio Necklace
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Former Lobbyist Becomes Biden Chief of Staff
text: WASHINGTON — Steve Ricchetti, a former lobbyist and Clinton administration veteran, will replace Bruce Reed as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s chief of staff next month, the White House announced Wednesday.

headline: Zombies in His Past, Now Onto Cops
text: In preparing for “Mob City,” a fictional look at the seedy underbelly of 1940s-era Los Angeles and his first new television series in three years, Frank Darabont has had to excise other favorite TV shows and movies from his regular cultural diet.

headline: Residents Suing to Stop ‘Fortresslike’ Plan for World Trade Center
text: To the question, “How much security apparatus is needed on city streets?” the agencies charged with guarding public safety seem to answer, “As much as we say.”

headline: 1929: Seal on The Loose in Paris
text: The New York Herald dedicated a fair amount of space to the smaller, curious events in its pages. When a seal escaped onto the streets of Paris, the “most serious of frivolous newspapers” reported on an argument between bystanders:

headline: ‘Maxed Out’ Author Thought Readers Would Critique Her Ideas. Instead, They Judged Her Choices.
text: When KJ Dell’Antonia’s article about my book, “Maxed Out: American Moms on the Brink,” was published on Motherlode last week (“Being a Working Mother Means Always Having to Say You’re Sorry“), I was thrilled to see it generating passionate discussion in the comments section. This is, after all, the main reason I wrote “Maxed Out” — to get people talking about the structural issues holding women back in their careers and their lives.

headline: Memory of a Mass Killing Becomes Another Casualty of Egyptian Protests
text: CAIRO — The police arrested the girls, interrogated them for hours, and then strip-searched and detained them for 10 days. They were charged with serious crimes, including endangering national security, for what the authorities regarded as an act of subversion: passing out yellow balloons.

headline: Off the Coast of Chile, an Island Getaway
text: With only the vaguest of plans, I pulled my rental car onto the ferry to Lemuy Island, 37 square miles of hills and farms and dirt roads and ocean views. As I headed out from the main island of the Chiloé Archipelago, off the Chilean coast, I had a simple agenda for that afternoon: drive around, visit one of the old wooden churches the islands are famous for, see what else happens.

headline: Live Music Gains as a Hotel Amenity
text: From guitars in rooms to full-on concerts in the lobbies, hotels are making music a major amenity.

headline: Schools That Separate the Child From the Trauma
text: Recently, I reported on the damaging effects that prolonged stress can have on young children who lack adequate protection from adults. Over the past 15 years, researchers have learned that highly stressful — and potentially traumatic — childhood experiences are more prevalent than previously understood. Now scientists are shedding light on the mechanisms by which they change the brain and body. These insights have far-reaching implications for schools, where it’s still standard practice to punish children for misbehavior that they often do not know how to control. This is comparable to punishing a child for having a seizure; it adds to the suffering and makes matters worse.

headline: Why Stay in High School, When You Could Be Out Drinking?
text: Coarse language, loose women, good-for-nothing men and rampant alcoholism are all dragging down Derby Street, the skid row of an unnamed Northern industrial city. So, unfortunately, is terrible direction.

headline: Classical Playlist: Andras Schiff, Janine Jansen, Rebekah Heller and More
text: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: In Britain, an Unlikely Call to Redistribute Cultural Capital
text: Imagine planning a trip to Britain with a stop to hear a new opera by Mark-Anthony Turnage at a newly built version of the Royal Opera House, not in Covent Garden, but in Liverpool. And from there, you might drive northeast to savor antiquities at the British Museum, which will have painstakingly rebuilt Sir Robert Smirke’s grand Greek Revival building in Morpeth, the county seat of Northumberland.

headline: Roundup: Staff Departures, an ‘Incorrect Promise’ and More
text: Here’s a roundup of items from all over that may be interesting to Times readers and to the readers of this blog:

headline: Health Website Official Tells of White House Briefings
text: WASHINGTON — The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace said Wednesday that he met periodically with White House aides to discuss the status of the website over the last three years, but he said the meetings focused narrowly on specific technical issues and therefore gave the president no clear warning of the disaster that ensued on Oct. 1.

headline: Out of Europe’s Long Jobs Crisis, Voices of the Young
text: The Times asked young people in Europe to share their stories about how the crisis has affected their lives. Here is a selection of the responses.

headline: Murder as Musical Punch Line
text: It’s a surprisingly fertile season on New York stages for witty variations on the nail biter, what with Beth Henley’s Southern Gothic “The Jacksonian,” the musical “Murder for Two” and John Pollono’s comic thriller “Small Engine Repair.”  Now comes another show to remind us, as Alfred Hitchcock was so fond of doing, that dark and deadly intrigue need not be deadly serious.

headline: Does Individual Insurance Work?
text: Amid this week’s hints that the federal exchange still won’t be anywhere close to functional on December 1st, Matt Yglesias offers the latest noble attempt to explain to Americans losing their individual-market coverage why they’re actually better off paying higher premiums for new, Obamacare-era plans. Instead of focusing on the more comprehensive benefits that the new plans offer, he takes a different tack — suggesting that most people with cheapish individual-market coverage didn’t really have insurance at all:

headline: An Old Guitar Finds New Life on the Internet
text: Connor Millican and Corey Pane, two friends from Connecticut who were playing music together and dabbling in video production, had an idea: They wanted to put a funky old guitar in the hands of some funky young musicians and ask them to pluck out a tune. While the players would vary, the guitar would be the constant, becoming a shared tool between artists with different styles and methods.

headline: Reviewing Opera Fan Fiction
text: The premise behind my article “Liberating the Librettos” was that opera-lovers inevitably become so involved with the stories of our favorite operas that we cultivate elaborate fantasies about what happens to the characters after the curtain goes down. My conviction was borne out by the insight, thoughtfulness and wit of the many comments that readers, all fellow opera-lovers, sent in.

headline: Video: ‘Annie Hall,’ the Sequel
text: Recently, Cara Araneta, 32, a brand designer, was strolling along Broadway in Union Square with a friend, her hands tucked into the pockets of her high-waist jeans. Not that far from Midtown and with the East Village only a couple of blocks away, Union Square is a “mix between uptown and downtown,” Ms. Araneta said. “You see a lot of young people hanging out, like skateboards, that kind of N.Y.U. school vibe, and then you see businesspeople coming here for lunch or going to work.”

headline: Skiers Tame the Magic Kingdom
text: In this first episode of Behind the Line, Ian McIntosh and Sage Cattabriga-Alosa make first descents in the Neacola Mountains of Alaska.

headline: Video: Skiers Tame the Magic Kingdom
text: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Ruscha’s Archives Go to the Ransom Center in Texas
text: The Harry Ransom Center, a museum and research library at the University of Texas, Austin, has acquired the archives of Ed Ruscha, the prolific Pop Art master who is best known for his quirky thematic photography books, like “Twentysix Gasoline Stations” (1963) and “Every Building on the Sunset Strip” (1966), and for his word paintings, in which words are manipulated in ways that transform their meanings or suggest amusing tangential underpinnings.

headline: Wheelies: The Magnificent Mazda Edition
text: A roundup of automotive news from around the web:

headline: House Hunting in ... Toronto
text: A HISTORIC NEO-ROMANESQUE HOME IN ROSEDALE, TORONTO

headline: House Hunting in Toronto
text: A red-brick semidetached home in the Rosedale neighborhood of Toronto is on the market for $3.7 million.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Great Beauty’
text: The director Paolo Sorrentino narrates the opening sequence of his film.

headline: Woman Accused of Stalking Alec Baldwin Takes Stand to Give Her Side
text: A woman accused of stalking Alec Baldwin took the witness stand on Wednesday to tell her story, saying Mr. Baldwin seduced her on a romantic New York date in February 2010, then wrote her for months afterward suggesting he cared for her.

headline: Perella Weinberg Hires Goldman Sachs Managing Director
text: Perella Weinberg Partners has hired Jonathan Prather, a managing director in Goldman Sachs’s global industrials group, as a partner in its advisory business.

headline: Chegg Falls in Debut, but Chief Remains Ebullient
text: Updated, 4:56 p.m. |

headline: At Bloomberg, Special Code Keeps Some Articles Out of China
text: It is called Code 204. Editors at Bloomberg News append it to an article to ensure that it does not appear on Bloomberg financial data and news terminals in mainland China. Little known outside Bloomberg, the system has been in place for more than two years, and it is used regularly to keep articles on Chinese politics and social issues away from the eyes of powerful people in China who might be offended, Bloomberg employees say.

headline: Hotel Review: Rosa Et Al Townhouse in Porto
text: Rates

headline: Listen Up | Three Indie Music Fixtures Venture Out on Their Own
text: This fall, individual members of three of indie music’s most inventive bands release their own solo projects that push the limits of their signature sounds.

headline: Which iPad? It Depends. What Do You Want to Do?
text: Apple is now selling the new iPad Mini, the smaller brother of the pleasing iPad Air, which I reviewed a couple of weeks ago. Somehow, Apple has squeezed all of the Air’s capabilities into the Mini — and by doing that, Apple has made the process of choosing an iPad easy.

headline: Coffey to Join Kramer Levin in a Return to Law Practice
text: John P. Coffey stood behind the lectern in a federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan this summer, firing off pointed questions and composing hand-drawn diagrams to defend his client, the former Goldman Sachs trader Fabrice Tourre.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Is Reviewing Discredited Benghazi Report
text: “60 Minutes” announced on Wednesday that it was conducting an internal review of its now discredited report on the terrorist attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Great Beauty’
text: The latest film from Paolo Sorrentino follows a journalist (Toni Servillo) in Rome as he reflects on his life. The film, much like its lead character, wanders around the city and focuses on many of its landmarks. In this video, Mr. Sorrentino narrates a look at the opening sequence, which suggests that the city can be so stunning to take in, that it can be deadly.

headline: Senator Joe Manchin: In His Own Words
text: In selections from a recent interview with Jonathan Weisman, Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, talks about sticking to his principles and the worst that can happen to a politician.

headline: A Lesson From Grandfather
text: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia told The Times's Jonathan Weisman in a recent interview that he first learned the importance of financial responsibility when he was just a child.

headline: Distress Grows for Philippine Typhoon Victims
text: Even as an enormous global aid effort gathered momentum, international officials expressed concern that delays could prevent supplies from reaching survivors of Typhoon Haiyan for days.

headline: Dropbox Aims at Business
text: Dropbox, an online storage service that has gained 200 million consumers in five years, is heading to the office.

headline: Stand-Alone Food Section Faces Demise in Bay Area
text: In the food-obsessed Bay Area, The San Francisco Chronicle’s food section has been as much of a city institution as the cable car, and to many San Franciscans, more useful. Over the years it has won many awards and developed a dedicated following.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Secrets of Sriracha
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A High Five and a Handshake for Aether and Icebreaker
text: A theory I toy around with is that the most attractive people wear the ugliest workout clothing. Maybe it’s because beautiful people have to give less thought to what they swaddle their glorious forms in, or maybe it’s because if you’re inclined to think about how good your athletic gear looks, you probably aren’t getting the maximum use out of it, or getting the item that’s designed for maximum use.

headline: Senator Manchin Takes On Democratic Party Leaders in Pursuit of a Middle Ground
text: WASHINGTON — In late August, Senate Democrats gathered on a conference call with President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, to hear why the administration had to respond militarily to a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government.

headline: App Smart: Teaching Kids Math
text: Children can learn math skills, from addition to algebra, through an array of apps for tablets and smartphones.

headline: With Apps, Children Can Play the Game of Math
text: My 5-year-old son recently explained to my 3-year-old son that they were two years apart. Three years old plus 2 years old equals 5 years old, he explained.

headline: OTB, a Bar in Williamsburg
text: A string of less scene-y bars has opened up in Williamsburg, one of the latest being OTB, on a sleepy stretch of Broadway next to the Williamsburg Bridge. Unlike its rowdier neighbors on the north side, this place is notable for what it lacks: hype, high prices and members of the maligned social subset that begins with the letter H.

headline: In Statement From Prison, Morsi Accuses Egypt’s Military Leaders of Treason
text: CAIRO — In a statement he dictated from prison and made public through his lawyers on Wednesday, Mohamed Morsi, the former Islamist president of Egypt, accused his opponents in the military-backed government of treason and warned that Egypt would “not recover” from its crisis until the “coup” that removed him from power was reversed.

headline: Police Say Spy Found in Bag Probably Died by Accident
text: LONDON — The bizarre death of a British intelligence analyst whose body was discovered inside a sports bag in a bathtub was called a probable accident by the London police on Wednesday, an inconclusive ending to one of the most puzzling investigations in recent years.

headline: Toronto Mayor Admits to Buying Drugs
text: At a Toronto City Council meeting, Mayor Rob Ford said he bought illegal drugs in the last two years. When asked if he had an addiction to illicit drugs, the mayor said “absolutely not.”

headline: Global Warming, College and Partisanship
text: It’s well known that Democrats and political independents are more likely than Republicans to believe that global warming is mainly due to human activity. But here’s something from the latest Pew poll on climate change: College has a significantly larger effect on Democrats’ understanding of the issue than on Republicans’.

headline: Tables Turned, Victims’ Relatives Get Their Chance at Bulger
text: BOSTON — David Wheeler stood in the well of a federal courtroom here Wednesday, gesturing toward James (Whitey) Bulger, the elderly man who was once the overlord of the Boston underworld and who had ordered his father’s murder.

headline: New Catfish Inspections Are Posing a Problem for a Pacific Trade Pact
text: WASHINGTON — A curious hurdle is threatening to complicate efforts by the United States to reach a major trade agreement with 11 Pacific nations by the end of the year: catfish.

headline: Wylie Dufresne's Turkey Hash
text: Wylie Dufresne, the owner of WD-50, doesn’t contribute to Thanksgiving dinner; he makes breakfast the next day. He shows Mark Bittman how he makes his fried eggs and turkey hash.

headline: Goldman Sachs Promotes 280 to Managing Director
text: Goldman Sachs has promoted 280 executives to managing director, one step down from the brass ring of partner. Promotions are up 5 percent over last year, when the firm named 266 employees managing director.

headline: The East Village: To Escape the Sirens
text: It wasn’t until the summer — his first in a large one-bedroom at Seventh Avenue and 14th Street — that Jeff Greenspan realized how noisy his home was. Maybe the racket came through the air-conditioner vents. Sirens shrieked by in an endless parade.

headline: Finance Lessons, From the World of Art Auctions
text: The record-busting $142 million sale on Tuesday by Christie’s of Francis Bacon’s triptych of Lucian Freud – not to mention the unprecedented New York auction total of almost $700 million – shows a contemporary art market in heady territory. It’s possible, if a bit tenuous, to extract a matching trio of lessons for the broader world of finance.

headline: Ask Well: Table Salt or Sea Salt?
text: The differences between table salt and sea salt explained, both in nutrition and taste.

headline: President Aquino on Typhoon Aftermath
text: A sample of President Benigno S. Aquino III’s statements on Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines.

headline: Remixing a Pulitzer Prize-Winning Work
text: New Amsterdam Presents, the feisty alt-classical label and concert-presenting organization that the composers William Brittelle, Judd Greenstein, and Sarah Kirkland Snider started in 2007, is collaborating with the Q2 Music web page on an unusual fund-raising project for the company. Every Wednesday for eight weeks, starting Nov. 13, Q2 will stream a remix of Caroline Shaw’s “Partita,” for which she won the Pulitzer Prize this year. The streaming tracks are freely available, but if you want to download one, or all eight, the page provides a link to New Amsterdam’s fund-raising page, where you can make a donation (the amount is not specified, but it is tax deductible) and download the tracks.

headline: We’re Buds, Right? It’s Hard to Tell.
text: Is it possible for the characters in a play to wrest control of it from the playwright? “How to Make Friends and Then Kill Them,” a very dark comedy by Halley Feiffer at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, starts out intriguingly but eventually spirals out of control, the three characters in it seeming as if they are trying to make you regret attending.

headline: A Swan Leaps Off the Page and Onto the Stage
text: A swan puppet makes an early appearance in certain versions of “Swan Lake,” illustrating the heroine’s ensnarement at the hands of an evil magician. It’s a big moment in the narrative, obviously, but that bird has it easy compared with Sophie, who carries on her feathered wings the entire production of “Ballerina Swan,” a children’s book by the former ballerina Allegra Kent that has been turned into a children’s dance-theater work by Making Books Sing.

headline: Egyptian Soccer Star Banned for Expressing Sympathy With Massacred Islamists
text: Updated, Thursday, 2:03 p.m. | Just days after he scored a crucial goal to clinch the African Champions League title for his club, Al Ahly of Cairo, an Egyptian soccer player has been suspended by the team and put up for sale because of the way he celebrated his strike, by raising four fingers in the air.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,300,000
text: MADISON, N.J.

headline: Homes for $1,300,000
text: A 1903 house in New Jersey, a stone cottage near Dallas and a midcentury modern near Detroit are featured this week.

headline: Only 106,000 Pick Health Insurance Plans in First Month
text: WASHINGTON — Just over 106,000 people picked health plans in the first month of open enrollment through the state and federal insurance marketplaces established by the Affordable Care Act, President Obama’s health secretary said Wednesday, a fraction of the administration’s initial estimate for enrollment during that period.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing Matchups of Top Wide Receivers
text: One of the most-used metrics in predicting fantasy football performance is matchup analysis (player versus opposing defense). A particular team gives up a certain amount of fantasy points per game to this position, which is presumed to be a relevant statistic when deciding which player to start that week.

headline: Teaching About the Typhoon in the Philippines
text: Please preview this Times video as there are many graphic images.

headline: NBCUniversal Takes Full Ownership of Sprout Cable Network
text: The NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired full ownership of the fast-growing preschool cable network PBS Kids Sprout, signaling its intent to more aggressively build up its children’s and family entertainment business, which already encompasses theme parks and movies.

headline: Health Care Enrollment Numbers
text: The Department of Health and Human Services released the number of people who have enrolled in the health insurance market place in November.

headline: Farm-to-Click
text: The Times’s Jenna Wortham reviews Good Eggs, a new food shopping website that delivers locally sourced farmer’s market products right to your door.

headline: Elegance in Auction Country at the Arizona Concours d’Élégance
text: PHOENIX — It’s not as if Kevin Cornish didn’t have enough to keep him busy. He’s an executive with a company that consults with hospitals, pharmaceutical manufacturers, health insurers and others in the industry on issues including legislation and litigation.

headline: Red Bulls Wrap-Up: Coach Looks Ahead
text: A week after the Red Bulls’ season came to an abrupt end in the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs, Coach Mike Petke on Wednesday took part in what is likely to be his final teleconference call this year with reporters.

headline: Good Eggs, a Virtual Farmer’s Market, Delivers Real Food
text: When I was growing up, my father was fond of ordering steaks through the mail. When they arrived, my sister and I gleefully danced around the icy packages and argued over who got to open them. I can still remember marveling at the novelty of meat arriving in the same pile as regular letters, and our amazement that it tasted as good as — if not better than — the beef we purchased in the supermarket.

headline: New Rules for Dolphin-Watching
text: As part of its sustainability program, the Six Senses Laamu resort in the Maldives has adopted a code of conduct for its dolphin-watching trips.

headline: Eminem Tops Album Chart; Lorde Signs a Deal for Songs
text: If you bought an album last week, there is a 1 in 7 chance that it was “The Marshall Mathers LP 2,” by Eminem.

headline: Till Baby Comes, Keep Smiling
text: LOS ANGELES — “Puuuush!”

headline: A Chef in the Field | Cauliflower
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Bloomberg Issues Final Letter Grades for New York Schools
text: Nothing came to epitomize the era of education reform under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg like the A-through-F letter grades he gave New York’s schools.

headline: Sotheby’s Contemporary Evening Sale
text: Notable works for sale at Wednesday night’s contemporary evening auction at Sotheby’s in New York.

headline: The Traditional Chorus That Keeps Bach Young
text: To comprehend the legacy of the St. Thomas Boys Choir of Leipzig, consider this: When Bach became its music director, called Thomaskantor, in 1723, this eminent institution had already been around for 511 years. Last year, the choir celebrated its 800th anniversary. Currently it is finishing an American tour, presenting 11 concerts over 16 days.

headline: E.U. Identifies Problems in Its Members’ Economies
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top economic policy chiefs, invoking new oversight tools, warned Germany, France and 14 other member countries on Wednesday to address problems with their economies.

headline: Holding Joy Close, and Age at Bay
text: “No Evidence of Failure” sounds like a phrase from an accident report in which the remains of a crashed vehicle give no clue as to what went wrong. At the Joyce Theater on Tuesday it was the title of a dance celebrating something that has gone mysteriously right: how the 51-year-old dancer Natalie Rogers, who returned to the Garth Fagan Dance company last year after an eight-year break, can still look so amazing.

headline: Book Deal or No Book Deal
text: “Masterpiece” is a new Italian reality show in which writers compete to have their work published.

headline: Tired Metaphors? Ciao, Contestant!
text: TURIN, Italy — A novelist craves solitude. Reality TV craves intrusion. So, what happens when writing becomes a broadcast spectacle?

headline: A Hostile Bank Takeover
text: The government of Bangladesh has played its trump card in its long-running campaign against Grameen Bank and its founder Muhammad Yunus. Last week, legislators passed a law that effectively nationalizes the bank, which pioneered the idea of making small loans to poor women, by wresting control of it from the 8.4 million rural women that own a majority of its shares.

headline: Clip: '12-12-12'
text: A clip from the documentary.

headline: Clip: Remembering Moms Mabley
text: A clip from the documentary "Whoopi Goldberg Presents Moms Mabley," airing on HBO Nov. 18.

headline: A Writer Thrives in Two Cultures
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2010 the novelist Daniel Alarcón was included on The New Yorker’s “20 Under 40” list of promising young American writers. Three years earlier his name had appeared on a similar list of Latin American novelists, the “Bogotá 39,” but as a Peruvian.

headline: Carlyle-Backed Brazilian Tour Operator Plans Stock Offering
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – A planned stock offering of a Brazilian tour agency and operator backed by the Carlyle Group could raise as much as 1 billion reais, or $428 million, for its existing shareholders, according to a filing on Wednesday.

headline: Navigating the Constraints on Reporting from China
text: ‘‘I ask myself why I stay on here,’’ William L. Shirer wrote in Berlin on Sept. 20, 1940, as World War II deepened and Nazi censorship of his CBS radio broadcasts became intolerable.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Inspires Famous Imitators
text: In 2008, Gwyneth Paltrow, the actress everyone loves to hate (or so it seems sometimes), decided she wanted to be more than just an actress. She started a “nourishing” website called Goop to pass along her wisdom of the good life.

headline: With Enrollment Slow, Some Democrats Back Change in Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — Anxious congressional Democrats are threatening to abandon President Obama on a central element of his signature health care law, voicing increasing support for proposals that would allow Americans who are losing their health insurance coverage because of the Affordable Care Act to retain it.

headline: Keynesian Economics and the Journals
text: Brad DeLong takes on John Cochrane again; I don’t have the heart or the time to do a full takedown myself. But I do want to make five points.

headline: Always an Air of Sorrow, Even in Songs of Love
text: Daniel Woolhouse set the tempo early on Tuesday night. Wearing a ski cap and black T-shirt, he sat down on the Mercury Lounge stage behind a pair of keyboards, pressed a couple of buttons, and there was that bass: sticky, gritty, creepy, oozy.

headline: The Crazy Lower Bound
text: John Holbo makes a really interesting point — it’s a bit subjective, but I suspect that smart political scientists could find a way to quantify it.

headline: The Lederer Memorial Trophy in London
text: All top players like to receive an invitation to the Lederer Memorial Trophy in London. It is a most enjoyable weekend, with a social atmosphere and top-level bridge.

headline: Going Backstage at a $50 Million Benefit Concert
text: The documentary filmmaker Amir Bar-Lev has made features about the fog of war and the follies of the fine art world, but he had always wanted to make a movie about a music scene. Last year he was given that chance and then some.

headline: A Rugged Tablet, but Not for Consumers
text: TOKYO — Would you try this with any tablet, be it an Apple iPad, Microsoft Surface or Samsung Galaxy? Dunk a tablet computer into a bucket of water and keep it submerged for half an hour? NEC, the Japanese electronics company, says you could do it with the NEC Shieldpro H11A tablet. It also says you could drop it from a five-foot height onto a concrete floor.

headline: A Star’s Tale Reveals Lore of Old Hollywood
text: Victoria Wilson’s gargantuan biography of Barbara Stanwyck manages to fill 860 glittering pages of text with only the first half of Stanwyck’s story. It ends after “Stella Dallas” (1937) but before “The Lady Eve” (1941) is even a twinkle in Preston Sturges’s eye. And it ends with a cliffhanger, creating eager anticipation for Ms. Wilson’s concluding volume. What kind of Parkinson’s law, about how work expands to fill available time, can possibly have expanded the Stanwyck story to these proportions?

headline: A Corporate ‘Upstairs Downstairs’ With an Express Elevator to Bed
text: In “Ground Floor,” a workplace sitcom that begins Thursday on TBS, Bill Lawrence oddly duplicates the template of “Cougar Town,” the successful series he helped create in 2009.

headline: Distortion and Reverberation as a Force of Nature
text: My Bloody Valentine brought its gorgeous onslaught to Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night — its last show, the band’s guitarist and leader Kevin Shields announced onstage, “for a long time.” It was the end of the tour associated with “m b v,” this Irish band’s first album since 1991, which it released in February. My Bloody Valentine’s sense of timing is entirely its own.

headline: Roll With It, Baby
text: It was 10 p.m., and the floor of the basketball court in a Bedford-Stuyvesant Salvation Army center was a blur of roller skate-powered counterclockwise motion.

headline: Roller Skating Goes Underground
text: A dance party on wheels attracts even roller disco denizens who never gave up.

headline: Reading a Violinist From the Arm, Not Fingers
text: Casual observers tend to concentrate on a violinist’s left arm: the one, in most cases, with the hand moving crazily up and down the fingerboard, fingers moving like little pistons. But it’s the right arm — the one with the bow — that makes music, finessing a series of notes into colors and phrases poetic or piquant.

headline: Yellen to Back Stimulus Plan in Remarks to Senators
text: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, President Obama’s choice to lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years, plans to tell senators at her confirmation hearing on Thursday that continuing the Fed’s enormous stimulus campaign is the best way to revive the economy and hasten the program’s end.

headline: April Bloomfield's Clam Chowder
text: Mark Bittman describes April Bloomfield’s clam chowder dish as a “very fall, New England dish.” She demonstrates how to make this coarse-chopped soup.

headline: Lou Reed’s New York Was Hell or Heaven
text: He wrote about hustlers, drag queens and speed freaks, and about the ordinary dreamers, misfits and down-and-outers who populated the hotels and nighttime streets of New York City — native-born New Yorkers like himself, and all the lost or marginal seekers who came to the city to become somebody else or take a walk on the wild side. Pearly Mae, who “can’t tell the night from the day”; Jackie, who thought “she was James Dean for a day”; the small kid standing by the Lincoln Tunnel, “selling plastic roses for a buck”; the “druggy downtown kids who spray-paint walls and trains.”

headline: Chihuahuas Catch a Flight to Their New Homes
text: Virgin America offered a group of California Chihuahuas a lift to the New York area on Wednesday, the fifth time the airline has assisted the San Francisco Department of Animal Care and Control with getting dogs to new homes on the East Coast.

headline: André Soltner's Pumpkin Soup
text: For Thanksgiving, André Soltner prepares a version of pumpkin soup that he watched his mother make over 75 years ago. The creamy soup is served in a pumpkin and garnished with croutons.

headline: Rachel Comey Aims for a Bigger Slice of Fashion’s Pie
text: One brisk afternoon this fall, a few weeks after Rachel Comey showed her spring collection at a dinner in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a few fans dropped by her studio on lower Broadway to browse the new designs.

headline: Fashion’s Royalty Pays Tribute to Its Successors
text: The designer Tom Ford has cultivated a hedonistic image, but who knew that among those to have seen him naked is Anna Wintour. When Mr. Ford was vacationing on St. Barts in the early 1990s, Ms. Wintour was staying near the nude beach, and — whoops — there she was when he sauntered by in the buff.

headline: Paper Dolls With Military Stories to Tell
text: The story of American women can be told through paper dolls.

headline: William T. Vollmann: The Self Images of a Cross-Dresser
text: SACRAMENTO — As far as writers go, William T. Vollmann is a man’s man. In pursuit of a story, he has roughed it with the mujahedeen in Afghanistan and survived a land mine explosion in Bosnia. He singed his eyebrows off and nearly froze to death exploring the magnetic North Pole. In Thailand, he rescued a teenage girl from sex slavery by kidnapping her from a pimp.

headline: An Ensemble, in Its 15th Season, Reimagines and Interprets
text: Character pieces, a staple of romantic repertory, traverse a range of often blissful or atmospheric moods and scenes. But there are no dreamy moments in Bernhard Gander’s “Schlechtecharakterstücke” (“Bad Character Pieces”), a savagely wry, contemporary take on the genre.

headline: The Homey Side of Louis Kahn
text: The architect Louis Kahn, who died in 1974, is known for his spare, geometric institutional work like the Salk Institute for Biological Study in the La Jolla section of San Diego and the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. The 2003 documentary ”My Architect,” directed by his son, Nathaniel Kahn, highlighted those buildings, along with Kahn’s romantic life. The architect had three children, with three different women, two of whom were professional collaborators. A new book, “The Houses of Louis Kahn” (Yale University Press, $65), provides an architectural bridge between the personal and the professional stories, focusing on the nine houses Kahn completed, and designs for two dozen more. The story told by the authors, George H. Marcus and William Whitaker, is one of warm client relations, attention to the smallest domestic detail and a philosophical search for the best arrangement of rooms to call home. Mr. Marcus, an adjunct assistant professor in the history of art at the University of Pennsylvania, spoke about it by phone late last month. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: Factory Farming, From an Animal Point of View
text: Part philosophy lecture, part animal-rights exposé, “Speciesism: The Movie” is a painfully gauche, galumphing attack on factory farming, meat eating, animal experimentation and human supremacy. So many evils, so little time.

headline: Opening Statements in Damages Phase of Patent Trial
text: SAN JOSE — Apple and Samsung Electronics this week started the second round of their big patent battle in California. The trial, which is to determine the remaining damages that Samsung will have to pay Apple for infringing on patents, so far feels like Groundhog Day.

headline: A Holiday Home to Take Home
text: The banisters of the townhouse at 19 East 75th Street are wrapped in magnolia leaf garlands, and a peek into parlor floor windows reveals a home decked out for the holidays. Except that everything in this home is for sale. It is the Holiday Works, a pop-up shop filled with new and vintage items designed or sourced by Bronson van Wyck, an event planner, and his good friend the interior designer Celerie Kemble. Some goods, like Mr. van Wyck’s salad dressings and napkin sets, are cash-and-carry. Others, like a bar cart from Ms. Kemble’s new furniture line for Henredon, must be ordered. But the indisputable stars are two glittering Christmas trees decorated by Mr. van Wyck, which can be assembled in one’s home by the so-called Van Wyck Elves (prices start at $17,500). “It is meant to be bewitching and engaging,” Ms. Kemble said of the shopping experience. Information: 212-861-6160 or theholidayworkshop.com.

headline: For D.I.Y.’ers, Designer Hardware
text: When Henry Wilson, a 28-year-old Australian designer, ordered hardware online for a sawhorse he was building, he was so disappointed with the quality that he decided to make his own.

headline: Bringing Beauty to Hand
text: The Danish designer Kay Bojesen, who was born in 1886 and died in 1958, believed that objects must be nice to hold and a pleasure to look at. Trained as a silversmith at Georg Jensen, he created a flatware pattern in 1938 that won the grand prize at the 1951 Milan Triennale, a biennial design showcase. It has been called Grand Prix ever since. Mr. Bojesen’s granddaughter, Susanne Bojesen Rosenqvist, lately reintroduced the pattern, which has been in and out of production since its inventor’s death. Ms. Rosenqvist, who said she has eaten with her grandfather’s utensils ever since she could hold a spoon, praised details like the small hump between the knife’s shaft and blade, which supports your forefinger when you cut, and the spoon’s milled edges, designed to capture drips. A five-piece place setting in stainless steel is $150 from Anise, 212-933-1406 or kaybojesen.dk.

headline: Deals on Pillows, Rugs and Sofas
text: During Kartell’s warehouse sale, through Monday, floor samples and some new pieces are up to 70 percent off (the Masters chair by Philippe Starck, originally from $269, is now from $161); 39 Greene Street (Broome Street); 212-966-6665; kartell.com.

headline: In the Belly of the Blue Whale
text: More than a year ago, Andy Romanoff, a photographer, was invited to show at a gallery in the Pacific Design Center and became fascinated by the massive Cesar Pelli-designed complex, which opened in 1975 in West Hollywood. “I think everybody in L.A. knows the Blue Whale,” Mr. Romanoff said, using the center’s nickname. “But very few people know the inside. There’s a Wolfgang Puck restaurant, a gym — it’s this secret city.”

headline: The Nanny Recipes: Skip the Microwave
text: Like other 5-year-olds, Erela Yashiv likes pizza and cupcakes and detests food that contains “green specks” of vegetables.

headline: A Dancer Tries Out Many Moves
text: If it weren’t already taken, “How to Be a Player” would probably be a better title for this movie about a 29-year-old Queens man named Julian whose womanizing ways are filmed for an instructional video. In “Sex, Love & Salsa,” Julian (Adrian Manzano) is a salsa-dancing stalker of dance floors and a crusher of hearts. He can’t settle for one woman, so he juggles a few: a naïve free spirit played by Sofia Rodriguez; an older woman (Susan Quinn) who’s also a friend and wants a baby; and a confident salsa dancer, played by the talented Gabrielle Ruiz, who initially (and wisely) resists his overtures.

headline: Brought to Your Knees by a Wood Floor
text: I finally understand how pregnant women feel when others bombard them with birthing horror stories, because I recently attempted the home-improvement equivalent of childbirth: refinishing wood floors.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Philippines, Spain, India and Afghanistan.

headline: Home Wireless Network Keeps the Snoops Away
text: LIKE most people, Kim Thomas has a broadband connection at home that she uses to check email, surf the Internet and stream music and video.

headline: Cindi Leive: Nonstop Days, a Red Carpet Night
text: On Monday, Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour magazine, was sitting in a mostly empty Carnegie Hall, discreetly sipping a smuggled-in container of coffee. She had just run through a rehearsal of her speech onstage for the magazine’s annual Women of the Year Awards due to start in a few hours, and was debating with a handful of her staff members the merits of using the word “Gaga-licious” in reference to the honoree Lady Gaga.

headline: Art Is Hard to See Through the Clutter of Dollar Signs
text: As our troubled age becomes ever more gilded, art auction prices soar with bone-numbing regularity. A new high-water mark was reached on Tuesday, when a 1969 triptych by the British painter Francis Bacon sold for $142 million while the Christie’s auction in which it was featured took in $692 million. Both figures exceeded recent highs: One arrived in spring 2012, when Edvard Munch’s “The Scream” sold for $119 million at Sotheby’s; the other came last spring, when a Christie’s auction total reached $492 million. It seems that people really, really like art these days.

headline: Scenes From the Health Care Hearing
text: Obama administration officials, including the chief technology officer of the United States, testified before Congress about the progress being made to fix the online health insurance exchange.

headline: Another Day, Another Catalog Shoot
text: Westport? So ’90s. TriBeCa? Over. Brownstone Brooklyn is ground zero for aspirational living now. Just count the ads.

headline: It’s That Brownstone. Again.
text: Margaret Reid Boyer’s photographs are arresting explorations of the evidence of family life and privilege: the domestic litter on a white marble bathroom sink; a patchwork of bright green sod in an expansive, lozenge-shaped backyard; a teenage girl with an inscrutable expression, a Parcheesi game laid out before her on an Indian print-covered table flanked by yellow Eames chairs.

headline: Bar Carts: Wheels With a Buzz
text: When a guest orders a martini at Dukes Bar in London, the 105-year-old establishment once frequented by Ian Fleming where the “shaken not stirred” line is said to have originated, a barman will prepare the drink tableside using provisions from a cart. If the guest is especially lucky, the barman will be Alessandro Palazzi, who has been the bar manager for seven years.

headline: Destruction and Dazed Survivors Found in Remote Philippine Areas
text: Updated 1:35 p.m., Nov. 14 The effects of Typhoon Haiyan’s destructive path on remote areas of the central Philippines are being pieced together as the authorities, journalists and relief workers are finally reaching hard-hit small towns and island fishing villages in eastern Samar Province.

headline: Tax Wizardry Accomplished With an Offbeat Merger
text: It used to be easier to avoid paying corporate taxes. Back in the 1990s, many corporations used tax shelters that had little economic substance other than to dodge tax liability. Aggressive enforcement actions by the Internal Revenue Service, coupled with changes in accounting and reporting requirements, have combined to make these shelters unattractive to most companies.

headline: Carlyn Cerf de Dudzeele: A Legend Who’s Unafraid to Say So
text: TRENDS? PFFT. They mean nothing to Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele. She prefers the staying power of a Chanel jacket, an Hermès Birkin bag and jeans. Like Manolo Blahnik pumps, navy turtlenecks or little black dresses by Azzedine Alaïa, “these things are never démodé,” she said in her Gallic gargle, “never, never, neverrh!”

headline: Spotless Where Others Go Topless
text: For years, Alex Lerner, the host of a Brazilian television show, has taken vacations on St. Barts, where he and his friends rented a house. Eventually, he decided he wanted to live the same way he did on vacation when he was at home.

headline: Purist Paradise
text: A fastidious Brazilian gets the house of his dreams, with ocean views and not a speck of dust in sight.

headline: Should I Place Furniture in Storage?
text: Q. Should I put some of my furniture in storage to make my apartment look bigger?

headline: Famed Austin Nightclub Is Sold
text: Antone’s, a nightclub in Austin, Tex., that played a big part in establishing that city’s reputation as one of the nation’s centers of live music, has agreed to be bought by a consortium including a National Geographic scientist and a former member of the Dave Matthews Band.

headline: ‘Anchorman’ Spoof of 1970s TV News Is Basis for Newseum Exhibition
text: WASHINGTON — “I don’t know how to put this, but I’m kind of a big deal. ... People know me. ... I’m very important. Uh, I have many leather-bound books, and my apartment smells of rich mahogany.”

headline: Shopping Events Starting Nov. 14 in New York City
text: Openings

headline: Tax Authorities in Italy Put Apple Under Investigation
text: ROME — Italian prosecutors have opened an investigation into whether Apple paid all its taxes in the country, an official in Milan said on Wednesday.

headline: Winners and Losers From Stimulus
text: As Wall Street tries to gauge when the Federal Reserve might start tapering its stimulus program, a new study from the McKinsey Global Institute illustrates just how deep the impact of such efforts has been since 2007. But it also makes clear that the benefits haven’t been distributed equally.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Snapchat Spurn, and Yahoo to Shed Sandwich.com

headline: Syrian Forces Recapture Damascus Suburb From Rebels
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government forces recaptured a suburb south of Damascus on Wednesday and continued battles to push insurgents out of long-held territory outside the northern city of Aleppo, in what appeared to be a major push to gain ground ahead of proposed internationally sponsored peace talks.

headline: Caution: Danger in the Traffic Lanes
Marianne Williamson, New-Age Guru, Seeks Congressional Seat
text: REDONDO BEACH, Calif. — Many in the audience at Marianne Williamson’s appearance here the other night thought they had come to a book signing: They arrived at the Mysterious Galaxy bookstore clutching her texts, expecting a lecture on the journey to inner peace.

headline: Judge to Review Files on Brooklyn Detective Scarcella
text: A State Supreme Court justice ordered the Brooklyn district attorney’s office on Wednesday to produce any documents regarding wrongdoing alleged by inmates, witnesses, lawyers and others against a former homicide detective who is the subject of a wide-ranging review.

text: JPMorgan Chase helped take Twitter public last week. But on Wednesday evening, the banking giant got a taste of the social network’s power — in a very negative way.

Negotiating With Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Considers ‘Neutrality Agreements’ Between Unions and Employers
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a major labor case that, depending on how it is resolved, could hamper the ability of unions to mount successful campaigns to organize workers.

headline: Crayons Down. Now Dig Into That Healthful Parfait.
text: The 22 children in a Head Start class in East Harlem shopped for plastic carrots and tomatoes at their own version of a New York City green cart, counted backward from five with a picture of blueberries, and jumped up and down to a song about bananas.

headline: Jewish Aid to the Philippines
text: To the Editor:

headline: Don’t Give More Patients Statins
text: ON Tuesday, the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology issued new cholesterol guidelines that essentially declared, in one fell swoop, that millions of healthy Americans should immediately start taking pills — namely statins — for undefined health “benefits.”

headline: Todd Christensen, Record-Setting Tight End, Dies at 57
text: Todd Christensen, a sticky-fingered, record-setting tight end for the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders who made five Pro Bowl teams and played on two Super Bowl champions, died on Wednesday in Murray, Utah, near Salt Lake City. He was 57.

headline: Raising a Sick Daughter Was Hard Enough, Then They Lost Their Jobs
text: When Megan McSween learned her second-grade class was scheduled to take a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge, she was ecstatic.

headline: Obamacare and Character
text: The president’s job approval numbers have hit new lows. That’s actually not the worst news in a new round of polling. The worst news — or what the White House should find most worrisome — is that the president’s character has taken a hit.

headline: Boehner Rules Out Negotiations on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Signaling an end to the push for major immigration legislation this year, Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday ruled out negotiations between the House and the Senate on an expansive immigration overhaul similar to one approved by the Senate with bipartisan support in June.

headline: M.T.A. Sees Smaller Fare Increases in ’15 and ’17
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Wednesday that it expected to scale back fare and toll increases planned for 2015 and 2017, potentially tempering the effects of what has become an unwelcome biennial ritual for riders.

headline: Four Marines Are Killed in Camp Pendleton Accident
text: LOS ANGELES — Four Marines were killed Wednesday in an accident during maintenance of an artillery range at a base outside San Diego, military officials said.

headline: State Dept. Calls Group in Nigeria Terrorists
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Wednesday branded Boko Haram, the homegrown Islamist insurgent movement in Nigeria that has ties to Al Qaeda’s regional affiliate in North and West Africa, as a foreign terrorist organization.

headline: Three Students Are Shot Near Pittsburgh School
text: Three students were shot near a Pittsburgh high school minutes after dismissal on Wednesday, and police officers who surrounded two nearby homes took six people into custody for questioning.

headline: Jets Consider Adding Reed at Safety
text: Coach Rex Ryan said he was pleased with the Jets’ safeties. Pleased enough to pass up a chance to add perhaps the best safety ever, Ed Reed?

headline: Car Mechanic Dreams Up a Tool to Ease Births
text: The idea came to Jorge Odón as he slept. Somehow, he said, his unconscious made the leap from a YouTube video he had just seen on extracting a lost cork from a wine bottle to the realization that the same parlor trick could save a baby stuck in the birth canal.

headline: Bring Me a Case
text: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wasn’t persuaded last week by a petition that asked the Supreme Court to review the fairness of the settlement of a lawsuit against Facebook. He joined his eight colleagues in deciding against hearing the case. No big deal there. The case, Marek v. Lane, was one of nearly 300 appeals the justices turned down upon their return from a two-week recess.

headline: New Cholesterol Advice Startles Even Some Doctors
text: Steven L. Zweibel has been taking a statin drug to lower his cholesterol for seven years. It has worked, and he has suffered no problems or side effects.

headline: Lin Is Better Off (and Better)
text: PHILADELPHIA — No one, least of all Jeremy Lin, would be so presumptuous to call it a last laugh. But it is fair to say that Lin has earned, at the expense of his former team and its impetuous owner, a well-timed chortle.

headline: Serving Life for This?
text: So you’re a judge, and Sharanda P. Jones comes before you for sentencing for conspiracy to distribute crack cocaine.

headline: Kerry and Biden Ask for Room to Reach a Nuclear Deal With Iran
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. pressed senators on Wednesday to give the Obama administration some breathing room to reach an accord with Iran to freeze its nuclear programs, warning that a new round of sanctions could mean war instead of diplomacy.

headline: California Health Exchange Beats All Others in Enrollment, Officials Say
text: In its first month of business, California’s insurance exchange enrolled more people than any other state-run exchange and more than the federal exchange serving 36 states, which has been paralyzed by technological failures.

headline: Iran and Western Powers Clash Over Why Nuclear Talks Failed
text: TEHRAN — Less than a week before the next round of nuclear talks in Geneva, it is still not clear why the last round failed, and who exactly walked away from the deal. Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, has laid the blame on the Western powers, saying they were divided. He says he has little to do now but wait for the world powers to get their act together.

headline: No Complete Games but a Cy Young Award
text: The Detroit Tigers’ Max Scherzer did something on Wednesday that no starting pitcher had ever done before. He won a Cy Young Award before registering his first career complete game.

headline: Brazil: Forensic Team Exhumes Leader’s Remains
text: A team of forensic experts on Wednesday began exhuming the remains of João Goulart, the Brazilian president ousted in a 1964 coup supported by the United States, to examine whether he was poisoned by spies while living in exile in Argentina. The authorities carried out the exhumation in São Borja, a city in southern Brazil, at the urging of Mr. Goulart’s family. They are seeking to examine a claim by a former Uruguayan intelligence operative that Mr. Goulart was assassinated by agents of Operation Condor, a joint campaign by South American military dictatorships in the 1970s and ’80s to eliminate political dissidents. Mr. Goulart had long been thought to have died from natural causes. Officials said that his remains would be flown to the capital, Brasília, to undergo testing.

headline: Imbruvica, Drug to Treat Blood Cancer, Gains F.D.A. Approval
text: A new cancer drug that has attracted considerable attention from doctors and investors won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday.

headline: Texas University’s Race Admissions Policy Is Debated Before a Federal Court
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — An affirmative-action program at the University of Texas at Austin that takes applicants’ race into account was unnecessary because the campus had achieved a “critical mass” of minority students, lawyers for the white applicant who sued the university told a federal appeals court here on Wednesday in a case with high stakes for the future of race-conscious admissions policies at public colleges and universities.

headline: Saudi Arabia Officially Rejects U.N. Security Council Seat
text: Saudi Arabia has officially rejected in writing the United Nations Security Council seat it won last month, clearing the way for a replacement country to be chosen, diplomatic officials said Wednesday.

headline: From Practice Squad to Starter
text: GREEN BAY — Until two weeks ago, Green Bay Packers quarterback Scott Tolzien dressed in the N.F.L.’s version of a bus station, the auxiliary locker room at Lambeau Field reserved for the practice squad. Occupants change weekly. Anonymity is never a problem.

headline: Council Asks Toronto Mayor to Step Down Temporarily
text: OTTAWA — Shortly after Toronto’s City Council voted Wednesday to ask Mayor Rob Ford to step down temporarily, a court released documents that painted a salacious picture of a combative, drunken mayor who assaulted staff members and entertained suspected prostitutes.

headline: Les Brown, Pioneer in Television Journalism, Dies at 84
text: Les Brown, who was one of the first journalists to cover television comprehensively from its early days, reporting on it for The New York Times, founding and editing a groundbreaking magazine about the industry and producing an authoritative TV encyclopedia, died on Nov. 4 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: HSN Joins With Univision to Reach the Hispanic Market
text: HSN, the home shopping network, is turning its sights toward Hispanic consumers with the announcement of a new e-commerce partnership with Univision Communications that will begin on Thursday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 13, 2013
Europe’s (Low) Inflation Problem
text: Just a quick chart that I think illustrates the problem of German non-reciprocity especially clearly.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Climate of Fear
text: Since the end of Sri Lanka’s civil war in 2009, the government of President Mahinda Rajapaksa has had a record of serious human rights violations and failed to provide accountability for wartime abuses.

headline: An Unwise Airline Merger
text: In August, the Justice Department’s antitrust division filed a lawsuit to block the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, which would create the world’s largest airline and concentrate 80 percent of the domestic air-travel business in the hands of four companies.

headline: A New Alliance on Climate Change
text: In an effort to compensate for the failure of central governments to address the dangers of climate change with comprehensive national policies, cities, states and regions have developed their own strategies to rein in emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. California’s ambitious plan aims to reduce emissions 80 percent by 2050 by requiring cleaner cars, more energy-efficient buildings and renewable fuels. Nine northeastern states have joined in a regional trading program aimed at reducing power-plant emissions.

headline: Resistance to Marriage Equality
text: “This is wrong.” That was Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s blunt response late last month to states defying his order in August that same-sex spouses of military personnel be given full spousal and family benefits, including health care coverage and housing allowances, on an equal, nondiscriminatory basis.

headline: At a Philippine Hospital, Survivors Face Quiet Despair
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Richard Pulga, a 27-year-old farmer with thick black hair and a gentle manner, has been lying on a hard steel bed in a dark hallway of the main hospital here since Saturday with a shattered lower right leg, abdominal pain and his right eye filling with blood.

headline: Future Unclear for Towers on East Side
text: The day after the Bloomberg administration withdrew its plan for a swath of glass towers in Midtown because of an absence of support in the City Council, a developer, David W. Levinson, was fielding phone calls at his office near Carnegie Hall.

headline: Does My Virginity Have a Shelf Life?
text: When I was 20, one of my close friends was killed in a car crash. At the funeral, as I watched her coffin carried down the aisle, another friend leaned over to whisper: “At least she wasn’t a virgin.”

headline: Twisting and Turbulent Case for Formula One Chief
text: LONDON — As 11 Formula One teams prepared recently to head for Austin, Tex., where the penultimate round of this year’s 19-race championship will take place Sunday, it was not the domination of the German driver Sebastian Vettel, winner of 11 of this year’s races and a strong favorite in Austin, that spurred the most fevered talk among grand prix racing insiders.

headline: The Art of Senate Stoppage
text: When we’re choosing a leader for the nation’s central banking system, one of the important things to consider is whether Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has heard enough testimony about the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Federal Panel Softens Tone on Judge It Removed From Stop-and-Frisk Case
text: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan that had abruptly removed Judge Shira A. Scheindlin from New York City’s high-profile stop-and-frisk litigation and questioned her conduct in the case issued a lengthy explanation on Wednesday, saying it had made “no findings of misconduct, actual bias or actual partiality” by the judge.

headline: Bernanke the Teacher, Talking to Teachers
text: Janet Yellen will take the stage Thursday morning in what is effectively her debut as the Federal Reserve’s new leader. But the job still belongs to Ben S. Bernanke, who on Wednesday night held a low-key question-and-answer session with teachers.

headline: Philippines’ President Faces Growing Anger
text: MANILA — Five days after a devastating typhoon swept through the midsection of this impoverished island nation, Filipinos are losing patience with the slow relief effort, increasingly angry with their president, Benigno S. Aquino III, a popular figure who has until now navigated multiple crises during his three years in office.

headline: Rejecting Billions, Snapchat Expects a Better Offer
text: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media service run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif.

headline: Giants, With a History of Losing to Backups, Are Wary of Tolzien
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants on Sunday will face quarterback Scott Tolzien, who threw his first N.F.L. pass just a few days ago. If this bodes well for the Giants, they are not buying it.

headline: Yes, You’ve Heard the Joke Before, but That’s Exactly the Point
text: Songs can get stuck in your head, but what about jokes?

headline: Should Politicians' Spouses Shape Policy?
text: Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, have always worked as a team. But are there pitfalls for voters and officials when a spouse is a formal adviser?

headline: Echo Chamber
text: Tom McCoy, a college freshman, makes his debut today with a crossword full of clever INTERPLAY between the clues. Certain items have an echo, like the duplicate entries about 007 (the ALIAS for British spy extraordinaire James BOND), and the repetition of “knight,” with clues about a knight’s title (SIR) and activity (QUESTING.)

headline: JPMorgan’s Fruitful Ties to a Member of China’s Elite
text: To promote its standing in China, JPMorgan Chase turned to a seemingly obscure consulting firm run by a 32-year-old executive named Lily Chang.

headline: From the Shadows, a Rebel Group Vexes Paraguay
text: The Paraguayan People’s Army is evolving from a ghostlike irritant for the authorities into a broader security threat.

headline: Guerrillas Step Up Campaign in Paraguay
text: TACUATÍ, Paraguay — The guerrillas appeared at dusk.

headline: Lawyer Concedes Mistakes in Chevron Case
text: For the last month, Chevron has presented a parade of witnesses against Steven R. Donziger, the freelance lawyer who has been suing the company for 20 years over pollution of the Ecuadorean Amazon jungle. One after another, the witnesses, including some of his closest allies and financiers who are now estranged from his cause, have testified that Mr. Donziger committed witness tampering and fraud.

headline: Nash Skates, but Return to Rangers Is Not Set
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Rick Nash, symptom-free, looked great in practice Wednesday, his first with his Rangers teammates since sustaining a concussion in a game at San Jose on Oct. 8.

text: The bank’s primary ties to the family of former Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China and its colleagues.

text: Teenagers and college students can spend only so much time cooped up with their families on a holiday like Thanksgiving.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 14, 2013
text: “I don’t have any money, I’ve lost everything, even my house is gone. That’s what is on my mind.”

headline: Corrections: November 14, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: India: Official Criticized for a Reference to Rape
text: One of India’s top law enforcement officials drew criticism on Wednesday for making an offhand reference to rape during a public debate on gambling, remarking that arguing to legalize betting is “like saying if you can’t prevent rape, enjoy it.” In a country newly sensitized to sexual violence, the remarks by Ranjit Sinha, director of the Central Bureau of Investigation, immediately echoed on Twitter and were covered by television news channels. Some activists called on Mr. Sinha, who heads a bureau supervising corruption and other grave crimes, including rape and murder, to step down. Mr. Sinha swiftly released a statement of apology: “I regret any hurt caused, as the same was inadvertent and unintended,” it read, explaining that he was condemning such reasoning, and adding, “I reiterate my deep sense of respect for women and commitment to gender issues.”

headline: After Strong Growth in First Half of 2013, the Japanese Economy Hits a Snag
text: TOKYO — After a surprising spurt of strong growth in the first half of the year, the Japanese economy seems to be running out of steam as exports and consumer spending show signs of weakening.

headline: IBM to Announce More Powerful Watson via the Internet
text: LAS VEGAS — Welcome to the age of supercomputing for everyone.

headline: Concession in Airline Merger Is Criticized
text: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department announced in August that it had filed suit to block the proposed merger of US Airways and American Airlines, it maintained that airline consolidation had gone too far and the proposed merger would lead to higher fares for consumers.

headline: Up in the Air
text: Developer SL Green Realty had hoped to build a massive structure across from Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Secret Service Officer Is Demoted From Presidential Detail
text: WASHINGTON — A Secret Service supervisor has been removed from President Obama’s security detail and demoted after being accused of leaving a bullet in a woman’s room at a luxury hotel near the White House this year, senior federal law enforcement officials said Wednesday.

headline: Redfin Raises $50 Million in Latest Financing Round
text: While the online home information space may be crowded, investors seem to believe that Redfin has a good chance of standing out.

headline: Grisly Warhol Painting Fetches $104.5 Million, Auction High for Artist
text: One of Andy Warhol’s more powerful and provocative images — a lifeless body amid the gruesome wreckage of a car crash — sold for $104.5 million at Sotheby’s contemporary art auction on Wednesday night, making it the highest price ever paid at auction for the Pop artist.

headline: Boras Has a Few Zingers, and a Few Free-Agent Stars, for the Mets
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Scott Boras entered the hotel lobby here Wednesday afternoon like a rock star, mobbed by reporters. He was about to give what has become his annual unofficial address at the general managers meetings, discussing his clients and baseball in general. One of the first questions posed to him was about the Mets.

headline: Shaking Up Strategy, Knicks Shake Off Woes and Hawks
text: ATLANTA — The Knicks arrived here accompanied by their usual turbulence. Starting guard Iman Shumpert, perhaps the player with the most upside on the roster, was mentioned in trade rumors. The team’s owner, James L. Dolan, guaranteed a win onstage with his blues band, and the team’s toughness on defense was questioned without the injured Tyson Chandler. Coach Mike Woodson was receiving blame for the team’s uneven start.

headline: Thursday’s Matchup: Colts (6-3) at Titans (4-5)
text: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

headline: Fair-Housing Case Is Settled Before It Reaches Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — A housing discrimination case scheduled to be heard by the Supreme Court next month has been settled, the parties announced Wednesday night. Civil rights groups, wary of a Supreme Court ruling that they feared could weaken protections for victims of housing discrimination, welcomed the development.

headline: N.F.L. Week 11 Game Probabilities: Can Chiefs Finish Undefeated?
text: One of the interesting things to do with game probabilities is estimate the likelihood that a team will finish undefeated. Coming off their bye week, the undefeated Kansas City Chiefs have seven games remaining. Winning all of those games is extremely unlikely, especially considering they have yet to face the formidable Denver Broncos.

headline: Tailored for Travel
text: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets — perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.

headline: A Pioneering Collaborator of Le Corbusier Finally Gets Her Due
text: As an homage to Charlotte Perriand’s creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernist’s never-realized designs.

headline: Sizing Up the Fiscal Future
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

text: Question:
