text: vicissitude •\və-ˈsi-sə-ˌtüd, vi-, -ˌtyüd\• noun

headline: Nets, Continuing Skid in Sacramento, Offer No Excuses
text: SACRAMENTO — For weeks, the Nets seemed willing to tie their poor play to their newness as a group. The process of adjusting to a new system, to new teammates, justified their string of surprising losses, and few could challenge them on that point.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS (2010) Michael Douglas, below, returns as the reptilian Gordon Gekko who, after eight years in prison, has landed in the spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf portrays the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekko’s fans and the live-in love of Gekko’s daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume. “To the question ‘What went wrong?’ the film offers an answer that is both irrefutable and unsatisfying: human nature,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And yet, he added, something vital here works. The director, Oliver Stone, “is not the man to explain Wall Street, or to stoke public indignation at its crimes,” he said. “But no one else could turn it into a show like ‘Wall Street.’ ”

headline: Boeing Workers Reject Labor Deal in Washington State
text: Members of a union representing thousands of Boeing employees voted late Wednesday to reject a controversial labor deal that would have cut compensation but have kept assembly of the company’s new 777X jets in Washington State, raising the chance that Boeing will move more production away from its traditional manufacturing base in the Seattle area.

headline: News Quiz | November 14, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: China Moving to End Some Cosmetics Testing on Animals
text: “YES!” wrote Hou Xiaomu, an animal lover, on Weibo, about the news that China’s food and drug authorities are moving toward ending the testing of cosmetics on animals. About 300,000 animals — rabbits, mice and others —  may be used each year in testing cosmetics here, Humane Society International estimates.

headline: Northern Chinese Brace for Smog Spike as Winter Heating Kicks In
text: Harbin — a metropolis in China’s northeastern reaches — made international headlines last month when it experienced air pollution so abysmal that the government closed all schools and officials urged the city’s 11 million residents to stay indoors as visibility dropped to just 10 meters, roughly the width of a typical traffic intersection.

headline: Japan Honors Chinese Student for Heroism
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan has honored a Chinese student for his “courageous act” in rescuing a Japanese boy from drowning, a bright spot in an otherwise tense period in diplomatic relations.

headline: Chinese Rights Campaigner Held Hunger Strike, Lawyer Says
text: HONG KONG — A prominent human rights campaigner in southern China won his first meeting with a lawyer on Thursday after more than three months in detention and said he had been on a hunger strike, one of his lawyers said.

headline: Overshadowed by Tacloban, Other Devastated Philippine Cities Fear Aid Will Not Come
text: HONG KONG — While relief efforts for Typhoon Haiyan have been focused on the Philippine city of Tacloban, aid groups say other cities in Leyte Province have also suffered vast devastation, with residents facing increasing dangers with the passage of time.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Political Editor of Open Magazine Hartosh Singh Bal
text: Hartosh Singh Bal, the political editor of Open magazine, announced on Wednesday that he had received a letter of termination. It was the second high-profile sacking within the Indian media in the space of a month; in late October, Siddharth Varadarajan resigned as editor-in-chief of The Hindu, an influential daily newspaper, when the paper’s owners told him he would be replaced.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 14, 2013
text: Use context clues to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | 1 World Trade Center Is Named the Tallest Building in the U.S.
text: In “By a Spire, Manhattan Regains a Title From Chicago,” Patrick McGeehan and Charles V. Bagli write about the new tallest building in the United States.

headline: Euro Zone Economy Stalls as Germany and France Backtrack
text: PARIS — The euro zone economy marked time in the third quarter of the year, growing just 0.1 percent from the second quarter, a report on Thursday showed, disappointing hopes that a full-fledged recovery was finally taking hold after five years of recession and stagnation.

headline: A Civil Rights Photographer, and a Struggle, Are Remembered
text: Jon Lewis shot thousands of archetypical civil rights photographs in the late 1960s: a picket line snaking along the horizon, children playing in squalor, activists huddled in a strategy session. What makes these photographs different is their location and the subjects. Taken in central California and not in the Jim Crow South, they depict farm laborers of Mexican and Filipino descent, the vanguard of the historic Delano grape strike.

headline: When the Doctor Disappears
text: Dr. Daniel Geynisman felt as if he had abandoned his patient, a sickening sensation.

headline: God Called Them to Adopt. And Adopt. And Adopt.
text: Misty and her husband, Jon, arrived at a house near Denver one day several years ago to pick up the two boys who would become their sons. A dirt yard led to a screen door dangling from its hinges. Inside, grime coated the linoleum steps to the living room, where a kind, if overwhelmed, single foster mother introduced Misty and Jon to Shon, 2 ½ years old, and his 9-month-old brother, Cory. She gave the couple a tiny suitcase with a broken zipper, a few borrowed clothes — some too big, others too small — and a piece of advice: Don’t touch Shon’s head or lift your hands near him. He will cower. Then she handed Jon a huge bag of frozen fish sticks. The kids love them, she said.

headline: How Important Are Parent-Teacher Conferences?
text: A recent Room for Debate feature presented a variety of views on the value of parent-teacher conferences.

headline: New York Today: Cabs of a Different Color
text: Updated 2:50 p.m. | A strange species of transport is appearing around the city: taxi cabs painted a sickly sour-apple green.

headline: Iceland Is Building a National Team to Watch
text: LONDON — With all due respect to Cristiano Ronaldo and Zlatan Ibrahimovic, whose egos go head to head for Portugal against Sweden on Friday, the good folks of Iceland will not even glance at the score coming from Lisbon.

headline: China Increases Aid to Philippines
text: BEIJING — China has announced that it is increasing its humanitarian assistance to typhoon victims in the Philippines, after international groups and a Chinese newspaper criticized an initial government donation of $100,000 as too meager.

headline: French Muscle, American Cheese
text: PARIS — French-American relations, often a study in how close love can be to hatred, have taken an interesting turn of late. The cheese-eating surrender monkeys of France, in the phrase from “The Simpsons,” have become the world’s meat-chomping enforcement tigers. As for the United States, it has, in the French view, gone a touch camembert-soft.

headline: Ravaged by Typhoon, Philippines Faces Threat of Serious Diseases
text: The aftermath of the Philippines typhoon is now threatening the country with outbreaks of debilitating and potentially fatal diseases, including some thought to have been nearly eradicated, because of a collapse in sanitation, shortages of fresh water and the inability of emergency health teams to respond quickly in the week since the storm struck, doctors and medical officials said Thursday.

headline: Slowdown in Japan Raises the Pressure on Abe
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is now under more pressure to deliver on his much-promoted effort to improve the country’s long-term growth prospects, after a government estimate on Thursday showed that the economy had slowed in the quarter that ended in September.

headline: What the Proposed Crowdfunding Rules Could Cost Businesses
text: A small business that elects to raise money from the masses should prepare for a lifetime of disclosure and fees. According to the recently proposed rules from the Securities and Exchange Commission, a crowdfunded company will have to file annual reports until either all of its crowdfunded securities have been bought out, it goes public or it is dissolved.

headline: India Pays Homage as Its Greatest Cricketer Nears Retirement
text: Long before Sachin Tendulkar arrived at the Eden Gardens cricket ground in Kolkata for the penultimate cricket match of his career, a wax statue of the greatest Indian cricketer was placed outside the Indian dressing room. The statue reproduced an image embedded in the psyche of every Indian cricket fan. It was the gesture the 40-year-old Mr. Tendulkar adopted whenever he reached a scoring landmark: cricket bat raised in one hand, helmet in the other.

headline: What to Watch For at the Yellen Hearing
text: Janet L. Yellen is widely expected to win confirmation as the Federal Reserve’s first chairwoman. Her appearance before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday morning is mostly a chance for senators to probe what kind of leader she will be.

headline: Daily Report: Snapchat Waits for a Better Offer Than Facebook’s
text: What business makes no money, has yet to pass its third anniversary and just turned down an offer worth billions of dollars? Snapchat, a social media platform run by a pair of 20-somethings who until last month worked out of a beachfront bungalow in Venice, Calif., Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: The Jon Stewart of Egypt Is Gagged
text: CAIRO — When the Egyptian comedian Bassem Youssef came back on the air late last month, everyone wondered whether he would have the courage to mock the army and its leader, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, as he once did the Islamists and former President Mohamed Morsi — and whether he’d get away with it.

headline: Hezbollah Chief Says His Forces Will Stay in Syria
text: LONDON — The head of Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militant group whose armed followers are fighting in Syria on the side of President Bashar al-Assad, pledged on Thursday that his forces would remain there as long as necessary.

headline: Former German President Goes on Trial
text: BERLIN — For the first time in modern German history, a former president, Christian Wulff, went on trial on Thursday in a state court in Hanover, charged with illegally accepting favors while he was governor of the state of Lower Saxony.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Member of China’s Elite Tied to JPMorgan
text: JPMORGAN’S TIES TO A MEMBER OF CHINA’S ELITE  |

headline: Amy Errett of Madison Reed, on Finding Your Genius
text: This interview with Amy Errett, chief executive and co-founder of Madison Reed, a provider of in-home hair color, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Food and Fuel Prices Push Indian Inflation Higher
text: MUMBAI, India — India’s benchmark inflation rate increased to 7 percent in October, the highest in eight months, driven primarily by higher fuel and food prices, according to government data released on Thursday.

headline: European Banking Unity Is No Easy Target
text: FRANKFURT — Low interest rates have a dark side, the German central bank warned on Thursday, sounding a gloomy note as European finance ministers gathered in Brussels to discuss the politically tricky question of how to share responsibility for fixing sick banks.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: ‘The Rise and Fall of Paramount Records, Volume One (1917-1927)’
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Hungry and Panhandling
text: Dear Diary:

headline: The Holidays: A Bit More Giving, a Bit Less Getting
text: Some people react to my obsession with parenting, money and values by assuming that it has little to do with them. Take my friends in a low-key Midwestern state, who are both public-sector employees. Wasn’t this topic, they wondered, something that only affluent suburban parents or private-school people needed to worry about?

headline: Storied French Piano Manufacturer to Close
text: PARIS — Ending an era on a mournful chord, Pleyel, the storied French piano manufacturer whose pianos were once favored by Frédéric Chopin and Maurice Ravel, has announced that it will close its workshop after two centuries of production.

headline: Air France-KLM Signals Wavering Faith in Alitalia
text: PARIS — Air France-KLM, the French-Dutch airline, said Thursday that it would not take part in a plan to inject 300 million euros into Alitalia, arguing that the faltering Italian flag carrier was not prepared to take sufficient steps to reduce its mounting debt.

headline: Homeless Kids in Rough Schools
text: Working-aged adults who lost their jobs, homes and savings to the recession will have a difficult enough time establishing normal lives when the economy rights itself. The trauma will be especially deep and long lasting for the burgeoning population of children who were driven into homelessness — or even given up by their parents — when the world turned upside down in the Great Recession of 2008.

headline: Yellen’s Confirmation Hearing
text: Janet L. Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, testified Thursday before the Senate Banking Committee at a hearing on her nomination to succeed Ben S. Bernanke as Fed chief. In her opening statement, released by the Fed on Wednesday, Ms. Yellen made the case for the Fed’s current stimulus program, declaring, “I believe that supporting the recovery today is the surest path to returning to a more normal approach to monetary policy.” A running account of the hearing follows.

headline: Knee or Hip Replacement Cuts Heart Risks
text: For people with severe arthritis, knee or hip replacement may have an added benefit: a reduction in the risk for cardiovascular disease.

headline: Census Shows Shift in New York’s Population Dynamic After Recession
text: The recession, which officially ended in 2009, affected New York City’s population dynamic in two ways. People who might have left the city didn’t, in part because they couldn’t sell their homes or weren’t lured to jobs elsewhere. Also, the influx of foreigners from abroad slowed.

headline: Can We Outgrow Growth (as the Metric That Matters)?
text: I’m running a discussion this morning at the United Nations focusing on a core issue on this blog: “Do We Have to Outgrow Growth?”

headline: Groups Mobilize to Aid Democrats in ’14 Data Arms Race
text: Liberal and Democratic-leaning groups, facing difficult midterm elections next year without the technological muscle of the Obama campaign behind them, are preparing a major effort to improve their data infrastructure.

headline: Ireland Is to Exit Its Bailout, and Without a Safety Net
text: LONDON — Ireland announced on Thursday that it would make a clean break from its international bailout program next month and do it without first seeking a precautionary credit line.

headline: Starboard Joins Fight Over Fate of Compuware
text: Compuware has already spent the better part of the year fending off one activist shareholder. Now, it faces another.

headline: With Bulls, It’s No Walk in the Park
text: Images from the Great Bull Run in Conyers, Ga., which included an event called the Tomato Royale.

headline: Running of the Bulls Comes to America
text: Thousands risked themselves during the Great Bull Run, an Americanized version of Spain’s running of the bulls.

headline: Crime Boss Bulger Gets 2 Life Terms and Is Assailed by Judge for His ‘Depravity’
text: BOSTON — James (Whitey) Bulger, Boston’s most notorious gangster, was condemned on Thursday to spend the rest of his life in prison, receiving two life sentences plus five years.

headline: For Thrill Seekers, a Bull Run With a Different Hook
text: CONYERS, Ga. — The 600 runners were limbering up for what they had been assured would be “the most awesome adventure” of their lives. And what might that be? They were paying for the opportunity to be chased around a dusty, quarter-mile track by an angry herd of stampeding bulls.

headline: Obama Moves to Avert Cancellation of Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, trying to quell a growing furor over the rollout of his health care law, bowed to bipartisan pressure on Thursday and announced a policy reversal that would allow insurance companies to temporarily keep people on health plans that were to be canceled under the new law because they did not meet minimum standards.

headline: Players, Here’s the Drill
text: Less than an hour before he was due to roar onto the stage on a motorcycle in “Romeo and Juliet,” Orlando Bloom strode along the gilded balcony of the Richard Rodgers Theater, contorting his mouth and making peculiar noises. “Imagine managing an imaginary menagerie,” he said so fast that the words blurred together, then repeated the tongue twister, more complex this time. He fluttered his lips like a horse, exhaling.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Forever – Is Composed of Nows –’
text: This Poetry Pairing pays tribute to Emily Dickinson (1830-86) and the scholars and archivists whose efforts ensure the poems, letters and other materials she left behind are preserved and accessible. We pair her poem “Forever – Is Composed of Nows –” with the article “Enigmatic Dickinson Revealed Online” by Jennifer Schuessler.

headline: In Our Pages: November 15
text: 1938: Rich Jews Told to Pay Fines

headline: What Makes a Great Shakespearean?
text: Tastes in acting, as in everything else, certainly vary, but a great Shakespearean performance is easy to spot. You know one when you see one, although it’s probably more accurate to say that you know one when you don’t see one: when the language no longer feels remote, when the humanity of the actor and the character seem indivisible, when the emotion being expressed is no longer veiled by poetic phrasing but revealed by it, creating a shock of recognition in your own heart.

headline: Some Help on the Nonrefundable Front
text: Nonrefundable hotel rates — they’re often the downfall of the thrifty traveler. While cheaper rates can be alluring, there is almost nothing more maddening than paying for a room you are not sleeping in owing to circumstances beyond your control.

headline: Amy Tan: By the Book
text: The author of “The Valley of Amazement” and “The Joy Luck Club” fantasizes about catching up on reading in prison: “No email, no useless warranties, . . . no invitations to fund-­raisers.”

headline: Robert Plant Produces a Documentary Series About Malian Music
text: When the singer Robert Plant visited Mali to perform at the Festival in the Desert, in 2003, he brought a video camera and documented Malian life, both in towns and in the desert, as well as the festival itself. Mostly, Mr. Plant was the cameraman; on occasion, Logan, his son, took over. Also with Mr. Plant on the trip, and seen in the footage, were Justin Adams and Skin Tyson, who both played bass and guitars in Mr. Plant’s band at the time, the Strange Sensation. (With Mr. Plant, formerly of Band of Joy, Led Zeppelin, the Honeydrippers and others – including, most recently, a new version of Band of Joy – you really can’t tell the players without a scorecard.)

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
text: Take the scenic route in timeless, relaxed silhouettes smartened up with sporty belts and tailored jackets — perfect for a grand tour or a weekend jaunt.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Matchup Breakdown
text: Remember when there was no safer play in fantasy football than Tom Brady?

headline: MARKET REPORT
text: Warm and fuzzy winter pieces range from the bold to the understated, all with extra fluff this season.

headline: Image of the Day: November 14
text: Children’s Day celebrated in India.

headline: A Sign of Desperation in Facebook’s Snapchat Offer
text: Facebook’s Snapchat bid shows triple the desperation. The social network paid $1 billion for no-revenue Instagram a little over a year ago. Now, it’s said to be dangling as much as $3 billion to lure a mobile app that sends self-destructing digital images. Facebook’s apparently escalating need to buy off marauders at its moat suggests its defenses may be scalable.

headline: Siding With Google, Judge Says Book Search Does Not Infringe Copyright
text: Google’s idea to scan millions of books and make them searchable online seemed audacious when it was announced in 2004. But fast-forward to today, when people expect to find almost anything they want online, and the plan seems like an unsurprising and unavoidable part of today’s Internet.

headline: Furniture by Lockwood de Forest and His Peers
text: The plutocrats of 19th-century New York relied on a handful of furniture makers who all knew one another. The connections among patrons and artisans have become more traceable in recent months, since rooms full of original commissions — with Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Moorish and Egyptian motifs — are being reassembled around the country. “It’s the most incredibly interlocking society,” Sarah D. Coffin, the lead decorative arts curator at the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, said in an interview. She was leafing through images of works by Lockwood de Forest and his cousin-in-law and business partner Louis Comfort Tiffany, made for the museum building’s first owner, Andrew Carnegie.

headline: JFK
text: TKTK

headline: On Philippines Relief, Comparing the U.S. and China
text: American marines landed in the Philippines this week, the vanguard of an operation to help thousands of desperate victims of the worst typhoon in recent decades. The United States is also sending an aircraft carrier, other ships, 5,000 sailors and $20 million, just to start. Meanwhile, China, the world’s second largest economy and the rising power that so many countries in Asia fear, initially donated a paltry $100,000 to the rescue effort. According to Xinhua, it then bumped the number to $1.4 million, still pretty meager.

headline: Reed, Not Ready for End, Joins Jets and Reunites With Ryan
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Ed Reed, a nine-time Pro Bowl safety, did not have the right uniform number, the right shoes at practice, or the right look for his first on-camera interviews as a member of the Jets.

headline: Acrostic
text: Acrostic puzzle for November 17, 2013

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Player Tiers
text: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Travel Guide: Chicago for Kids
text: Much of Chicago is surprisingly easy to visit with children, maybe even too easy. There is an array of kid-friendly museums, shops, shows, trolleys and tours, centrally located and positioned so close that they require little transportation or street smarts. And you will get few dirty looks when someone spills something or throws a tantrum. Chicago is used to that.

headline: Wheelies: The Electro-Wagen Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from around the web:

headline: Acrostic Answer
text: Acrostic answer for November 17, 2013

headline: BY THE NUMBERS
text: The interior designer Timothy Corrigan has spent years overseeing the restoration of a 40,000-square-foot estate in the Loire Valley. Here’s how he keeps tradition alive.

headline: Your Tips for Tackling Chicago With Kids
text: In Part 3 of our continuing series on traveling in big cities with children, we took a jaunt to Chicago to explore the city’s must-see attractions for little ones.

headline: Backing Off  ‘Wanting It All’  From a Spouse
text: In last week’s Unhitched, Ed and Arlene Petty discussed some of the issues that led to their divorce after 28 years of marriage, including her feelings of discontent after their last child left for college (“When Nest Emptied, Discontent Entered”). As a follow-up, we asked a couples therapist about the role of expectations in a marriage. Did you face a similar issue in your divorce? Or were you faced with other challenges? If so, we’d like to hear from you for this series.

headline: The Great Writ, North and South
text: During the Civil War both the federal and Confederate governments had to deal with a pressing question far from the battlefield: how to balance the rights enshrined in their respective constitutions against effectively fighting the war.

headline: For Filipino Workers Abroad, ‘There Is Nothing Worse Than the Waiting’
text: The first thing I read about the typhoon was actually on Facebook. Posted on one of my friend’s status updates was something about the wind getting stronger in our part of the Philippines. After that, all of my friends began to panic.

headline: Speculation, Spoilers and Sequels: Making Inferences to Predict What Happens Next
text: Overview | How do great authors build suspense and keep us engaged? What skills do readers need to make predictions? In this lesson, students will discuss how they “read” their favorite television shows in order to make predictions about what will happen, then apply these skills to speculate about what happens to literary characters after their favorite novels or plays end. Finally, they will use the inferences they gain through close reading to create imagined futures for these characters in comic strips, next chapters, letters, journals or videos.

headline: Today in Small Business: Corporate Welfare Queens
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Amazon Web Services Gets Personal and Pretty
text: LAS VEGAS — Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing part of Amazon’s sprawling online empire, is known for its globe-spanning system of millions of computer servers, data storage systems and complex software, estimated to be five times larger than 14 other cloud computing providers combined.

headline: Acrostic
text: Acrostic puzzle for November 17, 2013

headline: Poems Against Loss: Joan Naviyuk Kane Talks About ‘Hyperboreal’
text: The poems of Joan Naviyuk Kane are lyrical blasts from a far northern landscape of history and myth. From the first lines of her second book, “Hyperboreal,” just published by the University of Pittsburgh Press, Ms. Kane transports us: “Arnica nods heavy-headed on the bruised slope./Peaks recede in all directions, in heat-haze,/Evening in my recollection.” The poet Arthur Sze, who picked the book for the 2012 Donald Hall Prize in Poetry, calls her poems “vivid, disturbing and mysterious.” Ms. Kane, 36, is Inuit/Inupiaq and lives a few miles from where she grew up in Anchorage. Her family originally came from King Island and Mary’s Igloo, Alaska. Recruited by Harvard, she attended the university as an undergraduate, and then earned an M.F.A. from Columbia. Below are excerpts from an email interview.

headline: In Yellen Hearing, Senators Push for Fed Changes
text: WASHINGTON — The questions that Janet L. Yellen faced on Thursday from senators considering her nomination to lead the Federal Reserve made two things fairly clear: The job is hers, and it’s not going to be easy.

headline: Woman, Guilty of Stalking Alec Baldwin, Gets 6-Month Term
text: After a week of courtroom drama, featuring a star turn from Alec Baldwin and tearful histrionics from a woman accused of stalking him, it was a judge who had the last and defining word on Thursday: guilty on all charges.

headline: They Call Me ‘Dr. Kevorkian’
text: The patient had a severe pneumonia of advanced AIDS. He’d been lying in our intensive care unit for three weeks, a breathing tube thrust into his raw airway, his face a mixture of pain and resignation. His weakened lung tissue had popped in several areas, requiring chest tubes to drain the pockets of pressurized air. He looked like a sea creature with multiple tentacles.

headline: Yellen’s Opening Remarks
text: Janet L. Yellen, at her confirmation hearing before Congress to become the Federal Reserve’s first chairwoman, defended the Fed’s steps to spur economic growth.

headline: Skal
text: Inside the Nordic restaurant where the cooking tilts toward Noma.

headline: Following Nordic Tracks
text: At Skal, three little smelt lie in a chipped bowl, crispy tails flipped upward. You expect crunch and maybe a whiff of the sea, nothing more. But what you get is subtler and stranger: a texture like sopped bread and a burst of brine, both from within (the smelt are stuffed with capers) and without (a splash of apple cider vinegar after the smelt are dusted with rye flour and fried).

headline: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Running a Fabulous French Chateau
text: Timothy Corrigan works hard when he’s home in Los Angeles, but no less so when he’s on vacation at his chateau in France’s Loire Valley. For the past four years, the interior designer has overseen a meticulous restoration of the 40,000-square-foot country house he purchased there in 2004 for an undisclosed amount, driven by his passion for what the French call l’art de vivre. Most people who could live this way today opt for convenience instead. But recently, “Downton Abbey” has ignited a fascination with how estates like this one, which was built between 1760 and 1764 and has hosted everyone from Voltaire to Lee Radziwill, operate in the modern world. (It’s the subject of Corrigan’s new book, “An Invitation to Chateau du Grand-Lucé: Decorating a Great French Country House,” $65.) Here’s a look at how Corrigan keeps tradition alive, and at what cost.

headline: In Iraq, a Day of Religious Observance, and of Blood
text: BAGHDAD — A wave of attacks against Shiite Muslims in Iraq killed at least 47 people and wounded dozens on Thursday, security officials said, as they were marking the holy day of Ashura, which commemorates the killing of Imam Hussein, a grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, 1,300 years ago.

headline: Wolf to Dog: Scientists Agree on How, but Not Where
text: Where did dogs come from? That simple question is the subject of a scientific debate right now. In May, a team of scientists published a study pointing to East Asia as the place where dogs evolved from wolves. Now, another group of researchers has announced that dogs evolved several thousand miles to the west, in Europe.

headline: New Interactive Tool Helps Track Earth’s Forests
text: As carbon emissions build and environmentalists grow more certain of the consequences, scientists have been searching for more precise ways to track the state of Earth’s vast expanses of forest.

headline: Google Employees Speak Out About Government Spying
text: Google’s canned responses to reports of government spying have ranged from “concerned” to “outraged.” But some of its employees have been more outspoken.

headline: A Touch of the Toxic, for Good or Ill
text: Vampire bat saliva and a zebra longwing butterfly, devil’s gardens and fossilized fish teeth, golden-frog secretions and the sap of a manchineel tree: Pity the poor witches of Shakespeare’s “Macbeth” who had to settle for “tooth of wolf” and “tongue of dog.” Their boiling caldron makes an appearance in an exhibition opening Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History — “The Power of Poison“ — and so do they, black robed and stirring the pot as green smoke rises. But they don’t possess even a fraction of the esoteric ingredients the museum has assembled for this elaborate show, nor do they have the museum’s powers to brew something so alluring out of such potentially grim material.

headline: Hotels, a Place to Lay Your Head, or Bury It in a Book
text: Traditional brick-and-mortar bookstores have proved vulnerable to e-books and the web, but many new hotels aim to distinguish themselves with old-fashioned pages that guests can actually turn, housing libraries that range from historic collections to trendy ones.

headline: Dylan Joins France’s Legion of Honor
text: Bob Dylan added a new ribbon and pendant to his bucket of medals on Wednesday, when he was awarded the Legion of Honor, France’s highest prize, in a ceremony in Paris. The award was presented by the French minister of culture, Aurélie Filippetti, who praised him as an inspiration for young listeners who crave justice and independence, the BBC reported.

headline: Fairy Tale Ending in the Horror Realm
text: In the 1980s, when the home-video revolution turned backyard directors into VHS auteurs, Chester Novell Turner lived his childhood dream of making horror movies. He bought a video camera, borrowed money from his mother and enlisted the help of buddies, a girlfriend and a preacher to make two ultra-low-budget movies that looked as if they were shot in a basement, because, in some cases, they were. “Black Devil Doll From Hell” was about a kindly woman who is raped by a ventriloquist’s dummy; “Tales From the Quadead Zone” was a trilogy of shorts that featured a killer clown and the ghost of a dead child. As word slowly spread about Mr. Turner’s gritty movies with African-American casts — a rarity in the very white horror world — bootleg copies of his films spread like crazy along the VHS underground.

headline: Obama Calls for Patience in Iran Talks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama made a vigorous appeal to Congress on Thursday to give breathing space to his efforts to forge a nuclear deal with Iran, and the prospects for an interim agreement may have improved with the release of a report by international inspectors who said that for the first time in years, they saw evidence that the Iranians have put the brakes on their nuclear expansion.

headline: A Traumatized City Begins to Bury Its Dead
text: A group of firefighters lowered unidentified bodies into a mass grave outside Tacloban on Thursday, six days after the city was heavily damaged by Typhoon Haiyan.

headline: Jeter Prepares to Turn a Page and Publish Many Others
text: Derek Jeter, nearing the final act of a storied athletic career, is ready to talk about his life after baseball. He wants to be a book publisher.

headline: A Feast for the Senses at the R Lounge in Times Square
text: IT was hard to decide just which was the most memorable sight to be seen from the R Lounge, the second-level bar at the Renaissance Hotel that provides a “wow” of a panorama of Times Square.

headline: The Gun Report: November 14, 2013
text: There is no official set of criteria or definition for a mass shooting, but the F.B.I. considers mass murder to be a spasm of violence perpetrated by one person that takes at least four lives in the same location. By that metric, we’ve already had several just this month. And if the wounded are counted, the tally grows even higher.

headline: Obama’s Health Care Promise
text: There are important questions about whether the fix President Obama offered today for Americans whose insurance policies were cancelled will help them, whether it will hinder the broad goals of the health insurance reform law, and whether it will satisfy the opponents of reform.  We will start to address them later on the editorial page.

headline: Getting Up to Speed With an Apple TV, and Ditching Android Widgets
text: Q. How fast does my Internet connection have to be to stream movies on an Apple TV?

headline: Outsourcing Chores: The Economic Impact
text: My It’s the Economy column last Sunday explained how you too can live like an economist: by outsourcing lower-value services in order to give yourself more time to work, do rewarding things with your children or otherwise play. Outsourcing household production usually smacks of something only a hedge-fund billionaire or perhaps the Monopoly Man would do, but it is probably a good investment for plenty of middle-class people, too, since doing so can improve their future expected earnings.

headline: Selections From Obama on Health Care
text: President Obama announced a fix to his signature health care law that will allow existing customers to keep their insurance plans.

headline: The Console as Concierge
text: THE video game console is dead, and the body has been cold for a long time. Sure, Sony and Microsoft are releasing what everyone describes as new game consoles, but the term is a misnomer. The Sony PlayStation 4, released on Friday, and Microsoft’s Xbox One, due next Friday, are game consoles in the same way that the iPhone is a telephone.

headline: From Roman Gladiators to Marauding Goblins
text: Here are quick looks at a few games available on the new video game consoles from Sony and Microsoft.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
text: As an homage to Charlotte Perriand’s creative force, Louis Vuitton is building, for the first time, one of the legendary Modernist’s never-realized designs.

headline: Train in India Hits Elephants Crossing Track
text: NEW DELHI — A passenger train speeding through northeast India barreled into a herd of elephants as they crossed a set of tracks late Wednesday, killing five. Their bodies were scattered in pieces, so the authorities were at first unable to count them and reported that seven had died.

headline: Young African Writers Hold Forth in Brooklyn
text: The Miser has always felt that New York’s public libraries constitute the kind of cultural and civic asset that’s so obviously valuable yet often taken for granted. In a city of world-class art institutions, museums, performance halls, film festivals and athletic stadiums, some of the most vital programming unfolds among the stacks, as it were, in branches across the five boroughs, and is typically free and open to the public.

headline: Speculation Looms Over Sale of Cohen’s Artworks at Auction
text: It was a question whispered throughout this week’s contemporary art auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s: “How’s Steve’s stuff selling?”

headline: Things Didn’t Go as Planned
text: Alan Greenspan is one of the most famous living economists. But he is not what you would call an economist’s economist.

headline: Kljestan Seeks to Impress U.S. With His Play, Not His Mustache
text: GLASGOW — Furry facial hair seems to be a perpetual topic in American sports these days, but it also has its moments in the spotlight abroad. During a recent Champions League game between Paris St.-Germain and Anderlecht, United States midfielder Sacha Kljestan, who is a mainstay for the Belgian team, found himself chirping back and forth with the P.S.G. star Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

headline: 50 Years Later, CBS and Grammys to Commemorate Beatles’ Appearance on ‘Ed Sullivan’
text: The 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first visit to the United States is shaping up to be nearly as noisy as the original event, but without crowds of screaming fans congregating at Kennedy Airport and the Plaza Hotel and, of course, without the Beatles themselves. CBS announced on Thursday that it would show a two-hour special, “The Night That Changed America: A Grammy Salute to the Beatles,” on Feb. 9 at 8 p.m. – the same date and time slot (and on the same network) as “The Ed Sullivan Show,” on which the Beatles made their live American television debut. The show will include covers of Beatles songs by current stars (none of which have been announced) in performances to be taped Jan. 27.

headline: Heroes and Crusaders
text: If you find the grubby spectacle of today’s Washington cause for shame and despair — and, really, how could you not? — then I suggest you turn off the TV and board Doris Kearns Goodwin’s latest time machine. Let her transport you back to the turn of the 20th century, to a time when this country had politicians of stature and conscience, when the public believed that government could right great wrongs, when, before truncated attention spans, a 50,000-word exposé of corruption could sell out magazines and galvanize a reluctant Congress. The villains seemed bigger, too, or at least more brazen — industrial barons and political bosses who monopolized entire industries, strangled entire cities. And “change” was not just a slogan. “There are but a handful of times in the history of our country,” Goodwin writes in her introduction, “when there occurs a transformation so remarkable that a molt seems to take place, and an altered country begins to emerge.” The years covered in this book are such a time. It makes a pretty grand story.

headline: At Memorial for Lou Reed, Just Music
text: Lou Reed lived what was often a loud rock ‘n’ roll life filled with loud rock ‘n’ roll songs. So it was only fitting that an outdoor memorial service held in Manhattan on Thursday began with an unannounced burst of guitar feedback, startling pigeons and passers-by alike, before it coalesced into the opening chords of his song “The Blue Mask,” on which Mr. Reed defiantly sang, “I loathe and despise repentance.”

headline: Attack Ravages Power Grid. (Just a Test.)
text: WASHINGTON — In windowless rooms from here to California, nearly 10,000 electrical engineers, cybersecurity specialists, utility executives and F.B.I. agents furiously grappled over 48 hours with an unseen “enemy” who tried to turn out the lights across America. The enemy injected computer viruses into grid control systems, bombed transformers and substations and knocked out power lines by the dozen.

headline: In Bordeaux, Art, Music — and Dance Parties
text: Bordeaux may largely be known for its wine and history, but under the city’s classical facade, a vibrant contemporary art and performance community, fleeing the high cost of living in Paris, has established itself.

headline: Danny Bowien’s Thanksgiving Pastrami
text: Hanukkah and Thanksgiving coincide this year, so the chef Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese Food and Mark Bittman demonstrate how to make holiday pastrami, no smoker necessary.

headline: Philippine Official Fired for Estimate of 10,000 Dead From Typhoon
text: As the desperate search for survivors continued in the Philippines on Thursday, a senior police commander was fired for telling reporters last weekend that the death toll from the typhoon that devastated the nation could exceed 10,000, according to a government news agency.

headline: He Wrote Himself a Ticket to New York
text: John Pollono said he was knee deep writing a play about 19th-century Boston, the art of dueling and the myriad rules that govern such gunplay, when it suddenly occurred to him to lighten up.

headline: Harmony Hammond
text: Alexander Gray Associates

headline: Songs of Experience, the Two-Hearted Kind
text: Hey, all you hard-core Stephen Sondheim devotees, bet you can’t place this immortal lyric from the musical theater’s master of the mot juste: “Skeedoobeeeewahoowapawayskeebopooeee.”

headline: Eileen Quinlan: ‘Curtains’
text: Miguel Abreu Gallery

headline: Cyprien Gaillard: ‘Today Diggers, Tomorrow Dickens’
text: Gladstone Gallery

headline: Brad Kahlhamer: ‘A Fist Full of Feathers’
text: Jack Shainman Gallery

headline: Malerie Marder: ‘Anatomy’
text: Leslie Tonkonow

headline: Alison Elizabeth Taylor: ‘Surface Tension’
text: James Cohan Gallery

headline: A Haitian Boy’s Needless Death From Diabetes
text: JEAN-PAUL was 12 when he died. A diabetic, he might well have lived if not for a tragically simple problem, common in rural Haiti: the glucose test strips available did not match the only glucometer we had access to in our rudimentary district hospital.

headline: A Spectator’s View of J.F.K.’s Funeral Procession
text: With the 50th anniversary of President Kennedy’s assassination approaching, Donald Hughes, a retired builder in North Carolina, thought someone might be interested in a roll of film he took back when he was a high-school senior. He got in touch with a photographer friend of his in New York, Chris Verene, who in turn reached out to us. We were indeed interested.

headline: How the Russians Discovered America
text: Since 1981, Russian theatergoers have thrilled to the throbbing romance and power chords that have put the rock opera “Juno and Avos” on course to overtake “The Fantasticks” in a decade or so as the world’s longest-running musical. A cross between “Eugene Onegin” and “Madama Butterfly,” it tells the story of Nikolai Rezanov, a courtier and adventurer in the Napoleonic era, and his doomed love for the fetching Conchita Arguello, finest flower of the Spanish mission in San Francisco. The album of the show’s songs, on its release, sold 10 million copies.

headline: Police Shoot Man Fleeing With Gun in Wisconsin Children’s Hospital
text: Police in a Milwaukee suburb shot and wounded a man brandishing a handgun inside a children’s hospital on Thursday after officers had tried to arrest him on a warrant inside the hospital’s neonatal care unit, the authorities said. No one else was injured during the shooting.

headline: Rap Genius Says It Will Seek Licenses for Lyrics
text: Rap Genius, a website that was accused by music publishers on Monday of reprinting thousands of song lyrics without permission, revealed that it had a major licensing deal all along — and also indicated that the site was likely to pursue more such deals in the future rather than fight with publishers over copyright.

headline: Rogers Reflects on Season in the Spotlight as a Gay Athlete
text: Robbie Rogers generally prefers to avoid reminiscing. Even this week, as he considered all that had happened over the past 12 months — his decision to announce his sexual orientation, his brief retirement and his return to soccer as the first openly gay male athlete in a prominent North American professional league — he interspersed his memories with sizable dollops of excitement about what lies ahead.

headline: Record Label Owner Playing Along With Tech
text: When Alan Chan, the chief executive of Bre.ad, a link-shortening service, gave himself a 30th-birthday party in October, the event took place on a Sunday night — hangovers be damned — in a stylish loft in SoHo. Mr. Chan, who had just sold Bre.ad to Yahoo, had arranged, in the extravagant manner of the New York City tech world, for the Sugarhill Gang, an ’80s-era hip-hop group, to perform. Equally in keeping with local start-up fashion, he had also arranged for his gathering to be managed musically by the D.J. and independent-record-label owner Sean Glass.

headline: Kimberly-Clark to Spin Off Health Care Unit
text: Kimberly-Clark said on Thursday that it would pursue a potential spinoff its health care business, becoming the latest company to slim down its operations to help bolster its stock price.

headline: Health Law Rollout’s Stumbles Draw Parallels to Bush’s Hurricane Response
text: WASHINGTON — Barack Obama won the presidency by exploiting a political environment that devoured George W. Bush in a second term plagued by sinking credibility, failed legislative battles, fractured world relations and revolts inside his own party.

headline: John Oliver to Leave ‘The Daily Show’ to Host Weekly Show on HBO
text: John Oliver has turned his widely praised stint this summer filling in for Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show” into a regular program of his own on HBO.

headline: Full Transcript of Obama’s News Conference on Health Care
text: The following is the complete transcript of President Obama’s press conference on Thursday in Washington. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service.)

headline: Northern Illinois Says It Belongs With the Best
text: DeKALB, Ill. — Three weeks ago, Northern Illinois opened the Chessick Practice Center, a $9.5 million building with a full-size indoor turf field that will help its football team cope with Midwestern winters and perhaps further its rise from an anonymous team on the prairie to a national powerhouse.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
text: In the news: the female orgasm, knee ligaments and birthing babies. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Virtual Money Draws Notice of Regulators
text: Updated, 8:15 p.m. | New York’s top financial regulator is looking at issuing a “BitLicense” for businesses that conduct transactions in virtual currencies like bitcoin.

headline: Chicago Said to Weigh Suit Over Marketing of Painkillers
text: Lawyers for the city of Chicago are investigating marketing claims by producers of narcotic painkillers as a prelude to a possible lawsuit against them, according to interviews and a court filing.

headline: Information on Art Trove to Start Going Online
text: German authorities, trying to speed the identification of some of 1,400 works apparently lost during the Nazi era, said that they would soon begin posting information on 590 of those with questionable provenances on the website lostart.de, a database of art looted or missing since World War II. “Publication will start next week,” according to a statement issued by the Culture Ministry that quoted Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, who spent decades in government service helping to run cultural institutions in Germany and who was appointed to lead a group of art experts tasked with researching the history of the works. So far 25 works have been posted. “Possible rightful claimants can now more quickly identify missing art works and in relevant cases make their claims heard,” the statement said. Such news is welcome to claimants like David Toren, an 88-year-old New Yorker who recognized one of the works, a painting by Max Liebermann, as having once hung in the home of a great-uncle. State prosecutors took possession of the art in February from the apartment of Cornelius Gurlitt as part of a tax case.

headline: Modern Love | Broken Heart Doctor
text: After Thomas Hooven graduated from medical school, his girlfriend of 12 years ended their relationship. It was only three weeks before they planned to marry.

headline: Wines for Thanksgiving: Mixing Without Trying to Match
text: When I first came to The New York Times nearly 30 years ago (good God!), I worked with an editor who kept a file labeled “How We Did It Last Time.” Inside were detailed instructions for covering events that occurred regularly but infrequently, like elections. Rather than trying to reconstruct his procedures every time, he simply kept careful track of best practices and pulled out the file when necessary.

headline: Hyperbole and a Book
text: Allie Brosh, whose blog “Hyperbole and a Half” attracts as many as five million readers a month, has published her first book.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Court Orders German Firm to Pay Victims of Defective Breast Implants
text: PARIS — A French court on Thursday ordered a German quality-control company to compensate 1,600 victims of defective breast implants made by a French company about $4,000 each, according to news reports.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Philippines, Iran, Gaza and Turkey.

headline: Nursing a Wound in an Appropriate Setting
text: I started my pediatrics residency on the cardiology unit, which was appropriate: my heart had a giant hole in it. Just after I graduated from medical school, as I was moving into my fiancée’s New York apartment, she ended our relationship. We went out to dinner that night, and after we came home, she told me we were through.

headline: A Little Bit of Everything in One Place
text: “The Salon: Art & Design,” the smart young fair at the Park Avenue Armory this weekend, is doing an excellent job of splitting the difference between the auction-house randomness and white-cube-gallery control. As its title suggests, it is wide open in terms of material — art, craft, design, antiques from any period or place can be found here. It is up to the dealers to provide the focus, which they do. This means controlled diversity. You can bounce from concentrated views of French Art Deco to early Modern art to pre-Columbian ceramics in one aisle.

headline: A Nibble to Keep the Wine Company
text: At the Thanksgiving wine tasting, we started on the drinks before the food was served. There’s a good chance we’ll do that at home, too. But with the idea of offering guests a little something alongside a glass as they arrive for Thanksgiving, enough to take the edge off without spoiling appetites, I’ll serve gougères, little savory French cream puffs seasoned with cheese. Mine, enriched with cranberries and Cheddar, will pay homage to New England instead of Paris. I’ve made them already. They’re in the freezer, and they’ll be warmed in the oven before I enlist a granddaughter to pass them from a napkin-lined basket.

headline: Playing at DOC NYC
text: Select images from films in this documentary festival.

headline: Power Doses of a Rapper’s Idiosyncratic Religion
text: As much as Macklemore is a rapper, he is a motivational speaker, a preacher, a confessor, a scold. In almost every case, his yarn-spinning has a higher purpose, his stories vehicles for universal morals. He presents himself as someone to root for, and in so doing, he’s rooting for you, and everyone else, too.

headline: Love Child of a Renaissance Spirit
text: “My Days” is the title of a program of mostly Renaissance works for voices and viols that was presented Tuesday at St. Thomas  by that church’s Choir of Men and Boys and the wonderful English viol consort Fretwork. It’s also the title of an arresting new work by Nico Muhly, a touching declaration of fraternity with the great Elizabethan composers that had its United States premiere that evening.

headline: California Shuts Down Sites Mimicking State Insurance Marketplace
text: LOS ANGELES—The California attorney general’s office has shut down 10 websites that mimicked state’s official health insurance marketplace, the attorney general, Kamala Harris, announced Wednesday.

headline: Guidelines Help Heirs Assume and Modify Loans
text: New guidelines from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau are aimed at preventing mortgage servicers from unnecessarily foreclosing on homes after a borrower dies.

headline: When a Deal Goes Bad, Blame the Ratings
text: Did you make an incredibly bad decision during the great credit bubble?

headline: Task Force to Study Crime on Indian Reservations
text: A special Justice Department task force will hold a series of public meetings around the country to study the scope and impact that exposure to violence has on Native American and Alaska Native children, the Justice Department said.

headline: Alexander Payne on 'Nebraska'
text: The director discusses his film featuring Bruce Dern and Will Forte.

text: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Museum.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Spending Hours on the Co-op Board Minutes
text: The standard advice to apartment buyers is to make sure someone reviews the board minutes. But why? What’s in the minutes that is so important? It turns out to be quite a bit.

headline: Poignant Images, With Posterity the Ultimate Winner
text: In a photograph shot by Spencer Platt in Lebanon in 2006, the spectacle of five attractive, fashionably dressed young people in a glossy red convertible occupies the foreground. By surrealistic contrast, the immediate background is filled with the smoking wreckage of bombed buildings, where a few pedestrians pass by. While the title obliquely explains, “Beirut Residents Continue to Flock to Southern Neighborhoods,” the impression you get is of obnoxious rich kids out for a sensation-seeking drive.

headline: ‘The Shadows Took Shape’
text: The cultural movement called Afrofuturism is the subject of a new show at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

headline: Going Beyond Blackness, Into the Starry Skies
text: One day in the late 1930s, Herman Blount, an African-American music student in Alabama, had an unusual experience.

headline: Don’t Do Me Like That
text: For 40 years, my wife and I have been best friends with another couple. We all like concerts, so I tried to buy tickets for Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. The event was sold out, but I found four tickets for $900 on Craigslist. With my friend’s permission, I bought them. On concert night, he gave me a check for $450 just before we learned the tickets were fake. I handed back his check, never expecting him to take it. But he did, then suggested we split the loss on his pair for $225. I’d like to tell him I’m disappointed in him. He saw the tickets and approved all my actions. Thoughts?

headline: Where Bulgari’s Rare Baubles Come to Life
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Hoofbeats by the Sea
text: Does folk dance have a place in contemporary culture? The intriguing question came to the choreographer Will Rawls after a 2008 life-changing trip to the Balkans. While there, he began thinking about using folklore as a way to discover, in him, a new kind of dancer that could embody both the present and tradition.

headline: An Orange-Haired Dynamo and Friends Grow Up
text: Fist pumping, head banging, Finger pointing, high kicking, jumping, racing around the stage and leading arena singalongs, Hayley Williams was in her element when Paramore performed on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden. She was the petite, orange-haired, perpetually animated embodiment of the narrator of her songs, who faces down and joyfully overpowers one frustration after another, moving from complaints and sarcasm to self-empowerment.

headline: The Muse of Goethe, Intensified
text: In the end credits, a note identifies “Faust,” Alexander Sokurov’s brooding, hallucinatory, freehanded adaptation of Goethe’s great allegorical drama, as the concluding installment of a four-film sequence, the “Men of Power” tetralogy that also includes “Moloch” (1999), “Taurus” (2001) and “The Sun” (2005). Those movies are intimate and unsettling visits with some of the chief monsters of the 20th century: Hitler, Lenin and Hirohito. What links them is a lust for power at once madly destructive and profoundly lonely. While Mr. Sokurov does not exactly express sympathy for these devils, he refuses to view them as anything other than human.

headline: What Should Airlines Do About Children With Peanut Allergies?
text: Lianne and Joshua Mandelbaum never step on an airplane without six vials of injectable epinephrine and a bottle of liquid Benadryl. That’s because Joshua, who is 8 years old, is deathly allergic to peanuts. If exposed to them, he can go into anaphylactic shock. But even with the injectable epinephrine, he needs to be rushed to the hospital for emergency care. This makes flying scary; there aren’t many long-term medical options at 35,000 feet in the sky.

headline: We Interrupt This Generation ...
text: Life was pre-empted on Nov. 22, 1963.

headline: A Madwoman Lets It Rip
text: The extraordinary Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci has concentrated her career in Europe. Each appearance she makes in America, like her New York recital debut last year at Alice Tully Hall, is coveted by opera fans familiar with her intelligent and charismatic artistry.

headline: Key Brazilians in Graft Case Must Go to Jail, Court Says
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s highest court has ruled that the powerful figures in the governing Workers Party convicted in a vast vote-buying scheme must soon start their prison terms, a surprising twist in a country where corrupt lawmakers have long been sheltered from punishment.

headline: You May Already Be a Winner. Or Not.
text: It may or may not be a coincidence that Alexander Payne’s new film, “Nebraska,” shares its name with Bruce Springsteen’s austere album from 1982. Nebraska is a roomy state, and Mr. Payne, born and raised in Omaha, has set three of his previous features at least partly in it (“Citizen Ruth,” “Election” and “About Schmidt”). But to my ear, at least, a specific Springsteenian echo announces itself early and deepens as this movie winds from Billings, Mont., across the Badlands and toward Lincoln, stopping for a while in the tiny and fictitious hamlet of Hawthorne. Beyond the folky intonations of the fiddle-and-guitar waltz (by Mark Orton) that accompanies the opening images (shot by Phedon Papamichael) and beyond the bleak beauty of the images themselves, there is something in the movie that brings to mind the haunting last line of the album’s title track: “Sir I guess there’s just a meanness in this world.”

headline: Four Eccentric Senators as Capitol Hill Roomies
text: There is nothing not funny about Washington.

text: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced nearly a year ago that a trio of outside curators would be organizing the 2014 Biennial, each taking a floor of the museum. Each brings a different set of eyes and interests to the show.

headline: Prospecting for Dollars
text: International buyers are known for spending big money in New York, be it the woman from China who spent more than $6 million on a home for her toddler at the skyscraper One57, or the daughter of Dmitry Rybolovlev, the Russian potash magnate, who used a trust to pay $88 million for an apartment at 15 Central Park West.

headline: Hedge Fund Moguls Suddenly Turn Eyes to FedEx
text: Daniel S. Loeb may have broken the news of his firm’s position in FedEx earlier this week, but it turns out that at least two his fellow hedge fund moguls had the same idea in the third quarter.

headline: Would You Like Fries With Those Spicy Pork McBites?
text: With competition heating up in China’s $174 billion dollar fast-food market, McDonald’s is seeking to up its game by capitalizing on the country’s increasingly voracious appetite for pigs. The result? Spicy Pork McBites.

headline: It’s Opposite Day in the Senate
text: There were a lot of high points in today’s Senate confirmation hearings, but my favorite may be one particular malapropism about half of the Federal Reserve’s dual mandate. Here’s the excerpt:

headline: The Glory of Rome, the Sweetness of Life
text: The first time you see Jep Gambardella, the Roman sensualist magnificently, poetically adrift in “The Great Beauty,” he has a cigarette clenched in the center of his big, bared, ocher-stained teeth. People are surging all around him, their bodies pulsating to music that has transformed a multitude into an organism that beats like a heart. As he sways amid this delirium, Jep smiles with welcoming arms and lidded eyes, an attitude that brings to mind one of those marble saints scattered around Rome forever locked in rapture. And then Jep joins the dance, surrendering to a throng that, in absorbing him, turns an orgiastic reverie into something like a religious communion.

headline: Cancer Agency Is Back in Business, Writing Checks
text: More than 10 months after state leaders halted grant operations at the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas, known as Cprit, amid allegations of cronyism and misspent money, the $3 billion enterprise is getting back to the business of fighting cancer, with restructured leadership.

headline: West Bank: Palestinian Family’s Home Is Set on Fire
text: Assailants burned the entrance of a Palestinian family’s home in the West Bank village of Sinjil early Thursday. Hebrew graffiti sprayed on a stone wall outside suggested that the arson was an act of revenge by Jewish extremists for the fatal stabbing of an Israeli soldier by a Palestinian teenager the day before. The graffiti read “Regards from Eden, revenge!” apparently a reference to Eden Atias, the soldier who was stabbed on a bus in northern Israel. The house, belonging to the Dar Khalil family, which has no known connection with the stabbing, was set on fire as the parents and five children slept inside. They escaped without serious injury. The Israeli police said an investigation was underway. Also Thursday, Israeli warplanes attacked two concealed rocket launchers in northern Gaza after two rockets fired from Gaza landed in southern Israel, according to the military. No injuries were reported on either side.

headline: Pork Belly, Yes; Popovers, No
text: Comfort is a warm popover and not a pickled vegetable, if you ask me.

headline: Last Shipment of Nuclear Fuel From Russian Bombs Heads to U.S.
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The final shipment of civilian nuclear reactor fuel made from Soviet atomic bombs left port for the United States on Thursday, ending a post-Cold War program that has been a long-running boon for the American nuclear power industry.

headline: Wisconsin Governor Seeks to Extend Medicaid
text: Blaming an “abysmal” rollout of the new federal insurance market, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said on Thursday that he would ask the Legislature to allow thousands of low-income residents to remain in the state’s Medicaid program until April 1 — a three-month extension.

headline: Flavors of Portugal on a Cozy Scale
text: The pleasures of eating in the large and lively restaurants of Newark’s Ironbound section are available on a more intimate scale at Brasa Grille, a Portuguese restaurant in Chatham that has attracted regulars since it opened in 2008.

headline: Spare Times for Nov. 15-21
text: Iranian New Wave 1960s-1970s Film Series (through next Friday) When his documentaries about life in Iran under the pro-Western shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, focused too much on the poverty he saw, Kamran Shirdel — originally commissioned by the government to make these films — was expelled, and forced to leave some work behind. Four of his short films — several completed after the Islamic Revolution of 1979 — will be screened on Wednesday, starting at 6:30 p.m., at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.

headline: Instead of Mail, Delivering Tasty Morsels
text: If you have not been to Westport recently, you might be surprised to find that its old limestone-and-brick post office, which opened in 1935 on the town’s main thoroughfare, is now a snappy new restaurant, called Post 154, that fairly rocks in prime time.

headline: Europe’s Remarkable Achievement
text: After sort-of decent growth in the second quarter, Europe’s austerity advocates rushed to proclaim that their policies were bearing fruit. After the latest numbers, which show growth stalling, not so much.

headline: Cameroon: French Priest Kidnapped
text: A French priest was abducted from a monastery in the far north of Cameroon late Wednesday night, the French government and a witness said. There has been no claim of responsibility, but the Nigerian Islamist militant groups Boko Haram and Ansaru are known to operate in the region, near the border with Nigeria. The French government formally advises its citizens to avoid the area, “given the terrorist risk and the risk of kidnapping,” said Romain Nadal, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, in a statement. The priest, identified by the government as Georges Vandenbeusch, was taken by “bandits” who had unsuccessfully sought to open a monastery safe, according to Henri Djongyang, a priest who said he witnessed the kidnapping, which he recounted on the French radio station Europe 1. A French family of seven was kidnapped in the region in February and held for two months by Boko Haram fighters.

headline: Wine and Food Pairings at Thanksgiving
text: Just in time for Thanksgiving aperitifs, the innovative winemaker Christopher Tracy at Channing Daughters Winery has released three savory vermouths. These nonvintage fortified wines, which contain neutral grape brandy and honey, are named VerVino Variation One, Variation Two and Variation Three.

headline: Helping Our Troubled Cities Rebuild and Grow
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Venezuela, Campaign Takes the Form of a Fire Sale
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The transportation minister appeared on live television from an auto-parts store, trumpeting prices that had been slashed in half, at least. A top regional official, broadcasting from another shop, boasted that prices of toys and other goods had been cut to the bone. From an appliance store, the commerce minister called on shoppers to buy washers and dryers at new, low-low prices.

headline: A Reprieve for Midtown
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fortuneteller in Manhattan Is Sentenced to 5 to 15 Years in Prison
text: Sylvia Mitchell, the Manhattan fortuneteller whose ornate Greenwich Village parlor and air of uptown sophistication attracted well-to-do, distraught clients who preferred the finer things in life, was sentenced to five to 15 years in prison on Thursday, a month after a jury convicted her of grand larceny.

text: To the Editor:

text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Government in Egypt Eases Restrictions
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim government lifted a state of emergency as well as a nighttime curfew late Thursday, signaling its growing confidence in its ability to impose security after the unrest that followed the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi in July.

headline: Surrender, Oblivion, Survival
text: HADLEY, Mass. — TACLOBAN is my city. I grew up directly facing the Pacific Ocean, on the Philippines’ eastern shore, which takes the brunt of the yearly monsoons. Geography and history provide the textbook nickname of Leyte and Samar, the provinces hardest hit by Haiyan: “The Typhoon Path.”

headline: Law Says Hudson River Park Is Allowed to Sell Air Rights
text: On Wednesday night, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed into law the bill that will let Hudson River Park, the popular but financially beleaguered greensward on the West Side of Manhattan, sell development rights in order to collect much-needed revenue.

headline: C.I.A. Collects Global Data on Transfers of Money
text: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency is secretly collecting bulk records of international money transfers handled by companies like Western Union — including transactions into and out of the United States — under the same law that the National Security Agency uses for its huge database of Americans’ phone records, according to current and former government officials.

headline: Who’s Right on the Stock Market?
text: IF you’ve been wondering whether it’s possible to regularly beat the stock market averages — a natural question with the market at an all-time high — you didn’t get any guidance from the Nobel Prize committee this year: Two of the winning economists disagree on that perennial issue.

headline: High Price of Barely Getting By
text: The unmarried lovers in Laurie Collyer’s “Sunlight Jr.” are young working-class Americans buffeted by woe. The feisty, resilient Melissa (Naomi Watts) has a minimum-wage job at the convenience store that gives the movie its name. Her live-in boyfriend, Richie (Matt Dillon), a former TV repairman, has subsisted on disability benefits since a motorcycle accident left him in a wheelchair. Their home is a shabby motel somewhere in west central Florida.

headline: Chief’s Vision for Morgan Stanley Is Showing Some Success
text: Thunderclouds were gathering in April when James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, went for a run on the beach on Amelia Island in Florida after attending a closed-door meeting of the bank’s top stockbrokers. After just a few miles, the storm began to pick up speed, prompting Mr. Gorman to turn around and head for safety.

headline: A Scrapbook of a Memorable Night for Rock
text: The rock documentary “12-12-12,” directed by Amir Bar-Lev and Charlie Lightening, is a sustained adrenaline rush. Looking back nearly a year to the night rock’s elder statesmen gathered at Madison Square Garden for a concert to raise money for victims of Hurricane Sandy, it shows what celebrities and corporate honchos can accomplish when they pool their energies for the greater good. The actor Tony Danza, who appears briefly in the film, cites the phrase on the United States seal, “E pluribus unum” (“Out of many, one”), as defining the spirit of the event.

headline: Giants Cornerback Fighting the Image of Being Too Small
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ defensive coordinator, Perry Fewell, gave Trumaine McBride, a well-traveled sixth-year cornerback, the opportunity to start in place of the injured Corey Webster five games ago. It was not a decision that left Fewell feeling comfortable.

headline: Under My Thumb
text: SEATTLE — This is how the middle class dies, not with a bang, but a forced squeeze. After a global corporation posts record profits, it asks the state that has long nurtured its growth for the nation’s biggest single tax break, and then tells the people who make its products that their pension plan will be frozen, their benefits slashed, their pay raises meager. Take it or we leave. And everyone caves.

headline: Bonds Backed by Solar Power Payments Get Nod
text: Over the decades, Wall Street has used many assets to back up the bonds it sells, including car loans, life insurance policies and future royalties on David Bowie’s music. Now, in a milestone of sorts for the emerging solar industry, the finance wizards are embracing a new kind of security, this one backed by solar electricity payments.

headline: On a Mission Within Earshot of a War, Armed With Paint
text: GOLAN HEIGHTS — The graffiti painter known as Col Wallnuts likes to use exploding bursts of color, hiding the abstract letters that form his tag, or street name, so only he can find them. Last week, he applied his paint on concrete canvases that had themselves been exploded, often amid the sound of bombs detonating not far away in the Syrian civil war.

headline: ‘A Bubble Around My Heart’
text: You’ll forget many of the songs the moment you leave “Bubble Boy,” a musical being given its world premiere by the American Theater Group in Rahway. Still, when you look back on this likable and lightweight show, you’ll probably remember the good time you had when you first heard them.

headline: The Money Trap
text: When Greece hit the skids almost four years ago, some analysts (myself included) thought that we might be seeing the beginning of the end for the euro, Europe’s common currency. Others were more optimistic, believing that tough love — temporary aid tied to reform — would soon produce recovery. Both camps were wrong. What we actually got was a rolling crisis that never seems to reach any kind of resolution. Every time Europe seems ready to go over the edge, policy makers find a way to avoid complete disaster. But every time there are hints of true recovery, something else goes wrong.

headline: U.S. Dancer Quits the Bolshoi, Complaining of Bribery
text: MOSCOW — A young dancer from Texas who last year joined the Bolshoi Ballet after graduating from its training academy here has quit the storied company after alleging that she was denied opportunities to perform and ultimately told she would have to pay a bribe of $10,000 to get a solo role.

headline: Hazily Hoping for an Easy Hit
text: Dope-sick and out of cash, four meth addicts embark on an impromptu robbery in an upscale neighborhood. Their dealer, Tai (Anthony Ruivivar), needs a television as a birthday gift for his mother; in return, David (Tom Pelphrey) — the most rational of the meth heads and the group’s designated driver — will score some product, along with Tai’s unpredictable good will.

headline: Kalaparusha Maurice McIntyre, Tenor Saxophonist, Dies at 77
text: Kalaparusha Maurice McIntyre, a saxophonist who was a founding member of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a pioneering Chicago avant-garde coalition, died on Saturday in the Bronx. He was 77.

headline: Fatal Shooting of Black Woman Outside Detroit Stirs Racial Tensions
text: DEARBORN HEIGHTS, Mich. — Shortly before 1 a.m. on Saturday, Nov. 2, a young woman, just a year out of high school, crashed the car she was driving along a residential street on Detroit’s west side.

headline: Clothes That Do Away With the Attaché Case
text: NEW YORK — Whether you are a business executive flying between neighboring cities or across multiple time zones, it is easier than ever to travel light.

headline: A Most Valuable Player With an Invaluable Platform
text: By the end, they had all left the postseason stage: Brandon Phillips and Michael Bourn, Coco Crisp and Justin Upton, David Price and Andrew McCutchen, Carl Crawford and Prince Fielder. The World Series arrived, and all the African-American stars in the playoff field were gone.

headline: Is Nuclear Power the Answer?
text: A group of climate scientists want environmentalists to see nuclear power as a way to combat climate change. Are they on to something?

headline: Obama Selects Health Policy Advocate as Surgeon General
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, an early supporter and grass-roots advocate for the Affordable Care Act, as surgeon general on Thursday.

headline: Lockheed Will Cut 4,000 Jobs by 2015
text: Lockheed Martin said on Thursday that it would cut 4,000 jobs and close several plants in response to reductions in government spending.

headline: F.C.C. Smartphone App Gauges Speed of User’s Network
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released its first smartphone app, a free program that allows consumers to measure the broadband speed they are getting on their mobile devices and to determine whether it is as fast as wireless companies say.

headline: Union’s Rejection Puts Future Home of Boeing 777X in Doubt
text: Which state might get the thousands of coveted jobs producing Boeing’s planned 777X airliner seemed up for grabs on Thursday after Boeing’s machinists in Washington State overwhelmingly rejected a contract extension that the company said was pivotal to future production in the Puget Sound area.

headline: A Health Care Fix
text: President Obama has come up with a modest fix for a self-inflicted political wound: his repeated — and wrong — assertions that Americans would be able to keep their health insurance plans if they wanted to under the health care reform law.

headline: Jacqueline Kennedy’s Smart Pink Suit, Preserved in Memory and Kept Out of View
text: On the plane back to Washington, in her pink Chanel suit, caked with her husband’s blood, Jackie Kennedy resisted all suggestions from aides that she clean herself up. Instead, she just said, “Let them see what they’ve done.”

headline: Incognito Files Grievance Over Suspension by Dolphins
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Richie Incognito, accused of bullying Jonathan Martin, his teammate on the Dolphins’ offensive line, has filed a noninjury grievance against the Miami Dolphins challenging his suspension for conduct detrimental to the team. Under the N.F.L.’s collective bargaining agreement, an independent arbitrator hears all noninjury grievances, and Incognito has asked that his be heard as soon as possible.

headline: British Press Freedom Under Threat
text: Britain has a long tradition of a free, inquisitive press. That freedom, so essential to democratic accountability, is being challenged by the Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government of Prime Minister David Cameron.
