headline: Closeted High School Romances
text: It’s been 10 years since the publication of Brent Hartinger’s teenage novel “Geography Club,” and the new film adaptation of the book mostly serves to underscore just how far the culture has come in acknowledging the pressures faced by gay high school students. Television shows like “Glee” and “Pretty Little Liars” have given such students and their struggles a weekly spotlight, and documentaries like the searing “Valentine Road” have explored the issues in far more depth than “Geography Club” does.

headline: Turkey Moves to Silence Dissenters, but With One Eye on Its Image Abroad
text: ISTANBUL — Late one night last summer, at the height of antigovernment demonstrations sweeping Turkey, a group of protest leaders rushed to the home of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Ankara, the capital, to negotiate a solution to the growing crisis.

headline: Saul Kagan, Who Won Holocaust Restitution, Is Dead at 91
text: Saul Kagan, a former refugee who for decades led the Jewish service organization that was primarily responsible for securing more than $70 billion in restitution for Holocaust survivors and their heirs, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: The Stop-and-Frisk Case Takes Another Turn
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit embarrassed itself again on Wednesday by reaffirming a hasty and ill-considered decision last month to remove the presiding judge from the court battle over New York City’s stop-and-frisk program and to stay her remedies for the policy’s civil rights violations.

headline: U.S. Investigates Currency Trades by Major Banks
text: Updated, 6:56 p.m. | From their desks at some of the world’s biggest banks, traders exchanged a series of instant messages that earned them the nickname “the cartel.”

headline: Retailers Less Than Cheerful Over Christmas Sales
text: As the holiday shopping season accelerates with aggressive deals, Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer, joined other companies in painting a gloomy picture of consumer spending for the rest of the year.

headline: Obama Proposal Worries Insurers and Regulators
text: President Obama’s effort to quiet a political uproar by suggesting on Thursday that consumers should be allowed to keep their current health plans met significant resistance from many insurers and state regulators, who said they had not been consulted in advance about the proposal, doubted it could work and feared it might seriously damage the new insurance marketplace.

headline: Not Even Marcos Family Is Spared Residents’ Ire
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Look around this once-gracious city by a horseshoe-shape bay and it is still possible to imagine it before the mass deaths and devastation of last Friday’s typhoon, when it was a jewel of the Pacific thanks in good part to a local girl who became a global celebrity: Imelda R. Marcos, the flamboyant former first lady of the Philippines.

headline: Bobbie Handman, a Medal of Arts Winner, Dies at 85
text: Bobbie Handman, a behind-the-scenes force in Democratic politics, a theater preservationist and the first person to be awarded the National Medal of Arts for advocacy, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Airlifting Big Cats From Circus Hell
text: “Lion Ark,” a spunky account of a perilous rescue mission, has a ragtag rhythm that befits the mercurial behavior of its hulking hairy stars. Following a group from Animal Defenders International as it conducts the 2010 roundup and relocation of 25 captive lions illegally held in traveling circuses in Bolivia, this warmhearted documentary from Tim Phillips makes “Born Free” look like a beast story for babes.

headline: A Marijuana Stash That Carried Little Risk
text: Walking down Eighth Avenue a few weeks ago, I made sure my backpack was fully zipped shut. Inside was a modest stash of pot, bought just an hour or so earlier. A friend knew someone in that world, and after an introduction, then a quiet, discreet meeting, I was on my way to the subway. Never before had I walked through Midtown Manhattan with it on my person. There were four cookies in vacuum-sealed pouches — “edibles” is the technical term — and then a few pinches of what was described as “herb.”

headline: This Week’s Movies: Nov. 15, 2013
text: The New York Times film critics on “Nebraska,” “The Great Beauty” and “Faust.”

headline: Asia Rivalries Play Role in Aid to the Philippines
text: CEBU, the Philippines — The American aircraft carrier George Washington has arrived, its 5,000 sailors and 80 aircraft already busy ferrying relief supplies to storm-battered survivors, and the United States has committed an initial $20 million in humanitarian assistance. Japan is dispatching a naval force of 1,000 troops, in what officials say is that country’s largest ever disaster-relief deployment. Also on the way: the Illustrious, a British aircraft carrier stocked with transport planes, medical experts and $32 million worth of aid.

headline: Knicks’ Smith Raises Eyebrows in Twitter Feud With the Pistons’ Jennings
text: In the hours between Wednesday’s victory over the Atlanta Hawks and Thursday’s game against the Houston Rockets, the Knicks’ J. R. Smith somehow found the time to take on another opponent: Brandon Jennings of the Detroit Pistons.

headline: Europe Moves to Keep Its Corporate Trade Data Secret
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union plans to propose rules this month aimed at creating its first broad protection of trade secrets and setting penalties for those who try to profit from them illegally.

headline: Under Fire, Brooklyn Deputy Prosecutor Will Retire
text: Michael F. Vecchione, a longtime friend and top deputy of the Brooklyn district attorney, will retire from the office on Dec. 12, becoming the first in what is likely to be a wave of high-ranking deputies leaving as the district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, prepares to step down.

headline: $122 Million in 2012 Spending by Koch Group
text: A political nonprofit group founded by the billionaire industrialists David and Charles Koch spent $122 million during 2012, according to documents filed with the Colorado secretary of state, putting it among the biggest election spenders in the country.

headline: Message From Yellen Is Full Speed Ahead on the Stimulus
text: When Janet L. Yellen speaks, Wall Street listens — and investors liked what they heard on Thursday.

headline: $1 Million Medallions Stifling the Dreams of Cabdrivers
text: For decades, the New York City yellow cab has powered the consummate immigrant story — a tale of a new arrival who becomes a driver, a driver dogged enough to eventually become his own boss.

headline: A Digital Performance That Moves You — Literally
text: When a show is called “Meem: A Story Ballet About the Internet,” it’s not surprising that many things happen at once. The immersive production, choreographed by the performance artist Ryan McNamara for the Performa 13 biennial, places a cast of more than 18 dancers all over the Connelly Theater in the East Village: onstage, in the wings, in the balcony, in the foyer, like so many open tabs and windows in your browser. What is surprising, perhaps, is that the audience is seated.

headline: Questions for a New Class of Cholesterol Drugs
text: New guidelines governing the use of cholesterol-lowering medicines are a huge change for doctors and a vast number of patients, but the impact on the drug industry is expected to be less tumultuous.

headline: Team Owners Approve Funding for Expanded Use of Instant Replay
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Bud Selig’s father, Ben, once told him: Life is but a series of adjustments.

headline: A Push Away From Burning Coal as an Energy Source
text: The Tennessee Valley Authority sharply accelerated a shift away from coal as an energy source on Thursday, saying it would shut down eight electricity-generating units that together will burn nearly a fifth of its coal this year.

headline: Corrections: November 15, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Dangers Ahead for Climate, and Now for People
Performing Without a Net
text: The famous acrobatic troupe the Flying Wallendas made a name for themselves on the circus circuit by staring down the PERILS of performing without a NET. You might feel just as cavalier if you use a pen to take on this challenging Friday puzzle from David Woolf, the constructor who makes his debut today with a wild carnival of creativity.

headline: Fractious Family Indulging the Dream of a Child
text: The new musical “Little Miss Sunshine” opens with an emotional cloudburst. As the fractured family at the center of the show gathers for dinner, just about everyone has a grim comment to make on the state of existence.

headline: David Tepper Giving Carnegie Mellon a $67 Million Gift
text: A century ago, giants of America’s Gilded Age started the educational institutions that later became Carnegie Mellon University.

headline: Answering Questions About Health Savings Accounts
text: Recently, Your Money Adviser addressed the ins and outs of workplace health care spending options, including flexible spending plans and health savings accounts. Many workers were happy to hear about changes in workplace flexible-spending plans that will allow them to carry over $500 from one year to the next. Previously, any balance in the accounts had to be forfeited.

headline: Millennials With Boomer Angst
text: “The Fall of 1980” is a feature-length filmed fiction, but it’s a stretch to call this videotaped acting exercise a movie. Written and directed by a New York University graduate, Ryan Lonergan, and mostly starring other N.Y.U. graduates, it’s essentially a modern version of “The Big Chill” without the banging oldies soundtrack or competent actors.

headline: Survivor of Shooting Rampage Recalls Struggle With Killer
text: The first sound — a muffled pop — caused little alarm. It had come from somewhere on the third floor of a home in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, shared by musicians from Iran.

headline: As Nets Stumble, Garnett’s Actions Are Quieter Than Words
text: SACRAMENTO — Kevin Garnett arched himself over Mason Plumlee during a timeout here Wednesday night and barked loud encouragement and instruction at Plumlee, a rookie, for several intense seconds. Even from afar, it was clear that this was a one-way conversation.

headline: A Shorter Selling Season, So Marketers Take Risks
text: THEY say the holiday season is the Super Bowl of shopping because so much of retailers’ annual revenue — and profit — comes in during the run-up to Christmas. This year, marketers worried about the wobbly economy and wary of consumer sentiment are borrowing tactics from Super Bowl advertising, introducing campaigns in traditional, digital and social media that are stuffed with celebrities, surprises and schmaltz.

headline: Long Shadow of an All-Powerful Neighbor
text: “The Great Fallacy,” Paco Vázquez’s dense, lively new film about economic and sociological issues in Puerto Rico, eschews the storytelling form of many contemporary documentaries in favor of an instructive crash course in radical politics. It is propaganda, an educational tool and a practical manifesto for empowerment of the poor and the disenfranchised.

headline: Ban on Former Inmates in Public Housing Is Eased
text: The New York City Housing Authority will ease its ban on recently released prisoners and allow some of them to live in public housing as part of a pilot program set to start next month.

headline: A Rampage With No Rhyme or Reason
text: Unfolding with stripped-down simplicity, Charlie Minn’s “Long Island Railroad Massacre” details a 20-year-old American tragedy whose essential elements — one deeply disturbed gunman and many innocent victims — have become dismayingly common.

headline: The School of Arthur Danto
text: Each semester for a quarter-century, as I’ve geared up to teach one text or another by Arthur Danto, I’ve introduced him – as I did in my class on beauty on Thursday, Oct. 24 – as “our greatest living philosopher of art.” By the time we reconvened the next Monday, that statement was false; Danto died on the 25th at age 89, completing a transition from the idiosyncratic to the canonical.

headline: A Dead Father’s Presence, and a Daughter’s Challenge
text: Every evening, Julie Vann and her little sister carefully set the dinner table for four. The aroma of spiced curry permeates the halls of the small two-bedroom Bronx apartment, the very apartment their parents moved into after fleeing the brutal assault of Cambodia’s Khmer Rouge more than 35 years ago.

headline: The Genius Behind the Subversive Squiggles
text: It’s not entirely clear what documentaries larded with fawning testimonials aim to achieve. A professional seal of approval for the cautious? Reassurance for fans secretly gnawed by doubt? Peer pressure?

headline: Insurer Charged With Theft From a Charity
text: The owner of a Long Island insurance company has been charged with helping a longtime Jewish community leader loot more than $7 million from one of the city’s most influential social service organizations and pocketing at least $1 million himself, according to a criminal complaint filed in the case.

headline: Dispute Jeopardizes New Posting System for Japanese Players
text: A last-minute dispute placed the new posting system for Japanese players in jeopardy as small-market teams in Major League Baseball tried to put into effect a rule that would inhibit big-market teams, particularly the Yankees, from spending large sums on prospective Japanese stars like the ace pitcher Masahiro Tanaka.

headline: Bad Deathbed Advice, Indeed
text: Hearing such avowals earnestly delivered by the besotted title character of “Charlie Countryman” to his tough Romanian dream girl, you don’t know whether to laugh or to wince. Maybe both. The feature debut of Fredrik Bond from a screenplay by Matt Drake, this catastrophe of a movie zigzags drunkenly between action-adventure and surreal comedy with some magical realism slopped over it like ketchup.

headline: Reuniting as Grown-Ups, Kind Of
text: The writer-director Malcolm D. Lee gathers the crew of friends from his 1999 debut, “The Best Man,” for a Christmas reunion. In this follow-up, the struggling author Harper (Taye Diggs) and the football god Lance (Morris Chestnut) are wary former pals. Julian (Harold Perrineau) discovers that his wife, Candy (Regina Hall), has a past, preserved in a video online. And it’s not immediately apparent why anyone still puts up with the troublemaking television diva Shelby (Melissa De Sousa).

headline: HUD Storm-Protection Competition Will Narrow Ideas Big and Small
text: One project aims to raise parts of Lower Manhattan, put in a protective barrier that could double as a community center or an art installation, and sink the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive underground and cover it with a lush park.

headline: New Building Codes Passed After Lessons From Hurricane Sandy
text: Acting on the recommendations of a task force convened after Hurricane Sandy, the City Council on Thursday approved new requirements that were expected to make buildings more sustaining during emergencies and prevent some of the hardships that New Yorkers endured after the storm last year.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 14, 2013
Inquiry Focuses on Ammunition After Blast Kills 4 Marines at Camp Pendleton
text: LOS ANGELES — Four Marines who died at Camp Pendleton this week were killed by an explosion while clearing live ordnance from a training area, military officials said Thursday.

headline: How to Beat Rockets? Foul Howard and Wait for the Clank
text: It would be one thing if the Houston Rockets’ Dwight Howard, after being fouled, would step to the line, calmly bend his knees and make free throws with consistency. But he does not. So opposing teams, looking for a low-risk way of getting the ball back, keep hacking Howard on purpose.

headline: Devils Overcome Poor Start and Regain Successful Formula
text: Consistent play from Martin Brodeur, a stingy defense and two-way forward play that provided balanced and timely scoring made up a formula that helped the Devils win three Stanley Cups between 1995 and 2003.

headline: His Roots in Italy, de Blasio Now Has Fans There
text: SANT’AGATA DE’ GOTI, Italy — Pictures of Bill de Blasio and his family are plastered on bulletin boards around town. City officials will soon anoint him an honorary citizen. A sponge cake, filled with hazelnut and white chocolate, has been named in his honor.

headline: No Charges Against Cabby in Crash Injuring Tourist
text: No charges will be filed against the cabdriver who crashed onto a pedestrian plaza in Midtown Manhattan in August and pinned a British tourist, severing her left leg just below the knee, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Top Givers to the Philippines, and China
text: After criticism of China’s initial offer of a $100,000 cash donation, the country beefed up its contribution to the Philippines.

headline: Verizon to Pay City for Cost Overruns
text: Verizon has agreed to pay New York City at least $50 million because of software cost overruns associated with the city’s 911 system, city officials said on Thursday.

headline: De Blasio’s International Booster
text: More than a century after Giovanni de Blasio left Sant’Agata de’ Goti, in Italy, for America, residents there are celebrating the election of his grandson, Bill, as the next mayor of New York.

headline: In Myanmar, Retracing George Orwell’s Steps
text: In Myanmar, a long-isolated nation now opening up to the world after decades of brutal military rule, one still finds romantic echoes of the former British colony that inspired the young author to pen his first novel, ‘Burmese Days.’

headline: The Well-Composed Life of Faye Toogood
text: The designer Faye Toogood finds exceptional beauty in unexpected arrangements of objects, and uses them to create installations for fashion houses — and her own house.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 15, 2013
text: “He made the American dream come true. But he didn’t forget his roots. It’s a message of hope for us all.”

headline: Word of the Day | immutable
text: immutable •\(ˌ)i(m)-ˈmyü-tə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Anthony’s Burst Falls Short in Chaotic Final Moments
text: Over the course of a three-hour slugfest, Carmelo Anthony had done everything he could for the Knicks. He had scored on layups and on turnaround jumpers. He had rebounded and defended. At Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, nobody on the Houston Rockets could stop him. They tried, and they failed.

headline: Xi, in ‘Godfather’ Mold, Looks Assertive and Even Imperial
text: The president of China, Xi Jinping, has admitted to watching “The Godfather,” and this week he proved he could be a shrewd student of one of that film’s themes: the art of amassing and applying power in a small, secretive circle of men.

headline: What’s on Friday
text: 5:45 P.M. (Sho2) OUT OF SIGHT (1998) In this slick noir caper directed by Steven Soderbergh and based on the novel by Elmore Leonard, Jack Foley (George Clooney, above), the most charming bank robber you will ever meet, escapes from prison to join his partner (Ving Rhames) for one last heist: to rob the home of their former prison mate (Albert Brooks). Along the way they cross paths with Karen Sisco (Jennifer Lopez), a federal marshal who becomes caught between attraction and professional responsibility when she and Jack begin to wonder what could happen if only they had different occupations. “The hard-boiled beauty of the cinematography (by Elliot Davis, who has shot three previous Soderbergh films) brings out the story’s own innate color and creates a warmly inviting backdrop for the central star-crossed romance,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “The film’s sleek moodiness and visual sophistication are so effective that there’s even a scene here that makes Detroit look like the most romantic city in the world.”

headline: News Quiz | November 15, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: ‘Hearts Throbbed, Minds Wavered’ as Tendulkar Began Final Match
text: NEW DELHI — Even under ordinary circumstances, India’s newspaper writers are not known for bottling up their emotions. But the last cricket outing of Sachin Tendulkar this week prompted a full meltdown of ecstatic prose, as scribes all over the country tried to capture the final bittersweet moments of a career that has provided one of India’s most satisfying plotlines of the last two decades.

headline: A Computer Academy in France Defies Conventional Wisdom
text: PARIS — In a nation of schools typically christened with sensible acronyms or the names of dead Frenchmen, 42 seems an odd title for an institution of higher learning. But then, Xavier Niel’s new technology academy hardly aims to be conventional.

headline: Beijing Talks Up Economic Reform
text: After a Chinese Communist Party leadership meeting issued its eagerly anticipated communiqué on economic restructuring this week, the first reaction in stock markets appeared to be lamentation and derision. Investors who had waited for bold reforms instead read a turgid set of slogans.

headline: Relief Proceeds Slowly in Philippines, Where a Death Toll Remains Unclear
text: TANAUAN, the Philippines — For Teoderico Canales and her family, survival after Typhoon Haiyan has literally meant living in a pigsty. Their only water comes from a pump next to a small river where many people drowned.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Nov. 15, 2013
text: Reading the sentence in this Editing Practice question aloud can help you place the missing punctuation.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Skateboarding Thrills in New York City
text: In an article from October, “Despite Hazards, Street Skateboarding Thrives,” Winnie Hu writes about skateboard culture in New York City.

headline: French-Iranian Relations
text: The ayatollahs express their dismay over the failed nuclear talks.

headline: What Would You Invent to Make the World a Better Place?
text: An auto mechanic invented a tool to make births safer. He literally dreamed it up one night after watching a YouTube video about how to extract a lost cork from a wine bottle. If all goes well, doctors hope the inexpensive device might save lives — potentially millions of them.

headline: Beauty in the Everyday
text: There is something so poignant about Saul Leiter’s work that looking at it can feel like taking a dart to the heart. Drenched in luxuriant, saturated colors, the images instantly transport the viewer into the photographer’s shoes: peeping from beneath an awning to a snow-swept street, or through a befogged cafe window, weeping with condensation, to a man taking pause on a wintry sidewalk. Intimate and empathetic, Mr. Leiter’s photographs relay what all New Yorkers know about their roaring, daunting home: that life in the city is filled with stolen glimpses and fleeting, quietly personal and often gorgeous moments.

headline: Albania Won’t Aid in Destruction of Syria’s Chemical Arms
text: GENEVA — The international chemical weapons watchdog agency approved a plan for the elimination of Syria’s chemical arms on Friday that calls for most of the arsenal to be destroyed outside the country, despite another refusal by one of the countries approached to help with the disposal.

headline: Chinese Youth Sues Over Alleged Police Torture
text: When the police detained Yang Zhong, 16, for the crime of “spreading online rumors” after he raised questions on his Sina Weibo account about the mysterious death of a local karaoke club manager, they took him to their headquarters in Zhangjiachuan, in the northwestern province of Gansu.

headline: In Economic Review, Italy and Spain Get Warnings on Debt and Deficit
text: BRUSSELS — The top European economics official warned Italy and Spain on Friday that they risked missing important debt and deficit targets in the first such review of national budget plans for 13 countries in the euro zone.

headline: New York Today: Hey, Mr. Mayor-Elect
text: Updated 12:29 p.m. | An unusual structure has gone up on Canal Street in Manhattan.

headline: Week 11 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Chiefs (9-0) at Broncos (8-1)

headline: Japan Backs Off From Emissions Targets, Citing Fukushima Disaster
text: TOKYO — Japan took a major step back on Friday from earlier pledges to slash its greenhouse gas emissions, saying a shutdown of its nuclear power plants in the wake of the Fukushima disaster had made previous targets unattainable. The announcement cast a shadow over international talks underway in Warsaw aimed at fashioning a new global pact to address the threats of a changing climate.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Scanning of Books for Search Upheld by Court
text: Google’s idea to scan millions of books and make them searchable online seemed audacious when it was announced in 2004. But fast-forward to today, when people expect to find almost anything they want online, and the plan seems like an unsurprising and unavoidable part of today’s Internet, Claire Cain Miller and Julie Bosman report.

headline: Why Doctors Don’t Take Sick Days
text: THE bottle of Maalox sat perched on the triage desk in the emergency room. It was mint flavor, or maybe lemon — I don’t recall exactly — but it shimmered temptingly. I had just finished with a new admission, and my stomach had been groaning ominously for hours. It was after midnight, the whole night was still ahead of me, and I was getting desperate. I scribbled the last of my medication orders and snagged the Maalox bottle, popping the top and chugging two revolting capfuls on my way to the elevator.

headline: The Banality of Robbing the Jews
text: PARIS — The recent discovery of more than 1,400 prized paintings in the Munich residence of Cornelius Gurlitt, an art collector whose father collaborated with the Nazis, has brought the pillage of the Jews back into the limelight. Yet the bulk of anti-Semitic looting during World War II was at once much more banal and more widespread.

headline: Berkshire Buys $3.45 Billion Stake in Exxon Mobil
text: LONDON — Berkshire Hathaway took a stake valued at $3.45 billion in Exxon Mobil in the third quarter, the latest major addition to the portfolio controlled by the legendary value investor Warren E. Buffett, according to a regulatory filing late Thursday.

headline: Obama Health Care Fixes Give Small Businesses Time to Assess
text: For small businesses grappling with how the Affordable Care Act would affect their health insurance plans, the announcement on Thursday from the White House, delaying the transition to new rules by as much as two years, may come as welcome relief.

headline: Chill Out, 1 Percenters
text: IT’S not full-blown panic yet, but a discernible angst is descending over New York City’s affluent residents, who are worried about the coming mayoralty of Bill de Blasio.

headline: China to Ease Longtime Policy of 1-Child Limit
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government will ease its one-child family restrictions and abolish “re-education through labor” camps, significantly curtailing two policies that for decades have defined the state’s power to control citizens’ lives, the Communist Party said Friday.

headline: There’s Life in AMC’s ‘Hell on Wheels,’ Even After Move to Saturday
text: Apparently, cable drama can survive outside Sunday night: AMC announced Thursday that it had ordered a new season of its cowboy drama “Hell on Wheels,” which was moved to Saturday nights this season.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Ratings of Four Big Banks
text: LONDON — The rating agency Moody’s lowered its credit ratings late Thursday for four major United States banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, reflecting a belief that the institutions would not receive the same level of government support in another financial meltdown.

headline: Currency Trades Draw U.S. Scrutiny
text: U.S. INVESTIGATES CURRENCY TRADES BY BIG BANKS  |  Federal investigators suspect that a group of traders at some of the world’s biggest banks shared a mission to alter the price of foreign currencies, the largest and yet least regulated market in the financial world, Ben Protess, Landon Thomas Jr. and Chad Bray report in DealBook. “Much like companies that rigged the price of vitamins and animal feed, the traders were competitors that hatched alliances for their own profits, federal investigators suspect.”

headline: What Makes a Martyr?
text: LONDON — Because they die fighting in defense of Islam, they are guaranteed a place in heaven. Most major roads, hospitals and bridges in Pakistan are named after them. They are the martyrs, or shaheed.

headline: Yellen Impresses, but Fed’s Powers Are Finite
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Choosing a Life Built Just for Two
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Roche Bobois’s Jean Cocteau Tray
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: After the Fun Is Over
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Finns Pitch Frightful Weather as a Competitive Advantage
text: HELSINKI – In Europe’s crowded technology scene, cities are eager to differentiate themselves from local rivals.

headline: Jos. A. Bank Ends Its Offer for Men’s Wearhouse
text: Jos. A. Bank said on Friday that it had withdrawn its $2.3 billion takeover bid for Men’s Wearhouse after failing to entice the company into merger talks ahead of a Thursday deadline.

headline: In Performance: Samuel Barnett
text: Samuel Barnett performs a scene as Viola from “Twelfth Night,” now on Broadway at the Belasco Theater.

headline: In His Likely Final Innings, Tendulkar Does Not Disappoint
text: MUMBAI — In what is likely to be his final innings in cricket, the Indian star Sachin Tendulkar didn’t disappoint his 33,000 screaming fans at Wankhede Stadium on Friday as he scored 74 runs in the first innings of his last test match, helping his team recover from a potentially tricky position after the loss of two early wickets.

headline: China’s Economic Plans ‘Ambitious,’ U.S. Treasury Secretary Says
text: BEIJING — Treasury Secretary, Jacob J. Lew, described China’s declaration that market competition should have a decisive role in the country’s economy as an “ambitious reform agenda,” according to remarks on Friday by the secretary to the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: Protecting a Painter’s Tattered Legacy
text: Scholars are fighting to revive the work of the Mexican artist José Clemente Orozco.

headline: Mexico’s Not-So-Favorite Son
text: GUADALAJARA, MEXICO — For years, the rains came and the mural buckled. Near the edges of the colorful illustrated dome inside the Jalisco state legislature here, paint faded and fell from the last mural José Clemente Orozco completed before he died.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Nebraska,’ ‘The Great Beauty’ and ‘Faust’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on Alexander Payne’s bittersweet comedy “Nebraska,” Paolo Sorrentino’s “The Great Beauty” and Alexander Sokurov’s version of “Faust.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: How to Explain That Lost Job
text: My 27-year-old daughter was fired from a job under confusing circumstances. She had been hired as a project coordinator for a construction management firm. Although she had no background in the field, the company was aware of this and willing to train her. She had a rocky start with a project manager but then was reassigned and had an excellent working relationship with her new manager. At a review she was told, “This job will be yours in a year unless you choose to leave.” Six weeks later, she was terminated, and told she lacked the necessary “skill set.” The project manager she had worked with took a new job elsewhere shortly thereafter. In all, my daughter was there 10 months.

headline: Around the World, Inflation Is Falling to Levels Not Seen for Years
text: AMERICAN inflation, which has seemed to some conservative economists to be an impending threat ever since the Federal Reserve began to buy large quantities of government securities, appears to be falling to levels lower than any seen in recent years. There are similar declines in many European countries.

headline: Off the Charts: Quiet Inflation
text: In the United States, inflation as measured by the personal consumption expenditures deflator has fallen to under 1 percent.

headline: On a Mission, Armed With Paint
text: A group of graffiti artists bomb for peace in their own way.

headline: In Performance: Samuel Barnett
text: In the new all-male production of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night,” now on Broaway, the actor Samuel Barnett plays Viola, a young woman who disguises herself as a man, Cesario, in order to win the heart of Olivia, a countess, on behalf of Orsino, the man Viola is in servce to (and who Viola secretly loves.)

headline: Postal Service Reports Improved $5 Billion Loss
text: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Friday reported a $5 billion net loss for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, a significant improvement over last year, when the agency reported a record $15.9 billion loss.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
text: In Myanmar, a long-isolated nation now opening up to the world after decades of brutal military rule, one still finds romantic echoes of the former British colony that inspired the young author to pen his first novel, ‘Burmese Days.’

headline: Skills Practice | Making Arguments Through Art
text: The New York Times regularly commissions artists and cartoonists to create work to accompany Opinion pieces. How do illustrations like the one above add meaning to a text, while grabbing readers’ attention at the same time? What can students infer about the argument being made in an Op-Ed article by looking at the illustration alone?

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s ‘Bully Pulpit’
text: This week, Doris Kearns Goodwin discusses “The Bully Pulpit”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; N. Gregory Mankiw talks about Alan Greenspan’s “Map and the Territory”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: House Approves Bill That Allows Policy Renewals
text: WASHINGTON — Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House approved legislation on Friday that would allow insurance companies to renew individual health insurance policies and sell similar ones to new customers next year even if the coverage does not provide all the benefits and consumer protections required by the new health care law.

headline: The Comedy Pioneer in the Floppy Hat
text: With her toothless grin, floppy hat and tell-it-like-it-is persona, Moms Mabley may be one of the most influential comedians you don’t know. She rose to fame in the early decades of the 20th century on the chitlins circuit — the collection of stages around the country that employed black entertainers during segregation — and she would go on to a career that spanned more than 50 years. In that time, she pushed beyond racial and gender barriers, but she drew mainstream attention only starting in the 196os (she died in 1975) and little of her work has survived on film or video. That hasn’t deterred Whoopi Goldberg.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s ‘Bully Pulpit’
text: This week, Doris Kearns Goodwin and N. Gregory Mankiw.

headline: Hotel as Personal Trainer
text: As the holiday season approaches, helping guests keep up regular exercise and a balanced diet is a priority for a number of hotels.

headline: Letters: The Tech Issue
text: Special Tech Issue

headline: What Obamacare Needs Now …
text: … is not at all the same as what freaking-out Congressional Democrats think they need politically, and what the president tried to provide to them yesterday. That’s because all of the “if you like your plan, you keep your plan” ideas in the wind right now, including the White House’s pledge yesterday to allow/pressure insurers to temporarily extend plans that don’t meet the new law’s specifications, are likely to either do nothing meaningful at all to halt the flood of cancellations, or else exacerbate the threat to Obamacare’s viability that the busted website has created, by siphoning off precisely the healthy, lower-risk enrollees the new system needs to be sustainable.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Believer
text: This slender, charming book must be approached with a special tact. To read it feels a little like an intrusion on inwardness itself. The volume contains, alongside a lightly corrected transcription, a facsimile of the Sterling notebook in which Flannery O’Connor, just 20 years old, began a journal addressed to God. Written in her neat hand, it is reproduced complete with the empty final pages (her concluding words are “there is nothing left to say of me”) and not omitting a bit of musical notation floating on the inside of the back cover. The prayers, attempts at prayer and meditations on faith and art contained in it were written in 1946 and 1947, while O’Connor was a student in Iowa. The brilliance that would make her fictions literary classics is fully apparent in them.

headline: G.E. Announces Plans to Take Retail Finance Unit Public
text: General Electric formally disclosed its plans to hold an initial public offering of its North American retail finance unit on Friday, as part of an effort to shrink its enormous finance arm.

headline: Uncommon Prayers
text: Flannery O’Connor always stood out among 20th-century writers for her spiritual questing, more reminiscent of Kierkegaard and Dostoyevsky than of her peers. The discovery of a prayer journal she kept in her early 20s only reinforces her apartness. (Marilynne Robinson reviews “A Prayer Journal” this week.)

headline: Jewish Identities
text: JEWS IN GOTHAM  New York Jews in a Changing City, 1920–2010  By Jeffrey S. Gurock  New York University Press, $45.

headline: Paperback Row
text: WHY READ MOBY-DICK?,  by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Penguin, $13.) Philbrick, whose “In the Heart of the Sea: The Tragedy of the Whaleship Essex” recounted the real-life inspiration for Herman Melville’s shipwreck, now gives readers an enthusiastic shove toward the “one book that deserves to be called our American bible.” He broaches the novel thematically, with compact, often quirky essays on topics like landlessness, sharks and chowder.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE LUMINARIES,  by Eleanor Catton. (Little, Brown, $27.) In her Booker Prize winner, a love story and mystery set in New Zealand, Catton has built a lively parody of a 19th-century novel, while creating something utterly new for the 21st.

headline: Twists of Faith
text: In “Hunger of Memory,” the 1982 book that made him one of the most prominent Hispanic essayists in America, Richard Rodriguez wrote: “I wanted to forget that I had a body because I had a brown body.” In “Darling,” his new essay collection, he claims this body in all its difficulties. “Flesh is a complicated medium for grace,” he writes, exploring the importance of physical bodies in a digital era, the importance of brownness (“Brown has always been the sum of our breathing and eating and moving about”) as well as the importance of complication itself — the possibilities embedded in resistance, those experiences of refusal that shape our intimacies and our yearnings.

headline: Riddle Wrapped in a Mystery
text: It’s a spooky feeling, if you’re a translator who loves bicycling and word games and likes traveling to Russia, to open a book and encounter, in the very first chapter, a translating, cycling crossword fanatic who is plucked from a Kaliningrad beach by a homburg-hatted butcher, hurled into a carcass-strewn meat van and never heard from again. (Note to self: Avoid Kaliningrad.) At the time he was nabbed, the translator was carrying a notebook he’d used at a session of multilingual, high-stakes business negotiations. His abductor, flipping through the pages, was infuriated to find them filled with illegible doodles — stars, bugs, cats and spirals — the translator’s own private code. “Let the birds read it,” the butcher declared, flinging the notebook into the wind. Local children later found it in the sea grass.

headline: Compulsive Behavior
text: If folklorists are to be believed, the postnuptial tradition obliging the bridegroom to carry his bride over the threshold of their first home has less to do with ensuring the couple’s good luck and more to do with maintaining the bride’s good name. Apparently the custom spread from ancient Rome throughout medieval Europe as a politically fraught pantomime of chastity’s death at the marriage altar: The new wife, presumably reluctant to relinquish her virginity, had to be physically transported into her new matrimonial setting by her impatient husband.

headline: Running Battles
text: It’s a rare memoir that begins by telling you it’s been told several times before, but that’s the case with “The Death of Santini.” The very title of Pat Conroy’s latest book, alluding to his novel “The Great Santini,” affirms that the abusive fighter pilot at the center of that story and the father mourned here are essentially one and the same. To dispel any lingering doubt, Conroy announces at the outset that the fictions he has spun over his long, celebrated literary career aren’t really fictions. They’re diamonds hauled up to earth and into the light of day from the dark and bottomless mine of his Southern clan: the tyrannical patriarch, the wounded matriarch, their seven self-destructive sons and daughters. We’ve met their alter egos and avatars, those of us who’ve supped contentedly on Conroy’s big-flavored prose through the years. In “The Death of Santini,” he more or less acknowledges that we’ll simply be reintroduced to them by their real names.

headline: Weight Loss Surgery Raises Some Pregnancy Risks
text: Women who have undergone bariatric surgery are more likely to deliver premature babies and those with low birth weight, a large new study shows.

headline: On the Market in Miami
text: Properties include a waterfront contemporary; a Mediterranean revival; a downtown condo; an oceanfront condo; and a waterfront Mediterranean.

headline: Without a Trace
text: There are plenty of women among the ranks of genre authors, but not many like Sara Paretsky, whose intellectually lively mysteries featuring her gutsy Chicago private eye, V. I. Warshawski, are fired by political causes and feminist social issues. Her latest, CRITICAL MASS (Putnam, $26.95), hits a nerve with its historical back story about a Viennese atomic physicist named Martina Saginor, “a great scientist who had a gender handicap” and disappeared during World War II — a character inspired by the brilliant but unsung Austrian physicist Marietta Blau.

headline: Close Calls
text: “Never been there myself,” a bartender tells a customer looking for exotic sex in Russell Banks’s incisive new collection of stories, “A Permanent Member of the Family.” “But I’ve heard no matter what you’re into you can find it behind the Green Door.”

headline: Battle-Shocked
text: It’s no surprise Dennis McFarland chose the Battle of the Wilderness as the contextual scaffolding for his searing, poetic and often masterly new Civil War novel, “Nostalgia.” The intense three-day campaign, fought in Northern Virginia in May 1864, was the first showdown between the armies of Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee, and the casualties on both sides were staggering. It marked the beginning of Grant’s Overland Campaign, a strategy that eventually led to the sieges of Petersburg and Richmond and the defeat of the Confederacy. Yet details of the battle remain as shrouded as the thick forests in which it occurred. There were few brilliant maneuvers, few heroes remembered by history, and no clear winner. What a perfect setting, then, for a novel exploring the chaos of war and the confounding disorientation of its aftermath.

headline: Crushing Tons of Ivory, Wildlife Service Sends Signal to Smugglers
text: Updated below, 11:39 a.m. | The United States Fish and Wildlife Service on Thursday dropped six tons of confiscated ivory tusks and trinkets into a rock crusher near Denver, turning contraband that officials estimated was worth tens of millions of dollars into rubble.

headline: Upper Atmospherics
text: “The fact is, we are much more afraid of life than our ancestors,” Robert Louis Stevenson is heard remarking in “Footsteps” (1985), Richard Holmes’s sideways memoir of the “adventures of a Romantic biographer.” This feeling that the present is a time less adventurous in spirit than the past runs through Holmes’s vast body of work; in “Falling Upwards,” about balloonists and ballooning, it rises and spreads like a jet of fire-heated helium, making the new book at once lighter than Holmes’s other books and harder to read straight through.

headline: Inside the List
text: Now and Then: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s book “The Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4. One key to Goodwin’s popularity as a historian has been her ability to spot overlaps between contemporary politics and the distant past — or even to create those overlaps herself, through the strength of her storytelling; when Barack Obama tapped his primary opponents Joe Biden and Hillary Clinton for important posts in his administration, he cited Goodwin’s account of Lincoln’s cabinet, “Team of Rivals,” as one influence.

headline: Strong Proof
text: At a party for Ms. magazine’s 40th birthday, the Canadian writer Ann Dowsett Johnston waited for an audience with Gloria Steinem, hoping to cull wisdom for her research on women and alcohol. “Alcohol?” Steinem said to Johnston, looking “dismissive.” “Alcohol is not a women’s issue.”

headline: People of the Book
text: Divining a man’s beliefs from the books in his library is a perilous business. And when that man happens to be Thomas Jefferson, it’s like trying to staple vinaigrette to the ceiling. The third president, an omnivorous bibliophile, owned perhaps as many as 10,000 titles. He also was a reticent man of infinite contradictions, as well as a cunning politician. Could any one of this Delphic founder’s many books account for his most enduring contributions to liberal democracy? The answer, it seems, is yes.

headline: Blood Debt
text: Robert Stone, lapidary in his prose, is continent also in his output. Graham Greene is in some ways his most natural antecedent, but Stone has produced far fewer books. Almost all are memorable: “Dog Soldiers,” “A Flag for Sunrise,” “Outerbridge Reach,” “Damascus Gate.” He tackles a genre — frequently the thriller but, in the case of his latest book, the campus novel — and twists it to his purposes in ways that surprise and provoke. A subtle writer, he demands an attentive reader as he explores, through superficially familiar narratives, substantial themes.

headline: New York Observer
text: To enter the world of this wonderful memoir is to leave the dull certainties of home and go wandering. The author’s destination is always the great wide world Out There, and through his sharp, compact prose, Roger Rosenblatt takes the reader with him. He is, after all, what some 19th-century Parisians called a flâneur, a stroller sauntering through anonymous crowds in the noisy, greedy, unscripted panoramas of the city.

headline: Who Made That Redskins Logo?
text: When the newly formed Boston Redskins traveled to Chicago’s Soldier Field to play the Bears on Oct. 1, 1933, the visiting players were barely recognizable. The owner, George Preston Marshall, ordered team members to smear themselves with face paint before going out onto the field. His was the first pro-sports team to co-opt an American Indian identity with such fervor: The Redskins’ halftime band marched in tribal regalia; the coach wore feathers on the sideline; and Marshall had an Indian-head logo printed across the center of their uniforms.

headline: Today in Small Business: Health Care Fixes
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Road Trip in Western China
text: From Kashgar to Tashkurgan in the southern crescent of Xinjiang.

headline: Let Go of the College Essay, and Let Your Teenager Speak for Herself
text: Recently I told the story in the Wall Street Journal of a father who offered me, an independent college applications counselor, a $10,000 check to write his son’s college essays. Never mind that his son was standing right there. I didn’t take the check. Instead I took the boy: We fled his father’s Midtown Manhattan office and went for a walk, along sidewalks crowded with people who had gone to Ivy League colleges, non-Ivy League colleges and no colleges at all, to the park, where we could really talk.

headline: In Our Pages: November 16
text: 1888 Chamberlain’s Wedding

headline: A Few Tips on Trident Management
text: Before it was announced who would play the muscly, green-eyed, trident-wielding Finnick Odair in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire,” the second installment of the film adaptation of Suzanne Collins’s post-apocalyptic trilogy, fans made it clear that picking the right actor was serious business. (“One Does Not Joke About Finnick’s Casting” was the title of one of many obsessed Tumblr pages.) Sam Claflin, 27, won the part, which still seems to be sinking in for this classically trained British actor. Pre-Finnick, his biggest credits were minor roles in “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” and “Snow White and the Huntsman.” Now he has a more central role in a thriving power franchise. When he’s done promoting “Catching Fire,” he’ll begin shooting “Mockingjay,” the final chapter of the “Hunger Games” series, which is being split into two parts.

headline: Taking the High Road
text: For a few disconcerting moments, the gridlock that ensnared our minivan on the highway linking China to Pakistan sent my mind reeling to the countless hours I’d wasted on Beijing’s perpetually congested, smog-choked ring roads.

headline: Conductor’s Prize Goes to Jeffrey Milarsky
text: The Ditson Conductor’s Award, a prize for distinguished contributions to American music, given annually by Columbia University, will be presented to the conductor and percussionist Jeffrey Milarsky at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, during a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra that Mr. Milarsky is conducting. The $5,000 award, which was established in 1945, will be presented by the pianist Gilbert Kalish, the head of the Ditson advisory committee.

headline: High Schoolers Against the Redskin Name
text: Such mainline media as Slate and Mother Jones have stopped using the name of Washington’s professional football team, finding “Redskins” a racist slur for all its rah-rah fondness among hometown fans at kick-off time. No less offended, the editorial board of the student newspaper at Neshaminy High School in Bucks County, Penn., has voted to banish the word from their pages, arguing that it’s time for their own Neshaminy Redskins (10-and-1 and a state powerhouses) to be called something less insensitive toward genocidal history. “The word ‘Redskin’ is racist and very much so,” the board explained in its decision to drop the name from editions of The Playwickian. “It is not a term of honor, but a term of hate.”

headline: Submit Your Real Estate Questions
text: Got an upstairs neighbor who thinks there’s nothing wrong with coming home at 3 a.m. and hurling her three-inch heels across the uncarpeted hardwood floor? Or maybe you’re wondering if your co-op can really just decide to ban pets and tell you to find a new home for your 55-pound bulldog. Or you want to know what to do about the next-door neighbor who installed an eight-foot fence that you’re certain has veered into your backyard.

headline: Vivien Leigh, Before Tara Called
text: David O. Selznick’s much-publicized search for the star of “Gone With the Wind” culminated in early 1939 when he presented to the world one Vivien Leigh.

headline: N.Y. State Comptroller Invests in Lerer-Backed Tech Company
text: The New York State comptroller’s office said on Friday that it had invested in a website backed by Kenneth Lerer, the veteran venture capitalist, as it continues to support homegrown technology companies.

headline: Out of Economic Chaos, an Indie Spirit Is Forged
text: Konstantinos Kontovrakis was a programmer for the Thessaloniki Film Festival until 2009, when he quit to become a film producer. Unfortunately, that was the year “the whole mess started,” as Mr. Kontovrakis put it. He meant the Greek economic crisis that continues to send shivers through the global economy. “Since then, I haven’t made a lot of money.”

headline: Murder Charge in a Shooting on Doorstep
text: DETROIT — After a two-week investigation, the prosecutor here charged a white suburban homeowner on Friday with second-degree murder in the killing of an unarmed young black woman. The prosecutor rejected the man’s assertion that he had been acting in self-defense when he opened his front door and fired a shotgun at the woman through a locked screen door, striking her in the face.

headline: A Daring Film, Silenced No More
text: LOS ANGELES — The dark tale begins with a concert violinist infatuated with a young student and ends with blackmail and suicide. In between there are visits to bars and brothels, brawls in swanky digs, creepy shakedowns and a cameo by Oscar Wilde. It sounds like a slightly experimental indie project. In reality, the movie, “Different From the Others,” opened in the summer of 1919 to sold-out houses across Germany.

headline: 36 Hours in Chianti, Italy
text: There’s made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture and contemporary art worth a detour.

headline: Volkswagen Announces Global Recall of 2.6 Million Vehicles
text: Volkswagen will recall about 62,000 Tiguan sport utility vehicles from the 2009-11 model years because they can lose exterior lighting, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The action is part of a worldwide 2.6 million vehicle recall for lighting and transmission problems, Volkswagen announced Thursday morning in Germany.

headline: Coach’s Career: Heights to Depths, and Everything in Between
text: ATLANTA — The zigzag of a chart tracking the career of a typical football coaching lifer tends to mirror the charts that record the long-term performance of the stock market. For the coach, the line’s overall ascent is periodically interrupted by a flat line or a downturn, reflecting the inevitable firing or nonrenewal of a contract.

headline: Sizing Up the Better Business Bureau, and Its Rivals on the Internet
text: OVER the years, when writing about subjects as varied as driving schools and air duct cleaners, I’ve given the seemingly benign advice to check out companies with the Better Business Bureau.

headline: Footage of Death Plays On in Memory
text: Before Nov. 22, 1963, Abraham Zapruder was an ordinary citizen of Dallas: a 58-year-old prosperous manufacturer of women’s clothing who had arrived in the city from Russia by way of Brooklyn. If that day had unfolded differently, that is most likely what he would have remained. But like a small but growing number of Americans at the time, he was also a home-movie hobbyist. With his receptionist, Marilyn Sitzman, as location scout and technical support, Zapruder took his 414PD Director Series Bell and Howell 8-millimeter camera to a spot on Elm Street, not far from his office, hoping to film the presidential motorcade as it drove past.

headline: 36 Hours in Chianti, Italy
text: Stretching between Florence and Siena in the heart of Tuscany, the Chianti wine region is the romanticized Italy of daydreams: terra-cotta-roofed towns, wine-soaked dinners and vineyards stitching sun-dappled hillsides. But hidden amid Chianti’s winding roads and rolling hills are some surprisingly modern attractions. There’s made-to-measure fashion, new standout architecture, and contemporary art worth a detour. Certainly, there are copious amounts of red wine waiting to be drunk, but don’t expect kitschy straw-wrapped bottles or pizza-parlor reds. Today Chianti vintners are producing excellent, nuanced wines that are worthy of these scenic surroundings.

headline: Streaming and Cable Deal for ‘The Simpsons’
text: In one of television’s biggest syndication deals, “The Simpsons,” the longest-running scripted show in TV history, will finally be moving to cable television — and, not too surprisingly, it is staying in the family.

headline: Movie Review: 'Nebraska'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Nebraska."

headline: Jury Finds Pipe Maker Defrauded Governments
text: A federal jury in California found on Thursday that the nation’s largest maker of plastic pipe defrauded states and municipalities over a decade by knowingly selling them defective pipe for use in their drinking water, firefighting, irrigation and other essential public systems.

headline: Movie Review: 'Faust'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews the movie "Faust."

headline: Movie Review: 'The Great Beauty'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews the movie "The Great Beauty."

headline: Kelly Attacks Mayoral Candidates for Criticizing Police Dept.
text: New York City’s police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said he “resented” the way the Democratic candidates for mayor criticized him and the Police Department while they were campaigning, according to an interview in Playboy magazine that was released this week.

headline: How Do You Teach Kids to Eat Well When You’re Not With Them?
text: “You are what you eat, from your head down to your feet!” Growing up in the 1970s, I had the benefit of having “Time for Timer’s” advice on healthy eating drummed into me weekly during Saturday morning cartoon binges. I may endlessly “hanker for a hunka, a slab, a slice, a chunka” cheese, but I also knew that no kid could survive on sugar alone, because “all those motors in your body need a lot of fuel to go on,” like a healthy breakfast and a balanced snack.

headline: Photography Fair Arrives in Paris
text: PARIS — If light is the key ingredient of photography, there was no lack of it at the Paris Photo preview earlier this week. The 17th edition of the annual photography fair, which runs through Sunday under the dome of the Grand Palais, includes 136 international galleries from 24 countries.

headline: ValueVision Rejects Demands From Activist Investor
text: ValueVision, the Internet and television shopping network, has rebuffed demands from the activist investor Clinton Group to overhaul its board, saying that the investor has no legal basis to make those demands.

headline: Traveling to Find Your Roots
text: It was lunchtime at the Outlaws’ Shack in Poiana Brasov, a mountain resort in Transylvania, and we were washing down chunks of kashkaval cheese and peasant bread with sips of tsuica, a Romanian plum brandy. At a neighboring table, a man picked up a red onion and bit into it as if it were an apple — something I had seen only my father do.

headline: Image of the Day: November 15
text: Golfer Gaganjeet Bhullar in action at the Australian Masters golf tournament in Melbourne.

headline: And the Crowd Goes ... Well, You Know
text: Lady Gaga’s strategy at the new H&M Times Square store: to inject her wayward artistry into a staunchly corporate setting.

headline: Lady Gaga Drops In at H&M and the Crowd Goes ... Well, You Know
text: LADY GAGA’S ARRIVAL on Wednesday night atop a pink Skyline sightseeing bus was cheeky, all right. Fanning out her waist-length hair and wearing a paint-streaked H&M cat suit, she worked the public like a flaxen Cleopatra waving from her barge.

headline: The Gun Report: November 15, 2013
text: * The first 3D-printed gun, the “Liberator .380,” the design of which is widely available online, could emerge as a national security threat when a law banning undetectable firearms expires next month. The Undetectable Firearms Act, first passed in 1988, requires guns to have enough steel to set off a metal detector, but the Liberator uses only the smallest bits of metal for ammunition and a firing pin the size of a roofing nail. Some senators have proposed an updated version of the bill that would ban the design, manufacture, sale, import, export and possession of the plastic guns. The blueprint for the Liberator .380 has been downloaded 100,000 times since it was designed last year. “The fact that anyone with the right equipment can make a fully-functioning weapon from their own home with the click of a mouse is a truly frightening concept,” Sen. Bill Nelson said in a statement.

headline: Restaurant Report: State-Run Food Shop No. 37 in Hanoi
text: The dining scene in Hanoi has flourished in recent years. Travelers can feast on international fare like sushi and tapas, as well as on innovative takes on Vietnamese cuisine. But this tiny restaurant, which opened in the fall of 2012, evokes a simpler time: the decade starting in 1976, when the state controlled the economy so tightly that restaurants were barred from having names, and privately owned businesses were illegal.

headline: Love in the Time Before the Internet
text: It’s been noted that in the age of cellphones, the romance between Romeo and Juliet would not end in tragedy. But add the Internet to the plot of “The Most Happy Fella,” and the romance never happens. An immigrant farmer might still be captivated by a young, pretty hash-house waitress on his visit to San Francisco. He might still leave a piece of jewelry — although it wouldn’t be a tie pin — as a tip, along with a charmingly effusive love note.

headline: A Road Trip Through Alexander Payne’s Nebraska
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Air Pollution as a Heart Threat
text: Bit by bit over the past few decades, scientists have been building a new understanding of the ways that air pollution threatens human health. Much of their attention has been focused on lung diseases, including cancers. With good reason, it turns out: just last month, the World Health Organization declared air pollution to be one of the planet’s most dangerous environmental carcinogens.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Doris Kearns Goodwin’s ‘Bully Pulpit’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Bill Keller reviews Doris Kearns Goodwin’s “Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism.” Mr. Keller writes:

headline: The Impossible Refugee Boat Lift to Christmas Island
text: By LUKE MOGELSONMore than a thousand refugees have died trying to reach Christmas Island. But faced with unbearable conditions at home, they keep coming.Photographs by JOEL VAN HOUDT

headline: Exclusive | 18 East 74th Street
text: An opulent seven-story Neo-Renaissance-style mansion built in 1871 is about to enter the market at $34 million.

headline: Upper East Side Mansion, Ornate, Yet Cozy
text: An extravagantly appointed Upper East Side mansion that recalls the gravitas and gilding — if not quite the square footage — of Highclere Castle, which became a character in its own right on the PBS series “Downton Abbey,” is poised to enter the market at $34 million.

headline: Deflating Tesco’s Blow-Up Friend
text: A-Rod reality TV; rejected baby names; Bellamy Young’s leonine streak.

headline: Window Displays of Affection
text: Over the three days that followed the assassination of John F. Kennedy 50 years ago, 250,000 people viewed his flag-draped coffin in the Capitol Rotunda; dignitaries from more than 100 countries visited Washington to attend the funeral, procession and burial service at Arlington National Cemetery. On the eve of Kennedy’s burial, Dan Budnik, a photographer for Magnum at the time, was walking around downtown Washington and taking note of the framed portraits of the president that had been placed in store windows, often incongruously among office furniture or mannequins. “People were trying to figure out how to honor the fallen president,” says Budnik, who is now 80. “They incorporated the tragedy. I was just taken by the aspect of turning commercial into memorial. I was very moved by the individual gestures.” ﻿Julie Bosman

headline: Window Displays of Affection
text: Impromptu memorials to J.F.K.

headline: The 11.3.13 Issue
text: BROCCOLI’S EXTREME MAKEOVER

headline: What Cynthia Ozick Taught Me About My Grandfather
text: Cynthia Ozick and I have long differed on the name of my grandfather. Every decade or so, we run into each other at some New York gathering, and after exchanging pleasantries, I say, again, that the first name of my paternal grandfather, an immigrant from Ukraine, was Kusel (pronounced k’SEEL.) She informs me, once more, that it was Yekutiel, a name I’d never heard before I met her. Our discussions have always been cordial. Considering the fact that she is someone who is celebrated for her erudite essays as well as for her novels, she has been admirably free of condescension. I would compare the tone of our disagreement to a respectful difference in interpretation by two scholars — or maybe between one scholar and another person.

headline: Put Me in, Coach — I’m Ready to Pay
text: My granddaughter is being asked to pay more than $2,000 to be on a traveling sports team. The coach of her high-school team, who also coaches the unaffiliated traveling team, is asking for the payment as a condition of my granddaughter’s participation on the regular high-school squad. Is this unethical behavior by the coach? Is it proper for the person paying the fee (me) to bring this issue to the attention of the school system? How do I avoid retribution by the coach against my granddaughter? CHET M., ORINDA, CALIF.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Milwaukee; Jasper, Alberta; California
text: Exposed! Harley-Davidson’s Lost Photographs, 1915-1916, Milwaukee More than 50 black-and-white photographs documenting the early years of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company are on display through Jan. 1, in Milwaukee at the Harley-Davidson Museum. The photos, printed from a collection of more than 400 fragile glass-plate negatives, provide a glimpse back nearly 100 years ago and include employee portraits, depictions of the company’s 1916 racing team and images used for marketing.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Reports Increased Traffic Deaths
text: More people died on United States roads in 2012 than in 2011, according to a report from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Motorcyclist and pedestrian deaths each increased for the third year in a row, and deaths of bicyclists reached the highest level in six years. Over all, however, traffic deaths continue to be at historic lows.

headline: Gut-Wrenching
text: A woman suffers bouts of extreme abdominal pain that come and go and come again.

headline: Analyzing Obama on Health Care in The Times
text: It didn’t take long for Michael Shear’s news analysis on Friday’s front page to cause what he termed “an email and Twitter explosion” for the White House correspondent.

headline: Printed Books Are Alive and Sometimes Weird
text: The news about books today is often centered on the shift from print to digital, from paper to electronic devices. At the Islip Art Museum, entirely different kinds of transformations are on display, and none of them are electronic.

headline: Above, Below and Around Paris, on Foot
text: We drew a deep breath before entering the tunnel. The garbage strewn around the entrance was about as inviting as the prospect of walking nearly a mile under one of Paris’s most famous parks not knowing what, or whom, to expect. We were in the heart of the city, but completely removed from it.

headline: Facebook Reasserts Posts Can Be Used to Advertise
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If you post something on Facebook, let there be no doubt that it can end up as an ad shown to your friends and acquaintances.

headline: Seeing and Being Seen, Across Millenniums
text: Faces are everywhere at the Katonah Museum of Art. Some gaze boldly across the galleries, cheery, confrontational, sly; others turn aside, pensive and enigmatic. All hold stories of humanity, a gathering of characters, cultures and colors.

headline: Video: ‘Hyperbole,’ Comedy and Angst
text: Allie Brosh’s blog, Hyperbole and a Half, has a devoted following, attracting as many as five million readers a month. Her first post, in July 2009, had no pictures at all, but her drawings have become increasingly prominent. Although they’re somewhat crude, they reflect raw emotion and seamlessly blend comedy and pain. Ms. Brosh tells stories about her childhood, her life in Oregon with her husband and two dogs, and her struggles with depression, which caused a 19-month hiatus from her blog that ended in May.

headline: Forbes Says It Is for Sale
text: Forbes Media, which publishes Forbes magazine and has been making an extensive push into digital media and native advertising, is up for sale, the company confirmed in an email to the staff Friday morning.

headline: On the Path to Personalization: Part 1
text: This is the first in a series of posts exploring the underlying technology of our new recommendations engine. The second post is here.

headline: More Cities Consider Using Eminent Domain to Halt Foreclosures
text: New cities are joining the effort to head off home foreclosures by using a twist on the power of eminent domain, despite threats of financial retaliation from Wall Street and Washington.

headline: Glafkos Clerides, Greek Cypriot Leader Who Sought Unification, Is Dead at 94
text: Glafkos Clerides, the president of Cyprus from 1993 to 2003, who as leader of his nation’s Greek Cypriot majority was a frustrated peacemaker in futile talks with Turkish Cypriots to reunify their long-divided Mediterranean island, died on Friday in Nicosia, the capital. He was 94.

headline: Antidoping Lab’s Flaws Put Olympics in a Bind
text: JOHANNESBURG — Less than three months before the opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics, the antidoping laboratory in Russia charged with conducting drug screenings at those Winter Games has been deemed unreliable and may lose its authority to test Olympic athletes.

headline: Predicting a Fall’s Aftermath
text: For an elderly person, a bad fall can mark the difference between between walking and wheelchair, between living in one’s own home and moving to a nursing home. It can be a life-changing event.

headline: T WINTER TRAVEL
text: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

headline: Baffling About-Face in American-US Airways Merger
text: Did the Justice Department cave?

headline: New Grove Dictionary Broadens Scope on American Music
text: For classical music fans and scholars – and increasingly, for those devoted to other musical genres, including non-Western forms as well as jazz and popular music – the various editions of the Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians have been the principal resource for generations. Originally published in 1878 as a four-volume set, edited by Sir George Grove (but without his name in the title), the Grove took a huge leap with its sixth edition, which was so thoroughly revamped that when it appeared in 1980, “New” was added to the title. The current New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, published in 2001, fills 29 volumes.

headline: Finding Strength in Humility
text: Humility doesn’t get much respect in the corporate world. How often do you hear a leader say publicly, “I’m sorry, I got that wrong,” or, “I didn’t do that very well,” or even something as simple as, “I don’t know.”

headline: General Electric Finally Gets Past the Jack Welch Era
text: General Electric is finally putting the ghost of its former chief executive Jack Welch out to pasture. On Friday, the conglomerate said it intended to spin off its North America retail finance business. That will help return GE Capital to its roots of lending to midmarket companies and its parent’s industrial concerns.

headline: Houseful of Handfuls
text: One Fifth Avenue, the 27-story Art Deco apartment tower built in the late 1920s at the corner of Eighth Street, has a reputation as a Hollywood building. The directors who’ve called it home include Brian De Palma, Paul Mazursky, Ira Sachs and Tim Burton. It’s no wonder that Peter Newman, a film producer and a professor at New York University, and Antonia Dauphin, a casting agent who is about to direct her first feature, are so comfortable there.

headline: In Brooklyn, Friday Night Rites
text: They moved to the beat of a drum in the backyard, flames jumping from a caldron set in a circle drawn in the dirt. One by one they placed pieces of paper into the fire — with words of a burden they wanted to shed — and watched sparks rise into the Brooklyn night sky.

headline: Art Matters | From Matmos, a Musical Libretto Performed by Random Strangers
text: “There’s something suspicious about the work we do,” said Drew Daniel of the Baltimore experimental duo Matmos, “because it has an eerie ability to seem alien.” Daniel and Martin Schmidt, his partner in creativity and in life, are known for pulling sounds from unorthodox sources: squishing organs on operating tables, rats pattering across cages, rose petals being crushed. To create the sounds for their last album, “The Marriage of True Minds,” the duo conducted a Ganzfeld experiment — a parapsychological technique used to test for ESP — on subjects in Baltimore and Oxford, England. Participants were asked to lie on the floor, cover their eyes with Ping-Pong balls and listen to blasting white noise, then describe what they saw in their mind’s eye. “We’ve had some ideas that other people may object to or find a little odd,” Daniel admitted.

headline: Fewer Choices in the Air
text: The merger between American Airlines and US Airways comes after airlines have struggled for decades, cutting costs and slimming down service to turn around a trend of diminishing profits.

headline: Programmers Find New Way to Navigate Health Plans
text: The stumbling rollout of the federally run online health exchange has frustrated tens of thousands of Americans and sent some looking for alternative sources of information on where they can buy health insurance, and what it will cost them, under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Abuse Accusations Overshadow Commonwealth Meeting in Sri Lanka
text: NEW DELHI — Sri Lanka’s president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, tried to pre-empt criticism of his government’s human rights record on Friday as he welcomed leaders of Commonwealth countries to a summit  meeting in the Sri Lankan capital, Colombo, that was overshadowed by persistent allegations of state-sponsored abuse during a long civil war by the Sinhalese-dominated government against ethnic Tamils.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 15, 2013
text: Janet Yellen is poised to become the new head of the Federal Reserve. If she is confirmed by the Senate, she would arguably become the most powerful woman in the U.S. economy, with the power to keep interests rates low, prevent inflation and attack unemployment. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss Yellen’s confirmation hearing, as well as what’s going on at the regional Federal Reserve banks.

headline: Vocal Instructor Commands ‘Enough Nonsense,’ Sing!
text: Maria Zhorella recently turned 98, and if only she would just slow down and give her vocal students a break.

headline: Their Harmony Is Loud and Clear
text: Huai-Bin Mabel Ko is someone who revels in the chance to find beauty in places others would never think to look.

headline: Zulily Surges in Market Debut
text: Updated, 4:15 p.m. | It may not be a globally popular social network or a highly regarded human resources software company. But Zulily is finding plenty of demand from investors all the same.

headline: Bring On the Juggling Act
text: Even before they were married in 1999, Terry Williams and Patrick Cashin had an understanding about who would be their future children’s primary caretaker.

headline: Bill Moyers Will Stay on TV
text: The fans of Bill Moyers spoke, and he listened. Mr. Moyers announced late last month that his public television show “Moyers & Company” would end with the Jan. 3, 2014, program. But on Friday, the program’s executive producer, Judy Doctoroff, told a meeting of public television officials that the program would stay on the air after all, after receiving “thousands of heartfelt and well-written messages saying ‘don’t go.’ ” New funding was also lined up, she said.

headline: The Story of Manhattan’s Rectangular Street Grid
text: Q. When did Manhattan’s rectangular street grid first begin appearing?

headline: Isay Weinfeld Exhibition in TriBeCa
text: Isay Weinfeld, an architect, designer and filmmaker for 40 years, has built a following in his native Brazil. But now his reputation should ripple with the opening of the first show in the United States devoted to his multifaceted career. Called “A to Z,” the exhibition is on view through Dec. 1 at Espasso, a TriBeCa showroom of Brazilian design.

headline: Amazon Bares Its Computers
text: LAS VEGAS — However big and ambitious you think Amazon’s plan to run the world’s computing may be, you should probably think bigger.

headline: Reading, Walking and More Reading for Writer
text: If you are an attentive walker in New York City, any block might open up to you as a story: about the immigrants who once lived there, about the forces that moved them, about the direction of change and the people driving it. Pete Hamill, 78, the journalist and novelist, provided the language for many of those stories. So it is only fitting that for him, Sunday is a day of long walks, starting from the apartment in TriBeCa that he shares with his wife, Fukiko Aoki Hamill, 65, a writer. The paperback edition of his most recent book of short fiction, “The Christmas Kid: And Other Brooklyn Stories,” was published last month.

headline: Hell’s Kitchen Real Estate: Hot
text: Not so long ago, Hell’s Kitchen drowsed in the shadow of nearby Midtown. But now residential projects popping up left and right.

headline: Hell’s Kitchen: Sizzling
text: In the race to develop the West Side of Manhattan, Hell’s Kitchen can seem the tortoise to the Hudson Yards hare. Yet if Hudson Yards suddenly seems to be going up all at once, its neighbor to the north has been moving ahead in slow, deliberate steps, year after year.

headline: U.S. Appears More Open to Finance Discussions in Trade Talks With Europe
text: LONDON — American negotiators appear to be softening their resolve to keep financial services out of trans-Atlantic trade talks with the European Union.

headline: Big Ticket | A Limestone ‘Swan’ for $26 Million
