text: An ugly duckling townhouse that was the beneficiary of an ambitious $10 million neo-Roman makeover to restore its original 1879 panache with a striking facade of imported Italian limestone and a cornice that hides a rooftop soaking pool sold for $26 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The annual taxes on the 20-foot-wide property are $110,000.

headline: Convoluted Language Makes Cooper Tire Deal Harder to Execute
text: Cooper Tire is facing more legal issues in its snarled deal with Apollo Tyres Ltd. of India.

headline: Gluten-Free Pies for Thanksgiving
text: I’m by no means a gluten-free girl, and not much of an expert when it comes to gluten-free cooking. But Thanksgiving is coming up and what is Thanksgiving without pie? Since many of you may be stuck when it comes to pies and gluten-free family members and guests, I decided to tackle a gluten-free pie crust this week.

headline: For Some Aid Workers, Rescues Must Wait as Bodies Are Removed
text: Volunteers from the Philippine Red Cross searched for bodies in Tacloban as thousands of residents remain hungry and homeless.

headline: General Motors Recalls 2013-14 Chevrolet Malibus Over Electrical Problems
text: General Motors will recall 14,909 Chevrolet Malibus from the 2013 model year in the United States equipped with the eight-way power front seat and passenger seat option. G.M. says that in certain vehicles, the wiring harness may wear against the frame. If this happens, the insulation of a circuit on the wiring harness may become worn through to the conductor and a short to the grounded seat frame may occur.

headline: An Ice Rink Opens in Brooklyn
text: The ice skating rink at McCarren Park, north Brooklyn’s “first and only” outdoor skating rink, opened today. The rink is nestled atop the beach plaza at the center of the pool area. It will be open through January, from 11 a.m. to 10 p.m., seven days a week.

headline: Raising Healthy Eaters, with SNAP or American Express
text: A study in contrasts:

headline: Claudia Fleming's Apple Crumb Crostata
text: When Claudia Fleming was at Gramercy Tavern, she was known for her all-American desserts. Mark Bittman invited her to share her Thanksgiving specialty: apple crumb crostata with bacon toffee.

headline: A ‘Downton’ Weekend in Georgia
text: Sea Island resort in Georgia is celebrating the Jan. 5 debut of the fourth season of the British series “Downton Abbey” with a weekend inspired by the series and hosted by Allen Leech, who plays the character of Tom Branson, the outspoken former family chauffeur and widower of Lady Sybil.

headline: Probe May Help Solve Riddle of Mars’s Missing Air
text: NASA’s next mission to Mars aims to answer one question: What happened to the air that once made the surface habitable?

headline: Cutting the Heart Out of Health Reform
text: It’s easy to be mad at President Obama over health care reform – the broken website, the confusing choices, his false promise that everyone could keep their current plans.

headline: A New Era for Progressives
text: On the corner of Canal and Varick Streets at the moment sits a 15,000-square-foot plastic tent, one that required a week’s worth of construction, the kind of edifice that typically at this time of year is given over to the sale of hand-knit scarves and tiny things made of wood. The purpose of this particular tent is outside the scope of holiday crafts: The project, called Talking Transition, was developed by a consortium of nonprofit groups, including the Revson Foundation, to allow New Yorkers to voice their opinions about what sort of direction the city should take in the aftermath of Bill de Blasio’s victory in the mayor’s race.

headline: Review: 2014 Kia Sorento
text: A vehicle refresh normally means a new grille and taillights. Kia gives the 2014 Sorento an entirely different chassis structure, a new engine and an improved suspension. Who does that?

headline: Seventh Heaven
text: The polished seventh-generation Corvette Stingray is a world-class sports car that, unlike its brutish, twitchy predecessor, requires no compromises.

headline: Weekend Reading: JPMorgan’s Strategy in China
text: The daughter of China’s former prime minister used the alias “Lily Chang” while working for JPMorgan Chase. In fairness, we should reveal that DealBook sometimes comments anonymously under the pseudonym of Bargain Literary Work.

headline: Simon & Schuster & Jeter
text: At one point this past baseball season, Derek Jeter, out injured, revealed that he wasn’t watching Yankees games regularly. He didn’t have the Extra Innings package, he said, and the games were blacked out in Tampa. (Why the YES Network would say NO to Tampa like that, I have no idea.) Now we know what he might have been doing instead of watching TV — reading manuscripts!

headline: 22-Year-Old Wins a Big Game in Chess Championship
text: Magnus Carlsen has already accomplished more in his brief career as a chess player than almost anyone in the game’s history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Philippines, Nepal, Myanmar and India.

headline: A Bird of Courage and Success
text: If Benjamin Franklin had gotten his way, a gold-plated turkey would have presided atop every flagpole where the American bald eagle now stands. Franklin considered the bald eagle a “bird of bad moral character,” while the turkey was “a much more respectable bird,” and “though a little vain and silly, a Bird of Courage.”

headline: The Well-Concealed Newness of the Kia Sorento
text: In the hypercompetitive automotive industry, a car is often produced for four to six years, getting an update halfway through its life. Visually, this is the “new grille and taillights” phase. While full sheet metal overhauls are expensive, a new schnoz and back end can be done efficiently. These cosmetic revisions are a good way to ignite new sales.

headline: Bated Breath, as a Baton Is Raised for a Specialty
text: When the San Francisco Symphony canceled an East Coast tour in March because of a players’ strike, one event that went by the board was a Carnegie Hall performance of Mahler’s Ninth Symphony, to have been led by the ensemble’s music director, Michael Tilson Thomas. The loss disappointed many, since this combination of orchestra and conductor is typically potent in Mahler.

headline: Modern Love Child of a Renaissance Spirit
text: “My Days” is the title of a program of mostly Renaissance works for voices and viols that was presented Tuesday at St. Thomas  by that church’s Choir of Men and Boys and the wonderful English viol consort Fretwork. It’s also the title of an arresting new work by Nico Muhly, a touching declaration of fraternity with the great Elizabethan composers that had its United States premiere that evening.

headline: In the Air | Lush Landscapes
text: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

headline: Compromise May Be Near for Iran Nuclear Deal, U.S. Official Says
text: WASHINGTON — A senior Obama administration official said on Friday that a solution could be found for one of the major stumbling blocks to an agreement that would freeze Iran’s nuclear program, and that the accord might be achieved next week.

headline: Blurring Beginnings and Endings and Politics
text: Hofesh Shechter’s “Sun” is cheeky. First the voice of the Israeli-born choreographer, a popular success in Britain, announces that before starting, his company will show a bit of the ending, “so that you know everything is going to be just fine.”

headline: In the Air | Strange Paradise
text: Harnessing the majestic power of nature, artists and designers fashion exotic worlds that are as devoted to fantasy as they are to flora.

headline: One-Track Mind
text: Unlike the latest Corvette, the 2013 SRT Viper has no need for refinements like an automatic transmission or decent gas mileage. It puts speed above all other considerations.

headline: Boy Detective, Gilded New York and Best-Dressed Man
text: That Roger Rosenblatt’s “The Boy Detective” (Ecco) has no table of contents will make perfect sense to readers who follow the meandering path that constitutes his charming memoir of growing up around Gramercy Park. Categorizing his musings would be too confining.

headline: Stingray Returns With Styling à la Mode
text: Imagine, if you will, that an unnamed manufacturer just released an all-new sports car. It rockets from 0 to 60 miles per hour in 3.8 seconds, pulls more than one lateral g on the skid pad and has a carbon-fiber hood and roof. The interior includes dual high-resolution screens, top-quality materials and the option of racing seats. The manual transmission, with 7 forward speeds, will execute rev-matched downshifts, and it’s mounted at the rear of the car for optimal weight distribution.

headline: The Viper Strikes Back
text: In 2010, I entered the Spectre 341 Challenge, a terrifying 5.2-mile hill climb outside Virginia City, Nev. The official results show Lou Gigliotti winning with his 700-horsepower Chevrolet Corvette ZR1, and second place going to Steve Millen, a legendary rally racer, in a 620-horsepower Nissan GT-R. But Mr. Gigliotti’s ’Vette wasn’t really the quickest car on the mountain that weekend.

headline: Lincoln Joins the Crossover Party
text: Ford Motor took another step toward revitalizing its moribund Lincoln division in Manhattan on Wednesday when it unveiled a production version of a new small crossover utility, the MKC.

headline: Tortured Souls
text: Samuel Beckett has been everywhere this season: a Hoi Polloi production of three short plays in Brooklyn; a take on “All That Fall” at the 59E59 Theaters; and versions of “Waiting for Godot” at the Castillo Theater and now in previews on Broadway, at the Cort.

headline: Hacker Receives 10-Year Sentence for ‘Causing Mayhem’
text: A federal judge in New York on Friday delivered a 10-year prison sentence to Jeremy Hammond , a prominent member of the hacking group Anonymous who pleaded guilty earlier this year to breaking into the computer servers of a string of corporations, government agencies and law enforcement advocacy groups.

headline: French Say Kidnapped Priest Was Moved to Nigeria
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — The kidnappers of a French priest seized in northern Cameroon shouted for joy and fired celebratory shots in the air, one of his church superiors there said Friday, but only after crossing the border into Nigeria, in a region rife with members of the Islamist sect Boko Haram.

headline: At Auction, Masterpieces of the Drivable Kind
text: With paintings and sculptures selling for record prices in recent weeks, it makes sense for auction houses to market cars as artworks, too. That would seem to be at least part of the logic behind a coming sale by Sotheby’s and RM Auctions ambitiously titled “Art of the Automobile.”

headline: Tiptoeing Around the Music Video
text: The music video is in black and white. It consists entirely of women dancing in high heels, wearing identical, flesh-hugging outfits that expose their upper thighs. It is not Beyoncé’s “Single Ladies,” probably the most famous dance video of this century. It is “Stop,” by the choreographer Susan Marshall.

headline: Weaponized Keynesianism, Historical Edition
text: In my last post, I showed that Europe is at this point doing worse — at least as measured by industrial production, and probably in terms of overall output — than it did in the Great Depression.

headline: ‘Art of the Automobile’
text: A look at a few of the prized lots from the coming New York sale of high-end cars by Sotheby’s and RM Auctions.

headline: A Seminar on Suspense, in Service of the Blues
text: Gary Clark Jr. began his encore at the Apollo Theater on Thursday night in an air of pensive solitude, perched on a chair with a harmonica and his guitar. Unhurried, calmly self-possessed, he drifted through “In the Evening (When the Sun Goes Down),” in an arrangement that subtly acknowledged Big Bill Broonzy and Lightnin’ Hopkins, among other stewards of that song. “It’s so lonesome when your lover’s not around,” he sang in a soft, clear voice, trusting that pitiful line to do its own work.

headline: Tripleheader to Open Show Season
text: As 2013 is winding down, a fresh season of auto shows is booting up. Three big international salons — in Los Angeles, Tokyo and Guangzhou, China — are opening this week more or less on top of one another.

headline: Friday Night Music: More San Fermin
text: I know, it’s only Friday afternoon, but I’m deeply jet lagged, and ready to collapse.

headline: If It All Doesn’t Fit, Build a Bigger Box
text: The classical-music recording industry is collapsing. Right? That’s what we’ve heard.

headline: The Space Shuttle That Fell to Earth
text: “The Challenger Disaster,” the Science Channel’s first dramatic feature film, tries hard to make the search for those faulty O-rings into a pulse-quickening thriller along the lines of “All the President’s Men.” That it succeeds as well as it does can be credited largely to William Hurt, who manages to make the physicist Richard P. Feynman interesting all over again.

headline: Trying to Outrace Scientific Advances
text: Before he created the futuristic TV cop show “Almost Human,” J. H. Wyman faced a recurring challenge as producer of the sci-fi series “Fringe.” Actual scientists continually spawned projects that rivaled the wildest imaginary ones dreamed up in the writers’ room.

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Lupita Nyong’o’s Fashion
text: Ms. Nyong’o, a sure bet for a supporting actress Oscar nomination for her role in “12 Years a Slave” has emerged as a red carpet star.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Christie’s Highest Art Bid Ever, Tim Gunn’s New Series and H&M’s New Lady Gaga-Christened Flagship
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 9 – 15

headline: The Cautionary Tale of an Investment Adviser Gone Astray
text: IN the world of Ponzi schemes, Mark Spangler was a small-time crook. But his early career, as a respected investment adviser in Seattle and onetime head of a national adviser organization that pushes its members to act in their clients’ best interest, gives his recent conviction on 32 criminal counts a twist.

headline: An Elusive Mystery Man of Music
text: On a recent Saturday night, a boisterous crowd jammed into Buka, a Nigerian restaurant in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn, spilling out onto Fulton Street. This wasn’t the restaurant’s usual weekend clientele, primarily expat Nigerians already familiar with specialties like goat-head stew and giant land snails. Instead, the throng had gathered for a record-release party, listening to African-flavored D.J. sets by Steve Shelley, formerly of Sonic Youth, and Lizzi Bougatsos of Gang Gang Dance. Just past the bar, revelers took turns posing for selfies standing next to a six-foot-high cardboard cutout of an imposing man in a disco-era cream-colored tuxedo.

headline: An Interrogation Routine of Real Cop, Robot Cop?
text: In the future, your artificial limbs and joints will talk to you. Holographic gizmos will augment all those desktops, laptops and tablets we’re so fond of. And proper balance will be everything.

headline: The Devil Is Running for a Seat in Parliament
text: A radio talk show broke the news on Oct. 28: Nana Kwaku Bonsam will run for a seat in the Parliament of Ghana in 2016.

headline: Visiting the Island of the Dead
text: On Tuesday morning, the first snow flurries of the season fell on New York’s potter’s field, drifting down into an open trench, dusting the dirt next to hundreds of corpses in bare wooden caskets.

headline: Excerpt: 'Almost Human'
text: The new futuristic cop show on Fox pairs a detective with an android.

headline: Women Gain in Some STEM Fields, but Not Computer Science
text: A few weeks ago, I wrote about ways to get more women interested in computer science. One of the points that came up frequently in my reporting is that some other STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) have actually been quite successful attracting more women. A report this week from the National Science Foundation lays out these trends nicely:

headline: Inspiration Is Everywhere, Even in the Bargain Bin
text: Even if you don’t know Dev Hynes’s name, you’ve likely heard his music. At 27, Mr. Hynes has been an in-demand producer and songwriter for years, recording tracks for the Chemical Brothers, Sky Ferreira, Florence and the Machine and Solange. He’s also been in the studio with Britney Spears, Kylie Minogue, Jessie Ware and Grace Jones.

headline: Will Play for Health Care (at Least at One Music Event)
text: The O+ Festival in San Francisco this weekend would seem a typical indie arts event, with performances by local musicians and displays of funky art. But in a twist that highlights a longstanding problem in the creative economy, the artists involved will be paid not in cash but rather in something they may need just as badly: health care.

headline: Students Try to Occupy Bulgarian Parliament Building
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Student protesters tried but failed to occupy the Bulgarian Parliament building here on Friday, then marched through the city center and broke through four police cordons in the latest of a series of angry demonstrations against the center-left government of Prime Minister Plamen Oresharski.

headline: Blithely Crossing the Boundary Between Country and Hip-Hop
text: Country as a genre is both reverent and historically minded, so of course Florida Georgia Line, a young band that’s quickly emerged as a reliable hitmaker after several journeyman years, peppers its shows with covers.

headline: Where Witches Dance in Bushwick
text: Catland, a store and event space, draws Wiccans, pagans and devotees of occult books and full-moon rituals.

headline: Death After the Typhoon: ‘It Was Preventable’
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Richard Pulga lay on a hard steel gurney for five days with only a saline drip after being seriously injured in the typhoon that devastated his country.

headline: A Book Fair That Grew, Propelling the Arts in Miami
text: MIAMI — Three decades ago, the notion of a book fair in this city seemed wildly implausible.

headline: The Payoff in Waiting to Collect Social Security
text: If an insurance salesman offered a product with a guaranteed income of nearly 7 percent for life, it would be foolish not to question whether it was too good to be true.

headline: A Place for Work and Introspection
text: His name is Andy Bragen, and welcome to his office. He is a playwright, and good thing you’re here, because there’s a story he wants to tell about an artist’s residency he got: nine months in a Lower Manhattan office to do with as he wished.

headline: Amber Batchelor: Mayor of Women’s Hoops
text: On Sunday mornings, Amber Batchelor clears the men off a basketball court on the Upper West Side and runs one of the only all-female pickup games in the city.

text: Michael Chu runs a small travel agency in Queens but spends most of his time helping members of the community deal with landlords, government agencies and employers.

headline: Young and Educated in Europe, but Desperate for Jobs
text: MADRID — Alba Méndez, a 24-year-old with a master’s degree in sociology, sprang out of bed nervously one recent morning, carefully put on makeup and styled her hair. Her thin hands trembled as she clutched her résumé on her way out of the tiny room where a friend allows her to stay rent free.

headline: For JPMorgan, $4.5 Billion to Settle Mortgage Claims
text: The checks from JPMorgan Chase just keep on coming as the nation’s largest bank works to move beyond its mortgage-related troubles.

headline: A Master’s Bubbles and Panels, in Depth
text: In museums, we look all the time at drawings, prints and illustrated books from the past, art forms that entertain us with stories but also embody history. Modern comics, at their best, do this too, often with immense sophistication. Do we see them in museums? Hardly ever.

headline: Responding to a Typhoon on the Web
text: Every week, readers of The New York Times share thousands of comments in response to our reporting. What you keep telling us is that your fellow readers can be as illuminating as the news articles we produce. So we’re working on new ways to highlight your most notable comments, and introduce you to the readers behind them.

headline: For a Jeweler, All That Bedazzles
text: Every decade or so, when Joel A. Rosenthal comes out of his velvet-lined shell in Paris to show his magnificent jewels, as he will do starting Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the same chorus of words appear.

text: The North American Open Pairs Flight A final takes place next March, in the two days before the Spring North American Championships get into full swing in Dallas.

headline: Snapchat, How Quickly You Have Grown
text: While some might have been shocked this week by the multi-billion dollar offers the start-up Snapchat turned down, I found something else entirely perplexing about the valuation of this little company: just how quickly it grew.

text: The author Henry Alford attended the record-breaking auctions of modern art at Christie’s and Sotheby’s, but to watch, not buy.

headline: For First Time, E.P.A. Proposes Reducing Ethanol Requirement for Gas Mix
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday proposed reducing the amount of ethanol that is required to be mixed with the gasoline supply, the first time it has taken steps to slow down the drive to replace fossil fuels with renewable forms of energy.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Winter Fashion Begins
text: Madison Square Park was a shower of golden leaves, a backdrop for the Veterans Day Parade. The first blast of cold changed the look of fashion overnight. Men’s coats with brass buttons echoed the military theme, as did trench coats (but not cyclamen-pink fur). Black offset the leaves. Braided scarves from Loopy Mango appeared, too.

headline: House Tour | Faye Toogood
text: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.

headline: Washington Comes Out
text: Ten percent of adults in the District of Columbia identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender, nearly three times the national average. What makes the city such a gay-friendly place?

headline: Player Ratings: Scotland (0), U.S. (0)
text: No Clint Dempsey. No Landon Donovan. Nothing at stake, in terms of a result.

headline: Performance Art That Looks a Lot Like Theater
text: Alexandre Singh’s “The Humans” has its ups and downs, but it is still one of the outstanding achievements of the Performa 13 performance art biennial. Commissioned in collaboration with the Witte de With Center for Contemporary Art in the Netherlands, it is less performance art than classical theater with all the benefits of a highly skilled, well-rehearsed cast.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 15
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the season’s first snow, renovations at City Hall and the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan.

headline: Out in D.C.
text: The capital as the backdrop of a thriving gay scene.

headline: Think Big
text: I had the odd coincidence of reading Lawrence Osborne’s piece on Burma — in which he examines the country today alongside the one George Orwell wrote about in his first novel, “Burmese Days” — at the same time my husband happened to be reading Orwell’s “1984” aloud to our children.

headline: The Gayest Place in America?
text: WASHINGTON — My earliest sense of what it meant to be gay in the nation’s capital came more than a decade ago when I was a summer intern. I was a few blocks from Union Station when a congressman walked by and gave the reporters I was standing with a big, floppy wave hello.

headline: Oops. I Left My Millions at Home.
text: Behold the swirl. At the brunch last Sunday at Christie’s auction house for bidders and attendees of this past Tuesday’s history-making sale of postwar and contemporary art, hundreds of well-dressed art lovers sipped Champagne and nibbled party food while standing just inches from canvases, some of them valued for millions of dollars.

headline: The ‘Biggie’: A Tainted Status Symbol
text: The rise in violent fashion-related crime has coalesced around the growing cachet of streetwear and fashion’s embrace of celebrity culture — as the crowd skating at the Bryant Park ice rink on Nov. 9 can readily attest to.

headline: Justices to Revisit Securities Fraud Suits
text: The Supreme Court agreed Friday to hear a case that could make it harder for investors to win class-action lawsuits for securities fraud. The court also agreed to consider when police officers could be sued for using excessive force to stop fleeing suspects.

headline: Jay Z’s Blueprint Didn’t Call for This
text: This is how it usually happens.

headline: Together, at Home and at Work
text: I spent much of the last six months helping my wife with a rare professional opportunity. When friends heard how many days, nights and weekends we spent in the same room, they had the same reply: “Whoa! When are you getting divorced?”

headline: Beheading in Syria Is Called a Mistake
text: It was a deadly case of mistaken identity set against the chaotic, sectarian backdrop of the Syrian conflict.

headline: T’s Winter Travel Issue
text: The latest issue of T takes us to many destinations in many different ways. In our cover story, we provide a relaxed, versatile wardrobe with clean lines that are tailor-made for travel. Sometimes travel can simply be a state of mind; lovely interiors can transport a home. The designer Faye Toogood brings the English countryside to her London house, with her unexpected arrangements of objects. These days, travel envy happens with a few clicks. Instagram offers a fresh means to peek into others’ carefully curated lifestyles all around the world. Next, we travel to France by way of Miami; the designer Charlotte Perriand, who created furnishings, interiors and buildings with Le Corbusier, is being recognized at Design Miami this December for her ahead-of-the-curve sensibility. Sometimes it’s all about the journey — Alexander Payne shares his love for the wholesomeness of hometown Nebraska in a road trip with the novelist Kurt Andersen. In Montana, the investment banker-turned-hunter Georgia Pellegrini offers a weekend retreat for urban women like herself to get in touch with their primitive selves. Last but not least, Lawrence Osborne travels to Myanmar to search for the inspirations behind George Orwell’s books. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Tennessee Pastor Disputes Wildlife Possession Charge by State
text: JACKSBORO, Tenn. — In a mix of old-time religion, modern media and Tennessee law, a 22-year-old preacher who has become a reality television star because of his experience in handling poisonous snakes pleaded not guilty on Friday to illegally keeping dozens of them that he and his congregants routinely touch during worship services.

headline: Former Marcos Aide Is Stricken at Her Conspiracy Trial
text: A former aide to Imelda Marcos who is accused of selling a Monet masterpiece that she did not own was wheeled out of court during the prosecution’s closing arguments on Friday morning after experiencing chest pains and nausea.

headline: Immigrants Closely Tied to Military Get Reprieve
text: The Obama administration issued a new policy on Friday that will allow immigrants in the United States illegally who are close relatives of active military troops and veterans to stay and move toward becoming permanent residents.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: An enormous online shopping spree, the rejection of a Boeing contract and a confirmation hearing for a potential Federal Reserve chairwoman.

headline: She Doesn’t Expect Anything, and Hasn’t Been Disappointed
text: There is a photograph taped to the front of a building on Eighth Avenue in Chelsea that gives pause to people walking by. It shows a smiling old woman holding a striped cat. But any warm feelings fade upon reading a handwritten sign below.

headline: Libya Protest Turns Deadly as Militias Open Fire
text: CAIRO — Dozens of people were killed in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, on Friday after militiamen opened fire on unarmed protesters, setting off some of the worst violence in the capital since the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi almost three years ago.

headline: Off the Court, a Film’s Lens on Asian-American Faith
text: During his years getting started as a film producer, Christopher Chen took a great many meetings. He had his favorite places, like the Griddle Cafe in Hollywood and Nate ’n Al in Beverly Hills. Even if the movie he was pitching never came together, the deli served great corned beef hash.

headline: Judd Hirsch’s Wind-Power Plan Unsettles Catskill Town
text: DENNING, N.Y. — Blanketed by the stillness of stone-faced mountains and endless trees now shaded rust and gold, the town of Denning is quiet, so quiet, one longtime resident likes to say, you can hear your heartbeat.

headline: In a Bean, a Boon to Biotech
text: A new federal push to purge artery-clogging trans fats from foods could be just what the doctor ordered — not only for public health but for the unpopular biotechnology industry, specifically, two developers of genetically modified crops.

headline: African Call to Delay Kenyans’ Trials Fails at U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS — An African-led attempt to postpone the trials of Kenya’s top two leaders at the International Criminal Court collapsed on Friday when it failed to gain enough support on the United Nations Security Council, an outcome bitterly criticized by Kenya and other African nations that accused the Council’s majority of a patronizing mistrust.

headline: Tough Way to Lose a Friend
text: Every writer knows that unless you were born gifted with either supreme confidence or outsize ego, handing in your work holds, in some cases, admitted terror. If that’s too strong, at least fairly high anxiety. Even if what you wrote seems unusually good to you, part of you is vulnerable to the suggestion that you may have laid an egg. A bad one. As W.C. Fields might have put it as your editor, “Sadly, my little lad, you have contrived in this instance to produce a specimen of odoriferous hen fruit.”

headline: Who’s Sorry Now?
text: Barack Obama’s loyal supporters are heavy of heart. Perhaps their chief source of comfort is that the Obamacare mess hit the headlines at about the same time as the crack-smoking mayor of Toronto. At least the president didn’t claim he was drunk when he wrote the health care bill.

headline: Prosecutor Plans to Interview F.S.U. Quarterback’s Accuser
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — William N. Meggs, a state attorney for Florida’s Second Judicial Circuit, said he was not certain how a sexual assault complaint from almost a year ago involving Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston had just crossed his desk, but he promised he would “get to the bottom of it.”

headline: Conservation Group Keeps Buying Land, Helping State Parks Grow
text: MINNEWASKA STATE PARK, N.Y. — Over the last 25 years, this park in upstate Ulster County has doubled in size. Farther south, in Putnam County, Fahnestock State Park has grown even more, and in Orange County, Sterling Forest State Park has gained almost 15,000 acres.

text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Brazil: Arrests Begin in Vote-Fraud Case
text: The federal police on Friday began arresting a dozen powerful political figures, bankers and businessmen convicted in a vast vote-buying scandal that surfaced more than eight years ago. More than a year ago, Brazil’s highest court set the prison sentences for officials from the governing Workers Party, but the court’s consideration of appeals in the landmark corruption trial and what appeared to have been bureaucratic problems had delayed sending those found guilty in the scheme to prison. It is rare for high-profile Brazilian politicians convicted of crimes to serve time in prison. But this week the Supreme Federal Tribunal ruled that the convicted officials must soon start their prison terms. On Friday, José Genoino Guimarães Neto, a legislator who is a former president of the Workers Party, turned himself in at a police building in São Paulo and thrust his fist in the air in an act of defiance.

headline: After Obama Meeting, Insurers Question Plan’s Workability
text: A day after they were caught off guard by President Obama’s proposal to prevent cancellation of insurance policies for millions of Americans, top executives of some of the biggest insurance companies emerged from a meeting at the White House on Friday, expressing mixed feelings about whether the idea could work in every state.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 15, 2013
On Track and Off, Vettel Sets His Own Pace
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Nobody in Formula One racing is in a bigger rush than Sebastian Vettel, known for his blistering starts on the track and in his race to the record books.

headline: Emotional Support, With Fur, Draws Complaints on Planes
text: LOS ANGELES — Gigi Griffis, a writer who travels around the world as she works, and Luna, her sprightly 4-year-old Schnauzer-Yorkie mix, are nearly inseparable. They have dined in Mexican cafes near Puerto Vallarta, navigated the Paris Metro and hiked the alpine foothills of the Matterhorn.

headline: Canada: Toronto Council Curbs Mayor
text: After Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto, a self-confessed crack cocaine user, binge drinker and impaired driver, refused to step down, the Toronto City Council began stripping away his powers on Friday. A special session of the Council removed the mayor’s power to appoint the members of the city’s executive committee as well as the deputy mayor. It also transferred any powers Mr. Ford would have as mayor during a declared emergency to the deputy mayor. On Monday the Council will consider measures to eliminate the budget and staff for Mr. Ford’s office. Mr. Ford said he would challenge the sanctions in court. The Council has no legal means to remove the mayor from office.

headline: Disrespect, Race and Obama
text: In an interview with the BBC this week, Oprah Winfrey said of President Obama: “There is a level of disrespect for the office that occurs. And that occurs, in some cases, and maybe even many cases, because he’s African-American.”

headline: Obama Gives San Francisco’s Batkid a Six-Second Shout-Out
text: All Miles Scott wanted to do was to put on his Batman costume and fight crime on the grimy streets of Gotham City.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 16, 2013
text: “On the bad days, it’s really hard to get out of bed. I ask myself, ‘What did I do wrong?’”

headline: McBride’s Family on Murder Charge
text: The family of Renisha McBride, who was shot and killed on a front porch in a Detroit suburb, held a news conference to discuss the second-degree murder and manslaughter charges against the home owner.

headline: A Closer Look at a Centuries-Old Text
text: The Bay Psalm Book was the first book printed in the colonies and the first book printed in English in the New World. A copy will be auctioned on Nov. 26 and is expected to fetch $15 million to $30 million.

headline: Let Bidding Begin for the Bay Psalm Book From 1640
text: David N. Redden recited the opening of the 23rd Psalm the way he had memorized it as a child: “The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want. He maketh me to lie down in green pastures.”

headline: France: 4 Said to Recruit for Syrian War
text: French authorities near Paris have arrested four men suspected of involvement in a network sending fighters to Syria to join radical Sunni Islamist groups operating there, the Paris prosecutor’s office said Friday. The domestic intelligence service said three of the men had fought in Syria alongside the Nusra Front, which has links to Al Qaeda, and returned to France, said Agnès Thibault-Lecuivre, a spokeswoman for the prosecutor’s office. The fourth man is believed to be the network’s organizer. All four were to be charged on Friday with conspiring to commit “terrorist acts,” Ms. Thibault-Lecuivre said. More than 100 French residents or citizens are fighting in Syria, French officials say.

headline: Voter Suppression’s New Pretext
text: IRVINE, Calif. — IT’S the latest fad among state officials looking to make voting harder: We’re not racist, we’re just partisan.

headline: Corrections: November 16, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: From G-Funk to Geometry
text: David Steinberg may still be a teenager, but he’s proven that he has top talent as a crossword constructor. He’s already published a puzzle for every day of the week, and he’s back today with a Saturday.

headline: Not the Time to Squeeze Iran
text: A rare opportunity for a diplomatic resolution to the dispute over Iran’s nuclear program is at risk because many lawmakers, urged on by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, are insisting that Congress impose tougher economic sanctions, perhaps next week as an amendment to the defense bill.

headline: Gun Tragedies Without End
text: The latest woeful lesson in gun mayhem is playing out in Michigan, where a 54-year-old man in Dearborn Heights was charged Friday with second-degree murder in the shotgun slaying of a 19-year-old woman presumed to have knocked on his door in the middle of the night, seeking help after a traffic accident.

headline: A Leap for Equality
text: On Wednesday, Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii signed a bill that will allow same-sex couples to marry in the state, starting Dec. 2. The measure, ending a two-decade legal and political battle, caps a remarkable year of progress toward ensuring the basic civil rights of gay Americans.

headline: Starting Over After Hurricane Sandy
text: As Hurricane Sandy approached, Joseph Duodu, his wife and two daughters evacuated from their home on the Rockaway Peninsula and drove to a motel on Queens Boulevard. The family had packed only an overnight bag with a change of clothes because they thought they would be back home the next day. They ended up living in the motel for five months.

headline: Mike McCormack, Hall of Fame Browns Lineman, Dies at  83
text: Mike McCormack, a Hall of Fame tackle for the Cleveland Browns in the 1950s and early ’60s who protected quarterback Otto Graham and opened holes for fullback Jim Brown and then became an N.F.L. coach and executive, died on Friday in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 83.

headline: The Little Agency That Could
text: One of the big criticisms of the original team of financial regulators brought in by President Obama is that too many of them had worked in Bill Clinton’s Treasury Department. That, of course, was the Treasury Department run by Robert Rubin and then by Lawrence Summers — an agency with a bias toward deregulation. Those regulators had supported the elimination of Glass-Steagall, the 1930s law that separated investment banks from commercial banks, and were disinclined to regulate derivatives, “those financial weapons of mass destruction,” as Warren Buffett liked to call them.

headline: Elmer Lokkins, Symbol of Same-Sex Marriage Cause, Dies at 94
text: Elmer Lokkins and Gustavo Archilla kept their relationship private for nearly 60 years. Some knew; some just wondered. Most did not discuss the situation. Uncle Gus and Uncle Elmer, their family called them.

headline: MSNBC Suspends Alec Baldwin and His Talk Show
text: MSNBC suspended Alec Baldwin on Friday after a furor stirred by a gay slur that he made in a confrontation with reporters this week.

headline: The Rise of the Union Leagues
text: In the spring of 1863, a group of ardent Republicans in Centralia, a railroad town in south central Illinois, sought to revive the moribund local party newspaper. Needing an editor, they poached one from nearby Sparta. John W. Fletcher, a western New Yorker then 44 years old, was their man. On May 28 he took up his pen for the new weekly, The Centralia Sentinel.

headline: House Members React to Health Care Bill
text: The House of Representatives passed a bill that would allow people to keep their health care plan. Insurers would continue to sell plans that did not meet the new guidelines for one more year.

headline: As Knicks Hunt for Wins, Anthony Rarely Finds a Seat
text: In a quest to prevent his body from crumbling into a cartoonish pile of parts, Carmelo Anthony has turned to a between-games conditioning routine that runs the gamut from conventional to space age. There are ice packs and massages, cryogenic chambers and NormaTec compression sleeves.

headline: Bitterness Is Gone as Nolan and the Sabres Reunite
text: BUFFALO — Ted Nolan was traveling to Latvia last week when one of his former players, the Hall of Famer Pat LaFontaine, reached him by phone.

headline: Top Teenage Runner Is Turning Pro
text: Mary Cain, one of the most promising female American high school middle-distance runners in decades, has chosen to turn professional rather than run for a collegiate team.

headline: Asserting the Right to Handle Snakes
text: A 22-year-old preacher who has become a reality television star because of his experience in handling poisonous snakes is facing charges in Tennessee.

headline: Nets Lose Williams in Overtime Win
text: PHOENIX — The Nets worked themselves to full throttle on Friday night, just a couple of hours after the player meant to be their engine this season was stalled on the court.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 6:25 P.M. (Flix) MALLRATS (1995) A couple of recently dumped ne’er-do-wells (Jason Lee and Jeremy London) try to get over their girlfriends (Shannen Doherty and Claire Forlani) by wandering around the local mall. Writing in the The New York Times, Janet Maslin said this comedy, written and directed by Kevin Smith, “mixes clever bits and an appealing quirkiness (which goes a long way) with gross-out practical jokes, needless repetition and obvious padding, since it has no real plot.” She added: “Mr. Lee’s Brodie has the grunge and surliness to give him credibility here, but he also has a sweet, funny indignation over life’s little outrages, which are actually this film’s most heartfelt concerns.”

headline: In Worst-Hit Area of Tacloban, a Killer From Two Sides
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — In the corner of what used to be her living room, Mary Grace Golondrina, 20, dug through the mud and recovered a trophy — first-place runner-up in a fund-raiser for Santo Niño Church. There is little else here.

headline: Deadly Kabul Bombing Sends Message on Security Pact Vote
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A powerful car bomb that exploded near the site where Afghan elders are set to vote on a long-term security agreement with the United States killed at least 10 people on Saturday, rattling central Kabul and underscoring the insurgency’s desire to prevent an American presence in Afghanistan beyond 2014.

headline: Room for Agreement on Next Steps for Nuclear Power?
text: Room for Debate has posted a useful new discussion on whether and how nuclear power can safely contribute to advancing energy options without climate regrets. I can think of lots of other experts and practitioners to engage, of course.

text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Geithner to Join Private Equity Firm
text: Timothy F. Geithner will join the private equity firm Warburg Pincus as president, the firm announced on Saturday. It would be his first prominent position since leaving office as Treasury secretary this year.

headline: Variety: Ancient Philosophy
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s curious that two of the most memorable villains in fiction share a fondness for Marcus Aurelius. In Richard Connell’s 1924 short story “The Most Dangerous Game,” General Zaroff, the unhinged sophisticate who hunts humans on his island, unwinds at the end of the night with a bottle of chambertin and the writings of Aurelius. In “The Silence of the Lambs,” Hannibal Lecter quotes from The Meditations during a cellblock interrogation: “First principles, Clarice. Simplicity. Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each particular thing ask: what is it in itself? What is its nature? What does he do, this man you seek?”

headline: Vows: In Sickness and in Health
text: Breast cancer sidelined Virginia Wettlaufer just six months after she and Walter Tomenson started dating.

headline: Defection of Longtime Ally Splits Center-Right in Italy
text: ROME — Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right political movement, a powerful force in Italy, split Saturday, dealing another blow to the former prime minister as Italian lawmakers prepare for a final vote this month on whether to expel him from the Senate.

headline: Russian Manhunt Ends as Bus Bomber’s Husband Is Killed
text: MOSCOW — Ending a nearly monthlong manhunt, security forces killed the husband of a suicide bomber who blew up a public bus last month in the city of Volgograd, Russian officials said Saturday.

headline: A Lesson in Perseverance for a Giants Running Back
text: Shrouded in darkness, Michael A. Cox Sr., a plainclothes Boston police officer, sprinted after four murder suspects cornered on a dead-end street in a seedy neighborhood. As sirens wailed nearby, one of the suspects scaled a fence, with Cox in close pursuit.

headline: Mets and Yanks Must Swing for Fences
text: The Mets have fallen into a strange pattern lately. One player commands attention with a fantastic, must-see individual season — and then disappears the following year.

headline: Bob Pittman of Clear Channel, on the Value of Dissent
text: This interview with  Bob Pittman, chairman and chief executive of Clear Channel Communications, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: An Artist Uses Humor as a Salve for an Illness
text: If surgeons had to remove her left eye, it wouldn’t be so bad, Katie Commodore had reasoned. Think of the party tricks she could perform with a glass eye! Maybe she could stud it with diamonds, even fit it with a camera or a laser sight.

headline: A Tool Meant to Keep Her Safe Makes Her Feel Like a Target
text: Cynthia Gibbs-Pratt would rather walk into walls than use a cane to guide her. And often, she does.

headline: Petty. Earnhardt. Johnson? A Debate Expands.
text: If Richard Petty, Dale Earnhardt and Jimmie Johnson were placed in identical racecars side by side, who would win?

headline: Answer to Blindness Was Hidden in the Genes
text: Jasmine Carrero has big doelike eyes, an almond-shaped face and a willowy frame that she calls boyish. She also has Stickler syndrome, a group of genetic disorders whose hallmarks are these elongated features; it is responsible not just for the elegant tapering fingers possessed by nearly everyone in her family, but also for the family’s history of blindness.

headline: FIFA’s Puskas Award
text: Everyone has his favorite goal of the year.

headline: Rebuilding Strength
text: Katie Commodore, 35, a printmaking artist whose multiple sclerosis has caused her to lose some motor functions, has hired a physical trainer to rebuild her strength.

headline: Still on Facebook, but Finding Less to Like
text: Just a few years ago, most of my online social activity revolved around Facebook. I was an active member of several Facebook groups, including one that helped me and others find apartments and sell used items. Another group was wonderful for organizing midnight movie screenings. And I used Facebook to stay up-to-date on the latest achievements of my sisters and their children, and the many members of my extended family.

headline: Tennessee Governor Hesitates on Medicaid Expansion, Frustrating Many
text: NASHVILLE — Gov. Bill Haslam of Tennessee describes it as “trying to thread a needle from 80 yards.”

headline: Who Has Your Back? Hard to Tell
text: What is the duty of a trustee to protect investors?

headline: In the Zone With Peyton Manning
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — As the Denver Broncos ran out the clock in their win over the San Diego Chargers last weekend, football fans gasped as Peyton Manning, the undisputed face of the N.F.L., got up limping after being tackled around his legs.

headline: Ken Mobley
text: Ken Mobley, a jailer in Whitley County, Ky., talks about the difficulty of keeping Suboxone out of prisons.

headline: Buprenorphine Explained
text: Dr. Andrew Kolodny, the president of Physicians for Responsible Opioid Prescribing, describes the pharmacology of buprenorphine and the drug’s effect at the brain’s receptor level.

headline: Shawn Schneider
text: Over the past two years, Shawn Schneider, 38, has been taking buprenorphine to maintain his sobriety after an addiction to painkillers.

headline: Melissa Iverson
text: Melissa Iverson was transformed after doctors put her on buprenorphine following a psychotic break.

headline: House Tour | Faye Toogood
text: The multifaceted designer opens her London home, and discusses her affinity for using unusual juxtapositions in her decorating.

headline: Dr. Jeffrey T. Junig
text: Dr. Jeffrey T. Junig discusses the questions he asks himself when it comes to discharging patients from addiction treatment programs.

headline: The Pacers’ Perfect Beginning Will Not Guarantee Them a Happy Ending
text: When an N.B.A. team starts the season on an unbeaten run, curiosity always kicks in. What is the longest streak without a loss to start the season? What does a soaring start say about a team’s chances when the playoffs arrive six months down the road?

headline: Painting Pickett’s Charge
text: Like other Northern states, Pennsylvania had much business to attend to in the weeks and months that followed the end of the Civil War: there were regiments to be dissolved, soldiers to be mustered out, and wounded, widowed and orphaned to be provided for.

headline: Addiction Treatment With a Dark Side
text: For Shawn Schneider, a carpenter and rock musician, the descent into addiction began one Wisconsin winter with a fall from a rooftop construction site onto the frozen ground below. As the potent pain pills prescribed for his injuries became his obsessive focus, he lost everything: his band, his job, his wife, his will to live.

headline: Don’t Mess With My ‘Sacred Values’
text: ACCORDING to news reports, a key factor in last weekend’s diplomatic impasse over Iran’s nuclear program was Iran’s insistence on what President Hassan Rouhani has called its “right” to enrich uranium. “National interests are our red line,” he declared, echoing earlier statements by other Iranian leaders.

headline: Reining in Payday Lenders
text: At some point — soon, we hope — the Federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will issue regulations for the payday lending industry. The bureau took an important step in that direction when it announced earlier this month that it would begin collecting complaints from borrowers who may have been hit with unreasonable fees, unauthorized withdrawals from their checking accounts or other abuses. The bureau should rein in all of these practices, but its most important task is to ensure that the loans are affordable — which means requiring lenders to determine in advance that the borrower has the ability to repay.

headline: My Education, Repossessed
text: Like many post-grads, I’ve been struggling for years to keep up with my student loan payments. I can just about make it each month, with some modest sacrifices. For instance, doing my own dental work. But last night I had a terrible dream. In it, I fell so far behind in my payments that the government decided to move against me. They could have taken legal action, but they did something much more diabolical: They repossessed my education.

headline: Prudence or Cruelty?
text: WHEN members of Congress debate whether to slash the food stamp program, they should ask if they really want more small children arriving at school having skipped breakfast.

headline: Sentenced to a Slow Death
text: If this were happening in any other country, Americans would be aghast. A sentence of life in prison, without the possibility of parole, for trying to sell $10 of marijuana to an undercover officer? For sharing LSD at a Grateful Dead concert? For siphoning gas from a truck? The punishment is so extreme, so irrational, so wildly disproportionate to the crime that it defies explanation.

headline: Something for Barack and Bibi to Talk About
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel spoke on the phone for 90 minutes the other day. Wow — 90 minutes! I wonder if Obama has ever spoken to John Boehner for 90 minutes?

headline: China’s New Agenda
text: In one of several surprising and potentially welcome shifts in policy, China’s leaders announced Friday that they would relax China’s draconian one-child policy and end its brutal “re-education through labor” camps. They also outlined several ambitious economic initiatives that could make the country more hospitable to private enterprise in the coming years.

headline: The Three Burials of Obamacare
text: THE first time Obamacare seemed finished, doomed, doornail-dead, the voters of Massachusetts played the would-be executioner. In January 2010, they sent a pickup-driving Republican to the Senate to fill Ted Kennedy’s seat, apparently depriving the health care bill of its crucial 60th vote and sending Democrats scrambling for a Plan B.

headline: More Fun With Bill and Hill
text: BEFORE President Obama administered his fix to the Affordable Care Act last week and even before it was clear that he was leaning that way, Bill Clinton piped up, opining that Obama should honor his claim that Americans with insurance they liked could keep it. This advice wasn’t exactly solicited. And inasmuch as it gave detractors of Obama and Obamacare a fresh cudgel, it wasn’t terribly helpful, either.

headline: Billy Collins
text: Billy Collins is a best-selling poet who served as poet laureate of the United States from 2001 to 2003. His latest collection of poetry is “Aimless Love.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Academia’s Two Tracks
text: Are adjuncts better teachers than tenure-track faculty?

headline: Waiting to See if Ukraine Tilts East or West
text: Curiously, the ferocious tug-of-war between Russia and the European Union over Ukraine has come down to whether Yulia Tymoshenko, the former Ukrainian prime minister who is serving a seven-year prison sentence, is freed in the next few days.

headline: You’re So Self-Controlling
text: WHAT do you do if, when you get to a subway platform, you see that it is already packed with people? Do you join the throngs to wait for the train, or do you shake your head and seek an alternative way to get where you’re going?

headline: The Insanity of Our Food Policy
text: American food policy has long been rife with head-scratching illogic. We spend billions every year on farm subsidies, many of which help wealthy commercial operations to plant more crops than we need. The glut depresses world crop prices, harming farmers in developing countries. Meanwhile, millions of Americans live tenuously close to hunger, which is barely kept at bay by a food stamp program that gives most beneficiaries just a little more than $4 a day.

headline: To Fight Obesity, a Carrot, and a Stick
text: Childhood obesity, at long last, may have peaked — even among the poor, where the problem is most prevalent. Between 2008 and 2011, according to a study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 19 states and territories saw a small but significant drop in obesity rates among low-income preschoolers.

headline: Alzheimer’s Anxiety
text: PHILADELPHIA — ALMOST every day I worry about whether my parents have Alzheimer’s. My dad is 86 and my mother is about to turn 80. Just because of their age they are at high risk for the disease, and I constantly wonder if their forgetfulness is “normal” or a sign of the worst.

headline: Recovery and Reconstruction
text: The rural hinterland of the Philippines has been largely left to fend for itself since Typhoon Haiyan hit.

headline: Kidd Is Finding His Coaching Style (the Suit and Tie Are Just the Start)
text: PHOENIX — It has yet to feel natural seeing Jason Kidd fastened inside a coach’s workday attire. His players have joked that his suit jackets look too tight. His neckties never seem to hang at a proper length. If, somehow, these represent conscious sartorial decisions, they are unusual ones.

headline: I Was a Portrait by Francis Bacon
text: MILAN — MY bookshelves have a bad habit: They eat books. Especially the books I care most about. My books seem to vanish, and where they’ve gone nobody knows. So I find myself buying the same book, once, twice, even three times in certain cases. One night not long ago, around midnight, I set out, unsuccessfully, to find the book of David Sylvester’s interviews with the painter Francis Bacon. I wanted to verify a quote I use frequently that I suspected might be his, a quote that exemplifies my view of life in general and, sadly, also the less-than-Apollonian way I run my own:

headline: More Freedom on the Airplane, if Nowhere Else
text: It is sometimes the small events that reveal the really big problems lurking beneath the surface. That’s the case with the Federal Aviation Administration’s recent decision to grant airlines the liberty of allowing the use of electronic devices during takeoff and landing.

headline: The City With a Death Wish in Its Eye
text: FOR 50 years, Dallas has done its best to avoid coming to terms with the one event that made it famous: the assassination of John F. Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963. That’s because, for the self-styled “Big D,” grappling with the assassination means reckoning with its own legacy as the “city of hate,” the city that willed the death of the president.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Nov. 17
text: “There were times I thought we got slapped around unjustly. This one is deserved. It’s on us.”

headline: Ground-Shaking Noise Rocks N.F.L., and Eardrums Take Big Hit
text: National Football League teams are racing this season to secure the title of loudest outdoor stadium in the world.

headline: A Talk With Lars Peter Hansen, Nobel Laureate
text: Lars Peter Hansen, an economist at the University of Chicago, is one of three winners of this year’s Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, along with Eugene F. Fama, a fellow professor at the University of Chicago, and Robert J. Shiller, a professor at Yale.

headline: Lars Peter Hansen, the Nobel Laureate in the Middle
text: Lars Peter Hansen understands why he is being asked, but he isn’t comfortable with the question. “Are financial markets efficient or irrational?” repeats Professor Hansen, a University of Chicago economist. “I don’t really know how to answer that.”

headline: Why Food Stamps Are a Great Investment
text: My Sunday column looks at the issue of food stamps, subject of a forthcoming battle on Capitol Hill. The program will be cut, but it’s unclear by how much. My column argues that it would be short-sighted, as well as cruel, to slash the program, for a couple of reasons. First, almost two-thirds of recipients are children, elderly or disabled. Second, particularly with the children who are recipients, the malnutrition is real and there is mounting evidence that it has long-term effects that leave those children less equipped to succeed at school and live productive lives. I’m particularly swayed by the NBER study that my column cites and links to, indicating that when children under five get food stamps, their long-term health outcomes are better, and they are less likely to end up on welfare. Read the column, but I’d also encourage you to read the study.

headline: In a North Face Jacket, a Reversible Appeal
text: It started when I bought a North Face jacket.

headline: Secular Stagnation, Coalmines, Bubbles, and Larry Summers
text: I’m pretty annoyed with Larry Summers right now. His presentation at the IMF Research Conference is, justifiably, getting a lot of attention. And here’s the thing: I’ve been thinking along the same lines, and have, I think, hinted at this analysis in various writings. But Larry’s formulation is much clearer and more forceful, and altogether better, than anything I’ve done. Curse you, Red Baron Larry Summers!

headline: Child’s Play in a Day’s Work
Syrian Government’s Forces Gain, but a Siege War Goes On
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government forces have recently ousted rebels from a string of suburbs outside Damascus, threatening their yearlong control of territory south of the capital city, cutting supply lines and surrounding strongholds that one fighter called their “last castle” in the area.

headline: Reaching for Silicon Valley

headline: Periods of Joblessness
text: The number of people who have been unemployed for short periods has fallen close to its pre-recession level, but high rates of long-term unemployment persist.

headline: Caught in a Revolving Door of Unemployment
text: On a cold October morning, just after the federal government shutdown came to an end, Jenner Barrington-Ward headed into court in Boston to declare bankruptcy.

headline: Alex Calderwood, Creator and Face of the Unconventional Ace Hotel Chain, Dies at 47
text: Alex Calderwood, a founder of the Ace Hotel chain, whose quirky vintage interiors influenced the industry and became the backdrop for countless Instagram pictures, died on Thursday in London. He was 47.

headline: Success of Chinese Leader’s Ambitious Economic Plan May Rest on Rural Regions
text: HONG KONG — China’s Communist Party has burnished President Xi Jinping’s plans for an economic overhaul with exultant propaganda about a historic turning point. But the success of his proposals, and the long-term health of the Chinese economy, could rest on policy battles reaching down into thousands of towns and villages over land, money and a misshapen fiscal system that has bred public discontent and financial hazards.

headline: New Syrian Refugees Descend on Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Refugees poured into Arsal, a Lebanese town in the Bekaa Valley near Syria, on Saturday amid reports that a battle was beginning along the mountainous border, a sign that the government was broadening its offensive against rebel strongholds.

headline: For Yankees’ Sabathia, It Appears Less (Weight) Is Less (Success)
text: Theories about C. C. Sabathia’s declining performance the last two seasons include the effect of his heavy workload — an average of 227 innings over 16 seasons — and his operation for bone chips in his pitching elbow after the 2012 season.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: For Jets’ Hill, Receptions Are a Waiting Game
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It happens all the time to Stephen Hill. He will be leaning over his pregnant fiancée, talking to her belly, when their dog, a Shih-poo named Boss, bounds over to compete for his attention. Boss barks. Boss snatches a toy and drops it at their feet. Boss barks some more.

text: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: With Dominating Offense, Princeton Trounces Yale and Gains Share of Ivy Title
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Princeton clinched at least a share of its first Ivy League title since 2006 and re-established a long if inconsistent football tradition with a 59-23 homecoming victory against Yale on Saturday.

headline: Challenger Takes Lead Over World Chess Champion
text: For more than three years, Magnus Carlsen, a 22-year-old Norwegian, has been the uncrowned king of chess. It appears increasingly likely that within the next few days, he will officially wear the crown of world champion.

headline: For U.S., Scotland Game Was Chance to Evaluate Young Talent
text: GLASGOW — While much of the soccer world focused on the critical European World Cup qualifying playoff matches Friday night, the United States national team played an exhibition game here that seemed meaningless to just about everyone but a few American players.

headline: Foles’s Resilience Fortifies What Was a Fragile Position
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Michael Vick retreated to the end of Philadelphia’s bench after aggravating his strained left hamstring in the second quarter of the Eagles’ defeat against the Giants on Oct. 27, it seemed more than a game would be lost.

headline: Stretching Field Has Been Challenging for Manning and the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants were nursing a 13-10 lead against the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field when Eli Manning launched a desperation pass toward Hakeem Nicks in the left side of the end zone on the last play of the second quarter.

headline: Runoff Vote Is Completed in Maldives
text: NEW DELHI — The half brother of a former leader of the Maldives appears to have won that country’s runoff election for president on Saturday, defeating a popular favorite and ending a tumultuous voting process halted three times by court orders.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 17
text: President Obama encouraged Americans to blame him – not his party – for the problems with the rollout of the national health care law. Still, some top Democrats are taking to the Sunday shows to defend him and ask for more patience. Plus, one network will dedicate its program to the 50th anniversary of John F. Kennedy’s assassination.

headline: Vowel Play
text: If part of your Sunday morning routine is to sit down to solve the crossword over a cup of tea, you might have a hint to one of today’s clues right under your nose. That’s because a lot of popular breakfast blends include tea grown in ASSAM, a state in northeastern India known for its heavy rainfall and, as a result, prodigious tea output. English breakfast tea, a blend, includes Assam’s offerings. The region comes up today at 42 Down, one of several clues about Indian geography.

headline: With Braves Set to Move, a Broader Look at Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — A collective gasp rose here last week when the Atlanta Braves announced that they were moving to the suburbs. The franchise, after all, has been not only a sports team, but also a mirror of Atlanta’s aspirations.

headline: Fossil-Fuel Emissions by Country
text: The debate over how to address the effects of climate change intensified at a United Nations meeting, but determining each country’s responsibility is a complicated task.

headline: A Russian GPS Using U.S. Soil Stirs Spy Fears
text: WASHINGTON — In the view of America’s spy services, the next potential threat from Russia may not come from a nefarious cyberweapon or secrets gleaned from the files of Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor now in Moscow.

headline: William Weaver, Influential Translator of Modern Italian Literature, Dies at 90
text: William Weaver, whose translations of works by modern masters like Italo Calvino, Umberto Eco and Primo Levi helped lift Italian literature to prominence among readers of English, died on Tuesday in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: How Do Hurricanes Happen?
text: We explain how hurricanes form — and grow — when cold and warm air merge.

headline: Growing Clamor About Inequities of Climate Crisis
text: WARSAW — Following a devastating typhoon that killed thousands in the Philippines, a routine international climate change conference here turned into an emotional forum, with developing countries demanding compensation from the worst polluting countries for damage they say they are already suffering.

headline: Relief Supplies Pour Into Philippines, but Remote Areas Still Suffer
text: QUINAPONDAN, the Philippines — Day after day, the mayor of this storm-shattered town makes the two-hour drive past flattened villages and splintered palm groves to the nearest functioning airport, where he begs for provisions from those who run the relief supply staging area for eastern Samar Island.

headline: Joaquín Hernández Galicia, Oil Workers Chief, Dies at 91
text: Joaquín Hernández Galicia, a sometimes brutal Mexican power broker who earned the loyalty of his country’s vast army of oil workers as both their union boss and benevolent patriarch and who was later imprisoned, some say unjustly, died on Nov. 11 in Tampico, Mexico. He was 91.

headline: Keith Bradsher Answers Readers’ Questions on the Philippines
text: Keith Bradsher, the Hong Kong bureau chief for The New York Times, has been reporting on the aftermath of the powerful typhoon that hit the Philippines on Nov. 8, mostly from Tacloban, the city that was flattened when the storm made landfall. Mr. Bradsher answered a selection of readers’ questions, submitted via Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Life After Exoneration: Building a Business, and Helping Others
text: Christopher Scott planned it all from an uncomfortable state prison bed at the Coffield unit in East Texas, where he would kick back, listen to R & B and daydream:

headline: A Legal Case Waits as Florida State’s Winston Drives Another Rout
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Jameis Winston walked into his postgame news conference Saturday night without the look of someone carrying a burden. His suit fit loosely, he wore flip-flops, his shirttail was out, and his smile was wide. He looked at ease as he sat in a metal folding chair surrounded by reporters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 16, 2013
A Long Shot for Governor Is Suddenly a Presence in the Polls
text: She is barely a blip in the polls, and the odds of her securing the Republican nomination for Texas governor are viewed as vanishingly small. But Lisa Fritsch, a conservative activist, author and former radio show host, suddenly has bragging rights among second-tier candidates trying to make a respectable showing against the primary favorite, Attorney General Greg Abbott.

headline: In Fracas on Health Coverage, Some Democrats Feel Exposed
text: CONCORD, N.H. — The awards ceremony on Friday evening for New Hampshire’s police forces was full of pomp (a bagpipe band in full Scottish regalia), circumstance (tales of heroism and tragedy told to standing ovations), officers in dress uniforms and a show of support from the state’s full congressional delegation.

text: Score one for sincerity.

headline: Aleksandr Serebrov, 69, Dies; Cosmonaut Who Persevered
text: The Soviet Union led humanity into the heavens, sending the first satellite, man and woman into space, and all were duly celebrated by their country. The cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin, the first person to orbit the Earth, on April 12, 1961, received his nation’s highest award, Hero of the Soviet Union.

headline: College Football Around the Country
text: CONNOR HALLIDAY The Washington State quarterback threw for 319 yards and 2 touchdowns to lead the Cougars to a 24-17 victory at Arizona. It was his seventh 300-yard passing game of the season.

headline: In One County, the State’s Political Future
text: FOREST HILL — As she entered a Luby’s on Monday morning in this Democratic enclave southeast of Fort Worth, State Senator Wendy Davis drew a warm welcome from the roughly 100 attendees at a Veterans Day breakfast. Ms. Davis, Democrat of Fort Worth, had filed to run for governor of Texas two days earlier. “The sacrifices you’ve made on behalf of each of us will not be forgotten,” she said. “I will make sure to fight that we do a better job, a dramatically better job.”

headline: Looking Ahead, Perry Turns to the Middle
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Can’t Tell the Players Apart? The Knicks Are the Ones Not Scoring
text: From afar, for much of Saturday’s game, it was hard to tell the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks apart, so analogous were their play, their body language and their attire.
