headline: Melissa Currier, Andrew Briggie
text: Melissa Jean Currier and Andrew Wilson Briggie were married Saturday at the Lord Thompson Manor, an event space in Thompson, Conn. Catherine Nugent-Panepinto, an aunt of the bride and a justice of the Niagara County Supreme Court in New York, officiated.

headline: Diana Cornely, Theodore Clement
text: Diana Michelle Cornely, the daughter of Helen Zwiep Cornely and C. Michael Cornely of Palmetto Bay, Fla., was married in Brooklyn Saturday evening to Theodore Dayton Clement, a son of Sally Dayton Clement and Stephen M. Clement III of Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Lucy Forster-Smith, a Presbyterian minister, led the ceremony in the Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Pavilion and Lobby at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Danielle Ludwin, Zachary Goldberg
text: Dr. Danielle Beth Ludwin and Zachary Lee Goldberg were married Saturday evening at the Brooklake Country Club in Florham Park, N.J. Rabbi David C. Levy officiated.

headline: Eliza Gray, Nicholas Summers
text: Eliza Lindsay Gray, the daughter of C. Boyden Gray of Washington, was married Saturday to Nicholas Robert Summers, the son of K. C. Summers and Robert K. Summers of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Washington.

headline: Seven Personality Traits All Check Out
text: Sarah Brooks From and Rusty Morgen Stahl are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Ellen Lippmann at the Beacon Hebrew Alliance in Beacon, N.Y.

headline: A Dance Straight Into Romance
text: Virginia Duel Crosby and John Joseph Walsh were married Saturday evening at the New York Athletic Club. Kathy A. Bloomfield, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Christian Langbein, Benjamin Bashein
text: Christian Henry Langbein and Benjamin Anderson Bashein were married Friday at their home in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joanna Fernandes, an interfaith minister, officiated.

headline: That Phone Number Was No Prank
text: Watson Morgan Fauth, the daughter of Geren Watson Fauth and John J. Fauth IV of Naples, Fla., was married there Saturday to Kevin Patrick Coleman Jr., a son of Lisa Cullen Coleman and Mr. Coleman of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Michael P. Basden performed the ceremony at Trinity by the Cove Episcopal Church, where he is the rector. The Rev. Leo J. O’Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest and the former president of Georgetown University, took part.

headline: Laura Garvey, Jan Simmonds
text: Laura Elizabeth Garvey and Jan Stefan Simmonds were married Saturday by the Rev. Joseph P. O’Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Paul’s Church in Stone Harbor, N.J.

headline: Jaime Dragoon, Lonnie Passy
text: Jaime Leigh Dragoon and Lonnie Jordan Passy were married Saturday evening at the de Seversky Mansion, an event space in Old Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Ian S. Jacknis officiated.

headline: Lauren Kay, Adam Soufleris
text: Lauren Elizabeth Kay and Adam Mark Soufleris were married Saturday by the Rev. J. Howard Edington, a Presbyterian minister, at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Fla.

headline: Katina Pappas, Nicholas Dermatas
text: Katina Christopher Pappas and Nicholas Spyros Dermatas were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Michael J. Lambakis at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Houston.

headline: U.S.C. Erases Stanford From the National Title Picture
text: LOS ANGELES — As it turns out, a loss to Utah, once the lone blemish on Stanford’s sterling résumé, will have little effect on sorting out the Bowl Championship Series title contenders over the final weeks of the regular season.

headline: Nets, Missing Four Starters, Come Up Short Against Clippers
text: LOS ANGELES — Preventing mass attrition over an 82-game season was always expected to be a lofty challenge for the Nets, a very talented but veteran-heavy team. The injury bug, though, was probably not expected to bite so soon.

headline: Hurdles Seen for Change to China’s One-Child Rule
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government’s decision to relax a decades-old one-child limit on couples has already encountered two problems likely to test dozens of social and economic changes promised by President Xi Jinping — vagaries about implementation and magnified public expectations of even bigger changes ahead.

headline: For Son of a Nazi-Era Dealer, a Private Life Amid a Tainted Trove of Art
text: MUNICH — As an expert in works of art that the Nazis called “degenerate” and in the dealers who traded them during World War II, Vanessa Voigt often wondered what had become of Cornelius Gurlitt, the son of a prominent Nazi-era art dealer and a figure she had come to view as a “phantom.”

headline: With Great Reluctance, India Bids Farewell to Tendulkar
text: MUMBAI — The moment arrived shortly on the stroke of noon on Saturday, as the last West Indian batsman was dismissed at Wankhede Stadium — a moment that had gripped, and been dreaded, by a nation.

headline: New Boeing Jet, 777X, Hits $95 Billion in Orders
text: Three Middle Eastern airlines signed up on Sunday to buy 225 of Boeing’s new 777X jets, helping to bring the initial batch of orders for the plane to $95 billion, a strong start for sales of the commercial jet.

headline: My Father Didn’t ‘Know Best.’ How Will I?
text: I’m sure he thought he was doing the right thing. Father knows best and all that. Or at least better than his 3-year-old son. And his 3-year-old son was afraid of the dark and had to get over it.

headline: 9 Attackers and 2 Officers Reported Killed in Tense Western China
text: BEIJING — Nine assailants were shot and killed Saturday night after they tried to storm a police station in the restive western province of Xinjiang, the state-run Xinhua news agency and Radio Free Asia said. Two police officers also died in the attack.

headline: Childhood Cancer Tied to Heart Risks
text: Children who undergo chemotherapy treatments for cancer have an increased risk of developing early heart disease, a new study suggests.

headline: In Our Pages: November 18
text: 1888: Lack of pocket money pushed soldiers to suicide

headline: U.S. Military Considers a Mission to Train Libyan Security Forces
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The United States military is considering a mission to train Libyan security personnel with the goal of creating a force of 5,000 to 7,000 conventional soldiers and a separate, smaller unit for specialized counterterrorism missions, according to the top officer at the United States Special Operations Command.

headline: Exiting President Reflects on Georgia
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Mikheil Saakashvili, now the former president of Georgia, was still working his famously late nights, apparently intent on squeezing every last minute from the final days of his term. In an interview late last month that began after midnight and could well have stretched until dawn, Mr. Saakashvili boasted that in his decade in office, Georgia had made huge strides toward becoming an established democracy. He profanely dismissed allegations of heavy-handedness and authoritarian abuses, and voiced regret that he had not spent more money on education and less on weapons.

headline: Doris Lessing, Author Who Swept Aside Convention, Is Dead at 94
text: Doris Lessing, the uninhibited and outspoken novelist who won the 2007 Nobel Prize for a lifetime of writing that shattered convention, both social and artistic, died on Sunday at her home in London. She was 94.

headline: Disruptions: A Digital Underworld Cloaked in Anonymity
text: SAN FRANCISCO — So this is where they collared the man they call the Dread Pirate Roberts.

headline: Once a Temple of Corruption, Now a Landmark
text: Tammany Hall is history. Shortly before a Democrat was elected mayor for the first time in 24 years, the former headquarters of the Manhattan Democratic Party organization was declared an official New York City landmark.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Svbscription Luxury Parcel Service
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Me Too! Blogging
text: Aha. I thought I’d been saying something quite a lot like Larry Summers’s remarks at the IMF conference. But these days I write so much that I have trouble keeping up myself.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 3 P.M. (MTV) CLUELESS (1995) Alicia Silverstone (above left, with Stacey Dash) plays a Beverly Hills teenager who doubles as a matchmaker and a makeover expert for the new girl in school (Brittany Murphy), much to the chagrin of her strait-laced stepbrother (Paul Rudd) in this comedy written and directed by Amy Heckerling. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin said that Ms. Silverstone “makes a delectable teen queen in ‘Clueless,’ a candy-colored, brightly satirical showcase for her decidedly visual talents.” Ms. Heckerling “finds herself on friendly territory with the worst Californian academic talent this side of Ridgemont High,” Ms. Maslin wrote. “Surfer burnouts held center stage in that earlier comedy of Ms. Heckerling’s, but this time she has gone hilariously upscale.”

headline: Philippine Community Groups Fill Vacuum in Typhoon’s Aftermath
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Ofelia Casio could be called the mayor of the Tacloban City Convention Center. She was not elected to the position, but there is not much competition for the job.

headline: ‘Best Man’ Has Strong Start at Box Office, but Can’t Overpower ‘Thor’
text: Demonstrating the importance of the right release date, “The Best Man Holiday” radically outdid expectations over the weekend to take in about $30.6 million at North American theaters. Universal Pictures, which spent about $17 million to make the R-rated comedy, had hoped for an opening of around $20 million.

headline: Doris Lessing Has Died
text: Here. Yes, I had a cat named after her (and I just found myself crying thinking about that small loss); I like to think that Lessing, a cat lover, would have approved.

headline: What To Do When You’re Wrong
text: Barry Ritholtz reminds us that we’ve just passed the third anniversary of the debasement-and-inflation letter — the one in which a who’s who of right-wing econopundits warned that quantitative easing would have dire consequences. As Ritholtz notes, they were utterly wrong. Also, rereading the letter now, you have to wonder what kind of economic model they had in mind. They asserted that

headline: Dispute Over Gay Marriage Erupts in Cheney Family
text: Updated, 10:09 p.m. | WASHINGTON — They were the towheaded sisters who tagged along on campaigns, polite and smiling, as their father rose through Wyoming and then Washington politics to become one of the most powerful men in the country.

headline: Bloomberg News Suspends Reporter Whose Article on China Was Not Published
text: BEIJING — A reporter for Bloomberg News who worked on an unpublished article about China, which employees for the company said had been killed for political reasons by top Bloomberg editors, was suspended last week by managers.

headline: Doris Lessing on the Nobel Prize
text: When reporters in 2007 told Ms. Lessing that she had won the Nobel Prize for literature, she said, “I couldn’t care less.”

headline: Passenger Jet Crash in City East of Moscow Kills 50
text: MOSCOW — A passenger jet crashed Sunday evening while landing in Kazan, a regional capital east of Moscow, killing all 50 people on board, emergency officials said.

headline: Guerrilla Group Says It Killed 2 From a Greek Extremist Party in an Athens Suburb
text: ATHENS — A previously unknown guerrilla group has claimed responsibility for killing two members of Greece’s neofascist party Golden Dawn this month and has threatened more attacks against the party.

headline: PlayStation 4 Starts Strong Despite Reports of Defects
text: Sony’s latest video game console, the PlayStation 4, hit the market with a bang, even as the company said it was investigating reports of defective consoles.

headline: Shifting Gears to Explore the Realm of the Oboe
text: Rarely will I spare a thought for a different orchestra while awaiting a performance by the New York Philharmonic. Comparisons are pointless; best to be fully in the moment. Still, glancing through the program notes before a Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, I couldn’t help but reflect on the state of the Minnesota Orchestra, now locked in an acrimonious, costly conflict between management and players.

headline: 50 Years Matter, Even to a Time Lord
text: On Nov. 23, 1963, a Time Lord from the planet Gallifrey landed his blue police box in a British junkyard, and the universe has never been the same. This week, the BBC celebrates the 50th anniversary of “Doctor Who,” ranked as the most successful science-fiction television series by Guinness World Records, as it prepares for the arrival of the Twelfth Doctor (Peter Capaldi) in this year’s Christmas special.

headline: The Commentary of Found Objects
text: Over the past decade and more, the sculptural assemblages of the German artist Isa Genzken have become fixtures on the international circuit — and deservedly so.

headline: Kanye West’s Torment, Onstage
text: A reading from the Gospel according to John: “In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world.” It wouldn’t be a stretch to see somebody hawking that verse on a T-shirt outside Kanye West’s irreverent “Yeezus” tour, which stops in New York this week.

headline: One Composer, Two Boroughs
text: Embracing a landscape where cross-genre collaboration is the rule, the contemporary chamber music series Ear Heart Music continues its season at Roulette on Monday with the Brooklyn dance company Skybetter & Associates, joined by the new Ear Heart Music Ensemble in works set to music by Johann Johannsson, Henryk Gorecki and David Lang. (8 p.m., 509 Atlantic Avenue, near Third Avenue, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, roulette.org, 917-267-0363.)

headline: Gathering What Another Spills
text: The image of people scavenging in trash heaps to survive has enticed documentarians before and resulted in memorable films like Lucy Walker’s “Waste Land,” about a dump outside Rio de Janeiro. But “Good Garbage,” which shows on Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan as part of the Other Israel Film Festival, has an added dimension. The dump pickers it looks in on are Palestinians from the city of Yatta, and the trash heap they work, in the Hebron Hills, includes the discards of more prosperous Israelis.

headline: An Ode to Joy, Choreographically
text: Mark Morris created “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” during the three years his company was resident at the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels. It was 1988, he was 32 and, for the first time, had an 1,100-seat opera house, an orchestra and a costume department at his disposal. He used it all with relish. “L’Allegro,” which returns to Lincoln Center this week, wasn’t immediately acclaimed by the local critics. (Mr. Morris’s biographer, Joan Acocella, quotes one review: “Where is the profundity?”) But it has become Mr. Morris’s most famous piece, celebrated for its innocence, exuberance and how it suggests the physical embodiment of ideal worlds. The work is set to the 1740 Handel oratorio from which it takes its title, and which uses the texts of Milton’s “L’Allegro” and “Il Penseroso,” portraits of the joyful and contemplative minds. Filled with nymphs and shepherds, gods and humans, hunters and lovers, the dance is beautiful, lavish and funny. It is, as Ms. Acocella writes, “a hymn to the unity of poetry, music and dance.” (7:30 p.m. Thursday to Saturday, David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600, davidhkochtheater.com.)

headline: Ravaged Philippine City Ponders a Grim Road Ahead
text: GUIUAN, the Philippines — The Swedish Air Force brought German relief workers. The Australians delivered hulking pallets of water and food. The United States Navy dispatched so many supplies-laden Ospreys, Seahawks and C-130s on Sunday that the commanding officer in charge of the airport here lost count.

headline: A New Home for Recycling
text: A look inside the new Sims Municipal Recycling Facility in Brooklyn.

headline: A Grace Note for a Gritty Business
text: Recycling in New York is a scrappy business. Billions have gone toward building water tunnels, power plants, subways and sewage treatment facilities, but little toward an infrastructure of recycling. In turn, New Yorkers have been slow to separate bottles and cans the way they flip a light switch or swipe a MetroCard: Recycling remains less an everyday fact of life than a do-good option, like tipping the mail carrier at the holidays.

headline: On the Ark, Two by Two, Creatures (and Performers) Great and Small
text: Benjamin Britten loved composing pieces for children, not just for children to enjoy but also to perform. There is no better example that “Noye’s Fludde” (“Noah’s Flood”), a 60-minute opera based on a 15th-century mystery play, written for amateurs, especially children, with professionals mixed in. This telling of the biblical story was first performed in 1958 at Orford Church in Suffolk, England. It was presented as part of Britten’s Aldeburgh Festival with artists from the English Opera Group along with a large local cast, including a children’s choir.

headline: Scores of Tornadoes Slam Midwest States
text: Severe storms moved through the Midwest on Sunday, leveling towns, killing at least six people in Illinois and injuring dozens more, and causing thousands of power failures across the region.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Element of Surprise
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Washington Insurance Official Is Ousted
text: The insurance commissioner for the District of Columbia was dismissed from his job just a day after he publicly questioned a decision by President Obama to reverse a provision of the Affordable Care Act, a person with knowledge of the events said on Sunday.

headline: After Night of Fun and Games, Jets Find Game Is No Fun
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — The night before the Jets’ first game in two weeks, Coach Rex Ryan addressed his players and canceled their offensive and defensive meetings. He had a surprise: a trip to Dave & Buster’s for some arcade fun.

headline: Bitcoin Scandal Reflects Popularity of Virtual Currency in China
text: On Oct. 26, the website of Global Bond Limited, a Chinese exchange platform for bitcoins, the booming digital currency, suddenly went dead. Then, without warning, GBL’s roughly 500 remaining investors were kicked out of the company’s official QQ group, a social media platform that the company was using for investor relations. By nightfall, the scale of the swindle was made public – 25 million renminbi, or $4.1 million – making it one of the largest bitcoin fraud cases since the currency’s inception four years ago.

headline: Playing in Six Hearts After West Leads a Diamond
text: Some players have an eye for a good deal for a column. One is Karen Allison of Las Vegas, a winner of five national championships and a silver medal in the 1994 McConnell World Women’s Teams Championship.

headline: Carol Channing to Celebrate ‘Hello, Dolly!’ Anniversary
text: Carol Channing, above, is set to return for a one-night engagement commemorating the 50th anniversary of the opening of “Hello, Dolly!” The event’s producer, Daniel Nardicio, announced on Sunday that the transgender performer Justin Vivian Bond would host the celebration on Jan. 20 at Town Hall in Manhattan, and that it would include filmed celebrity tributes, footage from Ms. Channing’s career and video questions submitted in advance. Tickets go on sale on Monday. Ms. Channing, 92, was previously interviewed by Mr. Bond in August at the Ice Palace in Cherry Grove, on Fire Island, as part of Mr. Nardicio’s Icon Series.

headline: A Rookie Going Through Initiation With the Nets Is Proving to Be an Inspiration
text: LOS ANGELES — With reporters crammed around him, the Nets rookie Mason Plumlee was a dozen words into his first response when the discussion was punctured from afar.

headline: A Glittery Prelude to Oscars’ Big Night
text: LOS ANGELES — Dark horses. Underdogs. Some who would be thrilled just for a nomination.

headline: Warnings of New Turmoil as Pakistan Pursues a Treason Case for Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s government said Sunday that it was initiating a treason prosecution of the country’s former ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, in what would be a groundbreaking, if politically charged, assertion of civilian supremacy over the powerful Pakistani military.

headline: Turning Sleuth, With Reliable Dog in Tow
text: Theresa Schwegel is an Edgar-winning crime writer whose Chicago police stories are more nuanced and impassioned than most books of their genre. None of that has brought her much attention, and neither will the nondescript title of her fifth novel, “The Good Boy” — until readers figure out what it means. The story is well-woven enough to contain three contenders for “Good Boy” honors.

headline: Bacardi Campaign Focuses on Resilience, Rather Than Rum
text: IT is the time of the year when Bacardi typically promotes its recipe for holiday punch, but a new advertising campaign is instead promoting how the rum brand rolls with the punches.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 18
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Optimism Outlasted a Lifetime of Horrors
text: The Czech writer Ivan Klima’s new book, a memoir, is called “My Crazy Century.” It begins in 1941, when together with his family Mr. Klima, who until then hadn’t even been aware that he was Jewish, was imprisoned in the Nazi camp at Terezin, and it concludes with the Velvet Revolution of 1989, ending years of dictatorship and repression. “Sometimes, it was funny crazy,” Mr. Klima said last week, while visiting New York. “But mostly, it was crazy crazy.”

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 18
text: SAC TRIAL Jury selection is scheduled to begin Tuesday in the trial of Michael S. Steinberg, the most senior employee at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors indicted in insider trading. Federal prosecutors have accused Mr. Steinberg of trading on secret information about technology companies. Though SAC has been at the center of the government’s insider trading investigation for years, Mr. Steinberg is the first former SAC employee to stand trial. Six others, including the fund itself, have pleaded guilty.

headline: A Kentucky Singer Faces Down a Manhattan Crowd
text: There is no end to the variety of night life in New York, but it remains an open question whether this city could ever be home to a genuine honky-tonk. Native to the South, that would be loosely defined as part bar, part performance venue, part staging ground for a battle royal. The music matters, but it’s only one element of the tapestry.

headline: A Love Affair That Burned for Centuries, at Least in Song
text: At a concert of late medieval and early Renaissance vocal music presented in a church, you might expect to hear churchy music. And there was much of that in the second half of the Orlando Consort’s program at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square on Saturday evening, presented by the Miller Theater.

headline: History Comes to Life With Tweets From Past
text: LIKE watching a building collapse in slow motion, a Twitter account run by a group of German historians provides hour-by-hour updates of the horrors of Kristallnacht, which culminated in a night of anti-Jewish terror 75 years ago in Nazi Germany that plunged the country on a path to the Holocaust.

headline: Tapping Unseen Forces in the Dungeon
text: The Underground Theater at the Abrons Arts Center often goes by affectionate characterizations like “dungeon” and “cave.” Its subterranean aura, murky lighting and pockmarked concrete walls ensure that whatever happens will seem a little bit creepy. So it was a fitting location for Arturo Vidich’s “142241,” a duet (or quartet, if you count the audience participants) that attempted, as a news release put it, “to tune in to the invisible worlds that influence this world, if you believe in that sort of thing.”

headline: To the Sounds of Stevie Wonder, a Dance Baptism for a New Theater
text: BRIC House, the snazzily redesigned headquarters of BRIC, the venerable Brooklyn arts organization, opened last month, but it wasn’t until Wednesday night that the building’s flexible performance space had its first dance show. There couldn’t have been a better first choice than the Brooklyn company of Ronald K. Brown. This is dancing that consecrates. The warmth and artistry and infectious joy made this house into a home.

headline: Put Another Layer On
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Greetings! Did everyone have a good week? Thanks again to Tom “Trust Me, He’s Dapper” Gaffney for the chance to take some much-needed R&R.

headline: Offense, Not Defense, May Be the Knicks’ Biggest Concern
text: Ever since the Knicks elevated Mike Woodson to head coach after the March 2012 dismissal of Mike D’Antoni, Woodson has preached defense, toughness and rebounding. These are terms that resonate with Knicks fans, who cherished the gritty success of the teams led by Pat Riley and Jeff Van Gundy. After a 110-90 home loss to the Atlanta Hawks on Saturday, Woodson and the Knicks returned to the theme of defensive identity.

headline: Former President of Chile Poised to Regain Her Seat
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Michelle Bachelet, who was president of Chile from 2006 to 2010, far outpolled her opponents for the office in the general election on Sunday, after campaigning on promises of major changes in education, health, social security and taxes. But she fell short of the majority needed to avoid a runoff election in December.

headline: In the Maelstrom of Harlem’s Gentrification, and Nothing Is Sacred
text: We should not like Napoleon, a vicious Harlem landlord.

headline: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ to Get a CBS Spinoff
text: The CBS comedy “How I Met Your Mother” may be ending this spring, but the show could continue at least in spirit: CBS has ordered a pilot for a spinoff, “How I Met Your Dad.” The development was first reported by Deadline.com and was confirmed by the series creators Carter Bays and Craig Thomas on their Twitter feeds. Mr. Bays said the show would feature a new setting and new characters. The pilot will put a female spin on the original concept and is to be written by Emily Spivey, who created the NBC comedy “Up All Night.” It’s no surprise that CBS want to keep “How I Met Your Mother” going in some form. The ninth and final season has averaged 8.2 million total viewers this fall and has remained among the 10 highest-rated broadcast programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the category most cherished by advertisers. It is also the third highest-rated comedy in that demographic, finishing behind only “The Big Bang Theory” on CBS and “Modern Family” on ABC.

headline: Fresh Life via Netflix for ‘The Killing’
text: “The Killing,” the twice-canceled AMC cop drama, has been renewed — this time by Netflix — for a fourth season. Netflix announced that this six-episode season would be a streaming exclusive and would be made available simultaneously around the world; AMC is not involved in the deal. The first three seasons are already available on Netflix, and the company said that the fourth would be the last one. The principal creative team and cast are set to return, including the series creator and show runner, Veena Sud, and its stars Mireille Enos and Joel Kinnaman. “The Killing” was canceled by AMC for the first time in July 2012 after its second season, but it was resurrected in January for a third season. It returned with little fanfare both critically and in the ratings — the last three episodes of Season 3 on AMC hovered around 1.5 million total viewers — and was promptly canceled again in September. “The Killing” was originally based on the Danish series “Forbrydelsen.”

headline: Facebook, Still Dominant, Strives to Keep Cachet
text: When Evan Spiegel peered into a crystal ball to divine a future for his company, Snapchat, he did not see Facebook.

headline: A Tiny Label Is Behind an a Cappella Group’s Success
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — If you stopped 100 people on the manicured Sony Pictures lot here and asked them to point you toward Shelly Bunge’s office, they would most likely give you the same blank stare. Who?

headline: Larger Prize for Tucker Award
text: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation said on Sunday that it had increased the size of the cash prize given to the winner of the annual Richard Tucker Award to $50,000 from $30,000. As previously announced, the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard is the 2013 recipient at the ceremony, scheduled for Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center; this year is the centenary of Tucker’s birth. The award goes to an artist considered on the verge of a major international career. Ms. Leonard is a regular at the Metropolitan Opera and has recently performed in productions of Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” and Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites.”

headline: Disney Struggles to Make Its Free Gaming Apps Pay
text: LOS ANGELES — Two months ago, Disney released a sequel to Where’s My Water?, a hit smartphone game about a showering alligator. Hopes were high: Disney had pointed to the original game as evidence of overdue traction in mobile gaming.

headline: In Charge of the Macy’s Parade, but Not the Thanksgiving Dinner
text: Amy Kule spent a couple of afternoons with Maureen O’Hara in the late 1990s.

headline: A Lesson From Cuba on Race
text: In a recent article for The Stone, Gary Gutting posed a challenge. He urged readers to  look “past the outrage on race” provoked by the Trayvon Martin case and to focus on what he aptly described as the “deeper issue” that sustains the edifice of racial inequality — our unjust economic system. Under this system, people compete for basic goods and services in what seems to be a fair and non-discriminating market. But since they enter this market from vastly different social circumstances, competition is anything but fair. Those who already possess goods have a much better chance of renewing their access to them, whereas those who don’t have little chance of ever getting them.

headline: The Real Mayors of New York
text: Voters elected Bill de Blasio, but New York has always been a city of unofficial mayors.

headline: Suzanne Bianchi, 61, Who Analyzed Family Time, Dies
text: Suzanne M. Bianchi, a social scientist who explored the changing landscape of late-20th-century American families, tracing how divorce, the shrinking gender gap and women’s careers affected children, parents and their households (“Is Anyone Doing the Housework?” was the title of one of her papers), died on Nov. 4 in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 61.

headline: Estimating Risk
text: New guidelines recommend statins for people whose risk of a heart attack or stroke in the next 10 years is 7.5 percent or higher. But calculators to estimate a person’s 10-year risk may overestimate the actual risk of heart attack or stroke, according to an analysis of three large studies.

headline: At 70, Still Fighting to Live Independently
text: James Leak turned 70 last week, but he only recently started learning to read and write.

headline: Afghan Talks at Impasse Before Vote, Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite recent optimism about talks over a future American military presence here, two senior Afghan officials said on Sunday that the negotiations were at a profound impasse, days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet to seek popular support for a deal.

headline: Extension of Benefits for Jobless Is Set to End
text: WASHINGTON — Unless Congress acts, during the last week of December an estimated 1.3 million people will lose access to an emergency program providing them with additional weeks of jobless benefits. A further 850,000 will be denied benefits in the first quarter of 2014.

headline: Rescuing the Philippines
text: Aid to typhoon victims comes in at a trickle.

headline: An Inadvertent Paean to Jerry Bruckheimer, From the Studio That Ousted Him
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s not just a matter of size, though a new coffee-table retrospective of Jerry Bruckheimer’s film and television career — “Jerry Bruckheimer: When Lightning Strikes, Four Decades of Filmmaking” — certainly has heft.

headline: Pressure Builds to Finish Volcker Rule on Wall St. Oversight
text: The Obama administration, currently stumbling through the health care overhaul, has reached a critical stage in its other signature effort: reining in Wall Street.

headline: Vote on Alcohol Sales Divides a Utah Town Where Few Drink
text: HYDE PARK, Utah — When a convenience store chain approached city officials here last year about selling beer, people knew a fight was coming.

headline: From Winless Start to Winning Streak, Giants Have Climbed Back Into Division Race
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants had a fourth-quarter lead but Green Bay had whittled the edge to a single touchdown. As the Packers’ offense took over again, a tension was developing inside MetLife Stadium, the kind of unease that has dogged a season that began with comprehensive, aggregate failure.

headline: A New Path
text: Amanda Rogers, 32, became addicted to painkillers after both her mother and stepfather died from overdoses. Now, she is stable in her recovery and taking buprenorphine daily.

headline: Todd Smith
text: Todd Smith on taking buprenorphine after an addiction to painkillers.

headline: N.B.A. Will Try to Avoid Repeat of Fashion Faux Pas at Garden
text: It did not take long on Saturday night for fans and commentators at Madison Square Garden to realize something was amiss between the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks. Their uniforms looked alike. Too alike.

headline: The Existential Stress of Waiting for ...
Joellen Trippett
text: In a therapy session at Chestnut Ridge, Joellen Trippett explains how her life has changed since becoming a buprenorphine patient and why she never wants to return to a life of addiction.

text: Dr. Sullivan explaining how he gauges a patient’s recovery.

headline: Dr. Allan Clark
text: Dr. Allan Clark discussing how his experience with addiction has helped him relate to his patients.

headline: At Clinics, Tumultuous Lives and Turbulent Care
text: PITTSBURGH — The patient is an addict. His doctor is an addict, too. Over the last decade, both men hit their own versions of rock bottom. For the patient, it was the concrete floor of a jail where he writhed in withdrawal. For the doctor, it was the food stamp office where, his career as a child psychiatrist in tatters, he ashamedly sought help.

headline: Developing a Fax Machine to Copy Life on Mars
text: MOJAVE NATIONAL PRESERVE, Calif. — J. Craig Venter, the maverick scientist, is looking for a new world to conquer — Mars. He wants to detect life on Mars and bring it to Earth using a device called a digital biological converter, or biological teleporter.

headline: Toy Story
text: MY model American entrepreneur of the moment is Cheong Choon Ng. He has not attracted a $3 billion bid from Facebook, like the young inventors of the photo-sharing service Snapchat. Wall Street is not cooking up an I.P.O. But Ng is a star in my household. He is the creator of the Rainbow Loom, which in the middle-schooler market is the hottest device not called iSomething. If you have noticed that half the children in America — and a fair number of adults — seem to be sporting bracelets that are braids of brightly colored rubber bands, then you have seen the fruits of the Rainbow Loom.

headline: Crashing the Boards and Cracking the Books
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — Her Olympic hopes seemingly extinguished, Kate Buesser’s idea of mucking it up in the corners involved a lobster boat, not hockey.

headline: West Faces Challenge in Moving Syrian Chemical Arms Through Battlefields
text: WASHINGTON — A plan announced over the weekend for getting the bulk of Syria’s chemical weapons out of the country in coming weeks has raised major concerns in Washington, because it involves transporting the weapons over roads that are battlegrounds in the country’s civil war and loading them onto a ship that has no place to go.

headline: A Permanent Slump?
text: Spend any time around monetary officials and one word you’ll hear a lot is “normalization.” Most though not all such officials accept that now is no time to be tightfisted, that for the time being credit must be easy and interest rates low. Still, the men in dark suits look forward eagerly to the day when they can go back to their usual job, snatching away the punch bowl whenever the party gets going.

headline: Week After Shooting, Life Goes On at Bryant Park
text: The line outside the Bryant Park skating rink on Saturday night was at least 100 deep, the soon-to-be skaters waiting their turn as a seemingly endless flow of people circumambulated the ice, racing, kissing, all bathed in a pink light.

headline: At U.S.C., the Cookie Doesn’t Crumble; It Bonds
text: LOS ANGELES — It started with dessert. When Ed Orgeron stepped in as the interim coach at Southern California after Lane Kiffin was fired in late September, one of the first moves he made was restoring sweets to the football team’s training table.

headline: Lincoln’s Sound Bite: Have Faith in Democracy
text: The surprisingly short story of the Gettysburg Address is that it was a surprisingly short speech — 270 words or so — delivered by Abraham Lincoln as part of the dedication ceremonies for the Soldiers’ National Cemetery at Gettysburg, on Nov. 19, 1863, four and a half months after the climactic battle of the American Civil War.

headline: Where St. Nicholas Has His Black Pete(s), Charges of Racism Follow
text: AMSTERDAM — St. Nicholas entered Amsterdam twice this weekend.

headline: Lesson Is Seen in Failure of Law on Medicare in 1989
text: WASHINGTON — Angry Americans voice outrage at being asked to pay more for health coverage. Lawmakers and the White House say the public just doesn’t appreciate the benefits of the new health law. Opponents clamor for repeal before the program fully kicks in.

headline: For Assaulted Veterans, a Second Battle
text: For military veterans, the trauma of rape, sexual assault or sexual harassment can be as devastating as combat wounds. But these injuries, while real, are often invisible, and the circumstances behind them shrouded in secrecy and denial. The men and women who endure such crimes often have to fight a second battle, to convince the Department of Veterans Affairs that they are disabled and entitled to compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety and other afflictions resulting from service-connected sexual violence.

headline: A Deep-Water Diver From Brooklyn Dies After Trying for a Record
text: LONG ISLAND, Bahamas — As Nicholas Mevoli lay on his back, floating in the azure sea, attempting to relax, his exhales were audible. The countdown had begun, and he prepared to dive into Dean’s Blue Hole, hoping to reach 72 meters on a single inhalation, with no fins or supplemental oxygen. He began sipping the air, attempting to pack as much oxygen in his lungs as possible.

headline: Popular Demand
text: For most cooks, Thanksgiving is the most complicated meal of the year.

headline: Lincoln at Gettysburg Long Ago
text: Garry Wills once wrote that “all modern political prose descends from the Gettysburg Address,” which was read aloud by a bareheaded man, exhausted and ill, before a black-suited crowd 150 years ago. Mr. Wills chose the right word: “descends.” Lincoln’s speech is the pinnacle of American civic utterance. His words honoring the dead at Gettysburg on Nov. 19, 1863, do what words are only rarely able to do. They invoke an eloquent silence.

headline: Libyan Official Abducted Amid Unrest in Capital
text: CAIRO — The deputy chief of Libya’s intelligence service was abducted from the parking lot of the airport in Tripoli on Sunday afternoon as a standoff between militias and a general strike against militia rule virtually shut down the city.

headline: Princeton University Considers Use of Foreign Meningitis Vaccine
text: Fearing the spread of a meningitis outbreak that has caused seven people at Princeton University to be hospitalized this year, university officials have warned students to stop sharing drinks and to avoid kissing. Bright orange posters urge students to “keep healthy and carry on,” and red cups labeled “Mine. Not Yours” serve as reminders not to share drinks at parties.

headline: The Shame of American Health Care
text: Even as Americans struggle with the changes required by health care reform, an international survey released last week by the Commonwealth Fund, a research organization, shows why change is so necessary.

headline: Thailand’s Latest Troubles
text: Thailand is again on the verge of political turmoil. An ill-conceived amnesty bill pushed through the lower house of Parliament by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra earlier this month brought many thousands of demonstrators for and against the government into the streets of Bangkok, putting the country’s fragile democracy in peril.

headline: Bomb at Base Kills at Least 31 Syrian Troops
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 31 Syrian troops, including four senior officers, were killed on Sunday in a bombing that collapsed a building on a government military base just north of Damascus, the Syrian capital, an antigovernment monitoring group said. It was one of the deadliest attacks on government soldiers in recent months.

headline: Just for Chiefs Fans, a Welcome Taste of Kansas City in Queens
text: Few bar-stool debates are more tiresome than arguments over which team’s fans have suffered the most. But it’s hard to imagine a season much worse than the one Kansas City Chiefs fans endured last year. On the field, the team had the N.F.L.’s worst record; off it, a starting linebacker killed his girlfriend before shooting himself in front of the coach and general manager.

headline: Design Contest Seeks Just the Right Chair for Battery Park
text: One looks like a pale blue flower with five round petals. Another evokes a piece of playground equipment. A third shape shifts as needed — upright chair one direction, chaise longue the other. They are designs for a movable, stackable, weatherproof chair, one of which will eventually grace a new three-acre green at the Battery, the 22-acre park at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Iraq Bombings
text: BAGHDAD — Explosions targeting public markets and security checkpoints killed 44 people across Iraq on Sunday, including 20 in a northern Turkmen-dominated city, and wounded over 100, police and medical officials said.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Risk Calculator for Cholesterol Appears Flawed
text: Last week, the nation’s leading heart organizations released a sweeping new set of guidelines for lowering cholesterol, along with an online calculator meant to help doctors assess risks and treatment options. But, in a major embarrassment to the health groups, the calculator appears to greatly overestimate risk, so much so that it could mistakenly suggest that millions more people are candidates for statin drugs.

headline: Bumping Off Kin, a Song in Your Heart
text: Serial killers may be all the rage on bookshelves and television screens — so ubiquitous, you’d think they made up a major demographic of the world population — but they are comparatively rare in the peppier precincts of musical theater. Now, after a long dry spell, Broadway has a deadly sociopath to call its own. Please give a hearty welcome to Monty Navarro, the conniving killer who helps turn murder most foul into entertainment most merry in the new musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 17, 2013
The Revolution Will Have Live Music
text: Among the shouts and chants from a picket line on the Upper East Side on a recent evening were a few sounds of a less discordant nature: the thump of a bass drum, the toot of a trombone, the melodious drone of a clarinet.

headline: Inland, No Aid for Survivors of Typhoon
text: JARO, Philippines — Even as a major international aid effort has begun to take hold around the coastal city of Tacloban, the situation grimly differs just a few miles inland, where large numbers of injured or sick people in interior villages shattered by Typhoon Haiyan more than a week ago have received no assistance.

headline: When Medical Experts Disagree
text: How should doctors and patients react to the latest findings that come out about health concerns? How do you know whom to trust?

headline: Start-Up Leaders Recall Choice to Cash In or Stay Independent
text: Nine start-up founders recounted the moment they had to decide whether to sell or stay independent — when the money was on the table and the future was unpredictable.

headline: Rangers Have Lots of Chances but Don’t Capitalize on Any of Them
text: For all their strong play of late, the Rangers still have trouble beating good teams. Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, they took 37 shots against the Los Angeles Kings and sometimes dominated the game. But they could not produce a goal against the Kings, the 2012 Stanley Cup champions, despite having two separate two-man advantages, and lost, 1-0.

headline: French Leader Assures Israel He Will Keep Pressure on Iran
text: JERUSALEM — As France and other world powers prepared to resume talks with Iran this week on its disputed nuclear program, the French president, François Hollande, arrived in Israel on Sunday for a three-day visit and was warmly embraced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has been conducting a lonely campaign against a deal he calls “bad” and “dangerous.”

headline: Pakistan Has Export Plans for Jet Fighter Produced With China
text: The market for the JF-17 fighter appears to be expanding in unexpected ways. At the Dubai Airshow, which opened on Sunday, the Pakistan Aeronautical Complex had a freshly minted example on display, complete with an array of Chinese-made missiles and bombs.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 1 P.M. (TMC) THE FRIGHTENERS (1996) Michael J. Fox, left, stars as Frank Bannister, a private detective who can see and interact with ghosts in this spook fest directed by Peter Jackson. Frank normally uses his paranormal skills to cheat the unsuspecting people of a small town out of their money. But when he is blamed for a series of mysterious deaths, he searches for the real killer and ends up face to face with the grim reaper. “With material for a half-dozen different movies here, Mr. Jackson has no trouble keeping ‘The Frighteners’ spinning,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Phantoms skitter across the screen in record numbers, and Mr. Fox presides over the story with dependable skill.”

headline: Narendra Modi Casts B.J.P. as Tech-Friendly Party During Bangalore Rally
text: BANGALORE — In his first campaign stop in southern India, Narendra Modi, the opposition candidate for prime minister, appealed to voters in this outsourcing hub on Sunday by characterizing his Bharatiya Janata Party as the champion of information technology and the governing Congress Party as the enemy of social media.

text: DENVER — Two months ago, nobody thought the Denver Broncos and the Kansas City Chiefs would be on a collision course toward a midseason showdown with sole possession of the A.F.C. West lead on the line.

headline: Celebrating Elsa Schiaparelli
text: PARIS — “I would come in and she would be in her bed, with all these heart-shaped, shocking pink pillows,” the actress Marisa Berenson said about her grandmother Elsa Schiaparelli, the great couturier of the 1930s. “She had beautiful skin and beautiful shoulders and sexy nighties that were all embroidered.

headline: How Good Are You at Waiting for What You Really Want?
text: A cookie before dinner, news that is sure to affect your future, an invitation to spend time with a new friend or love interest: it can be hard to wait for the things you want.

headline: Bill Gates Can’t Build a Toilet
text: IN addition to eradicating polio in India and starting the personal computer revolution, the Seattle Superman of our age has managed to make going to the bathroom a cause célèbre. Five years ago, if I’d told people I worked on toilets, they would have surely assumed I was a plumber. Now, they exclaim: “Oh! Isn’t Bill Gates into that?”

headline: Challenge for the Government: 4 Million Are Displaced, and Hunger Grows
text: BASEY, the Philippines — When Typhoon Haiyan hit this coastal town, residents ran for Saint Michael the Archangel Church. Now, 10 days later, more than 100 of them remain.

headline: Lloyds Bank to Sell Asset Management Unit for $1.06 Billion
text: LONDON — The Lloyds Banking Group said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its asset management arm to Aberdeen Asset Management in stock and cash deal worth up to 660 million pounds, or $1.06 billion.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Luke Mogelson on the Risks of a Refugee Voyage
text: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | Luke Mogelson, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about Afghan and Iranian migrants attempting to reach Australia from Indonesia by boat. He last wrote for the magazine on the Afghan National Army. He is the co-founder and editor of an online magazine called Razistan.

headline: The Sleeper Cell That Wasn’t
text: Six days after 9/11, the F.B.I.’s raid on a Detroit sleeper cell signaled America’s resolve to fight terrorism. But, despite a celebrated conviction, there was one problem — they’d gotten it wrong.

headline: The Demise and Afterlife of the ‘Detroit Sleeper Cell’ Case
text: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of the “Detroit Sleeper Cell,” the first terrorism trial after 9/11. Here, a reporter who covers terrorism for The Times recalls the charged atmosphere at the time and the consequences for the Justice Department.

headline: Hooligans, Hooligans, Everywhere
text: MOSCOW — There are many hooligans in Russia, apparently, and judging by the way the state deals with them, they are extremely dangerous people. With jail sentences averaging three years and potentially reaching seven, they are treated as though they pose a greater threat to Russian society than drunk drivers and possibly as great a threat as murderers, who get sentences in the same range.

headline: R.B.S. Seeks Buyer for Unit

headline: A Conversation With: Novelist Tash Aw
text: Tash Aw is a writer of Malaysian origin who was born in Taiwan, grew up in Kuala Lumpur and currently resides in London. He is the author of “The Harmony Silk Factory” (2005), which won the Whitbread Book Award, given to authors based in Britain and Ireland, as well as the Commonwealth Writers’ Prize, and of “Map of the Invisible World” (2009). His most recent novel, “Five Star Billionaire,” which was released this year, was placed on the long list for the Man Booker Prize, Britain’s top literary award. The book captures the changes sweeping across China through the lives of five Malaysian-Chinese immigrants who move to Shanghai in pursuit of the Chinese dream.

headline: Abducted Libyan Official Is Released
text: CAIRO — The deputy chief of Libya’s intelligence service was temporarily abducted from the parking lot of the airport in Tripoli on Sunday as a standoff between militias and a general strike against militia rule virtually shut down the city.

headline: Salesforce Making Business Software More Social
text: Salesforce.com on Monday made what could turn out to be one of the biggest changes in the cloud computing pioneer’s history.

headline: Pressure to Finish Volcker Rule Quickly
text: The Obama administration has reached a critical stage in its effort to rein in Wall Street, Peter Eavis and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The push to reshape financial regulation hinges on negotiations in the coming weeks over the Volcker Rule, which bans banks from trading for their own gain.

headline: Japan Pitches Its High-Speed Train With an Offer to Finance
text: TSURU, Japan — As the world’s fastest train raced through central Japan, former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York hoisted his 6-foot-5 frame into the aisle and marveled at the smoothness of the ride.

headline: Daily Report: For Start-Up Leaders, to Sell or Hold Is a Tough Call
text: Were the young founders of Snapchat, a mobile-messaging start-up, delusional for turning down a multibillion-dollar buyout offer? Greedy to think they might get more later? Or courageous to chase their dreams?

headline: Top U.N. Official Warns of Coal Risks
text: WARSAW — Most of the world’s coal needs to stay in the ground if greenhouse gas emissions are to be held in check, the United Nations’ top climate change official said Monday in a speech to coal industry executives here in Poland, one of the most coal-dependent nations on Earth.

headline: Weighing Free Speech in Refusal to Photograph Lesbian Couple’s Ceremony
text: WASHINGTON — A New Mexico law forbids businesses open to the public to discriminate against gay people. Elaine Huguenin, a photographer, says she has no problem with that — so long as it does not force her to say something she does not believe.

headline: Chief of Newark Arts Center’s Development Unit Is Stepping Down
text: Lawrence P. Goldman, the founding chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark, is stepping down as president and chief executive of Theater Square Development Company, a subsidiary of the center that is focused on developing adjacent land.

headline: High Winning Bid for Photo by Mao’s Wife
text: A black-and-white photograph of a landscape snapped by Mao Zedong’s fourth wife, Jiang Qing, has sold for 391,000 renminbi, or $64,000, about 20 times the presale estimate, at Huachen Auctions in Beijing. The unexpectedly high price provides another sign of a bullish market for Mao-era art, driven by the competition among private collectors and public museums and libraries that are seeking to enhance their holdings.

headline: Tibetan Monastery’s Prayer Hall Lost in Fire
text: The main prayer hall of a 16th-century Tibetan Buddhist monastery burned to the ground in a fire set off by a short circuit in an electrical appliance, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

headline: Advent International to Take Dutch Firm Private for $1.58 Billion
text: Updated, 9:51 a.m. | LONDON — The private equity firm Advent International has reached a deal to take private Unit4, a software provider based in the Netherlands, for 1.17 billion euros in cash, or $1.58 billion.

headline: The New Keynesian Case for Fiscal Policy (Wonkish)
text: It’s been a bit funny on the academic front being a Keynesian during a Keynesian crisis. Much of the academic profession decided more than 30 years ago that the whole thing was nonsense and what we needed was an equilibrium model of the business cycle. By the time the utter failure of the equilibrium project became apparent, you had a whole generation of economists who knew that Keynesianism of any form was nonsense based on what they had heard somewhere, so they didn’t read any of the stuff, old or new — and were flabbergasted to learn that there was in fact an extensive New Keynesian literature that provided a justification for fiscal policy at the zero lower bound.

headline: Justices Reject Challenge to N.S.A. Program
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned away an unusual challenge to a National Security Agency surveillance program.

headline: Fuel Removal Underway at Crippled Plant in Japan
text: TOKYO — The operator of the crippled Fukushima Daiichi power plant on Monday began removing nuclear fuel assemblies from a storage pool atop one of the site’s blown-out reactor buildings, a delicate yet critical operation that could help reduce risks at the plant.

headline: New Prize Goes to Author of Book on Vietnam
text: Fredrik Logevall has won the first American Library in Paris Book Award for his “Embers of War: The Fall of an Empire and the Making of America’s Vietnam.” The library was founded and originally run by American expatriates in Paris in 1920, with books that had been sent by American libraries to soldiers fighting in World War I. It plans to offer the $5,000 award annually for what its jury considers the most distinguished book of the year about France or the encounters between France and the United States.

headline: Dried Porcini Consommé
text: I could drink this refreshing consommé for lunch every day. It makes a very light and satisfying appetizer soup or first course.

headline: Puréed Mushroom Soup
text: Thick and creamy, with no cream, this tastes so much richer than it is. I use a small amount of milk to thin out the soup, but you can also use stock to thin it, if you don’t want to include any dairy.

headline: Walkabout: Europe Is Expected to Loosen Restrictions on Electronic Devices

headline: Tate Britain Completes Renovation
text: LONDON — The $72 million renovation of the Tate Britain museum by the architectural firm Caruso St. John is complete, “on time and on budget,” said Penelope Curtis, the director of the museum, at a showing on Monday, the day before the museum will open its new areas to the public.

headline: Powerfully Wrong
