headline: New Leader Is Named for ArtPlace America
text: ArtPlace America, an organization that awards grants in the hope of encouraging what it calls “creative placemaking” – that is, the inclusion of arts and cultural projects in community development and renovation plans – has appointed Jamie L. Bennett to be its executive director, starting in January.

headline: Presumed Innocent, but Caged in Court
text: MOSCOW — Under the Russian Constitution, Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, the star dancer charged with arranging an acid attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, is innocent until proven guilty. But in court, Mr. Dmitrichenko sits in a locked iron cage, guarded by security officers and, at times, a nasty-looking dog.

headline: Measuring the Might of Haiyan
text: Typhoon Haiyan, which ravaged the Philippines earlier this month, might have been one of the strongest tropical cyclones ever to hit land, but its exact strength was a matter of dispute. Forecasting agencies said it would pack winds of up to 195 miles (about 315 kilometers) an hour, but meteorologists in the Philippines said that top measured speeds were closer to 150 m.p.h., or 240 k.p.h.

headline: A Dirty Secret Lurks in the Struggle Over a Fiscal ‘Grand Bargain’
text: WASHINGTON — The long-sought bipartisan “grand bargain” on the nation’s fiscal future is not going to happen this year, and probably not for the rest of President Obama’s term. There is the simple, familiar reason. And then there is the dirty secret.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Nathy Aviram joined McCann Erickson New York as executive vice president and director of integrated production. He assumes duties from Diane Hill, who had been senior vice president and director of integrated production; she left to return to BBDO New York, where she had previously worked, and is now senior vice president and group executive producer there. Mr. Aviram has worked for agencies that include TBWA/Chiat/Day New York and Y&R New York. McCann Erickson New York is part of the McCann Erickson Worldwide division of the McCann Worldgroup, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Before the Wedding, the Histrionics (but Not the Bride’s)
text: The cause of Annabell Armstrong’s latest panic attack seems petty: Annabell (a frenetic Polly Lee) is at Neiman Marcus in Dallas, and she cannot find the perfect dress for a cousin’s wedding. But as Helen Sneed’s 95-minute play explains again and again, her histrionics are but a manifestation of a lifetime of accumulated anxieties and emotional traumas, as evidenced by the memories that wander, unwanted, into the store’s dressing room.

headline: The Power of Two (Extra Wonkish)
text: This seems to be wonk Monday. But anyway, one commenter raised what may have been a complaint about my tendency to do New Keynesian models that say they have infinite horizons, but whose analysis always seems to boil down to just two periods, “now” and “forever after”.

headline: With More Indictments, New Clues in A.T.M. Robbery Case
text: When eight men from Queens were indicted last spring as part of a global network that looted $45 million from A.T.M.'s, an unanswered question was what happened to the money.

headline: The Read Around: Terry McMillan
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their latest books. Below, Terry McMillan, the author of “Waiting to Exhale” and, most recently, “Who Asked You?,” talks about why she prefers writing in the first person, how she gets to know her characters and why it’s important for writers to be diverse readers.

headline: Quitting the N.F.L.: For John Moffitt, the Money Wasn’t Worth It
text: SEATTLE — John Moffitt chugged mugs of black coffee and talked almost giddily about how, the week before, he called John Elway, the head of football operations for the Denver Broncos, to tell him he was quitting the National Football League, leaving behind the money and the fame, but also the constant pain and the danger.

headline: The V.A. and Sexual Trauma
text: An editorial in today’s Times cites disheartening discrepancies in how the Veterans Affairs Department handles disability claims involving post-traumatic stress disorder. According to a report released this month by advocates for women and men who were sexually harassed and attacked while serving in uniform, survivors of sexual trauma are far less likely than other veterans to have their disability benefits approved.

headline: Surveillance Video of Suspected Paris Gunman
text: As my colleague Scott Sayare reports, French police are scouring Paris for a gunman who shot a journalist at the headquarters of the newspaper Libération on Monday morning. The same man is suspected of shooting at a bank in another part of the French capital 90 minutes later, and of having menaced an editor at a television news channel late last week.

headline: Confused About Holiday Travel? Submit Your Questions Here
text: The Wednesday before Thanksgiving is one of the busiest travel days of the year, according to the Department of Transportation. And no matter how you’re getting to grandmother’s house – by air, rail or road – you probably have a few nagging questions that could get answered in the form of a rude awakening on the road. In order to reduce the number of known unknowns, we’d like to answer your questions about holiday travel before you set off.

headline: Vegetarian Too Young
text: When my daughter chose to become a vegetarian at age 4 after I read her “Charlotte’s Web,” I thought it was a passing phase, much like needing to receive a confidential sprinkle of fairy dust on her way to school. Her pediatrician approved her nutritional plan without hesitation, and we have Hindu friends whose children have been vegetarian from birth, so the idea hardly seemed radical in our household, where we consumed a modest amount of meat to begin with.

headline: A Hurdle to Winding Down a Failing Global Bank
text: A seemingly small derivatives detail could sink global bank wind-down plans. American and European regulators want to standardize contracts to help cross-border lenders fail smoothly. If the problem isn’t fixed, investors could undermine financial stability by calling in swaps. It’s a reminder of how much work still needs to be done to end “too big to fail.”

headline: In Washington State, Selling to the Sellers With a Lighthearted Touch
text: There’s a moment in the movie “Written on the Wind” when a character played by Robert Stack tells a character played by Lauren Bacall, “You advertising people, so clever with words.” But just how clever do advertising people have to be when creating advertising aimed at other advertising people?

headline: Congress and Courts Weigh Restraints on N.S.A. Spying
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional critics of the National Security Agency program that collects the telephone records of millions of Americans stepped up their efforts as the Supreme Court on Monday turned away an unusual challenge to the scope of the surveillance.

headline: ‘Here Lies Love’ Cast to Reunite for Benefit Performance
text: David Byrne is reconvening the cast of “Here Lies Love,” his immersive musical about Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, for a single performance on Nov. 25 at Terminal 5 to raise money for relief efforts in the Philippines in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, which struck on Nov. 8. All proceeds from the performance will be donated to Doctors Without Borders, the Paris-based physicians group.

headline: More Explorations in Space
text: With or without Kepler, the quest for habitable real estate in the galaxy will go on.

headline: Former Marcos Aide Is Convicted in Attempted Sale of Missing Paintings
text: Vilma Bautista was patient. She waited more than a quarter of a century before discreetly trying to sell the paintings she had in her New York apartment: Impressionist masterpieces that had once hung on the walls of a townhouse used by Imelda Marcos.

headline: New Plan for a Disabled Kepler
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — The little spacecraft that could may still have some life left in it.

headline: Real Honor for Fake Newsman
text: Plenty of journalists have received honorary degrees. But Ron Burgundy, the bumbling fictional television newsman played by Will Ferrell in “Anchorman,” will go one better next month when the Emerson College School of Communication is temporarily named after him.

headline: Medical Care Improves in Storm-Hit Areas, Though Many Are Still Out of Reach
text: PALO, the Philippines — Rosalina Doyola, a cheerful 22-year-old with an accounting degree and an air of youthful confidence, woke up on Monday morning in a field hospital tent, lucky to have kept both her legs.

headline: 3 From Greenpeace Ship Free on Bail in Russia
text: MOSCOW — A court in St. Petersburg on Monday granted bail to three of 30 crew members of a Greenpeace International ship seized during a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic in September. Some see this as a first sign of leniency in an investigation that could continue through the Olympic Games that Russia is hosting in Sochi.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 15-17, 2013
text: No charges will be filed in the shooting death of a 13-year-old girl at a friend’s home in Las Vegas, Nev., in June. Brooklynn Mohler was shot when her friend was holding a gun, which had been retrieved from a kitchen cabinet, and it accidentally discharged.

headline: G.M.’s Opel Unit Reaches Deal to Close a German Plant
text: FRANKFURT — The Opel unit of General Motors said on Monday that it reached a preliminary agreement with workers to close a factory in Bochum, Germany, at the end of next year, another example of the effort by hard-pressed European automakers to slowly close superfluous manufacturing plants.

headline: Lady Gaga Concert Prompts Fine for Russian Concert Agency
text: The Russian concert agency that presented a Lady Gaga concert in St. Petersburg in December has been fined 20,000 rubles – the equivalent of $614 – because, a St. Petersburg court ruled, Lady Gaga’s show promoted homosexuality and alcohol consumption.

headline: Arguments for Trusting the Data
text: Why don’t we trust data? More to the point, why don’t we act on what data tells us?

headline: Scores Killed in Tribal Clashes in Darfur
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Nearly 200 members of two Arab tribes that signed a peace treaty in July were killed in fighting in southwest Darfur over the past three weeks, a local tribal chief said.

headline: Sochi Games’ Doping Lab Provisionally Suspended
text: The Russian laboratory that has been assigned the task of processing drug tests for the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi will have its accreditation suspended for six months if it does not make operational improvements to ensure its reliability by Dec. 1.

headline: Pacers Have Built a Consistent (if Imperfect) Winner
text: CHICAGO — Several hours before his Indiana Pacers met the Chicago Bulls Saturday night at United Center, General Manager Kevin Pritchard lounged in a courtside folding chair during the afternoon shootaround.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Walmart’s Food Drive, for Employees
text: The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported on Monday that a Walmart in Canton, Ohio is organizing a food drive for its employees.

headline: Aaron Adler: Mayor of the Music Revue
text: Mr. Adler has taken the affable-neighborhood-retiree gig to a whole new level with the Kew Gardens Musicians.

headline: Obama’s First-Term Finance Team: Where Are They Now?
text: Timothy F. Geithner’s move to the private equity firm Warburg Pincus is a big shift by a finance official from the Obama administration’s first term to the private sector.

headline: In Store | Balenciaga’s Newest, Oldest-Looking, Store
text: With its dark green Verde Ramegiatto marble walls and a skylight ceiling covered with a lattice metal inlay, the new Balenciaga flagship in SoHo feels like it has been around for centuries. Alexander Wang designed it that way, working closely with his longtime friend and collaborator, the interior designer Ryan Korban, to turn the bilevel space on Mercer Street into something that felt like it had already stood the test of time. “I wanted to mix modern and classical materials to create a timeless space,” said Wang, who cited historic museums as inspiration for the store, his first as the brand’s creative director. The interiors are also a testament to Wang’s point of view for the brand, full of references to his debut collection for Balenciaga, which took place on a faux marble runway back in February. Even the chairs that dot the grand, open floor plan — which also includes several intimate rooms that each house different kinds of goods (ready-to-wear in one room, shoes in another, etc.) — have been upholstered in the same black “caviar” embroidery he applied to gowns in the fall 2013 collection. Combined with the sofas, they seem to beg shoppers to stay awhile. “I thought back to the time of the couture salon presentations in the Cristobal Balenciaga era, when clients had the luxury of time to view fashion in a leisurely way, but with an elevated sense of ceremony,” Wang said. The Balenciaga flagship opens on Nov. 22; 148 Mercer Street; (212) 206-0872.

headline: The Dow, Adjusted for Inflation
text: The Dow Jones industrial average broke through 16,000 on Monday for the first time on record — well, at least in nominal terms. If you adjust for inflation, technically the highest level was on Jan. 14, 2000 (both for closing price and intraday trading):

headline: A New Danger to Africans
text: Africans may become susceptible to a type of malaria that they had long been thought to be immune to because the parasite appears to be evolving, scientists said last week.

headline: Getting Realistic (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Casual Casualties (3 Letters)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Cameras Infiltrate Nursing Homes, Smart Reptiles, Mean Girls
text: Hidden cameras are finding their way into long-term care facilities, often placed by families to watch the staff; lizards, turtles and snakes are proving more intelligent than once thought; why it might be evolutionarily beneficial for women to be rude to one another.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 12-18, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Moving Content to a New iPad
text: Moving Content

headline: Street Style
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Nov. 7.

headline: Challenge for the Philippines: 4 Million Displaced
text: As the Philippines begins to clean up after the worst typhoon in memory, it is faced with the huge challenge of feeding and housing its displaced population.

headline: Deadly Tornadoes Rip Through Midwest
text: Scenes from the aftermath of the tornadoes that caused widespread destruction across the Midwest.

headline: Filming of Movie Won’t Close Clearwater Aquarium
text: After turning away scores of disappointed visitors, the Clearwater Marine Aquarium,  in Clearwater, Fla., has reversed its decision to close weekends during the filming of “Dolphin Tale 2” and will also remain open during  the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays.

headline: Sleep Therapy Seen as an Aid for Depression
text: Curing insomnia in people with depression could double their chance of a full recovery, scientists are reporting. The findings, based on an insomnia treatment that uses talk therapy rather than drugs, are the first to emerge from a series of closely watched studies of sleep and depression to be released in the coming year.

headline: A Business Traveler’s View of the Latest Airline Merger
text: WHEN discussing the airline business, Michael Boyd uses the term “raw, naked economics” as if it ought to be followed by a shriek off a movie screen.

headline: A Cold War Fought by Women
text: How aggressive is the human female? When the anthropologist Sarah B. Hrdy surveyed the research literature three decades ago, she concluded that “the competitive component in the nature of women remains anecdotal, intuitively sensed, but not confirmed by science.”

headline: Monday Motorsports: A Week of Triumph, Tragedy and Controversy
text: Jimmie Johnson clinched his sixth Nascar Sprint Cup championship with a ninth place finish in the season finale on Sunday at Homestead-Miami Speedway. Matt Kenseth finished the season in the runner-up position, 19 points behind Johnson, with a second-place finish in the race, behind the winner, Denny Hamlin. Dale Earnhardt Jr. took third in the race.

headline: A Singapore Crew Cut to Get Past the Hair Police
text: I’VE been flying regularly for about 40 years. I’m 62 years old, or, as I prefer, 62 years young, and fly once a week. I have a line of skin care products named after me, and that means that I have to meet with people, do events, find new avenues for business in the United States and abroad, and even travel so I can keep up with the trends and learn new things.

headline: Sony Entertainment Is Said to Hire Bain & Company for Cost-Cutting
text: LOS ANGELES — Sony Entertainment, under pressure to make its moviemaking operation more profitable, has hired Bain & Company to help it identify $100 million or more in additional overhead cuts, a move that would almost assuredly result in layoffs, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: A Conversation With Leander Kahney, Author of ‘Jony Ive’
text: Jony Ive, the designer behind some of Apple’s most successful products, became even more important to Apple after the death of Steve Jobs.

headline: Inequality of Feelings
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Agriculture as Solution
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Fennel and Lemon Turn Swordfish Into a More Complex Meal
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Zimmerman Is Charged With Aggravated Assault
text: ATLANTA — Barely four months after he was acquitted in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager that spurred demonstrations across the country, George Zimmerman was arrested on Monday in Florida following a dispute with his girlfriend, the authorities said.

headline: Watchful Eye in Nursing Homes
text: A pretty nightie, a new lipstick, a fresh toothbrush: Doris Racher noticed that small things she had bought for her 96-year-old mother, Eryetha Mayberry, a dementia patient at a nursing home in Oklahoma City, had been disappearing. Ms. Racher assumed the culprit was another resident who sometimes wandered into her mother’s room and fell asleep in her bed.

headline: German Chancellor Makes Plea for Ukraine
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel demanded on Monday that Russia allow its onetime subjects — particularly in Ukraine — to exercise the sovereign right to make alliances as they choose.

headline: Toronto Mayor Knocks Over City Council Member at Meeting
text: The embattled Toronto mayor, Rob Ford, knocked over a City Council member during a tense special session on Monday called to debate a motion that would strip him of almost all mayoral powers, according to The Globe and Mail, a Toronto newspaper. The meeting came after a string of reports that included an admission by Mr. Ford that he bought and used crack cocaine while in office.

headline: Cheneys Defend Elder Daughter in Feud on Gay Marriage
text: Breaking their silence about the public feud between their two daughters, former Vice President Dick Cheney and his wife, Lynne, said Monday that the situation had pained them, but offered some political cover for their elder child, who is seeking a United States Senate seat in Wyoming.

headline: A Rare Sample of a Much Saltier Time
text: Seawater retrieved from a crater deep under Chesapeake Bay is 100 million to 145 million years old, researchers say, offering a rare glimpse of ancient ocean conditions in the North Atlantic.

headline: Vienna Visit Is a Home Game for a U.S. Assistant
text: Almost everywhere that the United States national soccer team goes, Coach Jurgen Klinsmann is the most recognized member of the traveling party. Whether it is San Pedro Sula or Sarajevo, Klinsmann, a World Cup-winning striker with Germany, is catnip for soccer fans, autograph-seekers and admirers.

headline: In Performance: Zachary Quinto
text: Zachary Quinto as Tom in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Glass Menagerie,” on Broadway at the Booth Theater.

headline: Officials Were Warned About Health Site Woes
text: WASHINGTON — Senior Obama administration officials, including several in the White House, were warned by an outside management consultant early this year that the effort to build the HealthCare.gov site was falling behind and at risk of failure unless immediate steps were taken to correct the problems, according to documents released by House investigators.

headline: Not Much of an Appetite at 80
text: Q. Why would I totally lose my appetite at the age of 80, with no apparent medical problems?

headline: After Hours | An Irishman’s Inner Marcel Proust
text: Bush Moukarzel’s first line in the one-man play “Souvenir,” now playing at the Abrons Arts Center in New York, is, “For a long time, I went to bed early.” It’s also the very famous first line of Marcel Proust’s “Remembrance of Things Past,” published a century ago this year. Moukarzel’s hourlong piece, which was a sold-out hit in Dublin and London for the theater company Dead Centre, aims not so much to relive Proust’s epic, seven-volume story of social climbing, desire and memory as to distill its yearning, nostalgic essence into fragments of narrative and images. When the show begins, Moukarzel is running on a treadmill, his back to us, instantly conjuring images of being borne back ceaselessly into the past (or, stuck in the present). A giant diptych of Proust hangs overhead. Everywhere, there’s a clutter of half-opened packing boxes, marked cheekily with labels like “Mum,” “Apologies, “Bacon,” “Broken Glass” and (inevitably) “Madeleines.”

headline: Celtic Paths, Illuminated by a Sundial
text: BEWCASTLE, England — The road leading north from Carlisle through the low, windswept hills stretching to the Scottish border traces Hadrian’s Wall, once a remote outpost of the Roman Empire. Nearby is the tiny outcropping of Bewcastle, where a broken Celtic cross with one of the oldest sundials in England stands in a lonely churchyard.

headline: New Scrutiny for Medical Devices
text: Wayne Schneider’s heart stopped beating late last year while the Minneapolis paramedic was out on an emergency call. Another medic performed CPR for a few minutes, and then used a medical device that delivered cardiac compressions mechanically for 64 minutes, until Mr. Schneider’s heart started beating normally on its own.

headline: Bill on Drug Compounding Clears Congress a Year After a Meningitis Outbreak
text: A bill that would give the Food and Drug Administration more power to police compounding pharmacies passed its final hurdle in Congress on Monday, in what experts said was an important step to a safer drug supply in the United States.

headline: Jay Z and Barneys Announce Substantial Changes in Their Partnership
text: Over the weekend, Barneys New York and Jay Z reaffirmed their plans to go ahead with a collaboration that involves, among other things, the introduction of a fragrance this Wednesday, but announced some substantial changes in their partnership.

headline: ‘Baddest Man on the Planet’ (and His Vulnerable Side)
text: For many years, Mike Tyson lived a life without brakes.

headline: For a Tenor’s Centennial, Celebrating His Legacy With a Cast of Opera Stars
text: A dream team of opera singers assembled at Avery Fisher Hall for the Richard Tucker Gala on Sunday, an evening that included Stephanie Blythe, Joyce DiDonato, Renée Fleming, Susan Graham and Eric Owens. But before any of them sang a note, it was the voice of Tucker that filled the hall in a recording of “Thine Alone,” in which cantorial ardor and classical training blended into that combination of polish and popular appeal that made him one of the best-loved tenors of his time.

headline: A Historical Elephant’s New Identity
text: In 1752, King Adolf Fredrik of Sweden acquired a remarkable curiosity: an elephant fetus preserved in a jar. It did not take long for a fellow Swede, the famed naturalist Carl Linnaeus, to pay an eager visit to Drottningholm Palace to examine the withered specimen.

headline: Healthy Trips to Exotic Places
text: Long ago, I carried two seatbelts in my luggage. When the car that we rented for a month to drive around Turkey had no seatbelts in the back, as my husband and I had been warned, we took the two in my baggage to a body shop, paid to have them installed, and strapped our children in.

headline: U.N. Agency Seeks Details on American Held in Iran
text: The family of Amir Hekmati, a former American Marine who has been incarcerated in Iran for more than two years even though his espionage conviction was overturned, has been contacted by the United Nations for details on his case, Mr. Hekmati’s sister said Monday.

headline: Exploring Spirituality, and Ending on a Prayer
text: The British composer John Tavener, who died last week at 69, frequently collaborated with the Tallis Scholars, the superb a cappella ensemble founded and conducted by Peter Phillips. It seemed fitting that as an encore to the group’s impressive concert of Renaissance and contemporary music on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, it offered a Tavener work as a tribute: his setting of the Lord’s Prayer.

headline: Hearing What Radiohead Has Inspired
text: David Bowie, Tortoise, the Orb, Sufjan Stevens, Dan Deacon: The list of pop and rock performers and groups who have shown the composer Steve Reich’s influence is lengthy and continuing. On Saturday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Mr. Reich turned the tables, as Alarm Will Sound presented the New York premiere of his “Radio Rewrite,” based on two songs by the British rock band Radiohead. The performance was part of this adventurous new-music ensemble’s season-long residency, which includes formal events like this one, as well as unusual programs, like a pop-up concert that would unfold without warning in the museum’s Charles Engelhard Court on Monday at noon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Illinois and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Illinois, the Philippines, Pakistan and France.

headline: Clues to the Origins of Big Cats
text: A newly discovered set of big-cat fossils, believed to be the oldest ever found, belonged to a previously unknown species, and may help solve a longstanding mystery about the origins of big cats likes tigers, leopards and lions, researchers say.

headline: An Old Chinese Novel Is Racy Reading Still
text: When David Tod Roy entered a used-book shop in the Chinese city of Nanjing in 1950, he was a 16-year-old American missionary kid looking for a dirty book.

headline: Serving a Challenging Meal by Starting Off Easy
text: When it comes to ambitious, fearless orchestral programming, there is Leon Botstein, the music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, and then there is everyone else. Say what you will about Mr. Botstein’s esoteric tastes, professorial inclinations or limitations as a conductor. It’s all been said before, endlessly, and it’s not indicative of the edifying experiences his concerts tend to be for anyone whose tastes extend past the safety zone in which most other orchestras huddle.

headline: Israelis Embrace French President for Iran Position
text: JERUSALEM — President François Hollande’s trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories, like all state visits, was planned months ago. But coming days before France and other world powers prepared to resume the nuclear talks with Iran in Geneva, the three-day visit that started on Sunday could not have come at a more opportune time for Israel — or for France, according to some Israeli officials.

headline: Question Fed Policy? Sure. Audit It? No.
text: Mike Konczal has a very good piece on why Rand Paul’s proposal that the Fed be “audited” is a bad idea. You should read it; I’d just like to offer a complementary take.

headline: Reptilian Smarts
text: New research is showing that lizards, turtles and snakes are more intelligent than previously believed.

headline: Coldblooded Does Not Mean Stupid
text: Humans have no exclusive claim on intelligence. Across the animal kingdom, all sorts of creatures have performed impressive intellectual feats. A bonobo named Kanzi uses an array of symbols to communicate with humans. Chaser the border collie knows the English words for more than 1,000 objects. Crows make sophisticated tools, elephants recognize themselves in the mirror, and dolphins have a rudimentary number sense.

headline: Broader Pool of Madoff Victims to Benefit From Fund
text: The largest category of victims in the vast Ponzi scheme run by Bernard L. Madoff — those who lost cash through accounts with various middleman funds — will be first in line for compensation from a $2.35 billion fund collected by the Justice Department.

headline: Crossing the Ocean to Discover the Personal
text: The work of Devonté Hynes radiates a thorough, passionate, forgetting-to-eat-or-sleep love for the last 30 years of pop. His current project, Blood Orange, is a trans-Atlantic notion of urban dance music from the early ‘80s to the early ‘90s: freestyle, Prince ballads, Janet Jackson’s “Control,” Neneh Cherry. It reads now, on balance, as a New York sound. But it’s a New York as experienced by an outsider, exotic and blurry, with an indeterminate time stamp.

headline: An Earlier Exodus Amid Climate Change
text: Birds are migrating earlier and earlier each year, and scientists have long suspected that climate change is responsible. A new study by researchers at the University of East Anglia in England shows that individual birds migrate like clockwork, but nesting and hatching are happening earlier as a result of warmer temperatures, and this appears to be linked to the advancing of overall migration patterns.

headline: Eli's Championship M.O.
text: The Giants play some horrible football, then string together some wins and make the playoffs. William C. Rhoden has seen this movie twice before. It always ends with a Super Bowl victory parade.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: Eli’s Championship M.O.
text: The Giants play some horrible football, then string together a series of wins and qualify for the playoffs. We’ve seen this movie twice before, and it always ends with a Super Bowl victory parade.

headline: Need Condo Cleaned? Consider the Superintendent’s Family
text: When Ilir Topalli gets that yearly Christmas card from the management of the small Upper East Side building where he has lived for 10 years, the one that gently nudges residents to tip the staff, it contains the names of the superintendent, the doorman and the porter who trudges out with the trash. Also listed is someone who is not on the co-op’s payroll: the superintendent’s wife, who is the de facto housekeeper for many of the apartments.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Love and Math’
text: There’s a secret world out there. A hidden parallel universe of beauty and elegance, intricately intertwined with ours. It’s the world of mathematics. And it’s invisible to most of us. This book is an invitation to discover this world.

headline: Brilliance Triumphs Over Rejection
text: In 1984, when he was 16, Edward Frenkel was subjected to a malicious interrogation. Already a brilliant budding mathematician, he had applied for admission to “Mekh-Mat” at Moscow State University, the top mathematics program in the Soviet Union. But when he attended the critical oral entrance exam, his dream of becoming a professional mathematician came crashing down.

headline: Vibrating Along With Live Music
text: Some dancers execute movement; others breathe it. In Gina Gibney’s “Dividing Line,” which had its premiere run from Thursday through Saturday at Gould Hall, Amy Miller fell into the second category.

headline: A Romantic Evening
text: When David Ludwig wrote his “Swan Song” for violin and piano, he wanted to evoke the ghosts of 19th-century composers. He was particularly inspired by Schubert’s Fantasy for Violin and Piano, which opens with an elegiac melody over bustling piano figurations. The title of Mr. Ludwig’s contemporary reimagining refers to Schubert’s “Swan Song” cycle, written shortly before Schubert died of syphilis at 31.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: On Google’s Driverless Car, and Poking Fun at Downed YouTube
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Hurricanes and Climate, Helping Stuck Babies, Changing Forests
text: The typhoon that struck the Philippines this month prompted questions about a possible link between natural disasters and a warming planet. Delegates at the United Nations talks in Warsaw on a global climate treaty were quick to make the connection. And the head of the United Nations’ meteorological agency cited Australia’s severe summer heat and raised water levels around the Philippines as among the effects, reported ABC News. Still, most scientists remained cautious, saying there was not enough data to draw a direct connection.

headline: Pynchon Won’t Be Surfacing for National Book Awards
text: On Wednesday evening, the publishing industry will gather in black tie for the National Book Awards, where some of the most prestigious literary prizes in the business will be handed out.

headline: YouTube Website Goes Down
text: YouTube, the world’s third most popular website, went down for a short period on Monday, giving the millions of people who depend on the service for videos of news and kittens a heavy sense of withdrawal.

headline: Obama Pick for Court Is 3rd in a Row Blocked by Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Monday blocked President Obama’s third consecutive nominee to the country’s most powerful and prestigious appeals court and insisted they would not back down, inflaming a bitter debate over a president’s right to shape the judiciary.

headline: On View | An Artist’s Dueling Landscapes
text: What do the streets, storefronts and bodegas of South Williamsburg, Brooklyn, have to do with the deserts of southern California? It’s a question that the sculptor Halsey Rodman, who grew up in Davis, Calif., has been considering a lot lately, with two related projects in these radically opposed environments.

headline: Maria Bartiromo to Leave CNBC for Fox Business
text: Maria Bartiromo, one of the first women to become a star on television by reporting on business news, is leaving her longtime home at CNBC for its rival, the Fox Business Network.

headline: U.S. Poised to Announce $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
text: The Justice Department is set to announce a $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over the bank’s questionable mortgage practices in the run-up to the financial crisis, people briefed on the deal said on Monday, as prosecutors and the bank hashed out the final details of the deal.

headline: Commercial Breaks That Keep a Story Going
text: A YEAR after an innovative marketing effort for the Christmas shopping season brought together Target and ABC, the retailer and the network are teaming up again.

headline: Slowdown in Carbon Emissions Worldwide, but Coal Burning Continues to Grow
text: Global emissions of carbon dioxide are slowing somewhat from the rapid pace of the last decade, new figures show, but growth in coal burning continues to outstrip the growth in other forms of energy, and experts said the world remains far from meeting international goals on climate change.

headline: Inmate Buses Sit at Rikers; New York City Courts Stalled
text: Dozens of New York City corrections buses that were supposed to take prisoners to court on Monday never left Rikers Island, grinding many criminal courts in the city to a near halt.

headline: Researchers Work to Add More Anonymity to Bitcoin
text: In my column this week, Disruptions: A Digital Underworld Cloaked in Anonymity, I noted that the Deep Web, or Dark Internet, had mushroomed in recent years because of a growing belief that it was possible to remain anonymous online.

headline: Princeton University to Use Foreign Vaccine
text: Princeton University plans to offer students a meningitis vaccine not usually approved for use in the United States in an attempt to prevent an outbreak at the school from spreading, officials said on Monday.

headline: Dropbox Is Said to Seek $250 Million in Funding, Doubling Its Valuation
text: Online storage, once a backwater of the Silicon Valley technology scene, is suddenly a hot commodity.

headline: Bloomberg Lays Off Staff in Sports and Culture
text: Bloomberg News started laying off and reassigning employees on Monday, seeking to emphasize areas that promote growth and focus more on core subjects like finance and government.

headline: Cause of Gas Leak That Killed 2 Colorado Miners Is Sought
text: DENVER — Federal mine safety inspectors on Monday were trying to determine the cause of an accident that killed two miners and injured 20 others near the mountain town of Ouray in southwestern Colorado.

headline: Egyptian Protesters Destroy Tahrir Square Monument Erected by Interim Government
text: Updated, Tuesday, 9:56 a.m. | Just hours after Egypt’s military-led interim government tried to cement its claim to revolutionary legitimacy — with the dedication of a memorial to the uprisings that toppled two authoritarian presidents in two years — protesters swarmed the monument in the center of Tahrir Square on Monday night and defaced it, chanting, “The revolution’s returned to Tahrir.”

headline: Plan to Redevelop South Street Seaport Includes Marina and 50-Story Tower
text: South Street Seaport, an often-neglected corner of Manhattan dedicated to enshrining New York’s seafaring past, has been battered by storms, recessions and poor management.

headline: A Lifesaving Treatment, and a Killer
TV Series Will Focus on N.H.L. Players in Olympics
text: The N.H.L., once ambivalent about breaking up its 2013-14 season to enable players to participate in the 2014 Sochi Olympics, has come to embrace the break in its schedule. The league announced Monday that it has hired producers to make a seven-hour series that will track teams and players through the Olympics and five outdoor stadium games.

headline: At Swarovski’s New Outpost, a Look on the Bright Side
text: Until recently, I believed that Swarovski was just a manufacturer of rhinestones, or “bling”: used to jazz up cellphone cases, waxed bikini lines and other assorted fripperies that began to emerge in developed countries as the previous millennium waned.

headline: As the 50th Anniversary Nears, Dallas Reflects
text: To the Editor:

headline: Raising the Cigarette-Buying Age to 21
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jefferson in Quebec
text: To the Editor:

headline: Google to Pay $17 Million to Settle Privacy Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google agreed on Monday to pay $17 million to 37 states and the District of Columbia in a wide-reaching settlement over tracking consumers online without their knowledge.

headline: Colorado Governor Proposes Strict Limits on Greenhouse Gas Leaks From Drilling
text: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper of Colorado proposed on Monday tough new limits on leaks of methane and other gases from well sites and storage tanks. Supporters called the limits, which would exceed existing federal rules, the most sweeping in the nation.

headline: Cheney Family Values
text: If Liz Cheney, whose bid for the Senate has always had a stench of extreme opportunism, wants to discuss traditions and values, I’m all for it. Let’s start here: Isn’t there a tradition of close-knit family members’ taking care not to wound one another? Is there not value in that?

headline: Yankees Set to Resume Cano Negotiations, With Sides Still Far Apart
text: Hal Steinbrenner said last week at the owners meetings in Orlando, Fla., that the Yankees would resume negotiations this week with the free-agent second baseman Robinson Cano. But it does not seem as if there is a great deal to talk about, at least not yet.

headline: New Market Benchmarks Show a Lack of Options
text: Stocks rallied past two psychological barriers Monday morning, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average over 16,000 and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index beyond 1,800 for the first time, as investors still saw opportunities in the market.

headline: Alabama Judges Retain the Right to Override Juries in Capital Sentencing
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned down a challenge to an unusual Alabama capital-sentencing practice that has sent 95 defendants to death row despite jury determinations calling for life sentences.

headline: Many Wheels, but No Place to Ride Them
text: Dirt bike and A.T.V. enthusiasts find it hard  to find places to ride without interference from the authorities.

headline: Kenya: New Details on Mall Attackers
text: The attackers behind the siege of the Westgate shopping mall that left more than 60 people dead in September had been living in Nairobi and plotted the attack for several months, a Western official briefed on the investigation said Monday. Kenyan officials say they believe they have determined the identities of the four attackers who stormed the mall. All four of the men are Somali citizens, though one of the men, previously identified as Hassan Abdi Dhuhulow, grew up in Norway. Remains recovered from the mall that are believed to be those of the attackers are still undergoing forensic testing at an F.B.I. laboratory, the Western official said. A Somali militant group, the Shabab, claimed responsibility for the attack. The four men entered the country from Somalia in June and lived in Nairobi’s Somali neighborhood, Eastleigh. Kenyan authorities initially said that up to 15 assailants were involved in the attack, but only four are visible on mall surveillance tapes. Four other men have been charged as accomplices.

headline: For New York City’s Dirt Bikers, There Is No Place to Ride
text: The young man tore down the asphalt, the roar of his dirt bike trailing like a comet’s tail. When it seemed he could not go any faster, he went higher, hauling the bike into a near-vertical wheelie but never slowing down. A dozen other riders crisscrossed his path, their own front wheels aloft to the perfect fall sky.

headline: Venezuela: Former Bank Official Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
text: A former executive at a Venezuelan bank pleaded guilty in a New York federal court on Monday to charges stemming from a scheme in which she took bribes in exchange for steering millions of dollars of the bank’s business to an American brokerage firm. The executive, María de los Angeles González, 55, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, suggesting there could be further revelations about corruption at the government-controlled bank, the Economic and Social Development Bank of Venezuela, known as Bandes. A plea agreement signed by Ms. González indicated that the corruption she was involved in went much further than previously revealed and that she admitted involvement in several other payoff schemes at Bandes and another government-run bank where she worked as an officer, Industrial Bank of Venezuela. The agreement said that the charges that Ms. González pleaded guilty to carried sentences totaling up to 55 years in jail. Ms. González was arrested in Miami in May.

headline: More Than a Decade After 9/11, a Bull Market for Barriers and Checkpoints
text: When United Airlines Flight 175 hit the South Tower, the windows in Mark Scherzer’s apartment collapsed inward in a fine spray of glass shards. Then the tower collapsed and a metal beam flew in, true as an arrow. Dust, inches thick, covered his floors, bed and shelves.

headline: Chile: Former President’s Coalition Kept in Check
text: Former President Michelle Bachelet, a socialist who is favored to win a runoff election in December against a conservative candidate, Evelyn Matthei, was unable to elect enough lawmakers from her coalition to pass sweeping political proposals, but she still may be able to push through many of her social and economic policies if she is elected. Although the conservative Alliance bloc lost a considerable number of representatives in the lower house, its members retained their seats in the Senate, making it difficult for Ms. Bachelet’s New Majority coalition to pass constitutional amendments or overhaul the electoral system. Ms. Matthei’s far-right party, the Independent Democratic Union, suffered a serious blow in the lower house, losing nine of its 38 seats, while the Communist Party doubled its seats to six. Fewer than half of Chile’s potential 13.5 million voters turned out for the presidential election, the first one after voting was made voluntary.

headline: Egypt: Security Official Assassinated
text: Gunmen killed a senior Egyptian security official whose responsibilities included investigating Muslim extremists, the Interior Ministry said Monday. The official, Lt. Col. Mohamed Mabrouk, was driving to work in Cairo on Sunday when gunmen fired on it, striking him seven times, according to state media. In September, the interior minister survived when a bomb blew up his convoy. Shootings of lesser security officers around the country have become a near daily occurrence, especially in the relatively lawless Sinai. Egyptian officials have attributed the attacks to Islamist extremists retaliating for the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and the repression of his allies in the Muslim Brotherhood. Colonel Mabrouk had been involved in the investigation and arrests of senior Brotherhood members in recent months, state media reported.

headline: Quickly Gaining Value
text: The price of a bitcoin on an exchange that converts them to dollars rose to $780 on Monday, a meteoric gain from its beginnings in 2010.

headline: Prosecutor in Racially Charged Shooting Case Near Detroit Is No Stranger to Spotlight
text: DETROIT — For two weeks, the pressure on the prosecutor’s office here steadily grew.

headline: Regulators See Value in Bitcoin, and Investors Hasten to Agree
text: The virtual currency bitcoin took a big step toward the mainstream on Monday as federal authorities signaled their willingness to accept it as a legitimate payment alternative.

headline: Central African Republic Stirs Concern
text: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, raised the possibility on Monday that thousands of international peacekeeping troops in Africa might have to be temporarily redeployed in the Central African Republic, one of the most unstable on the continent. In a dire report, Mr. Ban said an African Union force that was set to assume peacekeeping and security responsibilities in the Central African Republic might not be ready in time for its December deployment schedule. If there were a “precipitous deterioration,” Mr. Ban said, the United Nations could respond by moving soldiers from neighboring peacekeeping missions, like those in the Democratic Republic of Congo or Sudan, with the approval of the Security Council and countries contributing troops. Outside Bangui, the capital, government authority is nonexistent, Mr. Ban said, and clashes between rebels and their opponents have become increasingly brutal and sectarian. “This cycle, if not addressed now, threatens to degenerate into a countrywide religious and ethnic divide, with the potential to spiral into an uncontrollable situation, including atrocity crimes, with serous national and regional implications,” he said.

headline: Syd Field, Who Wrote the Book on Writing Screenplays, Dies at 77
text: The term “plot point” appeared in The New York Times fewer than 10 times during the century or so before 1979. Since then, it has appeared more than 200 times.

headline: Despite Storms and Injuries, Bears Stay on Playoff Track
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — Monday morning dawned sunny and bright in the Chicago area, a day after a series of tornadoes touched down across Illinois and high-powered wind and heavy rainfall pummeled the city.

headline: A New G.O.P. Excuse for Doing Nothing
text: With unrestrained glee, Republicans are using the calamitous debut of the Affordable Care Act as their latest justification for undermining all of health care reform. But they’re not stopping there. The Obama administration’s fumbling is apparently a good excuse for them to do nothing on immigration reform, on a budget agreement, and on any other initiative coming out of the White House.

headline: Barbara Park, Author of Junie B. Jones Series, Dies at 66
text: Barbara Park, whose children’s books starring Junie B. Jones, a 6-year-old dispenser of abundant opinions, Runyonesque wisecracks and dubious syntax, have sold tens of millions of copies and delighted all but the most grammatically puritanical parents and teachers, died on Friday at her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 66.

headline: The Internet: A Welcome Distraction
text: Every time somebody says to me, “It’s so impressive how you manage to get writing done despite being on Facebook/Twitter/etc. all the time,” I cringe. I’ve been hit by a backhanded compliment. I’m surfing, tweeting and emailing — leaving my digital prints everywhere and probably picking up some nasty computer viruses — while serious writers are working pristinely, heroically beyond the clutches of the Internet.

headline: Death Meted Out by Politicians in Robes
text: In nearly all of the 32 states that permit capital punishment, a jury makes the final decision on whether a defendant will live or die. Not so in Alabama, where elected judges may override a jury verdict of life in prison and unilaterally impose a death sentence.

headline: Europeans Fault American Safety Effort in Bangladesh
text: Tensions broke into the open on Monday involving two large groups of retailers — one overwhelmingly American, the other dominated by Europeans — that have formed to improve factory safety in Bangladesh.

headline: Flawed Gauge for Cholesterol Risk Poses a New Challenge for Cardiologists
text: This week, cardiologists learned that a new online calculator meant to help them determine a patient’s suitability for cholesterol treatment was flawed, doubling the estimated risk of heart attack or stroke for the average patient. But fixing it would not be easy, because it is based on older data, and heart attack and stroke rates today are much lower than in decades past, meaning that people are at less risk than might be expected from historical extrapolations.

headline: Cholesterol Guidelines Under Attack
text: Patients in good cardiovascular health would be well advised to stay away for now from following the cholesterol guidelines issued last week by the nation’s two leading heart organizations.

headline: She Vanquished a Cruel Addiction, but Challenges Remain
text: Della Murray just didn’t care.

headline: A Conflict in Geithner’s New Job? Not Exactly
text: Within 24 hours of Timothy F. Geithner’s announcement on Saturday that he would join Warburg Pincus, the private equity firm, a parade of naysayers emerged, almost like clockwork, to criticize the former Treasury secretary’s move as a prime example of the evil of the government’s revolving door.

headline: Labor Panel Finds Illegal Punishments at Walmart
text: Walmart illegally disciplined and fired employees over strikes and protests, the National Labor Relations Board said on Monday.

headline: Are We Alone in the Universe?
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — THE recent announcement by a team of astronomers that there could be as many as 40 billion habitable planets in our galaxy has further fueled the speculation, popular even among many distinguished scientists, that the universe is teeming with life.

headline: Hollywood Studios Facing Upheaval at Highest Levels
text: LOS ANGELES — Advice for the power players at Hollywood’s coming round of black-tie galas: Don’t leave your seat to table-hop.

headline: One Breath, One Last Dive
text: Nicholas Mevoli died at a championship free-diving event in the Bahamas after he returned to the surface from his record attempt.
