text: 纽约城市芭蕾舞团的活动呈现了三场新芭蕾舞剧以及与三位时尚设计师 —  — 普拉巴·高隆、艾丽斯·范赫尔彭、奥利维尔·泰斯金斯 —  — 的新合作。

headline: Police Give New Meaning to ‘Taped Confession’
text: Taped confessions are increasingly common in Chinese police stations. But inventive police officers in Huizhou, far southern China, added a singular twist: literally taping up the would-be confessors.

headline: A Diver’s Rise, and Swift Death, at the Limits of a Growing Sport
text: Nicholas Mevoli saved money from an assortment of jobs to pay for the bottomless pursuit of holding his breath and sinking his body as far as possible into the ocean.

headline: Split on Accord on Iran Strains U.S.-Israel Ties
text: WASHINGTON — To the Israeli government, the preliminary deal with Iran that the Obama administration is trying to seal this week is a giveaway to a government that has spent two decades building a vast nuclear program. It enshrines the status quo — at a time when the Iranians are within reach of the technical capability to build a bomb — and rewards some unproven leaders with cash and sanctions relief.

headline: Police Say Officer Killed Man Who Threatened With Knife
text: A police officer shot and killed a 22-year-old man in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon after he lunged at the officer with a knife, the authorities said.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 19, 2013
text: “Wood cracking, walls falling, you can’t imagine what that sounds like.”

headline: Giants Volunteer for Extra Cowboys Preparation
text: On Monday morning, the Giants were obliged to go to the team’s practice complex for only a weight-lifting session. Then the players were free to do as they wanted. Since Tuesday is their customary day off, the Giants were staring at what amounted to almost a two-day break from practice, meetings or film study.

headline: Corrections: November 19, 2013
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: A Reunion With an Agenda, for Buddies Going Nowhere
text: A casual reunion of three longtime buddies slouching unprofitably through their 30s ultimately betrays a darker purpose in “Small Engine Repair,” a raw, funny and well-tooled new play written by and featuring John Pollono, who is making an impressive, double-barreled Off Broadway debut.

headline: Take the Bait
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — FOUR SCORE AND SEVEN YEARS AGO … it was 1926, which has absolutely nothing to do with today’s puzzle by David J. Kahn. Let’s try this a different way.

headline: His Honor? Toronto’s Mayor Rampages On, to City’s Shame
text: TORONTO — The end did not come for Rob Ford, the mayor of this city, when he proclaimed his proclivity for oral sex on live television.

headline: Brooklyn Diver Dies After Record Attempt
text: Nicholas Mevoli’s life and death reflect the spirit, and dangers, of a niche sport that has grown exponentially.

headline: Hollande’s Assertive Role in Foreign Policy Is a Good Fit for France
text: PARIS — In the past few weeks, President François Hollande of France has been booed at a solemn national ceremony and forced to retreat on an element of his economic agenda. He has seen his nation’s credit rating downgraded and watched as his already-low public support continued to erode.

headline: Knicks Demote Smith’s Brother
text: The Chris Smith story took another turn Monday when the Knicks assigned him to their N.B.A. Development League affiliate, the Erie BayHawks.

headline: Another Website, Another Problem for Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Some supporters who tried to log in to hear President Obama defend his embattled health care law on Monday night were unable to hear him because the website of the group behind the call, Organizing for Action, failed to work for them.

headline: Libération Under Fire
text: PARIS — Here at Libération, we have blood in the hall. A war zone in the middle of Paris, right by the Place de la Republique. In 2013.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ to Close on Broadway
text: The $75 million Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the most expensive theatrical production in history, will close in early January after months of declining ticket sales, one of the lead producers said on Monday night. A somewhat revamped version of the show is being planned for Las Vegas in 2015, according to the producer, Jeremiah J. Harris.

headline: Stop Animal Circus Shows, Advocates Tell Government
text: With Bengal tigers, Asian elephants, chimpanzees, parrots and poodles among dozens of animals due to perform at an international circus in southern China starting on Wednesday, more than 30 animal rights organizations have petitioned the government, a partner in the event, to cancel the shows because of cruelty to the animals.

headline: Felton Is Missing Shots, and Those He Guards Are Not
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Raymond Felton was a spectator for most of Monday’s practice. He sat on a training table next to Tyson Chandler, whose fractured right leg was no longer encased in a protective boot. This counted as progress for the Knicks, whose training facility has doubled as a sanitarium this season.

headline: Fracking’s Achilles’ Heel
text: It’s not very often that someone starts his career as a geologist and then winds up as governor, but John Hickenlooper, the governor of Colorado, can make that claim. “We had fracking when I was a working geologist in 1981,” he told me on Monday. “It was very primitive. What really changed the world is when we got horizontal drilling. It was a technique that allowed you to recover a lot more natural gas.”

headline: Songs of Remembrance for Voices Now Silenced
text: The photos showed them as they had been: Arash Farazmand, 28, bent over his drums; his brother, Soroush Farazmand, 27, with his guitar; their friend and roommate, Ali Eskandarian, 35, smiling as he sang into a microphone. Candles burned below their names, illuminating messages of love and remembrance left for them in English and Persian: “I love you”; “thank you for the beautiful moments”; three hearts.

headline: A Talk That Stirred Fear of Antigay Bias Is Postponed at a Bronx High School
text: Ever since Pope Francis spoke compassionately about gay people last summer — saying, “Who am I to judge?” — Roman Catholics around the world have debated the meaning of his words.

headline: Billy Hardwick, Hall of Fame Bowler, Dies at 72
text: Billy Hardwick, the first bowler to win all three of the most prestigious Professional Bowlers Association tournaments, or the triple crown, died Saturday near his home in Bradenton, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Natural Disasters or 'Acts of God'?
text: When the law and people of faith refer to an event as an "act of God," is that constructive or a distraction?

headline: Investment Gives Rise to Youth in Mexico
text: In Guanajuato, Mexico, foreign investment and local enrichment are cultivating a young, upwardly mobile middle class.

headline: In Middle of Mexico, a Middle Class Rises
text: GUANAJUATO, Mexico — A decade ago, Ivan Zamora, 23, might have already left for the United States. Instead, he graduated in May from a gleaming new university here, then moved on to an engineering internship at one of the many multinational companies just beyond the campus gates.

headline: With His Career Winding Down, Iginla Focuses on Winning a Stanley Cup
text: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Jarome Iginla calls it “the driver.” It has nothing to do with golf clubs or chauffeurs, but instead refers to a mind-set, a laserlike pursuit of the missing item on an almost certain Hall of Fame résumé: a Stanley Cup title.

headline: Latest Release of Documents on N.S.A. Includes 2004 Ruling on Email Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration released hundreds of pages of newly declassified documents related to National Security Agency surveillance late Monday, including an 87-page ruling in which the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court first approved a program to systematically track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.

headline: John Edwards Revisits His Past, Hanging Law Shingle Again
text: Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer.

headline: Casting Light on Little-Known Story of Albania Rescuing Jews From Nazis
text: There were a handful of European nations where the Nazi killing machine sputtered, but few seem more remarkable and less illuminated than Albania.

headline: Nets Start Fast but Lose Momentum and the Game
text: Up and down the Nets’ fortunes have bobbed through the early part of this season. Good vibes have remained ephemeral. Success has been fleeting.

headline: Sticking With Quarterback Grows More Risky for Ryan
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan has been burdened with turnover-prone quarterbacks during his tenure as the Jets’ coach, and he has handled them with incredible patience. Only once, after the Week 15 mess in Tennessee last year, has he benched the starter.

headline: After N.S.A. Disclosures, Yahoo Moves to Encrypt Internal Traffic
text: Thanks to the revelations of Edward Snowden, technology companies are feverishly enabling new security features in an effort to assure users, particularly abroad, that they are doing everything possible to secure their data from hackers and the National Security Agency.

headline: Medicare Part D: Republican Budget-Busting
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | defrock
text: defrock •\(ˌ)de-ˈfräk\• verb

headline: Hawkins Leaves Mets for Rockies
text: LaTroy Hawkins, 40, followed Marlon Byrd’s lead, becoming the latest Met to play well enough to price himself out of the team’s plans. Hawkins agreed to a one-year, $2.5 million contract with the Colorado Rockies, and will have a chance to be the team’s closer, according to a source with knowledge of the negotiations. In 72 relief appearances with the Mets, Hawkins compiled a 2.93 earned run average and had 13 saves.

headline: Another Animated Take on Bloomberg News
text: Next Media Animation of Taiwan is staying at the vanguard of coverage of the Bloomberg News self-censorship saga. It has posted its second take on the scandal — which, of course, Bloomberg says is not a scandal. Top Bloomberg editors have denied killing a story on a Chinese tycoon and his ties to Communist Party leaders for political reasons, despite accounts from several Bloomberg employees that that was the case.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 4:45 P.M. (IFC) JACKIE BROWN (1997) Pam Grier, above, stars as Jackie Brown, a flight attendant who makes ends meet by smuggling money from Mexico to the United States for a gun dealer named Ordell Robbie (Samuel L. Jackson) in this adaptation of the book “Rum Punch,” by Elmore Leonard, written for the screen and directed by Quentin Tarantino. When she is caught by a government agent (Michael Keaton), Jackie seeks to escape her menial existence with the help of a kindly bail bondsman (Robert Forster). “Among the best news about the film is that Samuel L. Jackson’s role is even splashier than the one he had in ‘Pulp Fiction’ and that his performance is even more of a treat,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “The film more than justifies its long, happy stretches of simply watching Ordell work his scams on the unsuspecting.”

headline: News Quiz | November 19, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: India’s Chief Climate Change Negotiator Ravi Shankar Prasad
text: WARSAW, Poland — The annual United Nations climate change conference, which runs from Nov. 11 to 22, started with an emotional appeal from the Philippine negotiator Yeb Sano, who declared that he would be fasting “until a meaningful outcome is in sight” in the wake of the  “staggering” devastation from Typhoon Haiyan in his country.

headline: Beirut Bombs Strike at Iran as Assad’s Ally
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A double bombing struck the Iranian Embassy compound in Beirut on Tuesday, in the deadliest assault on Iran’s interests since it emerged as the most forceful backer of the Syrian government against an armed insurgency. The frontal attack struck a symbol of the country’s powerful influence in Lebanon and neighboring Syria.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 19, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Tweets From the Past Make History Come Alive
text: In “History Comes to Life With Tweets From Past,” Noam Cohen writes about current “historical tweeting” projects.

headline: Chinese Nobel Winner Appealing Subversion Conviction
text: HONG KONG — Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned Chinese dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, will challenge his 2009 conviction on subversion charges in court, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Dutch Firm to Spin Off Drug-Making Business in $2.6 Billion Deal
text: LONDON — The Dutch life and materials sciences company Royal DSM said on Tuesday that it would spin off its pharmaceutical manufacturing business into a $2.6 billion joint venture with the New York private equity firm JLL Partners.

headline: What Does Cancer Smell Like?
text: On a lab bench in Philadelphia sits a tiny box lined with nearly invisible nanotubes and gold. A clear plastic pipe runs through it, and a thicket of pins, each sprouting a red or blue wire, protrudes from its end. As air from the pipe wafts over the nanotubes, electrical signals surge out of the box along the wire threads. The whole apparatus is situated near a vial of blood, “sniffing” the air above it through the pipe.

headline: Why Is Turkey Cheaper When Demand Is Higher?
text: When you do your Thanksgiving shopping this week, you will encounter two vastly different options for the centerpiece: an expensive heritage, organic, antibiotic-free, freshly killed turkey; or a relatively cheap, mass-produced, rock-solid-frozen bird. The frozen birds are a pretty attractive deal — especially because this time of year, they are unusually cheap. According to government data, frozen whole-turkey prices drop significantly every November; over the last decade, retail prices have fallen an average of 9 percent between October and November.

headline: Has Facebook Lost Its Edge?
text: Last week Facebook offered billions of dollars to buy Snapchat, the social media app that lets users send posts that disappear shortly after being viewed. When the yet-to-be-profitable upstart refused the whopping 10-digit offer, many have started asking the same question: Is Facebook losing its edge? What do you think?

headline: Josef Koudelka: Formed by the World
text: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: For Young Typhoon Survivors, Return of Play Is a Sign of Hope
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — At a typhoon refugee center on Samar Island in the Philippines, the traumatized children have slowly begun adjusting to their new normal.

headline: U.S. Budget Battles Seen as a Global Drag on Growth
text: FRANKFURT — Nervousness about United States monetary policy and fears of a budget and borrowing breakdown in Washington are creating a bigger drag on the global economy than expected, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned on Tuesday. The report was a more pessimistic view of global growth than six months ago.

headline: Daily Report: Dropbox Said to Seek $250 Million in New Funding
text: Online storage, once a backwater of the Silicon Valley technology scene, is suddenly a hot commodity, Quentin Hardy and David Gelles report.

headline: New York Today: Beware of Leaves
text: Updated 11:53 a.m. | Every year around this time, a silent menace threatens the region’s transit system.

headline: Voter Turnout in Nepal Is Heavy Despite Violence
text: NEW DELHI — Voters crowded polling stations across Nepal on Tuesday, defying attempts by a powerful Maoist group and other parties to disrupt or prevent new elections for an assembly to write a new constitution.

headline: Can ‘Right-Wing’ Grandparents’ Views on Homosexuality Be Changed?
text: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Assessing a Kevin O’Leary Investment on ‘Shark Tank’
text: Recently, when I sat down to watch the ABC reality show “Shark Tank” with my children, I was surprised to see a merchant cash advance lender, Total Merchant Resources, pitching the Sharks. Typically, the companies that present on the show offer a unique service or product. Instead, Total Merchant Resources is a “me too” player in the highly commoditized and competitive alternative-lending industry.

headline: Storm Brings Flooding and Destruction to Sardinia
text: ROME — Streets and fields were flooded, homes and cars were submerged, and at least 16 people were killed on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia after 17 inches of rain — half a year’s worth — pummeled the island over a 24-hour period.

headline: ‘Take Me to the River,’ From Al Green to Song Dogs
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Edwards Opens Law Firm
text: “Before he served as a United States senator, before he made a run at the presidency and before his political career collapsed amid a sex scandal and fraud trial, John Edwards was a trial lawyer,” Peter Lattman and Kim Severson write in DealBook. “Now, Mr. Edwards is returning to his roots and opening a new law practice. The plaintiffs’ firm, Edwards Kirby, reunites him with his former partner, David F. Kirby, and includes on its payroll his eldest daughter, Cate Edwards.”

headline: Fujifilm Finds Niche With Old-Style Cameras That Mask a High-Tech Core
text: TOKYO — Like many professional photographers, Irwin Wong, who shoots pictures for Japanese magazines, relies on digital single-lens reflex cameras for the bulk of his work — “bulk” being the operative word.

headline: My Mother, the Secret Communist
text: In 1928, my mother, Mary, dropped out of Hunter College to enter the family business: the domestic and international advancement of communism.

headline: International Style
text: This week, a few more highlights from the recent revisions in The Times’s stylebook.

headline: In Performance: Zachary Quinto of ‘The Glass Menagerie’
text: In the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams’s memory play “The Glass Menagerie,” Zachary Quinto plays Tom Wingfield, an aspiring writer and warehouse worker — and the play’s narrator — who lives in a cramped St. Louis apartment with his mother, Amanda, and his sister, Laura. In this scene, Tom talks about watching couples at a dance hall across from their home. The show, directed by John Tiffany, continues through Feb. 23 at the Booth Theater.

headline: China Offers Hospital Ship to the Philippines
text: Updated, 2:04 a.m. ET | After an outsized international effort to help the Philippines that has been notable for China’s slow response, it appears the Chinese authorities are trying to reverse the damage to their country’s image.

headline: After 3 Fires, Safety Agency Opens Inquiry Into Tesla Model S
text: DETROIT — A federal safety investigation of the Tesla Motors electric Model S sedan announced on Tuesday comes at a critical juncture for the car and the company.

headline: No Money, and a Growing Line at Starbucks
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Mapping Bitcoin
text: Bitcoin, the popular Internet currency, is on the map in more ways than one.

headline: Obstruction of Gossip
text: Updated, Nov. 20, 2013 | The singer mentioned in this post can now be named; the gag order has been lifted. He is Eyal Golan.

headline: Guwahati’s Cosmetic Development
text: “I come from Guwahati—a small town in the northeastern part of India,” I used to tell my friends in Minnesota, until one person asked me how large is Guwahati. When I answered, he looked at me shocked, “A small town of only 1.4 million people?” I smiled sheepishly because it was partly true, and partly untrue. Untrue because I had grown up believing that my Guwahati is a small town. True because, nowadays even I suspect that during my absence over the years—like a young girl in a large family — Guwahati has as if stealthily grown up without my notice.

headline: The Geezers Are Not Alright
text: The Washington Post editorial board wants to cut Medicare and Social Security. That has been its consistent position as long as I can remember. And what it advocates, always, are cuts in benefits, not costs — that is, while it may give lip service to efforts to control health-care costs (which seem to be going surprisingly well, in one of the untold success stories of Obamacare), what it has pushed repeatedly are things like a rise in the Medicare age. These are the kind of moves that are considered serious inside the Beltway. And as you might imagine, the Post has gone wild over recent suggestions that Social Security should be expanded, not cut.

headline: Changing Coaches Has Improved Fortunes in N.F.L.
text: N.F.L. teams are rarely patient. Owners and general managers are more apt to replace a struggling coach than to support him. This past off-season, eight teams switched coaches, not including New Orleans, which welcomed the return of Sean Payton after his one-year suspension. A coaching hire typically takes years to evaluate, but through 12 weeks, all eight coaches are either exceeding expectations or providing hope for the future.

headline: Carriers Reject a ‘Kill Switch’ for Preventing Cellphone Theft
text: Lawmakers in San Francisco and New York are pushing cellphone makers to adopt a so-called kill switch that would allow users to deactivate their phone remotely, discouraging criminals from stealing phones. But the cellphone carriers are not on board.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Uniform Wares Watch
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Sunday Style in Johannesburg
text: At the Maboneng Precinct in South Africa’s largest city, locals find style inspiration from their parents and African prints worn in a modern way.

headline: Progressive Caucus Seeks to Influence Race for New York Council Speaker
text: The populist groundswell that swept Bill de Blasio to victory in New York’s mayoral election is reshaping the City Council as well, with a cadre of fiercely liberal council members demanding a voice in choosing that body’s next speaker.

headline: The ‘Catch an Illegal Immigrant’ Game
text: The chapter of Young Conservatives of Texas at the University of Texas at Austin is planning on doing a silly thing on Wednesday. It has announced a game it calls “Catch an Illegal Immigrant,” in which students will walk around campus with the words “Illegal Immigrant” pinned to their clothing. People who spot and escort these students back to Y.C.T. will be given a $25 gift card.  The organization says it means to provoke a thoughtful discussion of a hot-button issue, but that is just a straight-faced put-on for what is really a sophomoric provocation.

headline: Another Taylor Rule
text: Or at least it seems to be a new rule — namely, pick whatever price index makes the point you want, even if it’s not at all the price index you would normally use.

headline: Chairman of Co-Operative Group Resigns Amid Scandal
text: Updated, 12:05 p.m. | LONDON – The chairman of the British food and financial services conglomerate Co-operative Group resigned on Tuesday amid media reports that the former top executive of its banking business was purportedly caught on video buying illegal drugs.

headline: Waging War on a Shoestring
text: SIMI VALLEY, Ca. – The four-star commander of all Air Force combat jets earned an audible gasp from the audience of national security specialists with his disclosure about American vulnerabilities brought on by the spending stalemate back in Washington.

headline: Photo of Palestinian Mother Was the Wrong Choice
text: Hundreds of readers wrote to me in recent days to protest the prominent use of a photograph that accompanied an article in The Times last Thursday.

headline: Report Documents a Rise in Fatal Shootings by New York City’s Police Officers
text: A knife-wielding man shot dead by New York police officers in the doorway of his Harlem apartment. An officer struck by a bullet in the base of his skull. A marked police van rattled by seven bullets as a group of officers sat inside.

headline: Whom or What Are Literary Prizes For?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Jennifer Szalai on the value of literary prizes.

headline: Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2013: Find Your Favorites
text: Every fall, Well pays tribute to the best part of the Thanksgiving table — the vegetable side dishes!

headline: Grace Club Gets a Redesign by Thom Filicia
text: Grace Bay Club, an upscale hotel in the Turks & Caicos, is giving itself a 20th-birthday present: a remodeling job by the celebrated designer Thom Filicia.

headline: Image of the Day: November 19
text: Bharatiya Mahila Bank is India’s first state owned women’s bank.

headline: A Short Sneak Peek at a New Robert Mitchum Documentary
text: For the last 12 years, by his own count, the photographer and filmmaker Bruce Weber has been assembling a documentary about Robert Mitchum, the movie star (and sometime recording artist) who died in 1997. It sounds like a natural counterpart to Mr. Weber’s gossamer 1988 masterpiece, “Let’s Get Lost,” about the jazz trumpet player Chet Baker.

headline: U.S. Striker Keeps Eye on His Next Target
text: VIENNA — The United States national soccer team will conclude its 2013 schedule with an exhibition against Austria on Tuesday. The result of the game will be of little consequence, but for many players it will be an important opportunity to make a case to be on next year’s World Cup roster.

headline: Israel Rejects Bid to Free Suspected Qaeda Operative
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected an appeal for the release of a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian who has been held in Israel without trial for more than three years, accused by the Israeli authorities of being a biological weapons expert in the service of Al Qaeda.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Equity in the Workplace
Typhoon Haiyan’s Epicenter
text: The Times’s Andrew Jacobs travels to Guiuan, on Samar Island, the Philippines, where residents are trying to resume normal life amid the devastation.

headline: On YouTube, Iranian Minister Says ‘Join Us’ in Ending Crisis
text: As soft piano music plays in the background, the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, strides through a vast, elegant hallway, skips down carpeted steps and pushes through glass-paneled doors. Then, seated, he looks directly at a video camera and asks: “What is dignity? What is respect? Are they negotiable? Is there a price tag?”

headline: The Other Gettysburg Address
text: Even before the address was given, Americans knew that a great speech was coming, and that it would come at Gettysburg. The battle had been so comprehensive, and its result so profound, that a lasting statement was needed to mark the burial of the dead. That the final resting place of the soldiers was in the North, conveniently close to media outlets, only added to the logic of a solemn utterance for the ages. Accordingly, an invitation went out to the person most likely to give it.

headline: Johnson & Johnson in Deal to Settle Hip Implant Lawsuits
text: Johnson & Johnson and lawyers for patients injured by a flawed hip implant announced a multibillion-dollar deal on Tuesday to settle thousands of lawsuits, but it was not clear whether the deal would satisfy enough claimants.

headline: Night Falls, and 5Pointz, a Graffiti Mecca, Is Whited Out in Queens
text: Graffiti is often denounced as vandalism, but the deliriously festooned, sprawling warehouses at the western edge of Queens rose far above that. Blanketed with giddy images, drawing street artists from around the world, 5Pointz was a decades-old legal haven considered both a “United Nations of Graffiti” and a semi-rebellious statement in a city some feel is growing too antiseptic. “Save 5Pointz,” the infamous British street artist Banksy urged in his final message to New Yorkers, after he wrapped his monthlong spree clandestinely decorating the city’s streets in October.

headline: From the Makers of Bonobos, a Shopping Site for the Ladies
text: Since 2007, men have been ordering pants from Bonobos.com, trying them on at home and returning them if they don’t fit. It was a way of shopping that fit the lifestyle of 20- and 30-somethings: without ever setting foot in a store or having to pay shipping costs. Today, the team behind Bonobos introduces Ayr.com, the women’s version of their successful men’s wear clearing house. Initially, the site will offer two styles of denim: skinny jeans ($175) and a cigarette leg ($165), each available in either a light or a dark wash. “I like to say you could do yoga in these jeans,” said the design director Jac Cameron, a veteran of Calvin Klein and Madewell. “I wanted to recreate a silhouette working with the stretch of the fabric to create a jean that molds to the body as you wear it.”

headline: Dallas, 50 Years After an Assassination
text: Half a century after President John F. Kennedy was killed, the city has been coming to grips with the worst moment in its history.

headline: Contest Aims for a Cleaner-Burning Wood Stove
text: WASHINGTON — Only blocks away, the Energy Department manages the search for quarks and NASA scours the heavens for Earth-like planets. But inside a big white tent on the National Mall, the focus is on something simpler: oak, ash and elm, and how to make them heat a house with as little pollution as possible.

headline: Four Principal Dancers at City Ballet to Retire
text: Four principal dancers with New York City Ballet — Jenifer Ringer, Janie Taylor, Sébastien Marcovici and Jonathan Stafford — will retire during the 2014 winter and spring seasons, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: 50 Years Later, a Changed Dallas Grapples With Its Darkest Day
text: DALLAS — When President John F. Kennedy’s motorcade left the airport here shortly before noon on Nov. 22, 1963, the man seated in the lead car was the county sheriff, Bill Decker, 65, a storied Texas lawman who led the hunt for Bonnie and Clyde. Fifty years later, the badge belongs to Lupe Valdez, 66, the daughter of Mexican migrant farmworkers. She is the only sheriff in America who is an openly gay Hispanic woman. Voters re-elected Sheriff Valdez, a Democrat, to a third term last year.

headline: Monty Python Troupe to Reunite for Live Shows
text: A certain Norwegian Blue parrot is still dead, nearly 44 years after it shuffled off its mortal coil and joined the choir invisible in a famous television comedy sketch. But there is life yet in Monty Python, the singularly influential British troupe, whose surviving members are to announce this week that they will join together for their first live performances in more than a decade.

headline: ‘Selfie’ Trumps ‘Twerk’ as Oxford Dictionaries Word of the Year
text: “Selfie” — defined as “a photograph that one has taken of oneself, typically one taken with a smartphone or webcam and uploaded to a social media website” — has beaten out “twerk,” “bitcoin” and other comers to claim the title of Oxford Dictionaries 2013 Word of the Year.

headline: An Art Teacher Preserves the History of Harlem, While Creating Her Own Legacy
text: She was only 6 years old and a first grader at a Catholic school in Harlem. But stepping into an art class at St. Aloysius taught by Alice Mizrachi steered Chayse Sheppard’s life at a young age in ways she did not fully appreciate until she was older.

headline: Today in Small Business: Turkey Shortage?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Our Pages: November 20
text: 1913: Dog Rescues Starving Lost Pet

headline: Nash’s Return From Concussion Isn’t Enough as Rangers Fall to Bruins
text: Tuukka Rask and his Boston teammates were too much for the Rangers and a returning Rick Nash to surmount Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, where the Bruins skated to a 2-1 victory.

headline: Afghans Demand That U.S. Admit Military Errors
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Months of fraught negotiations and public posturing over how a long-term American military force could remain in Afghanistan have suddenly come down to a demand for a single personal gesture: a display of contrition by President Obama for military mistakes that have hurt Afghans.

headline: Start-Up Founders Look Beyond the Usual Options of Selling or Going Public
text: Successful tech entrepreneurs eventually face a choice, known in Silicon Valley as an exit: either sell their start-ups to bigger companies or take them public. As we wrote on Monday, that decision can be painful and personal. And like Snapchat’s rejection of Facebook’s billion-dollar offer, it is often a high-stakes bet.

headline: Who’s Putting a Roof Over Parents’ Heads
text: Do you really need that in-law suite?

headline: Virginia Political Figure Stabbed as Son Takes Own Life, Police Say
text: State Senator R. Creigh Deeds, a leading Virginia political figure who ran unsuccessfully for governor in 2009, was stabbed repeatedly on Tuesday at his home during an altercation with his son, who then apparently took his own life, the authorities said.

headline: Senator Offers Overhaul of Corporate Tax Code
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the powerful Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday released a long-awaited plan to overhaul the tax code for multinational corporations, trying to jump-start an effort to stem the flow of jobs and money abroad.

headline: The Illusions of Employer-Based Health Insurance
text: My Sunday column closed with a warning to conservatives that Obamacare — at least in some form — may turn out to be more durable than its disastrous rollout would seem to suggest, because the nature of the welfare state means that even programs that don’t live up to their promises can be awfully hard to dislodge. (As a case in point, see the outcome of the weekend’s House election in Louisiana, where the anti-establishment, right-wing, “Duck Dynasty”-endorsed winner was also … in favor of Obamacare’s Medicaid expansion.)

headline: McKinsey & Company Report on the Health Care Law and the Website
text: A report by McKinsey & Company warned in March that HeathCare.gov was at risk of failure.

headline: S.E.C. Official Charged With Making False Statements
text: A Securities and Exchange Commission official was criminally charged on Tuesday with making false statements about stock holdings that he wasn’t allowed to own under the agency’s ethics rules.

headline: Caring for Aging Parents, Even From a Distance
text: THROUGH the 1990s, Patrick Quirke’s career was sailing along. Every few years, he would be promoted at the transportation company where he worked and move to another city. He said he had every reason to believe that he would be promoted to the company’s headquarters in a few more moves. Then, his parents’ health started to decline.

headline: John Hodgman to Highlight Under the Radar Festival
text: John Hodgman of “Daily Show” and Apple commercials fame, is heading downtown as a first-time participant in the Under the Radar festival, the Public Theater’s annual program of experimental works, which runs Jan. 8 to 19.

headline: Police Station Is Attacked by the Shabab in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Attackers from the Shabab militant group assaulted a police station in a Somali town north of Mogadishu on Tuesday, leaving at least 28 people dead and scores more wounded.

headline: A Bob Dylan Video 47 Years in the Making
text: Promotional video clips were hardly unknown when Bob Dylan released “Like a Rolling Stone” as a single in 1965, but Mr. Dylan never made one for the song. Now Columbia, his record label, is making up for that oversight with a newly produced web video for the song, mainly to promote “The Complete Album Collection, Volume 1,” a 47-CD set that includes all of Mr. Dylan’s studio albums, six live sets and a two-disc rarities compilation. But in the process, the company is redefining the way promotional clips are viewed.

headline: The Gun Report: November 19, 2013
text: A California law prohibiting anyone convicted of domestic violence from possessing a gun is a legitimate and constitutional measure to keep firearms out of the wrong hands, a federal appeals court has ruled.

headline: Wheelies: The Turbo Honda Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Grace Kelly on J.F.K.: An Animated Interview
text: In keeping with the (rightfully) bottomless wellspring of Kennedy retrospectives this month, the web series “Blank on Blank” made its own contribution today with an excerpted interview with Grace Kelly recorded not long after the president’s assassination. Set to video and accompanied by the animation of Patrick Smith, Princess Grace speaks of Kennedy’s fashion sense and youthful optimism, and she strains to find meaning in the tragedy that had just played out in front of the world.

headline: What Is Harry Reid Waiting For?
text: For the third time in as many weeks, Senate Republicans have blocked a judicial nominee to the second most powerful court in the country, and for the third time it is not because they doubt his qualifications — how could they? He’s a sitting district court judge who was unanimously confirmed by the Senate just three years ago. Nor is it because they fear he harbors an extreme ideology.

headline: Perks Ease Way in Health Plans for Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress like to boast that they will have the same health care enrollment experience as constituents struggling with the balky federal website, because the law they wrote forced lawmakers to get coverage from the new insurance exchanges.

headline: Antiquated Trades Endangered in a Rapidly Changing Myanmar
text: In every society, professions disappear in the name of progress. But Myanmar’s rapid modernization has accelerated that process for roadside phone shops, rubber stamp businesses and other trades.

headline: As Myanmar Modernizes, Old Trades Are Outpaced by New Competitors
text: YANGON, Myanmar — For years they poured out their hearts on the broken pavements of Myanmar’s cities and towns, young lovers desperate for privacy yet with no choice but to use what the Burmese call roadside phone shops.

headline: Handset Unit Nearly Sold, Nokia Now Looks to an Uncertain Future
text: HELSINKI, Finland — Nokia’s shareholders took a major step on Tuesday to reshape the company, voting overwhelmingly in favor of selling the company’s handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion.

headline: Opposition Voiced to Return of Klimt Work to Heirs of Former Owner
text: Two groups connected to the Secession building in Vienna, where Gustav Klimt’s monumental “Beethoven Frieze” is housed, have spoken out against a claim by heirs of its former owner to recover the artwork. Last month heirs of the Lederer family, Jews who owned the four-ton frieze before the Nazis’ annexation of Austria in 1938, filed a claim with Austria’s Art Restitution Advisory Board, arguing that after World War II the government had in effect used its power to grant export licenses to compel the family to sell the work at a cut-rate price to the state.

headline: Living in Island Park, L.I.
text: Though pummeled by Hurricane Sandy, this affordable South Shore community is rebounding.

headline: Island Park: Sandy as Mother of Reinvention
text: Last year, two days after Hurricane Sandy walloped the islet of Island Park, Rosmarie T. Bovino, the school superintendent, along with her principals and teachers, walked the square mile of the school district to see what each of its families needed. Though the two schools, the administration building and the public library had been devastated, Dr. Bovino, who calls the schools “the heart of the village,” wanted to “make sure the children had food to eat.”

headline: An Odd Spinoff by Royal DSM
text: Royal DSM has come up with an odd formulation to solve its drug-production headache. The company, which is the world’s biggest vitamin maker, is merging its DSM Pharmaceutical Products business with a private equity-backed rival.

headline: Israeli Military Stalls a College Career
text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — For months, Tom Maayan had been the focal point of an international tug of war, pitting the Israeli military against a major American university, while clouding what looked to be a bright basketball career. But when Maayan, a sophomore at Seton Hall, returned to the bustling campus here Aug. 16, after five months of army service in Upper Galilee, the northern Israeli province where he was raised, it was with a sense of relief.

headline: Grand Vision for Former Home of Walter Reed Hospital
text: WASHINGTON — The boxy Brutalist hospital built in the late 1970s stands virtually vacant, as do brick buildings erected during World War I, officers’ quarters dating to the 1920s or before, and myriad other structures that together make up the former Army medical center named for Walter Reed, the physician who linked mosquitoes to yellow fever at the turn of the 20th century.

headline: Pratt Institute Celebrates Four Leaders in Design and Culture
text: On Nov. 11, more than 350 people, including the singer Judy Collins, attended Pratt Institute’s Legends 2013 gala benefit, which honored four eminences in design and culture and raised nearly $800,000 for student scholarships. Held at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in New York, the event was hosted by Ted Allen, of the Food Network series “Chopped.” The honorees were the writer Pete Hamill; the artist James Turrell; David Easton, an interior designer; and Margaret Russell, the editor in chief of Architectural Digest.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in SAC Insider Trading Trial
text: Updated, 5:36 p.m. | Selection of a 12-member jury from a pool of about 100 people began on Tuesday at the insider trading trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager.

headline: Now With High-Tech Gifts for the Holidays
text: For a moment, you might think you’re in Oz. Nine huge, shining, transparent spheres rise into the air and drift inexorably toward you, as if nine versions of Glinda the Good Witch were about to burst forth.

headline: Taking Aspirin at Night May Boost Heart Benefits
text: Millions of adults take an aspirin every morning to ward off heart disease. But a new study suggests that the pills might be most effective if taken right before bed.

headline: Will Forte on the Glories of the Great Plains
text: In the new film “Nebraska,” Will Forte plays the dutiful son to Bruce Dern’s curmudgeonly father who is convinced he has become a sweepstakes millionaire.

headline: In Extracting Deal From JPMorgan, U.S. Aimed for Bottom Line
text: Updated, 9:44 p.m. | When Tony West arrived in a Justice Department conference room to put the finishing touches on a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase, he saw a familiar number flash on his cellphone.

headline: Jostens Agrees to Buy Rival in Commemorative Paraphernalia
text: Jostens, a seller of yearbooks and class rings to students across the United States, is looking to gain a bigger piece of the business of school spirit.

headline: Calico, Google Health Venture, Names New Hires
text: The new Google-backed venture to extend the human lifespan has hired away the head of global product development from Roche, the pharmaceutical giant, as well as a noted molecular biologist from Princeton.

headline: Brenda Fryson: Mayor of Stoops
text: Brenda Fryson manages a long list of community organizations, committees and revitalization and development projects from a home office she calls “The War Room.”

headline: The Bats Blog Is on the Move
text: Thank you for visiting Bats. This blog’s regular features, including live game analysis, news and notes from Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and others, and other coverage, can now be found on the baseball section of our website. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely baseball news.

headline: Holiday
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Charlotte Zolotow, Author of Books on Children’s Real Issues, Dies at 98
text: Charlotte Zolotow, a distinguished author and editor of children’s books whose work — both her own titles and those of the writers in her stable — offered even the youngest readers a forthright view of emotionally fraught subjects like anger, envy and death, died on Tuesday at her home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 98.

headline: Devon Said to Be Near Deal to Buy GeoSouthern for $6 Billion
text: Devon Energy is near a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energy, a privately held oil and gas driller, for about $6 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Craig Bierko Won’t Return to ‘Matilda’
text: Weeks after announcing a lengthy medical leave from the plum role of Miss Trunchbull in “Matilda the Musical,” Craig Bierko has bowed out of the Broadway production entirely.

headline: Senate Majority Leader Backs Gillibrand on Military Assault Measure
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, on Tuesday threw his support behind a measure that would give military prosecutors the power to decide which sexual assault cases to try, rather than commanders.

headline: Murdoch Divorce Said to Be Almost Final
text: Rupert Murdoch and Wendi Deng Murdoch are negotiating the final details of their divorce settlement, a deal that will officially end the 14-year marriage of the media mogul and his third wife, according to people with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Relief Efforts Improve in Storm-Hit Areas
text: Medical care is beginning to take hold, with 62 foreign or Filipino medical teams now working in areas with the most damage.

headline: Bipartisan Assent to Hold Off New Iran Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — In a meeting with Senate leaders on Tuesday, President Obama failed to sway critics of his effort to sign an interim nuclear deal with Iran. But in a modest concession, they agreed to hold off on a vote to impose new sanctions on Iran until after talks in Geneva later this week.

headline: Making ‘Healthy’ Treats of Halloween Leftovers
text: Am I the only one with Halloween candy still hanging around the house?

headline: No Budget, Because HealthCare.gov
text: After they were blamed for causing a disastrous shutdown, many Republicans seemed to want to get the year’s budget fights behind them. As of a few weeks ago, some of them seemed open to relieving the sequester, which is widely hated by lawmakers in both parties, and Congressional appropriators thought they had a chance to enact real spending bills instead of running the government with yet another continuing resolution.

headline: Update for a Global Medical App
text: HTH Worldwide, which offers health insurance and other products to those travelling internationally, has made updates to its mobile application, mPassport, adding more translations of drug names and medical phrases and providing regional health alerts.

headline: $13 Billion JPMorgan Settlement
text: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department finalized a $13 billion settlement, punctuating a long legal battle over the risky mortgage practices that became synonymous with the financial crisis.

headline: Piora
text: Inside the West Village restaurant where Korean flavors dart in and out of the menu.

headline: A Marriage of Ingenuity
text: You can put up with mediocre food in a restaurant that has other things going for it. When an exciting chef works in a terrible dining room, though, you feel the way you do when a friend hooks up with somebody you can’t stand. You may visit the two of them once or twice to savor the full extent of the new partner’s awfulness, but then you run for cover while you await the end.

headline: Monetary and Fiscal Implications of Secular Stagnation
text: Since I gave Larry Summers’s endorsement of secular stagnation theory a plug, I’ve been getting a lot of commentary in various forms. Some of it is the usual Keynes-hatred and/or incomprehension, and not worth going into. But there are also some questions/complaints that call for some serious further exegesis.

headline: Mini’s 3rd-Generation Hardtop Shows Subtle Aesthetic Changes
text: Next year’s calendars are already out, including one called Pug Mugs, which displays police-style headshots of adorable dogs. Mini could produce a calendar like that, now that the bulldog of cars has unveiled its third generation since BMW rolled out the first of the reborn Minis 13 years ago.

headline: Kids These Days: They’re All Older Than 50
text: When did “mature” get so immature?

headline: Woman Says Zimmerman Choked Her During Fight
text: George Zimmerman, whose February 2012 killing of an unarmed black teenager propelled him to the center of an emotional national debate about self-defense laws, choked his girlfriend during an argument this month, a Florida prosecutor said on Tuesday.

headline: How the Safety Net Held Up in the Recession
text: Finally, some kind words for government. Robert A. Moffitt, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, says in a new paper that the country’s social safety net did a good job during the recession, expanding by half a trillion dollars.

headline: Ronaldo’s 3 Goals Carry Portugal to World Cup Berth
text: The original pool of hopefuls had 207 teams, a diverse group of soccer nations ranging from minnows to monoliths that nonetheless had a common destination in mind. Now, more than 800 qualifying matches later, the field of 32 teams that will take part in the World Cup next year in Brazil is all but complete.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 12: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
text: As if the 2013 N.F.L. season were not strange enough, we are now at the point where 4-6 is a respectable record in the A.F.C. Unfortunately, 4-6 will probably not get you into your fantasy football playoffs, so it is time to buckle down with leagues a few weeks away from the postseason.

headline: Enduring Nazi Law Impedes Recovery of Art
text: HALLE, Germany — Wolfgang Büche was amazed this month when a watercolor seized by the Nazis from the small museum in this eastern city, where he is the curator, reappeared, part of a vast trove uncovered in a Munich apartment.

headline: Gotham West Market, a New Food Hall, Opens on the West Side
text: Headliner

headline: Vatican Unveils Revamped Catacombs Museum
text: ROME — Celebrating the meeting of ancient and modern worlds, the Vatican on Tuesday presented a revamped museum of antique funerary remains in Rome, while inviting the rest of the world to peek inside that space by computer.

headline: One Bach Influencing the Other
text: In his new book, “Bach: Music in the Castle of Heaven,” the conductor John Eliot Gardiner persuasively expands our sense of the influence that the brilliant composer Johann Christoph Bach (1642-1703) may have had on his young cousin Johann Sebastian (1685-1750). The two men’s music, Mr. Gardiner writes, shares a “subtle blend of intense subjectivity and polyphonic distance.”

headline: Hotel Review: The Graham Hotel in Washington, D.C.
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Guild & Company in Burlington, Vt.
text: As a restaurant concept, “farm-to-table steakhouse” comes off as so buzzwordy that it’s like a “Portlandia” sketch begging to be written. So perhaps it’s not incidental that Guild & Company, which executes the conceit with unfussy charm, sits along the outskirts of Burlington, Vt., the East Coast’s best facsimile of that tongue-in-cheek television utopia.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Lebanon, the Philippines, Nepal and Egypt.

headline: Mike Lee and the Republican Opportunity
text: One of my recurring themes in this space is the weakness of the Republican Party’s policy agenda; another is the limitations of the Bloombergist/“donorist” style of moderation that’s regularly offered as the obvious direction for the G.O.P. to take. So I’m grateful to Ron Fournier of National Journal for taking on the first issue in a way that lets me talk, at length, about the second. Here’s Fournier, attacking Republicans for remaining “the party of zilch” amid the Obama administration’s recent flailings:

headline: France Is Heading to Brazil and Can Make Amends
text: PARIS — Defying the bitterly low expectations of a populace that had largely written them off as prima donnas, the French national soccer team defeated Ukraine, 3-0, on Tuesday night and secured a place at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

headline: Judges Must Warn About Deportation, New York Appeals Court Rules
text: New York judges must warn immigrant defendants that they face deportation if they plead guilty to a felony, the state’s highest court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: A Writer Thanks Her Lucky Stars
text: Eleanor Catton was all but swallowed up the other day by the buzz and hum of a Midtown hotel lobby, with its chattering tourists. In the midst of a victory tour after winning the 2013 Man Booker Prize for her second novel, “The Luminaries,” Ms. Catton had not yet fully adjusted to being an object of attention, or even to being allowed to stay in a fancy hotel, as she described it.

headline: Advanced Maternal Age Mother Seeks a Big Fat Positive Pregnancy Test
text: I’m no fertility authority, despite what my husband might think.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Investors Shaken by Projected $60 Million Loss
text: Investors and executives with the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” said on Tuesday that the show will have historic losses of up to $60 million when it closes on Jan. 4. The closing follows a sharp decline in ticket sales because of competition from hotter musicals and a lack of star attractions in the cast.

text: NEED FOR SPEED

headline: Unavoidable Answer for the Problem of Climate Change
text: Japan’s announcement last week that it would not meet its promise to sharply reduce its carbon emissions met a chorus of disapproval from around the world.

headline: Son of Israel, Caught in the Middle
text: “If you want everyone to love you,” Saul Bellow wrote, “don’t discuss Israeli politics.” Yet when Bellow went to Israel for several months in 1975 to research a nonfiction book, all he did was talk politics — and everything else. It was what he loved best about Israel, the “gale of conversation.”

headline: Obama Speaks at Executive Summit
text: President Obama talked about economic progress despite the government shutdown and problems with the rollout of the health care website.

headline: Annual Firearms Discharge Report From the New York Police Department
text: More people died from police gunfire last year than during any previous year of the Bloomberg administration, according to a Police Department report released Tuesday.

headline: Arthur W. Zeckendorf
text: Mr. Zeckendorf, 54, is a principal, along with his brother, William Lie Zeckendorf, of Zeckendorf Realty, developer of luxury condominiums and retail space in Manhattan, like 15 Central Park West and 18 Gramercy Park, both in partnership with Global Holdings.

headline: Emotion at Final Shareholder Meeting for Microsoft’s Ballmer
text: BELLEVUE, Wash. — The turnout at Microsoft‘s annual shareholder meetings is often sparse, with loads of empty seats in a conference hall in this Seattle suburb.

headline: Attack in Beirut Through the Lens of Hezbollah TV
text: As our colleagues Hwaida Saad and Anne Barnard report from Beirut, the deadly bombings at the gate of the Iranian Embassy in the Lebanese capital on Tuesday were immediately interpreted there as a form of retaliation for Iran’s intervention in the civil war in neighboring Syria.

headline: Teaching About J.F.K. With The New York Times
text: Updated: Nov. 22, 2013

headline: G’Day From Bushwick
text: Standing in the dining room of the early 1900s-era brick rowhouse, deep in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn with not a frozen yogurt shop or Starbucks to be found, Alan Dixon, an investor from Australia, struggled to tally the houses he had bought in the area over the last year.

headline: Weighing the Risks of Going Without Health Insurance
text: FOR many people, complying with the new health care law will become a financial decision: Should I buy the insurance, or simply pay the penalty and take my chances?

headline: Navigating a Transformed Insurance Marketplace
text: ESSENTIAL benefits. Flexible benefits. High deductibles. Coinsurance. Bronze, silver, gold, platinum.

headline: Pushing Patients to Seek Value, Whatever That Is
text: PETER KREUTZER is, in many ways, an ideal patient. Mr. Kreutzer, a 57-year-old Brooklyn writer, is in good health, eats well and follows his doctor’s instructions.

headline: Medicaid Help Without Falling Into Poverty
text: WHEN Colin Sandler was in high school in the mid-1980s, her grandparents legally separated after 45 years of marriage. This was not because their marriage was troubled, but because her grandfather had fallen ill and medical bills threatened to consume their entire life savings and all their income, leaving Ms. Sandler’s grandmother penniless.

headline: Private Exchanges Rise as Health Care Options
text: THE troubled rollout of the federal health insurance marketplace this fall has given the word “health exchange” a bad name. Nonetheless, some companies are choosing to offer their employees health benefits via private exchanges — online insurance marketplaces that are separate from the federal system.

headline: Planning for a Future in the Face of Terminal Illness
text: PATRICK SKELDON, a commercial airline pilot, started having trouble walking in the autumn of 2003. His doctor thought he had a vitamin deficiency and prescribed supplements. When those didn’t work, the doctor referred him to a neurologist. The next year, he was told he had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, more commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s disease. He was 59.

headline: You Plan Your Retirement, Then You Get the Health Bill
text: JEFF STRACK, a 61-year-old sales manager in Charlotte, N.C., enjoys his work and is in good health. But the prospect of paying for health costs after he retires weighs on him.

headline: How Doctors Die: Showing Others the Way
text: BRAVE. You hear that word a lot when people are sick. It’s all about the fight, the survival instinct, the courage. But when Dr. Elizabeth D. McKinley’s family and friends talk about bravery, it is not so much about the way Dr. McKinley, a 53-year-old internist from Cleveland, battled breast cancer for 17 years. It is about the courage she has shown in doing something so few of us are able to do: stop fighting.

headline: For Those at Death’s Door, a Case for ‘Life Panels’
text: AT the beginning of 2012, my mother was 95 years old. She lived in an assisted-living center, with hospice care, in a hospital bed 24/7. She was hollow-eyed and emaciated. Though she had moments of clarity, she was confused, anxious and uncomfortable. Her quality of life was minimal, at best. And the cost to keep her in this condition had risen to close to $100,000 a year.

headline: ABC Shuffles Its Prime-Time Lineup
text: ABC, the network that has struggled most in the ratings this fall, announced a series of changes to its prime-time schedule Tuesday, which included the addition of five new series and the cancellation of one flop. The network also unveiled a new entrant in its long-running effort to fashion a hit comedy in the half-hour following its biggest hit, “Modern Family.”

headline: Art Matters | Art, Underground Music and Basketball Collide in Queens
text: Last Sunday afternoon, two different rhythms resounded through the VW Dome in the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Queens. One was provided by Future Brown — a new D.J. supergroup made up of the genre-bending artists and musicians Fatima Al Qadiri; Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda of Nguzunguzu; and J-Cush of Lit City Trax. The second, which synced well with the first, came from the steady bounce of basketballs.

headline: Go Elsewhere, Young Scientist
text: It’s hard to measure the economic consequences of sequestration, but surely this is not a good thing:

headline: Reid Preparing to Move for Limits on Filibuster
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, is prepared to move forward with a vote that could severely limit the minority party’s ability to filibuster presidential nominees, possibly as early as this week, Democrats said Tuesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Honoring the Selfie, and Questioning Dropbox’s Valuation
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Comparing Costs of Three Conditions
text: Expected costs for a year of medical care without insurance and under different tiers of coverage — silver, bronze or a high-deductible “catastrophic” plan that insures against major expenses.

headline: Estimating Retiree Health Costs
text: Total needed for the average couple retiring today at age 65, with average life expectancies (woman lives to be 85; man, 82).

headline: London Cyclist Fatalities Bring Calls for Truck Limits
text: LONDON — Public transport in London is always expensive, often crowded and sometimes unreliable, so there is no mystery about why bicycle trips here in Britain’s capital increased by around a third in the decade up to 2011.

headline: A Graphic Novel With Teeth (and Claws)
text: Comic book publishers have embraced the digital realm, incorporating entertaining features like motion and sound to attract new readers. But one start-up, Anomaly Productions, is taking a bigger step, adding augmented reality to the pages of its sci-fi graphic novels.

headline: Enhanced Sound, With Wi-Fi and Android
text: The Sceptre Speaker SoundBar SB301523 is a smart idea at a reasonable price — a soundbar with Wi-Fi and the Android operating system built in, so you can get TV shows and video from the Internet without adding another box. While the idea is good, the execution is half-baked.

headline: Engineered for Sound, at a Price
text: Is a pair of headphones worth $1,250? Shure thinks so.

headline: Justices Reject Bid to Block Texas Law on Abortions
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday turned away an emergency application asking it to block a Texas law that requires doctors performing abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.

headline: Egyptian Police Clear Tahrir Square With Tear Gas on Anniversary of Deadly Clashes
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 1:30 p.m. | As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, protesters were cleared from Tahrir Square on Tuesday night, after a day of demonstrations dedicated to the memory of dozens of activists who were killed by the security forces on this date two years ago.

headline: Options Narrowed, U.S. Is Said to Weigh Destroying Syrian Chemicals at Sea
text: WASHINGTON — Unable to find a country willing to dispose of Syria’s chemical weapons, the United States is considering plans to place the chemical components of the weapons on a barge where they would be dissolved or incinerated, according to senior American officials.

headline: Baucus Corporate Tax Proposal Takes Aim at Merger ‘Inversions’
text: There’s lots for big companies to like about a proposed overhaul of the corporate tax code, put forward on Tuesday by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.

headline: A Divided City
text: Murders have declined substantially in St. Louis, but violence remains persistent in the city’s majority-black areas.

headline: Shiller vs. Fama vs. the Skeptics
text: Robert Shiller and Eugene Fama, sharing a stage for the first time since it was announced last month that they would share the 2013 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, sparred with languorous familiarity Tuesday about the efficiency of financial markets.

headline: An Underground Drink Cast as a Film Star
text: A tall plastic soup container is filled with ice, over-proof rum, cheap liqueurs and fruit juices and stashed in a brown paper bag. Some money changes hands. What happens after that, at least for the buyer, can get blurry.

headline: Salesforce.com and HP Buck Common Wisdom of Cloud Computing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Are Hewlett-Packard and Salesforce.com onto something?

headline: Ahead of Anniversary, Promoting All Things Kennedy
text: ON a recent morning, pedestrians on Columbus Circle walked by a newsstand stocked with boxes of nickel candy bars like Hi-Noon and Tofy-Nut; cartons of Kent and Tareyton cigarettes; and periodicals that carried photographs of President John F. Kennedy on their covers or front pages.

headline: The End of 5Pointz
text: Works of graffiti artists at 5Pointz, a warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, were painted over during the night.

headline: California: Los Angeles Airport Shooting Suspect Leaves Hospital
text: The man accused of killing a federal agent at Los Angeles International Airport was released from Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center on Monday and taken to a federal holding facility, the authorities said Tuesday. The suspect, Paul A. Ciancia, 23, is believed to have opened fire in the crowded terminal on Nov. 1, killing Gerardo I. Hernandez, 39, a Transportation Security Administration agent, and wounding two others. A spokesman for the United States attorney’s office said that “no details about his custody status or location are being released at this time.” Mr. Ciancia led police officers through a chase in the terminal and was shot in the head and leg. He was listed in critical condition for more than 10 days, and federal investigators were not able to question him. Mr. Ciancia could face the death penalty if convicted.

headline: A New Party Challenges the One That Has Run India for Most of Its History
text: NEW DELHI — Snaking down one of this city’s dusty back streets on a recent afternoon was a line of auto-rickshaws, the motorized buggies that course through this city by the tens of thousands, carrying ordinary citizens on their daily rounds. Unless you looked closely, you could miss the fact that they were part of a political insurgency.

headline: Celebrities Beckon Indians to Travel Sites
text: India’s most revered athlete, Sachin Tendulkar, swung his final cricket bat on Friday ahead of one of the most watched and  talked-about retirements from athletics in India — or, for that matter, anywhere.

headline: Jane Pratt Fitzpatrick, 89, Savior of Pre-Revolutionary Inn, Dies
text: Jane Pratt Fitzpatrick, who with her husband saved the Red Lion Inn, the pre-Revolutionary hostelry in Western Massachusetts immortalized by Norman Rockwell in his painting “Stockbridge Main Street at Christmas,” died on Nov. 9 at her home in Stockbridge. She was 89.

headline: Florida Congressman Faces Charge of Cocaine Possession
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, was charged Tuesday with misdemeanor possession of cocaine after having been arrested here last month, according to District of Columbia Superior Court documents.

headline: Beware Marauding Carp
text: EARLIER this month, researchers demonstrated that a Eurasian species of fish, the grass carp, had begun reproducing in Lake Erie. This may not sound like alarming news, but unless we take steps to prevent its spread, this animal is poised to disrupt the ecology of the Hudson River and New York’s other inland waters.

headline: Bringing an End to a Senseless Policy
text: SHANGHAI — CHINA announced last week that it would loosen its famous “one-child” policy, enforced since 1980. The world’s most controversial birth-control policy, initially imposed as an emergency measure at the start of the economic reforms of Deng Xiaoping, seems to finally be on its way out, more than a generation later.

headline: Doctors Say Heart Drug Raised Risk of an Attack
text: Cardiologists have accused a small drug company of withholding data from a clinical trial showing that the company’s drug, meant to reduce the risk of heart attacks, increased the risk instead.

headline: Energy Dept. Is Told to Stop Collecting Fee for Nuclear Waste Disposal
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that the Energy Department must stop collecting fees of about $750 million a year that are paid by consumers and intended to fund a program for the disposal of nuclear waste. The reason, the court said, is that there is no such program.

headline: Vonn Crashes While Prepping for Return
text: Lindsey Vonn’s World Cup comeback from major knee surgery may have been delayed by a training crash Tuesday in Colorado. Vonn, the reigning Olympic downhill champion, was being evaluated by a team orthopedist after the crash, the United States Ski Team said. The team did not disclose what kind of injury Vonn had sustained.

headline: Mentally Ill, and Jailed in Isolation at Rikers Island
text: From the annals of Rikers Island comes a document titled, “Three Adolescents With Mental Illness in Punitive Segregation in Rikers Island.” Punitive segregation means solitary confinement for 23 hours a day. Schoolwork, if it comes, is passed through a slot in the cell door. Toothpaste is available once a day.

headline: N.S.A. Spying Scandal Hurts Close Ties Between Australia and Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The relationship between Indonesia and Australia, Pacific neighbors with a long history of cooperation and trade, has in recent years been marked by disagreements on a range of issues, including human rights, terrorism and asylum seekers. But relations reached a new low over the weekend over the latest bombshell from the surveillance scandal involving a third country, the United States.

headline: As Trader’s Trial Begins, Name of One Insider Stands Out
text: From his cubicle at Dell’s headquarters in Round Rock, Tex., Rob Ray shared insights about the computer maker that ricocheted across the country, reaching a trust company in California, a mutual fund in Manhattan and hedge funds in New York and Connecticut.

headline: Koch Brothers’ Group Uses Health Care Law to Attack Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity, the political group backed by the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, is targeting three of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats who are up for re-election next year. The group’s efforts are part of a new $3.5 million attack advertising campaign that hammers lawmakers for supporting President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Russians and Bach, With Equal Keyboard Energy
text: After playing Shostakovich’s Piano Sonata No. 2 in B minor at Zankel Hall last Tuesday evening, the pianist Olli Mustonen wiped the sweat from his brow and looked at the audience with an expression that hovered between exhaustion and resignation. He had just offered an impassioned rendition of this tormented piece, composed in 1943 after Shostakovich had been evacuated during the Siege of Leningrad. The composer dedicated the work to an important mentor, his teacher Leonid Nikolayev, who had died the previous year. Mr. Mustonen played the opening movement’s frenzied surges with powerful clarity, beautifully contrasting them with the yearning melody that unfolds between demonic outbursts. He brought a searching insight to the second movement Largo, with an emotionally subdued character that offers a respite between the angst of the outer movements. Mr. Mustonen’s judicious use of pedal and vivid touch created an impressive range of colors in the turbulent concluding section, in which a ruminative melody unfurls over rumbling bass chords and later, in the left hand, under intense right-hand patterns.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Calls for Transforming the Technology Used by Phone Systems
text: WASHINGTON — Americans could soon be one step closer to getting that videophone they were promised in the 1960s.

headline: A Municipal Bankruptcy May Create a Template
text: Jefferson County, Ala., which just became the first municipality to tap the public bond markets while bankrupt, will go to court on Wednesday to seek approval for its plan to exit bankruptcy by the end of this year.

headline: It’s a Fashion Show for Sports Teams
text: Sports teams once had simple fashion rules. Wear one uniform at home, usually white, and another on the road.

headline: Health Insurance Marketplace Is Still About 40 Percent Incomplete, Official Says
text: WASHINGTON — The chief digital architect for the federal health insurance marketplace said Tuesday that 30 percent to 40 percent of the project was still being built.

headline: Let’s Make a Deal
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — The Middle East once again proves that if you eat right, exercise regularly and don’t smoke, you’ll live long enough to see everything, including a day when the Jews controlling Jerusalem and the Sunni Saudi Custodians of the Great Mosques of Mecca and Medina would form a tacit alliance against the Shiite Persians of Iran and the Protestants of America — with the Hindus of India and the Confucians of China also supporting America, sort of, while the secularist French play all sides.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Vladimir Putin Clings to the Past
text: The former republics of the Soviet Union have been sovereign, independent countries for almost 22 years, free to develop economic and political relations with any foreign nation or trading bloc they choose. That point appears to have eluded President Vladimir Putin of Russia, who is doing everything he can to prevent these countries from developing closer ties with Europe — even threatening to cut off the gas that one country needs to get through the winter.

headline: Small Protest in Tahrir Square Restores Dissent to Cairo’s Heart
text: CAIRO — The protesters’ numbers were small, compared with the millions who have marched through Egypt’s streets in recent months. And at one point, a soccer game on television seemed more urgent than the chants.

headline: A Long-Running Trial
text: Nearly 40 years after the murder of 15-year-old Martha Moxley of Greenwich, Conn., people are still fascinated about the details of the case.

headline: Family’s Tenacity and Wealth Put Skakel at Cusp of Freedom
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — Since Michael C. Skakel’s conviction in 2002 in the 1975 murder of his Greenwich neighbor Martha Moxley when they were both 15, Mr. Skakel and his family have spared no expense in their efforts to clear his name.

headline: Advertisements for the Common Core
text: The country is engaged in a fierce debate about two educational reforms that bear directly on the future of its schoolchildren: first, teacher evaluation systems that are taking hold just about everywhere, and, second, the Common Core learning standards that have been adopted by all but a few states and are supposed to move the schools toward a more challenging, writing-intensive curriculum.

headline: The Expiring Ban on Plastic Guns
text: Even after the Newtown, Conn., massacre, Republican opponents of reasonable firearms restrictions in Congress blocked proposals for strengthened background checks and other steps to make future gun tragedies less likely. Now the question is whether anti-gun-control extremists will allow a federal ban on the manufacture, sale, import or possession of guns that are undetectable by metal detectors and X-ray machines to expire on Dec. 9.

headline: Citing Fed’s Efforts, Bernanke Says U.S. Economy Is Growing Stronger
text: WASHINGTON — A few months of scrambled economic data have not altered the Federal Reserve’s basic view that the American economy is gaining strength, nor its intention to start pulling back soon from its stimulus campaign, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Tuesday evening.

headline: Sounds From the Sky
text: Among the phrases I have never trusted are the collective nouns associated with animals — a murder of crows, a scurry of squirrels, that sort of thing. They turn up mostly when people are making lists of collective nouns associated with animals, and their roots — if they have roots — are usually never mentioned. All in all, they reek of a kind of linguistic cleverness I find far too cute. Plus, they’re all too easy to make: a puddle of poodles, a terrine of terriers, a rumpus of reptiles, etc.

headline: JPMorgan Settlement Offers Look Into Mortgage Machine
text: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department reached a record $13 billion settlement on Tuesday, wrapping up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Street’s mortgage machine before the financial crisis, when it churned out billions of dollars in securities that later imploded.

headline: A Mother’s Pain Fed That of Her Daughter
text: On a recent afternoon, Khalilah Hyde-Peyrefitte was bustling around the 20th floor of a towering office building in Midtown Manhattan, greeting colleagues with a wide, beaming smile. A small-business coordinator for McKissack & McKissack, a construction and design firm, she has the bearing of any bright, ambitious, recent college graduate, enthusiastic and eager to excel. But Ms. Hyde-Peyrefitte, 21, also carries the weight of the pain and disillusionment she had to overcome.

headline: In Places Like North St. Louis, Gunfire Still Rules the Night
text: ST. LOUIS — The unmistakable pop of a gunshot ricocheted through the park in the humid air, and Montez Wayne could only hope that the bullet did not have his name on it. He sprang from his seat beneath a sprawling bald cypress, ready to make his move.

headline: Charge Is Dropped in Beating Death in Harlem
text: Prosecutors on Tuesday moved to dismiss misdemeanor charges against a Harlem man accused in the beating death of a transgender woman in August, citing confusion over who exactly was involved in the assault.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 20, 2013
text: “Today’s event demonstrates the political and economic costs of Syria for Iran. Syria is a kind of flytrap for the Iranians. They’re just stuck to it.”

headline: Twisted Sister, and Brothers
text: WASHINGTON — And I thought my family Thanksgivings were rough.

headline: Sanctions' Successes and Failures
text: When do sanctions work? And when do they do more harm than good?
