Attorney General on JPMorgan Settlement
text: Eric H. Holder Jr. talks about JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion agreement for its  risky mortgage practices.

headline: Corrections: November 20, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Story to Question, Word for Word
text: Oscar Wilde’s warning that “the truth is rarely pure and never simple” should be affixed to all documentaries, whatever their form or content. Most television watchers are, by now, savvy enough to understand that there ain’t much reality in reality shows.

headline: Handy Way of Communicating
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this … this puzzle is the sound of my teen years. Sorry, did I say puzzle? I meant the album that the puzzle highlights. When you went to school dances where I lived, you did the Hustle and other disco horrors when you were in public but — if you were to be considered a teen of good taste — when you got home, it was Jackson Browne who lived on your turntable*.

headline: In Stance on Renewal of Old Health Policies, States Run the Gamut
text: Just a few days after President Obama said that millions of consumers should be able to keep their old insurance plans for another year — even if they did not meet the requirements of his health care law — he is finding support among states that would not exactly be described as allies.

headline: Chevron Assails Lawyer Who Led Multibillion-Dollar Suit Against It
text: For two years Chevron has said that a multibillion-dollar judgment in a pollution case against the company in Ecuador was rigged by an American lawyer, Steven R. Donziger, asserting that he tampered with witnesses and bribed an Ecuadorean judge. On Tuesday, the company’s lawyers confronted Mr. Donziger in a Manhattan federal courtroom.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,276 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Pierce, Now Surrounded by Scorers, Seeks a Role
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Three weeks ago, after the Nets secured a galvanizing victory at home over the Miami Heat, Kevin Garnett bestowed upon his longtime teammate Paul Pierce the nickname Picasso, reasoning that every night on the court, Pierce seemed to produce affecting artistry — “a beautiful painting,” Garnett said.

headline: Typhoon Response Highlights Weaknesses in Philippine Military
text: GUIUAN, the Philippines — As American cargo planes and military helicopters zipped across the sky above this decimated city, ferrying badly needed supplies to typhoon survivors, Philippine soldiers were working with what little they had — relying on motorcycles and boats to ferry messages between the army’s provincial headquarters and stricken municipalities along the eastern coast of Samar, some of them more than a hundred miles away.

headline: A Dynasty Strained
text: Michael C. Skakel’s legal defense has been supplemented by trust funds set up for the family by his grandparents.

headline: Cano to the Mets? Unlikely at His Price
text: If the Mets were going to puff out their chests and declare themselves spenders this off-season, they might as well act like it, at least once in a while. So on Monday night, Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager; Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer, and John Ricco, the assistant general manager, met for dinner in Manhattan with Jay Z and associates and listened to their pitch on Robinson Cano, the Yankees second baseman who has become the highest-priced item on baseball’s free-agent market.

headline: Pockets of Crime Persist in St. Louis Neighborhoods
text: Life on the North Side of St. Louis can be marked by shockingly violent interludes on seemingly ordinary days.

headline: The Obamacare Crisis
text: Health care as a necessity comes only after food, shelter and income security. The mismanagement of the website HealthCare.gov and the cancellation of millions of policies pushes an underlying question out into the open: Is the federal government capable of managing the provision of a fundamental service through an extraordinarily complex system?

headline: Toronto Residents Have Funny Feeling About Mayor, and His Longevity
text: TORONTO — When your city becomes the punch line of an international joke, it pays to keep your sense of humor too.

headline: Knicks, Running Out of Options, Fall Short Again
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — By the time Coach Mike Woodson called a timeout after an emphatic Andre Drummond dunk, there was not much left in the Knicks’ tank. They trailed the Detroit Pistons by 15 points with 9 minutes 20 seconds remaining as Woodson sat in the huddle. There was time for a comeback, but around Woodson, the options were limited.

headline: A Brutal Feud Emerges in Uzbekistan’s Fractured First Family
text: MOSCOW — Truth be told, Gulnara Karimova, the eldest daughter of the strongman leader of Uzbekistan, never did seem particularly well qualified to succeed her father at the head of their impoverished and troubled Central Asian nation.

headline: Canada: Doctor Convicted of Molesting Female Patients
text: An anesthesiologist at a Toronto hospital was convicted on Tuesday of sexually molesting 21 women after sedating them. Once he had put the women, who ranged in age from 25 to 75, into a state of semi-consciousness, Dr. George Doodnaught kissed and groped them and, in comes cases, forced them to perform sexual acts. Justice David McCombs of the Superior Court of Ontario said that expert witnesses effectively refuted claims by Dr. Doodnaught’s lawyers that the women were suffering from sexual hallucinations brought on by anesthesia drugs. Dr. Doodnaught will be sentenced early next year and faces another hearing about his medical license.

headline: Russia: Judges Grant Bail to Nine Greenpeace Activists
text: Russian judges in St. Petersburg granted bail to nine more crew members of a Greenpeace International ship who were arrested in September after a protest against oil drilling in the Arctic, all of them foreigners. The rulings came a day after three Russian crew members from the ship, the Arctic Sunrise, were also granted bail, though the detention of yet another activist, Colin Russel of Australia, was extended until February, as the investigation into the protest against an off-shore oil rig in the Pechora Sea continues.

headline: Venezuela: Assembly Hands More Powers to President
text: The National Assembly on Tuesday voted to give President Nicolás Maduro decree powers for one year, which will allow him to create laws on his own, without going through the legislative process. The so-called special powers permit Mr. Maduro, a socialist, to make laws aimed at fighting corruption and regulating the economy, but critics say that in practice those areas are broad enough that there may be few limits over the reach of his decrees. Many Venezuelan presidents have been given similar decree powers, including Mr. Maduro’s predecesor and mentor, Hugo Chávez, who died in March. Mr. Maduro, who is grappling with runaway inflation and severe shortages of many basic goods, has said that he will quickly move to create a law widening price controls and capping business profits.

headline: Zimbabwe: Sanitation Crisis Causes New Cholera Risk
text: Millions of Zimbabwe residents are at risk of waterborne diseases including a resumption of cholera because of a water and sanitation crisis in the capital, Harare, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Tuesday. The report, issued five years after cholera killed more than 4,000 Zimbabweans and sickened 100,000, described a collapse in water and sanitation services. Residents must often drink from shallow, unprotected wells befouled by sewage, according to the report, which was based on research conducted over the last two years.

headline: U.S. Player Ratings: Austria (1), U.S. (0)
text: VIENNA — On a cold night at Ernst Happel Stadium, the United States men’s national soccer team ended its 2013 year Tuesday with a sloppy exhibition loss against an Austria team that failed to qualify for the World Cup.

headline: The Labor Market and Labor Policy Since Kennedy
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Mother’s Exercise May Boost Baby’s Brain
text: If a woman is physically active during pregnancy, she may boost the development of her unborn child’s brain, according to a heart-tugging new study of expectant mothers and their newborns. The findings bolster a growing scientific consensus that the benefits of exercise can begin to accumulate even before someone is born.

headline: Word of the Day | virile
text: virile •\ˈvir-əl, ˈvir-ˌi(-ə)l\• adjective

headline: For Those in Their 20s, a Finding That They Don’t Manage Debt Well
text: You’re a young adult, starting to build your career. You’re trying to juggle student loan payments, pay your rent and cover other bills, so it’s tempting to make an occasional late payment on your credit card. No big deal, right?

headline: Albuquerque Voters Defeat Anti-Abortion Measure
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Voters here on Tuesday defeated a ballot question that sought to ban abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, delivering a critical setback to an anti-abortion movement that had sought to use this progressive city to recalibrate the national debate around women’s reproductive rights.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 11 P.M. (NBCSN) COSTAS TONIGHT SPECIAL — NO DAY FOR GAMES: THE COWBOYS AND J F K  Bob Costas, above, examines the assassination of President John F. Kennedy through the eyes of the 1963 Dallas Cowboys and Roger Staubach, then a college quarterback for Navy. Other former players, including the defensive tackle Bob Lilly, the linebacker Lee Roy Jordan and the tight end Pettis Norman; the Cowboys’ longtime personnel chief Gil Brandt; Dan Rooney, the chairman of the Pittsburgh Steelers; and the historian Michael Beschloss weigh in.

headline: Top Filmmaker Reportedly Sought for Bucking Family Planning Rules
text: Family planning officials in the eastern coastal city of Wuxi are apparently at wit’s end with a nationwide effort to find the internationally acclaimed director Zhang Yimou, according to a report by the state-run news agency Xinhua.

headline: States Where Insured Could Renew Plans Before Change by Obama
text: Some states have said they will not follow President Obama’s recently announced policy.

headline: News Quiz | November 20, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: British Climate Economist Lord Nicholas Stern
text: WARSAW, Poland — Even as the annual United Nations climate change conference is nearing its end on Friday, negotiations are obstructed by longstanding disputes over responsibilities of combating the crisis.

headline: Gary Locke to Leave as U.S. Ambassador to China
text: The American ambassador to China, Gary F. Locke, the first Chinese-American to hold the post, announced Wednesday that he was stepping down to rejoin his family in Seattle.

headline: Xi Puts Himself at Center of China’s Economic Makeover
text: Short, perhaps, of handing out autographed copies of the Chinese Communist Party’s plans for change, there is little more President Xi Jinping can do to show he has wagered his credibility on restructuring the economy while cleaning up and entrenching one-party rule.

headline: Property Taxes Hoped to Curb China’s Real Estate Excesses
text: Housing prices in China’s major cities continue to soar, according to a report released by the National Bureau of Statistics on Monday. With the exception of Wenzhou, in the eastern province of Zhejiang, housing prices rose in 69 of the 70 major cities in the survey during the first 10 months of 2013. In 21 cities, prices jumped more than 10 percent, and in 26 cities, they climbed by 8 percent to 10 percent. Shanghai and Beijing topped the list, with increases of 21.4 percent and 21.2 percent, respectively.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 20, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Thai Court Rejects Bid for Direct Elections of All Senators
text: BANGKOK — A Thai court ruled on Wednesday that a major initiative by the ruling party was an attempt to “overthrow” the country’s democratic system, increasing pressure on a beleaguered government already made fragile by weeks of antigovernment protests.

headline: 50 Years Later
text: The assassination of John F. Kennedy changed the world forever.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Graffiti Mecca Is Gone
text: In “5Pointz, a Graffiti Mecca in Queens, Is Wiped Clean Overnight,” Marc Santora and Cara Buckley write about the surprise that greeted fans of street art on Nov. 19.

headline: A Small-Scale Thanksgiving
text: Christmas persecutes the lonely and rejected, the New York newspaperman Jimmy Cannon wrote in a syndicated column in 1962. Perhaps it does. But the holiday holds nothing on Thanksgiving.

headline: How Is Hamid Karzai Still Standing?
text: The Karzai family graveyard lies a few miles outside Kandahar, on the edge of the village of Karz. On the day I drove there, burned-out cars stood rusting by the sides of the road, children splashed through open drains and bullet holes riddled the mud walls opposite checkpoints. Amid all this, the graveyard stood out — gleaming, immaculate. Straggling bougainvillea and mulberry trees blossomed over the calligraphic tiles topping the cream-colored walls. Through the double gates were lines of cypresses. In the middle stood a domed enclosure containing the graves of the clan elders.

headline: The Search for the Lost Marines of Tarawa
text: We had been on the island for about an hour when we found the first skeleton. It was a pile of yellow bones tucked inside a cardboard box. Mark Noah squatted down for a look. He is a stocky man of 48, with a light buzz of blond hair and the wind-beaten eyes of a lifelong outdoorsman. Since 2008, he has been traveling to the tiny Pacific atoll of Tarawa to search for the remains of more than 500 Marines who died there in World War II. Sometimes locals dig up their bones and leave them in his storage locker.

headline: Josef Koudelka: A Restless Eye
text: We highly recommend viewing the slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: A Misunderstood Directive
text: The old man lashed out the first night he spent in the nursing home. His behavior was so alarming that staff transferred him to a nearby hospital for evaluation.

headline: Who Is the ‘Mayor’ of Your School or Neighborhood?
text: “New York has always been a city of mayors. Every block has one. So do industries, underworlds and dog parks,” begins a new interactive that features nine New Yorkers nominated by readers for their role in different city communities — including Cheyanne Smith, whom the feature calls the “mayor of teenagers.”

headline: Egyptian Soldiers Killed in Sinai Attack
text: CAIRO — At least 11 Egyptian soldiers were killed on Wednesday after suicide bombers drove an explosives-laden car into a convoy of military buses traveling in the Sinai Peninsula, according to a spokesman for the armed forces.

headline: ScienceTake: Sea Slug Love
text: In the mating game, males and females can have different agendas even when they inhabit the same body.

headline: Bomb Attacks Kill Dozens in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — A wave of apparently coordinated bombings hit bakeries and public markets in Baghdad on Wednesday, killing at least 42 people and wounding more than 90, many of them as they rushed to shop during a break in heavy rainstorms, according to the police, residents and medical officials.

headline: New York Today: J.F.K. in the Bronx
text: Updated 12:05 p.m. | Let us now visit the house where a 10-year-old John F. Kennedy lived.

headline: Toyota Shows Off Fuel-Cell Automobile
text: TOKYO — Hydrogen-powered cars are finally being readied for their Prius moment — at least, that is what promoters of the environmentally friendly technology hope.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at 6 a.m.
text: Iranian nuclear talks resume in Geneva; reaction to the painting over of a graffiti mecca in Queens; and love among sea slugs.

headline: A Different Kind of Mating Dance
text: A sea slug from the Great Barrier Reef, so small that one would never notice it with the naked eye, has been caught on video in a mating behavior so extreme that it appears to be a scientific first.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Ethan Koh: Inspired by Home
text: The designer behind Ethan K sits down with Suzy Menkes to discuss the inspiration behind his handbags.

headline: How One Small Business Got Big
text: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners were joined by a guest, Rebecca Cenni, who founded Atrium Staffing in 1995. Atrium is a staffing and payroll firm with about 130 employees, $140 million in annual sales, and offices in New York, Boston, San Francisco, Pittsburgh, and four cities in New Jersey. Ms. Cenni talked about the challenges of growing and managing her business, offering insights she has gained since starting Atrium at age 23.

headline: Advice on How to Research Family History, Part 3
text: Elizabeth Shown Mills, a genealogist and historical writer, is answering readers’ questions about how to research family history using online sources, physical public records and the stories and DNA of living family members. Part 1 of her answers is here. Part 2 is here. [Update: Part 4 is here. This feature is now closed to new questions.]

headline: Cost Aside, JPMorgan May Have a Good Deal
text: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase on Tuesday agreed to a mortgage settlement that will cost the bank $13 billion, a large number that will bolster the government’s claims that justice was done.

headline: The Two Lucknows During Muslim Holy Month
text: The raised sign for Avadh Point on Victoria Road in Old Lucknow is missing two letters, the “O” and the “I.” The “D” in Avadh also hangs precariously, as if it is ready to become the third. The three-story building was constructed in 2005, but it stands dilapidated, walls thinning and paint peeling, as if it is as old as the Awadh culture it’s named after.

headline: Crime and No Punishment
text: MEXICO CITY — On the night of Jan. 30, 2010, in the border city of Ciudad Juárez, in a neighborhood called Villas de Salvarcar, a birthday party full of teenagers was interrupted by a commando. A group of about a dozen barged in shooting and ended up killing 15 people and wounding 10.

headline: Daily Report: Nokia Considers Its Uncertain Post-Handset Future
text: Nokia’s shareholders took a major step on Tuesday to reshape the company, voting overwhelmingly in favor of selling the company’s handset business to Microsoft for $7.2 billion, Mark Scott reports.

headline: Deal May Be Near as New Iran Nuclear Talks Open
text: GENEVA — Senior diplomats from six world powers and Iran opened a new round of talks on Wednesday in Geneva amid expectations that they were closing in on an agreement to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program.

headline: A Gift From Steve Jobs Returns Home
text: On a recent night at an elegant Beaux-Arts ballroom in San Francisco’s financial district, Laurene Powell Jobs received a computer with an unusually rich history. Around 1980, Ms. Powell Jobs’s husband, Steven P. Jobs, donated the computer to a nonprofit organization, the Seva Foundation, to help the group manage data from its efforts to restore sight in the developing world.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Glimpse Into JPMorgan’s Mortgage Machine
text: JPMORGAN SETTLEMENT OFFERS LOOK INTO MORTGAGE MACHINE  |  The record $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department on Tuesday wraps up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Street’s mortgage machine before the financial crisis, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook.

headline: Cooperating Witness a Key in SAC Insider Trading Case
text: The Justice Department has had a perfect record in winning insider trading cases since it began its most recent campaign in 2009. Now, it will put that record to the test as the trial of Michael S. Steinberg, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, begins this week. The case will highlight the crucial issue in most white-collar crime prosecutions: What did the defendant know about the illegal nature of the transactions?

headline: Giving a Subway Hog the Business
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Republican Leads San Diego Mayor’s Race
text: LOS ANGELES — A year after Bob Filner became the first Democratic mayor of San Diego in two decades, Republicans feel they are poised to reclaim the city’s top office.

headline: High Losses for Penney, but Shares Jump
text: J. C. Penney may have reported a bigger-than-expected loss on Wednesday, but investors say they are seeing signs that the retailer’s business is improving.

headline: Too Old to Get Rich?
text: I wonder why nobody has ever asked me to write a personal finance column, given that I’ve done so well in this area. The mortgage on my apartment is paid off. I have no debts. I have enough money in the bank that I can live decently until 93, unless I’m flattened by a truck and the hospital doesn’t take my secondary insurance:

headline: White Supremacist Convicted of Several Murders Is Put to Death in Missouri
text: Joseph P. Franklin, a white supremacist who killed at least eight people in a shooting spree from 1977 to 1980 and confessed to being the sniper who wounded the Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt and the lawyer and civil rights activist Vernon E. Jordan Jr., was executed on Wednesday, the Missouri Department of Public Safety said.

headline: Polish Prime Minister Replaces Top Cabinet Officials
text: WARSAW — Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland on Wednesday overhauled his cabinet apparently in an effort to bolster his flagging poll numbers, replacing Poland’s top finance official and changing environment ministers in the middle of a United Nations climate conference his country is hosting.

headline: Devon Clinches Deal for GeoSouthern Assets
text: Updated, 2:59 p.m. | Devon Energy, an independent drilling company, reached a deal to buy GeoSouthern Energy’s holdings in southern Texas for $6 billion, the two companies announced on Wednesday, in the biggest takeover in the oil and gas industry this year.

headline: Political Questions About the Jobs Report
text: With the economy dominating the campaign for the White House last fall, did the government cook the books to make the unemployment rate move lower and help President Obama’s re-election chances? Was manipulation responsible for lowering the unemployment rate to 7.8 percent in September 2012 from 8.1 percent in August, a big deal when the numbers came out in October 2012, just weeks before the election?

headline: Spike Lee, Still Gliding to Success
text: “Rage doesn’t have to fester for years, but revenge?” the director Spike Lee said, as he rapidly autographed 50 movie posters in a downtown Manhattan hotel suite. “That stuff takes time. It’s the oldest staple of films, in stories. It goes back to the Bible.”

headline: Gina Cecala: Mayor of the Block
text: Gina Cecala, 82, sits sentinel in front of a building in Little Italy, bantering with mail carriers, delivery people, beggars, friends and strangers.

headline: Elevated Park at Trade Center Site Comes Into View
text: The World Trade Center’s best-kept secret has finally come to light.

text: THE LITTLE MERMAIDA Pop-Up Adaptation of the Classic Fairy TaleBy Robert Sabuda12 pp. Little Simon/Simon & Schuster. $29.99. (Pop-up book; ages 4 to 11)

headline: Frederick Sanger, 95, Twice a Nobel Laureate and a Genetics Pioneer, Dies
text: Frederick Sanger, a British biochemist whose discoveries about the chemistry of life led to the decoding of the human genome and to the development of new drugs like human growth hormone, earning him two Nobel Prizes, a distinction held by only three other scientists, died on Tuesday in Cambridge, England. He was 95.

headline: Image of the Day: November 20
text: People in Kochi, Kerala, exercising and taking a walk along the Fort Kochi beach.

headline: The State of Obamacare
text: I haven’t been writing about the healthcare.gov thing, for the simple reason that I have nothing to say. What’s going on isn’t a policy question: we know from the states with working exchanges (including California) that the underlying structure of the law is workable. Instead, it’s about an implementation botch, which is an incredible mess, and reflects very badly on Obama. But the future of the reform depends not on policy per se but on whether the IT issues can be fixed well enough soon enough, a subject on which I have zero expertise.

headline: Today in Small Business: 577 Million Vacation Days
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Rolling Stones to Tour in Australia and New Zealand
text: Even before the Rolling Stones played what appeared to be the finale of their 50th anniversary tour, at Hyde Park in London on July 13, word was spreading among Stones fans that the band would reconvene after a hiatus, and Stones-related web pages buzzed with speculation about where the concerts would be: Germany, the Netherlands, Finland and Norway were all floated as likely, as were both North and South America.

headline: British Regulators Said to Be Reviewing Gold Benchmarks
text: LONDON – Regulators in Britain are reviewing whether global benchmarks tied to gold trading were improperly influenced as part of a wide-ranging investigation of potential manipulation of the $5 trillion-a-day currency market, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

headline: Feeling For | At Long Last, a Perfectly Designed Tote
text: I am on a perpetual quest for the perfect tote bag. My dream bag is boxy, so that nothing gets lost. It feels substantial, with handles that are sturdy but not clunky-looking. It has a couple of pockets, including one with a zipper. And it has no logos. Such a bag is not, I can assure you, available on every street corner.

headline: Consecrating Hallowed Ground
text: On the morning of Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2013, a small army of Civil War re-enactors, a well-known Lincoln impersonator, federal government representatives, the governor of Pennsylvania and its two senators, its congressional representative and a host of municipal officials gathered at the Gettysburg National Cemetery to mark the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s famous address.

headline: DeVos Institute of Arts Management to Relocate to the University of Maryland
text: Michael M. Kaiser’s arts management institute is moving from the Kennedy Center in Washington to the University of Maryland and Mr. Kaiser is moving with it — four months earlier than his originally announced departure.

headline: Top Japanese Court Stops Short of Nullifying 2012 Vote
text: TOKYO — In a widely watched ruling, Japan’s Supreme Court on Wednesday called last year’s parliamentary elections out of compliance with the Constitution because of inequalities in the size of voting districts, but stopped short of declaring the results invalid.

headline: Ann Demeulemeester Leaves Her Company
text: Ann Demeulemeester, one of the Antwerp Six designers who brought an original, if gloomy, look to fashion in the 1980s, has decided to leave her company, she said on Wednesday.

headline: Helping Out Cats and Dogs in Hawaii
text: Miss Fido while on vacation? In Hawaii, the Maui Humane Society offers two new fixes for pet-lonely travelers: afternoon visits with the shelter’s cats and dogs, and the opportunity to escort a pet off the island for adoption.

headline: Social Security and Secular Stagnation
text: A brief thought inspired by the suddenly prominent debate over secular stagnation.

text: 1938: Killer Frets Over Lack of Soap

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at Noon
text: Attacks in Baghdad kill dozens; ‘Spider-Man’ to go dark on Broadway; and dressing athletes in an array of uniforms.

headline: Message From Insurance Commissioners
text: Insurance commissioners from a handful of states, including North Carolina and Kansas, sent the following email to their counterparts in other states late Tuesday regarding the meeting between insurance commissioners and President Obama today to discuss the Affordable Care Act.

headline: States Are Left to Decide on Health Plan Change
text: A group of state insurance commissioners emerged from a meeting with President Obama and other federal officials on Wednesday saying that state regulators would continue to decide on their own whether to go along with his recent proposal to let consumers keep older insurance plans for an extra year, even if the plans did not comply with regulations under the new health care law.

headline: The 1950s, Roiling Under the Surface

Gurney (“The Dining Room,” “Love Letters” and many more) has been a probing storyteller, peeking behind curtains into the homes of families — many of them white Anglo-Saxon Protestant, upper-class types living the lifestyle of the country club set.

text: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: In Obama’s Pick to Lead a Financial Regulator, an Enigma
text: President Obama has nominated Timothy G. Massad to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. If you thought, “who?” — well, that may be the point.

headline: Florida Congressman in Cocaine Case Will Take a Leave of Absence
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, announced late Wednesday that he would take a leave of absence from office after pleading guilty earlier in the day to a misdemeanor charge stemming from his purchase of cocaine here last month. He was sentenced to one year of probation.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
text: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

headline: Wheelies: The R.I.P. Wankel Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Snowboard Legend Explores the Obscure
text: In the first episode of Higher Unplugged, a new series by Teton Gravity Research, snowboarder Jeremy Jones reveals why he has abandoned iconic peaks for obscure terrain.

headline: A Dublin Neighborhood Pushes Its Boundaries
text: The cobbled quarter of Temple Bar has long maintained its tourist-destination status with overpriced pints of Guinness and a reputation for wild bachelor parties. While these traits endure, entrepreneurs have begun to reclaim the historic streets flanking the south side of the Liffey River. Now, locals are being lured back into the compact neighborhood. The common theme is pushing boundaries, from a secret cocktail bar to restaurants showcasing flavors beyond the typical Irish canon. With fallen prices and available real estate from the economic downturn, the heart of city center Dublin is experiencing a creative revival.

headline: Finding a Luxurious Home Away From Home
text: Websites like Airbnb and Couchsurfing have long helped travelers save money by renting and swapping their homes (or merely their couches) rather than pay for hotels. But as the sharing economy evolves, and as luxury travel grows, rental and home swap sites are increasingly catering to travelers with the desire (and budget) for a more sumptuous home away from home.

headline: Amid the New, Glasgow Looks to the Past
text: In September, the Foster and Partners-designed Hydro arena opened to much ado in Glasgow’s gritty Docks area. The translucent ultramodern building — Wi-Fi-enabled for up to 12,000 users — glowed a thousand colors and beamed spotlights up and down the River Clyde. Outside, vendors hawked rainbow wigs and tartan clan mugs. Inside, live Twitter feeds scrolled across 145 oversize high-definition screens. Rod Stewart opened the space with a bang of a show that brought out plaid-clad Glaswegians and their teenage children (and grandchildren). Mr. Stewart closed with a ripping “Da Ya Think I’m Sexy?” but rather than a crooner’s finale, it seemed more like a question the newly tarted-up city was asking itself.

headline: Times Announces Changes in Washington
text: The New York Times on Wednesday announced a reorganization of its Washington bureau, including the elevation of Carolyn Ryan to bureau chief and the start of two new ventures.

headline: Another American Citizen Is Arrested in North Korea
text: BEIJING — An 85-year-old American veteran of the Korean War was detained in North Korea last month as he was about to depart after having visited the country on a tourist visa, his son said on Wednesday.

headline: Italian Oil Giant Eni Plans to Sell Gas Field in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Eni, the Italian oil company, said on Wednesday that it intended to sell its stake in a natural gas field in the far north of Russia for about $2.9 billion and focus instead on a subsea pipeline and another Arctic Ocean venture.

headline: For Some, Paying Sales Commissions No Longer Makes Sense
text: At the start of 2012, ThoughtWorks, a software company based in Chicago, decided to upend one of the sacrosanct principles of sales. It eliminated commissions and placed its entire sales force, a team of 40 stretching across 12 countries, on straight salary.

headline: Bronx Tale of a BB Gun and Infamy in the Making
text: Nearly 30 years ago, a seventh grader at the East Midwood Hebrew Day School in Brooklyn needed to complete a social studies assignment, something along the lines of what was it like in the olden days. She set down a cassette tape recorder in front of her saba, her grandfather, and pressed a button.

headline: Can You Attract Top Sales Representatives if You Don’t Pay Sales Commissions?
text: An article just published in The Times looks at companies that have decided to stop paying sales commissions to its sales representatives.

headline: Thompson Finds Job at Old Office
text: William C. Thompson Jr., the former New York City comptroller who this year waged an unsuccessful bid for mayor, announced on Wednesday that he was returning to the municipal bond underwriting firm where he had previously worked.

headline: Rodriguez Walks Out of Hearing and Pleads Case on Radio
text: Alex Rodriguez, locked in a fight with Major League Baseball over his 211-game doping suspension, slammed down his hand and walked out of his arbitration hearing Wednesday morning, saying he was “disgusted with this abusive process.”

headline: Student Crossword | Under the Sea: Marine Life
text: Learn more about marine life by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Wall Street Could Benefit From Tax Proposal
text: Changes to the tax code always create winners and losers. An ambitious plan to revise the system for taxing multinational corporations, released on Tuesday by the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Max Baucus, would hit technology companies and large pharmaceutical companies especially hard. Companies like Pfizer, Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Microsoft have become masters at reducing their tax liability in the United States by shifting income overseas.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Investor Continues to Push for Deal With Jos. A. Bank
text: One of the biggest investors in Men’s Wearhouse made clear on Wednesday that it saw no better future for the retailer than a merger with its smaller rival, Jos. A. Bank.

headline: Jaguar Introduces F-Type Coupe With a Laser Show
text: Celebrities, such as Simon Cowell and Adam Carolla, gathered with a horde of largely unknown journalists Tuesday night to greet the new Jaguar F-Type Coupe, which the automaker unveiled at an event near the Los Angeles Auto Show.

headline: The Chronicles of C. S. Lewis Lead to Poets’ Corner
text: LONDON — C. S. Lewis was a noted polymath: philosopher, theologian, professor, novelist, children’s writer, literary critic, lecturer. But he was not much of a poet.

headline: In Westchester, an End to Elevator and Subway Commutes
text: Megan Zinger tried her very best to be a city mouse.

headline: On Day of Symbolism, Honoring Kennedy, and Successor He Inspired
text: WASHINGTON — Standing wordlessly before a flickering flame, their faces etched in the sunlight slanting through a canopy of thinning trees, two Democratic presidents came together Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery to honor the memory of a third.

headline: App Smart: Making Art With a Stylus
text: The Times’s Kit Eaton reviews painting and sketching apps where using a stylus, instead of just your finger, can come in quite handy.

headline: The Unemployment Rate at Full Employment: How Low Can You Go?
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. Dean Baker is a co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research. They are the authors of “Getting Back to Full Employment: A Better Bargain for Working People,” being published this week.

headline: 24,000-Year-Old Body Shows Kinship to Europeans and American Indians
text: The genome of a young boy buried at Mal’ta near Lake Baikal in eastern Siberia some 24,000 years ago has turned out to hold two surprises for anthropologists.

headline: Painting With a Stylus, Despite What Steve Jobs Said
text: When he introduced the iPhone and iPad, Steven P. Jobs asserted the touch-screen devices didn’t need a stylus because humans come with 10 great touch-screen controllers sticking out of our palms: fingers. He was proved right, and most new smartphones and tablets don’t require a stylus to work their touch screen.

headline: Q. & A. | Kathleen Hanna on Love, Illness and the Life-Affirming Joy of Punk Rock
text: As the incendiary lead singer of the band Bikini Kill, Kathleen Hanna became the most famous face of the riot grrrl movement, the early-’90s feminist counterpart to grunge. (She coined the phrase “smells like teen spirit,” which her friend Kurt Cobain would make famous.) Later, she moved from the Pacific Northwest to New York City, where she fronted the socially conscious dance-rock outfit Le Tigre, and most recently she founded the band the Julie Ruin, which released the kinetic record “Run Fast” in September.

headline: Albuquerque Rejects 20-Week Abortion Ban
text: Earlier in 2013, the House proposed a ban on abortion after 20 weeks, and twelve states have gone ahead and enacted such bans. But when Americans are asked if legislators should be spending their time restricting the abortion window, most respondents say no. And the more Americans hear about what a 20-week bans really entail, the more they grow wary of them.

headline: Russia Revokes License of a Bank With Ties to Putin
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s central bank on Wednesday revoked the license of a midsize Russian bank, Master Bank, and accused its management of siphoning off assets in insider deals, in one of the larger bank failures here in recent years.

headline: Broadcasters’ Fight Against Aereo Doesn’t Serve Their Interests
text: The latest TV industry technophobia is just as repetitive as a 1980s rerun. American broadcasters, including Walt Disney-owned ABC, have garnered support in their Supreme Court bid to shut down the online video start-up Aereo. The arguments echo those used 30 years ago when networks tried to block the VCR, after which business boomed. For a creative profession, media firms sure can lack imagination.

headline: Egyptian Nazi Will No Longer Participate at Georgetown Conference
text: Georgetown University has come under fire for inviting a founder of the Egyptian Nazi Party to a conference planned for December on the future of Egypt, which will feature a keynote speech by Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota, the first Muslim member of the United States Congress, and Dalia Mogahed, a former adviser to President Obama.

headline: Aid Distribution and Rebuilding in the Philippines
text: Food and water remain scarce, but aid is beginning to reach typhoon-affected areas.

headline: Turkey Economics, Annotated
text: My It’s the Economy column for this Sunday looks at an economic puzzle: why whole frozen turkey prices typically fall just when demand is highest, around Thanksgiving. Below I’ve compiled some of the data and theory that went into my reporting for those interested in digging a bit deeper into turkey economics.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Matchup Breakdown
text: Eli Manning, we just can’t quit you.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Explores the Obscure
text: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: The Gun Report: November 20, 2013
Illegal Immigrants Are Divided Over Importance of Citizenship
text: Glendy Martínez is waiting anxiously to see if Congress will ever pass legislation to allow immigrants like her, without papers, to stay in the country legally. But frankly, she says, she does not care if it will include any promise of citizenship.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Is the Man...’
text: The director Michel Gondry narrates a scene from his animated documentary interview with Noam Chomsky, “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?”

headline: Fed Looks for Other Ways to Aid Economy
text: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials, many of them reluctant to continue the Fed’s economic stimulus campaign in its current form, wrestled at their most recent meeting with other ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.

headline: What You Get For … $2,500,000
text: Properties include a Garden District house in New Orleans, a converted barn in Connecticut and a midcentury modern in Los Angeles.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,500,000
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Dad Was a Film Giant, Mum Was Mona Lisa. Perfect, Right?
text: Anjelica Huston grew up in such a bedazzlingly beautiful place that she couldn’t see beyond its magic. At least that’s the impression created by “A Story Lately Told,” the first half of Ms. Huston’s life story. In this charm-filled but often oddly opaque book, she writes of life at St. Clerans, the grand estate in County Galway, Ireland, full of pets, flowers, exotic treasures and her parents’ famous friends. Ms. Huston presents lovely inventories of the things that made St. Clerans special, but she never says much about the elephant in the room.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?’
text: For his new documentary, the director Michel Gondry interviewed the linguist and philosopher Noam Chomsky. The interview blends live-action footage and animated sequences — many of them drawn by Mr. Gondry. In this video, Mr. Gondry narrates an early sequence in which he asks Mr. Chomsky about his first memory.

headline: The True Accountability in the JPMorgan Settlement
text: The watchword in the Justice Department’s $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase over the sale of questionable mortgage-backed securities is “accountability.” References to accountability appear 11 times in the news release detailing the resolution of federal and state cases against the bank over how it packaged faulty mortgages and sold them to investors.

headline: Tribune Company to Cut 700 Newspaper Employees
text: The Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, will lay off 700 employees at those newspapers and the six others it owns, it said in memos to the staff on Wednesday.

headline: Fighting Hearing Loss From the Crowd’s Roar
text: Earlier this fall, Seattle Seahawks fans at CenturyLink Field broke the world record for loudest stadium crowd with a skull-splitting 136.6 decibels.

headline: Global Fund Suspends 2 Mosquito Net Makers
text: The two top producers of mosquito nets for the war on malaria have been temporarily banned as suppliers by a global disease-fighting fund after admitting that they paid bribes to health officials in Cambodia.

headline: Afghan Migrants in Iran Face Painful Contradictions but Keep Coming
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — They have few rights, can be arrested on sight and deprived of a trial, and are often deported four, five or more times — and no sooner are they across the border than they head back.

headline: 10 Awesome Geek Gifts for Girls
text: There’s lots of online love for this GoldieBlox commercial (hat tip to Katy Waldman at Slate), with its Rube Goldberg use of dozens of pink toys and renegade rewrite of the Beastie Boys’ “Girls” song:

headline: Paul Ryan, Marxist
text: Groucho Marxist, that is.

headline: House Hunting in Sweden
text: Although vacation-home prices remained steady in Sweden during the downturn, very few homes have changed hands in the last three to four years.

headline: House Hunting in ... Sweden
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM TIMBER HOME IN STOCKSUND

headline: Lady Gaga Hits No. 1
text: The big winners on the music charts this week: Lady Gaga, Lorde and the Universal Music Group.

headline: Rob Ford, America’s Mayor
text: The senior Washington correspondent of Canada’s CBC News, Neil Macdonald, has been dutifully filing on the serial misbehavior of Toronto’s crack-smoking, binge-drinking mayor, Rob Ford, finding comfort in the fact that Mr. Ford at least has toppled Canada’s “reputation for monotonous, self-effacing reserve.”

headline: After Another Knee Injury, Duration of Recovery for Vonn Is Uncertain
text: In February, days after she sustained the first major knee injury of her career, Lindsey Vonn vowed to return to ski racing in record time. To Vonn, rehabilitating her reconstructed right anterior cruciate ligament became another competition — and she sped past every milestone in her recovery.

headline: New Minibar Offerings: Handbags and Jewlery
text: The Quin, a new luxury art-themed hotel on Manhattan’s West Side, has a unique take on the minibar. In addition to a traditional fridge with snacks and drinks, the 208 rooms have a “provisions cabinet” selling high-end items like jewelry, handbags and cuff links.

headline: 23 Weeks Pregnant, With ‘No Good Choices’
text: I was 23 weeks pregnant with my first child when we had our anatomic ultrasound here in Chile. In a darkened examination room, the doctor drew the wand over my belly, and our beautiful baby appeared on screen. His body flickered of his own volition, and I squeezed my husband’s shoulder in relief. The doctor measured the circumference of our baby’s head, drew digital white lines down each limb, and examined the kidneys, stomach and spine. He confirmed the gender of our boy and sent his heartbeat to travel across the bottom of the screen at 142 beats per minute.

headline: Republican Talking Points on Obamacare
text: The House Republicans’ response to the Affordable Care Act is increasingly organized and orchestrated, including collections of stories about people who say they were harmed by the health care law.

headline: Presidential Medal of Freedom Awarded
text: President Obama presented the award to 16 Americans, including former President Bill Clinton.

headline: De Blasio Talks With 3 Candidates for Police Commissioner
text: Breaking several days of silence, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio offered a glimpse on Wednesday into his efforts to form a new administration, acknowledging that he had met with three leading contenders for New York City’s next police commissioner.

headline: Pact May Extend U.S. Troops’ Stay in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Wednesday that the United States and Afghanistan had finalized the wording of a bilateral security agreement that would allow for a lasting American troop presence through 2024 and set the stage for billions of dollars of international assistance to keep flowing to the government in Kabul.

headline: ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Will Close on Dec. 8
text: The producers of “Romeo and Juliet” have announced that the show, which was the Broadway debut of Orlando Bloom (“Lord of the Rings”), will close on Dec. 8, more than a month earlier than had been previously planned.

headline: Where Does JPMorgan’s $13 Billion Go?
text: They were some of the biggest losers in the 2008 financial crisis: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, federal taxpayers, state pension funds, credit unions and, of course, homeowners.

headline: Talking Health Insurance Over Thanksgiving Dinner
text: Here’s a hypothetical scenario: You’re the president. You’ve just botched the roll out of what should have been your signature accomplishment, a major reform of the health insurance system. The public’s hopping mad because you said anyone who liked his insurance plan would be able to keep it, but that wasn’t true.

headline: In an Attack Ad, an Alaskan Voter Is Really an Actress From Maryland
text: WASHINGTON – In a tough new advertisement from the Koch brothers-backed Americans for Prosperity, an unnamed woman looks directly into the camera and upbraids Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska.

headline: E.C.B. Nominates New Banking Regulator
text: FRANKFURT — The governing council of the European Central Bank nominated Danièle Nouy on Wednesday as head of the new central bank regulator for the euro zone. With the move, the council fills one of the most prominent job openings in Europe while answering criticism that it has no women in senior leadership positions.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Kaufmann Mercantile Ceramic Growler
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Emblematically Yours
text: Logo culture reaches the next frontier as design elements for fashion.

headline: Surveillance Camera Captures Embassy Blast in Beirut
text: As the death toll continued to rise from the double bombing at the Iranian embassy compound in Beirut on Tuesday, surveillance video was released showing the moment of the first explosion. The footage was posted online by Al Mayadeen television, which highlighted what it identified as one of the explosives-laden vehicles used in the attack. It was also broadcast by Al Manar television and LBCI.

headline: Video: Fashion Diversity in Africa
text: Sporting overalls, yellow tinted glasses and arms covered in tattoos, Spleef Mczaul was recently walking along the street in the Maboneng Precinct in Johannesburg. Mr. Mczaul, who is opening a vintage store in the area, credits the neighborhood for bringing diversity in fashion to South Africa. “It’s people from different places coming together,” Mr. Mczaul said. “You’ll see someone who is wearing an English coat but with an African-print T-shirt.”

headline: J.F.K. Through the Pages of The Times
text: Fifty years after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, a new book showcases The Times’s coverage of his era.

headline: Right Stuff? The Library Thinks So, and Buys It
text: Tom Wolfe has long been a gleeful scourge of New York’s cultural institutions and the people who make them hum, from novelty-seeking museum curators and the mandarins of The New Yorker to the Wall Street buckaroos and “social X-ray” wives who swan around at all those galas.

headline: AT&T and Verizon Pressed to Detail Roles in U.S. Surveillance Efforts
text: Shareholders are putting AT&T and Verizon Wireless on notice: Tell the public more about the companies’ role in government surveillance efforts or risk a ding to the bottom line.

headline: Scene City: Balenciaga Opens a Marbled Store in SoHo
text: Alexander Wang, Julianne Moore and others unveil the brand’s flagship store in New York.

headline: The Return of Logo Culture
text: There are 17 logos on Heron Preston’s signature long-sleeve T-shirt: M&Ms and Trix; Google and Remington; Home Depot, huge, on the back; Nascar, upside down, on the front.

headline: John F. Kennedy Presidential Library
text: The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston emphasizes Kennedy as a president whose promise was cut short.

headline: Recalling Kennedy’s Death, or Life
text: DALLAS — Looking through the window next to the sniper’s perch, you can just make out the grassy knoll through the trees’ branches. It seems inconsequential, mundane — certainly not as imagination pictured it. A “knoll”? There are no rolling English hillocks in Dealey Plaza. There is a one-way, three-lane road that curves under an overpass, with plots of lawn on either side.

headline: After Kennedy Tragedy, Finding Solace in Art
text: In 1961, Jacqueline Kennedy created the office of the White House curator, transforming the nation’s most famous residence for the first time into a collecting art institution, which it remains to this day. But that same year, she also reached out for a handful of artworks that would come to play a profoundly personal role in her life before and after her husband’s death.

headline: Developing Nations Stage Protest at Climate Talks
text: WARSAW — The United Nations climate talks here are bogging down over the old divide between rich and poor nations on the question of who should pay when climate-related disaster strikes, with developing nations staging a symbolic walkout early Wednesday in protest at what they consider inadequate financial support from wealthy countries.

headline: Who Do You Want to Be (Besides a Playful Codger)?
text: Ending up in a retirement home could be joyous — if you’ve always wanted to relive dorm life and would like it even better with everybody having gotten cranky and lost both their youthful good looks and their hearing. (“You have to say everything twice in this place.”) And with no choice about which drugs you take or when. Richard Abrons apparently gave this prospect some thought before writing “Every Day a Visitor,” which Woodie King Jr.’s New Federal Theater is presenting at the Clurman Theater with a colorful, lovable and mostly mature cast.

headline: For Sale: Digital Camera. Estimated Price: $500,000 to $750,000.
text: Are you in need of a new digital camera? I have a deal for you. It’s a one-of-a-kind Leica that will cost an estimated $500,000 to $750,000. What about a new Mac computer? I know where you can pick one up for about $60,000. Need some new headphones? I have a deal on those, too. A pair of solid rose gold iPod earbuds for about $25,000.

headline: Improvising in Total Darkness
text: Darkness enveloped me as I listened to the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas’s String Quartet No. 3 on Tuesday night at Lincoln Center’s Clark Studio Theater. This is the way the composer intended for the piece to be performed. As much as I was engrossed by the music, the performance by the JACK Quartet and the rare experience of hearing music with others in darkness, I could not help feeling that some uncomfortable assumptions were being made for this event, called “In the Dark,” part of the center’s White Light Festival.

headline: Bodies That Spin, Sway and Swerve in Shadows
text: In Complexions Contemporary Ballet, dancers kick their legs to make a show of it. They swivel their hips with insouciance. Their swaying bodies might look as if they’re about to tip over, until a breath — irritatingly visible in a heaving chest — forces them upright. They are skilled technicians. The issue with Complexions, led by the founding artistic directors Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, is how far the repertory is from actually being contemporary.

headline: Michael Cappelletti and His One-No-Trump Opening
text: Michael Cappelletti of Alexandria, Va., died on Nov. 14, at 71. In national championships, he won the 1967 Master Mixed Teams and the 2013 Leventritt Silver Ribbon Pairs and had seven seconds. He amassed 24,317.23 master points, placing him 49th on the lifetime list.

headline: Memoir to Musical: Five-Year Journey
text: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has presented his share of complicated new musicals. But “Fun Home,” he said, was in a class by itself.

headline: Techies Striving for the Next Big Thing
text: “Betas” represents such an amalgam of digital story lines — it’s about a Silicon Valley start-up, and it’s bankrolled and hosted by an Internet behemoth, Amazon — that it’s tempting to review it as if it were a new app rather than an online comedy. Such as: While it lacks some features found in big-budget television sitcoms, and it can be glitchy when it comes to racial and sexual humor, it provides a better user experience than a majority of online series. A solid three-and-a-half stars.

headline: Roasted Turkey Stock
text: Julia Moskin makes roasted turkey stock adapted from a recipe by Suzanne Goin of A.O.C. restaurant.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photos from The Philippines, Virginia, Lebanon and Bulgaria.

headline: Food Stamp Spending and Caseload Are Declining, Report Says
text: The money spent on food stamps and the number of people who receive them are declining as the economy has improved, according to a report released Wednesday, even as the program remains a source of contention in congressional negotiations to complete a five-year farm bill.

headline: Ballet Dancers as Brands
text: LONDON — They are the new jeté set.

headline: Empowering Girls to Build the Future
text: GoldieBlox, a toy company, produced a commercial featuring three young girls that turn an average home into a massive, magical contraption.

headline: What’s He Really Like? Check the Lulu App
text: Not long ago, after Alexandra Amin, an assistant at Warner Brothers, broke up with an agent she had been dating for a year, her friend told her about a new, free, female-friendly social networking app that lets women anonymously review men who are their Facebook friends.

headline: Making Turkey Stock With Suzanne Goin
text: Updated | Nov. 25, 2013

headline: For Alexander Wang, a SoHo Housewarming Party
text: On Tuesday night, Alexander Wang, the new designer for Balenciaga, arrived for the opening of its SoHo store at 148 Mercer Street. It was heavy on the Italian green marble and limestone.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 20 at 6 p.m.
text: President Obama awards Medals of Freedom; a study compares daily quizzes with exams; and a 'real' mayor of New York City.

headline: Egypt’s Revolution Was ‘Stolen’ by Muslim Brotherhood, Kerry Says
text: Secretary of State John Kerry argued on Wednesday that Egypt’s 2011 revolution was started by tech-savvy young people with no ideological aims before being “stolen by” Islamists from the Muslim Brotherhood, who behaved autocratically after winning parliamentary and presidential elections.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Rupert and Wendi Murdoch Reach a Divorce Settlement
text: Rupert Murdoch and Wendi Deng Murdoch appeared in court Wednesday morning and announced they had reached a divorce settlement, an agreement that effectively ends the 14-year marriage of the media mogul and his third wife.

headline: Building Luxury Villas for Poor Neighbors
text: When 26-year-old Tang Guo left his hometown in Sichuan Province for the neighboring province of Yunnan in 1993, all he had was 2 renminbi in his pocket and, as Mr. Tang put it, a willingness to “eat bitterness,” a Chinese term for resilience and toughness. Twenty years later, Mr. Tang is the head of a real estate construction group with 20 subsidiaries and fixed assets worth more than 2 billion renminbi, or about $328 million.

headline: Art Furniture: A Form-Function Twofer
text: Kelly Behun is an interior designer with the eye of a gallerist. “The way I look at things,” she said, “designing a space is an exercise in curating: the chairs, the lamps and all that stuff is sculpture.”

headline: Sales at DDC, Park Avenue Garage and Others
text: DDC has opened a temporary outlet shop, with furniture and decorative accessories discounted up to 70 percent (the Andersen sofa by Rodolfo Dordoni for Minotti, originally $11,935, is $8,354); 33 East 33rd Street, 212-685-0800, ddcnyc.com.

headline: At 89, a Pioneering Street Photographer Finally Gets His Due
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Styling Black Jumpsuits
text: Bored with the L.B.D.? Here is the L.B.J. for holiday parties this year.

headline: Time to Take the Leap
text: Ah, the L.B.D. — so simple, so sensible, so ... snoozy. This holiday season, may we suggest the L.B.J.?

headline: Do As He Says, Not As He Does
text: The landscape architect Thomas Rainer defends his garden.

headline: He’ll Try Anything
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Don’t look at the garden in the pictures. This is no place Thomas Rainer wants exposed to the world.

headline: City (Manchester) in the City (N.Y.)
text: What do Brooklyn Bridge Park, the High Line, Yankee Stadium and Rucker Park have in common, besides being part of the fabric of New York City?

headline: What Would Sister Parish Do?
text: The beauty of a boxy apartment is that you can do anything you want with it, including turning it into an homage to the most celebrated decorators of the 20th century.

headline: The Peak of Chic: Borrowing From the Best
text: Jennifer Boles lives in a two-bedroom apartment in a brutalist high-rise on Peachtree Road. This stark, bunkerlike setting is worth noting because Ms. Boles, 41, is the creator of the Peak of Chic design blog, a love letter to — nay, an epic poem in celebration of — the sort of effusive, ebullient and, yes, very traditional decorating practiced by Dorothy Draper, Nancy Lancaster, Albert Hadley and Sister Parish, among other 20th-century greats. A more stark contrast between Ms. Boles’s highly embellished, high-gloss interiors, with their faux finishes, leopard prints, tufted wallpaper and Porthault sheets, and the building’s gritty concrete skin can hardly be imagined.

headline: Ryan McGinley, the Pied Piper of the Downtown Art World
text: The social orbit surrounding the photographer Ryan McGinley can sometimes feel like the world’s most exclusive nightclub, populated by good-looking and talented 20-somethings, who with their perfect skin and classic faces all seem to have walked out of a Kerouac novel, an idyllic Midwestern town or an American Apparel ad.

headline: Catering to the Masses: A New Edition of ‘Cooking for Crowds’
text: In Merry White’s Boston high school, lunch was a class called Gracious Living, where all the food was beige and served by maids, and pepper was considered “too heating for young ladies.” “From then on,” she writes in the foreword to the new 40th-anniversary edition of her 1974 classic, “Cooking for Crowds” (Princeton University Press, $29.95), “my life has been a search for the heat and pleasure of food.” Her book, made up of recipes she collected as the caterer for the Harvard Center for European Studies, suggested a new way of entertaining, with self-serve spanakopita, petite shrimp quiche and that savior of the anxious cook, the casserole that can be made a day ahead. Edward Koren’s woolly illustrations set the tone: vegetables are our friends, and food tastes best in groups. Even though pesto and vindaloo are no longer exotic, during the holidays her attitude (and her meatballs) may be what every stressed-out host needs.

headline: Belated, Yes; Forgotten, No: A Tribute to Dan Kiley
text: “Imagine not celebrating the 100th anniversary of the architect Mies van der Rohe’s birth,” said Charles Birnbaum, the founder of the Cultural Landscape Foundation. But in September 2012, that’s precisely the fate that befell Dan Kiley, the seminal postwar landscape architect behind the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial in St. Louis, featuring Eero Saarinen’s Gateway Arch, and Patterns, the garden of the du Pont home in Wilmington, Del.

headline: A Loft That’s a Real Showplace
text: When Diego Paccagnella, the president of Design-Apart, a company that sells custom Italian furnishings, wanted to display samples in New York, he found someone in Manhattan with a 2,600-square-foot loft who was willing to move out for a year and give it to him rent-free. Mr. Paccagnella; his wife, Livia; and their 16-month-old son, Giulio (all at top right), moved in and redecorated the apartment as a live-in showroom. In a year, the Paccagnellas will move out, leaving about a half-million dollars in furnishings for the owners to keep, while they find and redo another New York home.

headline: Treasures, but Only to You?
text: A few months after my mother died in 2011 at the age of 93, I put her Manhattan apartment on the market and was lucky enough to have a deal within days. The buyers were paying cash and seemed certain to be approved by the co-op board.

headline: Should Americans Fear Their Furniture?
text: The pet hairs and red wine stains on sofas across America, it turns out, should be the least of our concerns. The real issue is what is in the foam cushions we curl up on every day: up to two pounds of flame retardants.

headline: Soaking Up the Local Color
text: Deborah Osburn began making colorful tiles to brighten up a mostly beige-dominated industry nearly 30 years ago. And though in recent years she has been selling other artists’ designs, she has returned to her creative roots with the Watermark Collection for Tilevera, her artisan tile company. Inspired by Japanese techniques, she produced the ombré-stained tiles by placing unglazed porcelain into a cup of indigo and waiting for the dye to be absorbed.

headline: Should I Install Professional-Style Appliances?
text: Q. Would putting professional-style appliances in my kitchen increase my home’s value?

headline: The Nakeds Next Door
text: Shannon Sessoms has never been so ready for winter. Cold weather brings the promise of several months without awkward sightings of the neighbors whom her family refers to as the Nakeds.

headline: How Smart Is Your Smoke Alarm?
text: The Times’s Jenna Wortham considers whether the bang is worth the buck for a combination smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector called Nest Protect.

headline: Ad Takes Off Online: Less Doll, More Awl
text: Who said girls want to dress in pink and play with dolls, especially when they could be building Rube Goldberg machines instead?

headline: A Smart Smoke Alarm That Keeps Its Cool
text: The last apartment I lived in was a certifiable fire hazard. It was mostly my fault — I ripped out the smoke detector my landlord had installed because it was so sensitive that even a steamy shower would set off its earsplitting beeping.

headline: A Camera That Offers Instant Gratification and Prints
text: It’s great to see party pictures instantly on your smartphone, but you can’t easily hang those shots on your refrigerator or tuck one into the frame of a mirror. You can order prints, of course, if you don’t mind waiting.

headline: Money Traders Fret Over Possible U.S.-Iran Pact
text: TEHRAN — Sitting atop a bronze statue in the center of Tehran’s modest Manoucheri Square, where a group of illegal money changers gathers every day, a bald man waved a thick stack of dollar bills, as dozens of others shouted figures and numbers.

headline: Paul Sevigny Brings a New Bar to TriBeCa
text: Could this be (another) new Beatrice Inn? Since being silenced by griping neighbors in 2009, Paul Sevigny’s fashionable West Village bar has been endlessly imitated: Pyongyang door policies, shabby chic furniture, swirls of celebrities and downtown dirtbags. Paul’s Baby Grand, his first solo offering since Beatrice closed, has rejiggered an auxiliary space at the Tribeca Grand hotel into a lounge-like spiritual successor (albeit a smaller and less decadent incarnation).

headline: Fall Fashion, It’s all About the Details
text: The holidays are upon us — time to break out the pearls. They may have shed their patrician pedigree some time ago, but this season the makeover is almost decadent, though in the nicest way: a fat pearl hiding under the sole of Nicholas Kirkwood pumps; a single strand attached to dresses at Valentino; pearls as trim running up and down and around tailored Alexander McQueen separates. In jewelry, they’re affixed in surprising new ways to necklaces, rings and cuffs by Aurélie Bidermann, Delfina Delettrez and others. Earlier this year, everyone was head over heels about the Dior pearls worn as a single earring, on the back and front of the earlobe. Now, for resort, they come in pretty pink and bright blue. Seriously, they could become a girl’s best friend.

headline: Robert Bowie, 104, Adviser to Truman, Eisenhower, Johnson and Carter, Dies
text: Robert R. Bowie, a Harvard foreign policy expert who served four postwar administrations as an adviser on the Cold War, national security and conflicts around the globe, died on Nov. 2 in Towson, Md. He was 104.

headline: Condom Contest Produces 812 Ideas for Improvement
text: The condom of the future might be made of cow tendon or fish skin. It might have “shape memory” to instantly mold to a specific man. Or it might come with pull tabs so a man could slip it on with little fuss.

headline: In October, a Day for the New York City Subway’s Ridership Record Book
text: The weather was mild on the subway system’s perfect day — clear skies to coax New Yorkers outdoors, paired with a breeze that discouraged long walks.

headline: Readers React to Death of a Diver, and an Image of Him
text: When the free diver Nick Mevoli, 32, emerged Sunday from an attempt at diving 72 meters below the ocean surface in the Bahamas, the photographer Lia Hyun-Joo Barrett caught him in a frame. In the photo, Mr. Mevoli, accompanied by three safety divers, looks startled, his eyes bulging.

headline: John Varvatos: His Runway Has a Backbeat
text: Last Thursday night around 7, the designer John Varvatos was in his Chelsea showroom, about to head up to Harlem with a few staff members and his wife, Joyce. They were going to the Apollo Theater, where the guitarist Gary Clark Jr. was on the bill.

headline: Raw Sewage and Anger Flood Gaza’s Streets as Electricity Runs Low
text: GAZA CITY — Raw sewage has flooded streets in a southern Gaza City neighborhood in recent days, threatening a health disaster, after a shortage of electricity and cheap diesel fuel from Egypt led the Hamas government to shut down Gaza’s lone power plant, causing a pump station to flood.

headline: Andris Nelsons to Conduct During Tanglewood’s 2014 Season
text: His efforts to make it there last summer were thwarted by injury. But Andris Nelsons will head to the Berkshires this summer for his first appearances at the Tanglewood Festival since he was named the music director designate of the Boston Symphony Orchestra  — with plans to conduct music by Dvorak, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Rolf Martinsson and Christopher Rouse.

headline: Applicants Find Health Website Is Improving, but Not Fast Enough
text: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — Tilda Elias had reason to be optimistic when she opened the HealthCare.gov website on Monday, ready to help her first client of the week find health insurance. Technicians had made fixes to the online insurance exchange over the weekend. Even more promising, her client, Giovanna Romano, had managed to complete an online application at home with no problems.

text: As you gaze exasperatedly around the Thanksgiving table next week, perhaps you should consider that Aunt Sue or Granny Esther may be a potential font of beauty wisdom.

text: Nashville has long been the capital of a particular strain of country music, and lately the Nashville Symphony has established a reputation for adventurousness (but only narrowly avoided foreclosure proceedings on its spiffy new hall).

text: Thanks in part to the model Cara Delevingne, bushy eyebrows are finding favor this season. Here are a few new products to help prune and shape them.

text: AMERICAN and Iranian negotiators yesterday began a second round of talks in Geneva, seeking a deal on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Firefighters Are Injured in Major Fire in the Bronx
text: A fire tore through a section of the Hunts Point Terminal Produce Market in the Bronx late Wednesday morning, destroying crates of tropical fruit and leaving several firefighters injured.

headline: Campaign Seeks to Recruit Top Students to Become Teachers
text: If you can’t do, teach. The three best things about teaching? June, July and August.

headline: The Truth About Tornadoes
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — DOES global warming weaken tornadoes?

headline: Bus Stoppage Said to Target Rikers Inmate
text: When an apparent job action by city correction workers stranded dozens of city correction buses at Rikers Island this week, hundreds of inmates failed to make their scheduled court appearances — including one man of particular interest.

headline: Frequent Tests Can Enhance College Learning, Study Finds
text: Grading college students on quizzes given at the beginning of every class, rather than on midterms or a final exam, increases both attendance and overall performance, scientists reported Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hitting Stop on Winamp, and Snapchat’s Women
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Kazakhstan’s Bet on Rail
text: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — The railroad locomotive factory here on the outskirts of the capital of Kazakhstan is one of the most modern in the world, with huge yellow overhead cranes and a work force of 1,100. An engine factory being built next door will soon make some of the world’s most fuel-efficient 12-cylinder diesel engines.

headline: The Public Needs a Nap
text: One of the many problems with the Senate filibuster rule is that it requires us to think about the Senate filibuster rule.

headline: Yankees’ Best Deal Might Be Letting Cano Go
text: The Yankees have gotten nine excellent seasons and one championship from Robinson Cano. They have paid him about $58 million. Now he wants that much again, and about $250 million more, for a decade that almost certainly will not be as productive.

headline: Representative Meng Is Mugged on Capitol Hill
text: Representative Grace Meng was robbed this week in Washington by a person who hit her in the back of the head and stole her purse as she fell, she said on Wednesday.

headline: Voting via Twitter, Choosing Jennifer Lopez’s Route to an Awards Show
text: HEADING into the shopping frenzy of Thanksgiving week, Kohl’s is featuring one of its collection celebrities, Jennifer Lopez, in a social media campaign involving a series of commercials that will air during the American Music Awards on Sunday.

headline: Aid Groups Get Strong Response to Philippines Appeals
text: The United Nations relief agency has elicited a strong response so far to an emergency financing appeal for overcoming the Philippines typhoon disaster, receiving nearly half the amount requested in the week since the effort was begun, a humanitarian aid database reported in an update on Wednesday.

headline: When Children Are Traded
