headline: In Pursuit of Health and Happiness
text: “Free detox shots!” the waitress called out as she sashayed through the dining room, a tray of tiny glasses at her shoulder. The liquid in them was jungle green and wobbled. It tasted of kale and salvation, with celery and lemon for a bright-eyed, bushy-tailed finish. I downed it and waited for the world to change.

headline: Tax Proposal for an Economy No Longer Rooted in Manufacturing
text: A tax proposal released on Thursday by the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus, addresses a topic that tends to make my students’ eyes glaze over: cost recovery.

headline: Micron Shares Rise After Praise From Einhorn
text: Micron Technology can officially call itself a member of the David Einhorn club.

headline: Puerto Ricans Molded by New York
text: November is Puerto Rican Heritage Month in New York, giving the city a chance to recognize the ways figures like the Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the Knicks star Carmelo Anthony, the cultural historian Arturo Alfonso Schomburg and the founders of the Nuyorican poetry movement have shaped and been shaped by New York. And the Miser, being the Miser, after all, is happy to note that a number of the programs tied to the celebration are free and open to the public.

headline: David Webb’s Jewelry on Sale and for Show
text: AN ORNATE LEGACY,

headline: Valérie Blass
text: Parisian Laundry Projects

headline: Obama Campaign Veterans Start New Advertising Venture
text: A few months after members of President Obama’s 2012 advertising and data teams came together to start a new firm called AMG that would bring some of his campaign’s technical savvy to corporate America, a rival faction of advertising and data strategists say they are starting a competing effort.

headline: Refurnishing a 65-Room House, Piece by Piece
text: An upscale tag sale appears to be underway in the cavernous limestone rooms of Coe Hall mansion, run by the Planting Fields Foundation in Oyster Bay. But no prices are listed.

headline: Collecting, Simply for the Joy of It
text: Collecting and investing have eclipsed many other aspects of art, particularly in recent weeks as auction prices soared to absurd levels. When one work sells for $142.4 million, as a Francis Bacon triptych did this month, it prompts questions not only about the cultural and monetary value of art, but also about the unequal distribution of wealth and how such wealth is acquired in the first place. This is why the collectors, and not just the works, in “Many Things Placed Here and There: The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection at the Yale University Art Gallery” are important within the greater history of contemporary art.

headline: A Broken Copier, and Other Calamities
text: “You. Are not. Special.” So Stan, a 50-ish office drone, informs his young co-worker in a scene from “middlemen” at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. “You are not important. I know, your parents told you differently, but they were lying. If you were never born, if you had never existed at all,” things would have turned out the same way, he says, acknowledging that the same holds true for him.

headline: Ex-Journal Tech Writers Are Close to Deal With NBCUniversal
text: The technology writers Kara Swisher and Walter Mossberg, founders of the conference and media business All Things Digital, appear to have found a new home.

headline: Katherine Bernhardt and Youssef Jdia: ‘Holiday Services’
text: The Hole

headline: Liam Gillick / Louise Lawler
text: Casey Kaplan

headline: Rosemarie Trockel
text: Gladstone

headline: Barbara Probst
text: Murray Guy

headline: A New Holiday Face
text: I have officially started to dread Thanksgiving. Every year, I drive several hours to my childhood home to celebrate the holiday with my immediate family: my parents, an older brother and a younger sister. Within 30 seconds of being in the same room, we all assume our old roles. My brother was the brain, my sister was the jock and I was the troublemaker — but I’m not anymore. Do you have any ideas for short-circuiting those same old dynamics this year? It’s really demoralizing for me.

headline: Listen Up | A Brooklyn Disco Orchestra Unleashes Its Inner Barbarian
text: “Dance music played with live instruments has become really popular — it’s not just underground anymore,” says Eugene Cho, the keyboardist of the Brooklyn-based band Escort. Indeed, thanks to the surprise Top 40 success of Daft Punk’s “Get Lucky,” club grooves evoking the time before computer-made beats have reached mass consciousness anew. Escort, however, has been flying that flag for over half a decade. Founded by Cho and the guitarist Dan Balis, the band hails itself as “Brooklyn’s finest disco orchestra” — mixing mirror-ball rhythms and funky cowbell syncopation with club-ready choruses, as heard on the single “Barbarians,” from their forthcoming sophomore album, out next year. The song’s lush textures call to mind Studio 54 classics mixed with the legendary producer Trevor Horn’s work in the mid-1980s with Frankie Goes to Hollywood. “It’s not reasonable to expect everyone who listens to us to know the last 30 years of dance-music history,” Cho says. “We want what we do to translate broadly.”

headline: National Gallery Acquires a van Honthorst Masterwork
text: A MERRY DUTCH CONCERT, CAPTURED BY A MASTER

headline: Photographers Protest White House Restrictions
text: WASHINGTON — A mutiny has erupted among photographers who cover President Obama over what they say is the White House’s increasing practice of excluding them from events involving the president and then releasing its own photos or video.

headline: Nasty Nuns Can’t Shake a Faith
text: In “Philomena,” Judi Dench’s portrayal of a stubborn, kindhearted Irish Catholic trying to discover what became of the toddler she was forced to give up as a teenager is so quietly moving that it feels lit from within. A major theme of this film from Stephen Frears is forgiveness. Ms. Dench’s Philomena Lee glows with the radiance of someone serene in her faith despite inhumane treatment by the church. That she makes you believe her character has the capacity to forgive provides the movie with a solid moral center.

headline: Rescued London Women Say They Were Held 30 Years
text: LONDON — The London police announced Thursday that three women had been rescued from a city home where they claim to have been held against their will for about 30 years, and that a married couple who lived there had been arrested.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘My Work Is Very Difficult to Understand’
text: A look at the work of the German artist Isa Genzken, the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: No, It Isn’t Supposed to Be Easy
text: The German artist Isa Genzken once conducted a minute-long video interview with a fellow artist and titled it, “Why I Don’t Do Interviews.”

headline: Carlin’s Daughter Writing Memoir
text: Kelly Carlin, the only child of the comedian George Carlin, will write a memoir of her relationship with her father, her publisher said Thursday. St. Martin’s Press, part of Macmillan, acquired “A Carlin Home Companion” from Ms. Carlin, left, who said that the book developed from her one-woman show by the same name. “The man you knew as George Carlin, I called Dad,” Ms. Carlin said in a statement. “I want to offer readers a rare glimpse of the George Carlin they’ve never seen or heard about before.” The book is expected to be released in fall 2015.

headline: Assembling Brash Wholes From Scraps
text: The Museum of Modern Art’s grand, sometimes grating 40-year survey of the German sculptor Isa Genzken is a disturbance in the force of the New York art world. It counters the season’s trend of big retrospectives devoted to male artists and increases from a paltry four to a still paltry five the number of full-dress sixth-floor retrospectives the Modern has bestowed upon women since taking back its expanded building nine years ago.

headline: Records Are Dying? Not Here
text: BUZZSAWS were buzzing, hammers were hammering, and a sea of empty display racks awaited their wares one morning this week in a cavernous storefront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It was a typical scene of retail construction in every way except for what was coming: a record store.

headline: Rough Trade NYC
text: A new branch of a London record store is scheduled to open Monday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: The largest wholesale cut in SNAP since 1964, when Congress passed the first Food Stamp Act, is driving one in every seven Americans to seek out food pantries. Meanwhile, the median wage is plummeting, and more than 50 Walmart workers and supporters were arrested in downtown Los Angeles last week as they sat in the street protesting the retailer’s “poverty wages.”

headline: A Silent Partner to Share the Path of Love
text: “I have the chance to go to Japan for a year,” I told my boyfriend, Randy.

headline: A Portrait Painted in Heavy Strokes
text: Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon were rivals as well as friends. That scratching sound you hear is Freud clawing at his coffin at the news last week that Bacon’s 1969 portrait of him, a triptych titled “Three Studies of Lucian Freud,” went for $142.4 million, making it the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction.

headline: With Pitchfork Review, a Music Site Plants a Flag in Print
text: After 17 years as the definitive online publication about alternative music, Pitchfork is joining the tweedy world of print with a new quarterly journal.

headline: With Dad in Jail, a Family Carries on
text: Michael Winterbottom’s elusive family drama “Everyday” was filmed in two-week periods around Christmas over five successive years in a rural Scottish village. Its central character, Karen (Shirley Henderson), is a lean, intense working-class woman whose husband, Ian (John Simm), is serving time for an unspecified drug-related crime.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the Philippines, India, Pakistan and Nepal.

headline: The Ultimate Pinup Queen, With a Peek at the Sad Side
text: In the more than 50 years since the all-American pinup Bettie Page hung up her trusty riding crop, her life has morphed into unlikely legend and a surprisingly durable brand. Bettie mania has gone high with a Florida museum exhibition of images snapped by Bunny Yeager, and it’s also gone predictably low, with an endless parade of Bettie-related paraphernalia from T-shirts to handbags, lunchboxes, poker chips, beauty products, light-switch plates and a line of shoes that the licensee describes as “catering to the Rockabilly, Pin-Up and Burlesque genres.”

headline: Delinquency Rates on the Decline
text: As the economy improves, the number of borrowers who are seriously behind on their mortgage payments continues to decline. The enhanced outlook is such that even those in delinquency are feeling more optimistic about their circumstances and homeownership in general.

headline: As SAC Shrinks, Its Operations Chief Departs
text: In 2007, before the financial crisis and before federal authorities began listening to traders’ phone calls, the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was in aggressive expansion mode. And a charismatic young executive named Sol Kumin played an important role in its rise.

headline: When How It Looks Matters More Than What It Says
text: As you read this, you’re probably not paying much attention to what the letters look like. More likely, you’re focusing on the words and sentences that the letters spell, and what they are saying. Some artists, however, have made it their business to direct attention to what letters, words, sentences, texts and books look like more or less apart from what they mean. Nine of these are in “Drawing Time, Reading Time,” a thought-provoking show at the Drawing Center.

headline: Verdict in Apple-Samsung Damages Trial
text: A jury said that Samsung Electronics would have to pay Apple nearly $290 million in damages for violating patents.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: How the Original 1 Percent Showed Off
text: The staggering sums spent on art at last week’s auctions were interpreted by dealers and critics alike as evidence of a new Gilded Age. At such a moment, it may be useful to take a hard look at the old one, the late-19th-century period defined by the aggressive buying sprees of a few newly minted industrialists.

headline: Europeans Stray From the Vine
text: A recent article in Newsweek bemoaned that Italians, particularly younger Italians, are drinking less wine today than they did five years ago. Fifty years ago, they consumed about twice as much annually. All this, even though no country makes more wine than Italy (which exports a great deal of it, especially to the United States).

headline: A Quiz and a Drink
text: Scenes from a pub quiz at Dempsey’s, an East Village bar.

headline: An Abstractionism Shaped by Wounded Ideals
text: In recent years some of our big Chelsea galleries have given us what are basically museum shows. From Gagosian, a while back, came an invaluable retrospective of Piero Manzoni, followed by a survey of late Monet paintings that felt like an impossible dream. David Zwirner now enters the modern-old-masters lists with “Ad Reinhardt,” a trenchant centennial tribute to a classic American artist, and one of the best exhibitions in or out of a gallery this fall.

headline: Challenging Questions on Tap
text: The Beast could not conquer Astoria, thanks in part to a too-hasty guess about a pornographic cat and bad advice about a Mets pitcher. He could not conquer the East Village, where trivia sharks were lying in wait. But he did emerge from Social Bar in the theater district as, for one night at least, king of the inconsequential and obscure.

headline: Now From a Global Village, the Vienna Choir Boys
text: The Westchester County campus of Purchase College may not be known for its geological formations. But when the 24 members of the Vienna Boys Choir arrive on campus for their holiday show at the college’s Performing Arts Center on Dec. 7, they will find themselves searching for stones, which promise to play a memorable role in the show.

headline: Weighing Costs for the Many Who Hold Sway
text: Be careful what you wish for. The closed hearings into the political activities of a conservative group in Austin are slowly coming into the open.

headline: JetBlue Joins PreCheck Program
text: The Transportation Security Administration said Thursday that JetBlue Airways would join its roster of airlines participating in its PreCheck airport security program. JetBlue is the ninth airline to be included, joining Southwest, which announced its participation last week, Alaska, American (which now also includes US Airways), Delta, Hawaiian, United and Virgin America.

headline: Star Types and Stereotypes
text: The CW series “Nikita” begins its fourth and final season on Friday — an abbreviated run to tie up story lines, as the reluctant assassin Nikita stands falsely accused of killing the president — and while there’s still a chance, I’d like to celebrate a small but significant milestone. For six more weeks, two of the strongest and most interesting female leads on television are being played by Asian-American actresses.

headline: Showing That They’re Glad to Be Live, and Alive
text: The tools of “Play/Pause,” a New York premiere by the choreographer Susan Marshall that is inspired by music videos, build over time. At first, the stage is bare except for a large, standing piece of plywood, on which Luke Miller places strips of gaffers tape. Ching-I Chang scrapes a microphone on its surface. Christopher Adams pulls on a silver-sequined sock — a nod to Michael Jackson’s glove? — and, standing, lashes out an arm while lunging forward.

headline: In Oil and Gas Country, Water Recycling Can Be an Extremely Hard Sell
text: MIDLAND — Standing on a sprawling ranch where drilling rigs, cranes and bobbing stripper wells form a makeshift skyline, Jimmy Davis is not thinking solely about sucking up oil. It is not the only precious liquid that is pumped from under the land that he manages.

headline: Eclecticism Intact After a 17-Year Interlude
text: Mazzy Star was a throwback to a throwback when it performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night, touring behind its first album in 17 years. When the band emerged in 1990, its singer and lyricist, Hope Sandoval, and its guitarist and composer, David Roback, wrote songs that looked back to the 1960s, using selective memories of folk-rock and psychedelia to define its own sparse, pensive songs. Now — when newer bands from Beach House to the xx have also embraced the still-waters-run-deep aesthetic — Mazzy Star harks back to its earlier self.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Animating the Mind of Chomsky
text: An easygoing, sometimes tough-going meander through the world of ideas, the animated documentary “Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?” finds the French director Michel Gondry playing wide-eyed student to none other than Noam Chomsky. They’re a charmingly unpredictable, appealing match. Mr. Gondry, best known for films like “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and “The Green Hornet,” has occasionally dipped into documentary, with titles like the expansive “Dave Chappelle’s Block Party” (in which the comic hosts a rocking Brooklyn block party) and the considerably more hermetic “The Thorn in the Heart” (about Mr. Gondry’s aunt and her son).

headline: Still Restless, 50 Years On
text: The 50th anniversary of “Doctor Who” is being celebrated all week on BBC America, with episode marathons, documentaries and “The Day of the Doctor,” a stand-alone story uniting the 10th and 11th Doctors (David Tennant and Matt Smith) that is being broadcast around the world on Saturday.

headline: High Court May Clarify Rule on Impairment and Death Penalty
text: The United States Supreme Court’s ruling in a Florida death penalty case, in which an inmate argued that his intellectual disability made him exempt from execution, could help answer a decade-old question in Texas and other states about how to establish whether an inmate is too severely impaired to be subject to the death penalty.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 21 at 6 p.m.
text: Moves on the filibuster in Washington; Michael C. Skakel freed in Connecticut; and Monty Python to perform again.

headline: Love Machines
text: It’s the stuff of science-fiction fantasy, but also of high-tech reality: a personal helper robot with the power to process language and the capacity to learn over time, its responses ever more tailored to the needs of its master.

headline: Rethinking Further War
text: In a rich history of preposterous endings in opera, Tiridate’s awakening to the good and true in “Radamisto” ranks high.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: 'The Commons of Pensacola'
text: Sarah Jessica Parker and Michael Stahl-David in a scene from Amanda Peet's new play at City Center.

headline: F.C.C. to Weigh Allowing Cellphone Use on Flights
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that it would consider changing its rules to permit the use of cellphones and other wireless-data devices during airline flights. If approved, the change is certain to delight some passengers but frustrate many others.

headline: How Do They Like It? Loud
text: At Revel, an elegant restaurant that opened in early September in Garden City, most of the reveling is going on at the back of the place. Patrons going in the front door on Franklin Avenue see a smallish, somewhat modest dining room and a sign directing them to the hostess station in the rear dining room.

headline: Singing of the Cartels, and Investigating Them
text: “With an AK-47 and a bazooka on my shoulder/Cross my path and I’ll chop your head off/We’re bloodthirsty, crazy and we like to kill.”

headline: Lest a Pesky Stable Move In
text: Amos Pinchot would be indignant. So would Reginald De Koven and Lewis Gouverneur Morris and Edward Stettinius. They were all well-to-do townhouse owners at Park Avenue and 85th Street a century ago, and would have been dismayed by the prospect of an apartment house above the 1911 Park Avenue Christian Church, at the southwest corner of the intersection. They all relied on a network of deed restrictions designed to prevent just that kind of thing.

headline: Fatherhood, Supersized
text: As artificial as the inseminations it celebrates, “Delivery Man” is a soggy comedy more focused on stimulating your tear ducts than your funny bone.

headline: Vince Prices Above Its I.P.O. Range as Fashion Stays Hot With Investors
text: Fashion is still hot on Wall Street judging by Vince Holding’s initial public offering.

headline: Love Among the Gas Pumps
text: “Detroit Unleaded” is about as gentle as comedies come these days, commendably so. Rola Nashef, the director, who was born in Lebanon and raised in Michigan, wasn’t interested in the slapstick and vulgarity that pass for humor in most films. By avoiding those noisy distractions and staying within the confines of her sparse story, she has created a surprisingly affecting examination of one aspect of the Arab-American experience: the dissonance between American hookup culture and home-country traditions.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Litigating in the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, and Snapchat Video Depositions
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Enemies, Abroad and at Home
text: Early in his presidency, John F. Kennedy feared that in the face of a conflict he might not be in full control of the warmongering operatives in his government. The nuclear threat was palpable, and, as Cory Taylor explains in his well-researched documentary “JFK: A President Betrayed,” Kennedy had learned his lesson with the Bay of Pigs invasion. (According to the film, narrated by Morgan Freeman, he blamed himself for not asking the C.I.A. the right questions.)

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 22-28
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Homemade Polish Feast at Bargain Prices
text: New Britain, a Polish-American stronghold for many decades, hosts a handful of Polish restaurants with medieval-sounding names: Cracovia, Belvedere, Fatherland, Staropolska. It was at the last of these that I whiled away several pleasurable evenings recently, enjoying the robust delights of Central European cooking “Tu Jadamy Jak U Mamy” — the way your mother used to do it.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 22-28
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: James Murdoch Joins Board of Media Company Vice
text: James Murdoch, a 21st Century Fox executive and the son of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, has joined Vice Media as a director, two people with knowledge of the appointment said on Thursday.

headline: Cafes Powered by Coffee and Good Cheer
text: It’s hard to imagine a time when a foodie’s working vocabulary did not include “zeppole,” “macaron,” “pour over” and “panini.” Halfhearted interpretations of these abound; it’s harder to find places that get them just right.

headline: A Place, and Prescription, of One’s Own
text: Jack, the hero of Jono Oliver’s debut feature, “Home,” is balancing his dosage of antipsychotic medicine while seeking an apartment in New York for less than $600 a month. This seemingly impossible hunt is endured with humor and sensitivity, as well as minute pangs of suffering, thanks to a stunning performance from Gbenga Akinnagbe (Chris Partlow in “The Wire”) in the story of Jack’s efforts to leave a group home where he’s lived for many years.

headline: An Uptick in the Hiring of Women for Tech Jobs
text: There are signs that tech companies are hiring more women, but women still appear to make up far less than half of all new hires in the industry.

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View of Liberation
text: Burkhard von Harder’s “Die Narbe” (“The Scar”) bears witness to the legacy of the Berlin Wall in rather literal-minded fashion by filming the wall’s perimeter from a helicopter. Far from tapping Germany’s especially rich and haunted interplay between architecture and memory, the movie suggests, most immediately, that not all aerial photography is equal.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Record High for Number of Jobs in New York City
text: More than a month after the partial shutdown of the federal government, the New York State Labor Department issued some good news on Thursday about employment in New York City.

headline: FIFA Plans Final Test of Vanishing Spray
text: After approving a high-tech solution to goal-line controversies for use at the World Cup in Brazil, FIFA inched closer this week to a low-tech solution for a problem that usually arises farther from the goal.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 22-28
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Working Around Keystone XL, Suncor Energy Steps Up Oil Production in Canada
text: Suncor Energy, Canada’s top petroleum producer, announced on Thursday that it would expand its oil production in 2014 by 10 percent in another sign that the Obama administration’s delay in approving the Keystone XL pipeline extension is not holding back growth in the western Canadian oil sands fields.

headline: In Texas, Inmates and Officers Swelter
text: HUNTSVILLE, Tex. — IN August, right around the time when the Texas summer heat was at its brutal worst, the state’s prison system finalized a bid to replace its aging swine-production facilities with six new climate-controlled modular barns, at a cost of $750,000.

headline: Excerpt From ‘Radamisto’
text: John Holiday and Virginie Verrez perform “Se teco vive il cor,” a part of Juilliard Opera’s presentation of Handel’s “Radamisto.”

headline: As Syrian War Grinds On, a New Flock of Refugees Takes Flight
text: HACIPASA, Turkey — At an unmarked border crossing here in this village in southwestern Turkey, soldiers were interrogating four Syrian men trying to walk into this country one recent morning. Three, after a few animated minutes, were let in.

headline: Cuomo on the Radio
text: Since taking office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has granted interviews to a select few radio hosts. His appearances with Fredric U. Dicker stopped abruptly following Mr. Dicker’s criticism of the governor’s gun-control legislation in January.

headline: The South’s New Lost Cause
text: Before he was immortalized for saving the union, freeing the slaves and giving the best political speech in American history, Abraham Lincoln was just an unpopular new president handed a colossal crisis. Elected with 39.7 percent of the vote, Lincoln told a big lie in his inaugural address of 1861.

headline: In Manhattan Alleys, Dogs on Rat Hunts Find Bags of Fun
text: It was well after nightfall. The pack of dogs was split into two groups and was led to opposite ends of a desolate alley in downtown Manhattan.

headline: For a Tapas Cafe in Princeton, Some Baby Steps
text: Bruno Romero opened the tapas cafe and market Despaña Princeton, a spinoff of the eight-year-old Despaña SoHo in Manhattan, because of parallels he sensed in the two communities.

headline: Defendants in a Cage
text: To the Editor:

headline: News Cycle Delusions
text: Today’s big event was the filibuster busted, and I have absolutely nothing original to say. So instead let me say something about the GOP planned attack on Obamacare — also not original, but maybe blunter than you’ll read elsewhere.

headline: Flipping the Holiday Switch
text: The residents of the English village Gladbury in the period holiday film “The Christmas Candle” might as well be bustling about in a snow globe for all their dimples, yuletide obsession and quaint, consumptive coughs. This film — adapted by John Stephenson, a former vice president and creative supervisor of Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, from the book by the prolific preacher Max Lucado — relates the weak-tea parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.

headline: Rape Charge Is Set for Boy Held in Death of Teacher
text: BOSTON — A 14-year-old boy accused of killing his teacher was charged on Thursday with having raped her as well.
