text: Gifts for music-loving newlyweds, from a speaker that fits into a shower head to a puppy-shaped radio designed by an artist.

headline: New Obstacle to a Nuclear Deal: Taunts From Iran’s Ruler
text: As my colleague Michael Gordon reports, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that “inflammatory” statements against Israel and the United States this week from Iran’s ruling cleric, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, could make reaching an agreement over the Iranian nuclear program more difficult.

headline: Kerry to Join Iran Nuclear Talks, in Sign of Progress
text: GENEVA — Secretary of State John Kerry planned to fly to Geneva on Friday to join the talks on imposing a temporary freeze on Iran’s nuclear program, a sign that the negotiations are edging close to an agreement.

headline: In Store | Handsome Wallets for the Minimalist at Heart
text: In September, Vianel introduced a line of simple, streamlined wallets that were only available on its website (including same-day delivery service in New York City, where the brand is based). By Monday, and just in time for holiday shopping, fans of the handsome but affordable leather goods can stop into one of the 11 Barneys New York locations nationwide that will now carry them. In addition to offering Vianel’s signature cardholders, Barneys will also introduce the company’s newest styles: bifold and zip wallets, a zip pouch and folding card holders. “Our design revolves around the phrase ‘luxury is simplicity,'” says Andrew Brooks, C.E.O. of Vianel. “Why carry more than you need?” Each of the unisex, minimalist designs are branded simply with a tiny gold logo, and trimmed with an extra pop of color — cobalt blue, dove gray, oxblood — on the sides. $195 to $710; select Barneys locations and barneys.com next week.

headline: Kate Baldwin’s Après-Theater Spot
text: Kate Baldwin’s other stage is the house she shares with her husband and young son in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Extra Time to Sign Up for Health Coverage
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would give people eight more days, until Dec. 23, to sign up for health insurance coverage that takes effect on Jan. 1 under the new health care law.

headline: Her Après-Theater Spot
text: Kate Baldwin moved to a new apartment, a light, airy rental in a Park Slope brownstone, late this summer, precisely one week before rehearsals began for “Big Fish,” the Broadway musical she stars in with Norbert Leo Butz.

headline: Weekend Reading: Banks Worried They Might Be Next
text: After JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion mortgage settlement emerged this week, Jamie Dimon held a conference call with analysts. “It could’ve been somebody else,” the bank’s chief executive said. Who is next on the list?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Nothing Gold Can Stay
text: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one another’s highly individual style of dress.

headline: Review: 2014 Ford Fiesta
text: Some people won’t drive anything less than a luxury car. Others just need the luxury of driving. The refreshed 2014 Ford Fiesta offers budget buyers a slice of the good life. For a price.

headline: Vonn Does Not Rule Out a Return in Two Weeks
text: Lindsey Vonn on Friday officially withdrew from next week’s World Cup ski races in Beaver Creek, Colo., but in a surprise, she left open the possibility that she would race the next week when the women’s World Cup moves to the Lake Louise resort in Canada.

headline: Love, Blown on Course by a Storm
text: There was an unacknowledged matchmaker involved in the romance of Marie La France and Ken Jackson: New Orleans.

headline: Embracing, Not Resenting, Their Differences
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: A Short Drive in the 2015 Audi A3 E-tron
text: Driving any car in the rush hour traffic that coats Los Angeles roads like a viscous layer of hair gel is a chore. You could have the fastest, fanciest, most cool looking car in the world, and you’d still be sitting in the same motoring morass as someone perched behind the wheel of a dented ’92 Toyota Corolla.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Nothing Gold Can Stay
text: A rare street-fashion vignette, often observed on Fifth Avenue in Midtown, is a group of strangers, attracted by one another’s highly individual style of dress, who pause on their way to work to inquire of their clothes. The tradition may vanish, as one member of the group is moving to California. At times, they spontaneously try on one another’s look. Last week, nature provided a backdrop only it could create. In Central Park, a “Brigadoon” mist settled over the lake, and cascades of willows framed the Bow Bridge. All over the city, the ginkgo tree proved once again as the leaves fell that Manhattan streets are indeed paved with gold.

headline: An Upscale Bounty, and a Thankful Shopper
text: Since opening its first store in Austin, Tex., in 1980, Whole Foods Market has transformed the way Americans shop for food and eat at home — at least those who live in mostly affluent urban areas. When a branch opened in my neighborhood — theretofore a culinary desert — I wandered wide-eyed through what seemed a paradise of offerings tended by an eager and informed staff.

headline: Choosing Child Care When You Go Back to Work
text: The largest financial commitment that many new parents make is also the most emotional: choosing a full-time caregiver for your child as you head back to work.

headline: Holiday Finds Congress Well Short of Goals
text: WASHINGTON — The landmark Senate vote this week to end the minority party’s ability to filibuster most presidential nominees is just one symptom of the deep level of dysfunction coursing through the 113th Congress as the year before midterm elections draws to a close.

headline: Warned on Budget, Italy Is Given Leeway by E.U.
text: BRUSSELS — After Italy rebuffed warnings about its budget, euro-area finance ministers late Friday agreed to give the country additional opportunities to show it can make savings and bolster revenue.

headline: Indulging in Miso After the Holiday Feast
text: I don’t fast after the Thanksgiving Day eat-a-thon and the long weekend of continued feasting and indulgence; perhaps I should.

headline: Twitter Toughening Its Security to Thwart Government Snoops
text: A year ago, hardly anyone, save for cryptographers, had heard of Perfect Forward Secrecy. Now, some customers are demanding it, and technology companies are adding it, one by one, in large part to make government eavesdropping more difficult.

headline: The End of Willets Point
text: It is easy to drive past Willets Point, the 62-acre tangle of auto shops, car parts and grease-covered mechanics tinkering with automobiles, that sits hard by the Unisphere of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Passing by is far easier than driving through: The streets that cross each other at odd angles here in the glossy shadow of Citi Field look as if they had been blasted by land mines. They are pooled with dark, oil-slicked water or rutted with knee-deep holes that suck in a car’s tires. The chalkboard scrape of chassis meeting pavement sounds through the air here with the regularity of a bell tolling the hour.

headline: Heart in Mouth, for a Taxing Rarity
text: Before beginning a Britten program on Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic, the conductor Alan Gilbert welcomed the audience at Avery Fisher Hall to what he called the orchestra’s “small part in the worldwide celebrations” of the towering British composer in the year of his centennial. The concert took place the day before what would have been the actual anniversary of his birth. Britten died in 1976.

headline: A Dallas Concert Honors a Loss That’s 50 Years Old
text: DALLAS — As many have been reminded or have learned anew in recent days, the visual imagery surrounding the life and legacy of John F. Kennedy, who is often called the first television president, is mightily potent. Whether at work, at play or at rest, whether facing crisis or tragedy, whether flirting or consoling, the man exuded charisma and magnetism, enough so to spawn the myth of a Camelot on Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Remembering President Kennedy in Dallas
text: Dallas gathers to mourn on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Bach and His Italian Kin
text: Unlike many of the great composers of his time, Bach stayed put. In his 65 years, he never left a relatively small corner of Germany, even as Handel, his countryman, traveled to Italy and England and Vivaldi, born in Venice, died in Vienna.

headline: A Here-Comes-Trouble Homecoming
text: Back in her Pennsylvania hometown, with her latest letters of rejection in hand — from a publishing house, from her husband seeking divorce — Connie (Adria Vitlar), an English professor and poet, is a mess. As she tells Alexandra (Dee Hoty), the psychiatrist she is seeing, “It was a mistake coming back here without knowing why I was coming.”

headline: Leftovers for Breakfast
text: I’ve always had fond memories of cooking Thanksgiving.

headline: Principal Auctioneer of Sotheby’s Is Leaving Post
text: Tobias Meyer, the chief auctioneer for Sotheby’s, has been the public face and a deal-making catalyst for one of the world’s most powerful auction houses.

headline: Caring for the Aging, but Ignoring the Rules
text: The rules for depicting the frail elderly on television are fairly clear: it must be done with a gauzy somberness. Dementia and nursing homes and such are something to be whispered about and handled with kid gloves rather than considered a fact of life.

headline: An Early Start for Cyber Deals
text: Updated, 3:33 p.m. | It seems Cyber Monday can’t come soon enough for some hotels and resorts this year. Many are getting into the holiday spirit early, offering discounted rooms, spa vouchers and lots and lots of free drinks to travelers before they’ve even had a chance to cook their turkey.

headline: Bhutan Goes Electric
text: Bhutan, the tiny mountainous country that popularized the concept of gross national happiness, is planning to replace conventional cars with electric vehicles in what could be an interesting, albeit not easily repeatable, experiment for the rest of the world to watch.

headline: Actors on Actors Who Act Shakespeare
text: Shakespeare fans have no qualms about debating which Hamlet or Lady Macbeth was better than the rest. Last week Charles Isherwood asked: What makes a master Shakespearean actor? This week readers weighed in with their picks for the best Shakespearean performance they’d ever seen or heard.

headline: Pumpkins Beyond Halloween
text: There was a little farm near where we lived, in Alsace, France, in a small town by the name of Thann, where we got our pumpkins. My mother would make soup just this same way; she served it in the pumpkin, too. We kids looked forward to it every year.

headline: Questions on Drone Strike Find Only Silence
text: WASHINGTON — Standing on the marble floor just outside the House chamber, Faisal bin Ali Jaber looked lost in the human river of hard-charging lobbyists, members of Congress and staffers. It is not every day that a victim of American drone strikes travels 7,000 miles to Washington to look for answers.

headline: The Art of Burning Rubber vs. Steady Wins the Race
text: Television viewers who enjoy a study in contrasts will be served a doozy on Saturday night: stand-up comedy specials by Bill Cosby on Comedy Central and Sarah Silverman on HBO.

headline: Breslin and Son of Kennedy Gravedigger Recall the Famous Job
text: “Clifton Pollard was pretty sure he was going to be working on Sunday,” is the way that Jimmy Breslin’s famous gravedigger column begins, kicking off a poignant account of Mr. Pollard digging President Kennedy’s grave at Arlington National Cemetery shortly after the assassination in 1963.

headline: Audit Board Finds Flaws in Reviews by Deloitte
text: The regulator of accounting firms in the United States said on Friday that Deloitte & Touche, for the second consecutive year, had failed to correct deficiencies in its audit procedures to its satisfaction.

headline: Corporate Incubators Popping Up in Europe
text: LONDON – In an Art Deco office block on a side street in central London, groups of 20-something programmers and engineers sat hunched over laptops in teams of three or four people.

headline: Bringing Life to Museums’ Collections
text: Amid all the reports of a groundswell of disdain for car culture among young people, it may seem that the automobile is entering its twilight.

headline: Car Museums Get a Makeover
text: Instead of being relegated to dark corners as curious relics, automobiles are now receiving the kind of display and attention once reserved for fine art.

headline: A Deal Defended by Cathy Chen
text: Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., teaches on several bridge cruises each year. So he has a good eye for an instructive deal. The one in the diagram is based on a deal defended by Cathy Chen of East Meadow, N.Y., who is a tai chi instructor on ships.

headline: Chowder With an American Accent
text: Fish chowder is the type of dish you may find in England at a country pub or in a fishing village. But the addition of Quahog clams and intensely flavorful Long Island sweet corn makes this particular chowder unmistakably American, and, with its hearty vegetables, bacon, potatoes and cream, a great dish for the Thanksgiving table. It also reminds me of what I give thanks for every year: the warmth and comfort of family and friends, who gather around the pot with their bowls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Virginia, the Philippines, China and Bahrain.

headline: Brisket Barley Soup
text: If there was no room for Hanukkah on the Thanksgiving table, you can get a taste of brisket in this hearty winter soup.

headline: Brisket Is Coming to Dinner, in a Soup
text: When Hanukkah and Thanksgiving merge at our family table this year, we will keep the turkey and lose the brisket — at least for that one night.

headline: Loved by a King, but Doomed by a Hermit
text: When Puccini died in 1924, he left only sketches for the finale of his opera “Turandot.” A parade of prominent Italian composers were proposed and rejected before Franco Alfano was finally picked to complete it.

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Sandra Bullock’s Fashion Choices
text: Ms. Bullock, 49, has managed to clamber out of the conventional rom-com rut with gutsy roles that display a surprising versatility.

headline: Pastrami on Thanksgiving Turns Heads
text: Thanksgiving pastrami: I know it’s not traditional, but it is impressive, delicious and bountiful. Hear me out on this one.

headline: At Super Bowl, New York and New Jersey Will Be Top Rivals
text: For $9,199, a football fan can buy a sideline-seat-and-hotel-room package to the Super Bowl next year. The seat will be in New Jersey, where the game will be played. But the hotel room will be in New York, where “Super Bowl Boulevard” will stretch from Herald Square through Times Square with a temporary theme park and a 180-foot-tall toboggan slide.

headline: TimesOpen Hack Day 2013
text: Our fourth annual Hack Day drew more than 80 participants who created about 30 projects, many of which used APIs supported by representatives from Bitly, DocumentCloud, Mashery, NYPL Labs, Sunlight Foundation, Twilio and our very own NYT Developers. Together they taught, hacked and answered questions. By demo time, 23 projects were ready to show.

headline: Chat With Eric Asimov About Holiday Drinks
text: Eric Asimov, wine critic for The Times, answered some of your questions in a Twitter chat on Monday, Nov. 25, at 1 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: An Arty Home for Jazzy Sets
text: Music, as subject or spirit, doesn’t leap out of Christopher Wool’s wordy, designy, process-oriented paintings and silk-screen works. But sometimes it lives as a reference in the text and titles. One black-and-white stencil painting in his retrospective exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum says “You Make Me,” which is the incomplete outburst written in felt-tip pen on Richard Hell’s chest on the cover of the album “Blank Generation.”

headline: Mavis Batey, Allied Code Breaker in World War II, Dies at 92
text: After Britain declared war on Germany in September 1939, Mavis Lever, an 18-year-old British university student, volunteered to be an army nurse. Instead, because of her expertise in the German language, she was referred to the intelligence services.

headline: Every Picture Tells Anjelica Huston’s Story
text: In a sea of Santa Monica whites and tans, it was hard not to stare at the formidably chic woman with the dancer’s posture dressed in head-to-toe black.

headline: Treats Magazine Throws a Party
text: Mr. Shaw threw the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday.

headline: The Last Days of Willets Point
text: Newer developments will soon replace the stream of auto repair shops that have long lined and defined Willets Point. Those who work there see the city-planned upgrade as a threat to their livelihood.

headline: Tale as Old as Time, With Video Projections
text: The divided self assumes ravishing forms in “La Belle et la Bête,” a show out of Montreal that is as lovely to look at as it is hard to listen to. Individuals split and multiply as if by enchanted atomic fission in Lemieux Pilon 4D Art’s modern retelling of that eternal favorite of blind date recaps, “The Beauty and the Beast,” which runs through Saturday at the Howard Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Strong Rules on Fracking in Wyoming Seen as Model
text: In energy-friendly Wyoming, oil and gas companies are getting a clear message: Drill, baby, drill — but carefully.

headline: The Future Is Here. Are Customers?
text: LOS ANGELES — As another auto show season opened Wednesday with nearly simultaneous press previews at big salons in Los Angeles and Tokyo, followed closely by an exhibition in Guangzhou, China, the message from automakers to potential customers seems to be: The future is here.

headline: 2013 Los Angeles Auto Show
text: Highlights from the press previews in Los Angeles, which helped kick off another season of auto shows.

headline: An Orb of Trash Floats Down the Gowanus
text: The spindly skeletons of discarded umbrellas are a common sight after rainy days. But the collection that drifted down the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn on Friday was something else. The brainchild of the husband-and-wife firm SLO Architecture, Harvest Dome 2.0 is a floating orb made out of 450 cast-off umbrella frames, suspended over a ring of soda bottles.

headline: Mark Morris’s ‘L’Allegro,’ 25 Years Later
text: Mr. Morris’s company performed his masterwork, “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Heralding the Holidays With an Apple Crostata
text: When I saw my mother making her apple turnover, I knew company was coming. I also knew the dough scraps would be my treat. She’d roll them in sugar and cinnamon and bake them, and we’d enjoy the light, buttery morsels together with a cold glass of milk.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 22 at 6 p.m.
text: Magnus Carlsen is crowned the new chess champion; Clive Staples Lewis is honored today; and the oldest wine cellar.

headline: Kaleidoscope of Introspection, Joy and Pastoral Tranquility
text: In 1988, Mark Morris was given the break most choreographers only dream of: a three-year residency at the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels, where money and resources flowed like water. He could choreograph his heart out, and he did, creating one of those rare, euphoric dances that make life worth living.

headline: Fuel Cells at Center Stage
text: BERKELEY, CALIF. — Like thick-rim glasses, Doc Martens and so many other things that fell out of favor only to spring back to popularity years later, fuel-cell cars have resurfaced.

headline: Head of Hawaii Insurance Exchange Steps Down
text: The executive director of Hawaii’s state health care exchange announced her resignation on Friday amid delays in getting the insurance marketplace off the ground.

headline: Past Perfect
text: After living in what must have seemed like every neighborhood in three boroughs — Coney Island, the South Bronx, East Flatbush, Spanish Harlem (as it was then called), the Lower East Side — my mother’s parents, in their oldish age, settled in Astoria, which is where I spent almost all the Thanksgivings of my childhood.

headline: Rising With the Stars
text: The Griddle Cafe in Los Angeles serves up pancakes, plenty of sugar and the occasional bed-headed celebrity for the masses to ogle.

headline: The F.C.C. Puts Onus on Airlines for In-Flight Calls
text: The Federal Communications Commission rushed on Friday to send Americans a message: “Don’t blame us!”

headline: Sandra Bullock Discovers Color
text: WHO Sandra Bullock

headline: As the Clothes Come Off, the Magazines Dress Up
text: It was the kind of Halloween party that Hugh Hefner might have given in his heyday. Young, almost-but-not-quite-A-list celebrities like Derek Hough, Russell Simmons, Aaron Paul, Jeremy Piven and Ryan Seacrest mingled among a crowd of barely clad, voluptuous women (some who performed fire-throwing tricks in Indian-themed, barely there costumes) while occasionally flipping through copies of an erotic magazine featuring more barely clad (or not clad at all) women on its glossy pages.

headline: The Return of the Tight Squeeze
text: When Sarah A. Chrisman received a blue silk rose-patterned corset from her husband, a librarian and bicycle-shop manager, for her 29th birthday, she reluctantly allowed him to lace her into it. She believed then, she said recently, that corsets “deformed, broke bones, tortured and killed.”

headline: Stars, Yes, but Not Michelin
text: LOS ANGELES — The Chateau Marmont was still passed out. The only activity on the nearby RockWalk, where Tommy Lee’s paw prints are set in cement, came from a pair of pigeons. Nary a needle was buzzing at Tattoo Mania.

headline: An Art and Design Auction You Might Actually Be Able to Afford
text: After nearly 40 years as one of New York’s most revered generalist appraisers, Michael Capo has opened an auction house, Beaux-Arts Auction, in Long Island City, Queens, which hit the ground running in October with a first sale that brought in $250,000. The inventory is made up largely of finds from liquidated estates, ranging from antique furniture to contemporary art, making it a dream destination for interior designers and collectors. Capo founded Beaux-Arts, which sits in a sprawling 7,500-square-foot gallery, with his longtime friend Marc Lester, a Sotheby’s veteran who specializes in French and European furniture.

headline: Ex-Credit Suisse Executive Sentenced in Mortgage Bond Case
text: A former top executive at the Credit Suisse Group was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday for inflating the value of mortgage bonds as the housing market collapsed.

headline: Katie Couric Is Said to Be Close to Taking a Job at Yahoo
text: Katie Couric is “in the late stages” of negotiations to leave her job as a special correspondent at ABC News for a new, as-yet-undefined role at Yahoo, an executive with knowledge of the talks said on Friday evening.

headline: A Momentum Powered by Sudden U-Turns
text: Stormy. Stunning. Visionary. Heroic. Those were some of the words that lingered in my mind after the Pacifica Quartet’s Tuesday evening concert of works by Leo Ornstein and Beethoven at Zankel Hall. And I wasn’t thinking about Beethoven.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Week in Pictures for Nov. 22
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the real mayors of New York, the whitewashing of 5Pointz in Long Island City and the opening of an ice rink at McCarren Park.

headline: 3 Found Guilty in CityTime Corruption Trial
text: Three men who a prosecutor said had gotten “unbelievably rich” at the expense of New York City through a scandal-marred payroll modernization project were convicted on Friday in a federal corruption trial in Manhattan.

headline: The Thrill of Breathlessness
text: FREMANTLE, Australia — NEWS of Nicholas Mevoli’s death during a free-diving competition at Dean’s Blue Hole in the Bahamas earlier this week has shocked the sport’s devotees and touched many of us who spend time in the water holding our breaths. Doubtless some readers will have been puzzled as to why a young man put his life at such unnecessary risk in the first place.

headline: What the Filibuster Rule Changes, and What It Doesn't
text: What are the likely effects of the Senate's decision to limit filibusters?

headline: The Long Goodbye
text: “New York was no mere city,” Joan Didion wrote in her landmark 1967 essay, “Goodbye to All That,” explaining why she abandoned her adopted home of New York, seemingly for good, at the age of 29. “It was instead an infinitely romantic notion, the mysterious nexus of all love and money and power, the shining and perishable dream itself.”

headline: Founder of Reddit and the Internet’s Own Cheerleader
text: Alexis Ohanian bounded through the offices of Maker’s Row, a start-up in Brooklyn that pairs small businesses with manufacturers. At 6-foot-5, dressed in a gingham shirt and jeans, Mr. Ohanian was, in more ways than one, the big man on campus.

headline: Sale of T.G.I. Fridays Is Considered
text: Carlson, the global hospitality and travel company, said on Friday that it had authorized a review of strategic alternatives including a possible sale of T.G.I. Fridays restaurants.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Thom Browne’s Relaxed Style, Jay Z’s Negotiating Skills and Alexander Wang’s Marble Footprint
text: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTURENov. 16 – 22

headline: Biographies of the Famous Don’t Skimp on the Details
text: The book industry faces many challenges these days, but a rising cost of paper does not appear to be one of them. That, at least, is the conclusion to be drawn from the recent spate of plus-size biographies — tree-killer volumes pushing 1,000 pages — that have been making bookshelves sag.

headline: Life of Stanwyck Is an Aerobic Read
text: THE FIRST VOLUME of Victoria Wilson’s “A Life of Barbara Stanwyck: Steel-True, 1907-1940” ends as Europe erupts in war. Stanwyck herself would probably point out, with a laconic smile, that bigger things were happening than motion pictures.

headline: Fighter of Corruption in Nigeria Considers Next Steps
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — The cash was handed over in large sacks containing $15 million in $100 bills, bags so heavy that the stoop-shouldered civil servant needed help carrying them.

headline: Veteran Union Activist Fasts to Support Rights for Illegal Immigrants
text: WASHINGTON — As a teenage grape picker, Eliseo Medina learned political action at the feet of Cesar Chavez. In 1968, he watched Mr. Chavez hold a 25-day water-only fast that helped transform the farm workers’ union into a nationally known force.

headline: Editor in India, Known for Investigations Into Corruption, Is Accused of Rape
text: NEW DELHI — The police in the coastal state of Goa filed charges of rape and sexual assault on Friday against Tarun Tejpal, the editor of a liberal-minded magazine that has influenced a generation of young Indian journalists with its exposés of corruption and abuse of power.

headline: U.S. Retailers Decline to Aid Factory Victims in Bangladesh
text: One year after the Tazreen factory fire in Bangladesh, many retailers that sold garments produced there or inside the Rana Plaza building that collapsed last spring are refusing to join an effort to compensate the families of the more than 1,200 workers who died in those disasters.

headline: N.S.A. Report Outlined Goals for More Power
text: WASHINGTON — Officials at the National Security Agency, intent on maintaining its dominance in intelligence collection, pledged last year to push to expand its surveillance powers, according to a top-secret strategy document.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagram Messaging, and Room Reservations Courtesy of Twitter
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Phillip Lim: The Chinese-American Dream
text: Suzy Menkes sits down with Phillip Lim and Wen Zhou, his business partner, to discuss the influence that heritage has had on their brand.

headline: Norwegian, 22, Takes World Chess Title
text: Magnus Carlsen, the 22-year-old Norwegian who has been the most dominant chess player since 2010, finally broke through on Friday to win the game’s most important title, the world championship, for the first time.

headline: Japan: Governor of Tokyo Embroiled in Loan Scandal
text: Two months after winning the 2020 Olympics for his city, the governor of Tokyo has become embroiled in a scandal over a half-million dollars that he received from a hospital operator involved in an election-fraud case. The governor, Naoki Inose, has struggled to explain why he took the money from the Tokushukai hospital chain during his campaign to become governor in December. On Friday, he described the money as a personal loan that he hurriedly paid back in September, shortly after prosecutors raided the company in connection with the fraud case. Speculation has focused on whether the money was intended to facilitate the construction of a hospital in Tokyo; it appears to have no connection to the successful Olympic bid, which also took place in September.

headline: Gynecologists Run Afoul of Panel When Patient Is Male
text: About two months ago, Dr. Elizabeth Stier was shocked to learn that she would lose a vital credential, board certification as a gynecologist, unless she gave up an important part of her medical practice and her research: taking care of men at high risk for anal cancer.

headline: A Complex Love Story, Complete With Bells and a Ring
text: MACAU — Manny Pacquiao’s last fight ended with him facedown on the canvas, his arms tucked awkwardly underneath him, his body limp. His wife, Jinkee, was hysterical. She bolted toward the ring and fell into the arms of Pacquiao’s promoter and sobbed.

headline: Lincoln Looks South of the Border
text: In July 1863, just weeks after the twin Union victories at Gettysburg and Vicksburg, Abraham Lincoln turned his attention to the Rio Grande borderlands of Confederate Texas. On July 31, the president wrote Francis P. Blair Sr., one of his most powerful supporters, “Yesterday I commenced trying to get up an expedition for Texas. I shall do the best I can.” By November, 6,000 Union troops had landed in South Texas.

headline: A Players-Only Meeting? That Can’t Be Good News
text: When Chuck Daly was coaching the Orlando Magic in the late 1990s and his team was mired in a rough patch, he learned that a couple of his players were itching for a players-only meeting. Eric Musselman, one of his young assistants, recalled how Daly recruited him to relay a message to Horace Grant: permission denied.

headline: A Gamble in Iran Talks: Easing of the Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — In its delicate negotiations with Iran over freezing its nuclear program, the Obama administration is gambling that the gradual relaxation of punishing sanctions will whet Tehran’s appetite for greater economic relief, inducing the country’s leaders to negotiate a further deal to roll back its nuclear progress.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: The Dow Jones Industrial average closes above 16,000, the former presidential contender John Edwards opens a law office and European companies develop new drones.

headline: Marines Toughen Rules for Makers of Licensed Clothing
text: The Marine Corps trademark licensing office has adopted tougher production standards for manufacturers that produce clothing items like sweatshirts emblazoned with Marine mottos or insignia, after the corps was stung by the discovery of a licensed company’s designs in the rubble of a factory fire in Bangladesh a year ago.

headline: Saturday’s Games to Watch
text: 3 BAYLOR at

headline: Obama’s Bay of Pigs
text: This week, when we are remembering John F. Kennedy, I’d like to touch briefly on the greatest fiasco of his presidency: the Bay of Pigs invasion. No sooner had Kennedy taken the oath of office than he discovered that the Pentagon and C.I.A. were preparing to send 1,500 Cuban exiles to invade Cuba. Though they would be greatly outnumbered by Cuban troops, the American military and the C.I.A. assumed that once the attack began, the Cuban people would rise up and overthrow Fidel Castro.

headline: Fears of Violence Loom Over Honduran Elections
text: In a country where the rule of law has all but shriveled, Hondurans head to the polls in hopes of electing a president who will bring stability and security.

headline: Racial Abuse Is Alleged at San Jose State University
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Students at San Jose State University were grappling on Friday with accusations that three white students repeatedly abused a black freshman verbally and physically, calling him names referring to slavery and putting a bicycle lock around his neck.

headline: Political Doubt Poses Risk to Honduras, Battered by Coup and Violence
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — When police officers arrived last week after the murder of Felipe Nery Aguilar and his daughter Gladys, they seized on what appeared to be a clue: a childish scribble on a broken television set. A message from local gangs, the officers figured, demanding protection money, known here as a “war tax.” Case closed.

headline: Responding to a Meningitis Outbreak
text: A vaccine approved for use in Europe and Australia but not in the United States will be imported to help quell an outbreak of bacterial meningitis at Princeton University. This is a good example of how two federal agencies — the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration — can collaborate to reach a common-sense solution to protect the public’s health.

headline: Climbing Out of Albany’s Swamp
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly promised to “clean up Albany,” a vow that topped his priority list when he ran for office in 2010. Last January, he took the next step and proposed public matching funds for smaller campaign donations, a system that has worked remarkably well in New York City.

headline: Surveillance Goes on Trial
text: There was a lot that was ordinary about the hearing in Courtroom 20B of the Manhattan federal courthouse on Friday morning: a team of lawyers at the plaintiff’s table, spectators in the gallery. What was extraordinary was the defendant, the United States government, and the lawsuit it is facing over the National Security Agency’s seven-year-old, once top-secret phone-surveillance program, which until this week it never had to defend in open court.

headline: Leave an Idea, Take an Idea
text: Saturday is the last day for New Yorkers to give Bill de Blasio, the mayor-elect, a piece of their mind under the big white “Talking Transition” tent on Canal Street and Avenue of the Americas. Since the Nov. 5 election, inside that tent, in mobile tents that roamed the boroughs and online at talkingtransitionnyc.com, thousands have offered suggestions on stickers and postcards; sent emails; taped videos; and attended forums on topics like “food justice,” affordable housing and immigrant integration.

headline: Comparing Child Care Costs
text: Full-time child care is a large expense, but the cost varies regionally and by state with some scattered outliers among the highest.

headline: Texas Education Board Flags Biology Textbook Over Evolution Concerns
text: The Texas Board of Education on Friday delayed final approval of a widely used biology textbook because of concerns raised by one reviewer that it presents evolution as fact rather than theory.

headline: Iran Would Eliminate Stock of Some of Its Enriched Uranium Under Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Under the proposed six-month deal that six major powers are negotiating with Iran in Geneva, Iran would eliminate its current stock of uranium enriched to 20 percent by diluting it or turning it into fuel rods or oxide powder, forms that are unusable for weapons, senior Western officials said Friday.

headline: A Rural Retreat in China
text: The Times's Edward Wong visits the quiet town of Dali, where writers, artists and other residents have found an idyllic escape from the crowded cities of eastern China.

headline: Tension and Flaws Before Health Website Crash
text: WASHINGTON — On a sultry day in late August, a dozen staff members of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services gathered at the agency’s Baltimore headquarters with managers from the major contractors building HealthCare.gov to review numerous problems with President’s Obama’s online health insurance initiative. The mood was grim.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 23, 2013.
text: “It really puts a human face on the term ‘collateral damage.’”

headline: Police Unsure if Random Attacks Are Rising Threat or Urban Myth
text: Fear swept through Borough Park, Brooklyn, as soon as the news got out: A young man was randomly assaulted by strangers early Friday morning, and the attack was possibly part of the so-called Knockout Game.

headline: Singing Arias and Splitting Uprights, a Raven Knows How to Enhance a Score
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Justin Tucker’s right leg swung swiftly into the football’s gut, and he watched the ball travel straight and far before smashing off a seat deep in the second deck.

headline: North Korea Confirms It Is Holding U.S. Citizen
text: The State Department said Friday that North Korea had confirmed that it was holding an American citizen, whom family and friends have identified as an octogenarian veteran of the Korean War inexplicably detained there last month as he was concluding an officially approved nine-day tour of the country.

headline: Corrections: November 23, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 22, 2013
Slam Dunk
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well. If you thought you were going to relax with the crossword puzzle this weekend, you were clearly wrong. This is a “rock ’em, sock ’em” puzzle if ever I saw one, with a bit of obscurity and variance thrown in to keep us humble.

headline: For the Love of the Game
text: Columbia football’s long history of losing seasons, and long rides to the field, do not deter players from coming out for practices and games.

headline: Columbia Football’s Dogged Futility
text: Way uptown, at its gleaming new field house on the northern tip of Manhattan, Columbia is trying to win at football — really, it is — even though it may appear otherwise.

headline: Wind Energy Company to Pay $1 Million in Bird Deaths
text: Duke Energy agreed on Friday to pay $1 million in fines as part of the Justice Department’s first criminal case against a wind power company for the deaths of protected birds.

headline: Pentagon Releases Strategy for Arctic
text: WASHINGTON — As a shrinking northern ice cap sets the stage for increased competition over natural resources, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Friday released the Pentagon’s first “Arctic Strategy,” intended to safeguard American security interests and the region’s environment.

headline: A New Dispute Emerges in Brooklyn Prosecutor’s Office
text: The last several months have unfolded tempestuously for Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. He faces accusations that his office handled a series of wrongful convictions in murder cases, one of which has resulted in a $150 million lawsuit. He was criticized for allowing his office to be the focus of a television show. And he lost a primary and a lopsided general election, forcing him out after 24 years.

headline: Despite the Evidence, Trainers Deny a Doping Problem
text: On Thursday morning, representatives of the horse-racing industry told Congress that thoroughbred racing’s drug problem was a myth. On Thursday afternoon, a report by the California Horse Racing Board revealed that Bob Baffert, a Hall of Fame trainer, had been giving every horse in his barn a thyroid hormone without ever checking to see if any of them had thyroid problems.

headline: Urbanites Flee China’s Smog for Blue Skies
text: DALI, China — A typical morning for Lin Liya, a native of Shanghai transplanted to this ancient town in southwest China, goes like this: See her 3-year-old son off to school near the mountains; go for a half-hour run on the shores of Erhai Lake; and browse the local market for fresh vegetables and meat.

headline: Vern Mikkelsen, Hall of Famer Who Won Four Titles With the Lakers, Dies at 85
text: Vern Mikkelsen, a Hall of Fame forerunner of the modern-day power forward who helped lead the Minneapolis Lakers to four N.B.A. championships in the early 1950s, died on Thursday at his home in Wayzata, Minn. He was 85.

headline: John Egerton, Who Lent Spice to Social Justice, Dies at 78
text: John Egerton understood that the American South was a region of contradictions, holding both savagery and sweetness, churchgoers and evildoers, good cooking and bad.

headline: ‘Completely Different’ Giants Eager for Rematch With Cowboys
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants enter their rematch against Dallas at MetLife Stadium believing that their season-opening 36-31 loss to the Cowboys proved nothing about the superiority of either team.

headline: Rev. T. J. Jemison, Civil Rights Leader Who Organized Early Boycott, Dies at 95
text: The Rev. T. J. Jemison, a civil rights pioneer who organized a 1953 bus boycott in Baton Rouge, La., that foreshadowed the one set off by Rosa Parks in Montgomery, Ala., and who went on to lead the nation’s largest black Baptist organization into liberal political activism, died on Nov. 15 in Baton Rouge. He was 95.

headline: Kerry Opposes Afghan Delay on Security Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry talked with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Friday to express displeasure with his plan to put off signing the two countries’ security deal until next year, and a State Department spokeswoman said the delay threatened relations between Washington and Kabul.

headline: After Conviction, Focus Turns to Ownership of Marcos Artwork
text: The criminal trial concerning four Impressionist masterpieces once owned by Imelda Marcos may have ended this week with a jury’s quick conviction of her former personal secretary, but a more daunting question remains: What happens to the artwork?

headline: ‘Trouble Don’t Last Always’
text: There’s an old Gospel song called “Trouble Don’t Last Always.” My mother has repeated that phrase so often that the words are written on my consciousness.

headline: Flyers Rescue Season Behind Interim Coach and a Few Good Bounces
text: PHILADELPHIA — On Nov. 1, one month into the N.H.L. season, the Philadelphia Flyers lost to the Alex Ovechkin-less Washington Capitals, 7-0. They took nearly three times as many penalty minutes as shots, and goalie Ray Emery attracted criticism by leaving the crease to fight Washington’s Braden Holtby. The Flyers’ record fell to 3-9, and their star center Claude Giroux still had not scored a goal.

headline: Experts Say Poaching Could Soon Lead to a Decline in the Rhino Population
text: After two decades of gains, the world’s population of rhinoceroses is being killed off by poachers at such a high rate that conservationists fear the deaths could soon surpass the number of rhinos that are born each year.

headline: Garnett Has Impact, but Not the Right Kind, in a Rout
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Nights like Friday are when leadership matters in the N.B.A. Four injured players were out for the beleaguered Nets, including their leading scorer Brook Lopez. The situation demanded that the veterans with the championship rings, Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce, assert themselves. Especially Garnett, facing the Minnesota Timberwolves, the franchise where he spent his first 12 seasons.

headline: Argument Escalates to Stabbing at Kennedy Airport
text: A man was stabbed in the face during a dispute in a parking lot at Kennedy International Airport on Friday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Led by Veterans (in Early 20s), UConn Nips Indiana
text: It is a year featuring one of the deepest and most advanced freshman classes in memory, and Connecticut can seem a bit like a creaky wooden vessel in a flotilla of speedboats. The Huskies do not have that transcendent newcomer. They are led by that most arcane and passé of figures: the upperclassman.

headline: Bloomberg Wants Restaurants to Compost
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is slowly bringing New Yorkers around to the idea of recycling their food scraps, is trying to expand his composting campaign by bringing it to large restaurants.

headline: After a Long Silence, Dolan Speaks
text: On March 13, 2012, The New York Times published a story by Howard Beck that noted it had been exactly five years since James Dolan, the Knicks’ owner, had consented to any sort of interview with the reporters who covered his often inept team.

headline: Marines at Kennedy’s Funeral Stand Together Again
text: ALLEN, Tex. — Fifty years without seeing someone is a long time to remember a name, and when Bob DeBardelaben saw Tom Tallick at a reunion here of the Marines who served at President John F. Kennedy’s funeral, he could not.

headline: A Chance to Spend a Bit of Summer in the Country
text: Sitting in the living room of her two-bedroom apartment in the Marble Hill section of the Bronx, Kathleen Hicks, a former messenger service dispatcher, turned up her right wrist. The name Nancy is tattooed, in cursive, on the pulse point.

headline: A Strategy for Surveillance Powers
text: A National Security Agency mission statement provides a glimpse of agency officials’ goals before the Snowden leaks upset their political calculus.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) IDENTITY THIEF (2013) Melissa McCarthy stars as a crazed kewpie doll of a thief sometimes named Diana who wreaks havoc on a milquetoast, Sandy Patterson (Jason Bateman), after stealing his identity just as he lands a job insuring his upward mobility. After leaving his wife (Amanda Peet) and their kids in their meager apartment, Sandy heads toward Diana’s home in Florida to regain control over his life. But she’s not about to give up the spoils easily. “From the moment Diana comes on screen in ‘Identity Thief,’ sugar-talking Sandy out of his information while she’s slurping a soda, Ms. McCarthy owns the movie,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The character may be drawn in broad strokes, but Ms. McCarthy slips between the saucy and the demonic with exquisite effortlessness, fluttering her lashes and flashing her dimples one minute, unleashing her inner Medusa the next.”

headline: China Claims Air Rights Over Disputed Islands
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government on Saturday claimed the right to identify, monitor and possibly take military action against aircraft that enter a newly declared “air defense identification zone,” which covers sea and islands also claimed by Japan and threatens to escalate an already tense dispute over some of the maritime territory.

headline: Karzai Insists U.S. Forces Killed Civilians in a Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the second time in less than a week, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has picked a high-profile fight with his American allies, in the midst of a grand council that he convened to support a long-term security agreement with the United States.

headline: New Musical Partnership in China
text: One of the biggest, but least-tapped markets for classical music and dance — as both an importer and exporter — is China. So this week IMG Artists, a major representative of classical musicians in the West, announced a new partnership with the China Arts and Entertainment Group, a huge arts and entertainment company in China.

headline: Bubblephobia and Monetary Policy
text: How do you know that monetary policy is too loose? The textbook answer is that excessively expansionary monetary policy shows up in rising inflation; stable inflation means money is neither too loose nor too tight. This answer has, however, come under challenge from both sides. One side — the side I’m on, and I’m pretty sure the side Janet Yellen is on, says that at low inflation rates this rule breaks down: the Phillips curve isn’t vertical, even in the long run, at low inflation (perhaps thanks to downward nominal wage rigidity), so stable inflation at a low level is consistent with an economy operating well below potential.

headline: Egypt Expels Turkey’s Ambassador, Further Fraying Diplomatic Ties
text: CAIRO — Egypt announced on Saturday that it was downgrading its diplomatic relations with Turkey and expelled the Turkish ambassador because of “provocative” criticisms of Cairo by Turkey’s prime minister, a spokesman for Egypt’s foreign minister said.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Nov. 22, 2013
text: Healthcare.gov launched more than seven weeks ago and the program’s problems keep piling up, as hundreds of thousands of people received notifications that their current coverage is being cancelled. There are also concerns over the website’s security. Last week, President Obama announced a fix. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine consider if these changes put the entire law at risk and what the uncertainty means for consumers and businesses. Plus, a look at the recent JPMorgan settlement, which forced the bank to shell out a record $13 billion.

headline: In Our Pages: November 23
text: 1938: S.S. Vows ‘Fire and Sword’

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Tierney Gearon’s ‘Alphabet Book’
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: After Two Decades, a Shrinking Salary at a Job She Loved
text: Police cars were blocking the entrance to the bus yard in Brooklyn when Nicole Bouchotte, 61, arrived at work one day last January. It was at that moment, so early on a cold weekday morning that the sun had yet to rise, that she learned that her union, Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, was on strike.

headline: Arsenal’s Giroud Receives a Gift
text: Buried deep inside nearly every goalkeeper in the world is a skillful field player fighting to get out. At least that is a theory shared by most of the world’s goalkeepers.

headline: Variety: A New Diagramless
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’ll tell you exactly where I had trouble: PARIPASSU.

headline: Syrian Rebels Seize Control of Oil Field From Assad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A group of Syrian rebel brigades, including an affiliate of Al Qaeda, seized a large oil and gas field from government forces on Saturday, opposition activists said, further depriving the government of President Bashar al-Assad of the resources it needs to remain solvent.

headline: Teams Are Learning to Keep Their Best Players Off the Market
text: When the Detroit Tigers traded Prince Fielder to Texas last week, they still owed him a staggering $168 million. Only one player had ever been traded with more money still owed to him: Alex Rodriguez, from Texas to the Yankees in 2004.

headline: $62 Million in Sales at ‘Art of the Automobile’ Auction
text: A red Ferrari endurance-racing car that was on display in the lobby of Sotheby’s on the Upper East Side of Manhattan was the top sale in a closely watched auction on Thursday. The 1964 Ferrari 250 LM, which was been given a presale estimate of $12 million to $15 million, sold for $14.3 million including the buyer’s premium.

headline: Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program
text: GENEVA — The United States and five other world powers announced a landmark accord Sunday morning that would temporarily freeze Iran’s nuclear program and lay the foundation for a more sweeping agreement.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: In Golf, South Koreans Find a New Model for Success
text: NAPLES, Fla. — Se Ri Pak was the prototype, engineered by her father to be a mentally strong, mechanically sound golfing machine. His blueprint, in which he streamlined Pak’s existence by eliminating any activity not conducive to shooting low scores, was widely copied by other South Korean fathers of young daughters after Pak won the first of 25 titles on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

headline: Lakers’ Nash Shares Aches of His Elders
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — As Lakers guard Steve Nash speaks in such a clinical manner about nerve root irritation, proper alignment, asymptomatic discomfort and musculature default patterns, listening to him requires a quick reminder that he is a basketball player and not a Pilates instructor.

headline: Lynn Good of Duke Energy, on Effective Leaders
text: This interview with   Lynn J. Good, chief executive of Duke Energy, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Cowboys See a Chance to Move Past Troubles
text: IRVING, Tex. — One bye week may not be enough time to cure what ails the Dallas Cowboys, who appear as enigmatic as ever before their showdown with the Giants on Sunday.

headline: Almanacs Foresee a Super Bowl to Test Fans’ Resolve, and Snow Gear
text: When the N.F.L. owners met near Dallas three years ago and chose to hold Super Bowl XLVIII in New Jersey, it was a balmy 90 degrees and dry as a bone. The 80,000 fans who attend the game in February may be happy if it is half as warm.

headline: Haitian Photographer Wins Major U.S. Copyright Victory
text: Photographers have struggled financially over the last decade as millions of images have been taken and published on the Web without proper attribution or compensation. And when photographers try to pursue copyright violators, it is often difficult and expensive. On Friday, the Haitian photographer Daniel Morel won a major copyright victory after a four-year fight over images he had originally sent out via social media.

headline: Eli Manning’s Footballs Are Months in Making
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Eli Manning drops back to throw his first pass Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, the football in his hands will be as familiar as an old friend.

headline: For Sale: Craggy Isle Where Olympic Rocks Are the Stars
text: AILSA CRAIG, Scotland — This stunning volcanic island has been part of Scottish legend for a thousand years, its sugarloaf profile decorating Scottish bank notes and memorialized in a Keats sonnet.

headline: In Immigration Battle, Advocates for Overhaul Single Out Republicans
text: PUEBLO, Colo. — Representative Scott Tipton, Republican of Colorado, entered his town hall meeting and quickly began greeting the assembled crowd, including those who did not necessarily share his political views.

headline: Ed Reed’s Film Study Class Is Mesmerizing an Eager Acolyte
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Josh Bush had but one request soon after being drafted by the Jets in 2012. Bush, a safety, asked his position coach, Dennis Thurman, to put him in touch with Ed Reed, whom he had coached in Baltimore. No way, Thurman said. As much as Bush stood to learn from Reed, he was not ready — not yet.

headline: Unsettled in Goal, U.S. Keeps Looking
text: They fan out to the N.H.L.’s 30 rinks across the continent, a small group of hockey executives watching game after game, deciding which players might represent the United States at the Sochi Olympics. Of those decisions, none will be more crucial than picking the goaltenders.

headline: Bodies Still Being Found Weeks After Philippine Storm
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — A solemn procession walked down the main coastal road here Saturday morning through a light but steady rain, carrying a piece of plywood with a black object securely fastened on top with yellow packaging tape: a body bag holding the remains of Athena Mae Pelingon, age 3.

headline: Saddled Together
text: Marley Stone and Timothy Bourke often go head to head at equestrian competitions, but their friendly rivalry on the field hasn’t affected their romantic relationship.

headline: How Can We Jump-Start the Struggle for Gender Equality?
text: For several decades women’s success in the labor market was so breathtaking, so propulsive, that full gender equality seemed inevitable.

headline: When the Weather, Too, Was Memorable
text: With two almanacs forecasting a snowy Super Bowl at MetLife Stadium in February, it is worth noting that important sporting events often take place in weather that is less than ideal.

headline: Big Games in the Great, Unforgiving Outdoors
text: Some weather prognosticators are warning that the first outdoor Super Bowl in a winter environment could morph into the Snow Bowl. But conducting sporting events in extreme weather is nothing new. Reporters from The New York Times share their tales of meteorologic misery.

headline: In Defense of a Loaded Word
text: MY father’s name is William Paul Coates. I, like my six brothers and sisters, have always addressed him as Dad. Strangers often call him Mr. Coates. His friends call him Paul. If a stranger or one of my father’s friends called him Dad, my father might have a conversation. When I was a child, relatives of my paternal grandmother would call my father Billy. Were I to ever call my father Billy, we would probably have a different conversation.

headline: Puddleglum and the Savage
text: THEY died in their homes, not from an assassin’s bullet, and in their 60s, not in their prime. When C. S. Lewis collapsed in his Oxford bedroom, the presidential motorcade was leaving Love Field. When Aldous Huxley requested a final shot of LSD, a TV set in the next room had just blared the news that the president had been shot. And then the coincidence of two of modernity’s keenest critics dying on the same November day was lost in a storm of headlines and public grief.

headline: Why the Y?
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — EVEN sitting in an M.I.T. classroom made me feel smarter.

headline: Christopher Kimball
text: Christopher Kimball is the bow-tied and bespectacled chef and founder of America’s Test Kitchen, which produces television and radio shows of the same name and publishes Cooks Illustrated magazine.

headline: Right vs. Left in the Midwest
text: MINNESOTA and Wisconsin share much more than bone-chilling winters: German and Northern European roots; farming; and, until recently, a populist progressive tradition stretching back a century to Wisconsin’s Fighting Bob La Follette and the birth of Minnesota’s Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party.

headline: After Changes, How Green Is The Times?
text: EARLY this year, The Times came under heavy criticism from many readers who care deeply about news coverage about the environment — especially climate change.

headline: Oh, Brother! Big Brother Is Back
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — I’VE never been in a big earthquake, but I know what one feels like now, having spent this past week in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. The American-led interim negotiations in Geneva to modestly loosen some sanctions on Iran in return for some curbs on its nuclear program — in advance of talks for an end to sanctions in return for an end to any Iranian bomb-making capability — has hit the Sunni Arab world (and Israel) like a geopolitical earthquake. If and when a deal is struck, it could have a bigger impact on this region than anything since the Camp David peace treaty and Iran’s Islamic Revolution in the 1970s combined to reorder the Middle East.

headline: Taking Our Selfies Seriously
text: “Selfie” is the newly crowned champion word of the year by Oxford Dictionaries. It means a photograph taken of oneself by oneself but usually not for oneself — rather for the whole world — on a cellphone camera.

headline: Danger Lurks in That Mickey Mouse Couch
text: RESEARCHERS this summer purchased 42 children’s chairs, sofas and other furniture from major retailers and tested them for toxic flame retardants that have been linked to cancer, birth defects, diminished I.Q.’s and other problems.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Helping Women ‘Lean In’
text: Readers discuss promoting gender equality at work and home.

headline: A Most Expensive Book
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE first English-language book printed in the New World is scheduled to be auctioned on Tuesday by Sotheby’s of New York. It’s expected to command between $15 million and $30 million — more than anyone, anywhere, has ever paid for a printed book.

headline: Art Makes You Smart
text: FOR many education advocates, the arts are a panacea: They supposedly increase test scores, generate social responsibility and turn around failing schools. Most of the supporting evidence, though, does little more than establish correlations between exposure to the arts and certain outcomes. Research that demonstrates a causal relationship has been virtually nonexistent.

headline: Bringing Back My Real Self With Hormones
text: IN my early 30s, for a few months, I altered my body chemistry and hormones so that I was closer to a man in his early 20s. I was blown away by how dramatically my thoughts changed. I was angry almost all the time, thought about sex constantly, and assumed I was the smartest person in the entire world. Over the years I had met guys rather like this.

headline: $13 Billion, Yes, but What Took So Long?
text: After weeks of pre-deal chatter about its $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase, the Justice Department finally nailed it down last week. And for the first time, the department provided a glimpse of the investigatory findings upon which the settlement was based.

headline: More ‘Stand Your Ground’ Fantasizing
text: Ohio’s Republican-controlled Legislature is aiming to enact a Stand Your Ground gun law, despite pleas from urban government leaders that this would only compound the risks in inner-city neighborhoods where gun mayhem hits hardest. The measure, approved by the Ohio House and sent to the Senate, would eliminate the traditional requirement that a person prudently retreat in the face of danger before resorting to deadly force. It would make Ohio the latest of more than a score of other states following the foolhardy lead of Florida — where the first Stand Your Ground law has proved to be rife with risks to public safety and effective law enforcement.

headline: The Long Goodbye in Afghanistan
text: From his first campaign for the White House, President Obama has vowed to end more than a decade of war, bring the troops home and put America on a less militaristic footing. He has reduced the forces in Afghanistan from about 100,000 in 2010 to about 47,000 today and has promised that all American and international combat forces will be out by the end of 2014.

headline: An Oasis of Groceries
text: CHESTER, Pa.

headline: Curing Insomnia to Treat Depression
text: Psychiatrists have long thought that depression causes insomnia, but new research suggests that insomnia can actually precede and contribute to causing depression. The causal link works in both directions. Two small studies have shown that a small amount of cognitive behavioral therapy to treat insomnia, when added to a standard antidepressant pill to treat depression, can make a huge difference in curing both insomnia and depression in many patients. If the results hold up in other studies already underway at major medical centers, this could be the most dramatic advance in treating depression in decades.

headline: No Phones on My Plane, Please
text: The new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission wants to review and possibly get rid of the agency’s “outdated and restrictive rules” banning cellphone calls on planes. To which, most travelers would rightly ask: Why?

headline: Are Kids Too Coddled?
text: AT a middle school near Boston not long ago, teachers and administrators noticed that children would frequently return from a classmate’s weekend bar mitzvah with commemorative T-shirts, swag that advertised a party to which many fellow students hadn’t been invited.

headline: A Growing Chill Between South Korea and Japan Creates Problems for the U.S.
text: TOKYO — In the courtly world of diplomacy, the meeting between Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea was something of a shock.

headline: Forgotten Killer Among the Korean ‘Erased’

headline: In the Health Law, an Open Door for Entrepreneurs
text: In the weeks since the health insurance marketplaces of the Affordable Care Act went online, a well-publicized ripple of alarm and confusion has permeated the ranks of small-business owners. But less well known is the response of another contingent: newcomers to entrepreneurship who see the legislation as a solution to the often insurmountable expense of getting health insurance. Some even view the Affordable Care Act itself as a business opportunity.

headline: Swatting at a Swarm of Public Relations Spam
text: The Haggler typically starts his column with a complaint, and this time it’s the Haggler’s turn to complain. Specifically, the Haggler would like to complain about the complaints he’s getting.

headline: In Fed Policy, the Exit Music May Be Hard to Hear
text: Is it time for the Federal Reserve to start its exit from the extraordinary set of policies it has pursued over the past few years? That crucial question is on the minds of the nation’s central bankers, as well as the stock and bond traders who follow the Fed’s every move.

headline: A Bitcoin Puzzle: Heads, It’s Excitement. Tails, It’s Anxiety.
text: Bitcoin isn’t ready for popular consumption, and it may never be.

headline: McMansions Are Making a Comeback
text: When the housing bubble burst in 2007, there was a glut of unsold inventory on the market, and the size of newly built homes began to shrink. In both 2008 and 2009, Census Bureau figures show, the median size of a new home was smaller than it had been the previous year. It seemed that after more than a decade of swelling domiciles, the McMansion era was over. But that conclusion may have been premature.

headline: Beyond 3-D Printers’ Magic, Possible Legal Wrangling
text: When reports first appeared that computers could produce three-dimensional objects — from toys to auto parts to household items — it sounded like a page from a science fiction novel.

headline: Invasion of the Annual Reviews

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 24
text: Two stories are vying for the top slot on the Sunday news shows this week – one about the so-called “nuclear option” in the Senate that would limit filibusters, and the other the nuclear talks between Iran and Western nations. The potential fallout for both issues is equally dominating on the political panels this week, with in-depth discussion from experts on which sides may come out on top.

text: Adrienne Asch, an internationally known bioethicist who opposed the use of prenatal testing and abortion to select children free of disabilities, a stance informed partly by her own experience of blindness, died on Nov. 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

headline: Are You Sitting Down? On a Couch?
text: If you typically read the Sunday paper on a couch, you might want to move before reading my Sunday column. Your couch probably has flame retardants embedded in the foam, theoretically to prevent fires. In fact, flame retardants don’t help much with fire prevention (although they do rack up $5 billion in sales for chemical companies that make flame retardants).

headline: What Ethnic Diversity Looks Like: Fort Bend
text: SUGAR LAND — Nikhil Sabharwal of Toronto stood outside a hotel, next to a cart piled with luggage, holding a tall stick decorated with gold garland, a bhangra dance prop from an Indian wedding he had attended here. Steps away, at a coffee shop, a woman wearing a hijab sat near the spot where, minutes earlier, Lynne Gabriel, a fashion blogger of Filipino descent, had posed for photos for her website.

headline: Badgers Add to Streak, Shutting Down Rivals
text: MINNEAPOLIS — All week, Minnesota Coach Jerry Kill had warned his players about Wisconsin’s new-look defense. The 3-4 base installed by the defensive coordinator Dave Aranda, whom the first-year head coach Gary Andersen had brought with him from Utah State, made the Badgers unique in the Big Ten and even more formidable than usual, Kill said.

headline: Suspect Charged in Attack on Jewish Man in Brooklyn
text: An attack on a Jewish man in Brooklyn on Friday morning was not connected to the so-called Knockout Game, where assailants try to knock someone out with one punch, a lawyer for the man charged in the case said on Saturday. But prosecutors said the victim heard the suspect, Amrit Marajh, 28, of Brooklyn, and his friends talking about the game. During the altercation, prosecutors said, Mr. Marajh said to the victim, “I’ll knock you out.”

headline: West Looms as Knicks Keep Going South
text: WASHINGTON — Coach Mike Woodson spoke with Carmelo Anthony for a few minutes after Friday’s practice. There was no great significance to the meeting, according to Woodson, who always looks for opportunities to chat with his players. But with Anthony, who has endured more downs than ups this season, Woodson said he felt it was important “just to see where his head was.”

headline: Sleep Therapy Is Expected to Gain a Wider Role in Depression Treatment
text: An insomnia therapy that scientists just reported could double the effectiveness of depression treatment is not widely available nor particularly well understood by psychiatrists or the public. The American Board of Sleep Medicine has certified just 400 practitioners in the United States to administer it, and they are sparse, even in big cities.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) CAROL BURNETT: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Ms. Burnett, the 16th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony, taped Oct. 20. In addition to 11 years as the host and earlobe-tugging star of her CBS variety show, Ms. Burnett, above, has appeared in the films “Annie” and “Noises Off,” the television show “Glee” and the Broadway musical “Once Upon a Mattress.” She has also written three best sellers, including her autobiography “One More Time,” and received 12 People’s Choice Awards, eight Golden Globes, six Emmy Awards, a Horatio Alger Award, a Peabody Award and an Ace Award. She was also given the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President George W. Bush in 2006, was named a Kennedy Center honoree in 2003 and was inducted into the Television Hall of Fame in 1985. Among the friends and colleagues cheering her here are Julie Andrews, Lucie Arnaz, Tony Bennett, Tim Conway, Tina Fey, Rashida Jones, Vicki Lawrence, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Martin Short and Rosemary Watson. “I can’t believe I’m getting a humor prize from the Kennedy Center,” Ms. Burnett said when learned she would receive the distinction. “It’s almost impossible to be funnier than the people in Washington.”

headline: If Only the Pants Fit Right

headline: Japan Rejects China’s Claim to Air Rights Over Islands

headline: Patriotic Hold Music

After 35 minutes on hold, listening to “patriotic hold music“, the representative gave up.
