headline: Bid Farewell to Memories Forever Present
text: Like many an American of a certain age, Barbara Apple found herself on Friday trying to reconstruct exactly what happened on that Friday a half-century earlier when President John F. Kennedy was killed. Her tools of investigation weren’t copies of the Zapruder tapes or charts that graphed a bullet’s trajectory.

headline: My Lawn Guyland Roots Are Showing (Silly)
text: I see that some commentators were wondering why, in an earlier post, I wrote “pedal to the medal” instead of “pedal to the metal”. The answer is, typing fast, and writing what I heard in my head. The truth is that sometimes, usually when I’m tired, I do hear myself referring to a bottle of water as a boddle of oo-waugh-duh — gotta get the three-syllable pronunciation there.

headline: A Bandleader Pulls Teachable Moments From Afro-Latin Crosscurrents of Jazz
text: “Whoever told you mambo died in the 1950s hasn’t been paying attention,” Bobby Sanabria inveighed from behind a drum kit. He was closely surrounded by 18 other musicians. Directly behind him stood the singer and percussionist Hiram Remón. Inches to his right, sat the conga player Orestes Abrantes, wearing earplugs to protect himself against Mr. Sanabria’s crash cymbal.

headline: Jets’ Dreams Crash Into Harsh Reality in Loss to Ravens
text: BALTIMORE — Justin Tucker, the Ravens’ kicker, lined up for a 26-yard field goal Sunday. The snap was solid. The hold was, too. And when he booted the ball through the uprights, the scoreboard at M&T Bank Stadium might as well have flashed: “Ravens Win! Ravens Win!”

headline: Traveling With John Brown Along the Road to Literary Celebrity
text: James McBride was so sure that his novel “The Good Lord Bird” was not going to win the National Book Award that in the final moments before the prize was announced last Wednesday at a black-tie dinner in Manhattan, he barely looked up from his plate of apple mille-feuille.

headline: Bridging Playboy and Activist
text: The star of the new Hindi musical romance “Gori Tere Pyaar Mein,” Imran Khan, uncannily resembles a combination of Vince Vaughn and Cary Grant in his portrayal of the self-centered playboy, Sriram. With his classically handsome yet rounded face and his cocksure swagger, Mr. Khan seems to meld those two actors physically. The character he plays, an architect who is reminiscing to his fiancée (Shraddha Kapoor) about a past romance with a feisty activist named Dia (Kareena Kapoor, no relation to Shraddha), is also like Grant at his most roguishly charming and Mr. Vaughn at his most frustratingly caddish.

headline: Defying Conventional Wisdom at a Florida Regional
text: The axioms of the game are intended to guide less experienced players, although a primary reason bridge retains its worldwide appeal is that there are so many exceptions to these “rules.”

headline: Solemn Day Recalled by Strings and Heartstrings
text: DALLAS — One casualty of the cold front that swept through here on Thursday night was music.

headline: Meeting Village Ostracism With Repressed Rage
text: In the penultimate scene of Britten’s opera “Peter Grimes,” vengeance grips the townspeople of the Borough, a fishing village on the east coast of England. The strange, volatile Grimes, a fisherman and loner who disdains the gossipy talk of “interferers,” as he calls practically everyone, has disappeared, and there is no trace of the boy who had been working, miserably, as Grimes’s apprentice. The residents suspect that for the second time Grimes is responsible for the death of an apprentice. This is not just mob psychology. There are telltale clues: the boy’s jersey has washed ashore, and Grimes has a history of abuse.

headline: Graham Rarities Demonstrate Their Impact Beyond Explanations
text: In recent years, the Martha Graham Dance Company has made an effort to set the work of its founder in context with themed programming and spoken introductions. Sometimes helpful in offering entrances to forbidding and foreign-seeming terrain, these strategies also tend to focus attention on our distance from the context in which Graham’s work spoke for itself, our sad separation from the great artist who required no introduction.

headline: Knicks’ Chris Smith Starts Anew Amid Accusations of Nepotism
text: ERIE, Pa. — On the first shot of his professional basketball career, Chris Smith, the younger brother of J. R. Smith, took a handoff, squared up, dribbled left with a defender on his hip, elevated and fired. The ball clanged off the side of the rim. Beyond the hoop, two inflatable playhouses shook with children bouncing inside.

headline: For a Hero, Being Flat Can Have Its Advantages
text: A boy named Link has a sword, a shield and pounds of perseverance. In his world, no problem is unsolvable.

headline: ‘Catching Fire’ Wins at Weekend Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — The “Hunger Games” movie franchise became a full-fledged cultural phenomenon over the weekend, broadening its appeal by age and by gender with its second installment, and setting a November box-office record.

headline: Nets’ Lethargy Spreads: Even Boos Lack Vigor
text: Asked early Sunday afternoon to characterize the tone in the Nets’ organization, Billy King was succinct. “It’s frustration,” he said.

headline: Hercules and the Rival Studios
text: LOS ANGELES — A herculean custody battle is simmering in Hollywood.

headline: A Randy Royal in Britain Survived Mum’s Shadow
text: In her welcome new biography of Edward VII, who succeeded Queen Victoria on the British throne, Jane Ridley explains how this firstborn son managed to spend time in court — and not the kind of court royalty is supposed to frequent. Bertie, as this Prince of Wales was familiarly known for the first 59 years of his life, was a renowned crinoline chaser, and many efforts were made to keep his name out of matrimonial cases. Nevertheless, he ended up on the witness stand when Charles Mordaunt, who had been so angry at his wife for having male visitors that he shot her ponies, petitioned for divorce.

headline: Half Siblings Linked by a Mystery Father
text: Single mothers, happily married couples with sterile men, gay couples: They all turned to the California Cryobank in the early 1990s to buy what they couldn’t provide on their own. And they were successful, conceiving children with the sperm that came in the mail in an ice-cold tank.

headline: In Quest to Revive Goaltending Career, DiPietro Views Obscurity as an Ally
text: INDIAN TRAIL, N.C. — The Long Island mansion that Rick DiPietro bought in the heyday of his career with the Islanders is on the market. These days, he is downsizing. Home, for now, is a room at a Residence Inn in suburban Charlotte, N.C., a place where hockey is about as popular as surfing in Winnipeg.

headline: Mario Tries to Rescue His Console
text: I now have the brand-new Sony PlayStation 4 and Microsoft’s even newer Xbox One under my television set, but I spent the weekend with the Nintendo Wii U instead.

headline: Start of a Bumper Sticker
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you drive where I drive, you spend a lot of time sitting in bumper-to-bumper traffic, and the only decent reading material while you’re waiting to take your foot off the brake is often the rear bumper of the car ahead of you. That’s after you take note of the car owner’s family make up, which is prominently displayed on the window (Father sticker, mother sticker, various and sundry children and pets, etc.)

headline: Top Editor at Mental Floss Has Some Spicy Credentials
text: To the underpaid, well-educated magazine scribes hoping for a break in an industry with little growth opportunity, there is hope.

headline: Bloomberg’s Empire
text: The financial data and news company Bloomberg L.P. is three times as large as it was when Michael R. Bloomberg left to become mayor of New York City twelve years ago. As he prepares to leave office, the organization is at a crossroads.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Nov. 25
text: SHOPPING SEASON Thanksgiving week is one of the biggest and busiest weeks of the year for retailers. More than 139 million people shopped from Thursday through Sunday of Thanksgiving week last year, according to the National Retail Federation. Traditionally, the holiday shopping season begins on Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving, but this year many retailers will be open and offering deals on Thanksgiving Day, including Macy’s, J. C. Penney and Toys ‘R’ Us.

headline: Netanyahu on Nuclear Accord with Iran
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said his country was not bound by the nuclear deal between global powers and Iran.

headline: Iran’s Online Diplomacy Discomfits Israel
text: As Sweden’s foreign minister, Carl Bildt, noted in the wake of the interim deal on Iran’s nuclear program reached in Geneva on Saturday, the effort by Tehran’s negotiating team to explain and justify the country’s push for atomic energy behind closed doors was accompanied by a public diplomacy campaign conducted online.

In the Classroom, Learning for Today and Tomorrow

text: To the Editor:

headline: Merkel’s Quest for Consensus
text: BERLIN — More than two months after she triumphed in national elections, Chancellor Angela Merkel still has no new government. Even in a nation attuned to much political theater before dueling parties reach consensus, patience is wearing perilously thin.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Two of the West’s Best
text: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Grimm ‘Snow White’ Coming to Lincoln Center
text: The Joyce Theater Foundation plans to announce on Monday that it will present the New York premiere of “Snow White” with choreography by Angelin Preljocaj. Performed by Mr. Preljocaj’s French dance company, Ballet Preljocaj, and based on the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, not the 1937 animated Disney film, the production is scheduled for a six-performance run from April 23 to 27 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. Mr. Preljocaj recently choreographed a new work for the New York City Ballet and Ballet Preljocaj completed a run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music during its Next Wave Festival this month.

headline: Once Cable’s King, Malone Aims to Regain His Crown
text: John C. Malone made a fortune wiring American homes for cable television in the 1980s and 1990s. Known as the King of Cable, he sold TCI — once the country’s largest cable operator — to AT&T for $48 billion in 1999.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 25
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Shazam Deal Aims to Tie Songs Fast to Products
text: The choice of song has long been critical to a commercial’s success — think Volkswagen and Nick Drake’s “Pink Moon” back in 1999, or, more recently, Fiona Apple singing “Pure Imagination” in a stirring Chipotle ad.

headline: Triplets’ Arrival Was Joyful, but Also Strained Family
text: The story of Tiffany Knox-Floyd and Wendell Floyd began eight years ago, in a scene straight out of a romantic comedy.

headline: Iowa in the Amazon
text: A FEW years ago, one of my graduate students showed me a Google Earth image that changed my view of the world. On a photo showing all of South America, I could clearly see a single soybean farm in the Brazilian state of Mato Grosso. My first thought was that a farm that big, sitting on the edge of the Amazon, must be an environmental disaster. But when it comes to agricultural sustainability, all is not what it seems.

headline: The Weinstein Company, Seeking Hits, Shifts to TV
text: LOS ANGELES — As Oscar season approaches fever pitch, Harvey Weinstein, master of the movie awards game, is talking about ... television.

headline: The Untold Story of Military Sexual Assault
text: IT was 1974, and I was 19 years old, serving in the United States Air Force, and I thought I was the only one.

headline: Relaxing China’s One-Child Policy
text: The Chinese government announced that it will ease restrictions on the number of children couples can have.

headline: Fred Kavli, Benefactor of Science Prizes, Dies at 86
text: Fred Kavli, a physicist who left Norway for California as a young man and made millions manufacturing sensors for appliances, automobiles and aircraft, then late in life began donating much of his fortune to science, establishing a major prize he intended to rival the Nobel, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Life Inside a PlayStation
text: BUSAN, South Korea — In October 2012, my wife and I arrived in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bushwick and unpacked our suitcases. We had ended a two-year stay in New York and flown back to Korea in June, but returned to America for five weeks to promote the publication of my novel “Black Flower” in English.

headline: In Urban War for Peace and Quiet, Soundproofers Are Busier Than Ever
text: Erez Zohar was desperate. The neighbors’ air-conditioners outside his $1.2 million condo hummed and rattled around the clock through the summer and into the fall. His patio, larger than the living room, was unusable. Nights with the windows open were impossible.

headline: Whales and Anchovies
text: A spike in the anchovy population in California's Monterey Bay has made for exciting wildlife viewing as humpback whales, dolphins, sea lions and pelicans swarm to feed on the small fish.

headline: Developers Draft Casino Plans, Signaling Fight for New York’s Licenses
text: Aspiring casino developers are proposing ice-skating rinks and championship golf courses. They are promising fashionable restaurants and cocktail bars. And they are working to arrange the financing to pay for it all.

headline: Overlook the Value of Interns at Great Peril
text: Last week, The New York Post ran the kind of heart-rending article tabloids excel at. A young woman, new to New York, found herself pushed beyond what she could bear, forced to work by a big bad corporation for a compensation of exactly zero.

headline: Looking Into the Black Box
text: Here is something that might be worth selling your soul for: a magic black box that answers accurately any question you have about things to come. Who will be president in four years’ time? At what prices will the stock market close next Friday? What will be the precise position of the planets at midnight on that same day? When will I die?

headline: With Extra Anchovies, Deluxe Whale Watching
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — It began with the anchovies, miles and miles of them, their silvery blue bodies thick in the waters of Monterey Bay.

headline: Rake the Leaves? Some Towns Say Mow Them
text: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y. — They have been burned, blown into piles, raked into bags and generally scorned by homeowners everywhere. Fall leaves — so pretty on the trees, such a nuisance when they hit the ground — have long been a thing to be discarded. But now some suburban towns are asking residents to do something radical: Leave the leaves alone.

headline: Medicaid Expansion Faces Major Logistical Challenges Among the Homeless
text: CHICAGO — In a back room at the Franciscan House of Mary and Joseph, one of the largest homeless shelters in Chicago, a social worker named Sheena Ward guided Terry Cannon through a Medicaid application.

headline: Global Reach on Display as L.P.G.A. Ends Year
text: NAPLES, Fla. — The winner of the Titleholders on Sunday got to fire a cannon, but before Shanshan Feng of China did the honors, women’s golf sent a loud shot reverberating through the sports landscape.

headline: Drones Offer Journalists a Wider View
text: The best way to film the destruction wrought by Typhoon Haiyan in Tacloban, the Philippines, said Lewis Whyld, a British photographer, was from the air.

headline: As Legal Graffiti Walls Disappear, Street Artists Ponder Future
text: The masked artist hovering over the Bronx sidewalk is but a phantom. The cinder block wall on West Farms Road near East 172nd Street, which for years was a gallery of graffiti murals, is gone, too. It has been replaced by a blue wooden barrier festooned with demolition permits and a sign hawking “CHEAP DIVORCE.”

headline: Close Vote Raises Tensions in Honduras
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Honduras appeared headed toward days of political tension Sunday as the two leading candidates each declared they had won the presidency.

headline: In Bitcoin’s Orbit: Rival Virtual Currencies Vie for Acceptance
text: For many people, bitcoin seems like something from the day after tomorrow.

headline: Inmate Dies After Falling Down Stairs at Manhattan Court
text: After spending a month in custody on Rikers Island, Apolinar C. Solis arrived at the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building last Wednesday to appear before a judge on charges of drug possession.

headline: Popular Demand
text: According to Experian Marketing Services, shoppers anticipating Black Friday deals drove searches up 232 percent in the week that ended Nov. 16, compared with the same period in 2012.

headline: Bitcoin Believers
text: While regulators debate the pros and cons of bitcoins, this volatile digital currency inspires the question: What makes money, money?

headline: California, Here We Come?
text: It goes without saying that the rollout of Obamacare was an epic disaster. But what kind of disaster was it? Was it a failure of management, messing up the initial implementation of a fundamentally sound policy? Or was it a demonstration that the Affordable Care Act is inherently unworkable?

headline: How to Do Right by the Disabled
text: About a year ago the Senate fell five votes short of ratifying an international treaty that would improve protections for the disabled. It was an ignoble spectacle as the opponents rebuffed Bob Dole, a former colleague and disabled veteran, who came to the Senate floor to lobby for it. The Senate now has a chance to redeem itself.

headline: The Changing Mission
text: San Francisco's technology industry is booming. As housing costs increase some worry that the city's colorful neighborhoods, like the Mission, are at risk of losing their character.

headline: Bulls Bluffing Their Way Through the Loss of a Star
text: LOS ANGELES — Tom Thibodeau, who preaches toughness above all else, was not about to get out of character. So as he was asked to contemplate what life would be like for his basketball team without Derrick Rose — again — it did not require much thought.

headline: Signs of Change in News Mission at Bloomberg
text: Champagne flowed last Monday night as Hong Kong’s business elite gathered with top Bloomberg L.P. executives at a dinner for 100 guests at a cultural center in a former British colonial military complex.

headline: Little Rock Moves On
text: When the Supreme Court ordered an end to racial segregation in public schools in 1954, there was no foretelling what its mandate for integration “with all deliberate speed” would come to mean. In Little Rock, Ark., the site in 1957 of one of the most explosive desegregation struggles, it has come to mean decades of litigation that may now be nearing an end.

headline: Technology Boom Breeds Hostility
text: Resentment toward San Francisco’s tech workers has grown as many blame them for soaring housing prices and widening income disparities.

headline: Backlash by the Bay: Tech Riches Alter a City
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If there was a tipping point, a moment that crystallized the anger building here toward the so-called technorati for driving up housing prices and threatening the city’s bohemian identity, it came in response to a diatribe posted online in August by a young Internet entrepreneur.

headline: Under Pressure, N.C.A.A. Weighs Momentous Changes
text: After years of stalemate, uncertainty and bureaucratic delay, the N.C.A.A. is facing the possibility of seismic change on multiple fronts that could reshape the world of college sports.

headline: Conrad Susa, 78, Composer and Teacher, Dies
text: Conrad Susa, a composer for the voice, for the theater and for the operatic stage, where voice and theater converge, died on Nov. 21 at his home in San Francisco. He was 78.

headline: Sticking by a Murderous Brother, and Paying for It Dearly
text: BOSTON — For more than 40 years, power and influence fit William M. Bulger like a tailored suit, and his résumé expanded with accomplishment: up from the projects to become a lawyer, the longest-serving president of the State Senate, the president of the University of Massachusetts, a consummate Democratic power broker and a cultural lion in Boston.

headline: Nuclear Accord With Iran Opens Diplomatic Doors in the Mideast
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, whose popularity and second-term agenda have been ravaged by the chaotic rollout of the health care law, the preliminary nuclear deal reached with Iran on Sunday is more than a welcome change of subject.

headline: Getting to Yes With Iran
text: The interim nuclear deal between Iran and the major powers is an important step toward resolving the increasingly dangerous dispute over Iran’s progress on production of a nuclear weapon. President Obama and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran deserve credit for resisting fierce domestic opposition and a 30-year history of animosity between the two countries to get to this point.

headline: On Thanksgiving, Cooking Lessons for Life
text: On the first night, my father made chicken piccata. Flour and lemon, bouillon cubes, the funny-looking hammer. He had no idea what he was doing.

headline: Is It a Pollock?
text: A retired New York police detective used forensics to determine that a controversial painting is a Jackson Pollock work. Critics says science has its limits and cannot determine true authorship.

headline: A Real Pollock? On This, Art and Science Collide
text: For nearly 60 years, a small painting with swirls and splotches of red, black and silver has stood as a symbol of enmity between two women: Lee Krasner, Jackson Pollock’s widow, and Ruth Kligman, his lover.

headline: Giants’ Winning Streak Ends and Hopes Are Dented
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After losing their first six games of the season, the Giants attacked the next several weeks knowing there was little margin for error.

headline: Court Confronts Religious Rights of Corporations
text: WASHINGTON — Hobby Lobby, a chain of crafts stores, closes on Sundays, costing its owners millions but honoring their Christian faith.

headline: Less Than American
text: Not so long ago, it seemed the debate over immigration reform was all about borders. Politicians competed to offer the most draconian solutions — higher fences, longer fences, electrified fences, armies of guards, fleets of drones, moats and crocodiles. Never mind that the Border Patrol had already more than doubled in a decade. Never mind that many of those here illegally never hopped a fence but simply overstayed a student or tourist visa. The nativist mythology has us under siege from relentless hordes striding toward Arizona on, in the fevered imagination of Tea Party Congressman Steve King, “calves the size of cantaloupes because they’re hauling 75 pounds of marijuana across the desert.” To pacify the border neurotics, authors of the bill that passed the Senate last summer included $46.3 billion to militarize our southern flank.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 24, 2013
What We've Learned From Nafta
text: Has Nafta proved to be a success that the United States should try to replicate more widely or the type of trade agreement that should be avoided in the future?

headline: Peter B. Lewis, Philanthropist Who Led Progressive Auto Insurance, Dies at 80
text: Peter B. Lewis, who turned the 100-employee insurance firm co-founded by his father into one of the nation’s largest auto insurance companies, the Progressive Corporation, by insuring high-risk drivers and high-end sports cars, and who became an outspoken and sometimes quarrelsome supporter of liberal causes and the arts, died on Saturday at his home in Coconut Grove, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Welker Attends Bittersweet Reunion
text: In a matchup of Peyton Manning and Tom Brady, the undeniable story line at Gillette Stadium on Sunday night in the game between the Denver Broncos and the New England Patriots was the return of wide receiver Wes Welker.

headline: ‘No Man’s Land’ and ‘Waiting for Godot’
text: Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart star in new productions on Broadway.

headline: A Playwright’s Journey, Mapped From the Inside
text: The rough but fertile terrain from which August Wilson’s great body of work grew is explored in “How I Learned What I Learned,” a memoir in monologue written and originally performed by the playwright in 2003. It is now being delivered by Ruben Santiago-Hudson, an actor and director with long experience of Wilson’s plays.

headline: Filling the Existential Void
text: My, how they do go on, these two. In the absurdly enjoyable revivals of Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land” and Samuel Beckett’s “Waiting for Godot,” which opened in repertory on Sunday at the Cort Theater, Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart make a most persuasive case for conversation as both the liveliest and loneliest of arts.

headline: Photo Replay: Nov. 17-23
text: Reflecting on the duality of sports: We soar or stumble; it’s us versus them, elegant or humble. It ends with a win or loss (except when it’s a tie).

headline: An Illusion of Postseason Promise Heads for the Exits
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was eerily quiet inside a frigid MetLife Stadium on Sunday evening as the clock wound down to what felt like two seconds left in a largely confounding and now deflated season. Most fans stood and no doubt prayed for a Giants miracle, or one of those trademark Cowboys debacles. Some headed toward the exits rather than watch Dallas’s Dan Bailey line up for a 35-yard field goal.

headline: Sutton Foster to Star in Roundabout Theater Revival of ‘Violet’
text: Roundabout Theater Company may end up competing against itself in the Tony Award race for best musical revival this spring. Roundabout announced on Sunday that it would team up with several commercial producers to mount a Broadway run of the 1997 musical “Violet,” with Sutton Foster, a two-time Tony Award winner, starring as a disfigured woman on a journey to meet a televangelist faith healer.

headline: The Single-Payer Alternative
text: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: 家居| 第五大道上的宫殿
text: 室内设计师霍华德·斯拉特金让《纽约时报-国际生活》的萨拉·拉芬·科斯特洛参观了他在第五大道上宫殿似的公寓。

headline: Lifesaving Flu Drugs Fall in Use in Children
text: The flu can lead to serious complications, even death, in children, but relatively few studies have assessed the effectiveness of antiviral treatments in young patients hospitalized with the infection.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 12
text: Despite a late rally, the Giants missed an opportunity to advance in the N.F.C. East standings with their loss to the Cowboys.

headline: Word of the Day | undulate
text: undulate •\ˈən-jə-lət, ˈən-dyə-, ˈən-də-, -ˌlat\• verb

headline: In Report, 63% Back Way to Get Citizenship
text: A consistent and solid majority of Americans — 63 percent — crossing party and religious lines favors legislation to create a pathway to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally, while only 14 percent support legal residency with no option for citizenship, according a report published Monday by the nonpartisan Public Religion Research Institute.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 7:30 P.M. (Showtime 2) THE WOMAN IN THE FIFTH (2012) Tom Ricks (Ethan Hawke), an American writer down on his luck in Paris, embarks on a relationship with the enigmatic Margit (Kristin Scott Thomas, above with Mr. Hawke), who slinks up to him, lights a cigarette and announces that she was her husband’s muse in this psychological thriller directed by Pawel Pawlikowski. But can she help Tom, who has had writer’s block since the publication of his first book? “Although Mr. Pawlikowski often shows Mr. Hawke in medium and long shots, the actor draws you close,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “There’s anguish in Tom’s face that speaks of a terrible fragility and that leavens the story’s mysterioso proceedings with a real, recognizable humanity.” In “The Words” (2012), at 9, Dennis Quaid plays Clay Hammond, a successful author whose new novel tells the story of Rory Jansen (Bradley Cooper), a writer turned supervisor at a literary agency who comes upon an unsigned manuscript in a satchel that his wife (Zoë Saldana) gave him and decides to pass the work off as his own. And a star is born. Then an old man (Jeremy Irons) approaches Rory in Central Park and reveals his identity, and Rory’s eyes widen with alarm. Despite a compelling performance by Mr. Irons, this first feature film directed and written by Brian Klugman and Lee Sternthal “is a clever, entertaining yarn that doesn’t bear close scrutiny,” Stephen Holden wrote in The Times.

headline: Evacuation Questions After China Pipe Blast
text: A deadly explosion in the city of Qingdao came seven hours after initial reports of a leak in a crude pipeline, prompting some Chinese media outlets to ask why a more thorough evacuation had not been carried out. Those questions emerged as President Xi Jinping visited the coastal city to console people injured in the blast. He ordered a nationwide inspection of oil and gas pipelines and called on state-owned enterprises to ensure the safety of their projects.

headline: The Bard of the Tea Stall
text: NEW DELHI — Laxman Rao’s roadside tea stand in New Delhi sells the same items as most tea stalls in India, like various types of cookies, crispy fried snacks called namkeen and sweet milky tea. But Mr. Rao also offers something that most tea sellers, known as chai wallahs, do not – books that he has written and published himself.

headline: News Quiz | November 25, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: U.S. Embassy Stocks Up on Air Purifiers
text: Companies and institutions employing foreigners in China are starting to realize that to keep workers in the cities, they need to make changes to the way they operate. Based on anecdotal evidence, air pollution, more than anything else, is driving expatriate workers away from China, or dissuading those outside China from taking postings here. News reports of various rounds of  “airpocalypse” descending on Chinese cities have not helped.

headline: Ode to a New York Dawn
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Corrections: November 25, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Nov. 25, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Iran Agrees to Halt Its Nuclear Program
text: In “Accord Reached With Iran to Halt Nuclear Program,” Michael R. Gordon writes about the announcement.

headline: An Immigrant’s Dream, Detained
text: The Adelanto Detention Facility in California is designed like a federal prison, with cells, common areas and recreation centers. The 1,200-bed center keeps some detainees in “segregation cells,” for disciplinary reasons, and many of those are solitary confinement, where guards pass meals through openings in the bars.

headline: How Are You and Your Parents Alike and Different?
text: There is an old adage: the apple doesn’t fall too far from the tree. It suggests that children are a lot like their parents, or that they eventually end up with values and goals similar to their parents’.

headline: Courses Offer Help in Decoding the Third Plenum
text: Having trouble deciphering the Chinese Communist Party’s recently unveiled Third Plenum reform plan? You’re not alone.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 25 at 6 a.m.
text: Reactions to the Iran nuclear deal; C.S.I. meets Jackson Pollock; and a whale bonanza.

headline: India’s Negotiator Says Climate Treaty Talks ‘Partial Success’
text: WARSAW, Poland  — After more than 35 hours of continuous discussions, Ravi Shankar Prasad, one of India’s lead negotiators, described the United Nations climate change conference as “a partial success” for keeping the pathway open for a global climate treaty to be finalized in 2015.

headline: New York Today: Roots of Thanksgivukkah
text: Updated 12:18 p.m.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Mireille Silcoff on the Women Who Will Soar at the Olympics
text: Mireille Silcoff, a columnist for The National Post in Canada, wrote this week’s cover story about the U.S. Women’s Ski Jumping Team. Earlier this year she wrote for the magazine about how cool it is to be old.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: Protesters Raid Compound of Thai Finance Ministry
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters raided the compound of Thailand’s Finance Ministry and entered the grounds of the Foreign Ministry on Monday, in the latest escalation of a long-running battle between supporters and opponents of Thaksin Shinawatra, the billionaire former prime minister, whose party has a commanding majority in Parliament.

headline: Week 12 N.F.L. Quick Hits: Brady Wins Battle of Arm Strength in Wind
text: It was White Knuckle Sunday in the N.F.L. Seven games were decided in the final seconds. Or, technically, six games, as the Packers-Vikings contest was too close to be decided at all. But before going there, let’s start with the most anticipated and entertaining game of Week 12.

headline: Israel's Iran Dilemma
text: The era of traumatized alienation is over. The United States and Iran have embarked on a new phase in their relationship. It is marked by bilateral negotiations, handshakes, smiles, side-by-side flags and significant compromise, including United States acquiescence to a “mutually defined enrichment program” for Iran in any long-term agreement and an Iranian commitment that “under no circumstances” will it “ever seek or develop any nuclear weapons.”

headline: Love Canal: A Legacy of Doubt
text: Thirty-five years after Love Canal became a symbol of the dangers of toxic waste in residential neighborhoods, the legal and medical issues there are still playing out.

headline: Love Canal and Its Mixed Legacy
text: This week’s Retro Report video looks at the story that began 35 years ago when toxic chemicals leaking from an old landfill thrust a upstate New York community called Love Canal into the national headlines. Here, the environmental writer Andrew C. Revkin looks at the mixed legacy.

headline: Daily Report: Virtual Currencies Seek to Challenge Bitcoin
text: With mounting interest from prominent investors and growing acceptance from regulators, bitcoin — either the new gold or the next Dutch tulip craze, depending on who is being asked — is at the center of the virtual money universe. Yet there are dozens of digital alternatives, like PeerCoin, Litecoin and anoncoin, whose backers point to advantages they say their currencies have over bitcoin, Nathaniel Popper reports.

headline: Talks on Ending Syria’s Civil War to Begin in January
text: GENEVA — After months of delay, the United Nations said Monday that Syria’s government and the opposition would hold their first negotiations aimed at ending that country’s civil war in Geneva on Jan. 22. But the precise agenda for the negotiations, as well as a complete list of participants, remained unresolved.

headline: Casualties of Kashmir’s Unrest Live in the Dark
text: SRINAGAR — On an October afternoon I drove to Bemina, a middle-class area in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian-administered-Kashmir. An acquaintance led me to a spacious double-storied house to meet Hayat Ashraf Dar, 21, who is one of the numerous young men in Kashmir who have lost their eyesight after being fired at by the Indian troops and police with pellet guns. Most of the injured have lost one eye. Mr. Dar had lost both.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 25, 2013
text: Update: Nov. 26, 2013

headline: Seven Conclusions About Small-Business Health Insurance
text: In my recent posts, I have told the story of how I started to explore my options for renewing my insurance this year. It’s been my habit in writing for this blog to try to convey useful information, derived from my experience as an ordinary small-business owner, in the form of narrative episodes.

headline: Lending Practices at R.B.S. Condemned in Two Reports
text: LONDON — Royal Bank of Scotland, the British bank principally owned by the government, said on Monday that it had hired a law firm to examine its lending practices after government reports criticized its operations, including claims that it pushed some business clients into serious financial difficulties.

headline: Malone Aims to Shake Up Cable TV
text: John C. Malone, whose success wiring American homes for cable television in the 1980s and 1990s earned him the nickname King of Cable, is back on the prowl in the industry he helped create, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. Mr. Malone, 72, now the chairman of Liberty Media, is working behind the scenes to gain control of Time Warner Cable, the country’s second-largest cable operator by subscribers, behind Comcast.

headline: Revisiting Love Canal
text: I have a piece on the Booming blog of The Times looking back at the complicated environmental and political legacy of the Love Canal toxic waste site 35 years after state and federal officials declared an environmental emergency there. (Click on Google Maps to get the lay of the land.) My piece accompanies the latest video from Retro Report, a valuable new journalism project revisiting old stories to see which news elements held up, and which turned out to be unjustified. Here’s an excerpt and a link to the rest:

headline: Carlyle Raises $13 Billion for U.S. Buyouts
text: The Carlyle Group has a new $13 billion war chest for leveraged buyouts in the United States.

headline: Election Results in Nepal Signal a Political Right Turn
text: NEW DELHI — Nepal’s dominant Communist party was routed, the country’s politics swung sharply to the right and India’s influence in Nepal is likely to soar after the first set of results from last week’s election was finalized on Monday.

headline: Young and Uninsured, in Charts
text: Last week, the Census Bureau released some nice charts about the young and uninsured — that is, the folks that insurance companies are now falling over themselves to sign up because young people are cheap (and can be charged premiums higher than are actuarially fair in order to subsidize older people).

headline: Chrysler’s Stock Sale Is Delayed Until 2014
text: Chrysler will not move forward with an initial public offering until next year at the earliest, giving its parent company, Fiat, more time to negotiate the purchase of a 41.5 percent stake held by a union health care trust.

headline: Beastie Boys Fight Online Video Parody of ‘Girls’
text: Over a music career of more than 25 years, the Beastie Boys evolved from a goofy rap trio to a conscientious band with more nuanced positions on politics and art.

headline: Japan Answers China’s Warnings Over Islands’ Airspace
text: TOKYO — Matching China’s stern language with warnings of his own, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan vowed on Monday to defend his nation’s airspace after China declared an air defense zone over a disputed group of islands in the East China Sea.

headline: Couple Convicted of Murdering Teen Daughter and Domestic Help
text: NEW DELHI — A Noida couple were convicted on Monday of murdering their only child and their servant in a lurid case that has riveted the nation for the past five years.

headline: Nowhere Near The Exit
text: Dean Baker is annoyed with Greg Mankiw — not for the first time — for suggesting that the time for a Fed exit strategy may be drawing near. Dean focuses mainly on Greg’s use of what he considers a misleading wage number, but the problem runs deeper.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Closes Out History-Making Formula One Season
text: Sebastian Vettel ended the 2013 Formula One campaign in dominant fashion on Sunday at the season finale in Brazil, scoring a strong victory over his Red Bull Infiniti teammate, Mark Webber, and Ferrari’s Fernando Alonso. Vettel, 26, had already secured his fourth straight World Championship; Alonso was a distant runnerup in the points battle.

headline: Militia in Benghazi Flees After Deadly Gun Battle
text: CAIRO — A militia in Benghazi, Libya, tied to the killing of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens fled its headquarters on Monday after an hourslong gun battle with a local military unit, a potential turning point in a continuing struggle between Islamists and their foes for control of the city.

headline: Putin’s Dead Poets Society
text: MOSCOW — When President Vladimir Putin had finished talking, Tolstoy took the floor. He thanked Dostoyevsky, Lermontov, Sholokhov and Pasternak. Unfortunately, he said, Pushkin had fallen ill and could not fly in from his home in Belgium. “Pushkin is in the hall,” said Tolstoy, meaning that he was with them in spirit.

headline: The Reason Why
text: Terrific piece in the WaPo on how Kentucky’s rural poor are being helped by Kynect, the state’s version of Obamacare, which has had a picture-perfect rollout.

headline: ScienceTake: The Fungus Highway
text: One fungus, Neurospora crassa, has a highly efficient traffic system to spread nuclei among its filaments as it grows. Human highway designers, take note.

headline: 1963: Speech, Never Delivered, Stressed America’s Mission
text: DALLAS — President Kennedy died from an assassin’s bullets without being able to deliver his warning—that in today’s world, freedom could be lost without a shot being fired, by ballots as well as by bullets.

headline: What the Convertible Debt Boom Means for Bankruptcy
text: So the word is that convertible debt issuance is at a record high. On one level, that is totally predictable.

headline: New Law in Egypt Effectively Bans Street Protests
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-backed government has issued a law that all but bans street protests by applying jail time or heavy fines to the public demonstrations that have felled the last two presidents and regularly roiled the capital since the Arab Spring revolt.

headline: Food Matters | In Paris, Two Bourgeois Butchers Duke It Out for Steakhouse Supremacy
text: From couture to cuisine, Parisians have a passion for top-of-the-line everything, which now includes “haute boucherie.” Its two stars are Hugo Desnoyer and Yves-Marie Le Bourdonnec, who are duking it out for billing as the city’s best butcher. Desnoyer’s newest shop — his first to include an on-site table d’hôte with fabulous steaks and an extensive wine list — is housed in the same 16th Arrondissement building where he began his career 25 years ago, and he supplies some of the area’s most exalted chefs: Pascal Barbot and Pierre Gagnaire, whose restaurants both have three Michelin stars.

headline: Blackberry Chief Removes Some Top Executives
text: OTTAWA — In his first move since becoming acting chief executive of BlackBerry, John S. Chen has removed several senior executives at the troubled smartphone maker, the company said Monday.

headline: A Public Memorial for Julie Harris
text: The actress Julie Harris, who died on Aug. 24 at 87, will be remembered by colleagues and friends at a memorial celebration at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater,  242 West 45th Street, on Dec. 3 at noon.

headline: Times Names a New Editor of Video Content
text: Bruce Headlam, editor of the media desk at The New York Times since 2008, has been named managing editor of video content development. He will succeed Richard L. Berke, who recently left The Times to join Politico.

headline: At an SAC Parade Party, All Blown Up but Nowhere to Go
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — In finance, balloons are classic symbols of both growth and collapse. So when SAC Capital Advisors, the embattled hedge fund run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, sponsored a balloon-inflation party on Saturday in its hometown, Stamford, Conn., it was a particularly striking image.

headline: Apple Buys 3-D Sensor Company PrimeSense
text: Apple has purchased the motion sensor company PrimeSense, an Israeli firm that gained prominence from its early work on Microsoft’s Kinect.

headline: Mashed Potato and Broccoli Raab Pancakes
text: Use leftover mashed potatoes from Thanksgiving for these, or just steam up some potatoes and mash (that is what the nutritional values here are based on, not on your buttery leftover Thanksgiving mashed potatoes). Whichever way you go, the mixture is very quickly thrown together.

headline: Mashed Potato and Cabbage Pancakes
text: These have a sweet, comforting flavor. They are quick to mix up, using either leftover mashed potatoes from your Thanksgiving dinner, or potatoes that you have cut up and steamed for 20 minutes.

headline: Leek, Kale and Potato Latkes
text: I love the way the kale crisps when you fry these cumin-scented latkes.

headline: In Our Pages: November 26
text: 1888: Emperor Uses ‘I’ In Speech

headline: Gunman Scare at Yale Believed to Be a Hoax
text: NEW HAVEN — Yale University began the day Monday with a campus lockdown and swarms of law enforcement officials, but ended it with sighs of relief as reports of a gunman appeared to be a hoax.

headline: Sun, Rain and Sometimes Snow
text: Weather comparison for the past 11 Super Bowl sites and MetLife Stadium, site of this year’s Super Bowl.

headline: Breaking Down the Weather
text: Key weather statistics from 47 Super Bowls (data from the closest major airport).

headline: Image of the Day: November 25
text: State assembly elections in progress in the central state of Madhya Pradesh.

headline: F.D.A. Orders Genetic Testing Firm to Stop Selling DNA Analysis Service
text: In a crackdown on genetic testing that is offered directly to consumers, the Food and Drug Administration has demanded that 23andMe immediately cease selling and marketing its DNA testing service until it receives clearance from the agency.

headline: Russia May Seek to Reclaim Rachmaninoff Estate
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has ordered his government to look into buying the archive and Swiss estate of the emigre composer and pianist Sergei Rachmaninoff, continuing an effort to reclaim and repatriate Russian cultural legacy.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 25 at 12 p.m.
text: Syrian peace talks announced; drones for journalists; and the fungus highway.

headline: Obama Signals a Shift From Military Might to Diplomacy
text: WASHINGTON — The weekend ended with the first tangible sign of a nuclear deal with Iran, after more than three decades of hostility. Then on Monday came the announcement that a conference will convene in January to try to broker an end to the civil war in Syria.

headline: The New York Times Minute
text: In the Video

headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet 2013
text: This year several celebrities wore pieces straight off the runway including Rihanna in Jean Paul Gaultier couture and Lady Gaga in Versace.

headline: Gold Bars
text: This week’s puzzle was created at the Unsolved K-12 Conference, a recent event focused on identifying 13 unsolved problems in mathematics (one problem for each grade) that could be used to spur creative thinking and collaboration in elementary school math education. (The conference was held Nov. 15-17 in Banff, Alberta.) The puzzle, which was created by conference participants and edited by frequent Numberplay contributor Joshua Zucker, is the following:

headline: Listen Up | In the California Desert, a One-of-a-Kind Music Venue Blossoms
text: Ten years since taking over a desert saloon in Pioneertown, Calif., two New Yorkers have transformed it into an oasis of indie rock and a breeding ground for music stars.

headline: American Dreamer on 42nd Street Who Fled From a Deal
text: A four-story white stucco building, with its fire escapes painted baby blue crisscrossing the windows set in lemon-yellow sills, stands stubbornly at the western end of 42nd Street.

headline: The Battles of Chattanooga
text: For the North, the autumn of 1863 was a season of shattered hopes. The fall of Vicksburg and victory at Gettysburg in July had raised expectations of an end to the war before the New Year. But the Army of the Potomac had not followed up on its success, and Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant saw his army carved up to support peripheral operations. Then in September, Gen. Braxton Bragg’s Army of Tennessee defeated the Army of the Cumberland at Chickamauga, 12 miles southeast of Chattanooga, Tenn., stopping the North’s progress toward Atlanta.

headline: The Health Care ‘Distraction’ Conspiracy
text: Two things happened last week that had nothing to do with the Affordable Care Act. This, Republicans say, is proof of a devious Democratic conspiracy to distract the American people from the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Monty Python Reunion Adds Four More Shows
text: The 20,000 tickets to Monty Python’s reunion show at the O2 Arena in London, scheduled for July 1, were snapped up in just under 45 seconds — faster than an exasperating debate at the comedy troupe’s argument clinic — the show’s organizers told the BBC on Monday. They also announced that the run would be extended.

headline: When Good People Do Bad Things
text: At the sentencing hearing for Kareem Serageldin, a former senior executive at Credit Suisse, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Federal District Court in Manhattan pointedly asked why someone in such a position would engage in misconduct. As DealBook reported, the judge asked, “Why do so many good people do bad things?”

headline: Leaving ABC News, Couric Describes Move to Yahoo as ‘Being of the Moment’
text: Yahoo announced on Monday that it had signed the longtime network news star Katie Couric for a new position as the “global anchor” of its still-formative news operation.

headline: Sure-Footed Real Salt Lake Reaches M.L.S. Final
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Real Salt Lake’s players and coaches climbed atop a small makeshift stage at midfield for a trophy celebration after dispatching the Portland Timbers in Sunday’s M.L.S. Western Conference final. A machine sprayed red confetti in the air.

headline: Obama’s Visiting Security Adviser Tells Karzai to Sign Agreement
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Monday to stop his delay in signing a security agreement or potentially face the complete and final pullout of American troops by the end of 2014, according to American and Afghan officials.

headline: New Springsteen Album Coming in January
text: The drill for rock stars usually goes like this: record an album’s worth of new material and release it, then take the songs on tour, recording the shows for what, these days, is the inevitable live album. Bruce Springsteen has been tinkering with that formula in recent months, making new studio recordings of songs that have been part of his stage set for ages but were never released on studio albums. The result, “High Hopes,” is due out on Columbia on Jan. 14. He announced the album on Twitter on Sunday evening.

headline: A Succession at Walmart Puts an Insider at the Helm
text: As Walmart enters a fiercely competitive holiday season while still hampered by sluggish sales, the company’s board announced on Monday that Michael T. Duke, its chief executive, would retire early next year and a longtime executive, C. Douglas McMillon, would replace him.

headline: Government Abuse Drives Eritreans to Flee, U.N. Says
text: GENEVA — Severe government abuse, not harsh living conditions, is driving thousands of Eritreans to flee their country every month and risk their lives trying, often by precarious means, to reach other countries, a United Nations investigator said Monday. Her assertion puts a spotlight on an exodus that resulted in tragedy last month when hundreds of migrants, many of them Eritreans, drowned as they tried to cross the Mediterranean to Italy.

headline: Why a Times Photo Remains Online After Criticism
text: After I wrote last week about a photograph of a Palestinian mother, many readers and many other observers complained that – since two senior editors agreed it was not a good choice for dominant art with the story about an Israeli soldier’s death – it was wrong for The Times to not remove the photo online.

headline: Video: Testing the Ford Fiesta, a Small Car With Large Ambitions
text: For those who simply want a basic transportation appliance for commuting and grocery getting, Ford’s refreshed 2014 Fiesta is not the usual cheap and cheerful economy car. If you navigate the maze of competitors, models and available features, you may find that the Fiesta is often a more expensive set of wheels in a category where a couple hundred dollars makes a real difference. The roomier Nissan Versa Note is a full $600 less. For newlyweds, that’s a couple of rooms of IKEA furniture.

headline: For Kidd, Being a Player Was a Lot Easier
text: Jason Kidd had dribbled up and down N.B.A. courts for two decades when he opted to join the Knicks last year at age 39.

headline: Standard & Poor’s Ratings Names New President
text: A Citigroup executive has been named president of Standard & Poor’s Ratings Service.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Aesop Intensity Kit
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Basketball Bulletin, Updated: Both Ships Be Sinking
text: So, how many Knicks or Nets fans can honestly say they saw this coming?

headline: Making a Scene
text: The actors who gave the year’s best performances star in one-line films created by the Oscar-winning cinematographer Janusz Kaminski.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Jeremy Arnon joined ActionX, New York, in a new post, vice president for advertising sales. He had been running his own company, Moment Zero, and before that was at Google and Apple.

headline: In Time for Thanksgiving, Storm System Heads East
text: A storm system that has caused at least eight deaths across the West and Midwest is headed east and expected to bring snow, rain and strong winds that may disrupt Thanksgiving travel over a large area of the country, forecasters said Monday.

headline: If You Love Your Art, Ads Declare, Set It Free
text: Efforts by a commercial real estate company to support the arts are going online to observe 25 years of cultural initiatives, with a campaign that encourages artists to share their work digitally.

headline: Inquiry in Cover-Up of Ohio Rape Yields Indictment of Four Adults
text: Four adults in the school system of Steubenville, Ohio, including the superintendent, were indicted Monday by a grand jury looking into the cover-up of a rape that drew national attention and outrage because students recorded it on social media but did not alert the authorities.

headline: What We Do Now When We’re Not Watching Movies
text: A graphic analysis.

headline: The Unforgettables
text: 11 actors who gave defining performances this year, 14 top screenwriters and one legendary filmmaker create a portfolio of cinematic moments.

headline: Did This Movie Have to Be a Movie?
text: Or would it have worked just as well as a series or webisodes?

headline: The Big Picture Strikes Back
text: Like a character who develops a discreet but noticeable cough at the end of the first act, the movies have been dying for a long time. The latest chapter in their decline — which began, depending on who is telling the story, with the introduction of sound, the rise of television, the fall of the old studios, the spread of home video or the arrival of the Internet — was written earlier this year.

headline: Lights, Camera and, for the First Time, Dialogue
text: Movies exist, above all, to exalt the human face, and movie stars are people whose faces possess the mysterious power to make us look at them and want to keep looking. This is less a matter of beauty or of sexual magnetism than of individuality, of specialness. We like watching them pretend partly because we think we can see through the disguise. Their particular, paradoxical art is to bring credibility to the artifice. They are always themselves, even as their identities change from one role to the next. Seeing is believing.

headline: 5 Movies You Need(ed) to See in Theaters
text: As I argue in this year’s Movies Issue, sometimes the theater experience is irreplaceable. These five movies are proof.

headline: In Myanmar, Newly Free Media Struggle to Turn a Profit
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s journalists celebrated this year when the government lifted a five-decade ban on private newspapers.

headline: New Left-Wing Party in Honduras Cries Foul
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Nine dejected foot soldiers of a would-be revolution were sitting on the stoop of a local campaign headquarters in the Colonia Kennedy neighborhood on Monday afternoon, drinking soda out of small plastic cups and debating what comes next.

headline: Stroke Identified as Cause of Chef Trotter’s Death
text: The chef Charlie Trotter died of a stroke linked to high blood pressure, a medical examiner’s report on his death earlier this month has found.

headline: Oil Prices Dip on Iran Deal, but Exports May Not Rise
text: LONDON — Oil prices dipped and stocks around the world rose on Monday after the news of an agreement to temporarily freeze Iran’s nuclear program, but few specialists expected any significant change to consumer energy prices, at least in the short term.

headline: A Top Nasdaq Executive Steps Down
text: Updated, 4:15 p.m. | One of the top executives at Nasdaq OMX, Eric Noll, is leaving the company to lead the brokerage firm ConvergEx Group.

headline: Liz Cheney’s New Ad
text: Last week, the Cheney family erupted in a public spat over gay marriage. It started with Mary Cheney, who is a lesbian, criticizing her sister, Liz Cheney, who is running for a Senate seat in Wyoming and opposes same-sex marriage. Then Dick Cheney, the former vice president, and his wife jumped into the fray, defending “Liz’s many kindnesses.”

headline: Walkabout: Medellin, Reimagined; The New ‘Longest Flight in the World’
text: Medellin, the city once known as the murder capital of the world and home to cartel boss Pablo Escobar, has undergone a decade-long campaign to soften its image and appeal to travelers. The urban renewal has not only cut down on crime, but led to several inventive strides in architecture, technology, fashion and, of course, night life. (Bloomberg)

headline: Posters Elicit German Tips Concerning Nazi Crimes
text: BERLIN — A poster campaign by the Simon Wiesenthal Center intended to identify aging Germans who might have participated in Nazi crimes has yielded information about four people, including a woman who might have been a guard at Auschwitz, that has been passed to the authorities for further investigation, the group said Monday.

headline: Revisiting Kevin O’Leary and the Cash Advance Industry
text: My recent blog post about Kevin O’Leary’s investment in Total Merchant Resources — an alternative lender that charges high interest rates in return for quick access to capital — brought a response from Sean Murray, chief executive of Merchant Processing Resource. In his comment, Mr. Murray suggested that I yearn “for the glory days of 10-year loans at 8 percent interest for local mom and pop shops.” Mr. Murray, who says on his LinkedIn profile that he has been responsible for placing more than $100 million in loans to small businesses, went on to defend the merchant cash advance industry.

headline: New Study Finds U.S. Has Greatly Underestimated Methane Emissions
text: Updated, 3:53 p.m. | A comprehensive new study of atmospheric levels of methane, an important greenhouse gas released by leaky oil and gas operations and livestock, has found much higher levels over the United States than those estimated by the Environmental Protection Agency and an international greenhouse gas monitoring effort. The paper, “Anthropogenic emissions of methane in the United States,” is being published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: Whooping Cough Study May Offer Clue on Surge
text: Baboons vaccinated against whooping cough could still carry the illness in their throats and spread it, research published in a science journal on Monday has found. The surprising new finding has not been replicated in people, but scientists say it may provide an important clue to a puzzling spike in the incidence of whooping cough across the country, which reached a 50-year high last year.

headline: Cutting Through Financial Noise to a Well-Balanced Portfolio
text: It’s a noisy world for investors. Whether it is the debate about when the Federal Reserve will taper its bond purchasing or what it means if the Dow pushes past the 16,000 mark, it’s easy to get caught up in the noise and think our best bet is to react to the news as it comes. Who needs a plan? Just follow the ticker tape at the bottom of the TV screen.

headline: Chilling Look at Newtown Killer, but No ‘Why’
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — Adam Lanza spent the final months of his life mostly alone in his bedroom. His windows were covered with black trash bags. He was preoccupied with violent video games and created a spreadsheet of some of the worst massacres in American history.

headline: State’s Attorney’s Report on Sandy Hook Elementary School Shootings
text: Read the official public report on the Dec. 14, 2012, rampage in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Country Singer Dies After Nashville Bar Brawl
text: It was an unusually rough weekend for country music. An after-hours bar brawl in Nashville on Saturday left the singer and guitarist Wayne Mills dead of a gunshot wound to the head. And members of Willie Nelson’s band, including his longtime drummer, Paul English, were injured when the band’s tour bus crashed into an overpass pillar on a highway near Sulphur Springs, Tex., also in the wee hours of Saturday.

headline: In Delay of Chrysler I.P.O., Fiat May Have Gained Upper Hand
text: Fiat may have slipped into the driver’s seat. An autoworkers’ fund that owns 41.5 percent of Chrysler has been pushing for an initial public offering of the company as part of talks with its Italian partner. Chrysler’s board has decided to delay the stock sale until next year, suggesting Fiat’s negotiating position has improved.

headline: The Read Around: Bill Bryson
text: Bill Bryson, the author of “One Summer: America, 1927,” talks about his “intense desire to go out and see more of the world.”

headline: Microbes May Add Special Something to Wines
text: Terroir is a concept at the heart of French winemaking, but one so mysterious that the word has no English counterpart. It denotes the holistic combination of soil, geology, climate and local grape-growing practices that make each region’s wine unique.

headline: In Store | In London, a Cult Fashion Boutique With Lofty Aspirations
text: Since opening in 2010 in a Victorian building on Redchurch Street in London’s Shoreditch district, the men’s wear boutique Hostem has become a favorite for its bold, deconstructed offerings from designers like Ann Demeulemeester, Rick Owens and Visvim, as well as its striking, somewhat Dickensian interiors. Earlier this year, the store expanded into the basement to open its Chalk Room, designed by the local artists James Russell and Hannah Plumb (a.k.a. JamesPlumb), who created a series of haunting assemblages to showcase bespoke pieces by the likes of the avant-garde tailor Geoffrey B. Small and the luggage company Globe-Trotter.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 19-25, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: A Holocaust Opera Is Coming to New York
text: “The Passenger” will make its belated arrival in New York this summer, when the Lincoln Center Festival and the Park Avenue Armory present Mieczyslaw Weinberg’s 1968 opera about the Holocaust, which was not performed during his lifetime.

headline: Heart Attack Pain Similar for Men and Women
text: Women are more likely than men to die after a heart attack, and some researchers have suggested a reason: Doctors may be misdiagnosing women more often because their symptoms differ from those experienced by men.

headline: Jones Energy Buys Assets in Anadarko Basin
text: Jones Energy, an oil and gas company with a $1.3 billion market value, is buying about $200 million worth of producing and undeveloped fields in Texas and Oklahoma from a private seller, according to people briefed on the transaction.

headline: M.L.S. and Red Bulls Release 2014 Schedule
text: For the first time, Major League Soccer has announced the schedule for its next season before the completion of its current one.

headline: Less Need to Worry About Inflation
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: November 22-24, 2013
text: The images are jarring: a young father hoisting his baby son heavenward, an HK45 semi-automatic pistol holstered to his hip. A 16-year-old girl, blond and angelic, posing with her handgun. A couple and their six children, at least two of whom are visibly packing heat.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Libya, Thailand, Ukraine and Indonesia.

headline: Soon, Obamacare Will Become Benghazi
text: OK, I just created an Obamacare account for myself (if I broke any laws, please, it was just investigative journalism). I went all the way through the process at healthcare.gov, stopping before the final step of actually applying (I don’t qualify, of course, because Princeton provides insurance), just to see how hard it was. And the answer is that it was no problem at all, with no delays.

headline: Client Conflicts Undermine Planned Merger of 2 Law Firms
text: The biggest proposed law firm merger of the year has collapsed.

headline: The Read Around: Bill Bryson
text: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Below, Bill Bryson, the author of “A Walk in the Woods” and, most recently, “One Summer: America, 1927,” talks about getting work done on planes, his “intense desire to go out and see more of the world” and the one subject “no one wants me to write a book about — readers or publishers or anyone.”

headline: Albums From Destroyer, Kellie Pickler and Danielle Bradbery
text: DANIELLE BRADBERY

headline: Christmas Abbott’s Nascar Workout
text: Workout tips from a Nascar pit crew member and gym owner.

headline: The Workout: A Woman in Nascar
text: If you don’t think auto racing is a physically demanding sport, just ask a member of a team’s pit crew. This high-stakes job requires strength, speed and precision, as workers change 90-pound tires in a matter of seconds. We asked Christmas Abbott, 32 and one of the first women to become a full-time member of a Nascar crew, to take us through the pit crew workout.

headline: Scene City: Auction Fever Continues for Bono’s (Red) Charity
text: Jonathan Ive and Marc Newson teamed up for a design auction at Sotheby’s.

headline: The Happy Results of a Speedy Shift
text: LOS ANGELES — Who knew that the star of Mozart’s “The Magic Flute” could be a gangly black cat? In the Los Angeles Opera’s irresistible new production, which opened on Saturday at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion here, the mischievous bird catcher Papageno has traded feathers for a feline that leaps from tree to tree, fends off angry dogs and gets captured in a bell jar, radiating charisma all the while.

headline: A Company-Worthy Ginger Cake with Molasses and Stout
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Death Interrupted, Just by Making a Phone Call
text: It always causes a stab of panic — that moment when you’re watching a show, and a cellphone goes off. Could it be yours? During an otherwise silent moment in the Ballet Hispanico performance at the Apollo Theater on Saturday, a phone in the audience kept ringing, and Mario Ismael Espinoza, his face painted like a skull from the Mexican Day of the Dead, stopped dancing to hiss in its direction. How awkward.

headline: For a Professor, a Messy Affair
text: Robert Stone’s fast-paced new novel, “Death of the Black-Haired Girl,” does not take place in one of those hot, volatile places (Vietnam or Central America or the Middle East) where so many of his earlier characters sought adventure, oblivion or redemption. It takes place in a small New England town, where history is more personal than political.

headline: Gallery | Why Grannies Make the Best Fashion Models
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Clouds Gather on the Lake
text: The forecast is distinctly cloudy along the shores of Lake Erie, at least for the visitors from Buffalo in A. R. Gurney’s newest play, “Family Furniture,” which opened on Sunday night at the Flea Theater. In this tender, sepia-toned play about a traumatic passage in the lives of a tight-knit, well-bred clan — the latest in a long series of plays by Mr. Gurney detailing the manners and mores of the social milieu he was raised in — a sense of dangerous change seems to hang threateningly in the atmosphere, like a thunderstorm that just won’t burst.

headline: Not So Fast: Italian Church Is Halted on Its Way to PS1
text: It was a typically elaborate, provocative move by the Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli in a career full of them: He had contracted to buy the ruins of an old deconsecrated church in the southern Italian town of Montegiordano and had planned to ship them to New York, brick by brick, for exhibition in the courtyard of MoMA PS1. His videos would be shown inside.

headline: 14 Screenwriters Writing
text: Screenwriters famously get no respect. It probably doesn’t help that one of the most famous quotes about the trade boils down to money, competition and idiots. Herman J. Mankiewicz, in an often-cited telegram sent from Hollywood to his fellow writer Ben Hecht, promised: “Millions are to be grabbed out here, and your only competition is idiots. Don’t let this get around.”

headline: A Wink Toward Tradition in a Modern Evening
text: Successful entrepreneurs know that there’s an art to naming a new venture. You need to get your point across quickly, clearly and with nuance. Beth Morrison and Paola Prestini, the impresarios behind 21c Liederabend, nailed this straightaway when they started the biennial performance series in 2009: “21c” proclaims modernity. “Liederabend,” a 19th-century German term meaning “song night,” labels the package neatly, while hinting at Romantic notions of intimacy and literary depth.

headline: Flea Theater To Open Three-Stage Complex
text: The Flea Theater in Lower Manhattan plans to break ground Dec. 5 on an $18.5 million theater complex at 20 Thomas Street that will include three theaters along with offices and costume and scene shops.

headline: Distant Cousins, Conferring in Different Dialects
text: Jazz and Pakistani music aren’t complete strangers to each other, as long as you relate Pakistani music to the rest of South Asian music. Think about John Coltrane playing “India” in 1961, and consider that some of the most promising or accomplished improvisers in the United States today — Vijay Iyer, Rudresh Mahanthappa, Rafiq Bhatia and the Karachi-born Rez Abbasi, for instance — come from South Asian families. But musicians living in Pakistan and playing jazz, or something like it: that’s rarer.

headline: An Author Dives Into Pink Floyd
text: In his 2006 hit play, “Rock ’n’ Roll,” the British playwright Tom Stoppard examined the relationship between music and politics, shuttling back and forth between England and Czechoslovakia over a 25-year period. Now, in a new work, a one-hour radio play called “Darkside,” he has narrowed his focus to a single famous album, Pink Floyd’s “The Dark Side of the Moon.”

headline: Control and Nuance, With a Brazilian Flavor
text: The Brazilian pianist Nelson Freire often includes works by his compatriot Villa-Lobos in his programs. After an enthusiastically received performance at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, part of Lincoln Center’s Great Performers series, he offered Villa-Lobos’s “A lenda do caboclo” as an encore, as well as a poetic rendition of Chopin’s Nocturne in D flat (Op. 27, No. 2).

headline: For Young Ensembles, an Entrepreneur and an Audience
text: Welcoming the audience from the Zankel Hall stage brightly on Wednesday night, the composer David Lang said that when Carnegie Hall presented him with a range of possible activities to undertake as the newest holder of its Debs Composers Chair, he had responded that he wanted to do them all.

headline: In Performance: ‘Regular Singing’
text: Jon DeVries and Maryann Plunkett in “Regular Singing,” the final Apple Family play, set on the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy.

headline: Management Shake-Up at Concert Promoter A.E.G. Live
text: In a management shake-up at the world’s second-largest concert promoter, A.E.G. Live has parted ways with its longtime chief executive, Randy Phillips.

text: In the Video

headline: The Wayser-Schulte Family
text: The Schulte-Wayser family is both modern and traditional at the same time.

headline: The Indrakrishnan Family
text: The family of Dr. Indran Indrakrishnan is part of America’s fastest-growing immigrant population, Asian-Americans.

headline: The Glusac Family
text: Numerically, Srdan and Jan Glusac of Los Angeles, with their two children, add up to a typical middle-class family, but their lives tell a richer story.

headline: The Perez Family
text: Despite the instability of family life among the working class and the poor, Julian Hill, 39, and Ana Perez, 34, have stayed together for six years.

headline: In Store | Billy Reid Brings Easy Style to the Big Easy
text: New Orleans is an excellent destination for food and drink, but finding a stylish frock there can be like tracking down ripe tomatoes out of season. The newest Billy Reid shop, nestled among a cluster of antiques stores on a charming corner of Magazine Street, aims to fix that. “There’s a palpable energy in this town right now,” the fashion designer explained between sips of a bourbon cocktail and bites of duck liver pâté at the store’s opening party last weekend. “There are just a lot of positive vibes here.” The New Orleans store is his 10th to open in 9 years, joining locations in Nashville, Atlanta, Austin and New York.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 25 at 6 p.m.
text: The Newtown police report; Katie Couric moves to Yahoo; and famous actors make tiny films.

headline: In Performance: ‘Sorry’
text: Sally Murphy in “Sorry,” the third work in The Apple Family Plays cycle.

headline: In Performance: ‘Sweet and Sad’
text: Jay O. Sanders and Stephen Kunken perform a scene from the second in Richard Nelson’s Apple Family cycle.

headline: In Performance: ‘That Hopey Changey Thing’
text: Laila Robins and Jay O. Sanders perform a scene from the first in Richard Nelson’s Apple Family cycle of plays.
