text: Scenes from the four works in Richard Nelson’s Apple Family cycle of plays at the Public Theater.

headline: The Scene Behind the Scenes
text: Photographs from the making of the magazine’s 2013 Movies Issue.

headline: For Apple, 3-D Sensors Have Potential Beyond TV
text: Apple over the weekend confirmed its acquisition of PrimeSense, a 3-D sensor company that could help Apple unlock new applications for devices in the living room and beyond.

headline: Bringing Up the Modern American Family
text: The makeup of the American family is changing. This week report on one aspect of that change: marriage.

headline: Radiation Cleanup at Park on Staten Island to Take Years
text: The first sign that something was amiss at Great Kills Park, on Staten Island, came in 2005 when a police flyover of New York City detected a positive reading for radioactive material there.

headline: Storm Threatens to ‘Clobber’ Thanksgiving Travel Plans
text: Updated 11:05 a.m., Tuesday A powerful storm blamed for at least 12 deaths in Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and California since late last week is moving up the East Coast, threatening to disrupt Thanksgiving holiday travel plans for drivers and travelers at some of the nation’s busiest airports.

headline: Egyptians Vow to Fight New Protest Ban
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, the military-backed government that came to power in Egypt after mass demonstrations issued a new law that effectively banned mass demonstrations on Sunday.

headline: Summary of Sandy Hook Shooting Phone Calls and Emergency Response
text: A breakdown of the day’s events by time, including excerpts of 911 calls and radio transmissions on Dec. 14, 2012.

headline: Why Care About the N.S.A.?
text: A short film explores whether ordinary Americans should be concerned about online surveillance.

headline: Philadelphia Contractor Is Charged in Fatal Building Collapse
text: A Philadelphia building contractor was charged with murder on Monday in connection with a building collapse in June that killed six people and injured 13 others, the Philadelphia district attorney’s office said.

headline: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 23 People
text: A series of bombings and shootings on Monday left at least 23 people dead and more than 20 wounded, Iraqi security officials and medical workers said. Just after sunset, an explosion at a market in central Baghdad killed 12 people, the police said. Earlier, a suicide bomber attacked a police checkpoint north of Baghdad, killing three police officers and two civilians. South of Baghdad, two militia members were killed by a roadside bomb. Another militia member was killed by a bomb attached to his car in Salahuddin Province, north of Baghdad, while a roadside bomb near a high school in the region killed a woman. In Baghdad, a bomb blew up a truck driver and gunmen killed a Ministry of Justice employee. More than 300 Iraqis have been killed this month in similar attacks.

headline: The Heartbreaker That is Tony Romo
text: The Cowboys quarterback has the team in position to make the playoffs. But William C. Rhoden notes that history tells us Tony Romo will eventually disappoint Dallas fans.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: The Heartbreaker That Is Tony Romo
text: The Cowboys quarterback has the team in position to make the playoffs. But history tells us Tony Romo will eventually disappoint Dallas fans.

headline: Ten Former N.H.L. Players Sue League Over Head Injuries
text: Ten former N.H.L. players sued the league Monday for negligence and fraud, saying the sport’s officials should have done more to address head injuries but instead celebrated a culture of speed and violence.

headline: The Vatican: Putin Meets the Pope
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with Pope Francis in the Vatican on Monday, and their first encounter was primarily focused on the Middle East. They emphasized “the need to bring an end to the violence” in Syria, ensuring humanitarian assistance to Syrians affected by the fighting while seeking ways to find a “peaceful solution to the conflict,” the Vatican said in a statement. They also touched on “the life of the Catholic community in Russia,” according to the Vatican, but the Holy See spokesman, the Rev. Federico Lombardi, said that the “ecumenical question” between the Roman Catholic and Orthodox Churches, whose relationship has been tense since the two churches divided nearly 1,000 years ago, was not discussed.

headline: ‘Why Care About the N.S.A.?’
text: Like many Americans and people around the world, I was deeply disturbed to hear the revelations of Edward Snowden about N.S.A. surveillance, which is an affront to the United States Bill of Rights. But as a filmmaker who has made a number of documentaries about technology and online activism, I can’t say that Snowden’s revelations came as a surprise. Some concerned citizens have long understood that powerful digital technologies can be abused to carve away at civil liberties.

headline: Report Retraces Six Minutes of Horror, and Every Step a Gunman Took
text: At 9:30 a.m. on Dec. 14, in Room 9 of Sandy Hook Elementary School, the principal, psychologist, and other staff members had gathered for a meeting about student placement.

headline: Suit Accuses Rikers Officers of Illegal Strike
text: Lawyers for New York City filed a lawsuit on Monday against the correction officers’ union, accusing it of an illegal strike last week that prevented hundreds of inmates on Rikers Island from reaching court.

headline: Jean Banchet, Chef Who Translated French Cuisine, Dies at 72
text: Jean Banchet, a dashing chef whose traditional French cooking helped make the Chicago suburbs a global destination for food lovers in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Sunday at his home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Virginia: Democrat Certified as Attorney General
text: Mark R. Herring, a Democrat, was certified by the State Board of Elections as Virginia’s next attorney general on Monday, but he may face a recount in a race he won by just 165 votes out of 2.2 million cast. Both Mr. Herring and his Republican opponent, Mark D. Obenshain, have formed transition committees. Mr. Obenshain, who has 10 days to request a recount, issued a statement calling the Nov. 5 vote “the closest statewide election in modern Virginia history.” He said the choice to press a recount “is not one to be made lightly.” Both sides have lawyers at the ready for a recount battle. There is a “nuclear option”: to contest the election, which would throw it into the state House of Delegates. Republicans hold a majority there.

text: A BOUTIQUE agency that is becoming increasingly known for its unconventional creative output is bringing in its first chief executive to lead additional growth efforts.

text: To punctuate an impassioned pitch for his signature plan to raise taxes on the wealthy, Mayor-elect Bill de Blasio went out of his way during a speech on Monday to praise a cherished political mentor and former boss watching from the audience.

headline: PreCheck Meets Its Goal, and Prepares to Expand
text: THE Transportation Security Administration says it has met its goal of having 25 percent of air travelers using the speedy PreCheck security lanes by the end of this year.

headline: Israelis See Ticking Clock, and Alternate Approaches, on Iran and Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli leaders on Monday condemned the interim deal on Iran’s nuclear program as an exercise in appeasement by the Western powers and a delaying tactic by Iran. Yet many of them see the same strategy of interim confidence-building steps as the only realistic route to resolving their long-running conflict with the Palestinians.

headline: Emissions of Methane in U.S. Exceed Estimates, Study Finds
text: Emissions of the greenhouse gas methane due to human activity were roughly 1.5 times greater in the United States in the middle of the last decade than prevailing estimates, according to a new analysis by 15 climate scientists published Monday in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: Xbox One Release Follows Familiar Pattern
text: Microsoft’s Xbox One finished its first weekend on sale, sticking closely to the script that the release of new video game consoles invariably seem to follow.

headline: New Clues May Change Buddha’s Date of Birth
text: In traditional narratives, Queen Maya Devi, the mother of Buddha, gave birth to him while holding on to a branch of a tree in a garden at Lumbini, in what is now Nepal. Accounts vary as to when this occurred, leaving uncertain the founding century of one of the world’s major religions.

headline: Cage Fighter Who Faked Death Is Sentenced in Armed Robbery
text: Charles Rowan, a low-level cage fighter in Michigan who faked his death to escape a debt to a drug dealer, was sentenced Monday to 17 ½ to 40 years in prison after having pleaded guilty to armed robbery.

headline: After Six Million Miles in the Air, Few Complaints
text: I HAVE traveled my entire career, and now I am traveling more than ever. All these miles for business have helped shape my worldview. I think anyone who travels learns a lot about different cultures, and that’s never a negative.

headline: Poor Field Conditions Confounding Teams in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — When Bayern Munich’s players enter the modest Khimki Arena here for a UEFA Champions League match on Wednesday, their biggest concern might not be the Russian cold or hostile fans or even their opponent, CSKA Moscow. It might be the stadium’s worn and weary playing surface.

headline: Vestas Hopes to Bring Wind Power to World
text: In recent years, solar energy has emerged as a solution for powering places that lack sufficient electricity, frequently remote areas in developing nations where conventional fuel can be expensive.

headline: Bumps in the Road to New Cholesterol Guidelines
text: It was supposed to be a moment of triumph. An august committee had for the first time relied only on the most rigorous scientific evidence to formulate guidelines to prevent heart attacks and strokes, which kill one out of every three Americans. The group had worked for five years, unpaid, to develop them. Then, at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association, it all went horribly awry.

headline: In Campaign, Cash Flowed Circuitously
text: Well, thank God. We stumbled out of the mayoral election without watching the conservative Koch brothers grab our little liberal darlings out of their beds, paint them red and register them as Republicans.

headline: Egypt’s Government Struggles to Gain Footing as Dissent Grows
text: CAIRO — When the new military-backed Egyptian government lifted a nationwide state of emergency more than 10 days ago, it seemed to be proclaiming a momentary victory in the battle with its principal foe, the Muslim Brotherhood, whose regular protests had begun to wither.

headline: No Way Out: ‘12 Years a Slave’
text: (Readers beware: This column includes a detailed discussion of the film’s plot. -- The Editors.)

headline: China’s Coercive Play
text: China’s decision to impose a new air defense zone over a wide swath of the East China Sea is at odds with its claim to want a peaceful resolution to territorial disputes over a group of islands there. The announcement is a highly provocative move that has increased tensions and could make direct conflict with Japan more likely.

headline: Mets Send Holiday Cheer, and Mixed Messages
text: The Mets sent their holiday video e-card Monday featuring eight players — the franchise’s pillars among them — along with Mr. and Mrs. Met, some cartoon backdrops and a flurry of animated snow.

headline: New Jersey Goes All In, Online
text: Internet gambling goes live in New Jersey on Tuesday. It’s the biggest expansion of the casino business in the state since the 1970s. For gamblers with addiction problems, the process of tapping a paycheck and maxing out a credit card has just become infinitely easier.

headline: Caring for Others Was the Right Move to Defeat the Blues
text: There were days when Shawna Simmonds did not want to leave her bed. But it was a sagging spirit, not indolence, that kept her under the covers. Unemployment had left her demoralized.

headline: Helpful Definitions for Modern Authors
text: You, Author: Act as Book’s Publicist, responsible for promotion.

headline: A Glimmer of Sense on Guantánamo
text: The Senate, in a little-noticed but positive move, voted last Tuesday to give President Obama new leeway to move toward closing the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Defining, and Raising, a ‘Healthy Eater’
text: “You are what you eat, from your head down to your feet!”

headline: Bulls’ Rose to Miss Another Year After Knee Injury
text: CHICAGO — The somber news was delivered in a terse statement from the Chicago Bulls on Monday afternoon. “Earlier this morning, Chicago Bulls guard Derrick Rose underwent successful surgery to repair his previously torn medial meniscus in his right knee,” it read.

headline: End the N.S.A. Dragnet, Now
text: WASHINGTON — THE framers of the Constitution declared that government officials had no power to seize the records of individual Americans without evidence of wrongdoing, and they embedded this principle in the Fourth Amendment. The bulk collection of Americans’ telephone records — so-called metadata — by the National Security Agency is, in our view, a clear case of a general warrant that violates the spirit of the framers’ intentions. This intrusive program was authorized under a secret legal process by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, so for years American citizens did not have the knowledge needed to challenge the infringement of their privacy rights.

headline: ID Verification Lagging on Health Care Website
text: WASHINGTON — Just days before the Obama administration’s self-imposed deadline to fix the troubled federal health insurance website, officials said Monday that they were aware of another problem that has prevented thousands of people who were unable to verify their identity from shopping for health plans.

headline: The Charity Swindle
text: WASHINGTON — BY all outward indications, the U.S. Navy Veterans Association was a leader in the charitable community. Founded in 2002 to provide support to Navy veterans in need, the charity recorded astonishing financial success. In its first eight years, it raised around $100 million in charitable contributions, almost all of it through a direct marketing campaign. The organization, headed by Jack L. Nimitz, boasted of 41 state chapters and some 66,000 members.

headline: At Auction, Bids Are Placed on Vestiges of Koch Era
text: How’s he doing? Even in death, not bad.

headline: The North Carolina Five
text: The Uniform Athlete Agents Act was a bill drafted 13 years ago at the urging of the N.C.A.A. The drafters were members of something called the Uniform Law Commission, whose job it is to propose model legislation that the states can then adopt if they so choose. Today, 41 states have the law, or some variant of it, on their books.

headline: A Debate Over Paying Board Nominees of Activist Funds
text: When executives serve on a company’s board, they are often handsomely compensated.

headline: The State’s Findings on Newtown
text: One of the painful anomalies in the state’s official report about December’s school massacre in Newtown, Conn., is the evidence that while Adam Lanza, the shooter who murdered 20 children and six adults, was the object of his mother’s great and continuing concern, it did not stop her from writing a check so he might obtain his own pistol in a family already well stocked with firearms.

headline: Frustration From a Deal on Flawed Hip Implants
text: Patients injured by a flawed hip implant sold by Johnson & Johnson have directed their anger at myriad places over the years. The regulatory system that allowed the product’s sale. The company that repeatedly denied problems with the device. Even the doctors who implanted the hips.

headline: Judge Is Asked to Toss Out Conviction in ’90 Killing of Tourist
text: A decades-old murder case that galvanized public outrage over violent crime in New York was resurrected on Monday, as lawyers for one of the men convicted at trial say they have unearthed new evidence that proves their client was not involved in the attack.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 25, 2013
Obama Speaks About Immigration Overhaul
text: President Obama made the case for changes in immigration policy in a speech in San Francisco during which a man heckled him.

headline: N.S.A. May Have Hit Internet Companies at a Weak Spot
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The recent revelation that the National Security Agency was able to eavesdrop on the communications of Google and Yahoo users without breaking into either company’s data centers sounded like something pulled from a Robert Ludlum spy thriller.

headline: To Offset Risks Inside, Blazers Star Improves His Outside Shooting
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Damian Lillard has always had a dependable midrange game, but he spent time developing it over the summer. He was coming off his rookie season with the Portland Trail Blazers, and the league had delivered its hard lessons.

headline: Conservative Leads Effort to Raise Minimum Wage in California
text: LOS ANGELES — Ron Unz, a Silicon Valley millionaire, rose to fame by promoting a ballot initiative that essentially eliminated bilingual education in California. He went on to become publisher of The American Conservative, a libertarian-leaning magazine.

headline: Obama Calls for Quick Action on Immigration, and So Does a Heckler
text: SAN FRANCISCO — President Obama is often heckled, but it is rare for a guest who is part of a White House-approved backdrop to shout out a protest while the president is in mid-speech.

headline: U.S. Relations With Iran Thaw, and  Allies Shiver
text: If the United States continues to become more engaged with Iran, how would that affect relations with other allies in the region?

headline: F.D.A. Lifts Some Restrictions on Avandia
text: The Food and Drug Administration removed some restrictions on the prescribing and use of the diabetes drug Avandia on Monday, saying that new research showed the drug did not increase the chances of heart attacks.

headline: Brooklyn Pantry Struggling to Help Fill Gap Left by Federal Cuts to Food Stamps
text: In the middle of last week, panic set in at the food pantry in Brooklyn run by the Bed-Stuy Campaign Against Hunger.

headline: Intellectual Property Protection
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Now, here’s a puzzle you can learn something from. I do love it when that happens. Usually, there are only one or two words that I might not know in any given puzzle, but today, the whole theme was a learning experience.

headline: Alec Reid, Northern Ireland Priest Who Helped Broker Peace Accord, Dies at 82
text: DUBLIN — The Rev. Alec Reid, an unassuming Roman Catholic priest who played a quiet but crucial role in clandestine negotiations that led to the historic Good Friday peace accord in Northern Ireland in 1998, died here on Friday. He was 82.

headline: Officers Are Told Race Can Be a Factor in Street Stops, but Not the Only One
text: The warnings had been dire: A law broadening the types of lawsuits that can be filed over accusations of police profiling would make New York City less safe. It would cut into terrorism investigations and anti-gang initiatives and make police officers wary of stopping suspects on the street.

headline: New Pitch for Health Initiative: Mind Your Mom. Get Insured.
text: As the Obama administration’s health overhaul sputters in its opening weeks, insurers and advocacy groups are pursuing a new strategy in the quest to get millions of young people to sign up for health insurance: They’re appealing to their mothers.

headline: Skateboarding Twins Execute a Career 180 in Turning to Tennis
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Nic and Tristan Puehse spent six years sailing through the air with the greatest of ease, bending on their skateboards like yogis on mats. They had a clothing contract with Nike before their eighth birthdays, and by the age of 12, they were performing difficult feats like the stalefish.

headline: Reinventing Rio de Janeiro
text: With the World Cup and the Olympics bearing down on Rio within the next three years, officials here are struggling to reinvent this onetime third-world city with a first-world economy.

headline: A Divided Rio de Janeiro, Overreaching for the World
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The bumpy ride in the rickety van heads up the steep hill into Morro da Providência, this city’s oldest favela. Last stop: a small, silent square with a hardware shop, bar and pair of young policemen in armored gear toting machine guns, patrolling the still-unopened cable-car station that the city has recently built. The port spreads out below.

headline: Nicks’s Absence Against the Cowboys Adds to His Perplexing Season
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Hakeem Nicks, struggling through a middling, enigmatic season, spent all of last week insisting he was going to play against the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday. On game day, the Giants not only kept him out of uniform, they did not even let him warm up in the hours before kickoff to see if he could play.

headline: As Homeless Line Up for Food, Los Angeles Weighs Restrictions
text: LOS ANGELES — They began showing up at dusk last week, wandering the streets, slumped in wheelchairs and sitting on sidewalks, paper plates perched on their knees. By 6:30 p.m., more than 100 homeless people had lined up at a barren corner in Hollywood, drawn by free meals handed out from the back of a truck every night by volunteers.

headline: U.S. and Saudis in Growing Rift as Power Shifts
text: WASHINGTON — There was a time when Saudi and American interests in the Middle East seemed so aligned that the cigar-smoking former Saudi ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, was viewed as one of the most influential diplomats in Washington.

headline: Dispute Erupts in India Over Surveillance by Candidate
text: NEW DELHI — In a set of telephone transcripts and recordings that were published by an Indian website this month, high-ranking intelligence and security officers from the western state of Gujarat can be heard reporting back on an unusual assignment: covertly tracing every movement of a young woman, meticulously documenting her contacts with men. Their findings were passed to another high-ranking official they referred to as “Saheb.”

headline: Corrections: November 26, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: ‘One-Trick Pony’ Offense Nags Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — There was a splash of good news that came out of Sunday’s mauling in Baltimore, Rex Ryan said.

headline: James Rensenbrink, 81, Dies; Founded Aquarian Weekly
text: When James Rensenbrink started an alternative newspaper in 1969, its mission — speaking truth to power, debunking corporate journalism, promoting rock ’n’ roll, publishing sex tips and drug advice that no mainstream newspaper would — made it like a thousand other alternative papers in that high-water-mark counterculture year.

headline: Popping the Question, Tuhao-Style
text: How many pairs of shoes does it take to reach a Chinese girl’s heart? According to Xu Pengjie, a 28-year-old restaurant owner in Chengdu, the answer is 1,001.

headline: The Changing American Family
text: American households have never been more diverse, more surprising, more baffling. In this special issue of Science Times, NATALIE ANGIER takes stock of our changing definition of family.

headline: Franco and O’Dowd Confirmed for ‘Of Mice and Men’ on Broadway
text: James Franco (“127 Hours”) and Chris O’Dowd (“Bridesmaids”) will make their Broadway debuts as George and Lennie in John Steinbeck’s play “Of Mice and Men,” with performances starting March 19 at the Longacre Theater, the lead producer, David Binder, announced Monday. The two stars had been in negotiations with Mr. Binder for the last few months, and he has also lined up one of the few Broadway theaters still available for the spring season.

headline: Effective Corporate Tax Rates
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | aversion
text: aversion •\ə-ˈvər-zhən, -shən\• noun

headline: Lakers Finalize Deal With Bryant With Eye on 2014 Free Agents
text: Kobe Bryant and the Los Angeles Lakers finalized a two-year contract extension Monday that all but ensures Bryant will end his career with the team.

headline: Typhoon Haiyan Through the Lens of China’s 2008 Quake
text: Around the time I visited my second mass grave for victims of Typhoon Haiyan, I concluded this disaster was different. I had covered a catastrophic natural disaster before, the 2008 earthquake in China’s Sichuan Province that left nearly 90,000 dead or missing.

headline: Super Bowl First: A U.S. Telecast With Spanish Announcers
text: On Feb. 2, when Fox Sports carries Super Bowl XLVIII from MetLife Stadium, so will Fox Deportes, the Spanish-language network that is also part of 21st Century Fox. The Super Bowl has never before been televised in Spanish in the United States.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (FX) WANTED (2008) A meek cubicle drone (James McAvoy, above) is initiated into a secret society of assassins known as the Fraternity to avenge the murder of his father in this ultraviolent action-thriller directed by Timur Bekmambetov. Morgan Freeman plays the organization’s leader, and Angelina Jolie portrays an amoral if fashionably turned-out killer. “Mr. Bekmambetov, a Russian filmmaker who has earned a cult following with his razzly-dazzly thrillers ‘Day Watch’ and ‘Night Watch,’ certainly proves here that he knows how to use every blunt tool of the bullying trade: flashy effects, zippy cuts, simulated death, walls of sound, wheels of steel and, in between the bullets and blood, a hot mama to make the brother-to-brother, man-on-man action less worrisome,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Wanted’ is a goof, then, and for a short stretch a pretty diverting one.”

headline: Knicks Drop Sixth Straight, Falling in Portland
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Before Monday night’s game, one of the television sets inside the visitors’ locker room at the Moda Center was tuned to an N.F.L. game. This did not please Amar’e Stoudemire, the veteran Knicks forward who was sprawled on the floor studying film of the Trail Blazers. He wanted the football turned off. Why was it even on?

headline: A Conversation With: Prabhat Jauhari, C.E.O. of Mumbai Private Security Firm
text: Prabhat Jauhari is the chief executive officer of Tops Air Rescue and Topsline Life Response Services, the first private emergency response service in Mumbai, which was started by Topsgrup in 2004. The Topsline crew, which is trained in rescue and evacuation operations, worked with the Mumbai police during the terror attacks of Nov. 26, 2008, to rescue over 150 people.

headline: Qualcomm Investigated Under Antitrust Law
text: Qualcomm, the San Diego-based mobile chip maker, has become the target of an antitrust investigation led by the National Development and Reform Commission, China’s top economic planning body — a disclosure that sent Qualcomm shares tumbling 1.5 percent and raised concerns about the company’s prospects in its fastest-growing market.

headline: News Quiz | November 26, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Test Yourself | History, Nov. 26, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Bayer in Bid to Acquire Norwegian Cancer Drug Firm
text: LONDON – The Norwegian cancer drug maker Algeta said on Tuesday that it had received a preliminary offer to be acquired by the German drug giant Bayer for about $2.4 billion.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Whales, Sea Lions and Dolphins Congregate for Anchovy Feast
text: In “With Extra Anchovies, Deluxe Whale Watching,” Erica Goode reports on a rare convocation of sea life off the California coast.

headline: Ukraine in Turmoil After Leaders Reject Major E.U. Deal
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Yuri V. Lutsenko, a onetime field commander of Ukraine’s 2004 Orange Revolution, looked out across the tens of thousands of people who gathered on Sunday to protest the government’s decision to back away from a far-reaching political and trade deal with the European Union. Standing onstage under an ash-streaked sky, Mr. Lutsenko felt a powerful sense of déjà vu — and a deep need to apologize.

headline: Scots Propose Independence With Pounds and Passports
text: LONDON — Behind in the opinion polls, Scottish Nationalists who are seeking independence from Britain in a referendum next year set out their wish list for a new nation on Tuesday, but made several assertions about their future relations with Britain and international partners that are sharply disputed.

headline: Mind the Gap
text: At the not-yet-completed One57, a luxury residential tower off Central Park, the unsold floor-through apartments are going for $53 million and up. The penthouse sold for more than $90 million. One57 will be the tallest residence in the Western Hemisphere (until another luxury high-rise on Park Avenue is completed in 2015), and on a clear day, residents on the top floors should be able to just make out the South Bronx.

headline: The Final Frontier, in Photographs
text: There it is — the whole shebang. Or what’s left of the Big Bang, if you want to be precise and scientific about it. The trippy scene, all fall colors and gray splotches, was built from data captured by NASA’s Spitzer Space Telescope and puts in visual form the remaining background light from when the universe was less than one billion years old.

headline: Do We Need Art in Our Lives?
text: Do we need art in our lives? Should viewing art be part of every child’s education? Does it make us smarter or expose us to new ways of seeing the world?

headline: A New Way to Report Fraud
text: The letters arrive almost daily, on official-looking letterhead from a supposed charity, or from the J.M.D. Major Cash Disbursement Office. More blatantly, letters sometimes come from an outfit called Mountains of Money. They announce that the 85-year-old man to whom they’re addressed has won a prize — the amount seems to hover around $11,000 — and explain that to claim it, he has to fill out a form, often complete with a “verification code,” and send it in with a check for $6 or $7.

headline: China to Send ‘Jade Rabbit’ Rover to the Moon
text: China will send an unmanned rover to the moon in early December, a spokesman for the Commission of Science, Technology, and Industry for National Defense said on Tuesday. The lunar probe will be called the Yutu, or Jade Rabbit, a name that comes from a Chinese myth about a white rabbit that lives on the moon and was selected in an online poll.

headline: Demonstrations in Bangkok Raise Concerns About Stability of Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s governing party accused protesters on Tuesday of fomenting anarchy and trying to overthrow the government after thousands of people swarmed the streets of Bangkok, besieging crucial ministries and threatening to take their campaign nationwide.

text: Saudi Arabia on the Iran deal; Rio de Janeiro prepares to meet the world; and the science of modern families.

headline: A New University Offers Liberal Arts as Higher Education Alternative
text: NEW DELHI – For decades, India’s institutes of technology and management, the famed I.I.T.’s and I.I.M.’s, have been seen as the pinnacle of this country’s higher education, offering world-class courses and above all, employability to its graduates.

text: In the South Congress neighborhood of Austin, Tex., the heat keeps the local style casual and comfortable.

headline: Health Group Retracts Report on H.I.V. in Greece
text: LONDON — It took a while for people to notice, but once they did, the news spread like wildfire: The World Health Organization had said that about half of new H.I.V. cases in Greece were “self-inflicted” as a way to get state benefits.

headline: Noted Philosopher Moves to N.Y.U. — and Beyond
text: The philosopher Kwame Anthony Appiah, known for his wide-ranging and accessible writings on cosmopolitanism, identity and global ethics, will be leaving Princeton for New York University at the end of the year.

headline: In Performance: Jon DeVries and Maryann Plunkett of ‘Regular Singing’
text: The works in Richard Nelson’s four-part Apple Family Plays are each set on a specific day in recent American history: election days of 2010 (“That Hopey Changey Thing”) and 2012 (“Sorry”); the 10th anniversary of 9/11 (“Sweet and Sad”) and the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy (“Regular Singing”). In this scene from “Regular Singing,” Barbara, a schoolteacher (played by Maryann Plunkett), and her uncle, Benjamin, a retired actor dealing with memory loss (portrayed by Jon DeVries), discuss an article about the assassination in The New York Times. Scenes from the four plays, which are being performed in repertory at the Public Theater through Dec. 15, are in this In Performance video player.

headline: Tricky Little Things
text: Tiny as they are, misplaced commas form an outsize blot on a sentence. In the spectrum of grammatical lapses, they seem particularly amateurish.

headline: Dolf van den Brink of Heineken USA, on Transparency
text: This interview with Dolf van den Brink, president and chief executive of Heineken USA, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Behind the Scenes of The Movies Issue
text: Last week, we teased the 2013 Movies Issue with a 15-second Instagram video. This time, we aren’t teasing. You can watch all 11 original films that Janusz Kaminski created for the magazine, each of which contains a line of dialogue written by one (or a team) of the best screenwriters of the year. Watch how it all came together in the video shown here, and get more backstage insight from this slide show.

headline: Parents Receive Life Sentences in Murders of Daughter and Domestic Worker
text: NEW DELHI — Rajesh and Nupur Talwar were sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday by a special Central Bureau of Investigation court in Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, for the murders of their teenage daughter and a domestic worker.

headline: Activist Funds and Board Influence
text: “As activist hedge funds continue to get more of their preferred candidates on the boards of companies, some of the hedge funds are angling for certain directors to be paid twice: once by the company, and once by the hedge funds that supported their candidacy,” DealBook’s David Gelles reports.

headline: Musings on Minnesota Macro
text: Miles Kimball and Noah Smith have a long piece on the shakeup at the Minneapolis Fed, where a couple of prominent freshwater macro people have been fired. Kimball and Smith carefully tiptoe about exactly what happened, and so will I — I hear stuff, but it’s second- or third-order hearsay, and not reliable.

headline: Bain to Sell Insurance Software Company
text: Applied Systems, a software company that focuses on the insurance industry, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to be acquired by the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman in a deal valued at $1.8 billion.

headline: Daily Report: N.S.A. May Have Tapped Internet Cable Links
text: The recent revelation that the National Security Agency was able to eavesdrop on the communications of Google and Yahoo users without breaking into either companies’ data centers sounded like something pulled from a Robert Ludlum spy thriller. How on earth, the companies asked, did the N.S.A. get their data without them knowing about it?

headline: Pakistan Breaks Ground on Nuclear Plant Project With China
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Tuesday ceremonially broke ground on a $9.59 billion nuclear power complex to be built in Karachi with China’s help, seeking to ease Pakistan’s long-running energy crisis and signaling a new step by China in becoming a top nuclear supplier.

headline: France Adds Troops in Central African Republic
text: In a bid to stem deepening chaos in the Central African Republic, where brutal government-affiliated militia groups have been pillaging and burning villages, the French defense minister announced on Tuesday that France would increase its deployment of troops there to about 1,000.

headline: California Myths
text: Among the many vituperative reactions I had to yesterday’s column, one recurred a lot — namely, the assertion that California’s rising enrollment in Obamacare would bankrupt the state, which is already a fiscal basket case.

headline: Fifty Years Later, Why Does ‘Eichmann in Jerusalem’ Remain Contentious?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on pressing and provocative questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Rivka Galchen on why Hannah Arendt’s “Eichmann in Jerusalem” remains contentious fifty years after it was first published.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Alexander Wang Coasters
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: Image of the Day: November 26
text: The Taj Mahal hotel in Mumbai, Maharashtra, was one of the sites of the deadly terrorist attacks of Nov. 26, 2008.

headline: The Man Behind the MRAP Moves On
text: WASHINGTON – Amid the awards and decorations on display in the Pentagon office of Ashton B. Carter, the departing deputy secretary of defense, is a metal bearing, larger than a golf ball, which wears the scars of battle.

headline: Another Turnaround by Arians, This Time in Arizona
text: Bruce Arians is doing it again. A year ago, he helped turn the Indianapolis Colts from the worst team in the N.F.L. to a playoff team. Hired as the team’s offensive coordinator, he was named the Associated Press coach of the year after Chuck Pagano, who was found to have leukemia, took a leave of absence. The Arizona Cardinals hired Arians as their head coach after firing Ken Whisenhunt, and Arians is again a viable candidate for the award.

headline: What I Needed to Understand About Health Insurance
text: I have bought health insurance for my workers since 1994, and since then I’ve spent well over a million dollars paying premiums. I have always found it to be troubling that I was given sole authority to make the choice as to what kind of coverage we would offer, and to a certain extent, how much it would cost. Was I doing a good job? I never heard any complaints about the policies I chose, even when I moved us into an HMO in the late ’90s, when I made my workers contribute to their plan costs in 2005, and when rates skyrocketed in the years after that.

headline: To Help Typhoon Survivors, Go Local
text: Two years ago I watched the footage of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, willing myself not to start imagining what else was going on that I couldn’t see or read about.  As a Japanese national living in the States, I was struck by the well-meaning experts who discouraged the public from donating to the relief efforts.  Journalists questioned the logic of individuals giving to a wealthy country like Japan, and philanthropic advisors encouraged donors to give to organizations that could redirect funds to other more pressing needs outside of Japan after the initial relief effort. It was understandable, perhaps—the fog of disaster makes it hard to immediately know how much is “needed,” or what help is needed, even where.

headline: New Jersey’s ‘Mutinous 33rd’
text: John Toffey was sick with fever. The Union lieutenant had been ill for days and not able to attend to his duties. An Army surgeon in Chattanooga, Tenn., examined the 19-year-old officer on the evening of Nov. 22, 1863, and handed him a permit to go into the hospital.

headline: In Our Pages: November 27
text: 1913: Oil Town Told to Surrender

headline: Pope Sets Down Goals for an Inclusive Church, Reaching Out ‘on the Streets’
text: In his first nine months as leader of one billion Roman Catholics, Pope Francis has parceled out glimpses of his vision for remaking the church — in homilies and news conferences, interviews and offhand remarks to visitors.

headline: A Fresh Look at America’s Gas Lands
text: I’ve been meaning to post for awhile on “Gas Rush Stories,” a series of simple, but captivating short films on America’s gas drilling boom made by Kirsi Jansa, a Finnish video journalist currently living in Pittsburgh.

headline: American Family Redefined
text: If the Burnses (with a family of 4 children from three earlier marriages) seem atypical as an American nuclear family, how about the Schulte-Waysers, a merry band of two married dads, six kids and two dogs? Or the Indrakrishnans, a successful immigrant couple in Atlanta whose teenage daughter divides her time between prosaic homework and the precision footwork of ancient Hindu dance; the Glusacs of Los Angeles, with their two nearly grown children and their litany of middle-class challenges that seem like minor sagas; Ana Perez and Julian Hill of Harlem, unmarried and just getting by, but with Warren Buffett-size dreams for their three young children; and the alarming number of families with incarcerated parents, a sorry byproduct of America’s status as the world’s leading jailer. Read more in The Changing American Family in Science Times.

headline: At Least 30 Haitians Die After Boat Capsizes
text: MIAMI — At least 30 Haitians who tried to sail to the United States were found drowned on Tuesday after their overloaded boat ran aground off the Bahamas and capsized, several days after fishermen tipped off Bahamian military authorities about the vessel.

headline: Pat McKillen, the Newest to Relive Bob Dylan’s ‘Like a Rolling Stone’
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: A Well-Aged White Wine to Cosset Miso-Glazed Fish
text: This is a dish rich in umami, and you need a wine that won’t wilt before it, preferably on the savory rather than fruity side. The ideal choice would be a well-aged white, like a 15-year-old grand cru Chablis, with just the right amount of richness and minerality to cosset the fish. Other options include a white Bordeaux from Pessac-Léognan or an older dry riesling with amplitude.

headline: Take-Two Interactive Buys Back Icahn Stake
text: Take-Two Interactive Software announced on Tuesday that it had bought back the stake held by Carl C. Icahn, compelling the resignations of three board members he was allowed to appoint.

headline: Rodriguez Amends Suit, Adding Claims About Selig
text: Alex Rodriguez’s lawyers updated their lawsuit against Major League Baseball on Tuesday, adding new claims about the conduct of baseball’s commissioner, Bud Selig, in defending his 211-game suspension of Rodriguez, the Yankees’ third baseman.

headline: Feeling For | A Parisian-Style Retreat in the Heart of Greenwich Village
text: The Marlton House, built in 1900 and later a haven for Jack Kerouac and his crew, reopened this fall as the Marlton, a Parisian-inspired 107-room boutique hotel in the heart of Greenwich Village, just off Washington Square Park. It offers the same cool, casual elegance as the Bowery Hotel, a few blocks across town, but at a fraction of the price. The similarities to the Bowery are no surprise, as the Marlton is the work of the hotelier Sean MacPherson (also a developer of the Maritime and the Jane), who has once again created a hotel that feels as if it wasn’t designed just to sleep but also to sidle up to the bar in a dignified way and watch the P.Y.T.’s come and go. It’s the kind of place you could easily visit for afternoon tea with a parent on one of the plush sofas, or rendezvous with your lover for a martini followed by a trip to one of the small yet charming rooms, where the bed is the main attraction and finishing details are not overlooked. If you’re not in the mood for libations — and with creations like the Marvelous Sour (recipe below), the Marlton has taken steps to make sure that never happens — there is an espresso bar in the lobby that makes raw almond cappuccinos and gluten-free, vegan breakfast cookies. Coming soon will be a 98-seat restaurant in the rear of the lobby, Café Marlton, which will serve breakfast, lunch and dinner. As a longtime neighbor of the building the Marlton now occupies, I can safely say it’s the best recent addition to the neighborhood where charm reigns supreme.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 26 at Noon
text: Severe weather threatens Thanksgiving travel; protests in Thailand; and moms market health care.

headline: Battling Flames in Forests, With Prison as the Firehouse
text: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — The men cluster in a tight pack, identities obscured by fire-resistant Nomex clothes, each one anonymous except for the color of his helmet: red for corrections officers, blue and yellow for inmates.

headline: Most New York Voters Happy With Cuomo, Poll Finds
text: With no declared Republican candidate, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is approaching his re-election year with an enviable approval rating and a comfortable advantage against one potential opponent, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

headline: A $100 Weekend in Santiago, Chile
text: “My sofa is very comfortable,” boasted Marcos, the pony-tailed, Iron Maiden-loving Chilean who had met me at the centrally located Parque O’Higgins metro stop in the Chilean capital of Santiago and was walking me to his place. “I sometimes sleep on it myself.” When you have just $100 to spend all weekend, any place will do — but his worn-in black leather sofa, paired with a thick comforter for warmth and a snow-white cat named Ixi (named for Itchy, the “Simpsons” cartoon mouse) for company, turned out to be a dream.

headline: Barnes & Noble Reports Profit, but Sales Decline 8%
text: Barnes & Noble reported tepid sales in its bookstore and digital divisions for its most recent quarter, reflecting an overall weak publishing climate and flattening demand for e-books.

headline: Chico Hamilton, Drummer, Bandleader and Exponent of Cool Jazz, Dies at 92
text: Chico Hamilton, a drummer and bandleader who helped put California on the modern-jazz map in the 1950s and remained active into the 21st century, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Justices to Hear Contraception Cases Challenging Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a pair of cases on whether corporations may refuse to provide insurance coverage for contraception to their workers based on the religious beliefs of the corporations’ owners.

headline: U.S. Sends Two B-52 Bombers Into Air Zone Claimed by China
text: WASHINGTON — Defying China, two long-range American bombers flew through contested airspace over the East China Sea, days after the Chinese announced they were claiming the right to police the sky above a vast area that includes islands at the center of a simmering dispute with Japan.

headline: Down the Instagram Rabbit Hole
text: Stacey Baker, magazine photo editor and Instagram dynamo, has been getting so much attention for her portraits of women’s legs that she gets approached by fans offline. One time a tourist spotted her taking a “legs” shot and asked, “Are you @stace_a_lace?” The woman had worn special tights that day on her visit to New York hoping to be photographed.

headline: From the Beatles to Lorde, Musicians Offer Songs for Philippine Relief Album
text: More than three dozen musicians representing a broad range of pop styles — from the Beatles, Bob Dylan, U2 and Earth, Wind and Fire, at the classic end, to Lorde, Beyoncé, Justin Bieber and Katy Perry, among more recent hit makers — have contributed recordings to “Songs for the Philippines,” a 39-track compilation assembled to raise money for relief efforts in the country, which was devastated by Typhoon Haiyan on Nov. 8.

headline: Words of Love, Pain, Protest and Motown
text: Zora Neale Hurston (1891-1960) was probably the first great African-American food writer. She regularly hauled her appetites into her prose.

headline: Brazil Is Entranced by a Tale of Love, Taxes and Bribery
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — There were the boxes of Cuban cigars, which cost about $500 each at a shop in Vila Nova Conceição, one of the most exclusive districts of São Paulo, and the $2,260 bottles of Vega Sicilia Único, a legendary Spanish red. Throw in a Porsche Cayenne, speedboat jaunts to tropical islands and all-night soirees with high-end escorts, and what do you get?

headline: Taking a Break From I.V.F.
