headline: My Favorite Ways to Kick the Bucket
text: “Nobody at Warner’s died like me. It’s the one thing I had a knack for.”

headline: Familiar Faces, Broad Humor
text: When it’s Kirstie Alley, size doesn’t matter. But after bouts of self-mockery (“Fat Actress”) and a public weight-loss regimen (Jenny Craig and “Dancing With the Stars”), she has re-emerged: thinner, younger — at least in TV years — and ready for prime time once again.

headline: Tourist Sites as Inspiration
text: A look at the work of the Chinese artist Sun Xun.

headline: Inspiration Far From Home
text: When the Chinese artist Sun Xun was growing up in Fuxin, a small city near the North Korean border, he already knew that China was a country with at least two histories. In school, during the day, he studied the Chinese history presented in official accounts, a version remarkably free of such troubling episodes as the Great Leap Forward or the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Heading Wherever, Together
text: In the current issue of Billboard, at the end of the cover feature on One Direction, there is a cooling mist of reality spritzed by, who else, Simon Cowell, the TV judge-impresario who helped Frankenstein this group into existence on the 2010 season of the British version of “The X Factor.”

headline: Musical Underground
text: Xuefei Yang, a gifted guitarist who is said to have been the first guitar major at Beijing’s Central Conservatory of Music, will perform at SubCulture on Tuesday in a show presented by the 92nd Street Y. This intimate new subterranean space on Bleecker Street has joined Le Poisson Rouge, among others, as a prominent downtown platform for classical music. Ms. Yang, who has several records on EMI Classics, will perform works by Britten (whose centennial is being celebrated this season) as well as pieces by Ginastera, Chen Yi and Mertz. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.)

headline: Whitish Gray, Also Quite Green
text: An event of a relatively permanent nature may overshadow the five-day confab of art fairs that will descend on Miami this week: the inauguration of the striking Pérez Art Museum Miami (formerly the Miami Art Museum) in Bicentennial Park on the Bay of Biscayne. The whitish-gray, mostly environmentally green building is the latest museum from Herzog & de Meuron, which designed the expansion of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the De Young Museum in San Francisco. The three-story 120,000 square-foot building consists of a group of geometric volumes that seem almost to levitate between a base of several platforms and an immense perforated canopy overhead. In addition to reducing energy consumption, the canopy will support one of the museum’s most distinctive features: a hanging garden of native plants irrigated by collected rainwater. The effect is of an expanded Corbusier villa that has absorbed its greensward. The opening exhibitions seem bent on making the most of the museum’s small collection and nearly 31,000 square feet of gallery space, but with a probable destination building like this, it may not matter.

headline: Braided Bodies Up Onstage
text: It can’t be easy being the artistic director of one of America’s most beloved dance companies, but Robert Battle — after a little more than two years on the job — is gradually and imaginatively giving his dancers a reason to have an extra bounce in their steps. Beginning on Wednesday, his troupe, the versatile Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will unveil Wayne McGregor’s “Chroma,” originally choreographed for the Royal Ballet in 2006. The work pits John Pawson’s stark set against Joby Talbot’s original compositions and arrangements of music by the White Stripes. It was also the dance that led to Mr. McGregor’s appointment as resident choreographer at the Royal Ballet.

headline: Seeing Beauty With Saul Leiter
text: Tony Cenicola thought he was leaving behind the world of being a photo assistant to start his own studio. He had been helping a photographer move into a lower Fifth Avenue studio duplex in 1985 when its owner was struck by something: Mr. Cenicola could pack delicate cameras and gear. Soon, Mr. Cenicola got a call from that photographer to be his assistant. He spent the next 10 years working with Saul Leiter, an important figure in the New York School. Mr. Leiter died late Tuesday night in New York City. Mr. Cenicola, who is now a staff photographer at The New York Times, recalled his time assisting — and learning from — Mr. Leiter. His conversation with David Gonzalez has been edited into a first-person narrative.

headline: West Coast Style, by the Numbers
text: The rapper who calls himself 100s has a genuinely beautiful mane of hair not seen since the days of Suga Free, and that’s not an accident: 100s is part of the proud California pimp-rap legacy, and aesthetics matter. On his self-released debut album from last year, “Ice Cold Perm,” he raps with a smooth sneer over gooey tracks that recall the West Coast of the early-mid 1990s, a sound that’s been undervalued historically. And his new singles “Life of a Mack” (also heard in the video game “Grand Theft Auto V”) and “Keep a Bitch Broke” — in advance of a new EP, “IVRY” (Fool’s Gold) — show an admirable commitment to keeping that style alive. 100s is the most exciting artist on the “Turnt & Burnt” tour — along with the headliner, ASAP Ferg — which comes to Irving Plaza this week, and also features various other members of the ASAP Mob, as well as Joey Fatts, Aston Matthews and OverDoz. (Friday at 7 p.m., 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan; irvingplaza.com.)

headline: See Stanwyck, All Month Long
text: I recall watching “The Big Valley” as a child, a western series on ABC about a family led by a matriarch who was smart, graceful, independent and tough (and partial to turtlenecks and black leather). Only later did I learn the true majesty of the star, billed on the show as Miss Barbara Stanwyck. Stanwyck (1907-90) — born Ruby Stevens in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and a former Ziegfeld chorus girl — had 35 years of movies behind her. Forty of her best films, many in 35-millimeter prints, appear in “Stanwyck,” a Film Forum celebration running Friday through Dec. 31.

headline: Civil Complaint Against MSA Security
text: Read the full civil complaint against MSA Security.

headline: At Edward Hopper’s Home, Legally This Time
text: As a mischievous boy in the late 1960s, Tony Oursler sneaked into Edward Hopper’s childhood home, then unoccupied and in disrepair, and just blocks from where Mr. Oursler’s family lived in Nyack, N.Y. Now an internationally recognized multimedia artist, Mr. Oursler has returned to the scene of his trespassing, today known as the Edward Hopper House Art Center, with “Tony Oursler: hopped (popped),” a site-specific installation that interweaves anecdotal snippets from his youth with biting reimaginings of Hopper’s complicated 43-year marriage.

headline: A Violin Prodigy, Now Grown
text: The seeds of Sirena Huang’s professional relationship with Carolyn Kuan, music director of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra, were planted at the 2007 Eastern Music Festival in Greensboro, N.C. Ms. Huang, then a 12-year-old violinist in the Juilliard School’s pre-college division, was the soloist with a student orchestra conducted by Ms. Kuan, who was then assistant director of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra.

headline: House Hunting Near Marseille
text: A house designed by the architect André Stern is on the market for $2.6 million.

headline: House Hunting Near ... Marseille
text: A MODERN VILLA IN THE COASTAL TOWN OF ST.-CYR-SUR-MER

headline: Digital Passivity
text: I fear that 2013 will be remembered as a tragic  and dark year in the digital universe, despite the fact that a lot of wonderful advances took place.

headline: From the Editor
text: The experts we corralled for our “Conversation” on aging, as you are about to discover, agree that we are pushing death farther and farther back, so that many of us may now expect to live a century or more. I find this most heartening, sharing as I do the common fear of the Reaper. But I am also aware that I and my fellow centenarians will pose some difficult new problems for our 80-year-old kids and 60-something grandkids, problems memorably identified by the Beatles back in the day: Will you still need me, will you still feed me, when I’m one-oh-four?

headline: So Many Sounds, but Jazz Is the Core
text: LOS ANGELES —  Herbie Hancock, a pianist of sparkling touch and brisk intuition, has often seemed like a figure rushing ever onward, and the direction in which he has increasingly hurled himself is globe-trotting cultural diplomacy. “I don’t consider myself a spokesperson for jazz,” he said recently, implying that he has bigger concerns.

headline: Week 13 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: The Value of Aaron Rodgers
text: The model used here to produce the game probabilities is a “parametric” model, meaning its inputs are parameters that can be varied easily. That’s obviously a good thing, as team statistics certainly vary from week to week. It’s also handy because those parameters can be manually adjusted to account for injuries and just to play what-if.

headline: The Past in Our Future
text: I recently took my 16-year-old daughter Adele to see a section of the Berlin Wall that has been preserved as part of a museum devoted to the division of the city, Germany and Europe. It was a bright Berlin morning. Tourists gazed at the wall. They read placards describing the young lives lost in attempts at escape from the Soviet empire. Adele, born in 1997, with just a toehold in the last century, wandered around. She examined these curious relics. Every now and again she checked her Facebook page on her device. ‘‘This just seems so ancient,’’ she said, leaning back against the wall. ‘‘I mean, it feels like it comes from the 19th century.’’

headline: Our Compass
text: In each issue, the editors of Turning Points invite contributors to explore one of the big questions of the year. For 2013 we asked Elif Shafak, Salam Fayyad, Liao Yiwu, Rowan Williams, Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Mata Amritanandamayi Devi: Who are the moral leaders for these times?

headline: Cyber Subterfuge
text: I awoke one morning to a disturbing email from the software giant Adobe. The message warned that thieves had hacked into the company’s servers, stolen the source code for some of its software products and almost three million passwords and credit card details, among which might be mine. It included a link to reset my password.

headline: An Unlikely Throne for Dance Royalty
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — Michelangelo’s David framed by palm trees: The image may seem incongruous, but it’s a semiofficial symbol for this resort city on the Gulf Coast of Florida. A bronze version of that Italian Renaissance sculpture has long stood in a bayside courtyard of the Ringling Museum of Art here, part of the collection of European antiquities and old master paintings that the circus tycoon John Ringling imported in the early 1900s. Along with a long-established opera company, orchestra and repertory theater, the museum explains why Sarasota is accustomed to billing itself as Florida’s Cultural Coast.

headline: The World of Mars
text: ‘‘We have an unknown distance yet to run, an unknown river to explore. What falls there are, we know not; what rocks beset the channel, we know not; what walls ride over the river, we know not. Ah, well! we may conjecture many things.’’  — John Wesley Powell

headline: Leaving Home Coming Home
text: Organizing one’s address book is always a thankless task. Every year, from my home in Havana, I attack the job of reviewing, page by page, all the names and data that make up my network of personal and professional relationships. Like a tapestry in which I am barely one strand, I review every thread that remains and each thread that was lost. And I find myself facing the alarming evidence of how many people I must subtract.

headline: Power in 2030: The Roads We May Take
text: There is no question that we are at a turning point in world energy. But then we are often at a turning point. Just as everybody gets comfortable with what they expect to happen, a big change comes along that undercuts existing assumptions. Just consider:

headline: Father to a Nation, and to a Family
text: Zindzi Mandela’s earliest memory is sitting outside a Pretoria, South Africa, police station in 1962 while her mother, Winnie, delivered a favorite dish to her father, Nelson Mandela, being held inside.

headline: Deep Cover
text: “Please, what is my name  —  you have to tell me my name!’’ I was on the corner of 72nd Street and Broadway in New York, talking with the urgency of a madwoman into my cellphone.

headline: After Recovery, a Return Fit for Longing and Loss
text: When the tenor Rolando Villazón last sang at the Metropolitan Opera in 2009, he suffered various mishaps, prompting cancellations attributed to laryngitis and other illnesses. He sought medical advice and was told he would probably never sing again. He was eventually found to have a congenital internal cyst on his left vocal cord; after surgery in 2009, he relearned first how to speak and then how to sing, making a sometimes unsteady foray back into the professional opera world.

headline: Women Rising
text: In a Belfast hotel last spring, stories of children and life floated through the rooms.

headline: Drug War No More
text: After covering drug trafficking and violence in Latin America since 2001, I look through endless photos and videos and ask myself what would be its single most iconic image  —  one that people could look at in a hundred years and understand.

headline: A Force of 120 Million
text: I met Sharmila Devi when the youngest of her four children, Babita, was 4 months old. After Babita was born, Sharmila made a brave decision that will give her children a good chance at a better future.

headline: Euro Marriage in Peril
text: On the morning of July 26, 2012, I was meeting with the central bank governor of a country at the core, or stable center, of the euro zone. He was telling me that the European Central Bank could do little to rescue peripheral countries like Italy and Spain, whose interest rates were going through the roof.

headline: Do I Dare to Eat a Peach?
text: This discussion was held in London in partnership with the lecture curator 5x15. The moderator was Serge Schmemann, editor of the Magazine. The participants were Sarah Harper, a British gerontologist and founder of the Oxford Institute of Population Aging; Babatunde Osotimehin, a physician and former Nigerian minister of health who is executive director of UNFPA, the United Nations Populations Fund; and Ruby Wax, an American-born, London-based comedian, writer, TV personality and mental-health campaigner.

headline: Fashion’s Latest Muse
text: In the early 1980s, Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenue department store, asked a few designers to create looks for their windows. The instruction: What will we be wearing in the year 2000? Instead of designing a dress, I painted a leopard-print skin on a mannequin. Little did I know the wrap dresses I was making at the time would still be relevant in the 21st century. I am amazed that, as I celebrate the 40th anniversary of the dress in 2014, my little creation is still being worn by young women across the globe.

headline: What’s So Funny?
text: This year, the world became just a tad more crazy, sick and difficult to understand. “A man who is not confused is not well informed,” goes the old Irish saying, and that has never been more true. Economists, journalists, psychologists and other poor souls who deal with the hard questions of daily life  —  with no relief in sight  —  have no easy answers to offer.

headline: Notable Children’s Books of 2013
text: YOUNG ADULT

headline: Wrath, Lust and Other Punch Lines
text: Gigi Levangie’s latest black comedy is a set of scathing parables about the seven deadly sins, which are made a bit deadlier by the filthy-rich Beverly Hills ambience that the author can skewer so well. Ms. Levangie, now using this nom de divorce after writing her funnier books (“Maneater,” “The Starter Wife”) as Gigi Levangie Grazer, can be hit or miss, especially when she has a plot to concoct. But “Seven Deadlies” requires no such exertion. It’s not much more than a set of seven meanspirited stories about what sin and wretched excess can do.

headline: 2013: The Year in Images
text: A look at events around the world from the past year.

headline: A Record Store Rises
text: Stephen Mallon, a visual artist, shot a behind-the-scenes preparations for the opening of Rough Trade’s first flagship store in the U.S. on November 25th.

headline: Council Bill Aims to Limit Use of E-Cigarettes as Their Popularity Grows
text: The City Council is seeking to add electronic cigarettes to New York’s ban on smoking in public places.

headline: Global Agenda
text: What the editors of Turning Points look forward to in 2014.

headline: The Dead Return. They Need Hobbies.
text: The word “zombie” is thrown around a lot in reference to “The Returned,” the spooky French series whose first season has hit the halfway point on Sundance Channel. It’s even been called the French “Walking Dead.” But it’s not really a zombie show. Only one character eats flesh, and he started doing it while he was still alive. When an undead girl says, “Zombies have to stick together,” her smile tells you that she considers herself anything but.

headline: What Becomes a Diva Most?
text: On a recent Friday afternoon, the soprano Lisette Oropesa was standing in a mirrored changing room inside the Metropolitan Opera’s costume department playing with her wedding veil. The costume designer Brigitte Reiffenstuel looked on critically, stepping back as far as possible within the cramped space. Elise Aragon, a draper, knelt at the soprano’s feet with pins cupped in her hand. Ms. Oropesa fluffed the veil with her hands and allowed the diaphanous material to settle like a mist around her face. By way of experiment, she took a few deep breaths and declared herself satisfied. “I’ve had to sing with way worse stuff on my face,” she said.

headline: ‘Falstaff’ Costumes
text: Designing opera costumes in an era of high-tech challenges.

headline: The Gun Report: November 27, 2013
text: The gun violence we cover fades from the headlines after a day or two, when we’re onto the next batch. Here are follow-ups to some notable recent shootings we’ve covered in the report.

headline: Letters: The President and the Press
text: The President and the Press

headline: Music of the Season Taking Center Stage
text: All across Long Island this month, the holidays are being rung in with music including rock, pop and classical, at venues both traditional and less so. Here is a sampling of what is around.

headline: Art and Technology
text: ‘HOVER FLY’ and ‘MUSHROOM GILLS’ By Susumu Nishinaga, Japan

headline: A Surge in Value for Bitcoin and Currencies Similar to It
text: This has been quite the week for the peer-to-peer digital currencies. Exactly seven days ago, Bitcoin, the digital cryptocurrency, was trading at about $615, but early Wednesday morning it had passed $1,000 on Mt.Gox, the leading Bitcoin exchange, setting a new high. This pushed Bitcoin’s market capitalization to over $11 billion.

headline: Tom Perrotta: By the Book
text: The author of “Little Children,” “Election” and “The Leftovers” had to force himself to finish “Lolita”: “All that sparkling wordplay just got exhausting after a while.”

headline: How Long Does It Take to Shelve 23,000 Albums?
text: The biggest record store in New York City, Rough Trade NYC, opened in Williamsburg on Monday. The store carries approximately 23,000 CDs and vinyl records, and it took 20 employees plus various friends and family members 30 hours, over three days, to stock the shelves in time for the store’s opening party. They’ve still only stocked about two-thirds of their complete inventory, according to Stephen Godfroy, one of the owners.

headline: Grief and Heroism as Survivors Struggle in the Philippines
text: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — Jomar Pascual stirred a steel pot full of instant noodles carefully in a typhoon-damaged former kindergarten building. He had already cooked rice. His three younger brothers and a younger sister, suddenly orphans like him, were hungry, and he began to feed them, spooning the pallid meal onto their green plastic plates.

headline: Lorde Reigns at No. 1; Lady Gaga’s Sales Fall Sharply
text: On the music charts these days, it’s good to be Eminem. And really good to be Lorde. But not nearly as good to be Lady Gaga.

headline: Bryant Alone Can’t Carry the Lakers
text: As the architect of the 1990s, six-time champion Chicago Bulls, Jerry Krause was quoted as saying that players and coaches do not win championships; organizations do. Krause insisted he was misquoted because, he said, one word — “alone,” after “championships” — had been dropped.

headline: Saul Leiter, Photographer Who Captured New York’s Palette, Dies at 89
text: New York at midcentury was a monochrome town, or so its best-known documentarians would have us believe.

headline: Stylishly Smooth, Roughly Edged
text: “I don’t see enough lights,” Jaheim said, strutting across the Theater at Madison Square Garden stage on Tuesday night. “I got to do Luther right.”

headline: In Performance: David Harewood
text: The actor David Harewood in a scene as Oberon from Julie Taymor’s new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the West Bank, India, Ukraine and Egypt.

headline: Always an England
text: Jane Ridley’s book is timely in a double sense. When the British edition was released shortly after the 2012 Diamond Jubilee summer, America was still perplexed by the high point of that comically un-summery event as an armada-size flotilla of “tugboats and garbage barges” (Jon Stewart’s sardonic description) passed in hours’ long chugging convoy down the Thames, rain pelting remorselessly. Saluting on the dank royal barge were the freezing 86-year-old monarch and her nearly 91-year-old consort. The riverbanks were crowded with a million sodden subjects, roaring jubilantly. What, had Americans wondered, was that all about? Ridley’s book will go some way toward explaining.

headline: The Lure of a Brave New World
text: Since my last post dealt with the problems inherent in the various strategies for resisting modern society’s potential drift toward a kind of dystopic, Aldous Huxleyan destination, let me add, as a kind of pre-Thanksgiving coda, an example of how that drift tends to be packaged and sold by people who don’t see it as something to be resisted in the first place.

headline: Broadway Can Hear the Echoes of Jazz Tap
text: Is great tap dance on Broadway a thing of the past? In one sense, apparently not. “After Midnight,” the jazz revue that opened at the Brooks Atkinson this month, showcases some of the best, most state-of-the-art tapping presented in a Broadway theater in many a year. Funny thing is, it’s set in 1932.

headline: Another Round in Legal Battle Over Firing at El Museo del Barrio
text: The legal battle continues between Margarita Aguilar and officials at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan after her firing as director of the museum earlier this year and her subsequent claim that she was the victim of gender discrimination and a hostile workplace. The New York State Division of Human Rights dismissed her complaints in September. Ms. Aguilar is now calling for that dismissal to be set aside, citing a shoddy investigation.

headline: The Vaccination Effect: 100 Million Cases of Contagious Disease Prevented
text: Vaccination programs for children have prevented more than 100 million cases of serious contagious disease in the United States since 1924, according to a new study published in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Hospital Studies Link Heart Device to Clots
text: Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic began to suspect in 2012 that something might be wrong with a high-tech implant used to treat patients with advanced heart failure like former Vice President Dick Cheney.

headline: Gender Benders
text: As a new crop of cross-dressing actors appears in drag, a fresh look at some of the best in the genre, then and now.

headline: New Romanian Cinema
text: Select images from films in the series at the Film Society of Lincoln center.

headline: A Defaced Gap Ad Goes From the Subway to the Web to Its Demise
text: As the New York City-based photographer Robert Gerhardt waited last Sunday for the No. 6 subway train to take him from the Bronx to Manhattan, he spotted a poster from Gap’s “Make Love” ad campaign. It featured a female model and a man wearing the distinctive turban of the Sikh religion.

headline: Dim Sum, and Much More, in a No-Frills Setting
text: A friend of mine advised caution when I told him I was visiting Great Wall Restaurant in New Haven, noting the tripe and chicken feet on the menu. In fact, both are delicious, but the restaurant also offers pages of less adventuresome options.

headline: A Soldier’s Nightmare Follows Her Back Home
text: Charles Fuller tackles a searing subject — sexual assault in the armed forces — in his new play, “One Night ...,” set in a dingy motel room where two former soldiers have taken refuge after the shelter they were staying in caught fire. With increasing attention being paid to the alarming frequency of rape in the United States military — there are three competing pieces of legislation on the issue being considered by Congress — Mr. Fuller’s play could hardly be more timely.

headline: Discovering the D.J. Caroline Corley, Only to Quickly Lose Her
text: On Monday, as I often do, I tuned into Caroline Corley’s morning show on the Peak (107.1 FM in New York) during my commute to work.

headline: After 35 Years, They Know Their Fish
text: If the server at P.F. Market says to order the halibut, order it. The staff at this hybrid restaurant and fish market in West Caldwell knows what’s good, and happily for fish lovers, many of the 16 or so varieties of seafood available daily are fresher and more flavorful than at many inland restaurants.

headline: Yes, Survival’s Important. But Then What?
text: People do what they need to do in “Sunset Baby,” Dominique Morisseau’s smart and bracing new play about two generations of urban outlaws struggling to stay afloat in the lower depths. That can mean, among other things, lying to, stealing from, blackmailing and pulling a gun on your nearest and dearest.

headline: Zeke Jabbour’s Game at the Truscott Event
text: The American Contract Bridge League’s Fall North American Championships get underway in earnest on Friday in Phoenix.

headline: Some Still Like It Hot
text: Men in frocks, a tradition as ancient as Aeschylus, has been revived time and again onstage, in clubs and sometimes in the broadest strokes, at the suburban megaplex. Wherever she appears, though, the sight of a burly man compressed in a curve-hugging mermaid gown rarely fails to elicit in audiences a queasy mix of empathy and raucous laughter.

headline: Robert Hammond: Leaving the High Life
text: On a Sunday morning in early November, as Robert Hammond was taking one of his last official walks along the High Line, the urban park he helped develop 14 years ago, he was approached by a tall, well-dressed man who seemed to recognize him.

headline: Kerry and Zarif Turn to Selling Nuclear Deal to Skeptics Back Home
text: Having finally reached an interim agreement to freeze Iran’s nuclear program in Geneva on Saturday, Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, turned their attention this week to selling the deal to skeptics back home.

headline: Thai Classics in a Spot Known for Them
text: For more than a decade, 25 Main Street has been Thai food central in Kings Park. Bangkok Pavilion, which opened in September, is the latest in a series of Thai restaurants there. This one looks like a keeper.

text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Acid-Attack Trial, Dancers Trade Stage for Stand
text: MOSCOW — Dancers of the Bolshoi Ballet occupied a different stage on Wednesday as a procession of performers took the witness stand to defend the reputation of the troupe’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, who was the victim of an acid attack and — during the trial of those accused of involvement in the assault — the subject of denunciations by present and former company members.

headline: A Textbook Lecture With Tropical Heat
text: Three years ago, Patricia Hoffbauer presented  "Para-Dice (Stage 1)” at Danspace Project, as part of a platform called “certain difficulties, certain joy.”

headline: Pecan Shortage Raises Prices
text: Grocery store prices for pecans are up by 30 percent, which is causing Thanksgiving bakers to think twice about their menus.

headline: Times Minute: Nov. 27 at 6 p.m.
text: Online health care sign-up is delayed for small businesses; Silvio Berlusconi is expelled from Italy's Senate; and how to carve a turkey.

headline: In Search of the Perfect Holiday Drink
text: Whether you’re expecting a handful of holiday drop-ins or hosting a spirited party, a well-made cocktail can set the tone. As restaurants around the county are raising their mixology standards, consider enhancing your home efforts with this advice from behind-the-bar pros.

headline: Small Business Health Exchanges Delayed Again
text: With little more than a month before the new year — and many small businesses under pressure to make a decision about health insurance plans for 2014 — the Obama administration on Wednesday announced that the federally run small-business health insurance exchanges will not accept online enrollments for another year, until November 2014. It also announced that in the meantime, small businesses can enroll in exchange-listed plans through an insurance agent or broker, or directly with the carrier.

headline: Wines for Dessert, or Just for Fun
text: Dessert wines, which accompany all sorts of final dinner courses and sometimes serve as such courses in themselves, are a charming feature of Long Island vintners’ portfolios.

text: Suzanne Cooke bought a large and sunny one-bedroom in the Clinton Hill Co-ops in Brooklyn in 2000. She lived there happily while working in the television field.

headline: No Charges for Officers Who Killed Harlem Man
text: A grand jury has decided not to bring charges against police officers involved in the fatal 2012 shooting of Mohamed Bah, a 27-year-old Guinean immigrant who apparently had a mental breakdown and lunged at officers with a knife, the Manhattan district attorney said on Wednesday.

headline: Navy Suspends 2nd Contractor After Evidence of Overbilling
text: The Navy said Wednesday that it had suspended a ship-supply company for significantly overcharging on a contract, the second such suspension since mid-September.

headline: With an Eye for the Artisanal
text: A week ago Monday, Khen Rinpoche, a Tibetan Buddhist monk, blessed Lisa Fox’s new store, LF8, in the East Village. Ms. Fox promotes artisans and designers like Natalie Chanin, whose handmade garments and home goods are sold under the Alabama Chanin label.

headline: Dreamscapes Are Made of These
text: “I’ve always had very vivid dreams, dating back to childhood,” said Kristin Victoria Barron, an interior and product designer. “I started seeing a Jungian analyst in college because these dreams would stay with me in my waking life.”

headline: Crackdown in Egypt Fuels New Dissent
text: There were street protests in Egypt’s two largest cites on Wednesday, amid signs that attempts by the military-backed government to stifle dissent were fueling a backlash.

headline: Chandeliers That Like a Little Primping
text: Your chandelier need not be a permanent fixture, but can swing with the times. Michael McHale, a lighting designer, has created the Raw Collection, chandeliers whose looks can be easily transformed. The lights are made of black steel pipes covered with a grid of galvanized steel cable. They can be displayed in their naked form, but they are really meant as platforms for adornment. Festoon them with your own decorations, or buy kits from Mr. McHale. Two are available, with the promise of more to follow: an arrangement of plants ($940) by Matthew David, a floral designer, and a concoction of colorful Plexiglas ($680), below, by an East Village resident known as Billy the Artist. Neither version requires tools to install. The chandeliers will be introduced next week at Design Miami. The fixture is $980; 347-688-0070 or michaelmchaledesigns.com.

headline: Well-Appointed Kitchens Have Wish Lists, Too
text: Charlotte and Peter Fiell, a couple who have written many books about international design, are now giving advice about what to buy. They recently published “Essential Equipment for the Kitchen: A Sourcebook of the World’s Best Designs” (Goodman Fiell, about $30).

headline: Inspector Who Pepper-Sprayed Protesters Is Ordered to Appear Before Panel
text: The police commander whose pepper spraying of several women sparked sharp criticism of the New York Police Department’s response to the Occupy Wall Street protests has been ordered to appear before investigators and account for his actions, a state judge has ruled.

headline: A Talking Mailbox That Growls
text: The product designer Gauri Nanda, 34, is best known for waking up adults, and now she is giving children their first phones. In 2006, fresh out of M.I.T. graduate school, she introduced Clocky, a wheeled alarm clock that noisily runs away if no one turns it off. More than 600,000 Clockys and their spherical cousins, Tockys, have been sold through her company, Nanda Home. Her latest idea, Toymail, is a line of plastic miniature mailboxes with animal faces. They play messages sent from phones, and children can send recorded replies by pressing simple arrow buttons. Ms. Nanda spoke at her all-white Brooklyn apartment about how she and her co-developer, Audry Hill, finalized the creatures (expected to sell for $55, plus a minimal charge per message) and how young testers for Toymail Co. are reacting. (This interview has been condensed and edited.)

headline: How Do I Tackle Clutter?
text: Q. I have a small bathroom and end up storing my toiletries on the edge of the tub. How do I tackle the clutter?

headline: Gifts With a Twist of Nostalgia
text: In 1966, Hans Harald Rath of the Austrian company J. & L. Lobmeyr traveled to New York to present his design for chandeliers for the Metropolitan Opera House at the new Lincoln Center. The building’s architect, Wallace K. Harrison, rejected the proposal outright.

headline: The Masculine Mystique
text: Breakthrough ideas often come from the least expected sources.

headline: Vonn Hit a Tricky Turn, Coach Says
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — As Lindsey Vonn’s teammates trained on the downhill course on Wednesday, new details emerged about the crash that reinjured her right knee on Nov. 19 at Copper Mountain, Colo.

headline: Arik Einstein, 74, Beloved Israeli Singer, Dies
text: JERUSALEM — Arik Einstein, an Israeli singer and songwriter whose blend of folk and rock helped shape a new Hebrew popular culture and whose ballads became modern Israeli anthems, died on Nov. 26 in Tel Aviv. He was 74.

headline: A Scourge of Crops
text: Millions are being spent on stopping the stink bug’s rampage.

headline: The Benefits of a Trip to the Museum
Wanted Dead or Alive (No, Just Dead)
text: This Thanksgiving, I’ll be thanking the bugs, not the turkeys, for sustaining me in the wilderness. In my case, the wilderness was of the stink-bug variety.

headline: A Rustic Haven for a Life Remade
text: Most days, Alison Aldrich walks from her co-op in the West Village to the stately old building on Washington Square Park where she works as a professor at New York University. There, each year, she helps train a few hundred new social workers, many of whom will fan out into the city she has adored since moving here as a 19-year-old newlywed in 1965.

Christie Is Said to Waffle on In-State Tuition for People Living in U.S. Illegally
text: During his re-election campaign this year, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey made the Latino vote a priority, hiring a full-time director for Hispanic outreach, opening bilingual campaign offices and securing key Latino endorsements.

headline: 3 States End Resistance to Spousal Benefits Order
text: Texas, Oklahoma and West Virginia are now complying with an order from Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel requiring state National Guard units to process federal marriage benefits for same-sex spouses of guardsmen, according to the Department of Defense. Mr. Hagel issued the order — which also extended benefits to same-sex spouses of military service members — after the Supreme Court struck down a law this summer that had prevented federal recognition of same-sex marriages. At one point, nine states had objected to Mr. Hagel’s order, citing conflicts with state laws that do not recognize gay marriages. As a result, same-sex National Guard spouses in those states could sign up for benefits only by traveling to a federal military installation. As of Wednesday, only Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana were still defying Mr. Hagel’s order, said a spokesman for the National Guard Bureau in Washington.

headline: A Local Bakery That Draws From Afar
text: La Tropezienne in East Harlem offers traditional French baked goods, and its sandwiches are particularly popular with West African cabbies.

headline: Retirement Secured for Chimpanzees
text: It’s a good Thanksgiving for about 300 research chimpanzees headed for retirement. President Obama signed a bill on Wednesday removing a cap on spending for federally owned chimpanzees in sanctuaries. The change does not involve any budget increase. But it allows the National Institutes of Health to spend money to support the chimps in retirement that would have been used to support them in research labs. The institutes announced in June that the 300 would be retired, leaving only about 50 for potential future research needs.

headline: Official Quits in Backlash Over Colorado Gun Vote
text: DENVER — A populist backlash against Colorado’s new gun-control laws claimed its third political casualty on Wednesday as a Democratic state senator resigned her seat rather than face a recall vote that could have cost her party control of the chamber.

headline: French Flavor by the East River
text: The customers at La Tropezienne packed in tightly near the counter on a recent Sunday morning, bundled in coats and gently shouting over one another. Babacar Mbaye, 40, gave an assertive “Hello!” in order to be noticed. Originally from Gambia, he said he drove his cab to this little bakery and patisserie in East Harlem mainly for the coffee (but also for three croissants: two chocolate, one cinnamon).

headline: Illinois Lawmakers Say They Have Plan to Fix Underfunded Pension System
text: CHICAGO — Leaders of the Illinois legislature on Wednesday announced that they had found, at long last, a way to repair the state’s deeply troubled pension system, which has been deemed among the most underfunded public systems in the nation, has jeopardized the state’s financial stability and has become a political risk for state leaders.

headline: For Fervent Fans of the Dutch Masters, ‘It’s a Dream Come True’
text: Shin-Ichi Fukuoka, a molecular biologist from Tokyo, really — really — loves Johannes Vermeer. He has traveled around the world to visit 34 of the 36 paintings known or believed to be Vermeers.

headline: Thursday’s N.F.L. Matchups
text: Packers (5-5-1) at Lions (6-5)

headline: Democrats in Alaska Praise Palin
text: Democratic lawmakers remember Gov. Sarah Palin’s oil-profits taxes and oppose efforts by the Republican-controlled legislature to repeal her tax package.

headline: Not for Prime Time: Music Video With Iran’s President
text: TEHRAN — It might not make MTV, but a music video surfaced Wednesday honoring Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, and showing him alongside musical instruments — which are banned on state television — and women singing.

headline: Analyst Says SAC Trader Sought ‘Edgy’ Information
text: Jon Horvath needed to step up his game at SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Persistence in the Genes: Connecting the Dots to the Mayflower
text: A well-worn potato masher was a tantalizing clue.

headline: The Magic of Witch Hazel
text: There is something compelling about a plant flowering in autumn’s frosty grip, but our native witch hazel’s magic only begins there. Witch hazel (Hamamelis virginiana) is far better known as a bottled astringent than a native shrub. Its medicinal uses date back to the Native Americans, who taught Europeans how to identify the plant and decoct its leaves and stems into the now-familiar tonic.

headline: Moore, Rookie Giants Pass Rusher, Finds It Hard to Break Through
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants took defensive end Damontre Moore with their third pick in this year’s N.F.L. draft, General Manager Jerry Reese defined Moore’s worth in three words: “He is sacks.”

headline: Alaska Democrats See a Palin Legacy They Can Like
text: ANCHORAGE — For many Alaskans, Sarah Palin is a figure in the rearview mirror, the memories of her time as governor obscured and distorted by the national spotlight she stepped into as Republican vice-presidential candidate, pundit and Tea Party darling. And often as not the memories come with a grumble anyway, since her shooting-star career mostly took off after leaving the state.

headline: The Seeming Resurrection of Comet ISON
text: Updated 5:39p.m., Nov. 29 | After astronomers initially believed Comet ISON had melted away following its close encounter with the sun on Thursday, they had second thoughts on Friday, as we report here.

headline: Here’s to the Better Angels of the Sports World
text: In a sports year often interrupted by sorrow and scandal, more than ever some deserve a Thanksgiving Day thank-you:

headline: Deadly Accident at Stadium Raises Worry on Brazil’s World Cup Aims
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — At least two workers were killed on Wednesday when a construction crane collapsed at the stadium in São Paulo where Brazil plans to hold the opening game of next year’s World Cup, raising concerns over the country’s ability to finish an array of lavish arenas that have been plagued by delays and cost overruns.

headline: A Part of Utah Built on Coal Wonders What Comes Next
text: PRICE, Utah — For generations, coal has been the lifeblood of this mineral-rich stretch of eastern Utah. Mining families proudly recall all the years they toiled underground. Supply companies line the town streets. Above the road that winds toward the mines, a soot-smudged miner peers out from a billboard with the slogan “Coal = Jobs.”

headline: When the First Hurdle Is Remembering
text: Her memory ravaged by damage done to her brain, Nikkiya Simmonds, 32, returned to an apartment that might as well have belonged to a stranger. It was a cozy dwelling, strewn with cute knickknacks and calming artwork that she was tickled to learn that she had chosen, that she was, indeed, home.

headline: Where Is the Love?
text: When I’ve written recently about food stamp recipients, the uninsured and prison inmates, I’ve had plenty of pushback from readers.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 27, 2013
Secret Weapon in Mall Battle: Parking Apps
text: Phoebe Scott of Orange County, Calif., has a new routine before heading to the mall.

headline: Giving Thanks
text: Tuesday morning, I got a call about a girl — now a woman — whom I had gone to grade school with. She was gravely ill. Cancer. It had spread to her brain, I was told. From where, it wasn’t clear. She was on life support. By early afternoon her childhood friend and next-door neighbor had posted on Facebook:

headline: The Hard Charger at Obama’s Side Has His Hands Full
text: WASHINGTON — Denis McDonough was pacing the path on the South Lawn of the White House one day this fall, ruminating on the challenges of a second term for his boss, President Obama. Mr. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, likes to stroll outside from time to time. It helps clear his head when he has a lot on his mind.

headline: Doesn’t Eat, Doesn’t Pray and Doesn’t Love
text: The question of whether for-profit companies can claim a religious identity, one that exempts them from obeying a generally applicable law, is fully worthy of the attention the Supreme Court is about to give it. But to the extent that much of the commentary about the challenges to the Affordable Care Act’s contraception-coverage insurance mandate frames the issue as a debate about the rights of corporations – as a next step beyond Citizens United’s expansion of corporate free speech – I think it misses the point. What really makes these cases so rich, and the reason the court’s intervention will dramatically raise the temperature of the current term, lies elsewhere.

headline: After Football Player’s Death, California School Team Wavers, but Carries On
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — When DeAndre Thornton stretched every bit of his angular 6-foot-5 frame to catch a pass over the middle of the field, he could not immediately pull the ball down to protect himself. And so, when the hit arrived, with all the fury a 205-pound opponent with a running start could muster, the crunch of shoulder pads and helmets reverberated beyond the sidelines.

headline: Survivors Describe Fights and Fear After Haitian Migrants’ Boat Ran Aground
text: MIAMI — The Haitians piled onto the rickety vessel with visions of a new life in the United States. But five days into the voyage, the overloaded sailboat packed with 150 people ran aground and quickly broke apart. At least 30 people died in the frigid seas.

headline: China’s Move Puts Airspace in Spotlight
text: China’s proclamation of a new “air defense identification zone,” an obscure aviation term that became the catalyst for escalating military tensions with Japan and the United States this week, has thrown a broader spotlight on the control of international airspace, an issue that has created confusion, and danger, in other places affected by territorial disputes.

headline: End of an Era in Coal Country, Utah
text: The Carbon Power Plant, the state’s oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of new stricter federal pollution regulations.

headline: Loving Families, Lousy Meals
text: THANKSGIVING 2013 falls on my mother’s birthday, so I’ll begin by swearing that she was an excellent, ambitious cook who made her own blintzes, challah, marmalade and fudge. Her cakes were baked from scratch, and she had a repertory of five different custards (plain, rice, coconut, bread and Grape-Nut).

headline: Grief, Team Spirit and High School Football
text: The season has been one of raw emotions for Arlington High School in Riverside, Calif., after a football player, Tyler Lewellen, 16, sustained a head injury and later died.

headline: Silencing Dissent in Egypt
text: The military-backed government that has ruled Egypt for the past five months is looking increasingly like the old dictatorship of Hosni Mubarak without Mr. Mubarak. In the name of crushing all resistance by the Muslim Brotherhood supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the democratically elected president ousted by the military in July, Egyptian authorities have now moved to ban most public protests and threaten those who take part in them with jail or heavy fines.

headline: More Money to Treat AIDS Abroad
text: At a time when partisan bickering has crippled Congress, it is encouraging to find agreement on the important issue of curbing the global AIDS epidemic.

headline: The Perils of Polystyrene
text: Every year New York City residents throw away about 20,000 tons of plastic foam containers or, worse, the peanut-shaped packaging filler that sticks to anything in its path. Polystyrene foam is a plague on the environment. It is brittle. It breaks into pieces — sometimes very tiny pieces — that are devilishly hard to pick up. And there is no easy or cheap way to recycle it. New York City officials are considering a ban on foam containers and loose packaging. They should make it happen as soon as possible. Earlier this year the City Council speaker, Christine Quinn, made a pointed case for banning the substance. “It lives forever,” she said. “It’s worse than cockroaches.”

headline: Room at the Table
text: There may be a stranger at dinner today — the friend of a friend, the brother of a daughter’s roommate, a business acquaintance stuck in town, someone who reminds us how expandable this close-knit holiday really is. And there will surely be someone missing for whom we keep a place set in our thoughts. On Thanksgiving Day, we sit down with the memory of everyone who has shared this holiday with us, and perhaps with an unexpected stranger, the person who helps us tell this one Thanksgiving apart from all the others.

headline: During Lions Games, Giving Thanks While Gnashing Teeth
text: DETROIT — On Thanksgiving Day, Darin Idyle will be tailgating in a church parking lot, as he has every Thanksgiving for about a decade. Tim Harry will be bonding in Ford Field’s stands with his teenage son. And M. G. Shapiro’s family knows that his overtime rule is in effect once again — a tie score means he will be late for Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Tony Musante, Actor Known for Role in ‘Toma,’ Dies at 77
text: Tony Musante, a rugged-looking American actor who was seen on television, in films and on stage in the United States and Europe for over 50 years but who was probably best known for a TV series he left after one season, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Cult Classic
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle by Loren Muse Smith (who is making her New York Times debut today) and Jeff Chen is very clever. Even if you’re easily “squicked” out by SNAKES, you’re going to like this one. And there are two different ways to look at this answer, as it turns out. I’ll talk about how my noncaffeinated brain looked at it first.

headline: Mystery of Missing Mushrooms Leaves French Blaming Roma
text: PARIS — Guy Sant is distressed about the sorry state of his mushroom business this year. Usually in the autumn, when the weather turns brisk and the leaves begin to fall, his pickers gather 60 tons of wild fungi to satisfy European consumers, he said. This fall, they found only 16 tons. “I lost so much this year, I may have to close,” he said bleakly.

headline: Late to the Parade
text: Late to the parade.

headline: Savoring a Steak
text: CHRISTINE and I had been friends in high school — but only friends. Voted “Loveliest Lady” at the Coronation Ball, the signature social event of the Class of 1968, she was clearly out of my league. Plus, she already had a boyfriend. Tom was a suave older man of 21 who had graduated to that “real world” for which we high schoolers were being prepared via the manipulation of our slide rules, the firing up of our Bunsen burners, and our allemande-lefting and do-si-do-ing during the square dancing unit in gym. Two years later, Christine was Tom’s bride. I was a guest at their wedding.

headline: Egypt: 14 Female Protesters Receive 11-Year Sentences
text: A judge in Alexandria on Wednesday sentenced 14 women who participated in an Islamist protest last month to 11 years in prison, the state news media reported. In addition, seven girls ranging from 15 to 17 years old were also sentenced to an indeterminate term at a juvenile facility for joining the protest. The sentences, after an uncommonly swift trial, highlighted the severity of the military-led government’s crackdown on Islamists since the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi in July. Also on Wednesday, prosecutors ordered the arrests of two of the best known liberal activists in the country, Ahmed Maher and Alaa Abdel Fattah, for organizing what was called an unauthorized protest.

headline: The New Pope's New Direction
text: What does Pope Francis’s exhortation tell us about his priorities and plans? What obstacles will he face?

headline: Even After a Fortuitous Spill, the Nets See an Opportunity Slip Away
text: The tumbling Nets lost again, but this time, at least, the defeat came through bizarrely entertaining means.

headline: Bill Foulkes Dies at 81; Soccer Star Survived Team’s Plane Crash
text: The date Feb. 6, 1958, has long haunted the British consciousness. It was then that a plane carrying the Manchester United soccer team crashed while taking off from the Munich airport, killing 23 of 44 passengers, including eight starting players.

headline: Behind the Chinese-Pakistani Nuclear Deal
text: The prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, announced this week that China would help build two nuclear power reactors in Karachi, a port city with chronic electricity shortages. The deal marks a big step in nuclear energy cooperation between China and Pakistan, but financing and other important parts of the project have yet to be settled. Here is an explanation:

headline: The Hague: Eased Rules May Affect Trials of 2 Kenyans
text: Member states of the International Criminal Court eased the trial rules on Wednesday in ways that could enable Kenya’s two top leaders, facing prosecution on charges that include crimes against humanity, to avoid personal appearances and even miss parts of the proceedings against them, news agencies reported. The changes, which apply to suspects who hold high office, had been strongly advocated by Kenya and other African members that have criticized what they call the court’s unfair focus on prosecuting African political figures. President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto, have pleaded not guilty to charges that they were responsible for deadly violence after the 2007 elections. They have also asserted that the trials interfere with their ability to govern Kenya. Mr. Ruto’s trial has begun, and Mr. Kenyatta’s is scheduled to begin in February.

headline: Victorian Style Makes a Comeback
text: The Victorian aesthetic — high collars, leg-o-mutton sleeves, pearl trim — is having a renaissance. In the modern interpretation, minimalism is key and military references abound. Metallics are often paired with black so that they pop — as in the oversize brass buttons on a slim Balmain topcoat; the gold hardware on a simple Dolce & Gabbana bag and a Givenchy belt; and the trim around a dainty Phoebe Coleman lacquered pinkie ring. The ornate decoration of a simple Erdem skirt and round Monica Rich Kosann earrings are the essence of restrained elegance. Lace-up booties by Tabitha Simmons and a crown-shaped pendant necklace by Katie Mullally offer especially Anglophilic takes on the trend.

headline: 4 Hit and Killed by Cars in New York City
text: Four people were hit by cars and killed across the city on Wednesday, including two women who were hit by a single vehicle while crossing the street on Staten Island, the police said. The circumstances of each of the crashes were still under investigation as of midnight on Thursday. No one was immediately charged with a crime.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 9 A.M. (NBC) MACY’S THANKSGIVING DAY PARADE Matt Lauer, Al Roker and Savannah Guthrie host this 87th installment of the parade, with appearances by the Big Apple Circus; Kristin Chenoweth; the Cherokee National Youth Choir; Cirque du Soleil, Gavin DeGraw; Brett Eldredge; Fall Out Boy; Jimmy Fallon; Kellie Pickler; the Roots with the cast of “Sesame Street”; Florida Georgia Line; Megan Hilty; Joan Jett and the Blackhearts; Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings; Miss America 2014, Nina Davuluri; the retired N.F.L. players Bart Oates, Amani Toomer and Hines Ward; the retired N.H.L. players Cam Neely and Mike Richter; the Robertson family from “Duck Dynasty”; and the Radio City Rockettes. The casts of the Broadway shows “Matilda” and “Motown: The Musical” perform. So does Carrie Underwood, in her role as Maria in “The Sound of Music Live!,” next Thursday on NBC. Soaring above it all, weather permitting: Spider-Man; a 47-foot-tall balloon featuring portraits of characters from “The Wizard of Oz” and carrying the Wizard himself, in anticipation of the film’s 75th anniversary next year; Snoopy and Woodstock, in a 40th-anniversary tribute to “A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving”; and a spinning dreidel to celebrate Hanukkah.

headline: A Second Career as a Pastor, Schooled by the Homeless
text: The airplane that crashed had been heading to Greenville, S.C., where I was a reporter.

headline: The Art of the Carve
text: In 2007, The Times asked Ray Venezia, a butcher and then the head of the meat department at Fairway Market, to demonstrate how to carve a Thanksgiving turkey.

headline: Yao Ming on Third Year as a College Student
text: On class days, Yao Ming, the 7-foot-6 retired N.B.A. center, wakes up at the crack of dawn to beat the Shanghai traffic. Carrying a lunch prepared by his wife, Ye Li, a 6-foot-3 former player in China’s professional league, Mr. Yao drives more than an hour to Jiao Tong University, where he sits through his required courses in the economics and management department. According to one Chinese news report, Mr. Yao would prefer to live in the dorms with his 20-year-old classmates, a move that would save time and energy, “but the beds are too small.”

headline: Managing Editor of Newsmagazine Resigns Amid Sexual Assault Controversy
text: NEW DELHI — The managing editor of the newsmagazine Tehelka, whose editor in chief has been charged in the sexual assault of a junior reporter, resigned Thursday morning in an email to the staff, citing the growing controversy over her handling of the initial complaint.

headline: Corrections: November 28, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: No Solutions in Sight, Knicks Lose Seventh Straight
text: LOS ANGELES — J. R. Smith flew across the lane, the back of his untucked jersey flapping behind him. He was determined to do something Wednesday night to salvage the Knicks’ fourth-quarter hopes, and it came in the form of a flat-footed lob that the Clippers’ DeAndre Jordan batted away as soon as it left Smith’s hand.

headline: Happy Thanksgiving
text: We’re taking a brief break, until Monday, but we leave you with some reminders from Kid President, as well as a few ideas of our own:

headline: Protest This!
text: CAIRO — On Monday evening, Mohammed Adel, of the April 6 Youth Movement, and Ali Esam, of the liberal Constitution Party, headed to the Kasr El Nil police station, a pink stucco villa on a leafy side street in central Cairo. They came bearing an official request to hold a protest … against a protest law promulgated just the day before.

headline: Corruption Scandal Hits One of China’s Top Universities
text: Renmin University of China, in Beijing, one of the leading centers of higher learning in the country, conferred its first degrees this year in a new graduate program in combating corruption. Future classes now have a case study close to home to draw from.

headline: The Quest to Belong
text: With a grandchild about to be born in Atlanta, another on the way in Ho Chi Minh City, I have been thinking about the beginning of the family odyssey; of my great-grandfather, Isaac Michel, and his decision to leave the shtetl in northern Lithuania and head south from Russian pogroms toward the sun, the ostrich feathers, the gold and the promise of South Africa.

headline: Thailand’s Premier Survives Vote as Protests Continue
text: BANGKOK — Ignoring Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra’s victory in a parliamentary no-confidence vote, protesters in Thailand continued their campaign to shut down government offices, cutting power on Thursday to Bangkok’s police headquarters.

headline: China Patrols Air Zone Over Disputed Islands
text: BEIJING — China sent fighter jets on the first patrols of its new air defense zone over disputed islands in the East China Sea on Thursday, the state news agency, Xinhua, said.

headline: Julia Mancuso Carves Her Path in Lindsey Vonn’s Shadow
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Minutes after watching a helicopter pluck her injured teammate Lindsey Vonn from the super-G track at the Alpine world championships in Schladming, Austria, in February, Julia Mancuso raced down a foggy course to a third-place finish.

headline: Other Great Moments in Eating Fish Alone
text: Of the 11 films featured in this week’s Movies Issue, my hands-down favorite is Cate Blanchett’s fantastic exchange with a plate of fish, directed by Janusz Kaminski. When I watched it with my spouse at home, it reminded him of a poem by Billy Collins.

headline: A Not-So-Festive Season
text: When Zhang Xuyan accepted his cushy entry-level position at a major state-owned enterprise, the salary was not the main draw. Instead it was the unofficial benefits that lured him in: networking opportunities, close proximity to senior Communist Party members and, last but not least, the banquets and luxury gifts that the company regularly showered on its employees.

headline: How to Start a Year-Round Family Gratitude Ritual
text: Sometime this Thanksgiving or in the coming weeks, you and yours will probably share notes on the things for which you’re thankful.

headline: Ignore Karzai’s Arrogant Insults
text: WASHINGTON — What is going on with President Hamid Karzai? The world’s only superpower, leading a coalition of some 50 nations, is willing to stay on in his country after a war that has already lasted a dozen years and cost the United States more than $600 billion and more than 2,000 fatalities — and yet the Afghan president keeps throwing up roadblocks.

headline: Andhra Pradesh Heaves Sigh of Relief as Cyclone Lehar Becomes Deep Depression
text: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — Cyclone Lehar weakened to a deep depression over the Bay of Bengal on Thursday, to the relief of Andhra Pradesh disaster management officials, but the storm is still expected to bring heavy rain that could add to the damage caused by two previous cyclones over the past eight weeks.

headline: In Performance: David Harewood
text: In Julie Taymor’s new production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” David Harewood plays Oberon, the king of fairies, who is quarreling with his wife, the fairy queen Titania. In this scene he talks with the fairy Puck about a plan to make Titania “full of hateful fantasies” by having Puck apply the juice of a magic flower to her eyes so she falls in love with the first thing she sees when she wakes up.

headline: Linking Genes to Diseases by Sifting Through Electronic Medical Records
text: The days of scrawled doctor’s notes are slowly coming to a close. In the United States, 93 percent of hospitals are now using at least some electronic medical records and 2.2 percent have given up paper records completely, according to the consulting firm HIMSS Analytics.

headline: Giving Musical Thanks on Thanksgiving
text: On Thanksgiving (and Hannukah), here’s a quick note — and song — of thanks to you for reading this blog, for attending to the issues and opportunities facing humanity as we come of age on a finite planet and, for those who comment here, trying to maintain a constructive approach.

headline: Balloons Fly Low, but Parade Delights
text: To the joy of children and the relief of parents endlessly checking the weather report and bracing for their little ones’ dashed hopes, New York officials gave the giant balloons the all-clear Thursday morning to fly in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: T HOLIDAY
text: Evening sandals merge comfort with festiveness, and add a wink of hauteur without the heel.

headline: Holiday | The Daily Gift: Virginia Johnson Pouch
text: Every day from now until Christmas, the editors of T are sharing their personal gift suggestions.

headline: A Thanksgivukkah Song
text: Dear Diary:

headline: UBS Consolidates, and Shifts Executives, in Effort to Shrink Its Investment Bank
text: LONDON – The Swiss bank UBS is combining its currency, interest rates and credit trading businesses into one unit, according to a memo circulated at the bank earlier this month.

headline: Image of the Day: November 28
text: A cauliflower field in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Insert Homeless Headline Here
text: You can call this post: Don’t Let Them Eat Cake. Or, Let Them Eat Cake Somewhere Else. Or Hide the Cake Altogether.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Invited to Iranian Facility
text: LONDON — Days after Iran struck a landmark accord with world powers on its nuclear program, the International Atomic Energy Agency announced on Thursday that Tehran had invited its inspectors to visit a heavy-water production plant linked to the deal — the first tangible step since the agreement was concluded.

headline: Getting the Volcker Rule Done
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: E.U. Eases Rules on Liquids on Planes
text: The European Union will begin lifting restrictions on liquids, aerosols and gels at airports in its 28 member countries in phases, beginning in January, with the goal of completely eliminating the ban by January 2016. “What is happening in January is a small first step,” Dale Kidd, press officer for Transport at the European Commission in Brussels, said in a telephone interview.

headline: Europe vs. Amazon: Anger Rising
text: On its home territory, Amazon.com is routinely hailed as a jobs machine. Thanks to its warehouse building spree, it is hiring tens of thousands of workers, plus many more for the holidays. President Obama, speaking at the retailer’s Chattanooga, Tenn., warehouse in July, called Amazon “a great example of what’s possible.”

headline: A Scientist Predicts the Future
text: When making predictions, I have two criteria: the laws of physics must be obeyed and prototypes must exist that demonstrate “proof of principle.” I’ve interviewed more than 300 of the world’s top scientists, and many allowed me into laboratories where they are inventing the future. Their accomplishments and dreams are eye-opening. From my conversations with them, here’s a glimpse of what to expect in the coming decades:

headline: In Our Pages: November 29
text: 1913: Rebels Destroy Ciudad Victoria

headline: Orange to Sell Dominican Telecom Business
text: LONDON – The French telecommunications company Orange has reached an agreement to sell its Dominican Republic operations to the Luxembourg cable and broadband provider Altice for $1.4 billion.

headline: Once for Women Only, Georgian Court Looks to Men’s Teams to Raise Profile
text: LAKEWOOD, N.J. — Luka Zgonjanin arrived in the United States from Serbia in August, barely able to speak English. He had accepted a scholarship to play basketball at Georgian Court, a small liberal arts university on the outskirts of the Jersey Shore. A few months earlier, he had never heard of the college.

headline: 36 Hours in Shanghai
text: What takes most cities eons to build, Shanghai can do overnight. Consider this: Just a decade ago, the city had four metro lines; now there are a dozen. The Jin Mao Tower was the tallest building in the neon-streaked financial center of Pudong; it has since been surpassed by the Shanghai World Financial Center and the nearly completed Shanghai Tower, which will be the second-tallest building in the world (after Dubai’s Burj Khalifa) when it’s finished next year. Still, what fascinates about this city is how little seems to have changed in the maze of lanes that have (thus far) eluded the bulldozer in the Old City or the former foreign concessions. Here, residents haggle over freshly caught fish in tiny markets or doze in lawn chairs on summer afternoons, ignoring the pounding jackhammers. Shanghai is remaking itself to become a “City of the Future,” but what’s so alluring is how much old-world character remains.

headline: In Cyprus, a New Spirit Animates the Capital
text: Europe’s last divided capital, Nicosia, Cyprus, is experiencing a renaissance with more and more venues catering to the artistic set. No longer wary of the demilitarized United Nations Buffer Zone that bisects the ancient walled city between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot sides, young Nicosians have reclaimed their old town. Emboldened by falling real estate prices, arty cafes, boutiques celebrating homegrown fashion and buzzy restaurants have opened among the Venetian fortifications and Byzantine churches on the Greek side. While beachgoers have long flocked to the coasts, the rebirth of the inland capital is evidence of a historic city in transition.

headline: Who Was Rick of Rick’s Place in Prospect Park?
text: Q. On a hill near the Midwood in Prospect Park, an old sign says “Rick’s Place,” without any elaboration. I am a Rick, but not that Rick. Who was the Rick of Rick’s Place, and why is this place named after him?

headline: On Beauty | A London Spa That Is One With Nature
text: Each of the four areas of the David Chipperfield-designed Akasha Holistic Wellbeing Centre, opening on Dec. 9 in London’s Café Royal hotel — a favorite among the likes of Miuccia Prada and L’Wren Scott — corresponds to a natural element: water (Watsu pool), fire (Canadian hemlock saunas), air (personalized yoga) and earth (a food bar that serves Champagne).

headline: Fighting ‘Rooster’ Returns to Ensemble Studio Theater
text: Odysseus Rex the Rooster is back. “The Year of the Rooster,” the critically lauded play about cockfighting by the 25-year-old playwright Eric Dufault, featuring Bobby Moreno as the central gladiatorial bird, will return to the Ensemble Studio Theater for a four-week run, Jan. 9 through Feb. 2, after a run this fall that Neil Genzlinger writing in The Times called “astonishingly entertaining.”

headline: The World in a Toothpick
text: Impatience is anathema to a toothpick artist, and Steven J. Backman was inoculated against it in second grade when he smashed one of his figures, a molecular model, in frustration, impaling his hand.

headline: Medicaid Growth Could Aggravate Doctor Shortage
text: SAN DIEGO — Dr. Ted Mazer is one of the few ear, nose and throat specialists in this region who treat low-income people on Medicaid, so many of his patients travel long distances to see him.

headline: South Carolina Threatens Washington Over Cleanup
text: AIKEN, S.C. — The Energy Department began cleaning up an environmental nightmare at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant here in 1996 and promised a bright future: Within a quarter-century, officials said, they would turn liquid radioactive bomb waste into a solid that could not spill or dissolve.

headline: Slowdown in Radioactive Waste Cleanup
text: Officials in South Carolina say the federal government has not met its promise to clean up waste at the old Savannah River Site nuclear weapons plant.

headline: A White House Menu, Heavy on the Pies
text: President Obama and his family will have a traditional Thanksgiving meal this holiday, enjoying a menu that will look familiar to many American families: Turkey, ham, stuffing and plenty on the side. What’s remarkable is the dessert menu: the number of pies rivals the number of dishes in the dinner menu itself.

headline: Reclaiming Label of a Progressive City
text: If you’re terrified, or merely curious, about Bill de Blasio’s mayoral agenda, then read “Toward a 21st Century City for All: Progressive Policies for New York City in 2013 and Beyond,” edited by John H. Mollenkopf (City University of New York).

headline: The Birth of Thanksgiving
text: Though we most often associate Thanksgiving with Pilgrims and New England Indians, the holiday, at least as an official national event, began 150 years ago, at the height of the Civil War.

headline: Taking Flight
text: Balloons floated down the route of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade after an early scare they might be grounded because of high winds.

headline: Feeling For | Decorative Hair Ornaments That Are Perfect for the Holidays
text: Sparkle this holiday season with golden clips, combs and pins that add a flash of decorative romance and make styling a breeze.

headline: Salinger Stories  ‘Leaked’ Online
text: Three previously unpublished short stories by J. D. Salinger have appeared online for the first time, apparently after an unauthorized edition of the stories was sold on eBay and its pages scanned and uploaded, Buzzfeed reported.

headline: Ready for Some Football. A Lot of It.
text: “What I do on a Sunday impacts what a lot of other people do on a Sunday,” said Brian Schwartz, the C.E.O. and co-founder of DraftStreet, a daily online fantasy sports site. Mr. Schwartz, who is 30 and lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan with his wife, Jaime, their year-old daughter, Liv, and a pet puggle, Bascom, wasn’t being arrogant; he was being accurate. Since it started in 2010, DraftStreet has acquired more than 350,000 users, he said. Most of them visit the site on Sundays during football season, which tend — at least in part — to be workdays for Mr. Schwartz. The company has its Fantasy Football Championship on Dec. 15.

text: BAROQUE AND MODERN,

headline: At Large in the Kingdom of Dreams
text: THE SANDMAN OMNIBUS

headline: A Film Nudge to Find the Folkie in You
text: “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers film set among Greenwich Village musicians in the early 1960s, is poised to generate a tidal wave of nostalgia — and stir interest among moviegoers who were unfamiliar with this milieu. It’s a safe bet that anyone who sees the film (opening next Friday) will want to know more about the folkie world that the Coens recreate so wittily and well. There are great ways to read, see and hear more about it.

headline: They’re Already Boxed, Now Just Wrap
text: DEEP catalog keeps getting deeper in the annual outpouring of boxed sets. The latest collections are less likely to be anthologies of hits — that’s been done — than plunges into the archives. Superstars are represented by alternate versions, outtakes, live tracks, remixes and official versions of long-bootlegged material. Unknowns, meanwhile, get a new hearing, as compilers and collectors work through the holdings of ever more obscure labels and producers. Annotators, for their part, piece together stories, and art directors enjoy creating packages larger than a CD case. Here, the critics of The New York Times delve into the year’s notable boxed sets. Prices may vary, depending on where the purchase is made.

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 29-Dec. 5
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Holden Caulfield Redux
text: “The Goldfinch,” Donna Tartt’s third novel in 20 years, set in an opaquely rendered Manhattan of the 21st century, has followed its predecessors, selling robustly, while its eponym, a 1654 painting by Carel Fabritius, has been drawing crowds to the Frick. In an apparently serendipitous feat of cross-promotion, the painting currently appears at the museum as part of an exhibition of Dutch masterworks from the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis in The Hague, a show that has drawn more than 61,000 visitors since its debut in October.

text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.
