text: In the Video

headline: A Thaw for Frosty Toes
text: Audis that need a new crankcase pressure valve and Corvettes low on differential oil are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Performer Available for Private Parties
text: Mazda fans are like the denizens of a cool underground speakeasy, hidden behind a false door and a mounted antelope head. They’d love people to know how much fun they’re having, but they may not want the masses to force their way inside.

headline: In Formula One, It’s Already 2014
text: The competition for the 2013 Formula One drivers championship may have officially ended last Sunday with Sebastian Vettel’s victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix, but as a practical matter this year’s campaign was over soon after it began.

headline: To Bring Back the Drivers, Rallies Add Brain-Teasers
text: ISLANDIA, N.Y. — One by one, the cars rolled out of the parking lot and onto the Long Island Expressway for the start of the 2013 Vintage Rally:

headline: A Chevy So Exclusive That You Can Only Borrow, Not Buy
text: Rental cars are rarely anything special. And that’s just fine. All you really need from a rental is unlimited miles, long-term shelter for a few stray curly fries and a hassle-free ride from A to B and back again before those martinets at the counter charge you for an additional day.

headline: Image of the Day: November 29
text: The Mypadu Beach in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Offerings From Nashville, the Kitchen and This Side of Twisted
text: Throwing Muses

headline: Angela Lansbury Returning to London Stage in ‘Blithe Spirit’
text: After a four-decade absence from the London stage Angela Lansbury, best known for her portrayals of the detective Jessica Fletcher in the television series “Murder, She Wrote” and the murderous pie-maker in “Sweeney Todd,” plans to make her return in March in a new production of the  Noël Coward comedy “Blithe Spirit.”  She will reprise her portrayal of Madame Arcati, the medium who communicates with Elvira, the deceased ex-wife of the novelist Charles Condomine. She won a Tony Award when she played the role on Broadway in 2009.

headline: Big Ticket | Outdoor Living, in NoHo for $23 Million
text: A statement-making condominium that monopolizes the eighth floor at 40 Bond Street, the 11-story emerald-green-glass apparition that brought a dash of Oz downtown to NoHo in 2007, sold for $23.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Night Watchman With Wheels?
text: The night watchman of the future is five feet tall, weighs 300 pounds and looks a lot like R2D2 — without the whimsy. And will work for $6.25 an hour.

headline: Helping a Shy Guy Build Up His Nerve
text: While having a cocktail at a bar with my sister and her boyfriend, a woman walked in alone, looked around and took a seat at the bar. I thought it might be the woman I’d chatted with the night before on OkCupid (a dating website), but I wasn’t sure. And even if I was, we had only exchanged a couple of short messages. I didn’t even know her name. Well, it turns out, it was her. But instead of a fortuitous encounter with an attractive woman, I was the creepy guy who wasn’t confident enough to say hello. What should I do the next time something like this happens?

headline: Coming Out as a Modern Family (Updated With Podcast)
text: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress and writer Maria Bello in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below or subscribe on iTunes or Stitcher.

headline: Increased Global Demand Aids India’s Mild Recovery
text: MUMBAI, India — India’s economy is showing signs of a gradual recovery as gross domestic product increased at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the three months that ended in September.

headline: Diamond-Paved, Deal-Obsessed
text: The diamond district, on a block of West 47th Street, pulses with the competition of the jewelry sellers, who are always looking for a way to make a deal.

headline: Diamond-Paved, Deal-Obsessed
text: The diamond district, on a block of West 47th Street, pulses with the competition of the jewelry sellers, who are always looking for a way to make a deal.

headline: Timing of Baby’s First Solids May Affect Allergy Risk
text: Breast-feeding exclusively for four to six months, and introducing solid foods while breast-feeding continues, may be a good way to reduce the risk for food allergies in children.

headline: Out of Syria, Into a European Maze
text: SYRACUSE, Sicily — As war rages on, more refugees are risking a journey to what they hope will be prosperous new lives.

headline: Jim Harrison’s Upper Peninsula
text: About 10 years ago, before we sold our farm in northern Michigan and moved to Montana, I was accustomed to driving the five hours north to a cabin we kept near Grand Marais on Lake Superior in the Upper Peninsula. I made the drive countless times over the 25 years my wife, Linda, and I owned the log cabin that sat in the middle of 60 acres bisected by the Sucker River. If you’d been spending a month at a time in Hollywood, which I frequently was as a screenwriter in those years, there’s nothing like returning to a farm with horses and chickens, and then on to a fairly remote cabin off a two-track road where when you try to sleep at night you hear a river flowing, probably the best sound on earth.

headline: Shore, Snow and Sky in the Upper Peninsula
text: Scenes from Michigan’s sparsely populated north country.

headline: This Is Las Vegas?
text: Just after dawn, when the steady clang of slot machines slowed to an irregular heartbeat and most of Las Vegas was soused or sleeping — I was jogging. The sidewalks were empty. They no longer belonged to hucksters, heartbreakers and flocks of friends, decked out and glassy-eyed. They belonged to me. I ran past the hushed fountains of the Bellagio, over eye-popping cards for escorts and strip clubs that littered the streets like ticker tape on my way to the first of several weekend fitness classes: Yoga Among the Dolphins.

headline: Week in Pictures for Nov. 29
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include autumn leaves, the first book printed in the new world, and the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: A Marriage Tests an Advice Columnist
text: When Amy Dickinson, 54, and Bruno Schickel, 57, married five-plus years ago, she imagined their marriage would be like a good romantic comedy.

headline: Another Flap Over Justin Bieber’s ‘Art’
text: Justin Bieber is discovering that growing up in public just isn’t the fun you might expect it to be. Having spent recent weeks creating a ruckus in Latin America, where he upset fans in Brazil and Argentina by cutting short concerts, had to apologize to Argentine fans for dragging their country’s flag across the stage, and angered authorities in Colombia and Brazil by spray painting graffiti on public walls, the 19-year-old singer has taken his entourage to Australia, where he’s found trouble again.

headline: Cardinals Pitcher Joins a New Team
text: Some say that the pitcher’s mound can be the loneliest place on earth, with so much resting on the pitcher’s rhythm, arm and accuracy. For Shelby Miller, a 23-year-old player on the roster of the St. Louis Cardinals, not being selected to pitch for his team in this year’s World Series put him in an even lonelier place.

headline: Brash C.E.O. Keeps the Giants of Mobile Off Balance
text: As recently as two years ago, T-Mobile had all but been given up for dead. It was losing subscribers and struggling to upgrade its aging cellular network. Its owner, Deutsche Telekom, said it wanted out of the competitive North American market, agreed to sell T-Mobile to AT&T for $39 billion and was already describing T-Mobile as a “discontinued” operation in its financial statements. In lobbying the government to approve the merger, AT&T warned ominously that a stand-alone T-Mobile would probably fail and consumers would suffer.

headline: When Coaching Gamesmanship Gets in the Way
text: HOUSTON — Jason Kidd came clean on Friday, two days after he contrived to spill a cup of soda on the court so that he could buy some time to draw up a final play in a game in which his Nets team was trailing and out of timeouts.

headline: A Joyous Reunion
text: Tragedy is common, when the refugees come ashore. But there is also joy, as there was when a man named Jaffar came to the harbor to look for his brother and two nephews.

headline: A Rescue at Sea
text: A boat packed with Syrian refugees fleeing the war bobbed in the sea about 50 miles off the southeastern coast of Sicily as the Italian Coast Guard approached.

headline: On the Importance of Little Arrows (Wonkish)
text: A new post by Stephen Williamson has both Nick Rowe and Brad DeLong fulminating — and rightly so. But my sense is that they are so shocked at the level of misconception on the part of a guy who imagines himself more sophisticated than crude neoKeynesians that they’re not managing to convey what’s really going on.

headline: Document | Who Let the Bengal Tiger Inside the Palace?
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Cast Change for Met Opera’s ‘Fledermaus’
text: Christine Schäfer, the soprano who was to have sung Adele in the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Johann Strauss Jr.’s “Fledermaus,” has withdrawn from the production because of illness, the Met said.

headline: The Spectacle and Sales of Black Friday
text: Market analysts researching the buying habits of Americans have noted a growing trend in online shopping on Black Friday, the frenetic day after Thanksgiving when retailers try to boost annual sales with steep discounts.

headline: On New Buses, It Will Be ‘Buckle Up’
text: A new seat belt rule is meant to make buses safer than ever.

headline: Abrupt End to Player’s Misery in Qatar
text: Zahir Belounis’s Qatari ordeal ended not with a letter or a visa stamp or even with a visit from an official delivering news of his impending departure from the emirate. It ended with a phone call telling him to leave the country, and quickly.

headline: Wheelies: The Claiming Carolina Edition
text: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Ways of Lust
text: HOW does lust affect the way we think about people?

headline: Martha
text: Inside the Fort Greene restaurant named after the patron saint of cooks.

headline: A Jam Session in the Kitchen
text: Rarely have I been so captivated by gruel.

headline: Without Vonn, Americans Struggle in Beaver Creek Downhill
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Missing Lindsey Vonn, who skipped the race after reinjuring her right knee Nov. 19, the United States women’s ski team failed to deliver podium results in the season-opening downhill event on Friday.

headline: Wired: Putting a Writer and Readers to a Test
text: Writers working on new books often complain about the pressure. But on a recent evening, the Dutch novelist Arnon Grunberg was sitting at a cluttered desk in his shoe-box apartment in Midtown Manhattan, with more reason to kvetch than most.

headline: London Mayor Raises Eyebrows, and Ire
text: LONDON — Boris Johnson, the flamboyant, self-mocking and ambitious mayor of London, has put his gilded foot in his mouth once again, suggesting that the poor of Britain are victims of low I.Q. and that greed is good.

headline: Market Report | Feminine Flats With a Little Extra Dazzle
text: Evening sandals merge comfort with festiveness, and add a wink of hauteur without the heel.

headline: Takeda Hires Glaxo Executive for a Top Post
text: TOKYO — Japan’s largest drug maker, Takeda Pharmaceutical, announced on Friday that it had hired a GlaxoSmithKline executive to be its next chief operating officer.

headline: Dark Chocolate and Pomegranate Bark
text: Tom Faglon makes homemade gifts for the holidays. His gift to Melissa Clark: a dark chocolate and pomegranate bark with just a hint of ginger and sea salt.

headline: In London ‘Slaves’ Case, 3 Women Isolated Under a Maoist Guru’s Sway
text: LONDON — They have become known as the “Brixton slaves,” three women who say they were held against their will for 30 years in a South London home.

headline: Treats From Their Kitchens to Yours
text: Chocolate bark is the workhorse of homemade holiday gifts: easy, crowd-pleasing, expected.

headline: Consumer Safety Chief Leaves a Small Agency With Bigger Powers
text: WASHINGTON — When Inez M. Tenenbaum took over the Consumer Product Safety Commission in 2009, she found an agency in turmoil and uncertain of its mission to ensure that tens of thousands of products on American store shelves did not present a danger to buyers.

headline: Insurance on the Person Who Makes the Business Run
text: WHEN Richard Manfredi was running his family’s manufacturing business, the company took out a large insurance policy on him. If he died, his partners would use the money to buy out his family’s interest. This is how these policies, known as key-man insurance, are typically used.

headline: Shying From Fame’s Spotlight
text: Lorde, the 17-year-old pop prodigy from New Zealand whose real name is Ella Yelich-O’Connor, is suddenly quite famous. Her first full-length album, “Pure Heroine,” entered the Billboard charts in October at No. 3. Its breakout single, “Royals,” (a.k.a. Bill de Blasio’s victory anthem) has sold over 3.7 million copies in the United States alone during nine weeks atop the Billboard Hot 100; she is the youngest solo artist to hit No. 1 since Tiffany in 1988. And just recently, Songs Music Publishing secured the publishing rights to her songs in a reported multimillion-dollar deal.

headline: At Art Basel Miami Beach, Squeezing Art Out of the Picture
text: Let’s play a game: Are the following parties taking place during New York Fashion Week or Art Basel Miami Beach?

headline: Roseanne Barr and Mindy Kaling: Funny Women, Serious Talk
text: ON A RECENT Saturday, the weather California-perfect, Roseanne Barr, the star and co-creator of the groundbreaking sitcom “Roseanne,” which ran on ABC from October 1988 to May 1997 (and now in heavy rotation on TVLand), and Mindy Kaling, the TV writer and actress (“The Office”), best-selling author (“Is Everybody Hanging Out Without Me?”) and now the creator and star of “The Mindy Project” on Fox, met for lunch at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

headline: Moving Beyond the Sad and the Angry to Write a Valediction for New Orleans
text: HBO’s “Treme” was an unlikely proposition from the start. It was predicated on a natural disaster, Hurricane Katrina, that happened five years before the show started, and that lag has always been awkward. The meticulous re-creation of not quite recent outrages — perpetrated by politicians no longer in office and cops already indicted — has made the show seem to be in a weird time warp all its own.

headline: Rat-a-Tap-Tap: From Minneapolis, Fast, Furious Footwork and a Beatboxer
text: The phrase “Feet Don’t Fail Me Now!” might evoke a cartoon character in a tough spot, lower extremities spinning. Or it might call to mind the title song of a Little Feat album. Both associations apply to “Feet Don’t Fail Me Now!,” the harmlessly entertaining display of music and tap-dancing skills finishing a run at the New Victory Theater.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Reasons for Gratitude
text: Thanksgiving in New York City is a warm family experience.

headline: Comet ISON, Presumed Dead, Shows New Life
text: Astronomers are marveling at the death and apparent resurrection of a comet that dove close to the sun on Thanksgiving.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Reasons for Gratitude
text: Thanksgiving in the city is a warm family experience. Even in Wednesday’s winds, outdoor food markets were filled. A woman (above) carried a 36-pound turkey. Piles of cranberries awaited shoppers, who were stylish but practical. The first holiday evergreens arrived, and a traveler burdened with a duffel could only wish for some help from a parade balloon.

headline: Twelfth Night
text: Musician Arngeir Hauksson plays a hurdy-gurdy at the Belasco Theater before a performance of “Twelfth Night.”

headline: Is This a Sackbut I Hear Before Me?
text: It is no ordinary Broadway pit band. Its period instruments — sackbuts, shawms and rauschpfeifes — are decidedly more Akademie für Alte Musik Berlin than Irving Berlin.

headline: Posole Offers a December Warm-Up
text: Gathering during the winter holidays is a universal rite for most people, no matter what our religious or secular persuasion.

headline: From Behind the Canvas
text: As the art mob descends on South Florida this week for the 12th edition of the cross-platform marketing frenzy that is Art Basel Miami Beach — private jets disgorging art sharks and their adviser remoras — one slight and fashionable figure will stand out.

headline: Looking Back at Last Year’s Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
text: The premier event at the Fall North American Championships being held in Phoenix is the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, which take place over the last three days, beginning on Friday. It is generally considered the hardest of the Big Three (Spingold Knockout Teams, Vanderbilt Knockout Teams and Reisinger) to win.

headline: Single Mother Needs a Man: It Must Be Christmas on TV
text: Back in 1965, Linus stepped forward and calmed the chaos of “A Charlie Brown Christmas,” the classic animated special, by reciting verses from the Gospel of Luke about the birth of Jesus. “That’s what Christmas is all about, Charlie Brown,” he concluded.

headline: The New Giggler Behind Late-Night Interviews
text: Pete Holmes was talking about his divorce on his new late-night talk show, and not for the first time. He had already told a guest, Allison Williams of HBO’s “Girls,” that his ex-wife cheated on him, but this time he took blame.

headline: Dancey, Trancey, and Dabs of Spice
text: Britney Spears has been promising that her new album, “Britney Jean,” is her “most personal album ever” since July, when she first tweeted the phrase. Fans might have hoped for a candid look at a turbulent life: child stardom as a Mouseketeer, reinvention as a teenage tease and then a trashy sex symbol, marriages, motherhood, public meltdowns, stints in rehab and her rebound as a hitmaker, a judge on “The X Factor” and, at the end of December, a performer starting a two-year residency in Las Vegas.

headline: Gains for Einhorn and Loeb Could Bode Well for Hedge Funds
text: Forget about Black Friday. November is looking as if it could be the month that puts many hedge funds solidly in the black for the year, at least based on performance numbers for two notable portfolios.

headline: Talk of the Turner Prize, Where, for One Thing, Talk Is Art
text: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland — On a recent morning, a group of teenagers stood in a room, now an art gallery in a former military barracks here, and stared at the bare white walls. They were searching for the work of Tino Sehgal, one of the four nominees for this year’s Turner Prize.

headline: It Takes a Lot of Money to Look This Good
text: Lori Zaslow runs her own matchmaking business, ProjectSoulmate.com, but for a long time her look suggested less entrepreneur than anything goes. When she finally decided she needed a more sophisticated persona, she worked with Amanda Sanders, an image consultant she had met at a playgroup for their young children in the basement of a friend’s home. For a business event, Ms. Sanders put Ms. Zaslow in a Marc Jacobs red cocktail dress and clip-on pearl earrings.

headline: Movie Review: 'Frozen'
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Frozen."

headline: Movie Review: 'Oldboy'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Oldboy.”

headline: Movie Review: 'Black Nativity'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Black Nativity."

headline: For Egypt’s New Rulers, Familiar Scapegoats
text: Updated, Saturday, 2:39 p.m. | This week, when Egypt’s military-backed government issued arrest warrants for Alaa Abd El Fattah and Ahmed Maher — two activist bloggers who helped drive the uprising that forced Hosni Mubarak from power in 2011 only to find themselves blamed for inciting unrest by each successive government — the same thought occurred to several readers of their popular Twitter feeds. “The only stability and reliability we have in Egypt,” the journalist Sharif Kouddous joked, “is that successive rulers never fail to arrest @alaa.”

headline: Daughters of Famous Politicians Create Media Brands
text: Last spring, in her role as NBC News special correspondent, Chelsea Clinton interviewed the designer Stella McCartney. The anchor Brian Williams introduced the segment by describing Ms. McCartney as “a young woman of high accomplishment who happens to have a famous father. Well, we happen to have one of those around here as well.”

headline: You’re Cute and Fired
text: Does it really pay to be beautiful? Unless you’re a model, perhaps not.

headline: Who Killed the Catchphrase?
text: Wassup.

headline: Friday Night Music: Back on the Chain Gang
text: Why? I have no idea, but I went browsing and found this amazing performance:

headline: Reality Intrudes at a Utopian Market in Brooklyn, With Light Fingers
text: The woman looked like any other grocery shopper that day until the general manager of the store, after a tip, peered at the feed from the security cameras.

headline: Week in Pictures for Nov. 29
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include autumn leaves, the first book printed in the new world, and the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: British Loan Provider’s Steep Rates Under Siege
text: LONDON — The promotional film depicted the humble, happy lives of a dozen customers of Wonga, Britain’s biggest so-called payday lender.

headline: Obamas Meet Fasting Protesters
text: President Obama and Michelle Obama visited three advocates for immigrants who have been fasting in a tent on the National Mall to press the House of Representatives to act on an immigration overhaul. The Obamas met with Eliseo Medina, a labor leader who is 67, and two other people who were in the 18th day of water-only fasts, and with 24 other activists who have observed shorter fasts. Mr. Obama expressed concern for the their health and told them he believes House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio is “sincere” about wanting to pass immigration legislation, said Beatriz Lopez, a spokeswoman for the protesters.

headline: Saturday’s Games to Watch
text: 1 ALABAMA at 4 AUBURN

headline: As Fund-Raisers in Congress, Women Break the Cash Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — The first time Senator Patty Murray ran for local office, she was so embarrassed to ask people for money for her campaign that she and her husband held a garage sale. But her generous husband could not stop himself from giving away an expensive lawn mower, she said, leaving the fund-raiser at a net loss.

headline: Through a Novel, a Window to an Author’s Beliefs
text: Nearly 20 years ago, when he was three books into an acclaimed literary career, Oscar Hijuelos delivered the manuscript of his new novel to his editor. It was a Christmas tale filled with the joy Mr. Hijuelos had always taken in with the trappings of yuletide, from manger scenes to oratorios to evergreens strung with lights.

headline: Seeking Top Toys, Good Housekeeping Puts Them to Test
text: The challenge to find the most popular toys for this holiday season started on a steamy July morning at the Good Housekeeping Research Institute in Hearst’s headquarters in Midtown Manhattan. Dozens of children gathered in testing rooms usually reserved for reviewing washing machines and vacuum cleaners. In a surprisingly quiet space, except for the buzz of toy planes and the occasional chirps of children’s voices, the testers bent over tea sets and sprawled out on their bellies to play with cars as Good Housekeeping employees in white lab coats scribbled notes on manila folders.

headline: Chemical Weapons Watchdog Rejects a Request by Syria to Convert Arms Sites
text: GENEVA — Despite Syria’s cooperation with stringent terms laid down by the United States and Russia for the destruction of its chemical weapons, a request from Syria to convert some of the facilities used in that program to other activities failed Friday to win the approval of the international chemical weapons watchdog.

headline: Lights Slowly Come Back in a Storm-Crippled Park
text: Along the Hudson River in the West Village, temporary lights mounted on minigenerators illuminated determined bicyclists and the occasional dog walker who were out despite a persistent rain one recent afternoon.

headline: Abortion Cases in Court Helped Tilt Democrats Against the Filibuster
text: WASHINGTON — Within hours of each other, two federal appeals courts handed down separate decisions that affirmed sharp new limits on abortion and birth control. One on Oct. 31 forced abortion clinics across Texas to close. The other, on Nov. 1, compared contraception to “a grave moral wrong” and sided with businesses that refused to provide it in health care coverage.

headline: At Duke, Football Is the New Basketball
text: DURHAM, N.C. — At a university where basketball reigns, the football team is suddenly the talk of campus.

headline: Banning the Negative Book Review
text: THE estimable online publication BuzzFeed has changed the rules of critical engagement. All I can say is “Bravo!”

headline: Patience Along the Path to Employment
text: For Victoria Serans-Vidal, 47, patience is not just a virtue; it’s a way of life.

headline: The Almost Year-End Quiz
text: On this weekend after Thanksgiving, it’s time to see how much you avid readers remember from 2013. No cheating, people!

headline: A Forced Adoption, a Lifetime Quest and a Longing That Never Waned
text: LONDON — PHILOMENA LEE is 80 now, and she has made peace with many things. Yet her voice still catches when she describes her last glimpse of her firstborn child as he was being taken away to be adopted by an American family.

headline: Statins by Numbers
text: PHILADELPHIA — MEDICINE is having its moneyball moment.

headline: In Naming Top Police Official, De Blasio May Signal Change
text: Bill de Blasio had just left the 2011 West Indian American Day parade in Brooklyn when he received an alarming call. Two black leaders he had been marching with, one of them a New York City councilman, had been handcuffed by the police.

headline: Matthew Bucksbaum, Mall Developer, Dies at 87
text: Matthew Bucksbaum, who co-founded a family shopping mall empire that helped transform the landscape of suburbia and the habits of American consumers, died on Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 87.

headline: For Some Folks, Life Is a Hill
text: I strongly reject the concept of respectability politics, which postulates that a style of dress or speech justifies injustice, and often violence, against particular groups of people or explains away the ravages of their inequality.

headline: Mideast Tensions Alarm U.N. Chief
text: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, expressed alarm on Friday about what he called the “increasingly dangerous situation on the ground” in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, fearful that it could threaten the revived peace talks on a two-state solution that have been underway for the past four months. Mr. Ban criticized an “escalation of violence and incitement” on both sides, including Israeli settlement building, the demolition of Palestinian structures in eastern Jerusalem, and rocket fire and tunneling by Gaza militants into Israel. He said acute financial difficulties at the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which administers aid to millions of Palestinians in Gaza, also had aggravated the situation. “We cannot afford to lose the current moment of opportunity,” he said.

headline: Television Revenue Fuels a Construction Boom in the Pac-12
text: Bill Moos works in sleepy Pullman, Wash., a speck on the map near the Idaho border, but outside, on Washington State’s campus, it can sound lately more like central Hong Kong. Drills buzz and hammers pound and shovels clank.

headline: More Disclosures About Stop-and-Frisk
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg has often defended New York City’s discredited stop-and-frisk program by arguing that it is necessary to cut crime. That claim was never credible; crime declined in cities that did not detain citizens millions of times over the course of the decade, as New York did, often without legitimate reason.

headline: Health Care Site Rushing to Make Fixes by Sunday
text: As the Obama administration’s weekend deadline for a smoothly functioning online marketplace for health insurance arrives, more than a month of frantic repair work is paying off with fewer crashes and error messages and speedier loading of pages, according to government officials, groups that help people enroll and experts involved in the project.

headline: Harry Potter’s Latest Adventure
text: Can Harry Potter’s magic lift the sagging fortunes of the United States Postal Service? That’s the 46-cent question posed by the service’s new first-class Forever stamp — a series of 20 stamps honoring the fictitious British lad and global pop culture icon. The stamps portraying characters and scenes from the best-selling Harry Potter books and movies are a measure of the resolve of the deficit-ridden Postal Service to appeal to consumers’ cultural preferences to generate revenue.

headline: What You Don’t Know About Mortgages
text: Thanks largely to new rules from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, taking out a mortgage is not the risky business it was during the bubble. But it is still the largest and most complex financial transaction in the lives of most people. And it still involves inherent imbalances in expertise between lenders and borrowers, including the use of intermediaries who may or may not be trustworthy. In short, conditions for abuse still exist.

headline: Desperation in Tibet
text: On Nov. 11, Tsering Gyal, a 20-year-old Tibetan Buddhist monk, set himself on fire in China’s Qinghai Province. Mr. Gyal’s death brings the number of Tibetans who have self-immolated since 2009 to 123. Letters some have left and eyewitness accounts of dying words leave no doubt about the cause of these horrible deaths: anguish over Chinese repression.

headline: Short on Space, Taiwan Embraces a Boom in Recycling
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Twenty-five miles west of here on Taiwan’s rugged northwest coast, a cavernous warehouse under construction represents the new priorities for an island where the streets were once littered with piles of discarded electronics and other refuse.

headline: On the Line, Giants’ Boothe Can Play Anywhere
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Pugh was amazed how everyone reacted in the moment. Pugh, a right tackle who was the Giants’ first-round draft pick in April, noticed that none of his teammates hesitated after center Jim Cordle left Sunday’s game against the Dallas Cowboys in the second quarter with a knee injury. They all knew who would take Cordle’s place: Kevin Boothe.

headline: Plan to Overhaul Illinois’s Pension System
text: The Illinois legislative leaders’ plan for an overhaul to the state’s vastly underfunded pension system.

headline: Unions’ Response to Proposed Overhaul of Illinois’s Pension System
text: A response to the outline of what Illinois lawmakers want to do to pensions from We Are One Illinois, a union coalition.

headline: Illinois Gives Plan Details for Bailout of Pensions
text: CHICAGO — Seeking to repair one of the nation’s worst-financed public pension systems, legislative leaders in Illinois on Friday began urgently trying to sell a rescue plan that cuts cost-of-living increases for retirees, raises the age of retirement for some employees, and sets a cap on pensions for those with the highest salaries.

headline: A Place for Dirt Bikers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tale of Two Midwest States
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alzheimer’s Disease
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rise in Homelessness
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art Confiscated by Nazis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Common Core and Coddled Kids
At the New School’s New Building, a Sign Isn’t Just a Sign
text: Landing someone of Ruedi Baur’s stature to develop a “wayfinding” system for the New School’s new University Center was, in the words of the provost, Tim Marshall, “an absolute coup.”

headline: Securing Help for a Park at Site of World’s Fairs
text: Julissa Ferreras, a New York City councilwoman, grew up four blocks from Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. It is where she took her first spin on a carousel and learned to ride a bicycle. It is also where, in recent years, her constituents have complained about unkempt fields, potholes, erosion and stagnant lakes.

headline: Overcome by Mud
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If you are a fan of puzzle bylines as I am, you have no doubt noticed that there are some constructors who are capable of making solvers quake in their collective boots. Byron Walden and Brad Wilber are two such constructors, known for their solidly-built grids that are festooned with wonderfully fresh entries and the kinds of arcana that make you just want to jam a pencil in your temple in frustration.

headline: In Alabama, the Day of the Big Game (Really Big)
text: Alabama-Auburn is a major game every football season, but this year even more than usual is at stake, including championship hopes on both sides.

headline: Close the Store, It’s the Year’s Big Game in Alabama
text: AUBURN, Ala. — The Saturday evening Mass at St. Michael the Archangel Catholic Church here will be a cappella because the organist has football tickets. Weddings and funerals will be rarities. Car dealerships are expected to go dark. The J & M Bookstore will close at kickoff — and reopen after the game only if the home team wins.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 29, 2013
Paul Mayer, 82, Ex-Priest and Peace Activist, Dies
text: Paul Mayer, a Jewish-born former Roman Catholic priest who was at the forefront of peace and social justice campaigns for five decades, for a time working closely with the radical pacifist priests Philip and Daniel Berrigan, died on Nov. 22 at his home in East Orange, N.J. He was 82.

headline: Dolan Says Church Is ‘Caricatured’ as Antigay
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said on Friday that the Roman Catholic Church was being “caricatured as being anti-gay,” even as he lamented the continued expansion of same-sex marriage in the United States and vowed to keep fighting it.

headline: Peter Kaplan, Editor of New York Observer, Dies at 59
text: Peter W. Kaplan, who in his 15 years as editor was credited with making The New York Observer both pertinent and impertinent as it gleefully chronicled the every move and shake of the city’s movers and shakers, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 59.

headline: Looking Sluggish and Lost, Nets Are Routed by Rockets
text: HOUSTON — The Nets have played some pitiful games this season, but never did four quarters feel like such a formality.

headline: Scandal Widens Over Contracts for Navy Work
text: A scandal involving the Navy’s ship supply network, until now focused on the Pacific Fleet, has spread to another contractor working for Navy ships in the waters off the Middle East, Africa and South America.

headline: North Korea Accuses Captive U.S. Veteran of War Crimes
text: HONG KONG — North Korea accused a captive American military veteran of war crimes, saying he was involved in the killing of innocent civilians during the Korean War, state news media reported on Saturday.

headline: For Sacred Heart, Patience Has Rewards
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Gordon Hill is not used to spending Thanksgiving preparing for a football game.

headline: Rare Books Vanish, With a Librarian in the Plot
text: NAPLES — It was one of the most dramatic thefts ever to hit the rare-book world, the disappearance of thousands of volumes — including centuries-old editions of Aristotle, Descartes, Galileo and Machiavelli — from the Baroque-era Girolamini Library in Naples. Now, prosecutors at a trial here are trying to show how such a wholesale violation of Western cultural patrimony could have taken place.

headline: Al Plastino, 91, Dies; Drew Many Superheroes
text: In the heyday of Superman comic books — the late 1940s through the 1960s — Al Plastino drew scores of issues, earning $50 per page as a freelancer for the publisher that became known as DC Comics. In the late ’50s he helped create new characters, including Supergirl, and the Legion of Super-Heroes, and he drew the syndicated Superman and Batman newspaper strips.

headline: Experience Lifts Arizona Against Duke
text: It was billed as a matchup between Duke’s Jabari Parker and Arizona’s Aaron Gordon, top prospects on top teams meeting in a sort of preamble to a rivalry between budding talents.

headline: Part II: Adam Minter on China’s Scrap Trade and the Environment
text: In his new book “Junkyard Planet: Travels in the Billion-Dollar Trash Trade” (Bloomsbury Press), Adam Minter paints a Dickensian portrait of China’s massive garbage and recycling dumps. And then he tells us why they’re so vital to the environmental movement.

headline: Back in Denver, Anthony Is Booed as Knicks Lose
text: DENVER — The fans at the Pepsi Center booed Carmelo Anthony during pregame introductions. They booed him when he brought the ball up the court. They booed nearly every move he made on Friday night, with the notable exception of his missed shots. The crowd loved those.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) BEAUTIFUL CREATURES (2013) Ethan (Alden Ehrenreich), an almost-too-good-to-be-true high school boy despairing of his conservative South Carolina existence, meets his dream girl, Lena (Alice Englert), when her family of witches moves to town, and “it’s kind of like Romeo and Juliet, but, like you know, happier,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this “pop Southern Gothic amusement about teenage love and other powerful magic.” Lena has some spooky relatives, including her Uncle Macon (Jeremy Irons) and cousin Ridley (Emmy Rossum). Ethan comes with a nanny, Amma (Viola Davis, above left, with Ms. Englert and Mr. Ehrenreich). “ ‘Beautiful Creatures,’ its sweet young things and supernatural shenanigans have been marshaled to help fill the box office void left by the end of the ‘Harry Potter’ and ‘Twilight’ franchises,” Ms. Dargis said of this adaptation of Kami Garcia and Margaret Stohl’s book. “It’s a void that ‘The Hunger Games’ has already started to fill, partly by tapping into deeply American themes and giving them thrilling female form. ‘Beautiful Creatures’ has been spun from thinner material, despite its strong female characters, nods at the Civil War and a story that turns on good versus evil, a fight that — as in many young adult stories — is somewhat mirrored in the struggle between the high school herd and the individual. There’s not much new under the moon here, which makes what the writer and director Richard LaGravenese does with the story all the more notable.”

headline: From Today’s Paper: Funeral for a Teenage Morsi Supporter
text: Mourners on Friday carried the coffin of a 19-year-old student killed Thursday during a demonstration at Cairo University, as security forces using shotgun pellets continued their crackdown on supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Anger Over Ukraine’s Rejection of Pacts
text: The riot police in Kiev, Ukraine, blocked protesters who supported more cooperation with the European Union.

headline: North Korea Releases a Video of a U.S. Veteran Confessing to ‘Hostile Acts’
text: BEIJING — North Korea has accused an American veteran of war crimes and on Saturday released a video of him confessing to what it said were “hostile acts” during the Korean War and while he was visiting the country in October.

headline: Police Helicopter Crashes Into Crowded Glasgow Pub
text: LONDON — Eight people were killed when a police helicopter that apparently lost power crashed through the roof of a crowded pub in Glasgow, injuring at least 30 people, police officials said Saturday.

headline: Ukrainians Back in Street to Support E.U. Accord
text: KIEV, Ukraine — After the police violently dispersed several hundred protesters in the center of this roiled capital early Saturday, thousands more took to the streets to denounce President Viktor F. Yanukovich’s refusal to sign far-reaching political and free-trade accords with the European Union.

text: Updated, 10:50 a.m. | China is experiencing a boom in luxury hotels, and not just in major cities like Shanghai and Beijing — evidence that finer amenities and a touch of Western comfort are becoming more important to the country’s growing number of domestic tourists as well as to international visitors.

headline: 1963: False Real-Hair Mustache Speeds Youths to Manhood
text: PARIS — A dandy business is being done these days at le Drug Store in moustaches postiches. It was bound to come, as a natural order of events. If she has a wig, why shouldn’t he have a little something extra too?

headline: In the Halfpipe With David Wise, the Undude
text: RENO, Nev. — The light from the Monster Energy refrigerator, squatting on the floor below the framed wedding photographs and X Games gold medals, cast a steady glow in the living room. The Smith Optics sunglasses come in handy in the high-desert autumn sun, just as they will in the snow-blinding mountains of winter. Pairs of 4Frnt skis stood in various corners of the house, awaiting deployment.

headline: Healing With His Hands
text: Manny Granillo, 59, has been a massage therapist at Miraval Resort and Spa in Tucson for nine years.

headline: Variety: An Educational Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — SARAH VOWELL, who has one of the best names in the universe for a book with the word “WORDY” in the title, is an essayist and self-styled “social observer” who has been a contributing editor to NPR’s “This American Life.” She has also written a number of nonfiction books on American history and culture, although in many of them (including this one), she wanders off into anecdotes about her own life, politics and her apartment in New York City.

headline: A Founder Who Can’t Let Go
text: Dear Workologist:

headline: Inside the Race to Rescue a Health Care Site, and Obama
text: WASHINGTON — As a small coterie of grim-faced advisers shuffled into the Oval Office on the evening of Oct. 15, President Obama’s chief domestic accomplishment was falling apart 24 miles away, at a bustling high-tech data center in suburban Virginia.

headline: Arkansas Follows Fashion, and the Money, Out of Its Home Away From Home
text: As major college football teams look for ways to draw more money, more exposure and better recruits, they seem to have little use for certain traditions. Home-away-from-home games, which flourished before cable television as a way for programs to reach larger audiences, are vanishing.

headline: Japan Takes Airspace Issue to U.N. Agency
text: NIIGATA, Japan — Seeking broader international support for opposing China’s claims to airspace over the East China Sea, Japan has asked the United Nations agency that oversees civil aviation to look into whether the newly created Chinese air defense zone could endanger civilian airliners, the Foreign Ministry said Saturday.

headline: ‘Climate Casino’: An Overview of Global Warming
text: I’ve long looked at global warming as a worthy topic that I should try to wrap my mind around. Although I knew I needed to dig deeper, I never truly understood why.

headline: When Algorithms Grow Accustomed to Your Face
text: People often reveal their private emotions in tiny, fleeting facial expressions, visible only to a best friend — or to a skilled poker player. Now, computer software is using frame-by-frame video analysis to read subtle muscular changes that flash across our faces in milliseconds, signaling emotions like happiness, sadness and disgust.

text: A look back at how White House advisers have tried to fix the botched health care website.

headline: Afghans Assail Karzai’s Disparate Views on Killings
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As so often happens in the fog of war, the attack in a village in Kandahar on Friday missed the enemy patrol that was its intended target, instead killing an 8-year-old boy and wounding two other children.

headline: How to Gauge the Price of Danger
text: True or false? An investment banker who’s thrilled about his new twin-engine Cessna will be just as excited about it after discovering that his summer neighbor on Nantucket commutes there in a Gulfstream intercontinental jet.

text: Say hello to C. C. Sabathia, the Yankees’ newest ticket salesman. He’s a nice, philanthropic fellow with a dandy résumé if you don’t dwell on his numbers from 2013, when he won the fewest games in his five seasons as a Yankee and had the highest earned run average of his career.

headline: A Trusting Couple, Now Thrown for Two Loops
text: For most of their 38-year marriage, Ivor Rose and Rita Starr lived relatively modestly in Miami Beach, buying and renting commercial and residential properties there. Mr. Rose, 79, was a child of parents who lived through the Depression, and he embraced their thrifty values and their strong distaste for debt, said Ms. Starr, 63. The couple never borrowed money to buy the six warehouses and eight homes that, by 2006, had a value of around $15 million and made up the bulk of their assets.

headline: First-Year Players Deserve A Second Look
text: Anthony Bennett’s rookie season for the Cleveland Cavaliers has been so ugly that he is being called a bust after a dozen games.

headline: New Thinking and Old Books Revisited
text: I learn from Francesco Saraceno that some people are attacking me for, as they see it, defending an economic orthodoxy that has failed. It’s kind of an odd place to find myself, given how critical I’ve been of the way the economics profession has dealt with the crisis. But it’s not entirely unfair: I am quite skeptical of people whose response to the sorry state of affairs is to declare that what we need is a whole new field.

headline: Giants’ Decline Stands at 12 Months, 16 Games and Counting
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It has been a bad year for the Giants, which is not the same as a bad season.

headline: The Big Ten’s Bigger Footprint
text: Neither Rutgers University nor the University of Maryland has been considered a traditional football powerhouse. In the last decade, though, both have invested heavily in coaches and facilities in the hope of competing with the likes of Ohio State and Alabama. On the field, the outcomes have been mixed. Financially, the results have been dismal.

headline: Indian Editor Is Arrested in Assault of Employee
text: NEW DELHI — A crusading editor revered in India’s liberal circles has been arrested in connection with the sexual assault of a young employee at his magazine, raising the stakes in a case that has riveted India’s political and journalistic classes.

headline: Will P. K. Go to Sochi? Canada Wants to Know
text: A Montreal Canadiens fan has composed new lyrics to “Y.M.C.A.,” the Village People singalong staple at ballparks and bar mitzvahs. The new rendition, “Why Not P. K.?,” blasts over local radio and implores Canadiens Coach Michel Therrien to make better use of P. K. Subban, suggesting that he play 30 minutes a game.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Minimum Wage
text: Inflation-adjusted minimum wages in the United States have declined in both absolute and relative terms for most of the past four decades.

headline: Where Factory Apprenticeship Is Latest Model From Germany
text: GREER, S.C. — For Joerg Klisch, hiring the first 60 workers to build heavy engines at his company’s new factory in South Carolina was easy. Finding the next 60 was not so simple.

headline: Eye on 2016, Clintons Rebuild Bond With Blacks
text: Inside Bright Hope Baptist Church, the luminaries of Philadelphia’s black political world gathered for the funeral of former Representative William H. Gray III in July. Dozens of politicians — city, state and federal — packed the pews as former President Bill Clinton offered a stirring eulogy, quoting Scripture and proudly telling the crowd that he was once described as “the only white man in America who knew all the verses to ‘Lift Every Voice and Sing.’ ”

headline: The Minimum We Can Do
text: During most of the 20th century, wages in the United States were set not just by employers but by a mix of market and institutional mechanisms. Supply and demand were important factors; collective bargaining and minimum wage laws also played a key role. Under Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Richard M. Nixon, we even implemented more direct forms of wage controls.

headline: What if Christmas Trees Had a Holiday?
text: What would the next few weeks be like if the trees had a holiday for a change?

headline: The Real Humanities Crisis
text: “Crisis” and “decline” are the words of the day in discussions of the humanities. A primary stimulus for the concern is a startling factoid: only 8 percent of undergraduates major in humanities. But this figure is misleading. It does not include majors in closely related fields such as history, journalism and some of the social sciences. Nor does it take account of the many required and elective humanities courses students take outside their majors. Most important, the 8 percent includes only those with a serious academic interest in literature, music and art, not those devoted to producing the artistic works that humanists study.

headline: Creating Skilled Workers
text: Manufacturers say there is a critical shortage of trained workers in the United States. In South Carolina, a German company is training students in skilled labor through apprenticeships.

headline: One Drug, Two Names, Many Problems
text: My patient was shaking uncontrollably. People say such shaking feels unbelievably bad, but rigoring, as the medical profession calls it, is treatable with the narcotic Demerol. I hurried to the computer to order some from the pharmacy, thinking “rigors = Demerol.”

headline: Millennial Searchers
text: FOR Viktor Frankl, the Holocaust survivor who wrote the best-selling book “Man’s Search for Meaning,” the call to answer life’s ultimate question came early. When he was a high school student, one of his science teachers declared to the class, “Life is nothing more than a combustion process, a process of oxidation.” But Frankl would have none of it. “Sir, if this is so,” he cried, jumping out of his chair, “then what can be the meaning of life?”

headline: That ‘Made in U.S.A.’ Premium
text: The designer Nanette Lepore is a cheerleader for New York City’s garment district. Most of her contemporary women’s clothing line, which sells at stores like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale’s, is made locally.

headline: Joshua Sapan
text: Joshua Sapan is president and chief executive of AMC Networks, best known for its hit shows “Breaking Bad,” “Mad Men” and “The Walking Dead.”

headline: One Cooking Show You Shouldn’t Try at Home
text: SOCIETY’S clamor for more cooking on television will be met this evening with the debut of a new show called “Cook Your Ass Off” — but do not be alarmed. The name is meant to be taken figuratively, program executives emphasize, and not as an invitation to seek culinary success through bodily harm.

headline: When Writers Expose the Dead
text: Shortly after my father’s sudden death, a friend gave me C.S. Lewis’s “A Grief Observed.” I read it post-funeral, in the awkward days when visiting relatives have returned home, when you’re supposed to re-embrace work and routines. The book offered little comfort — it’s an often self-pitying look at Lewis’s “mad, midnight moments” following the loss of his wife. But one passage stood out. Lewis writes of tales he’s read, “in which the dead tell us that our mourning does them some kind of wrong. They beg us to stop it…It made the dead far more dead.”

headline: Into the Government Funnel
text: How names are placed on lists of known or suspected terrorists.

headline: Who Is Watching the Watch Lists?
text: GOVERNMENTS wade into treacherous waters when they compile lists of people who might cause their countries harm. As fears about Japanese-Americans and Communists have demonstrated in the past, predictions about individual behavior are often inaccurate, the motivations for list-making aren’t always noble and concerns about threats are frequently overblown.

headline: The Unregulated Sperm Industry
text: NEW HAVEN — THE new movie “Delivery Man” stars Vince Vaughn as a former sperm donor who finds out that he has more than 500 children. Is this a Hollywood exaggeration or a possible outcome? Truth is, no one knows. In the United States, we do not track how many sperm donors there are, how often they donate, or how many children are born from the donations.

headline: Honduras Election Results Challenged
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Xiomara Castro, the left-wing presidential candidate in last week’s elections, has rejected the official results and called on her supporters to march in the streets, adding new uncertainty to the country’s already polarized politics.

headline: Machine Age
text: Form and function have always fascinated me. I thoroughly enjoy being in grand spaces; I like feeling the magnitude of a dam looming over me, or the crackling of electricity everywhere about me. For 40 years I have tried to capture these forms, to convert them into images that bespeak their power and strength.

headline: The Shocking Sex Secrets of Insects
text: PROSTITUTION is supposedly the oldest profession, which means that sex itself must be one of the oldest behaviors, a conclusion underscored by the recent discovery of two bugs fossilized as they coupled 165 million years ago. Simply being ancient doesn’t make a sex act interesting, but this one was noteworthy in part because behavior is generally so ephemeral, leaving none of the preserved remains we rely upon to tell us about how early forms of life ate, or ran, or saw the world.

headline: All Dogs May Go to Heaven. These Days, Some Go to Hospice.
text: More and more, cats and dogs get the human treatment. There are pet spas, pet therapists, pet clothes. And as it goes in life, so it now goes in the twilight. The latest phenomenon: pet hospice.

headline: Putting Military Pay on the Table
text: Big-ticket weapons like aircraft carriers and the F-35 fighter jet have to be part of any conversation about cutting Pentagon spending to satisfy the mandatory budget reductions known as the sequester. But compensation for military personnel has to be on the table, too — even though no other defense issue is more politically volatile or emotionally fraught.

headline: Voter ID Gets Another Day in Court
text: A federal trial in Milwaukee on Wisconsin’s 2011 voter ID law concluded recently, and the verdict, when it comes, will help define the future of the Voting Rights Act, which has been in question since the Supreme Court gutted a core provision, Section 5, in June. This case could also set an important precedent for lawsuits recently filed against similar laws in Texas and North Carolina.

headline: Years of Mourning the Losses in Mumbai
text: IT’S hard to believe that five years have passed since terrorists attacked Mumbai on Nov. 26, 2008, the date everyone in India knows as 26/11. More than 160 people were killed. Two of the victims were my cousin Reshma Parekh and her husband, Sunil. They were gunned down as they waited for a table at Tiffin restaurant in the Oberoi Hotel. They died within hours of the attackers’ arrival in the city, but their deaths were not confirmed until the hotel was finally wrested from the gunmen’s control two days later.

headline: Congress Takes on Abusive Patent Suits
text: Both houses of Congress are considering sound proposals to restrict abusive patent litigation that takes aim at small and medium-sized businesses.

headline: The Pope and the Right
text: “NOW it’s your turn to be part of the loyal opposition,” a fellow Catholic journalist said to me earlier this year, as Pope Francis’s agenda was beginning to take shape.

headline: The Other Arab Awakening
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — AND so it turns out that there were actually two Arab awakenings.

headline: Win a Trip 2014
text: The Times columnist Nicholas D. Kristof invites students to enter a contest for an international reporting trip in 2014.

headline: Gifts That Reflect the Spirit of the Season
text: THIS holiday season, instead of giving your mother that instructional video on twerking that you think she is pining for, what about giving her something that will really make her dance? Like, say, a savings account for a struggling American kid? Or a literacy class for an Afghan woman?

headline: Vows | A Community of Co-Parents
text: David Dean had already had one son through a network of lesbian and gay co-parents when he met Steve Lowinger. They had one more child together, and in the process, built a large extended family.

headline: On Dying After Your Time
text: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — THIS fall Google announced that it would venture into territory far removed from Internet search. Through a new company, Calico, it will be “tackling” the “challenge” of aging.

headline: Bedouins in Israel Protest Plan to Regulate Settlement
text: JERUSALEM — Thousands of Bedouins and their supporters demonstrated in various locations across Israel on Saturday against a government plan to regulate Bedouin settlement in the Negev desert, and some protesters clashed with the police.

headline: Ohio State Survives Against Michigan and Receives Help From Auburn
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Michigan’s season had not gone according to plan, but with a victory against Ohio State, much would be forgiven. After the Wolverines scored with 32 seconds left, needing only an extra point to tie the game, Coach Brady Hoke decided to go for the 2-point conversion, to try to salvage the season by spoiling Ohio State’s undefeated season and national championship chances.

headline: Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
text: Raymundo de la Mora, a member of the Ensenada City Council who leads the commission for governing and legislation, defends the vote to increase development in the Guadalupe Valley.

headline: Mexico's Wine Crisis
text: Natalia Badán, the owner of Mogor Badán, a small winery and vineyard in Baja California, describes how new land-use rules could destroy Mexico’s premier wine region.

headline: American Made: Nanette Lepore
text: Nanette Lepore, a fashion designer, is an advocate for clothing that is manufactured in the United States. Most of her contemporary label, sold by major retailers, is produced in New York City.

headline: How the Public Views Purchases Made Overseas
text: The New York Times asked people about their opinions and buying habits regarding American-made products and those manufactured outside the United States.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Using the Power to Pardon
text: Readers discuss mandatory minimum sentences and mercy.

text: Kim Steele, whose photographs are in the Museum of Modern Art and other collections, focuses on industry and technology.

headline: Kreider Plays Tormentor in Tortorella’s Return to the Garden
text: In many ways, it was a familiar scene: John Tortorella behind the bench at Madison Square Garden, berating a defenseman for an error after a goal. Only it was the Vancouver bench, Tortorella was the coach of the Canucks, and the defenseman he was dressing down was Alex Edler, whose failure to clear the puck led to the first Rangers goal of a long afternoon.

headline: Machine Age
text: Kim Steele, whose photographs are in the Museum of Modern Art and other collections, focuses on industry and technology.

headline: Teams From Azerbaijan and Miami Seize Titles
text: Azerbaijan won the European Chess Championship on Nov. 18, and the Miami Sharks collected their first United States Chess League title two days later.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 1
text: The pressure is on and expectations are high as the Obama administration’s Dec. 1 deadline to fix the technical problems with HealthCare.gov arrives. The Sunday news shows this week will delve into that topic, plus the emerging details of an interim deal to halt Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Win a Trip in 2014!
text: My latest column, my annual gift-giving guide, also announces my next win-a-trip contest, an annual event in which I take a university student with me on a reporting trip to the developing world. The aim is to generate interest in global poverty both with the contest and with the blogging and videos that the winner will contribute to the New York Times website. I started the contest in 2006 and we’ve had some great trips over the years. For some of the winners, it has been life-changing, and HBO did a documentary called “Reporter” based on my 2007 trip; it’s on Amazon if you want to see what you’re getting yourself in for.

headline: Two Halves in One
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I know this is wrong, and probably way too undignified for a New York Times blog, but I couldn’t help headbanging along to this solve. I might have even stopped briefly to play some air guitar. Not only do we have a fun theme with a critical word hidden inside the black squares and a grid that is split in two, but we have a hardcore soundtrack playing in the background as we solve.

headline: As Oil Floods Plains Towns, Crime Pours In
text: SIDNEY, Mont. — One cold morning last year, a math teacher jogging through her hometown in eastern Montana was abducted, strangled and buried in a shallow grave. Charged in her death were two drifters from Colorado, drawn to the region by the allure of easy money in the oil fields.

headline: Limit on Access Stirs Tensions Between White House Photographer and Press Corps
text: WASHINGTON — Few ceremonies at the White House over the last five years have eluded the lens of Pete Souza, President Obama’s chief photographer and almost constant companion. One that did was Mr. Souza’s wedding, which was held last month in the Rose Garden with the president among 35 friends and family members on hand.

headline: The Troubles of Building Where Faults Collide
text: LOS ANGELES — The proposed Millennium towers, two skyscrapers that would soar against the Hollywood Hills, were supposed to be a powerful symbol of the campaign to transform Hollywood into a bustling urban hub.

headline: In Attorney General Contest, Conservatives Crowd the Field
text: Speaking at a mid-November fundraiser at her Dallas antiques and home furnishings store, Lisa Luby Ryan, an eloquent Republican activist, struggled to find the right word to introduce her guest of honor.

headline: Moving Time for Nurses Who Don’t Need Doctors
text: As an advanced practice nurse specializing in family medicine, Holly Jeffreys operates the only medical clinics in two rural Texas Panhandle counties. The state requires that she have a contract with a physician to supervise both clinics, but she operates the facilities almost independently.

headline: Supermajority Poses Dilemma for Both Parties
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: A First Gay Novel, a Poor Latino Boyhood and the Confluence
text: John Rechy, the youngest of five children born to poor Mexican parents during the Depression, once wrote, “There was so much poverty and hunger in El Paso and Juarez that we didn’t consider ourselves poor, because we ate and had a home.” But as a gay boy in Texas, he did often feel like an outsider.
